title: Food as Ritual, Dining as Theater; Then as Now, New York Sates Its Hungers in Public
description: Along a narrow hallway deep inside the Beaux Arts palace known as the New-York Historical Society, there is a single wall of artifacts from 100 years ago. It tells the story of food in New York City at the turn of this century. And it inspires a peculiar sense of deja vu.

description: In mid-1984, a former Egyptian Army officer with an engaging manner and a gift for languages approached the Central Intelligence Agency in Egypt with what seemed an intriguing offer: He volunteered to be a spy.

title: Totally Homework
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  If you have a child of a certain age say, old enough to need a dictionary but not old enough to go out and buy it herself -- the big news out of Ann Arbor, Mich., a few weeks ago was no news at all. According to a University of Michigan study, children have a lot less free time than they used to. You could have produced the same data from your kitchen table, where you preside over one of the chief culprits identified in the study: endless homework.

description: The IMC Mortgage Company, which deals in second mortgages, agreed to give Greenwich Street Capital Partners 95 percent control of the company in exchange for capital and credit needed to pay off existing loans. description: A Federal appeals court arrived at a Solomonic solution yesterday in a legal challenge to the Giuliani administration's virtual shutdown of public access to City Hall, ruling that hundreds of demonstrators could hold a rally today in the parking area in front of City Hall but could not set foot on the building's 11 steps.

description: After more than a month of lurching through space in fits and starts, an experimental spacecraft crammed with new technologies has begun to cruise away from Earth, driven by a recently revived ion propulsion engine taken from science fiction.

description: Members of the Supreme Court expressed considerable doubt today about whether they should resolve the legal and constitutional issues surrounding the Clinton Administration's plan to use statistical sampling to make the 2000 census more accurate.

description: Commercial farmers in Zimbabwe, under a constant threat of having their land seized, have been thrown into confusion again by notices that the Government now says it owns 841 of their farms.

title: A Prescription Pad That Computes
description: Finally, a cure for doctors' bad handwriting: the computer. When doctors put down their pens and typed prescriptions into a terminal, serious medication errors dropped by half, researchers at Brigham and Women's Hospital have found.

title: Eastern Third of U.S. Can Catch the Shuttle's Glow
description: Space fans who have always yearned to see a rocket launching but could never venture to Cape Canaveral will get a great chance, of sorts, early Thursday morning, when the space shuttle Endeavour is scheduled to blast off with the second component of the space station.

title: Stocks Slump As Traders Take Profits
description: Stocks had their worst trading session in two months yesterday, as waves of profit taking swept through the market.

title: Speculation Rises on Which Companies Are Ripe for Mergers
description: The question on the mind of almost every trader after Deutsche Bank A.G. announced its $10.1 billion acquisition of the Bankers Trust Corporation yesterday was, ''Who's next?''

title: A Rare Bridge Team Victory
description: For the first time in 35 years, a woman has won a major American Contract Bridge League team title. Rita Shugart of Pebble Beach, Calif., and three top European professionals won the prestigious Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship at the Fall Nationals here Sunday night. She and her teammates, Andrew Robson and Tony Forrester, both of England, and Geir Helgemo of Norway, led wire to wire in three days of strenuous play. This is usually regarded as the most difficult major title to win and is seldom won by a four-person squad; a team of six, allowing for some rest, is normal.

title: Boeing May Place Its Account in Review
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it was considering placing its account in review after 28 years at Cole & Weber in Seattle. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: Supporters Press for Parole of a Lawyer Who Stole Millions
description: Steven Romer stole more money from clients $7 million -- than any lawyer in the nation. He has already spent seven years in Sing Sing state prison paying for the crime. He and his family feel that it is time for him to get out. And, increasingly, they are getting politicians and parole experts to agree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKER, RONA MOUND
description: DRUCKER-Rona Mound of Newport News, VA on November 30, 1998. Wife of Erwin Drucker. Mother of Wendy and Michael Piercy & David and Lynn Drucker. Daughter of Isabel Mound and the late Milton Mound. Grandmother of Natalie, Adam, Nicole, and Evan. Part of her was still a New Yorker. A memorial service will take place in Virginia.

title: Mice Fail to Verify an Evolutionary Theory
description: Evolutionary biology can be long on theory but short on evidence. So biologists were delighted when they thought they had a rare chance to conduct an experimental test of a popular and appealing theory involving a kind of molecular arms race between the sexes. Not only was the test compelling but there was every indication that its results would turn out to support the theory.

title: Artistic Legacy Of AIDS, On Line
description: John Dugdale is a photographer who can barely see. In 1993 diseases resulting from infection by the AIDS virus took most of his vision and hearing. He thought he had months to live, but he's still here. That is why, Mr. Dugdale said, he is qualified to talk about the importance of a new on-line gallery of works by artists with AIDS.

title: Police Seek Advocate Of Wife Beating
description: The police yesterday were seeking the person behind a billboard on Route 9 that was papered with the message: ''Support domestic violence. If you don't beat your wife, who will?''

title: Bronx Store Owner Is Arrested In a 1975 Dominican Killing
description: An immigrant from the Dominican Republic who has quietly run a Bronx liquor store for the last few years has been charged with carrying out a politically motivated killing of a journalist in his native country 23 years ago, Federal authorities said yesterday.

title: Clearer Mammograms May Be Near
description: After a long delay, the Food and Drug Administration is on the verge of issuing revised guidelines that could enable a new generation of mammography devices to come to the market. The devices rely on digital imaging, a technique experts say offers clearer, more detailed pictures of some breast tissue than traditional X-ray film.

title: Troubled Small Bank To Be Merged in Japan
description: Hanshin Bank Ltd., a midsize Japanese lender based in Kobe, signed an agreement yesterday to take over the troubled Midori Bank Ltd. of Kobe in a stock swap valued at 61.82 billion yen ($499 million). The two banks will form a lender named Minato Bank Ltd., starting business on April 1. Under the deal, each Midori share will be exchanged for 180 shares of Hanshin.

title: On Gotham's Whips and Scorns
description: At its most perceptive and entertaining, ''Step In and Stand Clear'' is an insider's guide to survival in New York City or, more to the point, what happens to a human psyche afflicted by too much proximity.

title: Diet Is Not a Panacea, But It Cuts Risk of Cancer
description: When words like ''cure'' and ''prevention'' appear in the title of a book about a chronic, disabling or life-threatening disease, they often enrich authors and publishers at the public's expense. Such is likely the case with a best seller, ''The Breast Cancer Prevention Diet'' by Dr. Bob Arnot, the medical correspondent for NBC.

title: In an N.Y.U. Lab, Premonitions of Alzheimer's
description: Twenty years ago, my mother's mind went to battle with Alzheimer's disease and lost. Last month scientists at New York University Medical Center, in a hunt for clues to the blight of her brain, spent three days looking at mine.

title: President's Strategy
description: ''No accused,'' President Clinton's lawyers wrote in September in response to perjury accusations leveled by Kenneth W. Starr, ''has an obligation to help his accuser.''

title: Tosco to Close Refinery Units
description: The Tosco Corporation said today that it would close units at a San Francisco-area refinery, cut an unspecified number of jobs and take a $40 million pretax charge against fourth-quarter earnings to cover the reorganization cost.

title: Honors
description: * J. Andrea Alstrup was named the 1998 Advertising Woman of the Year by the Advertising Women of New York. She is vice president for advertising at Johnson & Johnson, New Brunswick, N.J., and also president of the company's in-house advertising agency, Raritan Advertising.

title: U.S. Pledges Military Cooperation to Colombia in Drug War
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen and Colombia's new President, Andres Pastrana, announced steps today to intensify military cooperation in the war on drug trafficking, including a pledge to increase Pentagon training of Colombia's armed forces and to share more aerial and satellite intelligence data.

title: Deutsche Gets Bankers Trust for $10 Billion
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. formally announced today its plan for a $10.1 billion takeover of the Bankers Trust Corporation and said that the acquisition would result in the elimination of 5,500 jobs, mostly in New York and London.

title: Police Find Two Boys In an Abduction Case
description: Two Long Island boys who the police said had been abducted by their biological mother were found yesterday in Philadelphia.

title: WELSH, CARSON REDUCES OFFER FOR CENTENNIAL CELLULAR
description: Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe L.P., a New York investment firm, said yesterday that it had lowered the price it would pay for the Centennial Cellular Corporation, an operator of wireless phone systems, to $41.50 a share from $43.50. The change reduces the purchase price by $60 million. The price was about $1.5 billion in cash when it was announced in July. Welsh, Carson and certain affiliates of Blackstone Capital Partners also agreed to raise their equity investment in the deal to $400 million from $350 million. Shares of Centennial, which is based in New Canaan, Conn., rose $3.125, to $40.

title: Swedish Packaging Deal By Rexam of Britain
description: Rexam P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it had offered $:380 million in cash ($625 million) for PLM A.B., the Swedish-based consumer packaging group. The bid values PLM at 5.13 billion Swedish kronor. The offer is supported by Industrivaerden A.B., PLM's largest shareholder, which has unconditionally agreed to sell its 23 percent stake in PLM to Rexam at the offering price.

title: VACCO ENDS FIGHT ON BALLOT COUNT IN RE-ELECTION BID
description: Dennis C. Vacco all but conceded defeat yesterday in his bid for re-election as New York Attorney General. His campaign dropped its challenge of thousands of uncounted ballots from the Nov. 3 election and said it accepted state tallies showing Eliot L. Spitzer in the lead.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: U.S. and Other Nations Plan More Aid for Palestinians
description: The United States today pledged an extra $400 million in aid to the Palestinians, which is expected to nearly double the amount of their economic assistance from the United States over the next five years.

title: An Ouster After Films Flounder
description: Casey Silver, the chairman of troubled Universal Pictures, was ousted today after the dismal box-office results of the studio's most recent big-budget films, ''Meet Joe Black'' and ''Babe: Pig in the City.''

title: Battle for Bouygues Ends As One Suitor Sells Stake
description: The investor Vincent Bollore sold his 12.61 percent stake in Bouygues S.A. yesterday to Artemis, the holding company of the French financier Francois Pinault, ending a battle for control of Bouygues, a French conglomerate. Mr. Bollore agreed to sell his stake for 1,160 French francs a share, a total of 3.8 billion francs ($666 million). Mr. Bollore bought most of his shares for about 600 francs each, so he appears to have made a profit of 1.5 billion francs ($263 million).

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Just how much will Met Life executives benefit when the company converts to stock ownership?
description: AS the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company reorganizes so that it can issue stock, the big winners are likely to be the company's executives.

title: Big Japanese Bank Denies Merger Talk
description: Chuo Trust and Banking, one of Japan's seven major trust banks, denied today that it was in merger talks with Nippon Credit Bank, one of the nation's three long-term credit banks.

title: Vanderbilt U. Receives a Gift of $300 Million
description: In what may be the largest private gift ever made to an American college or university, Vanderbilt University announced yesterday that it had received stock currently valued at more than $300 million.

title: Spending the Tobacco Billions
description: New York politicians are salivating over the $25 billion the state is expected to receive over the next 25 years as part of the proposed $206 billion multi-state settlement with the tobacco industry. But some hurdles still need to be cleared. State Supreme Court Justice Stephen Crane, who is overseeing the state's lawsuit, will have to approve the settlement. Many health experts, including former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, oppose the deal as being insufficient to reduce teen-age smoking. Some anti-smoking advocates are seeking to present their views in court before any deal is instituted. They should be afforded that opportunity, given the far-reaching impact of this settlement.

title: Mexico City Journal; Above the Law: Bodyguards Swell a Wave of Crime
description: The newest danger awaiting motorists on the mean streets of Mexico City comes from revolver-waving bodyguards in speeding unmarked cars, who swerve from lane to lane to make sure no one gets close to the chauffeur-driven limousines they follow.

title: Giants' Offense Needs A Leader Like Rice
description: San Francisco 49ers wide receiver Jerry Rice has always been a player who wants to be the first option. As he grows older, his skills no longer what they used to be, Rice watches teammates like Terrell Owens, J. J. Stokes and Garrison Hearst get the balls and the publicity. It infuriates him, and he speaks out as he did last week, saying the team needs to throw the ball his way more.

title: Japanese Minister Warns About Economy
description: Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said today that it was too early to conclude that the nation's economy had bottomed out.

title: Scientology Pleads Not Guilty in 1995 Death
description: The Church of Scientology pleaded not guilty today to criminal charges in connection with the 1995 death of a member whose family maintained that she had been held against her will by the church for 17 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASINOF, STANLEY A.
description: ASINOF-Stanley A. of Winchester, MA. formerly of Short Hills, New Jersey, and Longmeadow, MA., died on November 29, 1998 after a short illness. He is the husband of Estelle (Kadish) Asinof, his second wife. His first wife Gertrude (Davis) Asinof, died in a car accident in 1980. Born in New York City in 1917, he was the son of the late Moses and Pauline (Adelstein) Asinof. A graduate of Syracuse University, he worked for many years in the family-owned business, Asinof & Sons, in Chicopee Falls, MA. He was a veteran of World War II serving as a staff sergeant in the U.S. army. He leaves a sister Eleanore (Asinof) Dunn of Longmeadow, MA, a daughter, Paula Asinof of Tampa, FL, a daughter, Lynn Asinof and her husband Peter Shaw and their children Jeremy and Daniel of Lexington, MA, and a son, Richard Asinof, and his wife Pamela and their child, Sam of Barrington, RI. A graveside service will be held Wednesday, December 2, at Sinai Temple Memorial Park in Springfield, MA.

description: To the Editor:

title: Leetch, Making Big Plays Again, Is Seeking Big Money
description: The Rangers have had a few unpleasant experiences with unrestricted free agency for elite veterans since the era began with the collective bargaining agreement of 1995. Right wing Pat Verbeek left for Dallas in 1996, a move that depleted the team's attack. Center Mark Messier went to Vancouver in 1997, a departure that hurt many feelings, created a leadership void and led to a disastrous season. Goalie Mike Richter qualified in 1998 and returned to New York only after negotiations with several teams resulted in allegations of bad faith.

title: Jim Turner, 95, Former Yankees Pitching Coach, Is Dead
description: Jim Turner, the pitching coach for nine Yankee pennant-winning teams in the Casey Stengel era and a pitcher for the Braves, Reds and Yankees in a baseball career spanning 51 consecutive seasons, died Sunday in his hometown of Nashville. He was 95 and the oldest former Yankee.

title: Textron Names New Chairman
description: Textron Inc., the maker of Cessna aircraft and Bell helicopters, said today that it had named its chief executive, Lewis Campbell, its new chairman effective on Feb. 1, replacing James Hardymon, who is retiring.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOUGHERTY, JAMES W.
description: DOUGHERTY-James W. November 25, 1940 to December 1, 1995. Gone three years yet deeply missed each day. Love ya, Tisha

title: In Vietnam the Pen Was as Mighty as the Napalm
description: Common wisdom has it that the Vietnam War was the first television war, and that is no doubt true. But a new two-volume Library of America collection called ''Reporting Vietnam'' shows that the conflict was probably also the last writers' war, at least the last writers' war involving American forces in large numbers.

title: Reno Delays Ruling on Special Prosecutor for Clinton Aide
description: After months of deliberations, Attorney General Janet Reno today put off a decision on whether to ask an independent counsel to investigate the statements of Harold M. Ickes, a former top Presidential aide, about his efforts on behalf of the teamsters union.

title: The Hope, and Hype, of Cord Blood
description: Should parents pay a blood bank to store the blood from their newborn baby's umbilical cord and placenta, in case that child or another family member ever needs it to treat cancer or leukemia?

title: INSIDE
description: Job Cuts in Deutsche Deal

title: Cable and Wireless Names Chief in U.S.
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C., Britain's No. 2 phone company, named Dennis D. Matteucci chief executive of its American unit today, replacing a chief who resigned last week after eight months in the job.

title: Our Towns; H.O.V. Lanes: A 30-Mile Test That Failed
description: JENNIFER HEALD cannot think of a car pool that would have anything to do with her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSDORF, DIETER H., PH.D.
description: SUSSDORF-Dieter H., Ph.D. The Board of Overseers, Faculty, and Staff of the Weill Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences of Cornell University are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dieter H. Sussdorf, Ph.D. A distinguished member of the department of microbiology, Dr. Sussdorf also served as associate and acting dean of the Graduate School of Medical Sciences. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his family. Sanford I. Weill Chairman, Board of Overseers Weill Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences of Cornell University Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. Dean, Weill Medical College David P. Hajjar, Ph.D. Dean, Weill Graduate School of Medical Sciences Erik Falck-Pedersen, Ph.D. Acting Chairman, Department of Microbiology

title: Battle Shapes Up on Labor Chief's Future
description: As leaders of District Council 37's parent union arrived to take direct control of the council, a battle began shaping up yesterday over Stanley Hill's future as head of the council, New York City's biggest municipal union.

title: Unitog Considering a Sale
description: The Unitog Company, a maker of uniforms, said today that it had hired investment bankers -- Goldsmith, Agio, Helms & Company and George K. Baum & Company -- to advise it on ''strategic alternatives,'' including a sale or a merger. Shares of Unitog rose $1 today, to $21.75, giving the company a market capitalization of more than $200 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALENSTEIN, KATRINA ELY BURLINGHAM
description: VALENSTEIN-Katrina Ely Burlingham. We deeply grieve the passing of Tinky, beloved wife of Arthur F. Valenstein, devoted mother of David Valenstein and Anne Heller, and affectionate grandmother of Toby, Ella, and Daniel. Born on March 27, 1919 in NYC. Daughter of Dorothy Tiffany Burlingham and Robert Burlingham, and sister of Michael Burlingham. Died on November 28, 1998 in Cambridge after a long illness. A memorial gathering will be held at a later date. We will sorely miss her kindness and her love of life.

title: Stanley B. Kearl, 84, Sculptor and Professor
description: Stanley Brandon Kearl, a sculptor, died on Nov. 21 at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 84.

title: Scandal Kept in Military Perspective
description: Gen. Charles C. Krulak, the Commandant of the Marine Corps, had just finished a long speech on ''moral courage'' at the Naval War College in Newport, R.I., when the inevitable question arose.

title: Holocaust Money: Familiar Battle; Unfair Requirement
description: To the Editor:

title: Separatist Premier Keeps Control In Quebec's Provincial Election
description: Premier Lucien Bouchard and the separatist Parti Quebecois have retained control of Canada's largest province, possibly setting the stage for a bitter confrontation with the rest of Canada, and possibly another referendum on independence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, PARIS SCOTT, JR.
description: RUSSELL-Paris Scott, Jr. 89 years old. Died in Osprey, Florida on Nov. 14, 1998. Born May 27, 1909. He was an investment banker, partner of Glore Forgan, member of Squadron A, 101st Cavalry, Manhattan Unit. Survivors include his wife Elizabeth, three daughters Jill Benedict of Short Hills, N.J., Sandra Tait of Wisconsin, Pamela Bush of Chatham, Mass., a son Scott III of Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida, nine grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren.

title: Murdoch Puts 2 Satellites In New Orbit
description: Still searching for a way out of the direct-broadcast satellite business in the United States, the News Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell two satellites and their orbital license over the United States to the Echostar Communications Corporation for about $840 million in stock.

title: Debunking the Myths of Safety in Soccer
description: For every football player who limps or is carried off the field, there is a soccer player who gloats that soccer is the safer of the two sports. But a study published in the current issue of The British Journal of Sports Medicine reveals that the risk of injury in soccer may have been played down, at least at the professional level.

title: Bankers Trust Takeover to Save Companies $1.7 Billion a Year : Deutsche Bank To Chop 5,500 Jobs
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Bank AG said Monday that its $10.1 billion takeover of Bankers Trust Corp., which will create the world's biggest financial company, will cost 5,500 jobs, even as it is expected to save the companies $1.7 billion a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, M. DONALD
description: GRANT-M. Donald. The Board of Directors and the employees of Fahnestock & Co. Inc. note with sorrow the passing of our former Managing Partner, friend and associate of over 50 years. Our sympathy is extended to the family. Albert G. Lowenthal, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPPER, BELINA
description: POPPER-Belina. Died at age 91 after a brief illness on November 30, 1998 at Sound Shore Medical Center. She was born to Iancu and Bertha Saraga in Bucharest, Romania March 9, 1907. She married her beloved husband, Emil, in 1929. Her husband died in 1983 after 53 years of marriage. She was also predeceased by her sisters, Diana and Renee. She loved her gardens, dance, music and the arts. She is survived by her sons, Alex and Serge, her sister, Stefi, three grandchildren, nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends on Wednesday, December 2, from 4-6PM at the John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont, NY. Private entombment will take place at Ferncliff Cemetery. Memorial donations may be sent to the charity of your choice.

title: Johnson Signs With the Diamondbacks for $52 Million
description: And the winner is . . . the only nonwinner in the race.

title: Bazaars Set Off Debate Over Role of Parks
description: Mood rings for $3? Elegant soapstone sculptures from Kenya? A $35 Ecuadorean sweater? These and much more are available at Columbus Park in Brooklyn, next to Borough Hall, from vendors who pitch their alabaster tents there every Friday.

title: Laclede Steel and Two Units in Chapter 11
description: The Laclede Steel Company and two subsidiaries filed voluntary petitions seeking protection from creditors under Chapter 11 Federal bankruptcy reorganization.

title: The Orioles Stand Between the Mets and Free-Agent Help
description: The Baltimore Orioles' sudden interest in Albert Belle last week compelled the Yankees to sign Bernie Williams. Now the Orioles' machinations are having a major impact on New York's other team, the Mets.

title: After Giants Air It Out, 49ers Deflate Them
description: For the Giants, it began with a bomb, but it ended as just another dud.

title: A Series to Send Audiences Home Humming
description: Lincoln Center's American Songbook, a new series that aspires to be the popular song equivalent of the successful Jazz at Lincoln Center series, has announced its opening programs. On Feb. 5 and 6, it will make its debut at Alice Tully Hall with ''I Gotta Right to Sing the Blues,'' a salute to Harold Arlen, the composer of the standards ''Stormy Weather'' and ''Come Rain or Come Shine'' as well the scores of the movies ''The Wizard of Oz'' and the 1954 ''Star Is Born.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROEGER, JOHN F.
description: KROEGER-John F. The Board of Directors of the AIM Funds and AIM Management are deeply saddended by the loss of John F. Kroeger who has served our Funds as a Director since their start over 22 years ago. John's wisdom, dedication and work ethic were of the highest standards, which were executed by him always in a honest and gentlemanly manner. We will miss him greatly and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Janice and their family. AIM Funds and AIM Management

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHENG, DENISE
description: CHENG-Denise, 71, on November 29, 1998. Wife of Stephen. Mother of Pascal, Danielle, Olivier, Philippe and Lydia. Grandmother of Gabriel, Sophie and Sasha. She will be deeply missed. Service on Thursday, December 3rd, at the Church of Notre Dame on 114th St. and Morningside Dr. at 10 AM.

title: FORSTMANN LITTLE PLANS TO SELL COMMSCOPE SHARES
description: The private investment firm Forstmann Little & Company said yesterday that it planned to sell 6.75 million shares of Commscope Inc. valued at $102 million in a public offering and distribute an additional 450,000 shares to the investment firm's partners. The move reinstates plans that were canceled after Commscope shares lost almost half their value. The shares have risen 43 percent since Forstmann canceled its plans on Sept. 10 to sell its 14.7 percent stake in Commscope, a Hickory, N.C., maker of coaxial and fiber optic cable. Yesterday, they fell 18.75 cents, to $15.1875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANKIN, LEONARD J.
description: HANKIN-Leonard J. Age 81. On November 28, 1998. Retired Executive Vice President of Bergdorf Goodman. Beloved husband of Kathleen. Devoted father of Kim Hankin Barrett and Lyn Hankin. Adoring grandfather to Lindsey and Kendall Barrett. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, New York, NY 10002.

description: They Drank Their Milk

title: In a Bad Mood - for a Good Reason
description: According to a researcher at Harvard University, in any 24-hour period, married women are 50 percent more likely to complain of being in a bad mood than their Y-chromosomed counterparts. The reason, he theorizes, is that married women typically juggle more roles than men do, so they encounter more opportunities for things to go wrong in their lives.

title: For Health Care Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Censure Negotiations
description: With greater speed than anyone could have hoped a few weeks ago, negotiations that might lead to Congressional censure of President Clinton are moving forward. The White House is now openly shopping for a deal. Representative Paul McHale's proposed language condemning Mr. Clinton for ''deceitful and dishonest conduct that was grossly inconsistent with his constitutional obligation and sacred duty'' catches the spirit that should be reflected in censure proposals being quietly drafted by Republicans and Democrats alike. Meanwhile, the specious contention that the Constitution does not allow the House to consider censure as an alternative to impeachment is fading away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMER, EDWIN F.
description: ZIMMER-Edwin F. Of Ardsley, New York. Former owner Zimmer Industries. Funeral service on Thursday 10:30 AM EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry, New York. Visiting Tuesday 7-9PM, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: F.C.C. Approves Hearst TV Deal
description: Hearst-Argyle Television Inc. said yesterday that it had won Federal regulatory clearance to buy the Pulitzer Publishing Company's broadcast group for $1.85 billion in stock and debt.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOXER, DAVID H.
description: BOXER-David H. Dec. 1, 1994. Always remembered. Beloved husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather & great grandfather.

title: Australia Says Its Trade Deficit Widens
description: Australia's trade deficit widened in the third quarter, as imports increased to meet robust demand at home while exports were hurt by Asia's deepening recession.

title: Medtronic Set To Buy Arterial For $3.7 Billion
description: Expanding into a lucrative corner of the cardiovascular device market, Medtronic Inc., the big pacemaker manufacturer, announced yesterday that it would buy Arterial Vascular Engineering Inc. for $54 a share, or $3.7 billion, in Medtronic stock.

title: Microsoft Defense Strategy Starts to Come Into Focus
description: In a day of prickly, detailed cross-examination at Microsoft's antitrust trial, Frederick R. Warren-Boulton, an economist, summed up the Government's case of how the software giant wields its market power in the industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, ALLAN R.
description: JOHNSON-Allan R. November 26, 1998. Beloved husband Maria, devoted father of Jane Fell, Kathy Jones, Susan Johnson & Barbara Hobin, cherished grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of four, loving brother of Patrick Johnson, cherished Godfather of Steven Toia. With Saks Fifth Avenue for thirty-six years, ten of which he spent as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, he retired in 1981 as Chairman of the store's parent company BATUS, Inc. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday, December 1, 1998, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Religious service Wednesday, December 2, St. John the Evangelist Church, 55 Street and First Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions in his name may be made to The Boys Scouts of America.

title: British Military Supplier Expanding in Norway
description: Vickers P.L.C., Britain's fourth-largest military company, agreed yesterday to buy most of Ulstein Holding A.S. of Norway for $:304 million ($502 million) in cash in a move that will extend its position as the world's biggest maker of propulsion equipment for ships. In addition, Vickers will assume $:42.5 million of Ulstein debt. The offer of 175 kroner a share for Ulstein is more than twice the closing share price on Nov. 23, after which the stock was suspended.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the mounting financial problems of the theatrical production company Livent since it filed for bankruptcy protection reversed the rankings of the two musicals on Broadway with the highest weekly box office grosses. No. 1 is ''Ragtime,'' produced by Livent, not the Disney musical ''The Lion King.''

title: Pivotal Month of Sundays For Parcells and the Jets
description: The moment was right for a crunch-time speech to the troops by Coach Bill Parcells.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DERRICO, NICHOLAS A., M.D.
description: DERRICO-Nicholas A., M.D. On November 29, 1998, of Pelham Manor, NY. Beloved husband of Sylvia Rinaldi Derrico; devoted father of Michael, Thomas and Nicholas, Jr.; brother of Mary Petraglia, Frances Morino, Vincenza Sudano and Anna Derrico. Reposing Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave., Pelham, NY. Mass Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Thursday, 10 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting hours Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: PARKER RAISES EXCHANGE RATIO IN OFFER FOR SUPERIOR
description: The Parker Drilling Company yesterday increased the amount of stock that it would pay for Superior Energy Services Inc., after the value of the deal fell because of a decline in Parker's share price. Parker, a Tulsa, Okla., provider of offshore and land drilling services, agreed last month to buy Superior, which is based in Harvey, La. The total value of the deal still falls to about $139 million from about $168 million, though Parker will exchange 0.975 share for each Superior share instead of 0.9 share. The increased exchange ratio values Superior at $3.96 a share. Parker's shares have dropped 26 percent since the acquisition agreement on Oct. 28. They were down 31.25 cents yesterday at $3.75, while Superior slipped 12.5 cents, to $3.125.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am a book person and I never believed I would want to give up the books I carry around with me. But I'm starting to think of myself more as a content provider. I look at my 11-year-old son's school backpack, which I worry is ruining his spine, and I can see advantages to electronic books.''

title: DiMaggio Has Significant Setback
description: Joe DiMaggio, hospitalized in Hollywood, Fla., for more than seven weeks because of pneumonia and lung cancer surgery, had another significant setback over the weekend, his doctor said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOSEVELT, P. JAMES
description: ROOSEVELT-P. James. The Partners and staff of The Roosevelt Investment Group, Inc. mourn the passing of their chairman and friend on November 27, 1998, in Oyster Bay, NY. May God bless and keep him for all eternity.

title: A Brothel Suspect Rejects Plea Deal
description: A woman charged with running a brothel in a mansion in Morris Township rejected a prosecution offer yesterday under which she would have been sentenced to 250 hours of community service and no jail time in exchange for a guilty plea, the Morris County prosecutor's office said.

title: MONSANTO ADDRESSES DEKALB ANTITRUST ISSUES
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that it had resolved Federal antitrust concerns over its $2.3 billion purchase of the 60 percent of the DeKalb Genetics Corporation that it does not already own. The Justice Department's antitrust division had questioned Monsanto on genetic traits developed for corn seed by Monsanto's Holden's Foundation Seeds unit and agrobacterium transformation technology for corn. To satisfy the concerns, Monsanto agreed to allow customers of Holden's Foundation Seeds to create corn seed that combines traits developed by Holden's with traits developed by other companies. And Monsanto gave the University of California at Berkeley an exclusive license, with the right to sublicense, any rights that might result from Monsanto's pending applications relating to agrobacterium transformation technology for corn.

title: Government Made Easy
description: There are four main slices in the American political pie today.

title: Township's Plan to Kill Deer With Sharpshooters Is Rejected
description: The New Jersey Attorney General's office announced yesterday that plans by Princeton Township to begin eradicating deer with paid sharpshooters would violate state hunting laws.

title: Miscellany
description: * Publicis S.A., Paris, acquired a 60 percent stake in 67 Publicidad, Caracas, Venezuela. Terms were not disclosed. 67 Publicidad has billings estimated at $6.7 million from clients including British Airways P.L.C. and the Hewlett-Packard Co.

title: Controversies Bring Scrutiny for Referees
description: In the past five days, game officials in the National Football League have come under attack as much as at any time in recent history. Anyone wearing stripes had better duck for cover.

title: Ex-Senator Returns to Ulster As Peace Effort Starts to Stall
description: Former Senator George J. Mitchell, who was instrumental in arranging the Northern Ireland peace agreement in April, returned to the British province today to discuss the impasse that has stalled the peace effort.

title: Price Is About Average, But Average Often Shifts
description: Will Deutsche Bank's $10.1 billion acquisition of Bankers Trust be the big banking merger that actually melds vastly different cultures, titanic egos and far-flung businesses?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIERMAN, DORA
description: BIERMAN-Dora. Tifereth Israel/ Town & Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its beloved member of long standing and extends heartfelt condolences to her beloved husband, Bill Bierman, and the entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Rabbi Abby Sosland President Carol Green

title: Quentin Crewe, 72, Bon Vivant Who Was Unfazed by Disability
description: Quentin Crewe, who fell down so much as a child and bounced back with such good cheer that he grew up to challenge prevailing stereotypes as an iconoclastic journalist, an innovative restaurant critic, a high-spirited social lion, a high-minded gossip columnist, a globe-trotting adventurer, a prolific author and an even more prolific lover, died in his home in Oxfordshire, England, on Nov. 14. It was the 72d birthday of a man who had not so much suffered from, as gloried in, a lifelong affliction with muscular dystrophy.

title: Law Firms White & Case and Brown & Wood Discuss a Merger
description: Partners at two prominent New York law firms -- White & Case and Brown & Wood -- are discussing merging their practices to create a law firm that would be among the nation's 10 largest.

title: A.C.C.'s Presence Is Felt
description: With the quarterfinals coming up, the Atlantic Coast Conference has three teams, Clemson, Maryland and Virginia, remaining in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, which started with 32 teams. All three squads will play host to this week's quarterfinals, and all three have realistic hopes of making the final four on Dec. 11 and 13 at the University of Richmond Stadium.

title: People
description: * Tom Lantz was named to the new position of executive vice president for sales at Relationship Marketing Group, Fairfield, Conn. He had been vice president for sales at Madison Direct Marketing, Greenwich, Conn.

title: Playing Energetically (Never Mind the Years)
description: Even for a listener who has followed Alicia de Larrocha's career since her days as a cult figure in the late 1960's, when her recordings of Spanish works opened up a colorful world of otherwise rarely heard piano repertory, it was sobering to read in her program biography that 1999 brings the 70th anniversary of her first public concert. Granted, she was 6 at the time, but even so, Ms. de Larrocha seems too youthful a player to have reached such a landmark.

title: Metro Business; NBC Buys Internet Stake
description: General Electric Company's NBC said yesterday that it would buy a minority stake in iVillage.com, the No. 1 on-line network geared toward women, for an undisclosed price to strengthen its place on the Internet and among female audiences.

title: Scientists Seek a New Movie Role: Hero, Not Villain
description: ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' is a hit. But can an ''N.Y.Ph.D. Blue'' be one too?

title: Shell and Texaco Call Off Joint Venture Talks
description: Royal Dutch/Shell Group announced yesterday that it had broken off talks with Texaco about combining their refining and marketing businesses in Europe because a joint venture would not produce the savings they had sought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSBORNE, DORIS DURRAH
description: OSBORNE-Doris Durrah. On November 18, 1998 in Plainfield, N.J. Survived by one brother Fred D. Durrah. Services were held November 25th. For information, Brown's Funeral Home, 122 Plainfield Ave, Plainfield, NJ 07060.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Even in Death, Carl Sagan's Influence Is Still Cosmic
description: Two weeks before he died, Dr. Carl Sagan dropped by to see Daniel S. Goldin, the NASA Administrator. Dr. Sagan was deathly ill. His blue jeans hung limp. He had no hair. His losing battle against the bone-marrow disease myelodysplasia had taken a heavy toll.

title: Pataki Leaves Room for Deal on Lawmakers' Quest for Raise
description: As the Democratic leaders of the State Assembly proposed a 38 percent salary increase for the state's elected officials, Gov. George E. Pataki reiterated today that he did not think legislators deserved higher pay, but left open the possibility of a deal.

title: Ballet Hispanico Remembers Its Catalan Roots
description: The brooding psychic landscapes created by history and personal experience are the terrain inhabited by three of the new and recent dances that will be performed by Ballet Hispanico in a two-week season opening tonight at the Joyce Theater. That is not entirely a coincidence. Tina Ramirez, the founder and director of Ballet Hispanico, is quick to express her love for the kind of ''strong dancing and rich, full, very personal movement'' that she sees in Ramon Oller's new ''Bury Me Standing,'' a piece about Gypsies, and in two recent company commissions by Mr. Oller and Maria Rovira. And both choreographers are the product of the turbulent, stubbornly creative culture of Catalonia in Spain.

title: Sunbeam Dismisses Longtime Auditors
description: The Sunbeam Corporation said today that it had dismissed Arthur Andersen L.L.P. as its independent auditors after the company restated its results for the last two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHWALD, SYLVIA
description: BUCHWALD-Sylvia. Beloved wife of Irwin for 49 years. Cherished mother of Mary Beth Gardner and Cathy Buchwald, loving mother-inlaw of John Gardner, adored grandmother of Matthew, devoted sister of Helen Gerber and Mickey Gotlin. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her warmth, love, beauty and dignity.Funeral services will be held Wednesday, December 2, in West Palm Beach, Fl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBERBAUM, SYD (SADIE)
description: LOBERBAUM-Syd (Sadie). The Rabbi, Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst, NY and its Affiliates express deepest sympathy on the passing of its member. We grieve with her sons Robert, Donald and daughter Helene Wulwick and their families. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

title: Even on the Bad Days, Broncos Are Invincible
description: This is how confident the Denver Broncos are.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONG, RICHARD E.
description: LONG-Richard E. The Board of Governors of the New York Athletic Club records with profound sorrow the passing of their former beloved President. We have lost a true friend and a devoted member and to his family convey our heartfelt sympathy. James W. O'Brien, President Alfred H. Green, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, DR. REVIRA
description: SINGER-Dr. Revira in Berkeley, CA., on November 27. A Jewish educator for over 40 years. Survived by her two daughters, Ruth and Miriam; sisters Helen, Harriet, and Jeannie; and many admiring and devoted friends. Services were held in California.

title: Sports of The Times; Title Bout: The Mecca, the Temple, the Kings
description: IN front of the lowered scoreboard with ''Holyfield'' and ''Lewis'' in lights, the Madison Square Garden boxing ring was set up about where the Eighth Avenue basket would be if the Knicks had a game. One by one, Evander Holyfield, in a black suit, and Lennox Lewis, in a tan suit, appeared in a spray of fireworks, leaned through the burgundy velvet ropes and now stood side by side in the ring, their arms crossed defiantly.

title: For More Textbooks, a Shift From Printed Page to Screen
description: At Virginia Commonwealth University, sociology students use a ''textbook'' that exists only on line. It sends them to related Web sites, has recorded lectures that they can rewind and offers discussion areas that supplement and enliven their classroom discussions.

title: Aid and Corruption in the Mideast
description: President Clinton's call yesterday for a new multibillion-dollar international aid package for the Palestinians is a necessary complement to the peace agreement he helped put together in Maryland earlier this fall. That diplomatic deal remains wobbly. It can be reinforced by showing that peace delivers tangible economic and social gains to ordinary Palestinians. But outside financial assistance will be effective only if the Palestinians can curtail corrupt practices in administering the aid.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SIDE EFFECTS; After the Addiction, a Matter of Weight
description: The longest large study to date on weight gain after quitting smoking has underscored what many researchers consider one of the toughest obstacles facing smokers who want to stop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHAUPT, ANN R.
description: MOHAUPT-Ann R. November 26, 1998. Beloved sister of Margaret Hoops of Warwick, RI. Service and interment private.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIND, MARCUS
description: WIND-Marcus, 82. Formerly of New York City. Passed away on November 28th in Jacksonville, Florida. He is survived by his wife Marceline, daughter Robin Faillance and Winifred Keeble and four grandchildren. Graveside services today, at 11 A.M., Wellwood Cemetrey, Pinelawn, L.I.

title: More SIDS Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond Their Years: Young Faces of AIDS
description: Two pointed, moving new documentaries share one inarguable premise: no one on the outside can know what it's like to live with H.I.V., the AIDS virus. So these programs shrewdly allow people with H.I.V. to tell their stories without narrative interference. That the speakers are children and young adults, fitting no one's stereotype of a person with AIDS, makes their comments all the more enlightening.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Oil and Natural Gas Lead Drop in Commodity Prices

title: Jersey City Teachers Return To Class After 5-Day Strike
description: A day after ratifying a new three-year contract, teachers returned to work today at the city's 39 schools, with classes returning to normal after a five-day strike that had paralyzed the school system of 32,000 students.

title: A Gun Control Gain, and Loss
description: A new national computerized system for conducting instant background checks of prospective gun purchasers went into effect yesterday. The rules for the new ''instant check'' system call for the F.B.I. to conduct background checks before the sales of all firearms, not just of handguns, the previous focus of concern. This broadened coverage is potentially a big advance for public safety. But gun control advocates are correctly worried that the mandatory ''cooling off'' period previously required before a purchaser could take possession of a gun is expiring with the beginning of the Federal background checks.

title: Neanderthal Or Cretin? A Debate Over Iodine
description: In a study already drawing the fire of controversy, an American geographer has pointed out evidence suggesting, in his view, that little more than the amount of iodine in their diets may have been responsible for the physical differences between Neanderthals and modern humans and that this might solve the mystery of what happened to the Neanderthals.

title: Volvo to Cut 5,300 Workers by Mid-1999
description: Volvo A.B., the Swedish maker of cars, buses, trucks and construction equipment, said today that it would lay off more than 7 percent of its work force, or 5,300 workers, by the middle of next year as part of plans to increase productivity and increase profits.

title: Congress Steps Up Aid for Colombians to Combat Drugs
description: The Clinton Administration initially opposed it, and the Colombian Government was taken by surprise. But a recent Congressional initiative, spurred by direct appeals to conservative Republicans by the Colombian national police, sharply increased anti-drug assistance to Colombia next year, making it a top recipient of United States foreign aid.

title: Man With Rifle Keeps Police at Bay 2 Hours
description: A man with a rifle held officers at bay for more than two hours near a busy intersection in East Northport yesterday before surrendering without firing a shot, the Suffolk County police said.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES TO BUY DENRO, AN AIR TRAFFIC CONCERN
description: Litton Industries said yesterday that it would acquire the air traffic control communications company Denro Inc. for about $60 million in cash from the Firan Corporation, a Canadian maker of recreational vehicles. Denro, based in Gaithersburg, Md., is expected to have about $50 million in sales next year. It will become part of Litton's advanced electronics unit as a member of the Amecom division. Litton, the electronics and military company based in Woodland Hills, Calif., had 1997 revenues of $4.4 billion. Its shares fell $2.50, to $61.1875.

title: By Design; Versatile Coats
description: Coats with hems at the knee or slightly above are far and away the most popular this winter, probably because they look good with pants or with skirts of so many lengths.

title: Drug Aid for Colombia
description: A recent Congressional initiative, spurred by appeals to conservative Republicans, has more than doubled anti-drug money to Colombia. The increase brings the assistance to $289 million for 1999 and is mostly in the form of weapons and aircraft.

title: Taking the Tedium Out of Solitary Workouts
description: When Spinning first reached health clubs a few years ago, it was an instant hit with gym-goers. The International Health Racquet and Sportsclub Association estimates that nearly 46 percent of gyms now offer group cycling classes.

title: True North to Offer Shares in a Unit
description: True North Communications in Chicago said yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of stock in Modem Media. Poppe Tyson in Westport, Conn., its unit specializing in interactive communications.

title: Q & A
description: Snakes and Vipers

title: CELADON ANNOUNCES CANCELLATION OF BUYOUT ATTEMPT
description: Celadon Group Inc., the ninth-largest United States long-distance trucking company, said yesterday that a management-led buyout had been called off and that the company was exploring alternatives. Celadon warned in September that its sale to the New York-based investment firm Odyssey Investment Partners L.L.C. for $20 a share, or about $154 million, was in jeopardy. The deal would also have included the assumption of $99 million in debt. Celadon, of Indianapolis, said its review of alternatives ''may include but is not limited to a revised transaction with Odyssey.'' Its shares fell $1.5625, to $13.25.

title: A Price Index Hits a 26-Year Low, Led by Oil and Gas
description: Commodity prices, led by a plunge in oil and natural gas, dropped sharply yesterday, pushing one key index to a 26-year low.

title: San Fransiscans Tire of the Life of the Party
description: No one denies Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr.'s ability to stir an audience. The other day he spoke at the 20th-anniversary commemoration of the assassination of Mayor George Moscone and City Supervisor Harvey Milk, and his simple words on this ''tragedy of tragedies'' brought louder applause than the star attraction, Joan Baez.

title: House's 81 Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Investment Firm to Provide $23 Million Loan to Livent
description: An investment firm run by a good friend of Michael Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, yesterday came to the rescue of Livent Inc., the Broadway theater company that was about out of cash and at risk of closing its doors.

title: MILLENNIUM CHEMICALS WARNS ON 4TH-QUARTER EARNINGS
description: Millennium Chemicals Inc. warned yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would be about break-even, well below analysts' forecasts, because of declining chemical prices and higher-than-expected start-up costs at a British plant. The company, a chemical maker based in Red Bank, N.J., had been expected to earn 23 cents a share, the average estimate of nine analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. Shares in Millennium fell $1.375, to $23.875. Millennium also said it planned to repurchase as much as $200 million of its stock. The company said it would pay for the buyback partly through selling its stake in Suburban Propane Partners L.P. The sale of the 24.4 percent limited partnership and 2 percent general partnership interests is expected to generate about $75 million.

title: Malaysia Takes Control Of No. 2 Bank Company
description: The Malaysian financier Abdul Rashid Hussain ceded control of the country's second-largest banking company yesterday as it reported a $246.6 million loss, its worst on record. The Malaysian state bank, Pahang, agreed to acquire 29 percent of the company, Rashid Hussain Bhd., for 530 million ringgit ($139 million). Also, Danamodal Nasional Bhd. -- a Government agency that pumps fresh capital into ailing banks -- will buy a 30 percent stake in the RHB Bank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAY, OLIVER
description: MAY-Oliver. Of Old Saybrook, CT formerly of Southport, CT. Memorial services Thursday, (Dec 3) at 11 AM at the Grace Episcopal Church, Old Saybrook.

title: China Says It Has Not Wavered on Plans for Industrial Overhaul
description: Seeking to counter recent reports that an ambitious economic reform plan is losing steam, Chinese officials today strongly reiterated their intention to overhaul debt-ridden state-owned industries by the end of 2000.

title: Hospitals Prohibited From Delaying Care
description: With more than 200 people complaining each year that they had been illegally denied emergency care by hospitals, the Clinton Administration told hospitals that they must examine and stabilize patients without any delays to ask about insurance coverage.

title: Keeping the Legacy of a Professor Alive
description: Carl Sagan's legacy lives on in the popularization of science as well as in the practice of it. For instance, Bill Nye, ''the science guy'' who is the host of popular science television programs for children, took an astronomy course from Dr. Sagan at Cornell University and consulted with him after graduation on how to shape a science-communications career.

title: Daluiso's Kicking Is Off the Mark
description: Giants place-kicker Brad Daluiso strained his right hamstring on the opening kickoff of last night's game at San Francisco, but said it was not a factor in the 41-yard field goal he missed in the second half, or the 43-yarder he had blocked in the fourth quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, MERWIN
description: LEWIS-Merwin. It is with sorrow that the Directors of Greater New York Mutual Insurance Company record the death of their dear friend and colleague, Merwin Lewis, in his 99th year. The Lewis family has been prominently identified with our Company since its founding 85 years ago. Merwin Lewis joined our Board in 1954. He was a compassionate and caring person deeply involved with the welfare of the Company's employees. A highly respected and experienced attorney, he carried on an active practice until his death. He was a wise and judicious counsellor to our Company and a valuable resource to the Bar of this city and to the community as a whole. We shall miss him. We extend our deepest sympathy to the members of the bereaved family. Alexander E. Rosenthal Chairman of the Board Warren W. Heck, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASCELL, DANTE
description: FASCELL-Dante. The officers, members and staff of The American Jewish Committee mourn the passing of an extraordinary public servant. Tireless defender of human dignity and human rights, Congressman Fascell was especially active in defense of the USIsrael partnership, the yearning for freedom in the communist world, the quest of Soviet Jews to emigrate to the West, and the pursuit of social justice during his distinguished 37-year career in the House of Representatives. We express our heartfelt condolences to Congressman Fascell's grieving family. We shall always cherish the legacy of his manifold achievements-to which we paid tribute when we presented him with our Congressional Leadership Award in 1989-and the memory of his friendship. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Exec Dir. The American Jewish Committee

title: Starwood is treating the opening of a boutique business hotel like a Broadway premiere.
description: THE letter ''W'' is getting quite a workout these days as a result of the growing popularity of the World Wide Web. Not since Elmer Fudd began fulminating about that wascally wabbit have so many W's been tossed about so, um, wildly.

title: U.S. Shifts From Nazi Gold To Art, Land and Insurance
description: The Clinton Administration declared today that its investigations into Swiss banks and Nazi gold were essentially closed as it opened a 44-nation conference here to examine a host of related issues like repatriating stolen art, land and buildings and resolving billions of dollars in insurance claims on Holocaust victims.

description: To the Editor:

title: As Trial Ends, Espy Jury Is Left With 2 Views of Defendant: Ethically Lax or Dedicated
description: Mike Espy, a former Congressman and Agriculture Secretary once thought to be a rising political star, spent his 45th birthday today in a Federal courthouse hearing himself denounced by prosecutors as a corrupt official and praised by defense lawyers as a dedicated public servant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERLING, ERWIN
description: HERLING-Erwin. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of our esteemed friend and honorary alumnus who, as a YU Benefactor, expressed his love and concern for the future of the Jewish people through the advancement of higher Jewish education at our institution. This commitment was expressed through the endowment of scholarships and fellowships at YU and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Tova, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Holders Approve Corrections Deal
description: The Corrections Corporation of America, the biggest manager of prisons in the United States, said today that its shareholders had approved the company's planned $2 billion merger with CCA Prison Realty Trust.

title: An Argentine Rendezvous for the Meat-Eating Crowd
description: SUR, an Argentine restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, opened about five weeks ago on a previously barren stretch of Smith Street that in the last year has seen the arrival of several boutiques and restaurants like Patois and Rosina's. At dinner one recent night, my friends and I were wondering why neighborhood restaurants like Sur and Patois would open here rather than in a more upscale area like Park Slope, which has gained a reputation as the Upper West Side of Brooklyn, where good restaurants are few and far between.

title: More About the Oil Merger
description: THE ODD COUPLE -- The chief executives of Exxon and Mobil, Lee R. Raymond and Lucio A. Noto, have markedly different styles, making their proposed alliance seem an unusual match. Page C1.

title: Sports of The Times; This Skater Chooses to Come Home, of All Things
description: HER mom was wearing the silver medal. Her two younger sisters were doing their homework in the den. And Sarah Hughes was bubbling about being back in school yesterday after a week's absence.

title: Quebec Questions
description: While the results of Quebec's provincial election are muddy enough for both major parties to claim a victory of sorts, and to bear some degree of defeat, the real losers are those who had hoped the election would provide a clear sense of where Quebec, and Canada, are heading.

title: Mexico to Cancel Long-Distance Surcharge
description: Mexican regulators announced today that they would cancel a surcharge that Telefonos de Mexico S.A. collected from other long-distance companies to complete calls into Mexico.

title: Jet-Lagged Opponent Buys Time for UConn
description: One team of Huskies, in the midst of a multiple-time-zone road trip, played tired. The other Huskies, the nation's newly anointed No. 1 team, was just awful. In the end, it took an acrimonious huddle and a salty tirade from forward Kevin Freeman to set his Connecticut teammates' minds right and their pressure defense in motion tonight on the way to a 69-48 victory over Washington in the opening game of the Great Eight tournament at the United Center.

title: World War II, The Mini-Series
description: Acting in the movie ''Apollo 13'' helped inspire Tom Hanks to pursue his fascination with space travel by creating the 12-hour HBO mini-series ''From the Earth to the Moon,'' which won an Emmy this year.

title: Red Tape Keeps Children Uninsured, Report Finds
description: Nearly three out of four uninsured children in New York City are eligible for public health coverage, but barriers built into the Medicaid application process and widespread ignorance about another insurance program for low-income children keep them unenrolled, according to a report issued yesterday by the Commonwealth Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARRISON, EDITH (HOOE)
description: GARRISON-Edith (Hooe) 90. Of Essex Meadows, Essex, Ct. Died Tuesday December 1. She was the wife of the late John D. Garrison Sr. She was born in Washington D.C., grew up in New Haven, Ct., lived many years in Greenwich, Ct., moving to New York City and recently to Essex. She was a member of the Greenwich Chapter of the American Red Cross and was chairman during WW II. She is survived by her son John D. Garrison Jr. of Norfolk, Va and daughter Jean G. Thompson of Oyster Bay, L.I., six grandchildren: Edith Gibbons Conyers, Margaret M. Seybolt, Edward Bailey Meyer, Krista M. Garrison, Nina H. Garrison and Helen S. Garrison and seven great grandchildren. Funeral and burial private in Grove St. Cemetery, New Haven, Ct. In lieu of flowers contributions to Greenwich Chapter of the American Red Cross, Greenwich, Ct. 06830.

title: Younger Gotti Says Costs of Bail And Lost Assets Impoverish Him
description: Claiming that bail expenses and the Federal Government's seizure of his assets have impoverished him, John A. Gotti, the reputed mob boss, said yesterday that he was no longer able to pay the grocery, household and medical bills for his wife and four children.

title: Tyson Enters Plea of No Contest
description: Just when Mike Tyson is about to get his ring career back on track, his legal woes have put a cloud over his future. Tyson pleaded no contest yesterday to two misdemeanor assault charges from an incident after a traffic accident in Gaithersburg, Md., on Aug. 31.

title: Antipasti That Look Good, at Least
description: SOME cookbook authors are one-hit wonders. They come out with one big splashy book, then fall off the map, presumably retreating to their home kitchens. Others are like Lorenza de'Medici, who has produced more than 20 books during her lengthy career. To most cookbook collectors, she is the familiar name to which they are unable to put a face. ''She has pretty books,'' they might say.

description: When it comes to merger advice, J. P. Morgan isn't the brand name that first comes to mind. Unless you're rooting around in the oil patch.

description: NESTANPOWER-Marion M. Died December 1, 1998, 82 years old. Beloved wife of Samuel and sister of Herman Masin. Adored mother of Louise and Nathaniel Yohalem, Stephen and Ruth Nestanpower, cherished grandmother of Jennifer Yohalem, Eve Yohalem and Nicholas Polsky. Ecstatic greatgrandmother of Joseph Yohalem Polsky. A pioneering reading teacher for 25 years, Mary insured that no child left her classroom without being able to read. She worked tirelessly on behalf of her community, serving as President of B'nai Brith Redemption Chapter 275. Mary was the heart and bedrock of all who knew her. Funeral Wednesday, December 2, 1:15PM, Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to B'nai Brith and The Children's Home in Israel.

title: The Road to Cookbook Independence
description: IF you feel you have become a slave to Julia or Jacques, don't abandon your recipes all at once. And remember: the road to freedom begins with a familiar dish.

description: JOHNSON-Allan R. November 26, 1998. Beloved husband Maria, devoted father of Jane Fell, Kathy Jones, Susan Johnson & Barbara Hobin, cherished grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of four, loving brother of Patrick Johnson, cherished Godfather of Steven Toia. With Saks Fifth Avenue for thirty-six years, ten of which he spent as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, he retired in 1981 as Chairman of the store's parent company BATUS, Inc. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Tuesday, December 1, 1998, from 2-5 & 7-9 P.M. Religious service Wednesday, December 2nd, 10AM, St. John the Evangelist Church, 55th Street and First Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions in his name may be made to The Boys Scouts of America.

description: The hurdler Greg Foster and the high jumper Dwight Stones, recently elected to the National Track and Field Hall of Fame, said yesterday that their sport could use more ambassadors like they were in their long careers.

title: Experts Hail a Giant Deal, But Motorists Are Dubious
description: With oil supplies abundant and gasoline cheaper than bottled water, industry executives and even some consumer groups contended yesterday that consumers are unlikely to feel any immediate impact from a merger of Exxon and Mobil, the nation's two biggest oil companies.

title: Pact to Provide Minority Housing in White Areas in Yonkers
description: Bringing to a close a major theater of battle in a legal conflict that has had Yonkers in its grip for almost two decades, New York State agreed yesterday to pay $16.4 million to help the city build new housing and buy existing homes in white neighborhoods for black and Hispanic families.

title: Joffrey and the New School To Educate Dancers Jointly
description: The Joffrey Ballet School and the New School University will offer a new degree program in dance, starting in the fall of 1999, the two institutions announced yesterday. The four-year Bachelor of Fine Arts program will combine 90 credits of intensive professional dance training at the Joffrey school with a 30-credit liberal arts curriculum. Students will be selected by national audition.

title: Hyundai Completes Deal For Takeover of Kia
description: Completing a shift in control after months of uncertainty, the Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea's largest auto maker, signed a contract yesterday to take over 51 percent of the bankrupt Kia Motors Corporation and its truck-making subsidiary Asia Motors for 1.18 trillion won ($940 million). Hyundai will seek foreign investors to take stakes in the companies.

title: SONY AND GENERAL INSTRUMENT ANNOUNCE COLLABORATION
description: The Sony Corporation, the Japanese consumer electronics giant, said yesterday that it would form a business partnership with the General Instrument Corporation, a major maker of digital set-top boxes for the cable-television industry. Under their agreement, Sony will buy 7.5 million General Instrument shares for $187.5 million. The combined business will use Sony's network technology with General Instrument's digital boxes. General Instrument, based in Horsham, Pa., had revenue of $1.4 billion in the nine months ended Sept. 30.

title: Honors
description: * American Business Press, New York, named the Sony Corporation and Nobuyuki Idei, co-chief executive, as recipients of the Norman L. Cahners Lifetime Achievement Award. The award was presented at the annual Creative Excellence in Business Advertising Awards luncheon in New York.

description: MacLEAN-Lee Selden Howe. On November 30, 1998 in her 90th year. At her home in Lloyd Neck, Huntington, Long Island, New York. Grandmother of Melinda Lee Mackay, Michael William Mackay, Eric Bruce Salsbery, Heather Lee MacLean, Ian William MacLean, Kathryn Elizabeth MacLean and Stephanie Howe MacLean. Great-grandmother of Zoe Patricia Mackay. Funeral services will be private.

title: Testimony on Microsoft's League of Its Own
description: At an industry meeting in February 1997, an official of the Microsoft Corporation vowed that his company ''wouldn't be cowboys'' by altering the Java programming language on its own, an executive of Sun Microsystems Inc. said in testimony released today. Seven months later, he testified, Microsoft did just that, in an effort to eliminate ''the threat posed by Java technology to Microsoft's operating system monopoly.''

title: Memories Of Misery Under Apartheid
description: At the center of Koto Bolofo's quietly moving documentary, ''The Land Is White, the Seed Is Black,'' stands the filmmaker's father, a black South African teacher who tells a familiar story of persecution under apartheid followed by exile in England where he lived with his family for 24 years.

title: Giuliani Agrees to Let Experts Review Work of Child Agency
description: After striving to overhaul New York City's troubled child welfare agency for nearly three years, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has agreed to allow a panel of national experts to assess the agency's performance and to issue recommendations and timetables for improving abuse investigations, foster care placements and the pace of adoptions, lawyers close to the agreement say.

title: Risk of Social Crisis Rising In Asia, UN Agency Finds
description: HONG KONG  While some upbeat forecasters are saying the Asian economic crisis has bottomed out, an agency of the United Nations said Tuesday that the region's social crisis was far from over and was likely to get worse.

title: Jury Hears Final Arguments in Triple-Slaying Case in Queens
description: A Queens jury yesterday began deliberating the fate of a 26-year-old man on trial for his life, after hearing the prosecution chronicle what it said was his bloody rampage through an apartment house and the defendant assail what he called a campaign of ''tricknology'' intended to rob him of a fair hearing.

title: Metro Business; Towing Company Grows
description: United Road Services Inc., a vehicle transport and towing company, said yesterday that it had bought two companies and agreed to buy two others, the latest in a string of acquisitions it has made since going public in May.

title: N.B.A., Players to Talk Without Preconditions
description: After 15 days away from the bargaining table, players and owners tomorrow will make another bid to resuscitate the National Basketball Association season.

title: B.A.T. to Quit Making Cigarettes in Singapore
description: B.A.T. Industries of Britain, the world's second-largest tobacco company, said yesterday that it would stop making cigarettes in Singapore and dismiss about 300 employees, or 80 percent of its work force in the city-state, to cut costs. The Singapore unit, which made tobacco products for the local market and for export, will probably post a loss this year. Richard Wooding, chairman of the division, said the plant was no longer viable. Its closing ''will result in significant cost savings,'' he said.

title: Cables Snag Subway Car, Stranding Commuters
description: A northbound No. 2 train became snagged in a cluster of dangling electrical cables above the subway tracks yesterday, causing major disruptions to service on several Upper West Side lines and stranding or inconveniencing hundreds of thousands of commuters during the morning rush.

title: Ms. Is Bought By a Concern Led by Steinem
description: In what some might describe as a triumph of poetic justice and others as a last-ditch attempt to save a magazine some consider no longer relevant, Ms. magazine has been sold to a new media group founded by the magazine's original editor and co-founder, Gloria Steinem.

title: EXXON AND MOBIL ANNOUNCE $80 BILLION DEAL TO CREATE WORLD'S LARGEST COMPANY
description: Exxon, the nation's largest oil company, agreed yesterday to buy Mobil, the next largest, for $80 billion in stock, to form the world's biggest corporation.

title: Down by a Goal, 1 Second to Play, Rangers Still Win
description: In a game of great ebb and flow, the Rangers made three comebacks last night against the Florida Panthers at Madison Square Garden. Adam Graves made it all worthwhile by scoring his second goal of the game 2 minutes 10 seconds into overtime to snatch a 5-4 victory.

title: Lespinasse and Its Chef Exchange an Elegant Embrace
description: IF the dining room at Lespinasse were a person, it would be smiling today. After a long marriage with a chef determined to put the decor in the shadows, it has finally found a compatible partner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASHBURN, WILLIAM TUCKER
description: WASHBURN - William Tucker, aged 77, died October 25, 1998 in Madrid, Spain. Survived by his wife Elvira Alfageme, his three sisters, Elizabeth W. Delano, Mary D.W. Gray, and Pauline W. Rogers and by ten nieces and nephews.

title: Supply and Profits
description: For all the wealth of Exxon and Mobil -- and all the market power inherent in their announced merger -- these two oil giants are essentially purveyors of an ordinary commodity, and commodities are in huge supply. Their falling prices are cutting into profits everywhere and hurting national economies.

title: Water Main Break Leaves Jersey City Dry for Hours
description: Construction crews working to install fiber optic cables along the Garden State Parkway ruptured a six-foot water main early today, cutting off the water supply to Jersey City for several hours and forcing a shutdown of the city's public school system.

description: The Islanders, who drew only 3,000 fans to a home game early this season, have seen attendance at Nassau Coliseum improve significantly recently and are expecting the first sellout of 1998-99 tomorrow night as they play host to the rival Rangers.

title: N.R.A. Sues to Challenge New Database on Sale of Guns
description: The National Rifle Association filed a lawsuit today in Federal District Court here in an effort to block a Federal database of gun purchases generated from new instant background checks of people buying guns.

title: Exxon's Imperial Said to Be Set To Buy Mobil's Assets Separately
description: The Exxon Corporation's Imperial Oil Ltd., the largest petroleum company in Canada, may be set to acquire the Mobil Corporation's assets in Canada, analysts said, a purchase that could cost Imperial more than $4 billion (Canadian), or $2.6 billion (United States).

title: A Special-Ed Warning for New York
description: The Federal Government has warned that New York City could lose Federal aid if it continues to shunt disproportionate numbers of black and Latino children into special education. The city is a legitimate target. But the segregation that has raised red flags in Washington is common throughout the state -- and is due in part to a funding formula that penalizes districts that reduce special-education enrollment while rewarding those who keep enrollment as high as possible and have the highest per-pupil special-ed expenditures. Unless New York State junks this formula, it could find itself stripped of special-education aid and in violation of Federal civil rights laws.

description: New York's largest health care union completed contract negotiations yesterday for service and maintenance workers at six hospitals, giving the workers improved job security during what they feared would be a period of layoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNANUE, JOSEPH F.
description: UNANUE-Joseph F. 41. Died November 28 of complications from a bone marrow transplant. Mr. Unanue was Executive Vice President of Goya Foods, the country's largest Hispanic-owned food company. He was the grandson of the company's founders, Prudencio and Carolina Unanue and the son of Carmen Ana and Joseph A. Unanue, Goya President. Mr. Unanue was born in Puerto Rico. He graduated from Duke University and earned an MBA from the University of North Carolina. He began his career as Marketing Director at Goya's Secaucus, New Jersey, site in 1981; in 1986 he became VP of Operations. Later, in 1990, he was named General Manager of Goya de Puerto Rico, where he supervised manufacturing operations and marketing. Last year, Mr. Unanue was promoted to Executive Vice President. Mr. Unanue, a dedicated father, is survived by his three daughters; Isabel, Sofia and Juliana and his parents Carmen Ana and Joseph. In addition, he leaves four sisters: Mari, wife of John Norris; Mary Ann, wife of Xavier Quinones; Mimi, wife of Jose Guggenheim; Maribel, wife of Gerard McVicar, his brother Andy Unanue and other family members in the United States and Puerto Rico. The body will be flown to his native home of Puerto Rico today. The wake will be held December 3 at the Puerto Rico Memorial Funeral Home, 1712 Avenida Ponce De Leon, Santurce, Puerto Rico, 8:00am10:00pm (787-727-3222). The Mass will be held December 4 at Perpetuo Socorro Church at 9:00am, Jose Marti Street (between Jose Marti & Union St), Miramar, Puerto Rico. The burial will take place at the Porta Coeli Cemetery, Bayamon, Puerto Rico. En lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to the C&J Unanue Foundation, 100 Seaview Drive, Secaucus, NJ. The family foundation will be supporting the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, Washington.

title: CARGILL BUYS STAKE IN BUNGE'S VENEZUELA GRAIN BUSINESS

The new purchase will strengthen Cargill's position in the grain and cereals industry in Venezuela. Cargill, based in Minnetonka, Minn., already sells cooking oils and pastas there.
