title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOURCIER, CLAUDE L.
description: BOURCIER-Claude L. Died on November 24, 1998 in Perpignan, France, near his home in Thuir. He was 88 years young. Decorated three times by the French government, he was Dean of the French Summer School and Head of the French department at Middlebury College in Vermont during a career that spanned nearly 40 years. He also directed their School of French in Paris. He directed and acted in plays at the college and in the town's community theatre. He retired to France in 1975 but continued to teach at USC Santa Barbara, U. of Montana, and most recently with Colorado College. In his spare time he founded a theatre company in Thuir, ''Les Beaux Masques,'' which has been very successful. He also taught theatre to young children and was involved in various community activities. The town of Thuir honored him with a medal in 1997. He was buried in the beautiful Catalan area on November 26. He is survived by his wife Myra, his children Claudia Yapp & Gerard, & relatives in France, Jean-Francois Oudin, Alain Oudin, Sylvie Bourcier, Eric Bourcier and by the many people who knew and loved him. A memorial fund for Les Beaux Masques is being set up. We miss you Baba.

title: W. F. Baxter, 69, Ex-Antitrust Chief, Is Dead

title: Tending to Wounds of War He Didn't Know

Dr. Halpern is a specialist in sports medicine and a successful one: he's associate team physician for the Mets, attending physician at Manhattan's Hospital for Special Surgery, with an office in New Jersey and another in Manhattan.

title: Consequences of Perjury Debated in House
description: Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee held a nine-hour hearing today on the consequences of perjury, seeking to stoke support in the House for impeaching President Clinton on that charge.

title: Iraq Replies to U.N. Queries, But Says Little That Is New
description: In a flurry of letters released today Iraq began answering in considerable detail some of the questions posed by arms inspectors over the last year. But officials of the United Nations Special Commission, which is in charge of disarming Iraq, said they had found little new in the responses.

description: Following are excerpts from comments today as the House Judiciary Committee investigated impeaching President Clinton by questioning two women who had been prosecuted for lying in sex cases. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and their remarks were recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service.

title: Gates Giving $100 Million To Fight Childhood Disease
description: William H. Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, and his wife, Melinda, will announce a gift of $100 million today to speed the delivery of vaccines against four childhood diseases to developing countries.

title: On Ice or Bench, Fetisov Still Stars
description: Slava Fetisov, the heralded captain of Russia's national hockey team in the 1980's, was the pioneer in paving the way for Russian hockey players to come to the National Hockey League. Now, Fetisov could be on his way to becoming the league's first Russian head coach.

title: OPEN TEXT OFFERS $112.6 MILLION IN STOCK TO BUY PC DOCS
description: The Open Text Corporation made an unsolicited offer yesterday to acquire PC Docs Group International Inc. for stock valued at $112.6 million. Both companies are Canadian providers of software. Under the offer, Open Text would exchange one of its shares for every four PC Docs shares. Open Text, based in Waterloo, Ontario, provides software for companies to use in managing internal corporate information and communications, including E-mail and scheduling systems. PC Docs is based in Toronto and provides data base and document management software.

title: U.S. Will Release Files on Crimes Under Pinochet
description: Treading into a political and diplomatic confrontation it tried to avoid, the United States decided today to declassify some secret Government documents on the killings and torture committed during the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet in Chile.

Father of John Clarkson Philipp of Sonoma, CA, and Laurie Coughlin of Washington, DC, father-of-law of Timothy Coughlin. Born in Beaver Falls, PA, he attended Northwestern Univ. and was a member of Phi Gamma Delta fraternity. He was chairman of O. Philipp and Co., a foreign trade company based in NY with offices abroad in South America and Mexico. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to NY Presbyterian Hospital, Attn: Box 123, 525 East 68 Street, New York, N.Y. 10021.

The depiction of water pouring from a crystal pitcher, made of strips of balsa wood, was by Jordan Steckel; the photograph was by the Virginia Roehl Studio.

title: Business Travel; U.S. airlines are in a bit of a dust-up over 'sizers' for passengers' carry-on luggage.
description: UNTIL recently, the baggage ''sizers'' used at airports to determine whether luggage can be carried aboard planes or must be checked were often little more than adornments. But increasing emphasis on on-time performance has led many airlines to draw a harder line against oversized carry-on luggage, contending that it shortchanges other passengers, slows down the boarding process and leads to costly flight delays.

title: Rhone-Poulenc and Hoechst Agree on Start of a Merger
description: After months of negotiating, Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France and Hoechst A.G. of Germany said yesterday that they would combine their pharmaceutical and agricultural units into a new company as the first step of a merger.

title: Discover Card Account Is Placed in Review
description: In a surprise move, Discover Financial Services said yesterday that it had placed in review its Discover Card account, which has been handled for the last decade by DDB Needham Chicago. Though billings were not disclosed, Discover Card spent $77.4 million on advertising in 1997, according to the Competitive Media Reporting unit of VNU N.V.

title: 2 Decades On, Miami Endorses Gay Rights
description: More than 20 years after Anita Bryant's ''save our children'' crusade here led to the repeal of one of the country's first gay rights ordinances and galvanized the debate over gay rights in the nation, the Miami-Dade County Commission voted again today to ban discrimination based on sexual orientation.

title: Children Were Saved, but So Much Was Lost
description: Melissa Hacker's documentary, ''My Knees Were Jumping: Remembering the Kindertransports,'' is about the Jewish children who were saved by emigrating to Britain (from Germany, Austria, Poland and Czechoslovakia) 60 years ago. Since Ms. Hacker is the daughter of one such emigre -- the costume designer Ruth Morley, an Academy Award nominee for ''The Miracle Worker'' -- she approaches her poignant subject matter in a particularly earnest, intimate way.

title: PETRIE RETAIL RECEIVES AN OFFER FOR ITS REMAINING STORES
description: Petrie Retail Inc. of Secaucus, N.J., received a $61.3 million offer for its remaining 98 stores. The closely held Petrie has been selling its women's apparel stores since it entered bankruptcy proceedings in 1995. The $61.3 million offer from the Urban Acquisition Corporation came yesterday at a hearing in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. The bid requires the approval of Petrie's landlords and United States Bankruptcy Judge Arthur Gonzalez. The stores to be sold are mostly in Puerto Rico. Urban Acquisition operates Ashley Stewart plus-size women's clothing stores. At one time, Petrie operated 1,700 women's clothing stores in 49 states. In August, Petrie won court approval to sell its G& G junior clothing shops.

title: Universities Again Involved In Joint Ventures in China

But soon after, American and Chinese troops were shooting at each other in Korea, which led to some of the most intense days of the cold war.

description: Auditors for the Federal Election Commission have found that the 1996 campaigns of President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole illegally benefited from issue advertising paid for by their political parties. They called for the campaigns to repay millions of dollars to the Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULDER, HILDA BEIM
description: SCHULDER-Hilda Beim. Devoted wife of Jacob for sixty-two years, sister of the late Ruth Beim Krieger. Loving mother of Diane, Sylvia and Howard. Adoring grandmother of Robert, Jeffrey, Amy, Marcy, Rachel and Becky. Great grandmother of Marlie. Died peacefully at home on Sunday, November 29, 1998. Services were held on Monday and interment was at Beth David Cemetery. She was an elegant woman of valor. Shiva at the home of Bob and Diane Abrams, 11 East 86 St.

title: Johnny Roventini, 86, Bellhop Who Called for Phillip Morris
description: Johnny Roventini, the little Brooklyn-born bellhop with the big bell-clear voice whose ''Call for Phil-lip Mor-ris,'' delighted radio audiences in the 1930's and 40's and made the cigarette into a household name, died on Monday at a hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 86 and had been under lifetime contract to the company since 1933.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have always had the view that the objective is to be best. If in being best you also have to be biggest, that's fine.''

title: Lawsuit Against Drug Makers Is Dismissed
description: After more than nine weeks of testimony, a Federal judge here dismissed a class-action lawsuit that accused four major drug makers of conspiring to fix prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHWALD, SYLVIA
description: BUCHWALD-Sylvia. Beloved wife of Irwin for 49 years. Cherished mother of Mary Beth Gardner and Cathy Buchwald, loving mother-inlaw of John Gardner, adored grandmother of Matthew, devoted sister of Helen Gerber and Mickey Gotlin. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her warmth, love, beauty and dignity. Funeral services to be held in West Palm Beach Wednesday, December 2 at 1 PM.

title: Governor-Elect Gets Set, Hopes High, Profile Low
description: For months, Gray Davis was mocked as California's slow but steady gubernatorial candidate. So it was perhaps fitting that he made one of his first full-dress appearances as Governor-elect, at a news conference this week in the children's department of the Los Angeles Central Library, in front of a display copy of ''The Hare and the Tortoise.''

title: U.S. Seeking New Bases To Offset Panama Loss
description: The United States has begun talks with several countries to find new bases of operation in Central and South America for the American military forces that must soon leave Panama, American officials said today.

title: Filtration Plant Is Placed Within Van Cortlandt Park
description: New York City announced yesterday that it had chosen a corner of Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx to build its long-embattled, $600 million water filtration plant. In seeking a site for the plant, the city had faced fierce opposition from community groups in the Bronx worried about the disruption from years of construction, but was under a Federal court order to choose a site by yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONNELL, GRACE M.
description: McDONNELL-Grace M. On November 30, 1998. Of Sarasota, FL. Formerly of Long Beach, N.Y. College of New Rochelle, Class of 1944. Daughter of the late John J. and Anna L. McDonnell. Sister of the late Eugene J. McDonnell. Dear sister of John C., Robert E. and Arthur G. McDonnell and Louise Stevens. Funeral Mass Thursday, December 3rd, 11AM at Saint Brigid's Church, Westbury, L.I. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, L.I. Inquiries Coffey Funeral Home, Inc., Tarrytown, N.Y. 914-631-0983

description: DRUCKER-Rona Mound of Newport News, VA on November 30, 1998. Wife of Erwin Drucker. Mother of Wendy and Michael Piercy & David and Lynn Drucker. Daughter of Isabel Mound and the late Milton Mound. Grandmother of Natalie, Adam, Nicole, and Evan. Part of her was still a New Yorker. A memorial service will take place in Virginia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, DR. REVIRA
description: SINGER-Dr. Revira in Berkeley, CA., on November 27. A Jewish educator for over 40 years. Survived by her two daughters, Ruth and Miriam; sisters Helen, Harriet, and Jeannie; and many admiring and devoted friends. Services were held in California.

title: HIBERNIA TO BUY CHASE'S OPERATIONS IN BEAUMONT, TEX.
description: The Hibernia Corporation will acquire the operations of Chase Bank of Texas N.A. in Beaumont, Tex., for $87 million. The operations consist of four offices with $1.3 billion in assets, $452 million in deposits and $172 million in loans, Hibernia said. After this and other pending acquisitions, Hibernia, a bank holding company based in New Orleans, would have assets of $14.3 billion and 257 banking offices in Louisiana and Texas. Chase Bank of Texas is a unit of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the New York banking giant. The stock of Hibernia, which is based in New Orleans, rose 6.25 cents a share, to $16.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange, while shares of Chase fell $1.3125, to $62.125.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAMBERTSEN, ELEANOR
description: LAMBERTSEN - Eleanor, 1916-1998. A Memorial Service will be held on Monday, December 7, 1998 at 5PM at Teachers College, Columbia University, 525 West 120th Street, in Milbank Chapel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: A Bin Laden Agent Left Angry Record Of Gripes and Fears
description: Sometime in the summer of 1997, an operative for Osama bin Laden sat down at his personal computer in a hideaway in Kenya. He was worried, he wrote in an angry dispatch, about the security of the ''East Africa network'' of Mr. bin Laden, the Saudi exile charged with masterminding a worldwide terrorist conspiracy against Americans.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 26 about the Yale University scholar Warren Hunting Smith, who edited the letters of Horace Walpole, included an incorrect word in a quotation from another Yale scholar who commented on Mr. Smith's 50-year effort. Frank Brady, chairman of the project that edited the papers of James Boswell at Yale, said Mr. Smith's painstakingly handwritten work in the days before computers was like being ''in the scriptorium when Gutenberg came along,'' not ''in the solarium.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLL, WALTER A.
description: STOLL-Walter A. On November 27, 1998, of Chevy Chase, Maryland. Beloved husband of the late Phyllis J. Father of Jeanne E. Prettyman (Charles W.). Brother of Augusta Shader & Helen Vassi. Also survived by one granddaughter, Christine K. Swann. For information: Joseph Gawler's Sons, Washington, D.C. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E-7275, York Ave., NYC 10021 or charity of choice.

title: Mets Get Benitez and Near Ventura Deal
description: In a flurry of moves last night, the Mets traded their longtime catcher, Todd Hundley, acquired the hard-throwing reliever Armando Benitez and, according to several baseball officials, reached an agreement with the All-Star third baseman Robin Ventura.

title: Illegal Use of Soft Money
description: To everyone except the partisans, it has always been obvious that President Clinton and Bob Dole violated campaign spending laws in the 1996 election. Now the Federal Election Commission staff has advanced the cause of honest politics by studying both campaigns and formally concluding that the candidates broke the law and should pay millions of dollars to the Federal Government as punishment. The conclusion by commission auditors and counsel, made public yesterday, should help close the soft-money loophole that has destroyed the campaign finance laws. It should also finally prod Attorney General Janet Reno to get an independent counsel to investigate.

title: Schoolchildren Set Out to Liberate Slaves in Sudan
description: Josh did extra chores around the house to make at least $11. Leshai collects dropped coins. Ben brings in 50 cents or so from his $5 allowance.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CORNERSTONE CONSTRUCTION AND MATERIALS INC., Neptune, N.J., a unit of Hanson P.L.C., acquired the 50 percent of Gifford Hill-American Holdings Inc. it did not already own from Ameron International Corp., Pasadena, Calif., for $28.5 million in cash and debt.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Nov. 20 about the arrest of an Israeli on suspicion of planning an attack on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu referred incompletely to the suspect's association with the Orthodox Jewish movement known as Chabad. While the suspect, Shabtai Bloch, was identified by Israeli radio as a figure in the movement, Chabad officials say he is not known to them, and add that the movement's teachings condemn violence.

title: An Internet company with little freebies that could gains a place in the sun.
description: LINK EXCHANGE, a two-year-old Internet company that built a large membership by luring Web sites with the offer of free advertising, and then sold advertising to outside companies and products to its members, has clearly reaped its reward.

title: Let's Kill the Hyperbole
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Convicted of Killing Megan Kanka Asks for a New Trial
description: Lawyers for the paroled sex offender who raped and strangled 7-year-old Megan Kanka in 1994 asked the New Jersey Supreme Court today to overturn his murder conviction and death sentence on grounds including negative pretrial publicity and what they said were improper prosecution statements.

title: Timing of China's Move on Spratlys Raises Asian Suspicions
description: SINGAPORE  Despite its assurances of peaceful intent toward Southeast Asia, China is enforcing its claim on much of the South China Sea at a time when its smaller neighbors are being forced to cut back military spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINN, MARCELLE ASCH (NEE STEABMAN)
description: FINN-Marcelle Asch (nee Steabman). Died on November 25, 1998. Wife, mother, sister, grandmother, friend. Memorial service will be held at The Brooklyn Museum of Art on Friday, Dec 4 at 7:00 PM.

title: Campaign Finance Case Costs A Carpet Company $1 Million
description: One of the country's largest carpet manufacturers, Beaulieu of America Inc. of Dalton, Ga., was fined $1 million today after pleading guilty to Federal misdemeanor charges that it made $36,000 in illegal contributions to Lamar Alexander's 1996 Presidential campaign. The company is headed by Carl M. Bouckaert, a Belgian citizen who was one of the rougly 30 finance co-chairmen of Mr. Alexander's 1996 campaign.

title: UNITED DOMINION TO LET 600 GO IN CONSOLIDATION
description: United Dominion Industries Ltd. said yesterday that it was laying off about 600 employees, or 5 percent of its work force, and consolidating 12 facilities to cut costs as its customers decreased their capital spending. The company, a maker of cooling towers, valves and testing instruments, is also taking a $15 million pretax fourth-quarter charge, which could be offset by unrelated gains, for the cuts. The company said some facilities would be closed but would not specify how many or where they were. United Dominion said the cuts were necessary in the face of an ''uncertain'' economic environment. United Dominion, based in Charlotte, N.C., employs more than 11,000 and had sales of $1.65 billion in 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, M. DONALD
description: GRANT-M. Donald. The Board of Directors and the employees of Fahnestock & Co. Inc., note with sorrow the passing of our former Managing Partner, friend and associate of over 50 years. Our sympathy is extended to the family. Albert G. Lowenthal, Chairman

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the rise of nongovernmental organizations' involvement in foreign policy misidentified a company that was investigated by the British Government this year after being accused of breaking a United Nations arms embargo on Sierra Leone. It was Sandline International, a British company that sells arms and military assistance, not Executive Outcome of South Africa, another private military company, which was hired by the Sierra Leone Government to subdue rebels in 1995 and 1996.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Midtown Office Tower Preparing for a Comeback
description: As a founder of the Coca-Cola Company in Atlanta, Asa Griggs Candler was a step ahead of his time. As the developer of the Candler Building near Times Square, however, he was too far ahead -- 85 years, as it turns out.

title: Colleges Fall, But Prisons Rise In State Support
description: In the last 10 years, New York State increased spending on prisons by almost as much as it decreased allocations to higher education, according to a study released yesterday criticizing the Pataki administration's spending priorities.

title: Pataki Wants Surplus Spent on Transit
description: Saying that New York City Transit's resurgent subway and bus operations will pile up a $379 million surplus by the end of the year, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that most of the spare cash should be used to improve the service, maintenance and cleanliness of the mass transit system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, MERWIN
description: LEWIS-Merwin. It is with sorrow that the Directors of Greater New York Mutual Insurance Company record the death of their dear friend and colleague, Merwin Lewis, in his 99th year. The Lewis family has been prominently identified with our Company since its founding 85 years ago. Merwin Lewis joined our Board in 1954. He was a compassionate and caring person deeply involved with the welfare of the Company's employees. A highly respected and experienced attorney, he carried on an active practice until his death. He was a wise and judicious counsellor to our Company and a valuable resource to the Bar of this city and to the community as a whole. We shall miss him. We extend our deepest sympathy to the members of the bereaved family. Alexander E. Rosenthal Chairman of the Board Warren W. Heck, President

title: Memories of Mexico, Seasoned by Time
description: THE memoirist approach to cookbook writing is winning out. Increasingly, cookbooks are autobiographies instead of mere collections of recipes. There are two recent books of this kind, both about Mexican cooking by women who were not born in Mexico.

title: British Textile Maker To Close 8 Factories
description: Courtaulds Textiles of Britain said yesterday that it would cut 1,220 jobs and close eight factories of its Claremont Garments subsidiary. Courtaulds said the measures were necessary to bring Claremont, which it took over two months ago, back to profitability. A total of 1,125 jobs will be eliminated at the factories in England and a further 95 jobs will be cut at Claremont's headquarters.

description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Rewarding A Rock's Role In the Bronx
description: IN the years since they took a ramshackle loft in Mott Haven and turned it into Vamos a la Pena del Bronx, Victor Toro and Nieves Ayress have become used to laboring in obscurity. Relying on little more than the hearts and hands of friends and neighbors, they created a community center where immigrants get free food to strengthen their bodies, English lessons to nurture their future and music-filled festivals to sustain their culture.

title: Law's Scope of Perjury Is Pivotal in House Vote
description: Even President Clinton concedes that he did not tell the whole truth about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky. But did he commit perjury under the definition of the law?

title: REPUBLIC BANCORP TO BUY D& N FINANCIAL IN STOCK DEAL
description: Republic Bancorp Inc., based in Owosso, Mich., agreed yesterday to acquire the D& N Financial Corporation for stock worth $286 million at Monday's closing price. Shareholders of D& N Financial, based in Hancock, Mich., will receive 1.82 Republic Bancorp common shares for each D& N Financial share. The transaction will be accounted for as a pooling of interests. The companies said the transaction valued D& N Financial at $30.14 a share. The companies said the new corporate headquarters would be in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, SEYMOUR M.
description: ALEXANDER - Seymour M. Adored husband of Marion. Beloved father of William. Dear brother of Harriet Belsky. Services Thursday 10:30 AM at ''Parkside'' Chapels Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: A Player's Long Trip From Watts
description: The week leading up to the Army-Navy game is memorable for any player. For Bwerani Nettles, a 22-year-old Navy freshman, it is a time of awe.

title: All Perfume, No Pucker
description: Many people go through life with a single, vivid taste image of a lemon -- one of something acidic, clean tasting and unforgivingly sharp. Unlike an orange, which can have dozens of flavors, depending on the variety, the lemon has just one reliable note that sticks firmly in their minds.

title: A Simple Soup Turned Elegant
description: MANY soups have extraordinarily simple origins, none more so than an ancient peasant dish of southern France called, simply, boiled water. At its most impoverished, this is no more than garlic simmered in water to give it flavor, with a few crusts of bread added for bulk.

title: The Pinochet Precedent
description: If Britain allows Augusto Pinochet to be extradited to Spain to stand trial for atrocities committed under his 17-year rule, despots elsewhere will take note: if Mr. Pinochet cannot escape the long arm of international law, they might not, either.

title: In Kevorkian, Some See a Villain, Some a Hero
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Stephen K-M Tim, vice president for science, information services and publications at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, gave his educational background incompletely. He had a doctorate in botany from Rhodes University in South Africa.

title: Jim Beam Brands Seeks New Agency
description: Jim Beam Brands Worldwide said yesterday that it had placed in review its flagship Jim Beam brand of bourbon account, with billings estimated at $15 million. That account, along with several other brands, had been handled for a decade by Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis until the agency resigned last month.

title: Fashion Institute's New President Sets Her Own Course
description: It's a shirtsleeve day, and Dr. Joyce F. Brown, the newly appointed president of the Fashion Institute of Technology, has just finished meeting with a finance committee. Her desk is cluttered with papers and she wonders if she should have her picture taken behind such a jumble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TASHIRO, KIKUE
description: TASHIRO-Kikue, November 5th at Calvary Hospice. Survived by her husband, Ago Terayama. A native of Japan who made NYC her home, Kikue wrote many plays, including ''Sakura: The Bandit Princess'' and ''Kensuke'', which were seen in many NYC venues as well as in Toronto, Hawaii and Europe. A memorial celebration of her life and words will be held Monday, December 7th, 8PM, at Vineyard Theater, 108 E. 15th St.

title: Three Plead Guilty to Inflating Value of Mortgaged Properties
description: Three licensed real estate appraisers pleaded guilty today in Federal District Court here to charges of inflating property assessments as part of a scheme to secure large mortgages for dilapidated properties. But in a twist, two of the appraisers said in court that the scheme had been directed by officials at a mortgage company that has described itself as a victim of the fraud.

title: A $10,000 Challenge on a Banked Track
description: The New Balance athletic shoe company has thrown down the challenge: $10,000 to the man who can run a sub-four-minute mile or to the woman who can break 4:33 at the New Balance Games on Jan. 9.

title: Jets' Receiving Corps Throwing a Block Party
description: Last week, Keyshawn Johnson and Dedric Ward good-naturedly teased each other in the Jets' locker room at Hofstra University, with the gist of Johnson's barbs being Ward's inability to block like Johnson can.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, ABRAHAM
description: RESNICK-Abraham. Beloved husband of the late Ethel, devoted father of Judith Gaffney.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROEGER, JOHN F.
description: KROEGER-John F. The Board of Directors of the AIM Funds and AIM Management are deeply saddended by the loss of John F. Kroeger who has served our Funds as a Director since their start over 22 years ago. John's wisdom, dedication and work ethic were of the highest standards, which were executed by him always in a honest and gentlemanly manner. We will miss him greatly and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Janice and their family. AIM Funds and AIM Management

title: Souffle Dishes to Pig Spits: Renting for a Bash
description: YOU have just sent out the invitations for your holiday party. You have invited tons of people for drinks and hors d'oeuvres. But you own a total of eight glasses and no punch bowl. And if you want to make that spiked cider, you'll need to use all your pots and do it in batches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWHOUSE, THEODORE
description: NEWHOUSE - Theodore. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with sorrow the loss of Ted Newhouse. For almost ten years, Ted has been part of the Hebrew Home family. We will miss Ted and extend our heartfelt condolences to devoted wife Caroline and granddaughters Julie and Amy, as well as the entire Newhouse family. The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman Daniel A. Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: CALPINE TO BUY TWO GENERATING PLANTS FROM PG& E UNIT
description: The Calpine Corporation, the second-largest American producer of geothermal energy, agreed to buy two power plants in California from a unit of the PG& E Corporation for $73.8 million as Calpine moves to reduce costs. The steam-powered plants are in Lake County, north of San Francisco, and together can generate 150 megawatts of power. They are part of a group auctioned last month by PG& E's Pacific Gas & Electric utility and sold to a unit of the FPL Group for $213 million. Calpine, which is based in San Jose, Calif., was able to acquire the plants by exercising its right to match the winning bid. Calpine must also pay a 2 percent, or $1.5 million, breakup fee to FPL, a Calpine spokeswoman, Katherine Potter, said, for a total price of $75.3 million.

title: Early Start for the Tate's New Museum; Londoners Already Flock to the Site of a Modern-Art Gallery Opening in 2000
description: Several hundred people gathered recently on the south side of the Thames River in London, around the hulking facade of a former power station where Andy Warhol's 1964 film ''Empire'' was being projected larger than life. Joggers stopped to watch. So did neighbors on their way home from work, cyclists, film buffs and hordes of contemporary-art mavens who had read about the free screening.

title: Riffs, Not Recipes: Improvisational Cooking
description: NEARLY a decade ago, we were staying with two other couples in a rented beach house, and the agreement was that each of us would cook one meal. For mine, I was carrying a photocopy of a time-tested recipe. I spent a sunny, breezy day racing down supermarket aisles collecting ingredients. But the basil and saffron the recipe called for? None available. In the kitchen, I played fast and loose with garlic and pepper, but nothing could raise my shrimp-with-rice dish above the bland. Everyone murmured thanks. After all the work I had done, however, nothing less than a standing ovation could satisfy.

title: The New Oil Behemoth
description: It was only two decades ago that the oil industry seemed to be sitting astride the global economy. Oil prices were high and were expected to continue rising indefinitely, much of the developed world was facing economic difficulties caused in part by high energy prices, and there was fear that inflation would never be brought under control.

title: Bright Lights, Big City
description: Less than a week after smiling their way through three hours of the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, Matt Lauer and Al Roker of NBC are back on holiday-cheer duty tonight, this time in the evening hours as hosts of the Rockefeller Center Christmas-tree-lighting show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPPER, BELINA
description: POPPER-Belina. Died at age 91 after a brief illness on November 30, 1998 at Sound Shore Medical Center. She was born to Iancu and Bertha Saraga in Bucharest, Romania March 9, 1907. She married her beloved husband, Emil, in 1929. Her husband died in 1983 after 53 years of marriage. She was also predeceased by her sisters, Diana and Renee. She loved her gardens, dance, music and the arts. She is survived by her sons, Alex and Serge, her sister, Stefi, three grandchildren, nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends on Wednesday, December 2, from 4-6PM at the John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont, NY. Private entombment will take place at Ferncliff Cemetery. Memorial donations may be sent to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONG, RICHARD E.
description: LONG-Richard E. The Board of Governors of the New York Athletic Club records with profound sorrow the passing of their former beloved President. We have lost a true friend and a devoted member and to his family convey our heartfelt sympathy. James W. O'Brien, President Alfred H. Green, Vice President

title: A Premium of Billions Will Vanish on Accounting Ledgers
description: When Exxon and Mobil merge their financial ledgers, executives plan to use an accounting method that will leave no trace of a premium of more than $50 billion that Exxon has agreed to pay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANKIN, LEONARD J.
description: HANKIN-Leonard J. Honorary Trustee. The Officers, Trustees and staff of the Educational Alliance note with profound sadness the passing of Leonard J. Hankin, our Honorary Trustee and friend. Leonard joined the Alliance's Board of Trustees in 1957 and served as an officer and Chair of the Nominating Committee for many years. He was a wise, gentle, compassionate and caring human being. Always elegant in the clarity of his thinking and his style, Leonard's intelligence, integrity and vision were major sources of the Alliance's strength. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Leonard's loving family.

title: How High Can the Burgundy Market Go?
description: IN Bordeaux, a handful of top chateaus like Latour and Margaux set the pricing pattern for the rest of the region. Each spring, when they announce their prices for the previous vintage, everyone else soon follows, taking their cues from the leaders.

title: Torricelli Chosen to Run Democratic Campaigns
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli, a first-term Democrat from New Jersey known for his fund-raising prowess, was selected today to run the Senate Democrats' main campaign committee, an influential political job that traditionally has been a launching pad to top leadership positions in the Senate.

title: Boeing Sees Big Job Cuts Over 2 Years
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that the economic downturn in Asia was forcing it to scale back production of many passenger jets beginning next year and to cut more jobs over the next two years -- perhaps as many as 20,000 -- than it had indicated in June.

title: Lumbini Journal; Buddha's Birthplace Hopes for a New Incarnation
description: Some 2,500 years ago, on a spring day under a full moon, Siddhartha Gautama was born in Lumbini. His mother had gone into labor while on a stroll in a verdant grove, smelling the flowers and listening to the songbirds. The baby would grow up to be the Enlightened One -- the Buddha -- and this village would become holy soil to millions of Buddhists who, for the most part, would these days never think of coming here.

title: Playoffs Still in Sight, The Giants Step Down
description: Before his Giants played in San Francisco Monday night, Coach Jim Fassel told the team that a victory against the 49ers would put the Giants back in the playoff chase and set up a meaningful game with the Arizona Cardinals on Sunday.

title: Monsanto Gains Support of F.D.A. Panel
description: The Monsanto Company won the backing of a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel today for the first of a new class of painkillers with expected annual sales of as much as $5 billion.

title: Quebec's Timid Nationalism
description: On Monday voters in Quebec re-elected their Parti Quebecois government, which says it remains dedicated to establishing the province as a sovereign country. Yet the vote does not signal Canada's imminent breakup. What it probably means is merely the next installment of what Jacques Parizeau, the former Quebec Premier, called Canada's ''permanent trip to the dentist'' -- that is, another painful round of haggling over the sharing of powers and tax revenue in Canada's convoluted federal structure.

title: Study Calls Remedial Classes Good Investment
description: At a time when the City University of New York and other universities are trying to reduce the number of remedial classes in English and math, a new study commissioned by the Ford Foundation says such courses are ''a core function of higher education'' as well as a good investment for society.

title: PANEL CAN'T LINK BREAST IMPLANTS TO ANY DISEASES
description: A panel of four scientists, appointed by a Federal court, issued a report yesterday concluding that scientific evidence has so far failed to show that silicone breast implants cause disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZMAN, JULIUS
description: SALTZMAN-Julius. Of Fort Lauderdale, FL and N.Y.C. Much loved brother, brother-in-law, uncle, and great-uncle, passed away peacefully on November 20 at age 81 to join his beloved companion, the late Moe Fine, his cherished sister, the late Helen Pepose, and his dear brother, the late Murray Saltzman, after a brave battle with melanoma at the home of his niece, Maura Copeland and her husband, Paul of Swampscott, MA. Also survived by his brother, Irving Saltzman, and sisters-in-law Rae and Beatrice; nephews, Alan Saltzman, Robert Saltzman and wife Kathy, Jay Pepose and wife, Susan Feigenbaum, and niece, Arlene Berkman and husband Milton. He was adored by ten grandnieces and grand-nephews; Lysa, Lauryn, Seth, David, Marnine, Daniel, Maxwell, Samuel, Morissa, and Harry. He will be greatly missed. Services were held at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, November 22. Most appreciated donations in his memory to the FineSaltzman Nursing Fellowship, c/o Jimmie Holland, M.D., MemorialSloan Kettering, 1275 York Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Waiting for Daniel

title: Textron to Build Complex
description: Textron Inc. said today that it planned to build a complex near Detroit to design and develop automotive trim, as well as other products, for DaimlerChrysler A.G. The 87,000-square-foot center in Auburn Hills, Mich., will have offices, design studios and a secured mock-up area for new-vehicle development. It is scheduled to open in March and will house 250 employees. DaimlerChrysler is the biggest client of Textron Automotive's trim division.

title: Korean President Presses Overhaul of Industries
description: President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea increased the pressure on the nation's balky business groups yesterday, seeking a personal pledge for faster changes from the heads of the five biggest conglomerates, known as chaebols. Mr. Kim plans to meet next week with the heads of the Hyundai, Samsung, Daewoo, LG and SK groups to extract promises for firm action on corporate overhauls, a presidential spokesman, Park Jiewon, said.

title: Matching Poetry To Music

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROVENTINI, JOHN
description: ROVENTINI-John. ''Johnny Of Philip Morris''. Philip Morris Companies, Inc. notes with sorrow the death of John Roventini, who served for more than four decades as a Philip Morris spokesman and living trademark. Johnny's melodic ''Call for Phil-ip Morrees!''-first broadcast on the radio in 1933-was heard on thousands of Philip Morris-sponsored radio and television programs and at personal appearances across the country until he retired in 1974. By his own conservative estimate, Johnny shook hands with more than a million people and gave his perfect B-flat call more than a million times. The story of his career as a public personality parallels the development of modern entertainment, spanning the early days of radio and continuing through Philip Morris-sponsored television programs of the 1950s, such as ''I Love Lucy'' and ''Candid Camera''. Johnny's fame as an advertising legend was enhanced by an ever-present smile and outstretched hand that won him friends wherever he went. The Philip Morris Companies Inc. Board of Directors and staff pay warm tribute to the memory of our famous spokesman and roving ambassador, and we extend our deepest sympathies to his family.

title: A Writer With an Ear for the Melody of Peasant Speech; The New Nobel Prize Winner Jose Saramago Trains an Outsider's Irony on Time, Faith and History

Not that he was a surprise choice: he was already the pundits' favorite last year when the prize went to Dario Fo of Italy. It is just that, as he puts it softly, ''I was not born for this.''

title: DELAWARE JUDGE VOIDS QUICKTURN ANTI-TAKEOVER PLAN
description: A Delaware judge yesterday invalidated a potent but controversial anti-takeover plan adopted by Quickturn Design Systems Inc. in its attempt to fend off a hostile bid. The ruling by Vice Chancellor Jack Jacobs of Delaware Chancery Court eases the way for a proxy fight in which the Mentor Graphics Corporation is trying to oust Quickturn's current directors and thus force the company to accept its $215 million hostile offer. The judge also upheld a Quickturn bylaw change that allowed the company to delay by 90 to 100 days a special shareholders meeting at which a Mentor-nominated slate of directors would be voted upon. Mentor had wanted that meeting held next week, but under the Quickturn bylaw change, the meeting would be on Jan. 8.

title: CEREAL MAKER TO SELL LIQUI-DRI TO VALUE ADDED BAKERY
description: The Quaker Oats Company, the No. 4 United States cereal maker, agreed yesterday to sell Liqui-Dri Foods Inc., its biscuit and hot cake business, to the closely held Value Added Bakery Company for an undisclosed price. Liqui-Dri, which employs 350 people and will have 1998 sales of about $80 million, supplies the food-service industry from two plants in Louisville, Ky. The sale of Liqui-Dri is the latest move by the Chicago-based Quaker, which had 1997 sales of $5.02 billion, to streamline its operations. On Tuesday, the company said it would close its rice-cakes factory in Asheville, N.C., and dismiss 143 workers. Value Added Bakery is a new company, formed by Wind Point Partners III L.P. of Southfield, Mich., and by two bakery industry executives.

title: Bathhouses of Another Era
description: During the 19th century, when indoor plumbing was scarce, New Yorkers washed in 20 floating bathhouses along the Hudson and East Rivers, wood structures with plank floors, changing rooms and soap and towels for rent. ''New York's Floating Bathhouses,'' an exhibition of 30 images, including the bath at Fifth Street and the East River (above), opens today at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. ''Before 1870, people jumped into the rivers, bathing naked,'' David Gissen, the show's curator, said. In 1890, newspapers called the baths, fed with river water, ''floating sewers.'' By 1915, they had become swimming pools filled with piped water. The exhibition runs through April 15. Museum admission is $8; $6 for students and those over 60. Reservations: (212) 431-0233, ext. 555.

description: Art Barbuto's credit-card printer spat out a terse message this morning: ''Dear Mobil dealers,'' it said, ''A letter has been sent to you today with information on the Exxon Mobil merger.''

title: Joyful in Victory, Espy Is Mindful of Price
description: After four years of harrowing investigation and two months of sitting mute through his trial, Mike Espy broke his silence today, alternating bursts of exultation at his acquittal with condemnation of an independent counsel's $17 million dragnet effort to put him in prison.

title: Safety Commission Says Vinyl Pacifiers Should Be Discarded
description: Saying that it could not be certain of the risk to babies from a material found in vinyl that causes cancer in rats, the Consumer Product Safety Commission advised parents today to throw away nipples and pacifiers made of vinyl and asked manufacturers to stop using it in objects that children put into their mouths.

title: For Pursuing the Trivial, Choose Your Path
description: QUIZ shows have been around at least since the days of radio and were also a staple of early television programs. Even though the shows were broadcast through a speaker, they were often interactive for their listeners, who would play along and shout out the answers to the trivia questions along with the on-air contestants. At least they did in my family, where the nightly half-hour of ''Jeopardy'' was considered educational television.

The victory by Rita Shugart of Pebble Beach, Calif., at the end of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals in Orlando, Fla., on Sunday, was extraordinary for three reasons.

title: Grim Assessment by U.N. of Asia Crisis
description: The social costs of the Asian economic crisis are far higher than initial estimates and are ''dramatically worsening,'' according to a report here on Tuesday by the International Labor Organization, a United Nations agency.

title: Laptop Plus Handheld And a Bit of Gumby
description: The Clio, a handheld computer that arrives in stores this month, falls somewhere between standard laptops and the smaller Windows CE devices. Its 9.4-inch screen and nearly full-sized keyboard are akin to a laptop, but its brains -- no hard drive, 16 megabytes of RAM and a MIPS processor -- are not much more than a CE would muster.

title: A Weatherman as Downhill Seer
description: It's appropriate, somehow, that anyone calling himself a skiing weatherman might also ski. Isn't it easier for skiers and boarders facing wet snow or ice to know that their meteorologist might also be boot-deep in slush or skidding on boilerplate?

title: Seeing in the Dark
description: RARELY has an urban legend been born so quickly and openly as the tale that Sony's Nightshot video camera could see through clothes. Jay Leno joked about it: ''Hear about this new video camera that looks through clothes? Well, Sony has recalled it -- and raised the price.'' The Government of Malaysia banned the device with its No Lux infrared feature.

title: Accord Is Reached on Foster Care Review
description: At a hearing in United States District Court yesterday, advocates for foster children and Government lawyers formally announced that a team of national experts will assess and guide New York City's child welfare agency over the next two years.

But they do not have the old chutzpah. The proposed colossus lacks one thing that made Standard Oil the prime target of antitrust crusaders and muckraking journalists: a Rockefeller.

title: Clinton Lawyers to Face House Republicans at Inquiry
description: Trying to call attention to what they consider Republican bungling, White House lawyers said today that they would defend President Clinton before the House Judiciary Committee next week. But they demanded a raft of information in advance to cope with what they called a ''dramatically expanded'' impeachment inquiry.

title: Clinton Asks the Views of Top Aides on the Freeing of Pollard
description: The White House has asked the Government's top law enforcement and intelligence officials and key Cabinet members to recommend by early next month whether President Clinton should grant clemency to Jonathan Pollard, the former Navy analyst convicted of spying for Israel, Administration officials said today.

title: Critic's Notebook; Didi and Gogo in Middle Age, Unchanging but Fresh
description: Fifty years ago Samuel Beckett began writing ''Waiting for Godot,'' the play that was to transform his life and alter the direction of contemporary theater. In a recent survey, the Royal National Theater in London concluded that ''Godot'' was the most significant English language play of the 20th century, a point that no longer seems arguable. Somehow, in the intervening years, the play has been seen and appreciated by a wide theatergoing public, as demonstrated by the current production at the Classic Stage Company in the East Village. The times and the audience have changed, while Beckett has remained immutable.

title: Clemens Demands To Be Traded
description: When Roger Clemens was a free agent two years ago, he shunned two teams that had been, and would continue to be, legitimate contenders, the Yankees and the Cleveland Indians. Now, after winning his fourth and unprecedented fifth Cy Young awards but no championships with the Toronto Blue Jays, Clemens wants to be traded to a contender.

title: Conducting a Season, Joyful and Triumphant
description: KENT TRITLE grew up on a century-old family farm in Iowa, founded a high school rock band that played at proms across the prairie, graduated from the Juilliard School, transformed the music program at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue into one of the best in the city, performed as an organist with the New York Philharmonic and two springs ago bailed out the family farm when his bankrupt parents couldn't afford to plant the soybean crop.

description: In excerpts from a videotaped deposition played in Federal court today, William H. Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, professed general ignorance of his company's legal battles with Sun Microsystems Inc. over Sun's Java programming language.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The Japanese currency rose as a slump in stock market prices in the United States dampened the demand for dollars. In New York, the dollar settled at 119.93 yen, down from 122.17 yen late Tuesday.

title: A Close Vote on Gay Rights
description: The question is, what happens now? Two decades after passing a gay rights ordinance that spurred the rise of the religious right -- and was then defeated by the voters in a battle that raised civil rights for homosexuals to the level of a national debate -- the Miami-Dade County Commission has done it again. It took a whole generation to overcome the traumatic rejection of the original ordinance, but on Tuesday, by a vote of just 7 to 6, the commission added the category of sexual orientation to the county's human rights law. It will now be illegal to discriminate against homosexuals in housing, employment, credit, finance and public accommodation in metropolitan Dade County.

description: A one-star Navy admiral accepted a finding of guilt today on charges that he had improperly steered military contracts to his mistress, and he agreed to early retirement at a lower rank, with a substantially reduced pension, and penalties including 30 days of house arrest, Navy officials said.

title: A Hardware Store That's a Mall Unto Itself
description: Watch out Gracious Home, Crate and Barrel, Pottery Barn and Simon's Hardware and Bath. Restoration Hardware, a hybrid with aspects of all of those places, has just opened its 63d store, and its first in Manhattan. Some might view the shop as one more step in the malling of Manhattan, but it may answer the needs of home decorators, Sunday carpenters, house remodelers and gadget collectors. Restoration sells an unusual assortment of 5,000 products, including books, hardware items like the Tim Allen hammer (left, in jars, $32 apiece), as well as furniture (like the leather club chair, $1,395), lamps ($129) and framed posters ($199).

title: A Church Fights to Restore Windows With a Tiffany Look
description: WHEN you enter the long nave of St. James African Methodist Episcopal Church here, there is a deep, rich glow near the altar, coming from windows that pulsate with color and light. The dazzling interplay of emerald greens, dark blues, ambers and rubies inspires a feeling verging on rapture. Anyone seeing these six windows will wonder if they are by Louis Comfort Tiffany. The answer is a definite ''maybe'' and, in fact, the mystery may never be resolved.

title: EXEL AND INTERCARGO, TWO INSURERS, IN $88 MILLION DEAL
description: Exel Ltd., which provides a range of insurance services, agreed yesterday to buy the Intercargo Corporation, an insurer specializing in marine cargo underwriting and United States Customs bonds, for about $88 million. Exel, based in Hamilton, Bermuda, will pay $12 a share for Intercargo, based in Schaumberg, Ill. Exel offers general liability, directors and officers liability and employment practices liability insurance. Exel's stock fell 68.75 cents, to $73.4375, and Intercargo rose $1.3125 each, to $11.4375.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK; The Splendid Rage Of Tibor Kalman
description: CHOICE and free will have lost some of their philosophical luster in our day. Updated and retooled through the decibels of corporate advertising, free will is today expressed as the fashionable condition of being edgy or ''in your face.'' In America, corporate symbols, the young, the famous, all aspire to this sublime state. The same blank look of disaffected angst sells everything from stockbrokers to Buicks to white cotton briefs. Free will in the classical sense implies that you actually do something. Being edgy requires only that we show up, late of course, and that we buy something.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROVENTINI, JOHN
description: ROVENTINI-John. ''Johnny Of Philip Morris''. Philip Morris Companies, Inc. notes with sorrow the death of John Roventini, who served for more than four decades as a Philip Morris spokesman and living trademark. Johnny's melodic ''Call for Phil-ip Morrees!''-first broadcast on the radio in 1933-was heard on thousands of Philip Morris-sponsored radio and television programs and at personal appearances across the country until he retired in 1974. By his own conservative estimate, Johnny shook hands with more than a million people and gave his perfect B-flat call more than a million times. The story of his career as a public personality parallels the development of modern entertainment, spanning the early days of radio and continuing through Philip Morris-sponsored television programs of the 1950s, such as ''I Love Lucy'' and ''Candid Camera''. Johnny's fame as an advertising legend was enhanced by an ever-present smile and outstretched hand that won him friends wherever he went. The Philip Morris Companies Inc. Board of Directors and staff pay warm tribute to the memory of our famous spokesman and roving ambassador, and we extend our deepest sympathies to his family.

title: The Pop Life; Cartoons Dare To Mock Icons

Running for 10 years in alternative weekly newspapers, this pen-and-ink history of rock-and-roll has informed readers that Keith Richards of the Rolling Stones ate so much candy that ''his entire body rotted away from the teeth downwards,'' Madonna ''tried to change organized religion'' by ''wearing her underwear outside her clothes,'' Bob Dylan's music opened the way for new singer-songwriters who ''were usually discovered feeling sorry for themselves on the stairs at parties'' and Bono of U2 ''retired from music to make LP's.''

title: Deep in Texas, News Anchors and Teletubbies Are Missing
description: I'VE certainly cried over television before. Those stock triumph-over-tragedy movies have been known to reduce me to a quivering mess of smeared mascara, and even though I know I'm being had, I always fall victim to the schmaltzy AT&T commercials. And oh yes, when I was younger and less hardened to the vagaries of professional sports, I used to cry whenever the Minnesota Vikings lost. (In those days, that meant quite often.) As I planted tulips up and down the hill in front of our barn in Maryland over Thanksgiving, I scoured the old buildings for good junk that might lend itself to a container garden on the south side of the house, just outside the kitchen door.

title: ESKIMO PIE REJECTS HIGHER TAKOVER BID FROM YOGEN FRUZ
description: The Eskimo Pie Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected a new takeover bid -- $13 a share, or $45 million -- from Yogen Fruz World-Wide Inc. The offer was inadequate and ''not in the best interests of the company's shareholders,'' said Eskimo Pie, the Richmond-based maker of frozen desserts, including the ice cream bar that bears its name. Last month, the Toronto-based Yogen Fruz made an unsolicited bid of $10.25 a share, or $36 million, for Eskimo Pie. Eskimo Pie said its board had asked its financial adviser to continue exploring options to enhance shareholder value. Shares of Eskimo Pie were up $1, to $12.25. Yogen Fruz franchises frozen yogurt stores in 82 countries and supplies frozen desserts to supermarkets.

title: Rhode Island and Duke Pad Credentials

There were stops at Connecticut and upstate New York at prep schools in his senior year, followed by a summer in Las Vegas, where he was presumably going to join the Runnin' Rebels. Lamar Odom is probably the most well-traveled freshman in college basketball, and the road has always been bumpy.

title: City Hall, Behind Barricades
description: In an age when terrorists are on the loose, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has every right to be concerned about protecting New York's City Hall from attack. The bombings of the World Trade Center and the Federal building in Oklahoma City and the spraying of bullets around the Capitol in Washington are ample proof of the threat. But there is always a danger that the concrete barricades and police blockades now surrounding City Hall to thwart terrorists will stifle dissent and frustrate public access to the nerve center of government. Security is an issue that calls for an exquisite balance of competing values, and full public discussion of the reasons for it. The Mayor and the City Council need to think these through.

title: 3 Accused of Cheating Investors In a Florida Recycling Company
description: Three people who were promoting the stock of a Florida company that recycled toxic waste were indicted yesterday on charges that they cheated 200 investors, including more than 50 New York State court officers and their friends and families, out of more than $2.5 million.

title: An Oval Office to Make Workers Feel Right at Home
description: The challenge: To create an office for Nick and Paul, a brand agency that creates things like new drinks for Coca-Cola and new tools for Black & Decker. (It is at 425 West 15th Street, above Chelsea Market.) The solution? A translucent fiberglass oval ringed by a tilted elliptical wall, by the architect David Ling. Individual work spaces are outside the oval. Group work occurs in the 7,000-square-foot ellipse, furnished with mismatched sofas, chairs and tables from staff members' homes. Nick Shore, an agency owner, said: ''We wanted an office that forces you into a community, into human interaction. We wanted people to feel homey.'' Mr. Ling (left) had another image: ''The form is the womb.'' ELAINE LOUIE

Shares of Irvine Apartment, based in Newport Beach, Calif., rose $4.1875, to $31.5625. title: AS EXPECTED, KELLOGG WILL CUT 765 JOBS IN NORTH AMERICA
description: In a widely expected move intended to help revive its ailing cereal business, the Kellogg Company said yesterday that it would dismiss 525 salaried employees from its North American operations and would eliminate 240 of about 600 contracted positions. Kellogg, the maker of Rice Krispies and Frosted Flakes, said it would take a one-time charge against fourth-quarter profits of $45 million, or 11 cents a share, to pay for the job cuts, which the company expects will reduce annual expenses by about $105 million. Those savings would help offset increased spending on product development and promotions. Kellogg said most of the jobs to be eliminated would come from its headquarters in Battle Creek, Mich. The company's stock fell 93.75 cents, to $36.375.

Since all that is needed to celebrate the Feast of Lights are eight candles (one for each night) and a ninth to light them, design options for menorahs are endless. ''My Hanukkah menorahs are fun and funky,'' said Jennifer Cukier, a Quebec artist who uses the traditional menorah shape and sparks it up with color. Another artist is inspired by Noah's Ark. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROVENTINI, JOHN
description: ROVENTINI-John. ''Johnny Of Philip Morris''. Philip Morris Companies, Inc. notes with sorrow the death of John Roventini, who served for more than four decades as a Philip Morris spokesman and living trademark. Johnny's melodic ''Call for Phil-ip Morrees!''-first broadcast on the radio in 1933-was heard on thousands of Philip Morris-sponsored radio and television programs and at personal appearances across the country until he retired in 1974. By his own conservative estimate, Johnny shook hands with more than a million people and gave his perfect B-flat call more than a million times. The story of his career as a public personality parallels the development of modern entertainment, spanning the early days of radio and continuing through Philip Morris-sponsored television programs of the 1950s, such as ''I Love Lucy'' and ''Candid Camera''. Johnny's fame as an advertising legend was enhanced by an ever-present smile and outstretched hand that won him friends wherever he went. The Philip Morris Companies Inc. Board of Directors and staff pay warm tribute to the memory of our famous spokesman and roving ambassador, and we extend our deepest sympathies to his family.

title: MYERS INDUSTRIES AGREES TO BUY UNIT OF SOMMER ALLIBERT
description: Myers Industries, a maker of re-usable plastic and metal shipping containers, agreed yesterday to buy a unit of Sommer Allibert S.A. of France for about $130 million in cash. The purchase includes businesses with sales last year of $140 million, including a joint venture in St. Louis. Myers, based in Akron, Ohio, is making the purchase partly to increase its presence in Europe. The Sommer Allibert's unit operates seven plants in France, Britain, Spain and the United States and has a joint venture in China that makes plastic shipping containers. Sommer Allibert makes plastic products, mostly for the auto industry. Myers's stock rose 25 cents, to $22.50.

title: FAIRCHILD SAYS IT WILL BUY REMAINING 15% OF BANNER
description: The Fairchild Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy the remaining 15 percent of Banner Aerospace Inc. that it does not already own for about $40 million in stock. Fairchild, a maker of fasteners for airplane production based in Chantilly, Va., had 1998 sales of $741.2 million. It said it would offer Banner shareholders about $9.75 in Fairchild stock for each common and preferred share. Banner stock rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $9.375, while Fairchild fell 43.75 cents, to $15.0625. Banner, a supplier of aircraft parts based in Dulles, Va., would be merged with a newly formed Fairchild subsidiary.

title: Warhol's 15 Minutes Tick On, in Abstraction Shows
description: The anxiety of influence moves in mysterious ways. Take for example Andy Warhol. As a leading Pop artist, Warhol helped loosen the flood gates of mass culture, washing away Abstract Expressionism. Yet he often worried about being taken seriously as an artist and, for him, serious meant abstraction, the art of his immediate precursors.

title: STOCK OF VALLEY FORGE UP 45% ON NEWS OF PURCHASE DEAL
description: The stock of the Valley Forge Corporation soared 45 percent yesterday after the company, a recreational boating products holding concern, agreed to be acquired by Key Components L.L.C. for $19 a share, or $82.1 million. Key Components, which makes specialty locks and locking systems and flexible metal shaft components, is an affiliate of Millbrook Capital Management Inc., a private investment firm based in Millbrook, N.Y. Valley Forge, based in San Rafael, Calif., had revenue of $82 million in the nine months that ended on Sept. 30. Its shares were up $5.75, to $18.50.

title: Rutgers Prescribes Just the Right Medicine for Its Coach

Less than halfway through the game, while Bannon was feeling much better, Coach Armond Hill of Columbia stalked off the floor to his locker room feeling no less queasy.

title: BACK BAY RESTAURANT TO CONVERT TO PRIVATE OWNERSHIP
description: Back Bay Restaurant Group Inc. of Boston agreed yesterday to be bought by SRC Holdings as Back Bay seeks to convert to private ownership. SRC Holdings was formed by Back Bay's chief executive, Charles F. Sarkis, to buy the company in a transaction worth less than $38 million. Under the agreement, Back Bay shareholders will have the right to receive $10.25 a share for their holdings. Back Bay's shares rose 31.25 cents, to $9.4375. Back Bay owns 34 restaurants in New England, New York, New Jersey and the Washington area.

title: L-3 COMMUNICATIONS IN $65 MILLION DEAL FOR MICRODYNE
description: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Microdyne Corporation for $5 a share, or $65.5 million. L-3 will also assume $24.5 million in debt. Microdyne, an aerospace electronics developer and manufacturer of aerospace electronics, is based in Alexandria, Va. On a pro forma basis, it had revenue of $73.5 million in the year ended Sept. 30. L-3 Communications, based in New York, was created last year from 10 businesses spun off by the Lockheed Martin Corporation. It makes communications systems for the military and other businesses and had sales of $708.3 million in the first nine months of 1998. Shares of Microdyne were up 43.75 cents, to $4.75, while shares of L-3 fell $1.125, to $45.375.

title: ALLIANT FOODSERVICE SAYS IT WILL LAY OFF 1,200 WORKERS
description: Alliant Foodservice Inc., one of the largest closely held United States food service distributors, said yesterday that it would lay off up to 1,200 workers, or 10 percent of its work force, in an attempt to deliver food at ''lower costs and higher value.'' Alliant, based in Deerfield, Ill., said it would provide a package of transition benefits and job placement assistance to the workers. Alliant has 46 distribution centers across the United States and delivers more than one million cases of food and food-related products every day to about 200,000 restaurants, hotels, contract management operations and hospitals. The company expects to have revenues of more than $6 billion in 1998.

But this is no sham. The film (like the play on which it is based) originated as a showcase for the uncanny Jane Horrocks, and she produces these fabulous sounds for real. Ms. Horrocks's phenomenal mimicry of musical grande dames from Marlene Dietrich to Marilyn Monroe, lavishing special loving care on Judy Garland, makes a splendid centerpiece for the otherwise more ordinary film built around it.

title: When Montmartre Was a Hot Spot for the Avant-Garde
description: For a clever young thing in turn-of-the-century Paris, the place to hang out was Montmartre. In its avant-garde heyday, between 1875 and 1905, political dissension prevailed, and far-out journals, exhibitions and festivities flourished, sowing the seeds of Dada, Surrealism and even conceptual art. Montmartre's talented denizens were out to shock the bourgeoisie (of which they themselves were often members). Its cabarets, providing what today we'd call ''alternate spaces'' for the Parisian culturati, promoted poetry, art, performance and musical entertainments. The atmosphere favored fun, free love and fumisme, the knack of knocking establishment norms through satire and practical jokes.

He was 96.

title: Corrections

Dr. Lederman and his colleagues discovered that an elusive subatomic particle known as the neutrino had a cousin, dubbed the ''muon neutrino,'' during experiments in the early 1960's in Upton, N.Y., at the Brookhaven National Laboratory -- not in Batavia, Ill., at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, known as Fermilab.

title: Dr. Arthur Henry Green, 67; Worked With Abused Children

title: Symbols Cast Shadows On Clinton Trip to Gaza

title: Bradley Takes First Step Toward Presidential Race

As of yesterday afternoon, Mr. Bradley was among a half-dozen Democrats who were talking about joining the Presidential hunt next year.

title: The Rural Life; Where Spring Lies Waiting
description: The urge to quarter the year into seasons is nearly irresistible, whether the impulse is astronomical, agricultural, liturgical or fiscal. Instead of inhabiting the undivided plain of time, humans prefer to live in the rooms the seasons make. There is something gratifying about seeing fall, winter, spring and summer, the very idea of seasonality, represented, no matter how -- in a Herrick poem or a Boucher painting or in the stiff vellum pages of a medieval illuminated manuscript. The pleasure is so strong it must be adaptive, a way of preparing a biological affinity in us for what the calendar inevitably holds in store.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRILLICK, BLANCHE ROTH
description: DRILLICK-Blanche Roth. Died in Hackensack, New Jersey, on Thursday, December 3, 1998 of ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease) Blanche, ''Blimi,'' was born, October 9, 1923, in Brooklyn, NY, the youngest of six children of Israel and Hinda Roth. A precocious observer of people and customs, she wrote poetry from childhood onwards. She grew up in a warm family environment, surrounded by her brothers Jack, Bill, Irving and Nat, her sister Reggie and many friends and relatives. The strong memories of these early years are the foundation of the stories she wrote about growing up on 46th Street. She attended PS 169 in Boro Park, Pershing Junior High School and then graduated Summa Cum Laude from New Utrecht High School. Blanche attended Brooklyn College, graduating with a degree in psychology. During WW II, while brothers Nat, Bill & Irving served in the Army, she worked at the Norden Bombsight factory. After the war, she served as a social worker for the American National Red Cross, and then as a field organizer for the Pioneer Women. She married Jacob Drillick in 1948, and was instrumental in the success of Jack's companies, serving as business manager. She lived in London, England during the 1970's and traveled to Israel, Europe, Hawaii and Australia. Blanche was the Coordinator of the Hackensack Municipal Volunteer Corps from 1991 to 1993. She received several awards for this work, including the United to Serve America Diamond Award, and was the subject of an article in the NY Times. In recent years Blanche pursued her lifelong love of writing and painting by attending many shows, workshops and classes. Her work is being published by the family: here is a thought from one of her poems: ''Life is truly beautiful, if one does not forget, To welcome joy unabashed, if one continues, To greet with wonder each dawn.'' She is survived by her children Ira, Anne and David: Ira's wife Barbara and son Benjamin; her brothers Nat and Irving, their wives Harriet and Shirley; her sisters-in-law Anne and Claire, and many loving nieces and nephews. Services are Sunday, Dec 6 1998. Arrival at 10:30 AM at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park St., Hackensack, 201-489-3800. Donations to Kessler Institute-ALS Program, 1199 Pleasant Valley Way West. Orange NJ 07052.

title: Janet Lewis, 99, Poet of Spirit and Keeper of the Hearth, Dies
description: Her first writings to reach print ran shoulder to shoulder with Ernest Hemingway's. For her first published poetry she was grouped with William Carlos Williams and Marianne Moore. She made it to Paris ahead of both Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgerald. She was a leader of the University of Chicago school of imagist poets, and if hers is not a household name, by the time she died on Monday at the age of 99 in the house in Los Altos, Calif., she had occupied for two-thirds of a century, Janet Lewis had the satisfaction of knowing she had written poetry throughout the 20th century and seen it published and praised in every decade since the first.

title: COULTER AND SMITHKLINE IN CANCER DRUG PACT
description: Coulter Pharmaceutical Inc. and SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. have agreed to jointly market Coulter's Bexxar treatment for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. For Coulter, a developer of cancer treatments based in Palo Alto, Calif., the agreement could be worth up to $132 million plus shared profits and royalties. Coulter said that in Phase 3 trials Bexxar had been more effective than conventional chemotherapy in lengthening remissions in non-Hodgkin's lymphoma patients in 78 percent of cases. Phase 3 trials test drugs for safety and efficacy on human subjects. Under the agreement, SmithKline will make an up-front payment of $41.5 million to Coulter. SmithKline will also provide Coulter with a $15 million credit line and make additional payments of as much as $76 million as milestones are reached.
