title: Nairobi Journal; Beer War In Kenya Has Pubs Cheering
description: In 1922 two brothers from England, George and Charles Hurst, started brewing beer here. But they had no name for it. A year later an elephant killed George on a hunting trip. Charles turned tragedy into macabre inspiration: He named the beer Tusker.

title: Tractor-Trailer Accident Delays L.I.R.R. Service
description: Service on the Long Island Rail Road was suspended for an hour yesterday at the height of the afternoon rush after a tractor-trailer became wedged under a railroad trestle in Garden City.

title: A FORMER TOP CHRYSLER EXECUTIVE IS SET TO RETIRE
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. said yesterday that Dennis Pawley, who managed the Chrysler Corporation's worldwide manufacturing, will retire in January. He is the first top Chrysler executive to leave the auto maker since its acquisition last month by Daimler-Benz of Germany. Mr. Pawley, 57, was appointed to the DaimlerChrysler board of management about two weeks ago and was Chrysler's top negotiator with the United Automobile Workers. Mr. Pawley was a likely candidate to direct the bargaining with the union next year. Mr. Pawley said he would pursue a new career as a manufacturing consultant. ''This move has nothing to do with the merger,'' he said.

title: Israel's Ultra-Orthodox Are Losing Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweden Sweeps Opening Matches
description: Davis Cup has long made a habit of transforming mundane encounters into memorable ones, and that habit was not broken in Milan yesterday, which ended with Sweden leading Italy by 2-0 in the Davis Cup final. The nearly five-hour opening match came to a close abruptly and prematurely with Andrea Gaudenzi in great pain and Magnus Norman in great spirits after a 6-7 (9-11), 7-6 (7-0), 4-6, 6-3, 6-6 (30-0) victory.

title: Judged by Its Cover
description: To the Editor:

title: Football Stadium Folly
description: Talk about an offer you can't refuse. The one that Gov. John Rowland of Connecticut made to the owner of the New England Patriots to lure the football team to Hartford was so generous and encompassing as to put the recent sports giveaways in Tampa, Baltimore, St. Louis and Cleveland to shame.

title: JUMP IN NOVEMBER SENT WORK FORCE TO A RECORD HIGH
description: In the midst of a fresh wave of corporate downsizing announcements, the Government reported yesterday that more Americans are working than ever and that the overall economy continued to create jobs at a robust clip.

title: FOOTBALL: COLLEGE ROUNDUP -- SOUTH CAROLINA; Holtz Takes Charge And Vows Improvement
description: Lou Holtz hit South Carolina yesterday flanked by plainclothes security men, greeted by a cheering crowd, and carrying the belief that the same methods that won a national championship at Notre Dame can turn around the worst program in the Southeastern Conference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, ARTHUR
description: GREEN-Arthur. Colleagues, students, fellows and families at Babies & Children's Hospital and the Department of Pediatrics of the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University mourn the loss of Dr. Arthur Green who recently died after eighteen years of devoted service to this hospital. A pioneer in his chosen field, child abuse, Dr. Green was one of the first (and still few) psychiatrists capable of assessing troubled parents, children and their relationships in a psychoanalytically and therapeutically oriented way. A co-founder and medical director of both the Family Center and Therapeutic Nursery at Babies & Childrens Hospital, Dr. Green also (wrote the book) on sexual abuse & was a major respected and innovative clinician, investigator, mentor and teacher nationally, and internationally. He will be missed by his many admirers in Italy, in Croatia, in Holland and in the countries where he conversed fluently, gave unstintingly of himself, worked and played energetically and was ever eager to help a maltreated child regardless of bureaucratic barriers, right up to the final days of his oh-so-full life. John M. Driscoll, Jr., M.D. Reuben S. Carpentier, Professor Director, Pediatrics Service Chairman, Dept. of Pediatrics Nicholas Cunningham, MD, Dr. PH Professor of Clinical Pediatrics and Clinical Public Health Director, Division of General Pediatrics

title: Florida Will Tighten Child Welfare Policies After Father's Killing of Girl, 6
description: Florida child welfare officials plan to revamp workers' training and the way they handle child abuse cases after failing to act on signs of abuse in a 6-year-old girl who was ultimately beaten to death by her father, the secretary of the State Department of Children and Families said today.

title: Officers Cleared in Shooting of Youth Wielding Toy Gun
description: Two police officers who shot and critically wounded a teen-ager who was carrying a water pistol last August acted appropriately, since they mistook the toy for a gun, the Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday.

title: PLUS: COLLEGE SOCCER -- DIVISION I WOMEN; Florida and North Carolina to Meet
description: Florida University and Coach Becky Burleigh made history in women's college soccer by defeating Santa Clara, 1-0, yesterday to advance to the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game.

title: Stocks Rally On Strength Of Jobs Data
description: A unexpected jump in new jobs and an even more surprising drop in the unemployment rate helped stabilize Wall Street and slow the decline in emerging stock markets yesterday.

title: Rita Shugart, 70's Dropout, Wins a Title At Nationals
description: Players of the highest class usually win major titles before they are 30, and sometimes before they are 20. One of the few to hit the headlines later in life is Rita Shugart of Pebble Beach, Calif., who became a life master two decades ago but then devoted herself primarily to her family.

title: Everglades Comeback Threatens Way of Life
description: The way some residents tell it, the area on the edge of the Everglades National Park known as East Everglades can have all the charm of a swamp: flooding, mosquitoes, remoteness. But the same residents describe the bright side of the neighborhood as ''magical'' and ''breathtaking.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBASCH, MURRAY
description: LUBASCH-Murray. On December 3, 1998 at the age of 95. Beloved and devoted husband of Betty for 63 years. Loving father of Arlene and her husband Harry, and of Richard & his wife Lois. Cherished grandfather of Eric, Lisa and Douglas. Also survived by his brother Leroy. Funeral service Sunday, December 6th, Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 12:30 P.M.

title: India's Testing Issue
description: The Hindu nationalists who lead India's Government were trounced in state elections last week because of their failure to deliver on pocketbook economic issues. But the defeats, which weakened their already tenuous grip on power at the national level, are also likely to make it more difficult for them to sign the nuclear test ban treaty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, EDITH
description: MILLER-Edith (nee Goldschmidt) December 4, 1998. Wife of the late Ralph Kurt Miller of Medford, NJ. Daughter of the late Emil and Rosa (nee Eichmann) Goldschmidt, sister of the late Lothar Goldschmidt, aunt of Ralph Miller, dear friend of Suzanne and Stefan Frank & Kim Fendrick. Interment Sunday, 11AM, Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to HIAS, 226 S. 16th Street, Phila. PA., 19102 or OXFAM America, 26 West Street, Boston, MA. 02111.

title: No Banker's Holiday for Europe; With a Jan. 4 Debut for the Euro, the Rush Is On
description: The bank where Salvatore Bellu works is strongest in Italy's dynamic northern industrial belt, filled with mighty little multinationals, like Zanussi and Rex, washing machine makers in Sweden's big Electrolux appliance group. Come January, Electrolux is shifting its business to Europe's new single currency, the euro, and Zanussi and Rex are under orders to do likewise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERESKY, RICHARD ALLEN
description: SHERESKY-Richard Allen. Loving father of Ronnie (George) Igel and Andrew. Devoted son of the late Harry and Rose. Beloved brother of Norman and the late Kenneth and Jackie Gruder. Much loved grandfather of James, Brian, and Johanna Igel. A gentle man. Services Sunday, 11 AM at ''The Riverside,'' Amsterdam & 76 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Dick's name to Cornell University Athletic Department.

title: At Gathering For Williams, The Subject Is Clemens
description: George Steinbrenner likes Roger Clemens, likes his grit, likes the way he tries to intimidate hitters. Steinbrenner acknowledges that the addition of the five-time Cy Young Award winner would improve his team's pitching staff.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIPNISS, RACHEL
description: KIPNISS-Rachel. For 52 years, a personal shopper at Macy's, New York. Beloved aunt of Robert, Betty and Zinna.

description: To the Editor:

title: Space Station's First Construction Crew Lifts Off Aboard the Shuttle
description: The planet's most daring construction job began today as the shuttle Endeavour carried into orbit six astronauts and the first American-built part of an international space station that is expected to cost more than $100 billion.

title: Ellington as a Starting Point
description: There wasn't much hesitation when the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra hit the stage on Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall. The group has been on tour, and groups that tour sound different, assured and ready to prove their points, and the orchestra spent several hours playing hard, authoritative music. By the time it opened the second half, with Duke Ellington's ''Diminuendo and Crescendo in Blue,'' with chorus after chorus of intense, minimalist improvisation by Victor Goines on tenor saxophone, it had arrived at a point reached only by the best bands.

title: Fight City Hall? If You Can Find It; 'Routine' Security
description: To the Editor:

title: CLINTON LAWYERS DEMANDING 3 DAYS FOR HIS DEFENSE
description: With the House Judiciary Committee just a week away from a scheduled vote on articles of impeachment against President Clinton, the White House challenged the panel's inquiry tonight by demanding several days to present a defense that would slow the committee's deliberations.

title: Xerox to Sell Stake in Unit
description: The Xerox Corporation, the world's biggest copier maker, plans to sell a controlling stake in its digital-imaging software unit, Scansoft Inc., to the Visioneer Corporation in a transaction valued at $10.2 million. Xerox is selling a 55 percent stake in Scansoft. Xerox will receive 6.9 million newly issued Visioneer common shares and 3.8 million preferred shares convertible into common stock after two years.

title: Corrections
description: A performance listing in Weekend yesterday with an article about the Met Chamber Ensemble, which is to perform at Carnegie Hall on Sunday at 5 P.M., misstated the telephone number for Carnegie Charge. It is (212) 247-7800.

title: Wounded Hearts Find Each Other
description: When Melissa Hacker was an elementary school girl growing up in New York City, she remembers feeling that her relationship with her mother, Ruth Morley, a successful costume designer for Hollywood films, was different from the relationships other children had with their parents.

title: On Clinton Scandal: No Lack of Outrage
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Bradley Enters the Game
description: Speculation about the next Presidential campaign has already gone on for so long that some citizens may be surprised to learn that Vice President Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas are not already nominated. But although both men would probably like to be selected by pre-emption, there are plenty of other Democrats and Republicans of their generation who are not yet willing to give up their own Oval Office dreams. After two years of rumination, Bill Bradley, the former Democratic Senator from New Jersey, has formed an exploratory committee. The hills of New Hampshire are teeming with Republicans. Lamar Alexander apparently never left.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the pioneering Russian transplant surgeon Vladimir P. Demikhov on Nov. 25 misstated the given name of a Case Western Reserve professor who praised the surgeon's work. He is Dr. Robert J. White, not Richard.

title: GLOBAL MARINE SAID TO SEEK MERGER PARTNERS
description: Global Marine Inc., the largest United States oil drilling contractor, said yesterday that it was aggressively seeking merger partners that could help it remain profitable in a period of low oil prices. Faced with declining revenues, oil companies are merging to cut costs, in part to get big enough so that they can negotiate better prices from drilling equipment and service suppliers like the Houston-based Global Marine. Global Marine, which has a fleet of 31 offshore rigs, estimates it could save about $4 million annually by reducing administrative expenses after a merger, the chief executive, Robert Rose, said.

title: In Mayoral Race in Taipei, Some Politics Is Global
description: In a country that has enjoyed democracy for less than a decade, an epic mayoral battle is being fought here in the capital between two rising political stars. The battle has drawn the attention of Beijing and Washington, where officials worry that the result could upset Taiwan's precarious standoff with mainland China.

title: Both Sides See N.B.A. Season as Ever More Remote
description: Commissioner David Stern wore a look of resignation, saying he had accepted the idea there might not be a basketball season. Billy Hunter, the executive director of the union, rambled on about not accepting a bad deal until he ran out of breath himself.

title: Taking Out the City's Trash
description: When New Jersey's Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, heard this week that New York City was planning to unload a sizable chunk of its garbage on her state in a few years, she did what any politician would do in such a case -- she went ballistic. It was a feeling some New Yorkers understood well.

title: Automaker Is Held Liable In Air-Bag Death of Boy
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan ordered DaimlerChrysler yesterday to pay $750,000 to the estate of a 5-year-old Bronx boy who was killed when an air bag deployed.

title: Salo Like a Sieve in Goal As Islanders Keep Sinking
description: They were the kind of routine shots Tommy Salo allowed to pass into the net with frequency last season. And tonight, three shots, all of which appeared to be stoppable, penetrated the Islanders' goalie in the third period of a 5-1 loss to the Capitals at the M.C.I. Center.

title: Always at Work And Ready to Play
description: In Queensbridge, the section of Long Island City where Ron Artest grew up, not being tough means being run over. Not depending on others can mean not surviving, and the easy road almost always ends in disaster. Through fistfights and athletic competition, those lessons were embedded into Artest's mentality. So excuse him if he expects nothing less than the ultimate effort from himself and his St. John's teammates on the basketball court.

title: Seeking Bombs? No, a Wife, Arab Suspect Tells the F.B.I.
description: The reasons Mamdouh Mahmud Salim gives for coming here a few months ago are at once prosaic and touching: he wanted to buy a Mercedes, and find a wife.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTA, ROBERT J.
description: COSTA-Robert J. at age 34 on December 2, in Manhasset, Long Island. Cherished life companion of Allen J. Pilikian, loving son of John Costa and Alice Tighe, devoted grandson of the late William and Delfina Costa, beloved brother of John Costa Jr., Thomas Costa and Joni DiMuro. A warm and wonderful human being who will be missed by all whom he touched. His battle against his disease was a source of inspiration to all who knew him. He was deeply loved and will be sorely missed. He is with the angels now. His funeral Mass will be held at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Nanuet, N.Y. on Saturday, December 5th at 12 Noon. Interment to follow at Fern Cliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, N.Y. Contributions in his memory should be made to God's Love We Deliver 166 6 Ave. NYC, NY 10013.

title: DiMaggio Marks Day 56 in Hospital
description: For weeks, Joe DiMaggio's longtime friend Morris Engelberg had kiddingly told the Hall of Famer that he must check out of the hospital before 56 days, the magic number of his record hitting streak in 1941.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, LUCY F.
description: DUFFY-Lucy F. Of Yonkers, on December 4, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Loving mother of Terrence, Walter Jr., Raymond, Gerard, Stephen and Joseph Duffy, and Louanne Fitzgerald and Mary DiRuzzo. Cherished sister of Katherine Casey, Terese McArdle and Joan Rhodes. Also survived by twenty grandchildren and one great-grandchild. The family will receive friends at Westchester Funeral Home, Eastchester, on Saturday 7-9PM and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM. A Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, December 7 at 10AM, St. Eugene's Church, Yonkers. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Friends who wish may contribute to the Sisters of Charity, Archdiocese of New York.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Unocal Quits Afghanistan Pipeline Project
description: The Unocal Corporation has withdrawn from a consortium that planned an $8 billion energy pipeline system traversing war-torn Afghanistan, a company official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, WILLIAM J.
description: WALSH-William J. Formerly of Yorkville, on Dec. 4. Beloved husband of the late Anna Savino. Loving father of Patricia (Cookie). Grandfather of Noah and Aidan. Employee of Metropolitan Hospital for over forty years. Known as ''The Mayor of Yorkville,'' a very funny guy who made everyone laugh. Reposing Sunday, Dec. 6, 24 and 7-9 p.m., Hanneman Funeral Home, Nyack, NY. Mass of the Resurrection Monday, Dec. 7, 10 A.M., Sacred Heart Chapel, Rte 340, Sparkill, NY. Interment, Calvary Cemetery, Queens. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Bide-A-Wee Animal Shelter, 410 E. 38 St, NYC 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHBERG, HAROLD
description: ROTHBERG-Harold. On December 3, 1998 of Del Ray Beach, FL and formerly of New Rochelle, NY. Loving and devoted husband of Muriel Wolfsie Rothberg, beloved father of Joan and Diane Rothberg, cherished father-in-law of Steven Segall and Larry Schloff, loving grandfather of Molly Segall, devoted cousin of Lawrence and Shirley Zadanowsky. Services on Sunday, noon, at The Westchester Riverside, 21 W. Broad St., Mount Vernon. In lieu of flowers, contributions to your favorite charity.

title: INSIDE
description: Political Fallout in India

title: Astronauts on Line For Live Discussion
description: Members of the crew of the space shuttle Endeavour will take part in a half-hour live discussion on The New York Times on America Online late tonight.

title: C.I.A. Is Focus of Inquiry in China Rocket Case
description: The Justice Department is investigating whether the Central Intelligence Agency may have obstructed justice by giving an American aerospace concern information about a Congressional inquiry involving that company, Government officials said today.

title: Abandoned, Cargo Ship And Seamen Wait in Gulf
description: A crew of 22 Pakistani seamen aboard a bedraggled and bankrupt cargo ship that fled Mexican waters without food or drinking water has spent 10 days bobbing in the Gulf of Mexico, three and a half miles off South Texas, while bankers, shipping agents and Coast Guard officials try to untangle the mess.

title: Premiums Rising for Individuals
description: Renee Couture earns about $21,000 a year as owner of a struggling Domino's pizza franchise in Danville, Ky. Single, 37, the mother of a 5-year-old daughter, Ms. Couture also has diabetes, though thanks to her health insurance from Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield, she said, ''My diabetes is in the best control it's been in my whole life.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Catalan influence on Ballet Hispanico's current season misstated the publication year of the book ''Bury Me Standing,'' from which the Catalan choreographer Ramon Oller took the title of his new dance about Gypsies. It is 1995, not 1955.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIEG, ROSEMARY M.
description: GRIEG-Rosemary M., died Nov. 30, 1998. Beloved sister of John (Fairfax, VA), daughter of the late John M. and Mary R. Grieg of Chicago. Memorial service at 3PM Saturday, December 5th at Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th St., New York City. Contributions in her memory may be made to The American Cancer Society.

title: THINK TANK; Disinterring Truth in a Dungeon
description: I like to call them ''Hot Docs.'' Every biographer dreams of stumbling upon a private archive of old letters and diaries. Interviews and oral histories are necessary, of course, but notoriously unreliable. A diary entry, a private letter or better yet, a verbatim telephone transcript is like gold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, DOROTHY
description: BERGER-Dorothy. SAR Academy extends condolences to sons Bruce and Miles upon the loss of our friend and supporter. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President

title: Jets' Offense Is Balanced, but What if They Must Change?
description: No matter what, Bill Parcells announced midway through the season when his running game had faltered badly, the Jets will continue running the ball.

title: Britain Joins France's Call for European Force
description: Britain accepted a longstanding French proposal today that calls for the 15-nation European Union to be able to conduct military actions on its own in situations where the United States and other NATO allies do not want to become involved.

title: Girl Awaits Father's 2d Kidney, And Decision by Medical Ethicists
description: Renada Daniel-Patterson's relationship with her father began when she was 13 years old and he called from prison, offering her his kidney.

title: Shares of Ubid Have Strong Trading Debut
description: The on-line auction company Ubid Inc. began trading yesterday, with the shares closing at $48 -- far above the $15 offering price.

title: Reno Leaning Away From Inquiry Into Clinton Advertisements
description: Attorney General Janet Reno is leaning against the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate whether President Clinton and his aides evaded Federal election laws when they directed a multimillion-dollar political advertising campaign in the 1996 election, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: A Drug Maker Is Said to Face A Suit on Prices
description: With the prices of some generic drugs soaring to record levels this year, the Federal Government is preparing to accuse one of the world's largest producers of tripling its prices after trying to corner the market on the drugs' raw materials, lawyers involved in the anti-competition case said today.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY
description: KEEPING JACOB ALIVE

description: To the Editor:

title: Orioles Sign DeShields And Surhoff
description: Intent on keeping the Yankees within sight, even if they need binoculars to do it, the Baltimore Orioles continued scratching and clawing yesterday to put together a starting lineup. They filled two positions in a matter of hours, signing Delino DeShields to play second base and re-signing B. J. Surhoff to play the outfield.

title: The Last Disciples Of Bacchus; In the Bronx, Home Winemaking of a Certain Vintage
description: There are two kinds of home winemakers. There are those who choose to make wine. And there are those who can't help themselves.

title: The Mama's Boy, His Motel Guest And That Shower
description: Gus Van Sant's new color replica of ''Psycho'' opened without advance screenings yesterday, adopting Alfred Hitchcock's policy of dodging reviews but neglecting some of his other, even better marketing ideas. There was a time when no one could enter a theater playing ''Psycho'' after the film had started. Today's audiences can traipse freely, and at the theater I attended somebody even made a loud cellular phone call just as the rest of us were bracing ourselves for the shower scene. Anyway, the film's main suspense revolved around a single question: now that room rent at the Bates Motel is up to $36.50, what else is new?

title: State Panel May Disappoint Police on Pay, Experts Say
description: For years, the police union in New York City has pushed a proposal that would allow it to take its contract disputes to a state panel, where union leaders hope to win large raises for city police officers.

title: White House May Get Time
description: Henry J. Hyde said he would try to accommodate a White House request for more time to present witnesses in the impeachment inquiry. Page 33.

title: American Crafts Take the Spotlight Again in New Haven
description: THIS year is different. ''This is the most colorful show we've ever had,'' said Bob Arnstein, chairman of the selection and display committee of the ''30th annual celebration of American crafts'' at the Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HARLIN C.
description: SCHWARTZ-Harlin C. November 2, 1929-December 7, 1984. Forever in our hearts. The family

title: For Game Shows, Fewer and Fewer Winners
description: TELEVISION for $200, Alex: Whatever happened to game shows? Baby boomers of a certain age may fondly recall when daytime television was a wall-to-wall orgy of game shows and a day off from school meant a wallow in them, from ''Concentration'' in the morning through ''The Match Game'' late in the afternoon. But the game show -- a network staple since radio days -- has largely disappeared from broadcast television, save for three long-running hits: ''Wheel of Fortune,'' ''Jeopardy!'' and ''The Price Is Right.''

title: No-Risk Wish Lists
description: Who needs to send letters to Santa? Junior giftees can now bypass the tubby middleman in the red suit and register with retailers directly. At large chains like Toys ''R'' Us, which has 18,205 children on its Manhattan list, and boutiques like Marsha D.D. on the Upper East Side, children are preselecting toys and clothes, leaving nothing to chance. ''We get lots of uncles in here wondering about the perfect gift,'' said Chris Retmeir, the owner of Geppetto's Toy Box, on Seventh Avenue. Here are some frequently requested registry items.

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Nov. 22 about train travel in Japan misstated a comparison in illustrating the value of a Japan Rail Pass. The pass is slightly more expensive than a round-trip express ticket between Tokyo and Kyoto, not a one-way ticket.

title: Albert Gore Sr., Father of the Vice President, Dies at 90
description: Former Senator Albert Gore Sr., the father of the Vice President and a longtime powerful figure in the Democratic Party, died yesterday at his home in Carthage, Tenn., three weeks before his 91st birthday, the White House said.

title: Editorial Observer; Chop! Slash! 'Psycho' Is Back, in Dying Color
description: For a Hollywood studio, redoing a classic is always a risk. For Universal Pictures, troubled by a recent series of flops, remaking ''Psycho'' was risky, and weird. After all, Gus Van Sant, the versatile director of ''Good Will Hunting,'' has not merely remade Alfred Hitchcock's 1960 thriller. He has replicated it shot for shot, using the same script, the same mesmerizing score by Bernard Herrmann and the same Saul Bass titles. The only significant difference besides casting is that the new movie is in color rather than black and white.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENKIN, IDA
description: HENKIN-Ida, 89. Died November 25 of advanced age in Bethesda, MD. Mother of David, Laurel, MD; and Charles, Arlington, VA; sister of Dr. Harry Levine, Mrs. Yetta Mayer, Mrs. Ben Rothstein, Mr. George Lawson; grandmother; educator; dear friend. Preceded in death by father Isaac Levine, mother Anna Levine, husband Samuel, brother Isidore, and sister Dora. Ida was a beloved elementary school teacher in Long Beach from 1935 until 1970, and an educator at the collegiate level thereafter. Services were conducted on November 27 at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Rockville Centre, and interment was at Mount Ararat cemetery.

title: The Military-Technological Complex Is Thriving in Israel
description: YOUNG soldiers with automatic rifles slung across their backs are a familiar sight here, defending the country's borders, boundaries and bus stops. With few exceptions, mainly for medical or religious reasons, conscription at age 18 is universal, and almost all Israelis serve a term in the Israel Defense Forces.

title: The Nation; Finding a Common Foe, Fringe Groups Join Forces
description: FRUSTRATED and embittered by their failure to stop abortions -- and by a Federal law protecting clinics -- fringes of the anti-abortion movement are linking up with a new ally: the right-wing militia movement.

title: POSTINGS: Survey Compares Price Medians of Co-ops and Condos; Condo Premium: 4% to 47%
description: Yes, condominiums generally command higher prices than co-ops. But not always. And depending on many factors, the median price premium can vary sharply -- from 4 percent for some prewar condominiums to 47 percent for some studio units.

title: Notable Books of 1998
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Holiday Books issue of December 1997. It is meant to suggest some of the high points in this year's fiction, poetry, nonfiction, children's books, mysteries and science fiction. The books are arranged alphabetically under genre headings. The complete reviews of these books may be found at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.

title: With Tables Turned, Devils Surge Past Isles
description: When the Islanders and Devils last played, the teams were headed in distinctly different directions. The Islanders were riding a wave of a few surprising victories while the Devils were struggling to stay afloat.

title: Keeping Walgreens on Main St.
description: WHEN L. Daniel Jorndt, the chief executive of the Walgreen Company, wanted to know how big the parking lot was at a rival Wal-Mart store, he had a look for himself.

title: Tenants in S.R.O. Hotel Were Offered a Good Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Warm and Welcoming
description: I CALL Mia Sorella Ristorante for directions, and a young man named Anthony di Aniello carefully tells me how to get there. He seems excited that I want to make the trip and assures me that the meal will be worth it. Because I've heard that Mia Sorella is an intimate, mom-and-pop Italian restaurant with homemade everything, I cannot get into the car fast enough.

title: Guess Who'll Be Jamming. Just Guess.
description: SHE'S a Mystery to Me'' is an old Roy Orbison song, but it could just as well be the theme for the state's rock-and-roll fans as they await word on who may show up at next weekend's traditional Christmastime benefit show.

title: The Poet as Working Stiff
description: CERTAIN poets are associated with particular places: Walt Whitman with Camden, William Carlos Williams with Rutherford, Allen Ginsberg with Paterson. Joe Weil is Elizabeth: working-class, irreverent, modest, but open to the world and filled with a wealth of possibilities.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: Once upon a time, Apple was an insider's insider. His Ivy League degree, bigtime newspaper job and Georgetown address were his passport to tony dos. But alas. Clinton (the Fan) came to town. Celebrities poured in, poisoning the Potomac.

title: The Bubble Is Back, Compliments Of the Fed
description: THIS has been a very strange year. Consider these events:

title: When an Old Wine Is Not Always a Keeper
description: I RECENTLY had the opportunity to try a 1966 Chianti. This tasting of aged wine came about not as a result of a careful purchase 30-odd years ago, or out of a sense of exploration or because I hopped in a Tardis with Dr. Who for some oenological time travel. To be honest, I was not all that thrilled with the prospect of tasting this wine, but it is a dirty job and someone has to do it.

title: Children's Books
description: POPPA'S ITCHY CHRISTMAS By Angela Shelf Medearis. Illustrated by John Ward. Holiday House, $15.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, DOROTHY
description: BERGER-Dorothy. The Trustees and staff of the Riverdale YMYWHA extend our heartfelt condolences to our Vice President, Bruce Berger and his family on the death of their mother and grandmother Dorothy. May the entire Berger family be spared further sorrow. Jeffrey A. Moerdler, President Harry M. Feder, Chairman of the Board Diane Rubin, Exec. Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOYER, KERRY
description: MOYER-Kerry. Age 41, of Manhattan. Beloved son of Grace Moyer of Reading, PA, and the late Leonard Lecce; brother of Lenora. Penn State and Parsons ('79). His talent for design -from a tycoon's Mexican Shangri-la to smart Park Avenue addresses and outlandish Pines parties -was matched by his capacity to love. He never met a room he couldn't make fabulous, if just by walking in. Visiting today, 5-8 PM, Redden's, 324 W. 14 St. Service Monday, 10:30 AM, St. Luke-in-theFields, 487 Hudson St. Contributions to Friends In Deed, 925-2009.

title: Fighting for Jacob
description: Jordana and Richard Sontag were speeding toward Yale University, angry, desperate, ready to unleash their secret weapon, which they had carefully loaded into the back of their Grand Cherokee. For a year, they had done everything in their power to save their dying baby boy, Jacob. The well-to-do young couple and relatives had donated more than $200,000 to Yale to underwrite experimental gene-therapy research aimed at curing the rare genetic disease that plagued Jacob. They had helped pay to bring two leading researchers from the other side of the world to Yale and to transport from a lab in Germany the precious concoction of healthy genes that might save their son and a dozen other dying children with Canavan disease. They had hired lawyers and enlisted United States Senators to lobby the medical oversight committees for approval of the experimental procedure.

title: President Who Was Forced From Job at Adelphi Is Hired at Boston University
description: Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos, who was forced out as president of Adelphi University last year over issues of excessive compensation and mismanagement, has been hired as a special assistant to the president of Boston University.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 1 about Nathaniel Hawthorne's Rome referred imprecisely to admission policies at the National Gallery of Ancient Art in the Barberini Palace. Free admission for visitors under 18 and over 60 is limited to those from countries that have the necessary agreements with the Italian Government; it is not free to everyone in those age groups. Americans, for example, do not qualify. A reader's letter received Nov. 17 pointed out the error.

title: Nov. 29-Dec. 5; New Jersey Sniffs At New York's Garbage
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has always dealt with New York City's problems with elegant simplicity. Pedestrians getting in the way of cars? Reroute the pedestrians. Too many potholes? Well, fill them. No place to put the city's garbage? Send it to New Jersey. It would presumably have violated the spirit of simplicity, though, to check to see if New Jersey actually wanted it. So when Gov. Christine Todd Whitman got a whiff of Mr. Giuliani's malodorous offering, she responded with Giulianian simplicity: ''Drop dead.'' HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Finessing Your Freedom
description: Q. I'm a part-time contractor at a high-technology company. Recently, my supervisor asked if I would be interested in a full-time job, at less pay per hour but with stock options and other benefits. The truth is that I'm not interested -- I like the freedom and my current pay -- but I worry that if I reject his offer, he'll replace me with someone committed to the long haul. Any negotiating suggestions?

title: Roman Roost for the Rich and Famous
description: ROME has seven hills, and from the best rooms at the Hassler Hotel, which sits gloriously at the top of the Spanish Steps, the panorama includes not only two of them -- the Aventine and the Quirinale -- but also the Piazza di Spagna, St. Peter's and the Pantheon.

title: Gambling Becomes the Talk of a Campus
description: It is reading week, the week before exams, and the students at Northwestern University are actually reading.

title: Plummer Is Blazing Own Comeback Trail
description: The Arizona Cardinals' publicity staff has begun to compile a list of ''Jake Plummer Game-Saving Comebacks.'' It's the sort of thing done for a Joe Montana or a John Elway, but in only 19 National Football League starts -- Sunday's game with the Giants will be his 20th -- Plummer has already brought the Cardinals from behind in the fourth quarter seven times.

title: In America; Justice Betrayed
description: Most of the suspects hauled into the treacherous confines of the criminal justice system are guilty. They are not all treated fairly, but for the most part they have committed the crimes for which they are prosecuted.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-21

title: New Yorkers Rush to Invest In College Plan
description: When state officials announced the creation of New York's College Savings Program in September to help parents pay for their children's educations, it sounded like a narrow -- if nice -- election year initiative.

title: Yes, Virginia, There Is a Space-Time Wave
description: THE PHYSICS OF CHRISTMAS From the Aerodynamics of Reindeer to the Thermodynamics of Turkey. By Roger Highfield. 293 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $20.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a cooperative program involving a Jewish geriatric center and a Roman Catholic hospice misspelled the name of a counselor for the program. He is Rabbi Zev Schostak, not Shostak.

title: Bruges -- Ralph Lauren amid the canals at a family-run hotel
description: Bruges, Belgium's medieval showplace, is awash in charming small hotels. Of the more than 20 that have four stars in the national rating system (five is highest), the Pandhotel is a standout. In November, my wife, Helen, and I made our way to our junior suite by means of two miniature elevators, fitted into the stairwells of the two adjoining houses that make up the hotel. Room 108, one of six newly created junior suites (there is a sitting area in the room), is done in gold-tinged beige damask, used with abandon for bedspread, curtains and the four-poster bed. The hotel's decor could perhaps best be described as eclectic coziness. A partial inventory of more than a dozen artifacts in our room included a 19th-century traveling escritoire, a dressmaker's dummy, a large wooden shop sign in the shape of an Elgin watch face and the ''Summa Theologica'' of Thomas Aquinas in eight volumes. Our small, modern bathroom had two marble sinks and a tub with a hand-held shower.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: As a part-time professional, recently retired from full-time motherhood, I'd like to believe that stay-at-home moms actually have the status and respect that Amy Finnerty's ''Stay-at-Home Mom'' asserts. My own experience suggests otherwise. Two years ago, while putting my 8-year-old daughter to bed, she turned her sweet, soap-scrubbed face to me and asked, ''Mommy, are you smart?'' Undoubtedly, she was comparing my accomplishments to those of her father, a physician. Daddy goes forth each day to heal the sick, while Mom stays behind to heat the roast.

title: Two Attacks Cause Worry To the Critics Of Iran Rulers
description: An attack on visiting American businessmen and the assassination of a prominent dissident here have caused fresh unease among critics of the Government, who say they fear a campaign of violence by conservative forces.

title: A Passion For Things Mexican
description: For most of her life, Dina Leor-Isaacson has had an unyielding passion for Mexican culture. Her two-week-old store, La Sirena, at 107 Avenue B (near Seventh Street) is only the latest incarnation of her enthusiasm.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Sports of The Times; Will Bills Secede From the No-Replay Nine?
description: THEY'RE the No-Replay Nine -- the nine National Football League clubs that voted ''no'' last March on reinstalling instant replay as an officiating tool. But now Ralph Wilson, the owner of the Buffalo Bills, already annoyed at Commissioner Paul Tagliabue's intention to fine him $50,000 for critical comments about officiating, is leaning toward voting for instant replay next season.

title: Gardening
description: Judging from the pile of gardening books at my feet, this is the season, or so publishers believe, when gardeners throw off the petty restraints of practicality -- considerations like time, money and space -- and unstay their imaginations. A gardener is always trying to steep himself in the moment and to read the year ahead as well. But the snowdrops are still very distant this month, too far away to anticipate, and the midwinter moment is dark and uninspiring. So instead of pretending to find salvation in seed catalogues, instead of staring at the iced-over brush pile that will neither compost nor burn, instead of refining the pencil scratchings that pass for garden plans, why not open a book and transport yourself to a softer hardiness zone, where gardens are as extensive as the mind and labor is as cheap as thought?

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: Michael Sean Winters's ''Heavenly Cuff Links'' evoked fond memories. The young priests who sported these signs of status in the lively 60's knew the path to power and followed it.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: Sara Mosle's Lives column, ''The Importance of Being Busy,'' reminded me of an episode I once had in Los Angeles. My best friend in college, now a lawyer, had invited me to a dinner party. That afternoon, he showed up at my apartment looking for a lasagna dish. On the way out the door, he casually mentioned that his place couldn't accommodate all of his guests and therefore he was disinviting me. Since I was one of his closest friends, he was sure I would understand.

description: DAVIDSON-Dan. The friends and neighbors of Dan Davidson at Harbour House wish to express our sorrow at his passing. Our sympathy to Irma and the entire family. Harbour House

description: EXPLORERS are still arriving along the northeast coast of Florida. Ponce de Leon was looking for the Fountain of Youth when he reached what is now St. Augustine in 1513. He didn't discover it -- but maybe Nobuko Koop has come as close as anyone will.

description: ONE friend described Noah Nicholas Emmerich as so likable he could ''charm a bird down from a tree.'' Others added that he was funny, freckled and generally larger than life.

title: At Former Strip Club, Black Culture May Take the Stage
description: The windows in the hulking building on Flatbush Avenue Extension were once walled off, back when it housed Steam Heat, an all-nude nightclub that closed in the summer of 1996 after a lengthy legal battle. Now Carlos E. Russell, a former Brooklyn College dean, has unblocked the windows in his effort to turn the former home of the strip joint into a cultural center.

title: Children's Books
description: THE CHRISTMAS CROCODILE By Bonny Becker. Illustrated by David Small. Unpaged. New York: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers. $16. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: A Blessing and a Curse: Life Without Overtime
description: NOW that his weekends are suddenly free, Ronald L. Grissom is not sure how to spend the idle time. He slept a lot on that first free weekend, in November, and he and his wife, Stephanie, decorated the Christmas tree last weekend. They have been talking about the various movies they would like to see, and if the weather stays warm they will probably go bicycling in the flat, open countryside.

title: 'In Sam We Trust'
description: To the Editor:

title: Christmas Plans
description: TAKE advantage of mild weather to continue watering and cleaning up, but don't overdo tidiness. Foliage that is not diseased will protect crowns of herbaceous perennials in winter.

title: POSTINGS: $20 Million, 12-Story, 68-Unit Condominium; New TriBeCa Building Resembles Neighbors
description: Passers-by just may wonder, come the spring of 2000, whether the new building on Hubert Street in downtown Manhattan hasn't, in fact, been there for decades.

title: No Thanks
description: To the Editor: Regarding the V.A.T.-refund letters you have published in recent weeks from travelers who get the runaround from European functionaries in charge of the V.A.T. information -- functionaries who are obnoxious, indifferent, absent, irritated or simply will not speak any language other than a local dialect: I certainly have something to add.

title: Rightness of Freedom From School Taxes
description: Governor Pataki's Star Program, whereby homeowners over age 65 with an income under $60,000 reap savings of up to 40 percent on their school tax bills, is landmark legislation. On Long Island, where taxes are the highest in the state, the ramifications assume gigantic proportions.

title: Nov. 29-Dec. 5; Ickes Put on Hold
description: Harold M. Ickes, the combative former top Clinton aide, will have to wait to find out whether Attorney General Janet Reno will request an independent counsel to investigate him. Undecided on the final day of a three-month inquiry, Ms. Reno announced that she had obtained a 60-day extension.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINOR, MILLER G.
description: MINOR-Miller G. On November 26, 1998. Husband of Lorna. Father of Michael, Marianne and Martin. Grandfather of Zachary. Brother of Joyce Jenkins. Memorial service December 19 at Community Unitarian Church, White Plains.

title: Since 1987, the Bus Stops Here
description: At Bus World, a modest, two-story hotel, restaurant and bus repair depot perched on the marshes three miles from the Boardwalk, every day is a busman's holiday.

title: Towns Turn to Art To Help Downtowns
description: CAN mom and pop be saved by the arts? A growing number of communities think so and are altering zoning rules to allow the formation of arts districts downtown to fill vacant space and spur business.

title: Second Straight Title for Morristown
description: On a weekend that was supposed to showcase the top high school football teams in New Jersey, only four of six state championship games at Giants Stadium were even competitive.

title: O.K., So Don't Clap
description: STRANGE AND

title: SOAPBOX; You Row in That?
description: THE Passaic River is messing with my head. And my relationship with my wife. She's not just miffed with my rowing and my early morning departures, but also with the aroma I leave behind in the Taurus. In better moments, she puts up with it. In worse, my continuing to scull is threatened.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: If your special issue (Nov. 15) is to be believed, status still depends on birth. At the top of nearly every heap you describe -- gamblers, fighter pilots, Arab immigrants, priests, Talmudic scholars, tribal dancers or truck drivers -- stands a guy. If we're lucky, those of us lacking Y chromosomes can serve as status symbols, but rarely, it seems can we attain status on our own merits. It must be reassuring to stay-at-home moms and networked secretaries to know that they symbolize cachet about as well as beachfront property or a valid driver's license.

title: Renaissance, Vegas Style
description: The current growth spurt in Las Vegas -- a crop of new hotels costing a total of more than $5 billion -- represents one of the largest city-building exercises in history, and it's happening at hyperspeed. Bellagio, a 3,000-room homage to Lake Como in Italy, opened in October. Coming next spring is Mandalay Bay, followed by a pair of city replicas, Paris and the Venetian. The new upscale Vegas is being built by a teeming army of construction workers and artisans: painters, sculptors and miniaturists are combining ancient techniques with high-volume manufacturing methods. To some, a casino reproduction of Paris may sound like City of Lite. But the giddy audacity of Las Vegas's mimicry makes it an expression of human ambition that transcends imitation. Here's a look.

title: Hanukkah in Lights
description: Winter Wonderlands are in full animated cry in department store windows. In West Orange, the same sort of displays will be entertaining children at a Hanukkah Wonderland. Among the scenes will be the ancient Syrians oppressing Jews observing their religion, the Maccabees waging war against the much stronger Syrian Army and the lighting of the menorah in the ruined Temple. There will also be an eight-foot-high walk-in dreidel, a demonstration of olive pressing to produce the oil used to light the ancient menorah, a ''Torah Concentration'' game show and a crafts workshop. The Hanukkah Wonderland, a project of the Rabbinical College of America, which is in Morristown, and J.C.C. Metro West, takes place at 160 Northfield Avenue, West Orange. Admission is $4 a person or $18 for a family. It is open next Sunday, and Dec. 17 and 20 from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. It is open for groups between next Sunday and Dec. 21 by reservation at (973) 829-0856.

title: Nov. 29-Dec. 5; An Indulgent Pope
description: For the year 2000, Pope John Paul II has introduced a fast track to heaven. Throughout the yearlong millennium celebration, Roman Catholics who quit smoking or drinking for a day can earn indulgences to avoid punishment in the hereafter.

title: A Shifting American Landscape; In the Heartland, A Cornucopia Of Culture
description: WHEN Richard Nixon asked, ''Will it play in Peoria?'' he was taking the nation's temperature, checking on the predilections of mainstream citizens. But he was also reviving an adage from the early part of the century, when this city was a center of whisky production and an active vaudeville circuit stop, and the farm folks were renowned as a particularly dour and tough-to-please audience.

title: An Abundance of Song
description: SINGING ensembles are hoping for the pleasure of audience attention today. At 2 o'clock, the East Haven High School Choir joins the Connecticut Chamber Orchestra in the school's auditorium, the music directors Judy Webber and Sayard Stone sharing the podium.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 22 about new art galleries on 14th Street between 9th and 10th Avenues misidentified the first one to open there. It was the Earl, in 1996; Au Bas opened last year.

title: Squabbling, Spaniards Mark 20th Birthday of Their Constitution
description: Spain's celebration this week of the 20th anniversary of its Constitution was supposed to be a big congratulatory moment to mark the longest period of democracy in the nation's history.

title: First Woman, Then Baby Make Landing at Kennedy
description: A Nigerian woman seven and a half months pregnant went into labor on a flight from Ghana to New York yesterday, but the pilots radioed ahead and two Port Authority police officers rushed on board when the plane landed at Kennedy International Airport and helped deliver a healthy baby girl in coach class.

description: Best Bet

title: Rebuilding Honduras
description: In Orocuina, a town just south of the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa, a woman bathes two children in a shallow pool of water. They are surrounded by an enormous, mostly empty bed of gravel that was once the Choluteca River, the heart of a fertile valley. Downstream, the water has been poisoned by effluent from a destroyed fertilizer plant. The woman looks at me somewhat oddly. Then she asks if I'm Chinese. (My father is Irish. My mother is Dutch.) She has heard that the Chinese are coming to help. In nearby Choluteca, Soledad Selaya and her family have already shoveled tons of mud from their home. Enough earth has been hauled from the narrow streets to create a new nation. And in a way, that is just what has happened.

title: A Filmmaker's Duty: To Document Her Homeland
description: EARLY in the spring of 1992, when lining up at the gas pumps was a weekly ritual of life in the newly non-Soviet Russia, the documentary filmmaker Marina Goldovskaya decided to take advantage of the two-hour wait at a Moscow station. She stepped out of her car, lifted her Super VHS camera onto her right shoulder and began shooting video for her latest work, ''The Shattered Mirror: Journal of a Time of Trouble.'' Turning toward a man waiting his turn in a blue Zhugili sedan, she kept her camera rolling as he called out his window.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLET, VERA V. (HANSON)
description: BERLET-Vera V. (Hanson) Died Nov 21, 1998. Born Sleepy Eye, MN 11/17/13. Writer, antique dealer. Wife of the late Lt. Col. George N. Berlet, Jr. of Paterson, NJ. For info call Chip Berlet: 617-661-9313

title: Musically, the Twain Meet, in Vietnam
description: THE twain met here last month, when the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, the conductorless ensemble from New York, performed at the Hanoi Opera House. Orpheus, which plays on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall, was the first professional American orchestra to appear in this country since the Vietnam War ended in 1975. The two sold-out concerts were glittering affairs, attended by culture-starved expatriates and curious Vietnamese, turned out in their dressiest Western-style clothes. Even Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, the revered former commander of the Vietnamese army, who led his forces to victory over both France and the United States-backed regime in Saigon, was in the audience on opening night.

title: College-Ready Students Seek Exam Options
description: FOR as long as she can remember, Carrie Johnson wanted to go to Elon College, a small selective school in Elon, N.C. As a student at Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua, she took the SAT I, the reasoning test of the Scholastic Assessment Tests, and applied early to her first-choice school.

description: FIALKOV-Elaine. Beloved wife of Herman and devoted mother of Carol and Richard Kopelman and Jay and Claire Fialkov. Cherished grandmother of Joshua (Rena) and Michael Kopelman and David and Emma Fialkov. Services Sunday, 1 PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: So Long, Chrysler. It's Been Fun.
description: THE courtship was a whirlwind. The German-American nuptials were lavish. And, for now, DaimlerChrysler A.G. appears to be in wedded bliss.

title: FILM; Tabloid Stars of Another Century
description: SIX strapping men are pulling a black-topped carriage down a narrow cobblestone street on the Left Bank here. No need for horses, since the camera is tightly focused on the coach window. For the 10th time, Juliette Binoche gazes distractedly outside, barely listening to the stout gentleman with the long sideburns seated next to her.

title: County Seeks Ways To Harvest Methane Gas At Landfill
description: WHAT Westchester does for today's garbage it also wants to do for the garbage of yesteryear: use it as fuel. Westchester officials are exploring ways to harvest the methane gas created by decaying garbage at the former Croton Point landfill, long the dumping ground for all of the county's garbage. That was until it was closed, capped and became a park about five years ago. Now the gas is simply burned.

title: Word & Image; Let's Be Chromatically Correct
description: Americans who are simplistically called people of color seem to have had none of the difficulty felt by the allegedly uncolored in absorbing the evidence that Thomas Jefferson sired at least one of Sally Hemings's children. ''Everybody knew that already,'' Fareed Thomas told a Times reporter, referring to his like-minded African-American classmates in a Los Angeles high school.

title: The Moves Of a Jazz Contrarian
description: ONE of the best jazz records of 1998 dares you, at first glance and listen, to take it seriously. Sold in stores at a budget price, the alto saxophonist Greg Osby's ''Banned in New York'' is a live recording with one original tune and a few standards, and aside from a little professional editing, it was made for about $7. The music was captured on a small minidisk recorder over the course of a few nights last winter at Sweet Basil, a Manhattan club, with a single microphone placed in front of the stage. As you might expect, the drums sound a little too loud, the piano a little too soft.

title: North Korean Nuclear Arms Pact Reported Near Breakdown
description: With North Korea refusing to allow inspection of a huge underground construction site that could be used to hide a nuclear reactor, Clinton Administration officials acknowledge that a four-year-old agreement meant to freeze North Korean's nuclear weapons program could collapse within weeks.

title: Richard Furman, Michele Silverstein
description: Dr. Michele Karen Silverstein and Dr. Richard Raymond Furman are to be married today at the Woodbury (N.Y.) Jewish Center. Rabbi Lewis Barth, a cousin of the bride, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEIGER, RICHARD L., 81, (CAPTAIN, USN RET.)
description: GEIGER-Richard L., 81, (Captain, USN Ret.), died peacefully on November 29, 1998. Burial will be at Arlington National Cemetery, December 10, 3PM. Devoted husband of the late Emmy Lou, father of James and Ellen, an exemplary husband and father. A native New Yorker and graduate of CUNY and NYU, he saw action during WWII at Pearl Harbor. A partner in the venture capital firm Geiger & Fialkov, he helped to found Microsemi, Inc. and served as Chairma of the Board for many years. Their endownment at the Polytechnic University in Brooklyn funds scholarships for deserving engineering students. A memorial service will be held in January. A quiet but loving man, he will be dearly missed.

title: Fresh Faces, Familiar Names
description: FOR the Italian actor Alessandro Gassman, taking the lead role in ''Steam: The Turkish Bath'' was the riskiest -- and maybe the smartest -- move of his career. Mr. Gassman plays a married Italian designer who goes to Istanbul to take care of his aunt's estate. While there, he discovers the enticing culture of the Turkish bath -- and with it, the realization that he is gay.

title: Sewer-Repair Financing Rejected
description: A PLAN by the county to spend $39 million to repair its leaky sewers was dealt a setback last week when Republicans on the Board of Legislators refused to go along with a financing proposal from County Executive Andrew J. Spano, a Democrat.

title: A Census Man Retires After 6 Decades (but Who's Counting)
description: Milton Kaufman never planned on a Government career when he was growing up in Coney Island in the 1920's. Working at Steeplechase amusement park, he dreamed of becoming a mathematics teacher. But after he graduated from the City University of New York with a master's degree in mathematics in 1933, the Government was the only place hiring. Schools could not afford to hire new teachers in the Depression.

description: Pure political Scarlett O'Hara, Barbara Russell could not immediately say how many Presidential hopefuls have recently asked her on the equivalent of a date, seeking the support she might deign to cast their way as assistant chairwoman of New Hampshire's Republican State Committee.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: Your status issue was splendid. Just the right tone and combination of irony, humor and facts. For an inveterate reader of The Times like myself, I still feel, however, that the ultimate status remains having one's letter published in the magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUSSBAUM, SAMUEL
description: NUSSBAUM-Samuel. Of Monsey, New York, widowed, father of Jack Nussbaum and Meir Nussbaum. Beloved grandfather and great-grandfather. Mr. Nussbaum was involved in numerous philanthropic organizations. He was the founder and president of Kupat Ezra of Monsey. He was also the founder of the Monsey Food Coop. Services 11 AM today at Community Synagogue, 89 W. Maple Ave., Monsey, NY.

title: In Their Element: Schoolroom Scientists Compete
description: THE last i is dotted, the final formula checked, the entry forms completed. Now hundreds of Long Island high school seniors who met Wednesday's deadline to enter this year's Intel Science Talent Search are holding their breath and waiting for good news.

title: McCarter Theater Getting A $3.5 Million Gift
description: It's no news that the McCarter Theater keeps making theater news. Last Thursday's Broadway opening of Sophocles's ''Electra'' is the latest Princeton import to enhance the New York theater season.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BALLAS, LILA
description: BALLAS-Lila. December 6, 1997. In loving memory. Dearest Mom, it's been a year since you left us. We all miss your sunny presence, especially now around the holidays. Your bright spirit still lives on, guiding us and helping us take pride in our achievements. You will live in our hearts forever. Your loving children, Dianne, Ginny and the two Lennys

description: The United States and 32 other countries concluded four days of arms control meetings here with a public commitment to exercise ''maximum restraint'' before selling weapons to regions of conflict.

description: Judith Kelly Dempsey says she is already worn out.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: My ride of choice is a muscular, black Ford F-150 with a full-size bed and eight growling cylinders under the hood (Culture Zone: ''Hauling Your Cool Around,'' by Lesley Hazleton). It is the coolest beast on the street.

title: An Appreciation of Cute Finds a Niche in High Art
description: KNOWN to American television viewers as Astro Boy, Tetsuwan Atom was one of the earliest icons of cuteness in Japan, a country preoccupied with youthful paraphernalia. The wide-eyed robot with a nuclear-reactor heart and rockets in his feet launched Japan's first animated television show in the 1960's. Atom was created by the comic-book artist Osamu Tezuka, and he spent each episode battling evil robots and supernatural phenomena that threatened to wipe out the human race.

title: North Fork Duck Farmer Holds His Ground
description: SURVIVING as a duck farmer in the suburbs isn't easy.

title: Nov. 29-Dec. 5; Time Out in Quebec
description: It may be just a temporary truce, but Quebec and the rest of Canada are looking forward to a respite from 30 years of rancor and uncertainty caused by the predominately French-speaking province's struggle for independence. Lucien Bouchard, the separatist Premier, who was re-elected with a disappointing level of popular support last week, put off a third referendum on secession until at least the second half of his five-year term. ANTHONY DePALMA

title: Miss Zamansky And Mr. Arora
description: Martine Zamansky and Pankaj Arora are to be married today at the Jewel of India, a restaurant in Manhattan. Rabbi Charles Davidson will officiate, and Pandit Mahesh Shastri will perform a Hindu wedding ritual.

title: More Bad News, but Few Losses, for the 49ers
description: One moment, San Francisco 49ers tackle Bryant Young was arguably the best defensive player in football; the next, after a brutal collision with a teammate, he was in the back of an ambulance, speeding toward Stanford Hospital with two broken bones in his lower right leg and damaged knee ligaments. By his side was the 49ers' owner, Eddie DeBartolo, holding Young's hand, telling him everything would be all right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODS, GERTRUDE B.
description: WOODS-Gertrude B. The family of Gaby Woods grieves for the loss of this devoted wife, mother and grandmother. Her many friends remember her honesty and zest for living. Gaby showed special courage in her final year, when she gallantly withstood cancer until finally succumbing on December 4, at age 71. She was a loving wife to William, devoted mother to Michael, sympathetic mother-in-law to Lois, and delighted grandmother of Tyler and Christopher. We miss her deeply.

title: Oil Is Down, but Don't Count It Out
description: THE world of oil may appear to be falling apart, but in oil things are never quite as bad or as good as they seem. Huge mergers have thrown the industry into confusion as oil prices have dipped to historic bottoms. Yet, if history is any guide, investors who write off energy will miss opportunities.

title: Endless Compost? Some Cures for Slowpoke Piles
description: IN the 1970's, composting was all the rage, an earth-friendly way to get rid of ''garbage'' and to create a material in which plants would revel. Lots of people took up the cause, and lots of them stopped doing it. True, composting is a natural, self-regulating process, bound to succeed. Even so, problems sometimes arise along the way.

title: Last Rebels In Cambodia Send Message Of Surrender
description: In a modest televised ceremony, several hundred Khmer Rouge guerrillas surrendered to the Phnom Penh Government today in what was presented as a final end to the armed Communist movement that tore Cambodia apart for decades.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: 'Hollywood, D.C.'' (by R.W. Apple Jr.) was an epiphany for a reader who is disgusted with continuous spin and political theater. The public would be well served if these activities were highlighted in daily reporting.

title: Pinochet Is Best Left to His Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Cooking
description: Like the other arts, cooking goes through stylistic phases. Baroque curlicues give way to a clean classical line, which eventually sharpens the appetite for adornment and fascinating complications. At the moment, after several years of tricky fusion cooking by high-strung superchefs, a purifying wind seems to be blowing across the culinary landscape. A new simplicity is in the air, and it can be seen in the latest crop of cookbooks.

title: Westchester Briefs; Teacher Convicted
description: Martin O'Keefe, 53, a tenured teacher in the Yonkers school system where he taught for more than 25 years, was convicted on Nov. 23 by a Westchester County jury of nine counts of sexual abuse in the first degree and three counts of endangering the welfare of a child. The conviction followed a seven-day trial, during which three of the defendant's former students testified that Mr. O'Keefe had molested them.

title: Man Is Killed in Fire Started by Gas Explosion
description: One man was killed and a teen-ager was seriously injured after a natural gas explosion ignited a fire in a Brooklyn apartment yesterday, the authorities said.

title: The World: Eating Disorder; Lean Times at the Russian Dinner Table
description: THEY sell bread on the streets in Russia, from the windows of little roadside kiosks identified by signs proclaiming a single beloved word: bread. White bread, black bread, delicious Georgian bread laced with cheese, braided loaves and loaves baked in the shape of big brown domes, and much more. The average Russian's consumption of baked goods rose 5 percent from 1990 to 1995. In 1996 he ate 143 pounds of bread -- 6.4 ounces every day, 365 days a year. Russians even have a saying: ''Bread is the beginning of everything.''

title: Combining Nuts With Pears for Desserts and Salads
description: SWEETLY luscious ripe pears have an affinity for nuts of all kinds. Walnuts, pecans and almonds can be scattered on pear desserts and salads or used in the batter of pear cakes.

title: HOTEL CHECK-IN: ROOMS WITH A PERSONAL MAGNETISM; Jaipur -- Behind the pink walls, every guest is a maharajah
description: In the 18th-century pink city of Jaipur in the Indian state of Rajasthan, the exotic dazzle of jacarandas, acacias and flame-of-the-forest blossoms is juxtaposed against an intensely arid and rocky landscape. Rajput palaces, grand sculpture and Hindu temples inspire nostalgia for the India that was, recollections of historic, princely battles and towering forts where fierce and proud warrior clans ruled for over 1,000 years.

title: As the Dust Settles, Only One Team Is Unbeaten
description: Just when it appeared that the Bowl Championship Series would need a Ouija board and the Amazing Kreskin to sort out this college football season, Tennessee restored some order to the process tonight by surviving Mississippi State, 24-14, in the Southeastern Conference title game.

title: Allyson Silver and Andrew Wiener
description: Allyson Silver, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neil Silver of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married last evening to Andrew Nolan Wiener, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Wiener of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Henry Adler Sosland performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Nov. 29-Dec. 5; In Display of Unity, European Nations Cut Rates
description: Eleven European nations cut their interest rates to a nearly uniform level in an unusual display of unity. The cuts are intended to bolster European economies by making it cheaper for businesses and consumers to borrow.

title: Anti-Apartheid Champion Standing Trial on Fraud Charges
description: All Allan A. Boesak says he is guilty of is ''struggle bookkeeping.''

title: Pilar Frank, William O'Leary
description: Pilar Cristina Frank, the daughter of Dr. Irma Frank and Richard H. Frank of McLean, Va., was married yesterday to William Ronald O'Leary, a son of Gloria and Ronald O'Leary of Boxford, Mass. The Rev. Joseph Sweeney performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University in Washington.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: Apple writes with regret, ''In Washington, as elsewhere, fame and fortune, not talent and perseverance, are now what's most widely respected.'' Since when does going to the Ivy League, having the ''right contacts'' and living in Georgetown equate with ''talent and perseverance?'' Intentionally or unintentionally, he underscores the way in which status can skew us to the point that we confuse good fortune and superficial affectations with innate worth.

title: Single-Screen Theaters Find Their Days (And Nights) Numbered
description: THE LAST PICTURE SHOW'' would have been an appropriate film to feature at the Branford Theater on Oct. 10. That was the day that John and Lee Vogel closed the theater they had operated in the center of town for the last 23 years. As it was, the final feature attraction was the far more recent ''Studio 54.''

title: A Happier Ending This Time Around?
description: THEY go on, those star-crossed youngsters, be it in Verona, Italy, or Passaic, N.J. Shakespeare's plot for ''Romeo and Juliet'' actually dates back to third-century Greece. ''West Side Story,'' set in the 1950's, was originally titled ''East Side Story'' (as in Lower East Side); in the new film ''Shakespeare in Love,'' set in the 1590's, Marc Norman and Tom Stoppard invent a behind-the-scenes romance that inspires the play about the ultimate romance no one has ever wanted to believe was fictitious.

title: Law Students Keep Bargain Loan Deal
description: Nancy A. Slahetka felt fear in the pit of her stomach as she read a letter from her alma mater, Brooklyn Law School, last month. The letter said the school would be changing its loan-assistance program for graduates who pursue low-paying public interest work. After doing some math, a desolate Ms. Slahetka realized that her $386 monthly loan payment would balloon to $741, an impossible bill to pay on her $30,900-a-year job handling class actions at the Social Justice Project, a legal services organization.

title: The Fear That Made The Fed Step In
description: THE slide toward financial panic would have begun with a flutter of pages off a fax machine in Greenwich, Conn., each a notice of foreclosure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOKOUDOVSKY, VLADIMIR ALEXEVITCH
description: DOKOUDOVSKY-Vladimir Alexevitch, December 2, 1998. He was an internationally renowned dancer, instructor and choreographer. Loving husband of Patricia Heyes Dokoudovsky. Survived by his sister, Tatiana Dokoudovska; also survived by six nieces and one nephew. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday, December 6, 1998, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Religious service Monday, December 7, 9:30 AM, at The Russian Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Virgin Protection, 59 E. 2nd St, NYC.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on Nov. 8 about cruising Ireland's waters referred incorrectly to the accessibility of the city of Kilkenny by boat. The city is not on the Barrow Navigation, but on the River Nore about 12 miles to the west.

title: Police Officer Kills Himself After Leaving Crash Scene
description: A New York City police officer who had been drinking with fellow officers at a Nassau County bar committed suicide Friday night after leaving the scene of a a multiple-car accident, law enforcement officials said. They said he had been released by a county police officer who pulled him over shortly after the accident.

title: She 'Moved Mountains,' and a New Nursing Home Opens
description: For nearly 25 years the block between Cleveland and Ashford Streets on Linden Boulevard was a barren expanse, overgrown with weeds and used as a garbage dump. But last month, after three years of planning and building, a bright brick-and-glass nursing home called Ruby Weston Manor opened on the lot, part of a gradual economic revival in East New York.

title: Skateboard, Ho!
description: Douglas Dupin (pictured) is a California native who renovates old houses in Washington and in his spare time designs and builds skateboards. Earlier this fall, inspiration called: he would build a skateboard capable of carrying him the length of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal towpath, a 184-mile scenic route that runs from Cumberland, Md., to Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, ABRAHAM
description: FEINBERG-Abraham. 90, on December 5, 1998. Loving husband of Lillian. Adoring father of Judith Schneider Weissberg and the late E. Richard Feinberg. Cherished brother of Belle Feinberg and the Honorable Judge Wilfred Feinberg. Dear grandfather to Jeffrey, Audrey, Michael and Steven. Great-grandfather of Jonathan, Noah, Will, Gabriela, Daniel, Jason and Lily-Rachael. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Services Tuesday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions for the Ethics and Justice and Public Life, c/o Office of President, Brandeis University, Waltham, MA 02254.

title: Bialystok
description: To the Editor: Jane Perlez tells us about Jews returning to Bialystok, Poland, to learn about their history (''Bialystok Guide Recalls a Center of Polish Jewry,'' Oct. 18). But there are many other reasons to visit.

title: Where's Grandpa?
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentina on the Mind, Think Beef
description: THE cuisines of Latin America may never reach trend proportions, but a mini- trend could be in the making in Fairfield County, manifested most recently by the arrival in Stamford of La Estancia, featuring Argentinian grilled dishes.

title: A Party Cut Short
description: DAD was dubious about having our traditional party within a party this year.

title: Credit the Producers
description: To the Editor:

title: F.Y.I
description: Languid Park Fences

title: Corrections
description: The Right Thing column on Nov. 15, about the ethical dimensions of a worker's donation of a kidney to her supervisor, misstated the work arrangements of the donor, Nancy Nearing, at Applied Management Systems of Rockville, Md. She works 26 hours a week, not two days a week.

title: Inspiration From Motion, Nature and Abstraction
description: 'All-Stars'

title: The Capitalist; The Web Gets Ugly
description: In a mild case of man bites dog, Carl Shapiro and Hal Varian's ''Information Rules: A Strategic Guide to the Network Economy'' is apparently outselling Kevin Kelly's ''New Rules for the New Economy: 10 Radical Strategies for a Connected World.'' Both books purport to be manuals for business in the Internet age. However, not only is Kelly the executive editor of Wired, but he also writes in the best Tom Peters style, a rapid-fire blur of neologisms and breathless declarations that all the rules have changed, that there are limitless opportunities for those who have the courage to let go of old assumptions. Why, then, is he being outsold by a couple of economics professors who rather primly declare that ''we seek models, not trends; concepts, not vocabulary; and analysis, not analogies''?

title: BETTING ON POLITICS: A special report.; A Gambling Impresario Leaves Little to Chance
description: In a modest office building across the street from the Deja Vu nude showgirls lounge, 15 workers, most of them elderly, spend their days in a long, narrow room lined with cubicles, computers and telephones.

title: A '-San' Snares a 'Sir'
description: You can almost hear the bureaucrats at Japan's Ministry of Trade and Industry gnashing their teeth: Queen Elizabeth has knighted Nobuhiko Kawamoto, the former president and chief executive of the Honda Motor Company. Years ago, when the ministry was trying to protect Japan's auto industry leaders, Toyota and Nissan, it discouraged bankers from lending to Honda, then a motorcycle maker. The strategy failed, and Honda is now a global giant, producing 150,000 vehicles a year in Swindon, England, with plans to increase capacity by 100,000.

title: Queens Sculpture Garden Is Made a Permanent Park
description: New York City has sided with artists and their allies over developers and will make Socrates Sculpture Park in Astoria, Queens, a permanent park.

title: In China, a New House of Cautious Openness
description: WHEN enthusiastic applause erupted at the final curtain for a recent production of Verdi's ''Aida,'' the first opera to appear in Shanghai's sparklingly attractive new opera house, Bonko Chan thought that he might collapse with a heart attack.

title: RIGHT TO ABORTION QUIETLY ADVANCES IN STATE COURTS
description: Abortion rights advocates have slowly and quietly been winning victories in state courts to make abortions more widely available.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about investing in companies with large exposure to Asia misstated the name of one that derives a sizable share of its revenues there. It is Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain, not Cable and Wireless Communications.

title: Romance at the Soup Kitchen
description: SINGLE men and women beware. It's mistletoe season yet again, which means it's time for your annual holiday endurance test: trying to dodge meddling relatives who insist you call the son or daughter of a friend (''One dinner won't kill you!'') and cocktail parties where no one will let you drink in peace (''There's this woman from my office I've been wanting you to meet''). Finally there is the blessed release of January, when the nasty truth about so many of those happy couples touting togetherness comes out and the single population gets a fresh infusion of blood.

title: Misdiagnosis Led to Man's Handcuffing, Suit Claims
