description: A quadriplegic man who went to a Bronx hospital with stomach pains and ended up handcuffed to a gurney for more than 24 hours because his doctors thought his bladder stones were bags of heroin has sued the hospital, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: Lost in Spain
description: To the Editor: Driving our rental car through northern Spain in September, we got hideously lost looking for hotels in Segovia, Burgos, Olite, Hondarribia, Leon and Santiago de Compostela. But in Salamanca, we had no trouble at all! An older couple told us their secret. We'd like to share this with those who've been stymied in a maze of medieval one-way streets whose names change at every block.

title: East of Suez
description: PASSAGE EAST

title: On-Line Jokesters Meet in All 3 Dimensions
description: THE SETTING -- The back lounge at Bar Nine, a dark space with the semi-anonymity of an on-line chat room -- if chat rooms had velveteen love seats and bottled beer -- at Ninth Avenue and 53d Street. The regular players of News Quiz, an interactive humor column at the on-line magazine Slate, gathered on Monday night to put a face to people they had only known as bylines to topical jokes. Presiding was Randy Cohen, a former writer for the ''Late Show With David Letterman'' and the Rosie O'Donnell show, who moderates the four-day-a-week column by choosing the 40 best E-mail submissions to his news-related joke setup.

title: Quality of Life? Back to Basics On Well-Being
description: IT was one of those unforgettable crisp fall days in Westchester. Skies were clear, temperatures hovered in the upper 50's and the decibel level soared.

title: Yale Senior Is Found Stabbed to Death Off Campus in New Haven
description: A Yale University senior was found stabbed to death Friday night a mile and a half from campus.

title: Lessons of a Long, Hot Summer
description: TODAY, with stock markets stronger and bond markets quietly going about their workaday business, it hardly seems possible that less than three months ago some of Wall Street's smartest and most powerful people thought the problems of one giant hedge fund, Long-Term Capital Management L.P. of Greenwich, Conn., might push the world's markets to the brink of disaster.

title: Pinochet Is Best Left to His Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Photography
description: This season's bounty of photography books has an international flavor in both subject matter and source. Volumes surveying places far and near -- Algeria, India, Jerusalem, South Africa, New York City -- abound. That's par for the course, though; what's interesting is that American trade publishers are increasingly relying on offshore imprints for their titles. Art houses like Editions du Seuil in Paris, Phaidon in London and Scalo and Edition Stemmle in Zurich are the source of many of the most beautiful and interesting books this year, but you often have to look carefully to tell. The trend has a downside: for all the virtues of the photographs, the texts in these books can be stiffly translated and negligible in terms of scholarship.

title: Saying It With Flowers, Dramatically and Exotically
description: Bruno Abikhzir and Anne Bickel moved to New York one year ago, because, according to Mr. Abikhzir, although they love their native Paris, the husband-wife florist team decided that this city was ''a more interesting place to start new things.'' That new thing is their first store in either country, Anne Bruno, a flower boutique at 115 West Broadway (between Duane and Reade Streets) in TriBeCa.

title: South of the Border on a Dime
description: HEY, you've got to know how to arrive!'' My friend Henry quoted me a famous line from the Mexican song ''El Rey'' as he swept his arm toward the gleaming white Cadillac in the Avis rental parking lot in downtown Los Angeles. I appreciated his instincts; a white Caddy would be the perfect car in which to glide stylishly across the border into Tijuana, which is what we were about to do. Very ''Touch of Evil'': Squinting slightly, I could see a pencil-mustachioed Charlton Heston in dark pancake makeup behind the wheel, with Janet Leigh, wearing an ensemble more sausage casing than sweater, batting eyelashes at his side.

title: HOTEL CHECK-IN; Palace of the Nouveau West
description: AMANGANI. We see it perched on the edge of East Gros Ventre Butte, wings outstretched, walled in sandstone, blinking out at the cloud-shrouded Teton Range. There is nothing like it on the yellow, sere meadows along Spring Gulch Road, or in the brown hills laced with quaking aspen. It does not resemble the old-time ranches with their cracked logs and peeling paint, or the spanking new trophy homes zigzagging up every available slope. This is no typical Wyoming dude outfit (the concept of paying to ride horses on a cattle ranch was perfected in Jackson Hole); it's an elegant vision appropriate to the nouveau West.

title: Children's Books
description: MICHELANGELO'S SURPRISE Written and illustrated by Tony Parillo. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Caryn Herold And Wade Teman
description: Caryn Michele Herold, the daughter of Rochelle Herold and Dr. Frederick Herold of Hollywood, Fla., was married last evening to Wade Teman, a son of Arlene and Seymour Teman of Melville, N.Y. Rabbi Robert P. Frazin performed the ceremony at the Turnberry Isle Resort and Club in Aventura, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, KEN
description: ROSENTHAL-Ken. December 7, 1988. ''Angel On My Shoulder''. Love, Mom.

title: Where Death Can Be A Great Career Move
description: ABSTRACT EXPRESSION'' might put you in touch with your compassion for society's underclass -- or make you realize you feel nothing. It could tap into your sensitivity about the artistic process, or confront you with your lack of it.

title: Hollies, in Black and Yellow as Well as Red
description: WITH holidays ahead, much thought is given to the greenery that can be used for trimmings and bouquets. Much of it has a long life indoors. But one, holly, needs to remain in the garden as long as possible. It does not keep well indoors.

title: Put Caring for Students Ahead of Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: I wish I had read Mosle's essay before I ended a friendship with someone who constantly stood me up. According to her, he liked me. . .he really liked me!

title: The Secret Is Out
description: To the Editor:

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: Now that I know we are living in a class-free society, I can't wait to tell the Mexican immigrant workers who cluster on my block waiting for work. They'll be relieved that no longer do people make class distinctions between their homes in East Los Angeles and the homes whose yards they tend in Brentwood. Unfortunately, your articles were a bit light on status building for blue-collar workers and laborers. In fact, the only thing I learned was that the distinction between upper middle class and upper class has been blurred. More feel-good boosterism for the rich!

title: Better Luck Next Nobel
description: When the Portuguese novelist Jose Saramago accepts the Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday, Dr. Antonio Lobo Antunes may see his own chance at the prize evaporate.

title: When a Golden-Age Writer Decided to Go Commercial
description: THE television writer and producer Rod Serling died 23 years ago, but watching him in action today is as engrossing as taking in one of his fanciful dramas. Maybe more so. ''There is a fifth dimension,'' he says at the start of many episodes of ''The Twilight Zone,'' the famed science fiction series that ran from 1959 to 1965 and was his signature. ''It is the middle ground between light and shadow, between science and superstition, and it lies between the pit of man's fears and the summit of his knowledge.''

title: Libya Rebuffs U.N. Chief on Bomb Trial
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, gambled on an unusual trip to Libya yesterday but apparently failed to persuade Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to turn over two suspects wanted in the bombing of a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988.

title: Strong Capital Starts A Network of Its Own
description: Strong Capital Management of Milwaukee has tossed its hat into the funds network arena with a service that offers investors the funds of eight other no-load families, without transaction fees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISENFELD, MILDRED MOSLER
description: WEISENFELD-Mildred Mosler. The Board of Directors, staff and friends of Fight for Sight, Inc. remember our founder and executive director of fifty-one years on the first anniversary of her death, December 6th, 1997. Mildred Weisenfeld was a visionary leader who contributed her extraordinary talents to finding causes and treatments for blinding eye diseases, helping to save sight for millions of people. Her legacy continues at Fight for Sight

title: SOAPBOX; Time to Rethink Our H.O.V. Lanes
description: THE debate over high-occupancy vehicle lanes on the Long Island Expressway is heating up again and it's not a moment too soon, especially for communities west of Exit 40 to the Cross Island Parkway interchange. Residents have just begun to receive notice from the New York State Department of Transportation detailing the options for noise-abatement walls in their neighborhoods. At the same time, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey has just turned over 20 miles of H.O.V. lanes to general-purpose lanes. Why? According to Governor Whitman, suburban sprawl coupled with life styles not conducive to carpooling made H.O.V. lanes unworkable in New Jersey. Sounds like Long Island to me.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GLASSMAN, BOB
description: GLASSMAN-Boblorence/d. Another day, another year. My brother ''Bob'' you are always in our thoughts. My loving mother ''Flo'' our years together were always a true joy. We love you and miss you both. Selma & Morty Our very best to David & Eli

title: Holly Boughs With Unusual Berry Colors
description: WITH holidays ahead, much thought is given to the greenery that can be used for trimmings and bouquets. Much of it has a long life indoors. But one, holly, needs to remain in the garden as long as possible. It does not keep well indoors.

title: Debra Etelson, Adam Mayblum
description: Dr. Debra Helene Etelson, a daughter of Barbara and Arnold P. Etelson of Suffern, N.Y., is to be married today to Adam Gabriel Mayblum, a son of Evelyn and Martin Mayblum of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi David Chanovsky is to perform the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, N.Y.

title: Cleopa, 87, an Orthodox Monk In Romania Sought by Pilgrims
description: Cleopa, an Orthodox monk who once fled Communist pressure by becoming a solitary anchorite in Romania's forests, died this week in the remote monastery where his down-to-earth teachings came to attract large and steady streams of pilgrims. He was 87.

title: Corporations and Conscience
description: Americans are understandably ambivalent about the foreign entanglements of American business. Overseas operations can produce profits and support some jobs at home, but they can also help sustain abusive dictatorships and labor practices. In recent years companies like Nike and Unocal have embarrassed themselves with questionable overseas partnerships, but the problem extends far back in American industrial history.

title: Style; The Ties That Bind
description: In a lean season between college and full-scale employment, I took a job as a clerk in a French car-importing company. My immediate superior was a formal gentleman of the old school named Mr. Thompson, who, though a fellow New Yorker, spoke French with educated fluency. The fact that he was black was, in the eyes of our French employers, less of a social barrier than the fact that he was American.

title: Who Can Shut a Beloved Church's Doors?
description: PARISHIONERS grumble that their feelings are being ignored.

title: For Gay Men, Matchmaking as an Extreme Sport
description: STEVEN PRESCOTT grabbed a clipboard, a No. 2 pencil and some scrap paper and took a seat alongside 100 other nerve-racked men in a stuffy, overheated basement in Chelsea.

title: Liberties; Our Retro Patriotism
description: If only we could order self-sacrifice from the Sharper Image catalogue. If only it could arrive by U.P.S. next-day, along with the exfoliating foot cream and the portable shoulder & neck massager and the designer dog-biscuit mix.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: Sara Rimer looks at the status of retirement-villagers and refers only to ''a (still!) valid driver's license.'' Where has she been? We are concerned about keeping in good shape. If one of us is heavy, it is not ignored! And we dress. We look good. Our wives and girlfriends are dressed to the hilt when the time and place demand it. We are politically awake and our politicians know it.

title: Mergers May Not Be Music to Investor Ears
description: They've only just begun to merge.

title: Going Out
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: It's Not Just Big Talk Anymore: Costco Buys a Spot
description: Talk of a large, new Costco store planned for West 23d Street so alarmed community leaders that they began mobilizing against the plan even though it was only a rumor. On Friday, the rumor was confirmed.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: As a stay-at-home mother, I have finally figured out what to do with all the free time I'm often told I have. I shall rent myself out as a status symbol. Then, the next time some Donna Karan-wearing, Range Rover-driving, Starbucks-drinking, paycheck-earning mother asks me, I can finally tell her I have a job! Thanks for the idea.

title: Building Better Pulp
description: It's 10 A.M. on a Saturday in Bethesda, Md., and about 40 women and men are plotting felonies.

title: Food; Someone's in The Kitchen With Fritzie
description: In a tiny kitchen on manhattan's upper West Side, three generations of Abadi women are packed as tightly as the inner workings of a Swiss watch. Mincing and chopping the ingredients for a Syrian Hanukkah meal are 83-year old Fritzie Abadi, her 61-year-old daughter, Annette Hidary, and her granddaughter, Jennifer Abadi, 32. Mostly, they move like clockwork. But tiny gaps across the generational divide cause them to miss a beat or two.

title: An Author's Dogs, In His Plot and Theirs
description: To the Editor:

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: I was disappointed that your item on the prestige a valid driver's license gives to residents of retirement communities in Florida, California and North Carolina was not balanced by one in which New Yorkers make fun of those who use cars to get around a city so well supplied with public transportation.

title: Lara Cohen, Ari Markenson
description: Lara J. Cohen, a daughter of Linda R. Cohen of Great Neck, N.Y., and the late Dr. Richard M. Cohen, was married last evening to Ari Jonathan Markenson, a son of Dr. Alicejane Lippner of Highland Park, N.J., and Dr. Joseph Markenson of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Joshua Lookstein performed the ceremony at the Pratt Mansions in Manhattan.

title: New York at Odd Angles
description: YOU can't be blamed if it's been a while since you last looked up to admire the city in all its vertical splendor. You're a New Yorker. You have other things on your mind, like trying to make that next light. Horst Hamann, the photographer, has looked up for you, and presents his findings in ''New York Vertical,'' an exhibition (based on his book of the same name) of 35 8-foot tall black-and-white images at the Museum of the City of New York. One of the Statue of Liberty is at left.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, SARA
description: STRAUSS-Sara. On December 4, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Ben, beloved mother of Norman and Leona; Victor and Fran; cherished sister of Ada and Phil Podhoretz; adored and adoring ''Nanny'' of Laurence and Jean, Kenny, Andrea and Jay Friedman, Paul and Kathy, Hillary and Bruce Klein; loving great-grandmother of Imogene, Ella, Danielle, Bennett, Brandon, Remi, Isabel and Abigail. Dear aunt of Penny and David Rosen. She will always be in the hearts of those who loved her. Service Sunday, December 6, 12:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Architecture
description: AFRICAN PAINTED HOUSES: Basotho Dwellings of Southern Africa. By Gary N. van Wyk. (Abrams, $39.95.) Every few generations, Western architects wake up to the fact that our civilization's habitual fear of strong color and bold pattern on the exteriors of buildings causes us to lose out on a powerful form of architectural expression. Fortunately, no such inhibitions restrict the Basotho women of Lesotho. After each rainy season they redecorate the outer walls of their single-story mud-brick houses with pulsating polychrome designs of such potent graphic impact that the tradition constitutes one of the continuing glories of African culture.

title: Margin Rule Tightens For Internet Stocks
description: CONCERNED about wild swings in the prices of hot Internet stocks, a number of brokerage houses said last week that they had changed their rules so that investors who buy these stocks on margin -- with money borrowed from the broker -- may have to put up more of their own money to maintain their holdings.

title: All Species Welcome at Vegan Mixer
description: So, a guy walks into a party with a lizard on his chest . . .

title: Massachusetts Hangs On and Turns Back Lehigh
description: The Massachusetts players were absorbing the school's first playoff triumph at home today when they watched the unthinkable: ecstatic students mobbed the field at McGuirk Stadium and tore down a goal post. It was the kind of display usually reserved for the UMass basketball team, not the football team.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: INSIDE
description: From Bullets to Ballots

title: Two on the Aisle
description: HOT SEAT

title: Worried by Visions of an El
description: To the budget-conscious traveler, a proposal to build a rail link connecting the N train to La Guardia Airport may be time and money in the bank. But to the residents of western Queens, the prospect of an elevated train rumbling above their streets is causing panic.

title: Fight Fans Can Light Up In New Center
description: This weekend's Saturday-night boxing match between Nana Konadu and Johnny Tapia was the first time that smokers were allowed to light up at the city's new Convention Center.

title: Rudy, for What?
description: The foreign dignitary paid his visit to Columbia, S.C., on an evening so muggy that the Confederate flag drooped like wet laundry from its perch atop the Statehouse dome. But the humidity did not deter dozens of Republicans from gathering at their state chairman's elegant home, just down the street, to listen as their exotic guest explained why -- when you get right down to it -- he was just like them.

title: PULSE; Pundit on Board
description: ''They get to play shuffleboard,'' said Victor Navasky, publisher of The Nation. ''They get to listen to Guy Lombardo at midnight. They get seminars on the end of liberalism.'' The left-leaning magazine recently launched its ''first annual seminar cruise,'' a fund-raising sail from Fort Lauderdale through the Virgin Islands and the Bahamas aboard Holland-America's MS Veendam. Now, instead of ruminating over the globalization of capital, eating Danish in a dismal hotel meeting room, Nation readers are paying $2,800 each to discuss such heady topics with deckside pundits like George McGovern and writers like Calvin Trillin (far left) and Christopher Hitchens (left).

title: Q&A / Peter A. Gisolfi; Preserving the Castles of Westchester
description: ON a 64-acre Tarrytown site once occupied by a Weckquaesgeck tribe of Indians, Gen. Howard Carroll, son of a Civil War general, had his home built between 1900 and 1910. If a man's home is his castle, his truly was. It covered 28,000 square feet and was built of stone to look like a Norman castle, with a tower rising 75 feet and a swimming pool, tennis courts, a farmhouse, vegetable gardens, a cattle shed, poultry houses and an animal shelter.

title: New Checks Of Gun Buyers Are a Success, Clinton Says
description: President Clinton said today that the new system of computerized, instant background checks on gun buyers, run by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, had already stopped ''400 felons, fugitives, stalkers and other prohibited purchasers from walking away with new guns.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDER, JANET SLOANE
description: BENDER-Janet Sloane. Died on December 3, 1998 at her home in Greenwich, CT two weeks before her 94th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Michael M. Bender. A woman of grace and beauty, elegant of bone and spirit, she was born and educated in New York City. From 1939 until 1982, she designed women's apparel and scouted the European ready-to-wear markets for the Janet Sloane shops she established in partnership with her husband on Madison Avenue, Greenwich, and Hyannis, MA. In 1961, the business was consolidated in Greenwich which also became their home. Michael Bender died in 1984. She is survived by a daughter Marylin Bender Altschul and a grandson James S. Altschul of New York. Funeral service private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Greenwich Hospital or the Greenwich Library, Greenwich, CT 06830.

title: In Miami Beach, an Almost Brand-New Hotel
description: For a decade or more, Miami Beach has been restoring its famed Art Deco hotels, making them as much a tourist attraction as the wide beach. This month, what is described as the first major new hotel built in 30 years is to open on that famed spit of beach and bravura.

title: Corrections
description: A credit is omitted on page 12 of the Travel section today for pictures of two hotels in Majorca. They are by Quim Llenas/Cover, for The New York Times.

title: Markets Battered, Then Bolstered
description: Perhaps investors overindulged during Thanks-giving week, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to a record of 9,374.27, for last week seemed to be the post-party hangover. Shares were repeatedly battered, and a 185-point tumble on Thursday left the Dow nearly 500 points below its record.

title: Finding Common Ground on Child Welfare
description: The two reformers were rivals from the very beginning. And for nearly three years, they waged war over the direction of New York City's dysfunctional child welfare agency.

title: Why Not Yell Out Starr's Innocence?; Just Don't Get Caught
description: To the Editor:

title: Schnitzler's Intent
description: To the Editor:

title: Standoff Begins at Vendors' Mart
description: The eviction deadline for merchants at Mart 125, the indoor vendors' market on West 125th Street, came and went on Monday, and most of the tenants defiantly refused to budge.

title: Connecticut Guide
description: 'Black Nativity'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, SARAH
description: GOODMAN-Sarah, 93, on December 3rd, 1998. Beloved wife of Saul L. Goodman, father of Jacob Eli, mother-in-law of Josy, and grandmother of Rachel and Naomi. Born in Baranovka, Ukraine, she came to this country at age 16 and unselfishly devoted her life to her family and to the advancement of Jewish education. A graveside service was held at Cedar Park Cemetery on Friday, December 4th.

title: DeFirmian Defeats Benjamin to Become U.S. Champion
description: Nick DeFirmian won the United States Championship, which was held in Denver from Oct. 30 through Nov. 18. The 41-year-old grandmaster, formerly of Manhattan but now making his base in Denmark, defeated Joel Benjamin, a 34-year-old Manhattan grandmaster and last year's champion, by 2 1/2-1 1/2 in the final match. DeFirmian had shared the top prize in 1987 and 1995, but this was the first time he did not have to split the money, which was $12,000. Benjamin was awarded the $7,500 second prize.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: Matthew Klam's ''Air-to-Air Kill'' mistakenly states that ''Mongo's (Lieut. Comdr. Nicholas Mongillo) kill has made him an ace.'' Sorry, Mr. Klam, an ace is a fighter pilot who has shot down five enemy planes, not one.

title: A Shifting American Landscape; Downtown, Theme Parks For the Arts
description: LATE at night, along Main Street in Louisville, the Kentucky Center for the Arts sits in desolate silence across from the office building of a major financial supporter, the Humana Foundation. Restaurants are barely visible in the corners of office towers on deserted streets. A few pedestrians turn up, walking with purposeful strides. Cars pull into lots beneath the center.

title: Setting Kipling Stories to Music
description: FIRST of all, no matter how many great songs there are in a score, it is no good unless you get the book right.'' Thus spake Cameron Mackintosh in the new book, ''Hey Mr. Producer,'' recently published by Backstage Books.

title: Handling the Perils of Condensation
description: DURING the fall, homeowners often awaken to find their windows fogged over. In the winter, the windows may be covered with a thin layer of frost. Both the fog and the frost are examples of condensation. It occurs when moisture, in the form of invisible vapor in the warm interior air, meets with the cold surface of the window pane.

title: The Ups and Downs of Holiday Travel
description: THIS is the season of the great family migration. Love, guilt and sneaky thoughts of inheritance will draw millions of American families together, performing feats of long-distance travel that make the Oregon Trail look like a stroll through the mall.

title: Jury Rejects Liability Claim of Witness in His Mother's Slaying
description: A jury on Friday rejected the assertions of a witness in a murder case who sued local authorities on the basis that they failed to protect his mother, who was killed in a drive-by shooting after he testified.

title: Advertisers Play A New Tune: Jazz
description: TURN on the television, and there's John Coltrane's resonant saxophone in commercials for Jeep Cherokee and Burger King. Turn the channel, and there's Dinah Washington singing ''Destination Moon'' to sell Nike sneakers. Open a magazine, and there's Lena Horne looking sharp in Gap jeans, or perhaps Cassandra Wilson smiling prettily next to a luxurious Coach handbag.

title: Overcoming a Door Jam
description: FOUR years have passed since Barry Tesser plunked down $1,500 for a sofa bed at Jennifer Convertibles. It had deep cushions, a high upholstered back and heavily padded armrests.

title: Nov. 29-Dec. 5; Jury Acquits Espy In Corruption Case
description: Donald C. Smaltz spent four years investigating Mike Espy, the former Agriculture Secretary, alleging that he had illegally accepted sports tickets, luggage and other favors from companies he was supposed to be regulating. A jury took two days to find Mr. Espy not guilty of all 30 charges. In the process, the jury provided powerful new political ammunition for opponents of the law, set to expire in June, that provides for the appointment of independent prosecutors.

title: What to Tip
description: To the Editor: Your treatise on tipping is something to be considered, but are not the bellhops, waiters, busmen, guides, baggagemen, deliverymen, concierges and all others, being paid by their employers? They have a job to do and should be paid for it by those who hired them. Why do we, the traveling public, have to hand out tips all over the world? Even more to the point: Why not have those who offer tours include tipping, if necessary, so that we don't have to walk around with one hand in our pocket?

title: Sports of The Times; In Newest Winter Sport, Some Advice: Let's Have a Fair Fight
description: ONCE upon a time, a frontier woman heard a frightful commotion right outside the log cabin. Seeing her loutish husband and a vicious bear locked in mortal combat, she paused for a moment and then blurted: ''Go husband! Go bear!''

title: Commercial Property; The Lure of Converting Retail Space to Condos
description: THE retail spaces of office or residential buildings are often the most valuable parts of the property, commanding per-square-foot rents several times that of the rest of the structure. They are also often orphans of a sort in residential buildings, with the original owner retaining control of the stores after the living space has been converted into a co-op or condominium and sold to its occupants.

title: The Nation: Masters of Jersey; Wall Street Shudders At Life Across the River
description: TO the surprise of almost no one, the New York Stock Exchange has agreed to stay in New York. Whether its well-heeled officials really, truly, turn-blue-and-die meant their many threats to move to New Jersey will probably never be known.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARMACHE, STELLA
description: BARMACHE-Stella. On November 21, 1998, in her 83rd year. Internationally known fashion coordinator and loving wife of the late Leon Barmache. In her long career she was in charge of running fashion shows in all the major capitals of the world for the most illustrious names in the fashion industry. Though living in Manhattan, she was an honorary citizen of Monaco where she spent a great deal of her time. She and Leon, for the past 40 years, spent their summers in Westhampton where they were known for their enthusiastic and expensive personalities. She is survived by her nieces Andrea Tannenbaum, Long Beach, NY, and Holly Aloisia, Queens, NY. A memeorial service will be held on December 10, 11 AM, at Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY.

title: Emily Durham, John McCarthy
description: Emily Rose Durham, the daughter of Betsy and Vaughn Durham of Waterford, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Leighton McCarthy, the son of Brenda Jean and Leighton Wilckes McCarthy of Toronto. The Rev. Richard W. Mitchell, a Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) minister, performed the ceremony at the Seventh Day Baptist Church.

title: Paris -- A prestigious address, with prices to match
description: Problem: In a city with more than its share of super-luxurious hotels, how do you elbow your way into the competition? Simple: You come up with something more luxurious still. And call it the Hotel de Vendome.

title: Streetscapes / Readers' Questions; Two Buildings With Unusual Touches, and Histories
description: Red House, 350 West 85th Street

title: Hotels at J.F.K. Buff Their Image
description: ALMOST everyone who flies has spent at least part of a night at an airport hotel. Predawn departures, missed connections, canceled flights, oversold seats: all sorts of things can lead to a sleepless stay, watching car headlights flicker across the ceiling and hearing planes taking off and landing. We stalled travelers are known in airport-hotel jargon as ''distress'' customers. The phrase is usually apt: already pained by the forces that brought us there, we are still more distressed by the place we have been deposited.

title: Defining A Listing Agreement
description: ONE of the more common terms in the lexicon of real estate -- ''the listing agreement'' -- is also one of the most difficult to define.

title: At Very End, St. John's Winds Up Face Down
description: The St. John's soccer team had all the ingredients to insure another appearance in the national semifinals this month and perhaps its second National Collegiate Athletic Association title in three years. But all of the school's dreams of matching its 1996 accomplishment, when it won its first national title, came tumbling down in the quarterfinals at Adelphi this afternoon.

title: On Language; Return of The Luddites
description: The lead attorney for Microsoft, the firm accused by the U.S. Government of seeking to monopolize the computer industry, strode into a Washington courtroom and told the judge that the proceedings had turned into ''a return of the Luddites.''

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: If some guy at Yale taped his loafers in the 60's, it didn't hurt anybody, did it? Why do you base an argument about the demise of the Puritan work ethic, etc., on shoes?

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: MOVIES on tap this week include a portrait of an aging Mid-western couple, a marvelous old murder puzzle, the story of a British teacher who became a legend and a classy James Bond knockout.

title: The Man Who Helped Make Rome Eternal
description: BERNINI AND THE ART

title: PULSE; Get-a-Grip Nail Polish
description: Tony & Tina, the New Age makeup company that came out with anti-depressant lipstick, now has nail polish for the uncoordinated. Its Millennium Key nail polish comes in a futuristic egg-shaped bottle with notches so it can rest between the fingers. ''It makes it so much easier to paint your nails, because you don't have to hold the bottle,'' said Tony Gill, the company's owner, who noticed the bottle in the Museum of Modern Art's design section.

title: FILM; When Stars Need a Little Forgiveness
description: WHAT, an incredulous Jay Leno asked Hugh Grant on a hot July night in 1995, were you thinking? As the ''Tonight Show'' host and millions of viewers leaned in to listen, the British actor, who had spent the preceding weeks caught in an unrelenting firestorm of publicity over his arrest with a prostitute, looked down, then back up and said simply, and sincerely: I think you know in life what's a good thing to do and what's a bad thing, and I did a bad thing. And there you have it.

title: SOAPBOX; Monitoring Baby (and the Neighbors) Cordless Phone Calls Tempt the Accidental Listener
description: I'VE always been suspicious of cordless phones, imagining that someone with a high-tech eavesdropping device might be listening in. Well, I've finally been proved wrong. It doesn't take a high-tech listening device; a no-frills baby monitor will do.

title: Jewish Music With Revivalist Joy
description: DEBBIE FRIEDMAN was amazed the first time people got up from their seats at one of her concerts and ''let it rip,'' dancing in the aisles as they sang along.

title: Hollies, in Black and Yellow as Well as Red
description: WITH holidays ahead, much thought is given to the greenery that can be used for trimmings and bouquets. Much of it has a long life indoors. But one, holly, needs to remain in the garden as long as possible. It does not keep well indoors.

title: Nancy Blumenthal, Jason Dolinsky
description: Nancy Ruth Blumenthal and Dr. Jason Hunter Dolinsky are to be married today in New York. Rabbi Kenneth Stern is to perform the ceremony at the Four Seasons restaurant.

title: Amid Chaos, Harmony
description: INSTEAD of sitting down to dinner, Sandy Barr, a soprano, and her husband, Frank, a bass-baritone, are driving from Manhattan to Ridgewood in a rental car for the weekly rehearsal of Ars Musica Chorale. Ms. Barr's Tercel was sideswiped (and she doubts insurance will cover the rental), but she's not about to miss chorus, not with a semi-staged ''Aida'' coming up in Hackensack.

title: Dragging Martha Back From The Dead
description: DESPITE forensic evidence, the modern-dance pioneer Martha Graham did not die in 1991. She can be found performing, name dropping and introducing guest choreographers the first Wednesday and Thursday of most months at a club in Manhattan's meatpacking district. Oh, she also grew 16 inches and is often mistaken for a soft-spoken, witty man named Richard Move.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBASCH, MURRAY
description: LUBASCH-Murray. On December 3, 1998 at the age of 95. Beloved and devoted husband of Betty for 63 years. Loving father of Arlene and her husband Harry, and of Richard & his wife Lois. Cherished grandfather of Eric, Lisa and Douglas. Also survived by his brother Leroy. Funeral service Sunday, December 6th, Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 12:30 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POST, EUGENE J.
description: POST-Eugene J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Eugene J. Post, associated with The Times from 1977.

title: Hyde Says White House May Get Days For Questions
description: Representative Henry J. Hyde said today that he would to try to accommodate a White House request that it be given several days to call witnesses and raise questions about the impeachment inquiry's legal and constitutional basis.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: Peter D. Kramer's ''Really Getting Inside a Head'' suffers from that telltale symptom of middle age: recreating the past with a glory that never was. My recollection of psychiatry 25 years ago is of a time when the status of psychiatrists was measured by the health and wealth of their patients, and those of us embarking on a career working with the chronically mentally ill and people suffering from schizophrenia were viewed with skepticism and pity. This decade has brought a more enlightened attitude toward such patients.

title: Travel
description: TRAVEL writing is the most accommodating -- one might almost say promiscuous -- of genres. Write a book that might otherwise be shelved under memoir, social commentary, humor or even popular science, and as long as you leave the property at some point, you can call it travel writing.

title: John Glenns, With a Bit Less Altitude
description: THE next time a youth-obsessed advertising agency convenes a focus group to divine how to spend a client's money, maybe Jack McQuillan should be included. Or Jimmie Troccoli. Or Richard Handel. These three men have lived a combined 208 years and are fulfilling shared, long-held fantasies that would tax the imagination, drive and pocketbooks of many people half their ages.

title: What If the Legislature Really Deserves a Raise?
description: No, that silence emanating from the New Jersey State House isn't the symptom of some epidemic of legislative laryngitis. There's no mime contest going on, pitting the Assembly against the state Senate. The peculiar hush surrounding New Jersey's elected officials these days is actually one of the most time-honored forms of political shadow play: the nearly imperceptible sound of government officials beginning to raise their own pay.

title: Street Vendors Protest Ouster From a Busy Site in Chinatown
description: As tourists crammed the Chinatown streets examining the sweaters, snow peas and lo mein for sale on the sidewalks yesterday, another group of vendors rallied to protest their ouster by the police from their curb-side places of business.

title: Bigfoot
description: GOUT

title: Q & A
description: Roaming Around Mobile

title: The Impeachment Bully
description: The decision on whether to impeach or censure President Clinton is too important to be left to a ferocious partisan like Representative Tom DeLay, the Republican whip. But that is what the next Speaker, Robert Livingston, and his becalmed G.O.P. leadership team are doing. If they continue to tolerate Mr. DeLay's bullying, they will be allowing a single willful legislator to frustrate the public's desire to settle the Monica Lewinsky scandal by censuring President Clinton sternly for his lies and failures of leadership.

title: Mercury Seeping From Ceiling Affects Historic Edison Lab
description: Among the 1,093 patents awarded to Thomas Alva Edison, 141 of them involved storage batteries. Batteries are believed to be the source of liquid mercury that dripped through floorboards and onto a worker's head in one of at the 15 buildings at the Edison National Historic Site in West Orange. Since the incident two months ago, tests on Building No. 5, the main laboratory building, shown here, show high but not necessarily hazardous levels of mercury, according to David Eisenhardt, deputy director of the Environmental Health Service branch of the Division of Federal Occupational Health.

title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless Youths in New York, A Search for Happy Endings
description: David Hilton, the star point guard for the Hyde School Phoenix, never despairs when his basketball team falls way behind.

title: Hanging CD's May Gleam But May Run Afoul of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: To paraphrase Robert Browning: Ah, but man's status should exceed his class, or, What's a credit card for?

title: Colorado Resorts Get An International Accent
description: DEEP in the nation's heartland, the Colorado Rockies are 1,000 miles from the nearest seaport. But jet travel, satellite television and foreign-language Web sites are quickly integrating America's most popular skiing state into the world tourism economy.

title: Of Frogs' Legs and Tripe, Eel and Emu
description: TO grow up in a house where Friday night meant a kitchen sink crawling with lobsters, and walking on the beach meant pounding the sand with one's bare heel for the squirt of a clam and a quick raw snack, is to abjure squeamishness at an early age. But I succumbed anyway. On a Sunday morning when I was eagerly awaiting a dinner featuring ham, the only meat I really liked, I read a magazine article -- illustrated, alas -- about a cannibal tribe. Butt of human looked suspiciously like butt of ham. As a consequence, I dined only on succotash.

title: Raising Holiday Spirits for 250-Plus Years
description: THINGS are seldom what they seem: Handel's ''Messiah,'' beloved and widely famed as a Christmas oratorio, was first introduced at Easter. And not even at Easter, exactly, but in Lent as a substitute for opera, which was thought too blatantly entertaining for that penitential season.

title: Dana Bol and Johannes Muller
description: Dana Marie Bol was married yesterday to Johannes Hendrik Muller at the National Arts Club in New York. Judge Arlene Hahn of New York City Civil Court officiated.

title: Repair Plans Pass a Hurdle
description: In many of Parkchester's condominiums and apartments, plaster walls made sodden by leaky pipes peel like snakeskins, old windows fail to keep out the wind and outdated wiring prevents residents from using air-conditioners or even two appliances at once.

title: Nov. 29-Dec. 5; Hey, a Guy's Gotta Eat
description: For a typical suburban family, the monthly bills seem extravagant: $11,000 for mortgage payments, $1,600 for groceries and $1,100 for utilities.

title: The Other Shotgun In an Oil Marriage?
description: What's really behind Exxon's takeover of Mobil? ''Exxon was insanely jealous of Mobil's sponsorship of 'Masterpiece Theater' and its lock on a part of the Times Op-Ed page,'' joked Herbert Schmertz, former vice president for public affairs at Mobil. ''They were willing to pay $80 billion to get their hands on it, and you know what? It's a good deal for them.''

title: Urgently Needed: A Party
description: MICHAEL RAPAPORT grimaced, hunching over the mahogany bar at the Front, a new lounge in TriBeCa. The oversize armchairs and mismatched couches were empty -- worrisome for the 27-year-old actor, since he is a part owner of the bar, which opened on Warren Street in October.

title: Trying Out the Eye of An Eagle
description: CLOSE in a little tighter, and we'll make a pass to the left,'' the director, Jeff Poretsky, instructed the cameraman, Keith Feldman, as the crew embarked on one more session of Westchester-Fairfield County Geography 101. The image of the Castle at Tarrytown glided by on a monitor, and a passenger realized that after seeing the mansion perched on a hilltop for years, it actually sits on a ridge, one of those protrusions that makes east-west travel in the area such an adventure.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: THE GOLDEN BOOKS FAMILY TREASURY OF POETRY. Selected and with a commentary by Louis Untermeyer. Illustrated by Joan Walsh Anglund. Golden Books. $24.95. (All ages) Here's a reissue of the exuberant collection of over 400 poems and commentary first published in 1959. Today's parents and grandparents may remember it with affection. Allowing for the omission of work from the last 30 years, it remains a generous and satisfying sampler menu of all kinds of poetry for browsing throughout childhood.

title: HOFFA WILL LEAD TEAMSTERS AFTER CHIEF RIVAL CONCEDES
description: James P. Hoffa won election today to the presidency of the teamsters' union, the job that his powerful father held for more than a decade, after the younger Hoffa's main opponent conceded defeat.

title: Foreigner Seeking Entry Gets Insulting Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: 60 Nations Prepare for Kosovo Mission
description: Diplomats from 60 countries meeting here this week pushed to speed the deployment of 2,000 monitors to Kosovo province in Serbia.

title: In the Region/ New Jersey; Converting the Former Revlon Complex in Edison
description: FOR the last 40 years the Revlon Corporation has owned a 63-acre complex in the heart of the Middlesex County township of Edison, which includes the cosmetics giant's worldwide research and development center.

title: Gyroscopic Vision Alters Perspectives
description: CLOSE in a little tighter, and we'll make a pass to the left,'' the director, Jeff Poretsky, instructed the cameraman, Keith Feldman, as the crew embarked on one more session of Westchester-Fairfield County Geography 101. The image of the Castle at Tarrytown glided by on a video monitor, and a passenger realized that after seeing the mansion perched on a hilltop for years, it actually sits on a ridge, one of those bony protrusions that makes east-west travel in the area such an adventure.

title: Where the Boards Meet
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Port Morris, Melrose, Mott Haven; meetings usually on last Thursday of month, but next meeting is Dec. 17, 6:30 P.M., Lincoln Hospital, 234 East 149th Street (Conference Room 6); (718) 585-7117. Chairman: George Rodriguez; District Manager: Cedric L. Loftin.

title: Nov. 29-Dec. 5; Good News for Makers Of Silicone Implants
description: The long battle over the safety of silicone breast implants took a new turn when a panel of four scientists appointed by a Federal court reported that there was no evidence the implants caused disease.

title: And the Rich Get Richer
description: When it comes to initial public offerings, the word ''unprofitable'' seems to be excused by the word ''Internet.'' Add Barry Diller, the media impresario, to the list of beneficiaries of the suspension of disbelief, which appears to fuel stock trading related to things on line.

title: New York -- A warm Irish welcome just a stroll from Grand Central
description: There was something festive about the Fitzpatrick Grand Central in New York when I arrived on a recent Tuesday night. The guests chatting in the lobby looked so pretty, dressed in party-quality black, surrounded by gleaming mahogany and brass. They sounded pretty, too, in a blend of British and Irish voices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, DORA (NEE BAUM)
description: WEISS-Dora (nee Baum). Age 90 on December 4, 1998. Beloved sister of Frederick Baum and Ruth Goldsmith. Devoted aunt to John, Ann, Dennis and Barbara. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the United Hebrew Geriatric Center, New Rochelle, NY.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 6, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Word for Word/Pearl Harbor Diary; 'The Grace of God and the Mailed Fist': A Calm Sunday Abruptly Shattered
description: AS the years pass, the number of survivors of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor dwindles. The strike, on the quiet Sunday morning of Dec. 7, 1941, killed 2,403 of the 65,000 people stationed at the base.

title: Children's Books; Good Will Toward Cobtown, 1845
description: Only Scrooge could resist this elaborately packaged plum pudding of a picture book, A COBTOWN CHRISTMAS: From the Diaries of Lucky Hart (Doubleday, $15.99; ages 5 and up), by Julia Van Nutt, illustrated by Robert Van Nutt. It purports to be an 1845 diary written by one Lucky Hart (there's also a character called Fliberty Jibbert), which details the exciting revels and events that lead up to Christmas Day in the little hamlet of Cobtown. Will the gift Lucky has ordered from Ploomajiggy for her Mama arrive in time? Will the townspeople discover the identity of the lost blind man who keeps on muttering about ''nine donkeys''? Will the dog with the hurt paw -- bound up by Lucky's Aunt Heddy, who keeps a wild pig as a pet -- find a good home? Luckily for the reader, Lucky herself, who's all set to sing for the whole town on Christmas (if the busted organ is fixed), is funny and dear. ''There are other things I'd rather do than memorize the new hymn,'' she confides to her diary, and then supplies a list, which includes ''eating Christmas cookies'' and ''baking more Christmas cookies (I ate all the first ones).'' A rustic Mrs. Beeton, Lucky also supplies a recipe for Snow Cream (''be sure to use only clean snow'') and an illustrated lesson in how to make pomander balls.

title: What Kind of Growth Is in Store for Myrtle Beach?
description: FROM his desk on the top floor of the Founders Building, Douglas P. Wendel can look out over the expanse of high-rise hotels that makes up Myrtle Beach.

title: Singer of Irish Songs Bridges Old and New
description: CATHIE RYAN, a singer of both traditional Irish and contemporary music, has been away from her home in South Salem almost every weekend of the last four months, and instead of tending her garden she has been on a circuit of outdoor festivals, theaters and performance spaces to promote the release of her second and latest CD, ''The Music of What Happens.''

title: Office Christmases, Grinch by Grinch
description: If the mail is any guide, Charles Dickens was surely writing from life when he created Ebenezer Scrooge, who threatened Bob Cratchit with the loss of his livelihood on Christmas Eve. There seems to be something about the season that brings out the beast in many a manager.

title: Nov. 29-Dec. 5; Painful Truth, Painful Lie
description: If the Congressional impeachment inquiry into President Clinton's sex life accomplishes nothing else, it afforded Pam Parsons a heartfelt opportunity to apologize for committing perjury by lying about her sex life as a lesbian. ''Anything that I ever denied about myself was what created a spiraling journey through hell,'' Ms. Parsons told the House Judiciary Committee. Her appearance was designed by the Republicans to prod greater public outrage over the President's sex-and-mendacity scandal by showing that ordinary Americans suffer jail time for lying.

title: Seasonal Music Abounds
description: A 10-YEAR-OLD violinist, a Christmas duo, a classical trio and a tuba quartet, not to mention choral cheer and operatic tragedy: that is just part of what is on today's schedule. At 10 A.M. the St. Andrew's Singers, with soloists and an instrumental ensemble conducted by David Ralph, perform Bach's ''Magnificat'' in White Plains Presbyterian Church.

title: DEALS AND DISCOUNTS
description: TWO FOR ONE AT SEA -- Norwegian Cruise Line has a Two for One promotion on various seven-day sailings of four ships. Passengers must book by Dec. 31 to receive the discount of 50 percent off brochure rates. The promotion is good on the Norwegian Sea's cruises departing Houston for Mexico and Honduras from Jan. 3 through March 7 as well as March 28 through May 23; 11 of the Norwegian Wind's western Caribbean itineraries from Miami; 7 of the Norway's eastern Caribbean cruises from Miami, and 6 of the Norwegian Dream's southern Caribbean itineraries from San Juan. Except for those on the Norwegian Sea, all the discounted sailings are from January through March. The ships range in size from the 1,518-passenger Norwegian Sea to the 2,032-passenger Norway. With the discount, rates start at $599 a person, double occupancy, on the Norway; $745 on the Norwegian Dream and the Norwegian Wind, and $789 on the Norwegian Sea. Rates are cruise-only; flights are additional. For more information and reservations: (800) 327-7030 or (305) 436-0866. On the Internet: www.ncl.com.

title: How the Aging Post-Deb Meets Her Match (Shh! Don't Tell)
description: WHAT'S an aging, still-single former deb to do? The traditional route to marriage for many social types brought up in the world of debutante balls and Southampton summer houses is to meet a mate through introductions by friends or family or at country-club parties and black-tie charity affairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMAN, ELI H.
description: KRAMAN-Eli H. Age 81, on December 4, 1998. He will be remembered for his talent as a painter. He bore his final illness with great dignity and courage. Beloved husband of Esther. Loving father of Nadine, Cynthia and father-in-law of Abbot Genser. Dear brother of Al. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st Street, Sunday December 6, 11 AM. Interment to follow at New Paltz Rural Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to Jacob Perlow Hospice, c/o Beth Israel Hospital.

title: A Pathbreaking Partnership in a New Dimension
description: IN 1976 the composer Philip Glass and the theater maker Robert Wilson unveiled ''Einstein on the Beach,'' an opera that expanded the horizons of musical theater. It was nearly five hours long with no intermission, no plot, no narrative and a sung text that consisted entirely of numbers and solfege syllables.

title: Lives; The Catbird Seat
description: I wasn't in a hurry to get back to my hospital room, but I had a lot on my mind. I was adjusting to my new fate, quadriplegia. Besides, I had been waiting at least three minutes for the elevator, which in teen-age time is three years. When I heard the ding, I dashed into the car, unintentionally cutting off the handful of other riders.

title: Mingle Belles
description: For $350, Anetta Nowosielska can guarantee at least one pretty face for your office Christmas party. In September, Ms. Nowosielska, a Polish-born model, started Mostess, a service offering models as an alternative to the cater waiter at parties.

title: Why Not Yell Out Starr's Innocence?
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Briefs; Telephone Schemes
description: The District Attorney's office is alerting consumers to a continuing telephone scheme. Residents and businesses have been receiving calls from people who say they are AT&T service technicians who are testing a phone line. They ask the person who is called to punch the 9 button, the 0 and the ''pound'' key and hang up. According to the District Attorney's office, that procedure enables the caller to charge long-distance calls to the unsuspecting customer.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Once Again, Jets' Lewis Is a Force; Aggressive Ways Return Under Parcells's Tutelage
description: Mo Lewis didn't make any early-morning trips to Queens last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELBERG, SADIE
description: EDELBERG-Sadie. At age 100. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Devoted mother of the late Saul Edelberg and Lorraine and Jerry Sadler and daughter-in-law Lillian. Cherished grandmother of Susan, Charles, Carole, Karen and Andrew and great-grandmother of David, Amanda and Stephanie. Services Sunday 1PM at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Myrtle Ave, 78 St, Glendale, Queens, N.Y.

title: Eight Million Stories Out There . . .
description: In a cramped, windowless office in one of the former factory buildings on Thomson Avenue that house La Guardia Community College, Michael Blaine, surrounded by cardboard boxes of manuscripts, hunts for the perfect New York story.

title: On an East Side Block, Something New in the Mix
description: What's missing from a block that has three Italian restaurants, a Japanese sushi spot and an American bar and grill? Maybe Marco Colantonio answered the question by opening a French bistro, Steak au Poivre, two weeks ago at 1160 First Avenue (between 63d and 64th Streets). Steak au Poivre sits next to one of those Italian restaurants, Uzie & Marco's, of which Mr. Colantonio is an owner.

title: Miss Sirefman, Mr. Shapiro
description: Susanna Sirefman and Alexander H. Shapiro are to be married today at the University Club in New York. Rabbi Michael Paley is to officiate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHEL, LOSCHKA
description: MICHEL-Loschka. Of Whitestone, New York, and Bridgehampton, L.I. died peacefully in her sleep on November 26 at the age of 96. A well known caterer and patroness of the arts, she leaves a wide circle of friends and aficionados. Married to the late Maximilian Michel. She is survived by her son, Frank Michel, her son and daughter-in-law Henry and Mary Elizabeth Michel and three loving granddaughters, Eve Musette Michel-Milanese, Alix Michel, Ann Elizabeth Michel-Wilde and greatgranddaughter Ava Elizabeth Milanese. A memorial service will be planned for spring 1999. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, New York 11920.

title: Kerry O'Connell, Michael Tepedino
description: Kerry Virginia O'Connell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. O'Connell of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael Joseph Tepedino, the son of Jacqueline Tepedino of Brooklyn and the late Joseph Tepedino. The Rev. Dennis Keane performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: Everyone Wants a Piece of Ades: This Piece
description: IN the second act of Thomas Ades's opera ''Powder Her Face,'' which opens at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday, the central character -- a Duchess, anonymous but based on the Duchess of Argyll who gave Britain some widely enjoyed scandal in the 1950's -- is being interviewed. She will not, she says, speak about certain ''matters'': matters the opera has already disclosed, including the rapid social ascent that her money gained her and the lurid divorce that came when she was revealed to be treating male servants and hotel employees with too much attention.

title: Cynthia Gale, Joseph Miranda
description: Cynthia Ellen Gale and Joseph Scott Miranda were married yesterday at St. Mary's Church in Greenwich, Conn. Msgr. Frank Wissel performed the ceremony.

title: Where to Hear Holiday Music, Choral and Otherwise
description: These are some of the holiday concerts scheduled in New Jersey this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, PIERRE F.
description: SIMON-Pierre F. December 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Jacqueline Albert. Loving father of Lisette and her husband Paul Jacobs, Orville Simon and his wife Stephanie. Adoring grandfather of Alexia and Caroline Jacobs. Mr. Simon was an internationally known industrialist in the electronics and aircraft industries. A memorial service will announced at a later date.

title: Backups Help Rally Cadets; 9 Fans Are Injured in Fall
description: The 99th Army-Navy game finally ended today when cornerback Tony Coaxum intercepted the last Navy pass with three seconds left. That sealed a victory that had seemed beyond Army's reach, in a game that featured big plays -- 5 touchdowns of 49 yards or more -- but was marred by a 38-minute delay in the fourth quarter after nine spectators were injured when a railing gave way.

title: Last 3 Tenants End Eviction Fight in Chelsea
description: For nearly six years, the women fought to keep their home, a century-old low-rent Chelsea residence catering to single women, from closing its doors. Even when the eviction orders came, they refused to go.

title: Nov. 29-Dec. 5; Chinese Dissidents Held
description: Three prominent dissidents who had been trying to set up China's first opposition political party were arrested and charged with endangering state security. For the last six months, Xu Wenli, Qin Yongmin and Wang Youcai have led a small network of activists across China trying to win recognition for the China Democratic Party. Although the White House and human rights groups decried the arrests, senior Chinese officials defended them, reminding the world that China is not a multi-party political system, and angrily telling America to mind its own business. ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

title: Mexico -- A resort combines luxury with love for the environment
description: Every evening at dusk, nearly a thousand candles are lighted at the Hotelito Desconocido, a tucked-away retreat in the coastal cowboy country of western Mexico. On clear nights, with the Milky Way arching overhead and jubilant armies of fireflies glittering below, the whole resort shimmers in a near-mystical glow. After a couple of nights there, it's easy to interpret that flickering luminescence as a beacon for a new direction in hotel luxury.

title: Lockout View From the Other Side
description: Until this season, the National Basketball Association had never in its 52-year history lost a single game because of a labor dispute. As of today, the N.B.A. lockout enters its 159th day and approximately 35 percent of the 1998-99 season has already been canceled. The absence of any progress at the bargaining table is now threatening the entire season.

title: HUNTER DAN
description: ''There was G.I. Joe, there was Hulk Hogan, but there was no action figure for hunting and the outdoors,'' says Gary Harpole, co-creator of Hunter Dan, American Sportsman, the world's first deer-slaying doll. Eight inches tall, Dan comes fully loaded with a high-caliber rifle, binoculars, waterproof boots, orange hat and vest, a tree stand -- and a decidedly hip goatee. ''That idea came from my partner, Dave Ranard,'' Harpole says. ''He thought it gave him more of an outdoorsman's look.'' Dan is sold for $19.99 through Cabela's, the Nebraska-based outdoor-catalogue giant. For his part, Ranard plans to accessorize the wee huntsman. Now on the drawing board are designs for a tiny compound bow, toy deer, elk and bear for Dan to hunt and -- to keep Dan company on those cold days in the duck blind -- an as-yet-unnamed huntress.

title: The View From / Uncasville; Dinosaurs Lurk in These Woods
description: UNCASVILLE, in southeastern Connecticut, is in the heart of casinoland. But in this high-roller neighborhood a barely known attraction lurks in the woods -- a hillside of dinosaurs.

title: Glen Cove Weighs Uniforms for Its Schools
description: WHEN Jeanmarie Solomito imagines herself wearing a school uniform, the picture that comes to mind is a pleated plaid skirt and button-down blouse, similar to the typical uniform of students who attend Catholic school.

title: Our Towns; Checking Out Bordello Art In the Suburbs
description: JENNIFER BLANKEN learned about the auction from the newspaper and quickly called her friend Sunny Hersh. Furniture belonging to the woman who became notorious last summer as the Morristown Madam was being sold. Wouldn't it be fun to preview the very items that helped fire up the office-park Casanovas who had stolen off to her 20-room mansion for what her advertisements promised would be ''An Afternoon Delight''?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTOSH, PETER HARTFORD
description: McINTOSH-Peter Hartford. On November 29, 1998 in Redding, CT of Lou Gehrig's Disease (ALS). Survivors include wife Joan, sons Bruce, Keith, Alan and Duncan; brother Michael of Washington, DC; sister Joy McIntosh of Taos, NM; and two granddaughters. Predeceased by sister Karen Collins of Preston, MD. Son of Josephine Hoffman McIntosh and Allan James McIntosh of Bedford, NY. Attended Eaglebrook and Principia schools. Was an Air Force veteran and was a pilot for United Airlines. Service Christ Episcopal Church, Redding Ridge, CT, December 12, 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, ALS Assn., c/o Westport Galleries, 125 Main St., Westport, CT 06880.

title: A Show That Ends Where It Begins
description: AT the Neuberger Museum here, ''Al Loving: Color Constructs,'' an exhibition of selected paintings from the last 30 years, makes a wide loop, ending up where it begins. But the final works carry many of the developments that occurred along the way. Mr. Loving is an abstract painter whose early works show a great dedication to the formal thinking of the mid-1960's. These shaped canvases hint illusionistically at volume or three dimensions even though the surface is resolutely flat. ''Cube'' is painted as if it were the scaffolding for a solid form.

title: Here's Your Raise. Now, You Can Take the Day Off.
description: Not all bosses have big egos, big mouths and tight fists. Many are softies who will go the extra mile to help an employee, even if there is nothing in it for them. What acts of kindness, or workplace heroism, has your boss performed? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: In an Unreal City, Real Masterworks Beat the Odds
description: THIS being Las Vegas, the art gallery at Steve Wynn's new Bellagio Hotel was still open the other night at 11 o'clock, so I wandered in. Every day, I'm told, 1,800 people, which is the maximum number allowed, pay $10 to see what's in the gallery's two small rooms (dark walls, spotlights on the pictures). Half of the visitors buy the $4 audio guides narrated by Mr. Wynn.

title: The World; A War Turned Free-for-All Tears at Africa's Center
description: MOST wars in Africa since the end of colonialism have been civil wars. Even though their borders were drawn by Victorian imperialists, African states have generally kept their armies inside them, no matter how flagrantly those long-dead European males ignored tribal affinities and natural landscapes.

title: A Solomonic Landmarking Decision at Riverside Church
description: After a year of rancorous debate over whether to seek official landmark status for Riverside Church, the congregation voted last Sunday to nominate the nave and tower, completed in 1930, but not its southern wing, which was built 25 years later.

title: Rolando Alphonso, Musician And Buoyant Ska Pioneer, 67
description: Rolando Alphonso, the tenor saxophonist for the Skatalites and a major figure in Jamaican music, died on Nov. 20 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 67 and lived in New York City.

title: Annette Healey, W. Q. Dowling 3d
description: Annette Marie Healey and William Quinton Dowling 3d were married yesterday at the Bronxville (N.Y.) Reformed Church. The Rev. Dr. William L. Steele officiated, with the Rev. Leslie Merlin, a Presbyterian minister, taking part.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: Why does The New York Times persist in using the term WASP (''The Decline of WASP Reserve,'' by Charles McGrath)? Don't you realize that it is an ethnic slur? It is not only offensive, it's redundant (all Anglo-Saxons were white) and inaccurate (by the 17th century the English were predominantly Anglo-Norman). If you want to call us ANPs, be my guest. Anglo-American or English-American is preferable, however, and conforms with other usages.

title: Westchester Briefs; 'No Excuses Left'
description: On learning that a Federal judge had approved an agreement requiring the state to share the cost of building affordable homes throughout Yonkers, Diane Pearson, president of the city's branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said, ''Now there are no excuses left.''

title: Authentic Crocodile! (Or Is It Caiman?)
description: THE elegant brown belt, priced at around $275, was hanging on a rack in the men's furnishings department at Barneys New York, on 60th Street and Madison Avenue. Peter Brazaitis picked it up to take a closer look. The words genuine crocodile were stamped on the back.

title: Not All Mergers Are Created Equal
description: In these days of proliferating mergers, it's many an investor's dream: buying a stock, then picking up the paper the next day to read that the company is being bought by a rival -- for a fat premium.

title: Nationalists Oust Taipei Mayor in Vote Watched by China
description: The Nationalist Party challenger unseated Taipei's popular Mayor today in a suspenseful election that was closely watched here and abroad because of its possible effects on Taiwan's relations with mainland China.

title: Rangers Hit .500, And Keep Climbing
description: A .500 record is usually not much to brag about, so the Rangers won't, at least not much. But they can take some satisfaction with this measure of mediocrity. They have not been this good for more than a year, and they opened this season with four consecutive defeats. Yet they reached the level mark tonight at 9-9-7 with a 2-1 victory over the Ottawa Senators.

title: Buttes-Chaumont
description: To the Editor: I thought that readers might like to know that while Hollywood was still an orange grove, the Buttes-Chaumont district in Paris, described in ''A Quiet Quarter and Its Crown Jewel'' (Nov. 1), was home to one of the largest film studios in Europe.

title: BASEBALL: Sports of The Times; Thread of Hype in a Great Yarn?
description: THIS just in. Orlando Hernandez, it has been learned, did not escape Cuba as originally believed, on the fin of a shark. There is also no truth to reports that El Duque survived for days on sand and dental floss; he actually gorged himself at the news media buffet at the Caribbean baseball championships held on Anguilla Cay. Which, it turns out, is not a tiny, uninhabited island but the bustling home of a Class AAA Yankee farm team.

title: Man in the News; A Contradiction to Many: James Phillip Hoffa
description: Like his famous -- many would say infamous -- father, James P. Hoffa, the newly elected president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, is a contradiction.

title: Montreal
description: Winter takes Montreal fast and takes it hard, but that doesn't change the city's engaging style of life except to move it indoors. The streets and sidewalks remain crowded, but mostly with people sprinting through the cold to get from one warm place to another in the lively, cosmopolitan city. And hotel rates drop with the temperature.

title: Police Academy Program Should Not Continue
description: To the Editor:

title: Fantasy Machines From Technology's Dark Side
description: AT first glance, Steven Montgomery's fantasy machines resemble the images that inspired them -- metal engines rusting in Detroit junkyards and giant electrical conduits snaking along the walls of tunnels and stairwells in the subways of Lower Manhattan. Most of the machines are huge, up to six feet long, while others are quite small, less than a foot tall.

title: Along the Surf, the Fish Are Up
description: On a recent Sunday morning, a big Bronco slalomed through the sand of Gillikin's Beach. In the back seat, William Tustin, a 35-year-old construction worker from Maple Shade, near Camden, squinted through the last shreds of night and made out patch of dark water just offshore. A few birds circled overhead.

title: The Nation; Gray Area: The Sense of Congress
description: IN June, the House of Representatives voted to condemn, by name, the three white men in Texas who were charged with murdering a black man by dragging him behind a pickup truck.

title: Westchester Guide
description: A Christmas Tale

title: SHAKEN AND STIRRED
description: * The first of a series of three catalogues of limited-edition tchotchkes (knickknacks) for the end of the millennium is now available from New York's Boym Design Studio, which is exploring ''new typologies in culture-related products.'' * Items for sale include $230 sterling-silver spoons designed by a Little Rock artisan that commemorate ''stirring'' moments in the Clinton Presidency. * The ''Buildings of Disaster'' is a line of $95, 1.5-pound replicas of structures linked to famous tragedies. * Among them: the Chernobyl plant, the Alfred P. Murrah building and the Unabomber cabin. * Constantin Boym, Boym Design's co-director, says: ''Souvenirs are important cultural objects that store and communicate memories and emotions. You don't know why you want them, you just know that you do.''

title: After Deals and Signings, What's Left for Winter Meeting?
description: In the span of three days, 35 free agents signed contracts worth $225 million, and there went the winter meetings. This was in December 1992, in Louisville, Ky., and the free-agent frenzy sent officials home reeling. Never again, they said, vowing not to provide agents with that kind of opportunity in subsequent Decembers. It was like shooting fish in a barrel, the officials decided, the general managers being the overmatched swimmers.

title: BENEFITS
description: Film Premiere

title: A Spirited Susanna
description: To the Editor:

title: Pinochet Is Best Left to His Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Alsace Meets Latin America
description: Cross-cultural wine-and-food matings take an inventive turn at Mosaico, 175 Madison Avenue (33d Street). The 30-seat nuevo Latino takeout cafe offers a lovely, seldom-seen Alsace white, Albert Mann's '97 pinot auxerrois vieilles vignes (old vines), at $1.50 for a two-ounce glass and $3.75 for a five-ouncer (no bottle sales).

title: Q. & A.
description: Cameras in A Laundry Room

title: New Routes for Moving the Workers to Work, Bus Style
description: THE bus, not more traffic lanes, is the way to relieve highway congestion. Commuters will park their cars and hop on, if the bus is comfortable and convenient. So say transportation planners studying shifting travel patterns and a changing economy.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: So what if the spoiled nouveau riche want it now, the food guerrillas want it raw, the pundits want the last word and gay men want it cooing and wrapped in a receiving blanket.

title: In First Step to Democracy, Nigerians Vote
description: Five months after the death of Nigeria's longtime military dictator raised the prospect of greater political openness here, Nigerians cast ballots today for local government officers across the country.

title: 'High Above Hudson Heights'
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion Makeovers for the Truly Desperate
description: Makeovers are wasted on starlets and supermodels. Proof positive is offered six days a week on the E! channel's show ''Fashion Emergency,'' in which lavish beauty treatments are given to ordinary folks facing extraordinary fashion crises. Subjects have included a former nun assembling a flashy post-convent wardrobe, a professional wrestler looking to trade his tights for trousers and a nudist couple preparing to cover up in style for a family reunion. ''We bring fashion to the masses,'' said the show's anchor, Emme, the full-figured supermodel who teams up with two beauty specialists, Brenda Cooper and Leon Hall, to deliver on-site makeovers to the disheveled and clueless. ''Most people think fashion is only accessible to the rich, thin and elite. We show how fashion can work for anyone.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, LISA M.
description: JOHNSON-Lisa M. December 7th, 1990. Dear Mom, I will always treasure you. Hope Dad is with you. Your son, Robbie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NACHTIGAL, IRVING M., M.D.
description: NACHTIGAL-Irving M., M.D. On December 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Dr. Beatrice. Devoted father of Suzanne, Maxine and Daniel. Cherished grandfather of Katherine, Elizabeth, Kim, Ariel, Julian & Mischa. Services Sunday, 2 PM at Gutterman's Inc., 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI.

title: In His Own Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Notes; It Took Weeks, but Spitzer Gets a Party
description: It would be more than 10 days before the certification of a winner in the race for state attorney general. But that did not stop nearly 2,000 supporters of Eliot L. Spitzer from gathering at the Waldorf-Astoria last week for a ''victory party.''

title: Berlin Journal; Berlin Has a Word for Its Ambitions: English
description: The fight to be the leading newspaper of the city with ambitions to be Europe's new capital is a ferocious one, so when executives at the Berliner Morgenpost sat down recently to dream up a new advertising slogan, they thought long and hard. What they came up with was: ''Simply the Best.''

title: Pinochet Is Best Left to His Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Sometimes, Words Become Less Fleeting
description: Corporate luminaries are often invited to address the monthly breakfast meetings of the New York Venture Group, a forum for financiers, held at the Rainbow Room in New York's Rockefeller Center. Past speakers have included Michael Bloomberg, founder of Bloomberg L.P.; John Sculley, former chief of Apple Computer, and Fred Joseph, former chief of Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: The Nation: Big Time; From Trustbusters To Trust Trusters
description: TEDDY ROOSEVELT plotted the beginning of the end of John D. Rockefeller's oil empire at a secret meeting at the White House on a summer night in 1906. Surrounded by his Attorney General and other key cabinet members, he mapped out the antitrust suit against Standard Oil that prompted Henry Clay Frick, the steel baron, to complain on behalf of his fellow oligarchs, ''We bought the son of a bitch, and then he didn't stay bought.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERLE, SMITH, FOWLER
description: MERLE-SMITH-Fowler. Age 72. Of Princeton, N.J. On December 2, 1998 after courageously combatting Parkinson's Disease for 22 years. He was a graduate of Brooks School, Princeton University Class of 1952 and the Teachers College, Columbia University. He served with the U.S. Marine Corps on Iwo Jima. Taught at Punahoe School, Hawaii, served as administrator and teacher at Buckley School, NYC and later at Princeton Day School, Princeton, N.J. He is survived by his wife, Annette, daughter Margaret and brother Rev. Van S. Merle-Smith. Private service and interment will be in Keene Valley, N.Y. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Metropolitan Opera Guild, New York City.

title: Wine With Perspective
description: Cupola, Bedell Cellars, Cutchogue, 1994. (About $25.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFER, MILDRED O.
description: KAUFER-Mildred O. 96, died suddenly on December 3, 1998, at her residence in Stamford, NY. She was formerly a resident of Fairlawn, NJ, and Jamaica, Queens. She was retired from her position as Credit Manager for the New York Times Advertising Division. She is survived by her sister Florence Charlton of Greenville, NC; a brother, Edwin of Anaheim, CA; three nephews and six nieces; and many loving great and greatgreat-nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be be held Sunday, December 6, at the Trinity Lutheran Church in Stamford, NY, at 12 noon. Burial will be Monday, December 7, at the Evergreen Cemetery in Brooklyn, NY, at 1 PM. For information, contact the William A. Tari Funeral Home, Stamford, NY, 607-652-5007.

title: Jarvis Enjoys A Winning Homecoming
description: It was a homecoming of sorts for St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis, so naturally he wanted everything to go perfectly. With his mother and other family members in the stands, he wanted to walk the sideline with little anxiety, to win his first Big East game easily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARAVELLA, MICHAEL P.
description: CARAVELLA-Michael P. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Michael P. Caravella, associated with The Times from 1975, until retiring in 1976.

title: Put Caring for Students Ahead of Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLIGLER, SEYMOUR H.
