description: KLIGLER-Seymour H. On December 1, 1998. Beloved husband of Judith. Loving father of Cheryl and husband Gary, Roger and wife Cathy and Jeffrey and wife Elizabeth. Adoring grandfather of Ben, David and Laura. Loving husband of the late Gloria Kligler. Service Sun., 12:30PM at Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Qns Blvd, FH. In lieu of flowers charitable contributions may be made in his memory.

title: Nov. 29-Dec. 5; U.S. to Declassify Some Pinochet Files
description: The United States, treading into a political and diplomatic confrontation it tried to avoid, said it would declassify some Government documents on the killing and torture conducted by the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet. The decision could open ''a can of worms,'' in the words of a former C.I.A. official, exposing American knowledge of General Pinochet's crimes. The general, evicted from a London hospital, awaits the British Government's decision on whether to expel him to face charges filed in Spain. TIM WEINER

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: In Henry Hathaway's NIAGARA (1953), Marilyn Monroe's role as the wanton, cunning and dangerous wife of a neurotic war veteran (Joseph Cotten) fits her like a satin glove. The climax of the picture, when the great Niagara literally takes over the screen, is pictorially teriffic. Hathaway keeps the suspense churning with a startled Hollywood couple (Jean Peters and Casey Adams) caught up in Monroe's murderous schemings. Cotten is effective as the unhappy cuckold husband. From start to finish, the picture makes superb use of the thundering falls - Wednesday at 6 P.M. adn Midnight on AMC.

title: Row Over Recess in Road
description: Opposing outdoor recess for grade school students might seem Draconian, but neighbors of the Cathedral School, on 74th Street between First and Second Avenues, say it's a matter of quality of life.

title: On Lush Majorca, 2 Grand Choices
description: MAJORCA, the lush, mountainous island of Spain, is one of those stunningly beautiful places that are best known for who slept there. Its history always begins with a long list of occupiers -- Romans, Vandals, Christians, Moors, Spanish conquistadors, Napoleonic generals.

title: Santa's Writing Workshop
description: ''Happy Ho-Ho Holidays! It's time again for our annual holiday newsletter!'' For years that's how I'd begin our holiday newsletter, remember? Now I know better. Why? Because Debbie, the kids and I have just returned from our very first writers' workshop. It changed our lives. We'd been looking for a new family activity, and I'd heard that what photography was to divorcees in the 70's and pottery making was to active seniors in the 80's, creative writing is to the rest of us in the 90's. It's everywhere. Even the film director Francis Ford Coppola has a creative writing magazine, and a writers' workshop at his resort down in Belize.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: Perhaps Dan Savage is so flush with fatherhood that the irony (particularly in the context of the AIDS carnage) of reducing another life to an accessory or, worse, a means of communicating wealth, is lost on him (''The Baby'').

title: Garage Firm and Union Warned on Dismissed Employees
description: A Federal official said last week that his office had notified a parking garage company and a union local that it might file a civil complaint contending that they dismissed, transferred and threatened workers who were organizing for a competing union.

title: Renegade Officer Favored in Venezuelan Election Today
description: The podium rose two stories above the multitude, but ''El Comandante,'' Hugo Chavez, floated higher. Standing in a box draped to look like a balcony, raised by a mechanical lift, he swept his arm way over his head, vowing to throw out Venezuela's legendary corruption in one swift and forceful toss.

title: IN MY... SUITCASE/ROBERT M. WORSLEY
description: EVERYWHERE he goes, his Boxlight data projector goes, too. Robert M. Worsley, chief executive of Skymall Inc., a publisher of in-flight shopping catalogues based in Phoenix, spends one or two weeks a month on the road, meeting with airline executives and retailers. He learned the hard way that you can't always depend on machines provided by your hosts, so, several years ago, he began lugging around his own. A few months ago, he spent $6,000 for the Boxlight, which weighs less than 7 pounds and fits neatly into his Tumi roller bag.

title: The Dancers And Dinosaurs
description: Celebrating Alvin Ailey, the Fresh Air Fund, museun and the arts.

title: Janet Kadin, Eric Giesser
description: Janet Beth Kadin and Eric Paul Giesser are to be married this morning at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston. Rabbi Albert Axelrad is to officiate.

title: JERSEYANA; In a Town Tucked Away To the North Sits a Store Back in Time
description: Off County Road 519 sits a smattering of rundown buildings a gone-to-heaven church, several empty wooden houses and a shuttered hotel. Make a right turn and a visitor glimpses signs of life.

title: Lessons at the End of a Paintgun Barrel
description: ABOUT 30 years ago while attending New York University, Jerry Braun, 56, a Chappaqua resident, helped lead student protests against the Vietnam War. Today Mr. Braun has become an arms dealer of sorts, but true to his youthful principles the guns he sells fire only colorful pellets. He has, made one concession to age, however. He is a successful capitalist, one of the magnates of paintball, a rapidly growing sport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIMBERG, LESTER B.
description: SHIMBERG-Lester B. Beloved husband of Bernyce. Loving father of Judith Montminy (Robert) and Steven (Tara). Dearest brother of Bernice Baiman (Marvin). Cherished grandfather of Jordan, David and Ethan. Services Sunday, 2 PM, Gutterman's, Woodbury, NY.

title: Q. & A. / Gary C. Wendt; On Divorce, an Executive Responds
description: OVER the past three years, Gary C. Wendt, chairman of the GE Capital Corporation, says his private life has been made public in a fashion more in keeping with Hollywood celebrities than with corporate executives. And he is not happy about it.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / West Islip, L.I.; Beach on the Bay, Wide Range of Housing
description: WHEN Laura and Kurt Potter decided to move from Jackson Heights, Queens, and began looking for a house on Long Island, friends suggested West Islip.

title: Ornstein Gets Title Chance, Albeit on a Smaller Stage
description: An hour before the start of today's National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III semifinal, Gus Ornstein warmed up, tossing a football casually with teammates outside the locker room, just a few yards from the parking lot at Rowan University. Children tossed footballs around behind him, and fans straggled to the restrooms in front of him.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: What fun it was to read your status issue. I particularly enjoyed Johnny Apple on the Washington power circle. I found it hilarious, better than Sally Quinn in her recent Style essay in The Washington Post.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, LAWRENCE H.
description: JOHNSON-Lawrence H. December 8th, 1970. Gone 28 years but remembered with love forever. Your son, Robbie

title: Lynn Levoy, Brett Pollak
description: Lynn Amy Levoy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Levoy of Roslyn, N.Y., was married last evening to Brett Adam Pollak, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Pollak of Roslyn. Rabbi Abner Bergman officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Children's Voices Lifted in Sweet Song
description: MUSIC is always in the air in Norfolk, it seems. And in these crisp months from fall into winter in the village, the sound of crystalline young voices performs a heavenly descant to nature's bluster. The Chorus Angelicus, as the group of young singers is known, sends its sweet strains out from the Battell Chapel, situated right on the green.

title: Backtalk; Relentless Symbolism of Muhammad Ali
description: Post-Apocalypse, when Muhammad Ali's old fight videos become the graven images of a new religion based on individual reinvention, one of the sacred texts will surely be David Remnick's ''King of the World,'' a shrewd and lively retelling of Cassius Clay's two fights with Sonny Liston.

title: COVER; 'Houdini' Star Has Some Tricks of His Own
description: The muscular young man, tightly bound in iron chains, is slowly hoisted into the air, feet first. As the audience cheers and screams, he is plunged into the icy waters of the glass-walled Chinese Water Torture Cell. The cell is closed, a panel is raised to cover its glass front, and the clock starts to tick. Will Harry Houdini, master escape artist, be able to cheat death one more time?

title: Children's Books
description: HOW SANTA GOT HIS JOB

title: Landscape Designer To the Celebrated In Sunny California
description: WITH gardens covered and plants taken indoors in the Northeast, the time seems ripe for a California idyll. Southern California is often touted as a place where the weather never changes, and that's why it is sometimes called an Eden.

title: The View From /White Plains; Ritual Shopping Day On Road to Christmas
description: THERE she was in all her splendor, the $900 Collectible Barbie. With her gown of pure pink silk, 24-karat, gold-thread stitching and Austrian crystal bead work, she was indeed a pretty sight for the holidays -- albeit a sight that remained locked behind clear plastic. Not surprisingly, there were not any takers for this version of the doll at F. A. O. Schwarz at The Westchester here, even if it was one of the busiest shopping days of the year.

title: The Nation; By Any Name, It's Still C.A.S.H.
description: RICHARD NIXON'S political advisers were eerily prescient when they named his 1972 campaign organization the Committee to Re-elect the President: It wasn't too long before his critics dubbed it CREEP, a moniker that proved hard to shake, especially after the Watergate break-in.

title: BEST SELLERS: December 6, 1998
description: Weeks

title: In the Contest of Point Guards, El-Amin Comes Through
description: The big question coming into today's game between top-ranked Connecticut and eighth-ranked Michigan State was whether this would be a day of rebirth for Mateen Cleaves, last year's Big Ten player of the ear and consensus preseason all-American, or Khalid El-Amin, the pre-eminent freshman in the Big East last season.

title: Adult Day Care Center Finds New Home at Synagogue
description: Three months after city officials shuttered the Neponsit Adult Day Health Care Center because they had decided that its building and those of a nearby nursing home were unsafe, the center plans to reopen in a synagogue's gymnasium.

title: Washington Memo; Capital's Elite Mostly Shrug At Mention of Impeachment
description: Things were odd enough here when the roses started blooming in December. But then the White House started complaining that people were not paying enough attention to the possible impeachment of President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNEGAN, JOHN K.
description: FINNEGAN-John K. Of Howell, NJ. Age 87. On December 3, 1998. Formerly a teacher at Xavier High School, New York City, 20 years ago. Relatives and friends may call Sunday from 2-4 and 7-9 at Lakewood Funeral Home, 6250 Hwy. #

title: Personal Business; To Teach, Perchance to Manage
description: A MANAGEMENT course with Shakespeare as the main text? Must be a gimmick -- a way to pry M.B.A. students away from stuffy case studies for a few heady whiffs of great literature.

title: His Bangin' Is the Sound of Music
description: WHAT does a drummer in a Broadway show do on a night off? If he is Jared Crawford, who created and performs the percussion features in ''Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk,'' he drums.

title: Stop, in the Name of the Law
description: After a 10-month investigation, the Lewinsky affair has come to this.

title: It's Never Too Soon for the Squirt to Wise Up
description: THE two words that strike the most terror into the hearts of educators these days are ''core curriculum.'' This refers to the Department of Education's list of 61 skills that each New Jersey school child will have to master by the time today's fifth graders graduate in 2006.

title: New Jersey's Landfills Want the Right Stuff
description: Like New York City, New Jersey has a trash problem these days.

title: Westchester Briefs; Theater Plans Delayed
description: The announcement earlier this year that a developer would build a $100 million project, including a multiplex theater, in downtown White Plains by next year, may have been premature.

title: Bid for Hangar Withdrawn
description: In an abrupt move, the General Electric Company late last month withdrew its proposal for a hangar at the County Airport.

title: T. Rowe Price Mid-Cap Growth Fund
description: WHEN many passionate antique collectors find a prize item, they are likely to pay whatever it takes to clinch the deal. Not Brian W. H. Berghuis, manager of the T. Rowe Price Mid-Cap Growth fund. He scours the countryside and looks for the best bargains in Federal-style chests, chairs and other furniture even when traveling abroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSHMAN, JOHN C., JR.
description: CUSHMAN-John C., Jr. John Clydesdale Cushman, Jr., died November 30, 1998, in Escondido, CA. He lived in Lake San Marcos, CA, since 1981, and prior to that in Montclair, NJ, since age two. A 12th generation Mayflower descendant, Mr. Cushman was born in NYC on September 24, 1912. He graduated from Governor Dummer Academy, South Byfield, MA, in 1932, and Amherst College, Amherst, MA, in 1936. He attended Fordham Law School. Mr. Cushman joined Cushman & Wakefield, Inc., in NYC in 1936, the commercial real estate brokerage and management firm founded in 1917 by his father and uncle, respectively, John C. Cushman and Bernard Wakefield. After serving as Executive Vice President, Secretary and Director, he left in 1964 to form J.C. Cushman, Inc. Until his death, Mr. Cushman served as President and Director of D.A. Cushman Realty Corporation, a real estate ownership and management firm founded in 1830 in the Chelsea/23rd Street area of NYC by his great-grandfather, Don Alozo Cushman. Stationed in Washington, DC, Mr. Cushman served as Lt. Commander in the U.S. Navy during World War II. In NYC, he was a Director of Windsor Life Insurance Company, Director of 9th Federal Savings & Loan Association, Director and President of the Lexington First Avenue Association, Governor and Secretary of The Real Estate Board of New York, and Governor of the Army Navy Club of New York. Memberships in NYC included: the University Club, International Association of Building Owners & Managers (BOMA), The Institute of Real Estate Management (IREM) with a Certified Property Manager (CPM) designation, International Real Estate Federation, National Association of Real Estate Boards, East Side Association, and the American Arbitration Association. Other memberships included: Alpha Delta Phi, Rock Spring Club (West Orange, NJ), Secretary and Governor of Deer Lake Club (Boonton, NJ), United Fund of West Essex County (NJ), Visiting Nurse Association (San Diego), and Lake San Marcos Country Club and Lake San Marcos Yacht Club (both in Lake San Marcos, CA). Survivors include sister Anne Cushman Reynolds of Milwaukie, OR; brother Robert William Cushman of Sarasota, FL; his wife of 59 years, Florence Blauvelt Cushman of Lake San Marcos, CA; twin sons John Clydesdale Cushman III of Pasadena, CA and Louis Blauvelt Cushman of Houston, TX, and son David Goodrich Cushman of Glendale, CA; and eight grandsons, two granddaughters and one greatgrandson. Donations may be made to ''The San Marcos High School Scholarship Fund,'' in memory of Jack Cushman, for a deserving member of the golf team. Send to: c/o Bobbi Mathies, Cushman Realty Corporation, 601 S. Figueroa St, 47th flr, Los Angeles, CA 90017.

title: Vladimir Dokoudovsky, Dancer And Ballet Theater Founder, 79
description: Vladimir Dokoudovsky, a founding member of Ballet Theater, a principal dancer with the Ballets Russes troupes of the 1930's and 40's and an influential teacher in New York, died on Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Set of Chinese Boxes for the Stage
description: FORGET coherence. Just try to keep up.

title: Highway Cable Project Tests New Jersey Law on Digging
description: Until workers dug into two buried water mains next to the Garden State Parkway here on Tuesday, installation of a $488 million E-Z Pass system on New Jersey's toll roads had been going just fine. But now, after about 300,000 people in Jersey City, Hoboken and Lyndhurst spent most of Tuesday without water, the project has become a test for the state's four-year-old law intended to prevent excavators from digging into buried pipelines and cables.

title: Put Caring for Students Ahead of Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: OUT THERE: MOSCOW; There's Night Life After the Iceberg
description: REGULARS call it ''Kafe.'' Mick Jagger, who dropped in four nights in a row while in town on a concert tour this summer, referred to it as ''Jazz.'' By whatever name, the ultrahip uninhibited Jazz Kafe, which is Moscow's most-sought-out night spot, is riding out Russia's economic implosion as if the party never ended.

title: Gas Prices Unaffected; Impact on Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Something Wicked This Way Comes
description: Charles Brockden Brown

title: When Homing Pigeons Don't Go Home Again
description: SCIENTISTS, as well as homing pigeon breeders and trainers, are struggling to explain why most of the birds that competed in races over New York, Pennsylvania and Virginia in October have still not returned to their home lofts. Connecticut participants in the ancient sport say the birds' losses are adding a new and costly element of risk to their exacting sport. Among the highly specialized pedigreed pigeons known as ''race horses of the sky,'' a bird with the genes for breeding champions can command a price of $250,000.

title: The Spirit of Cruise Wear Past
description: The season's long skirts and wide trousers recall an era in which the rich were content ot be idle.

title: Adobe's Motto: 'We Do What We Want To Do'
description: WITH the bravado of youth, the Adobe Theater Company, a nonprofit troupe that prefers to spell its name in lowercase letters, shuns other unnecessary highs: high art, high-handedness and -- until their recent transfer to the 170-seat Actors Playhouse in Greenwich Village -- high overhead.

title: Yachts Nearly Too Fast to Control in Around Alone Race
description: The background noise on the telephone didn't sound like a boat at anchor, or even a marina for that matter. It was a chattering, clattering kind of sound, like people standing around wheels and brakes and asphalt. So what was Mike Golding, leader in the Around Alone race for solo sailors, doing at a go-cart park in South Africa?

title: Needles, Yarn and No. 2 Pencil
description: The boy's face was wrinkled with determination as he worked the knitting needles in his delicate fingers. While some of his third-grade classmates at the Manhattan School for Children, on 109th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue, were playing math games on Wednesday morning and some were writing, a few others, like Liam Cavadini, were knitting.

title: Is 90 Percent of Vote Suspicious? Charge Puzzles Kazakh Leader
description: With his open, unlined face, Nursultan Nazarbayev talks like a man without a care, as might any entrenched ruler of a resource-rich nation courted by world leaders.

title: A Meshing of the Upscale and Casual
description: LET'S hear two, rather than three, cheers for Old Glory, the tavern, not the flag. The new American theme restaurant, at 230 Jericho Turnpike in Floral Park (354-8185), where the Magnolia Grill had been is a collaborative enterprise between two unlikely partners, Finley's, a Huntington pub well-known for its extensive selection of beers, and Michael Meehan and Michele Brown, the executive and pastry chefs from Tupelo Honey, a cutting-edge contemporary American restaurant in Seacliff.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE best books of 1998, chosen by the eight editors of the Book Review from 25 initial nominees, are three novels, two collections of stories, three biographies, a scientific tour d'horizon and two books about slaughter -- one concerning diplomacy to end it in the Balkans and another asking why it happened and no one tried to stop it in Africa.

title: Santorini -- Friendly, secluded lodgings with cliffside views of the sea
description: When I visited the Cycladic island of Santorini in Greece last May, both the capital, Fira, and the picturesque village of Oia were already seriously crowded. If I'd stayed in either place, I would have found myself wishing that I could turn all the other visitors into lemmings and point them toward Santorini's famous multicolored cliffs along the caldera. The sea filled the great crater when a volcano blew out the center of the island around 1600 B.C.

title: Pluralism In Action: Viewpoints Born Abroad
description: AS the most densely populated county in South Jersey, Camden County has become a veritable mosaic of diversity. Demographic studies reveal a steady increase in the Asian, Pacific Islander, Hispanic and black populations. It is therefore appropriate that ''Made in America,'' an exhibition of works by 20 artists representing a broad range of ethnic, racial and cultural backgrounds, is being sponsored by the Camden County Cultural and Heritage Commission at Hopkins House here.

title: Sushi, the Japanese Fast Food, in Elmsford
description: LOVERS of sushi abound in the county and with reason: the ultimate fast food, sushi satisfies both body and mind. Where else but at a Japanese restaurant can one eat so well and feel so virtuous? Our region is fortunate in the consistently high quality of these offerings.

title: Diana Statland, Richard Friedman
description: Diana Joyce Statland and Richard Adam Friedman were married last Sunday at the Crystal Plaza, a caterer in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Alan Blaine officiated.

title: A State of Never-Ending Invention
description: MARK KOBYLENSKI and Dave Dupill of Goshen never thought of themselves as inventors, but they have always been incurable tinkerers. When they were kids they nailed a chair to a pair of water skis just to see if they could skim across a lake in a seated position. ''We've tinkered all our lives,'' Mr. Kobylenski said.

title: The World; The French Aren't Alone in Having Gall
description: WITH allies like France, does the United States really need enemies? Put another way: With allies like Britain, who needs France?

title: Claudia Cooper, C. F. Church 4th
description: Claudia Cooper, the daughter of Diane Dalzell Cooper of Lapla, N.Y., and Alexander Cooper of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Coleman Frederick Church 4th, the son of Wendy and Coleman F. Church 3d of Boston. The Rev. Malcia Rymer-Bean, a Universal Life Church minister, performed the ceremony on Guana Island in the British Virgin Islands.

title: Bradley Is Rested and Raring for Biggest of Games: Presidential Race
description: ''It's a good time to be out of Washington,'' Bill Bradley was saying two hours after he held a news conference to announce his yearning to return there as President in the year 2001.

title: Giving Thanks for a Great Fishing Year
description: At 8 o'clock on Thanksgiving morning, the green-gray ocean matched the clouds overhead, but a band of clear, intense blue circled the horizon. The westerly wind blew gently, keeping the air warmer than it had any right to be so late in the season.

title: If Sex Has Lost Its Shock Value, How About God?
description: BIBLICAL fundamentalists often dismiss gay people by claiming that ''God made Adam and Eve, not Adam and Steve.'' This remark is probably the full extent of fundamentalist repartee. About three years ago, I decided to take these hard-hearted folks at their words: What if God did make Adam and Steve, and the first lesbians as well, Jane and Mabel?

title: Hospital Departure Adds Tension
description: Dr. Linette Webb, executive director of the Harlem Hospital Center, has stepped down and been quickly replaced, and these events have heightened the continuing tensions between a troubled hospital and the local community.

title: What We Look Up To Now
description: You present no evidence that we in the real world espouse the values that you laud in your issue -- i.e., a big jeep, a swimming pool, a Viking stove, etc. One would hope that you'd cover issues of substance like history, philosophy and the arts (which you do, sometimes). Do the majority of Americans agree with your notion of the ''right'' preschool, the right car, the right clothes? I don't think so!

description: To the Editor:

description: Mo Hotta-Mo Betta: (800) 462-3220 or www.mohotta.com

title: Westchester Briefs; Bonds Downgraded
description: Moody's Investors Service has downgraded Mount Vernon's financial rating because of a falling tax base and poor tax-collection record. Saying the city's financial condition did not appear to be improving, the municipal credit research division of Moody's dropped the rating to A2 from A1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINDER, REGINA
description: FINDER-Regina. On December 3, during her 91st year, in Los Angeles, CA. Mother of Alisa and Morty Sorkin, and Miriam and Alan Compton. Grandmother of six, great-grandmother of seven. We will all miss you, Grandma. Services will be held today, 10 AM, at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave.

title: What to Tip
description: To the Editor: I have come to one conclusion: if the service is really excellent, pay for it. If the service is not so hot, do nothing. This has caused me some pain over the years but I have found it to be internally satisfying.

title: Daring to Dress
description: It could be the return of the peacock, or at least a ripple of interest in stemming the deluge of dress-down Fridays. This fall, a few men have been mixing their plaid sports jackets with vests, felt fedoras, pigskin gloves and New Age backpacks. Hamish Bowles, above, a Vogue editor, wore a colorful sports jacket each day during the recent fashion collections. They were acquired last January in London at Sotheby's sale of the extraordinary wardrobe of the late Bunny Roger, a dandy in the Edwardian style. Mr. Roger's clothes were custom tailored, from the London firm of Watson, Fargerstrom & Hughes. Mr. Bowles bought a dozen pieces, all with a silhouette completely opposite the prevailing loose-fitting Italian vogue.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article last Sunday with a report about Roth I.R.A.'s and other tax-favored savings plans misstated the rule for contributing to an Education I.R.A. for a child. Total contributions are limited to $500 a child per year, according to the Internal Revenue Service; a child cannot receive a $500 contribution from each parent.

title: Miami and James Overcome McNown
description: When Cade McNown's final pass fell incomplete in the end zone today, U.C.L.A.'s 20-game winning streak, its shot at an undefeated season and, it seemed, its hopes for a national title ended in a wild 49-45 loss to Miami.

title: The Losses Pile Up For Season Yet to Start
description: They say they are not bluffing, that the season could be terminated in the next few weeks. But as players and owners stare down each other at the bargaining table, how likely is it that the National Basketball Association's 82-game schedule will be permanently wiped away?

title: When Animals Attack, Cars Crash and Stunts Go Bad
description: It is a postcard-blue Los Angeles day, and inside Building 88 on the Fox Television Studio lot a group of executives and producers have gathered to watch videotapes of car crashes and police chases. Mike Darnell, executive vice president of specials and alternative programming for Fox, sits behind a desk. On a couch opposite sit Paul Stojanovich, owner of Pursuit Productions, an independent company that makes movies and reality-TV shows; Darnell's wife, Carolyn (a TV-awards consultant, she is here today, as on other days, to spend time with her overbooked husband); and two Pursuit producers. A few other Fox employees have pulled up chairs. Today, Pursuit is giving Darnell a first look at two works in progress, ''World's Scariest Police Chases 4'' and what will eventually become ''Surviving the Moment of Impact.''

title: If Only Stan and Ollie Were Waiting
description: THE landscape is empty, the horizon a flat, unbroken line that meets itself behind you. There is no place bleaker or more horizontal than this patch of arid earth at the edge of time. The only sign of nature is a small, spindly, leafless tree. In a moment of uncharacteristic despondency, Ollie and Stan, two fastidious tramps in ancient derby hats, decide they can't go on. Better to end it all. They will hang themselves from the tree.

title: London Home Stays With the Owner Away
description: Temporarily vacant private homes in London can be a reasonably priced and comfortable alternative to the city's hotels. Go Native, a London company, offers more than 150 fully equipped and furnished homes there, including a warehouse apartment overlooking the Thames; lofts and studios in Clerkenwell, Soho and Bloomsbury; apartments and townhouses in Chelsea, Little Venice, Knightsbridge and Notting Hill; a houseboat on the Thames, and a cottage in the former stable block of Kensington Palace. Prices range from $602 a week for a studio apartment five minutes' walk from Sloane Square, based on $1.72 to the British pound, to $4,300 a week for a five-bedroom townhouse in Chelsea. Most homes are one- or two-bedroom apartments in the $860 to $1,720 range.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, AMELIA LANGE
description: BELL-Amelia Lange. Widow of the late Elliott V. Bell. On Thanksgiving Day, November 26th at her home on Quaker Hill in Pawling, N.Y. At age 96 surrounded by her family: daughter Nancy Bell Hoving, son-in-law Tom Hoving of New York City, granddaughter Petrea Hoving Leventhal, grandsonin-law Colin David Leventhal and great-granddaughter Amelia Olga Leventhal of London, U.K. Contributions may be made to Christ Church Quaker Hill, Pawling, N.Y. 12564 or Hospice of Dutchess County, 70 South Hamilton St, Poughkeepsie, New York 12601.

title: Ferry From Tampa To the Mexican Coast
description: American Viking Lines has begun offering European-style ferry service twice a week between Tampa, Fla., and Progreso, Mexico on the Yucatan coast. The 630-passenger vessel Scotia Prince also operates as a cargo ship. It departs from Tampa on Tuesdays and Fridays and leaves Progreso on Sundays and Wednesdays. The trip takes 36 hours. Two decks carry cargo as well as passengers' cars and recreational vehicles.

title: Fire Sets Back Museum Plans For Pullman In Chicago
description: Through its storied history, the Pullman rail car factory has stood for a lot.

description: MANHATTAN

title: Ellen Devlin And Jason Sample
description: Ellen Elizabeth Devlin, a daughter of Kathleen and Edmund Devlin of Clifton, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Jason Michael Sample, the son of Grace and Jack Sample of Tewksbury, Mass. The Rev. Daniel Ulloa performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in New York.

title: Art
description: FROM VAN EYCK TO BRUEGEL: Early Netherlandish Painting in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Edited by Maryan W. Ainsworth and Keith Christiansen. (Metropolitan Museum of Art/Abrams, $75.) If there were a first prize in this column for beauty of statement and probity of elucidation, this catalogue would run away with it. The exhibition it describes is not a loan show. It has no catchpenny title. Everything pictured in it belongs to the Metropolitan Museum. Quite a few of the works come tagged as ''Workshop of,'' ''Style of,'' ''Copy after,'' ''Follower of'' or ''Attributed to.''

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES -- Portrait of the Young as Homeless
description: In past years, New York City earned a reputation as a magnet for homeless youths. But today, most experts agree that the overwhelming majority of the estimated 20,000 young people sleeping on the streets, on rooftops and in tunnels in the five boroughs are not small-town runaways. ''These kids are not from Utah,'' said Tom Bundrick, a social worker at a Times Square shelter for homeless teen-agers. ''These are the children of New York City.'' Article, page 65.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: N.J. Transit Bus Trips Ranked U.S.'s Most Costly
description: New Jersey Transit charges more per trip than any other commuter bus system in the county, according to a study conducted by a University of North Carolina professor.

title: Nov. 29-Dec. 5; Serb General Arrested
description: The arrest of a high-ranking Bosnian Serb general on charges of genocide for directing the 1995 attack on Srebrenica, in which 7,000 Bosnian Muslims were marched off, presumably to their deaths, provided a potent reminder that those responsible for the atrocities of the Bosnian civil war cannot rest easy.

title: Helping the Fish Return Upstream
description: SHAD and other anadromous fish -- even some salmon -- are back in the Connecticut River, thanks mainly to the construction of fishways that let fish get past the river's dams. But small streams with dams of their own, also matter, in a big way. Recent collaborative efforts have put fishways on lesser-known streams, and more such projects lie ahead. The plan is to boost not just the fish, but the ecosystem.

title: Study Bolsters Courts In Finding That Poor Lag Without Preschool
description: Kindergartners in New Jersey's poor urban school districts lag 18 months behind average 5-year-olds in performing simple tasks like naming colors and giving their ages, according to a study to be released this week by the Center for Early Education at Rutgers University.

title: Dolan Uses a Gentlemanly Approach to Get His Way
description: He can be quiet, cryptic, even difficult to hear during a negotiation. He grasps minute details, sees the long-term value of a deal before others, prefers listening to talking and does not mind waiting to get his way. He lets others fulminate on his behalf while he maintains his gentlemanly demeanor.

title: What We Look Up To Now

title: Time Really Is Money
description: Charities are already fretting now that Mobil, an avid patron of museums and public television, is merging with Exxon, which makes less of a splash in philanthropy circles. Now they have another merger to worry about. Sanford I. Weill, the co-chairman of Citigroup, the new financial behemoth, has chosen the charitable-giving program of his old company, Travelers Group, over the more free-spending plan at the old Citicorp. Mr. Weill prefers Travelers' money-for-time program, which makes grants only to charities where employees donate their time. Citicorp has a matching gift plan that doubles any employee's gift to a favorite charity, to the tune of $7 million in 1997. The new policy won't take effect until next year, and Citigroup promises to honor any multiyear commitments made by the old Citicorp. Mr. Weill is a big giver himself, recently pledging $100 million to Cornell Medical School. ''But he feels strongly that people should be involved, not just write checks,'' a Citigroup spokesman said. JOSEPH KAHN

title: The A.M.A.'s 'Partial Birth' Fiasco

Confronted with this finding, the organization has but one honorable path. It ought to use the gathering of its house of delegates this week in Honolulu to rescind its support for an abortion measure that intrudes on decisions best made by women and their doctors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSHMAN, JOHN C., JR
description: CUSHMAN-John C., Jr. John Clydesdale Cushman, Jr., died November 30, 1998, in Escondido, CA. He lived in Lake San Marcos, CA, since 1981, and prior to that in Montclair, NJ, since age two. A 12th generation Mayflower descendant, Mr. Cushman was born in NYC on September 24, 1912. He graduated from Governor Dummer Academy, South Byfield, MA, in 1932, and Amherst College, Amherst, MA, in 1936. He attended Fordham Law School. Mr. Cushman joined Cushman & Wakefield, Inc., in NYC in 1936, the commercial real estate brokerage and management firm founded in 1917 by his father and uncle, respectively, John C. Cushman and Bernard Wakefield. After serving as Executive Vice President, Secretary and Director, he left in 1964 to form J.C. Cushman, Inc. Until his death, Mr. Cushman served as President and Director of D.A. Cushman Realty Corporation, a real estate ownership and management firm founded in 1830 in the Chelsea/23rd Street area of NYC by his great-grandfather, Don Alozo Cushman. Stationed in Washington, DC, Mr. Cushman served as Lt. Commander in the U.S. Navy during World War II. In NYC, he was a Director of Windsor Life Insurance Company, Director of 9th Federal Savings & Loan Association, Director and President of the Lexington First Avenue Association, Governor and Secretary of The Real Estate Board of New York, and Governor of the Army Navy Club of New York. Memberships in NYC included: the University Club, International Association of Building Owners & Managers (BOMA), The Institute of Real Estate Management (IREM) with a Certified Property Manager (CPM) designation, International Real Estate Federation, National Association of Real Estate Boards, East Side Association, and the American Arbitration Association. Other memberships included: Alpha Delta Phi, Rock Spring Club (West Orange, NJ), Secretary and Governor of Deer Lake Club (Boonton, NJ), United Fund of West Essex County (NJ), Visiting Nurse Association (San Diego), and Lake San Marcos Country Club and Lake San Marcos Yacht Club (both in Lake San Marcos, CA). Survivors include sister Anne Cushman Reynolds of Milwaukie, OR; brother Robert William Cushman of Sarasota, FL; his wife of 59 years, Florence Blauvelt Cushman of Lake San Marcos, CA; twin sons John Clydesdale Cushman III of Pasadena, CA and Louis Blauvelt Cushman of Houston, TX, and son David Goodrich Cushman of Glendale, CA; and eight grandsons, two granddaughters and one greatgrandson. Donations may be made to ''The San Marcos High School Scholarship Fund,'' in memory of Jack Cushman, for a deserving member of the golf team. Send to: c/o Bobbi Mathies, Cushman Realty Corporation, 601 S. Figueroa St, 47th flr, Los Angeles, CA 90017.

title: African Dance in a Post-Modern Mode
description: Alvin Ailey's imprint on his dance company is still so strong that one often forgets how many works he commissioned from experimental choreographers who worked in styles other than his own. That is the context in which to view Judith Jamison's ''Echo: Far From Home,'' a new work that gives nonlinear narrative an original twist.

title: New Visions for NATO
description: Though NATO has played a useful role in suppressing violence in the Balkans in recent years, it remains a military alliance without a clear purpose in the wake of the cold war. Washington's answer to this identity crisis has been mischievous. First it pushed through the admission of three new members from Central Europe without adequately weighing potential consequences. Now it is pressing ideas that could ultimately lead to transforming the alliance into a global strike force against threats to American and European interests. Such a role would go far beyond any sensible mandate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANOS, MARGARET MACDONALD

Beloved mother of the late John Boyd, Maria Govier and Theonie White. Loved mother-in-law of Robert Govier and Howard White. Sister of Isabel Milliken of Canada. Cherished grandmother of Glenn and Cliff Govier, John and W. Gordon Boyd of Scotland and Theonie Mackovinyi of South Africa. Great-grandmother to David (deceased) and Alison Boyd, Claire Mackovinyi and Joshua Govier. She was loved by all who knew her. Her sense of humor brought joy to those around her. She brought a ray of sunshine into every life she touched. She will be greatly missed. The family will receive friends at the Riverdale Funeral Home, Broadway and 214th Street, on Tuesday, December 8, 1998, 2 PM to 4 PM and 7 PM to 9 PM. Funeral service will be Wednesday, December 9, at 10 AM, at the Riverdale Funeral Home, followed by interment at Ferncliff Cemetery, Ardsley, New York. title: The Strauss of 'Don Juan,' But a Horn Concerto, Too
description: When the New York Philharmonic announced this current season a year ago, some of us raised our eyebrows at the prospect of two entire programs of Richard Strauss. Well, our eyebrows were wrong. The first of those programs, given on Thursday night, was strongly played and strongly conducted by Kurt Masur. It was also strongly planned. The first half began with ''Don Juan,'' an excellent big overture, and the second with ''Death and Transfiguration,'' the tone poem that came right after ''Don Juan'' and starts out with similar themes. Then ''Death and Transfiguration'' itself was recalled in the ''Four Last Songs,'' gorgeously sung by Deborah Voigt.

So when Mr. Turner, now vice chairman of Time Warner Inc., announced late last year that he planned to donate $1 billion to the United Nations over the next decade, many wondered if the philanthropic gesture would turn out to be all talk.

title: Downsizing Comes Back, but the Outcry Is Muted

She helped to counsel fellow workers through their shock. She used her $13,000 in severance to pay off a car loan. And once the plant shut in April, she enrolled as an accounting student -- hoping to one day get back to her old wage of $10.60 an hour.

Her medical plan does not cover infertility treatments, she owes her doctor almost $10,000 and she can afford to pay only a few hundred dollars a month to retire the debt. Thus, he has refused to continue treating her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, ABRAHAM.
description: FEINBERG - Abraham. The Schneider Children's Medical Center of Israel (SCMCI) and Medical Development for Israel, Inc. are deeply saddened at the loss of one of their staunchest supporters. Abe Feinberg has been a valued friend of the Schneider Children's Medical Center since its very beginning. Recently, Abe and Lillian Feinberg established the Dr. E. Richard Feinberg Department of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at SCMCI in memory of their late son Richard. It was Abe's idea to perpetuate the ideals of his son's work by providing help to children who suffer from mental anguish. Abe Feinberg was a giant who made an indelible mark on the history of the state of Israel. His charitable endeavors will continue to make his presence felt for many years. The entire staff of the Schneider Children's Medical Center of Israel and the Board of Directors and staff of Medical Development for Israel express sincere condolences to his wife Lil, his daughter Dr. Judith Schneider, his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Abe will be sorely missed and his memory will always be cherished. Medical Development for Israel, Inc. H. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEFFREYS, JEFFREY M
description: JEFFREYS-Jeffrey M. This is a big one, friends. Jeff has died at 59, on December 3, 1998, at his home in Greenwich Village. He had cancer, but the end was fairly quick as these things go. (Jeff did tend to disapprove of pain and suffering except at the opera.) Born in Iowa, he came to NYC in 1957 and only left it to serve as a Navy Medical Corpsman or for his many trips abroad. He worked mostly as a theatre treasurer and had been at Radio City Music Hall since 1992, but sometimes he performed, notably in 1973 in Jean Dubuffet's ''Coucou Bazar'' in NY and Paris, and with ''Liquid Theatre'' at the Guggenheim. A charismatic and charming guy, he had a passion for two islands, Manhattan and Vieques. He will be much missed in both. Officially survived by his sister, Joan J. Mayer of Falkville, AL. Jeff has a large family of friends, and though final arrangements are private, there will be a memorial TBA. Donations to Broadway Cares/EFA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTOSH, ANDREW D.
description: McINTOSH-Andrew D., Jr. 90. Died Sunday, Dec. 6th at his home on Looking Glass Hill, Bantam, CT. Mr. McIntosh was born in Malden, MA, 27 August 1908, son of the late Andrew D. McIntosh, Sr. and Mary K. McIntosh. His father was formerly Dean of the Taft School. He was the husband of Jennie Clarke Arnold McIntosh who died in 1989. Mr. McIntosh was a graduate of the Taft School and Yale University, Class of 1931. He was with New York Telephone Co. in Albany and N.Y. City from 1932 to 1942 when he took military leave and was commissioned a 2nd Lieutenant in the Army Air Corps where he served until 1946, and then as a Major in the Air Force Reserve until 1956. He transferred to the Southern New England Telephone Co. in 1946 and retired in 1973. He was a member of Squadron A. in N.Y. City and the Sanctum in Litchfield, CT. His sister, Mrs. Clay Goodloe Barry, Alexandria, VA died in 1985. He is survived by a cousin, Donald McIntosh, Hinsdale, IL, Mrs. McIntosh's brotherin-law, Alexander W. Keer, Lawrenceville, NJ, and two nephews, Carrington Beach Day, Saginaw, MI, and Frederick Talmadge Day, Montreal, Canada. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Bantam on Dec. 19th, 3 p.m. Interment will be in the Bantam Cemetery. There are no calling hours. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Paul's Church, Bantam, CT. For information Rowe Funeral Home, 283 Torrington Rd., Litchfield.

More chunks along with comets continued to bombard the planet's growing mass, according to this view, bringing with them one of the earth's most basic materials: water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSHMAN, JOHN C.
description: CUSHMAN-John C., Jr. John Clydesdale Cushman, Jr., died November 30, 1998, in Escondido, CA. He lived in Lake San Marcos, CA, since 1981, and prior to that in Montclair, NJ, since age two. A 12th generation Mayflower descendant, Mr. Cushman was born in NYC on September 24, 1912. He graduated from Governor Dummer Academy, South Byfield, MA, in 1932, and Amherst College, Amherst, MA, in 1936. He attended Fordham Law School. Mr. Cushman joined Cushman & Wakefield, Inc., in NYC in 1936, the commercial real estate brokerage and management firm founded in 1917 by his father and uncle, respectively, John C. Cushman and Bernard Wakefield. After serving as Executive Vice President, Secretary and Director, he left in 1964 to form J.C. Cushman, Inc. Until his death, Mr. Cushman served as President and Director of D.A. Cushman Realty Corporation, a real estate ownership and management firm founded in 1830 in the Chelsea/23rd Street area of NYC by his great-grandfather, Don Alozo Cushman. Stationed in Washington, DC, Mr. Cushman served as Lt. Commander in the U.S. Navy during World War II. In NYC, he was a Director of Windsor Life Insurance Company, Director of 9th Federal Savings & Loan Association, Director and President of the Lexington First Avenue Association, Governor and Secretary of The Real Estate Board of New York, and Governor of the Army Navy Club of New York. Memberships in NYC included: the University Club, International Association of Building Owners & Managers (BOMA), The Institute of Real Estate Management (IREM) with a Certified Property Manager (CPM) designation, International Real Estate Federation, National Association of Real Estate Boards, East Side Association, and the American Arbitration Association. Other memberships included: Alpha Delta Phi, Rock Spring Club (West Orange, NJ), Secretary and Governor of Deer Lake Club (Boonton, NJ), United Fund of West Essex County (NJ), Visiting Nurse Association (San Diego), and Lake San Marcos Country Club and Lake San Marcos Yacht Club (both in Lake San Marcos, CA). Survivors include sister Anne Cushman Reynolds of Milwaukie, OR; brother Robert William Cushman of Sarasota, FL; his wife of 59 years, Florence Blauvelt Cushman of Lake San Marcos, CA; twin sons John Clydesdale Cushman III of Pasadena, CA and Louis Blauvelt Cushman of Houston, TX, and son David Goodrich Cushman of Glendale, CA; and eight grandsons, two granddaughters and one greatgrandson. Donations may be made to ''The San Marcos High School Scholarship Fund,'' in memory of Jack Cushman, for a deserving member of the golf team. Send to: c/o Bobbi Mathies, Cushman Realty Corporation, 601 S. Figueroa St, 47th flr, Los Angeles, CA 90017.

title: Weak Bones Among Men Are Linked To Estrogen
description: New research is challenging the medical textbook view of osteoporosis as largely a women's disease linked to the singularly female experience of menopause. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRIMAL, CHARLES E.
description: DRIMAL-Charles E. CLU, ChFC, MSFS. Insurance Industry leader and General Agent emeritus of The Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company died Saturday, December 5, 1998 at Christ Hospital in Cincinnati, Ohio while visiting his daughter. At his side, as always, was his beloved wife Juanita and family. Mr. Drimal was born October 22, 1918 in Astoria, was a long time resident of Valley Stream, NY and was currently residing in Manhattan. He graduated from New York University in 1949, and received his Masters of Financial Services from The American College in 1980. In his career he served as a Captain in the U.S. Army Corps 1942-1946, as President of the NY Society of Financial Service Professionals, President of NY Chapter of GAMA International, the Penn Mutual Agency Association, Chairman of the New York Round Table and a founder of the New York Center of Financial Services. Charles E. Drimal was a business and community leader extraordinaire helping over 100 Insurance Professionals establish their careers. The Charles E. Drimal, CLU, ChFC Bridgebuilder Award was established in his honor. He was a leader by example committed to professionalism, ethics, continuing education and helping thousands of families prepare for a lifetime of financial well being. Mr. Drimal was constantly recognized for his guidance and charitable service to The Holy Trinity Episcopal Church of Long Island, the Variety Boys and Girls Club of Astoria, The National Hypertension Association, Inc. and The American College. He is survived by his wife Juanita and three loving children; Lynn Lippert and son-in-law Wayne of Cincinnati, Ohio, Charles E. Jr. and daughter-in-law Sandra, Craig and daughter-in-law Arlene both of Connecticut and thirteen grandchildren. Visitation will be Tuesday evening December 8th from 5:00 to 8:00 PM at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, Brooklyn Avenue and Seventh Street, Valley Stream, Long Island. A Memorial Service will be held Wednesday, December 9, 1998 from 7:00 to 8:00 PM at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to any of the above mentioned charitable organizations.

description: EVERY day, the runoff from 31 states and two Canadian provinces washes past Juarine Wallace's simple blue house in a drainage ditch that is better known as the Mississippi River. Snow melt, rainwater, agricultural chemicals, ground water -- in all, 41 percent of the runoff in the United States passes en route to New Orleans and, finally, the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWASSER, JEAN SHIRLEY
description: TOWASSER-Jean Shirley (nee Monck). Died in her bed on November 24, 1998, in her home in Riverside, CT. Beloved wife to the late David E. Towasser. Ceaselessly devoted and loving mother to Nicholas Towasser. A memorial service will be held on December 12, at 2 PM at Gallagher's Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St, Stamford, CT. Born in Northumberland, England on May 11, 1930. Shirley attended King's College, University of Durham. She wrote for The Guardian (Manchester) and The Observer (London). She came to the United States in 1960, and was a researcher for Time. Beginning in 1967, she devoted her time to raising her newly born son. She returned to her editorial career in the early 1980's as a researcher for Vanity Fair and later for House & Garden. She retired in 1993, and for several years worked as a fund raiser for Carnegie Hall. Never, never was there a woman of greater integrity, wit, wisdom and beauty. A generous woman, Shirley was quick to help both friend and stranger alike. Donations in her memory can be made to Housing Works and to God's Love We Deliver. Her son deeply misses the loss of his mother and best friend.

title: Exercising the Heart in Smaller Doses
description: Shoehorning exercise into the schedule by doing small amounts several times a day improves fitness as much as a single daily workout of the same total time, according to research in the last few years. Now, a new report says that the multiple-dose plan also helps lower blood fats -- which are associated with heart disease -- as much as a one-shot session.

title: Fumbled Calls on the Football Field
description: Even the most die-hard Jets fan knows that the team's come-from-behind victory over the Seattle Seahawks on Sunday was outright robbery -- a gift not from the deity, as the Jets coach, Bill Parcells, would have it, but from a linesman whose eyes or mind must have wandered. Vinny Testaverde clearly came up short when he tried a quarterback sneak in the final seconds, but an official signaled a touchdown, even though video replays showed that the ball never crossed the goal line. Seattle's hopes of making the playoffs were shattered, and the Jets' hopes of winning the division remained intact.

description: Two hundred years ago the Rev. Thomas Robert Malthus, an English economist and mathematician, anonymously published an essay predicting that the world's burgeoning human population would overwhelm the Earth's capacity to sustain it.

title: Long a Supporting Voice, Now Owning the Spotlight
description: Women showed up to sing along with Kelly Price at the Apollo Theater on Saturday night. They sang when her voice was heard from backstage; they sang in place of absent guest singers from her album, ''Soul of a Woman'' (Island). Even with the band drowning them out, they sang for themselves and to show solidarity with the character Ms. Price plays in her songs: a woman who's too loving for her own good.

title: Treatments Offer Promise for Embarrassing Ailment
description: For the last decade, Susan, a Long Island businesswoman who recently turned 50, has been plagued by an annoying and potentially humiliating problem: She has to empty her bladder a dozen or more times a day and several times a night, or risk an embarrassing accident. When she has to go, she has to go, and soon. Fortunately, Susan is not shy about seeking out lavatories wherever she may be.

title: Union Leaders Got $382,000 With Ouster
description: Two labor officials forced from top posts in the city's largest municipal union after admitting they knew of fraud in the union's 1996 contract vote were paid a total of $382,000 by the union when they resigned last month, union officials said yesterday.

title: Soaring Prices Spur a Revolt in Scientific Publishing
description: Esoteric and highly technical, scientific journals have never been viewed as a hot publication market. In recent years, however, scientific journals have become big business, with large commercial publishers entering a scene once dominated by nonprofit scientific societies whose only goal was to disseminate scientific information. It is a change that many academics say has sent prices skyrocketing -- with some journals now costing libraries more than $15,000 a year.

title: TORSTAR INCREASES CASH PORTION OF BID FOR SUN MEDIA
description: The Torstar Corporation, publisher of The Toronto Star, Canada's biggest newspaper, increased its offer yesterday for the Sun Media Corporation by 16.6 percent, to $19.34 (Canadian) a share in cash and stock. Torstar is offering $14.75 in cash and 0.25 of a class B nonvoting share for each share of Sun Media, Canada's No. 2 newspaper chain. It will also assume about $400 million in debt. Torstar's new bid represents an increase of $2.75 a share in the cash portion of its Oct. 28 offer, which Sun Media directors rejected as too low. Torstar fell 85 cents, to $17.50, on the Toronto Stock Exchange, where Sun Media rose $1.30, to $18.70. The cash and stock portion of the deal is now valued at $908 million (Canadian), or about $592 million (United States).

title: A President Without a Plan
description: Between them, the White House and the House Judiciary Committee seem determined to have a constitutional collision. An act of leadership by the Republicans' designated Speaker, Robert Livingston, could avoid the impending crisis, but Mr. Livingston does not appear to have the stuff for it. The other way to avoid it would be for Mr. Clinton to start behaving like a President instead of a criminal defendant. Over the next two days we will see whether Mr. Clinton has the stuff for that.

Wells, retired reader in zoology at Cambridge University, one of the world's great experts on cephalopods and author of the just released, ''Civilization and the Limpet'' (Perseus, $22), can speak for hours about the wonders of cuttlefish, squids and octopuses -- his specialty and great passion. He held forth on a recent November afternoon in his sprawling 17th century house in Cambridge, England, while his wife, Joyce, put together a supper of steamed vegetables and cheese.

Properly placed and stretched, the pause can generate suspense, contemplative sadness and of course that Pinteresque sense of unknown menace. It is usually anticipatory or, to use the adjective that is the pause's frequent and hoary companion, pregnant.

title: No Depression? Fun With a (Musical) Purpose
description: ''We're from the big West,'' announced the singer and multi-instrumentalist Gary Louris in a put-on cowboy drawl during Golden Smog's show at Irving Plaza on Saturday night. This six-man posse is indeed based in parts west of New York, but not in sagebrush country. Its turf is Minneapolis, home to some of the most exciting underground rock bands of the past two decades and as some of those rockers have settled into less frenetic styles, to the current exploration of American roots music known as No Depression.

title: LAKELAND BANCORP IN DEAL FOR HIGH POINT FINANCIAL
description: Lakeland Bancorp agreed yesterday to buy the High Point Financial Corporation for about $68 million. High Point, a commercial bank based in Branchville, N.J., said its shareholders would receive 1.2 Lakeland shares for each of High Point's 3.8 million shares outstanding. Shares of High Point rose 15 percent, or $2, to $15.375. Shares of Lakeland, which is based in Oak Ridge, N.J., rose 25 cents, to $15.75. High Point said it did not expect any large-scale layoffs as part of the acquisition. The combined assets will be about $770 million.

title: Ms. Reno Undermines Justice
description: One of the sorriest episodes in modern Justice Department history has concluded with another demonstration of Attorney General Janet Reno's obstinacy. For the third time in a month, she has refused to hand her department's anemic investigation into President Clinton's 1996 campaign abuses over to an independent counsel. Both the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Justice's top prosecutor for campaign finance urged her to appoint an independent counsel under the part of the law allowing an Attorney General to avoid conflicts of interest. Although she is mired in conflict, Ms. Reno decreed that no one would be appointed to investigate whether her boss illegally used ''soft money'' to support his re-election. Congress now has a duty to demand an inquiry run by someone not beholden to Mr. Clinton.

title: Girl in Abuse Case Is Brain Dead; Relatives Say State Failed to Help
description: A 4-year-old Newark girl in an abuse case was declared brain dead yesterday, and relatives of the girl said the case had been improperly handled by New Jersey officials who had ignored or failed to respond to their calls for help.

I did just that one recent weekend: in a little valley approximately four miles from our home, we walked a trail along a creek that led to an old-growth cedar grove, where my 2-year-old daughter hovered admiringly over a very beautiful banana slug.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZASLOW, MICHAEL
description: ZASLOW-Michael. The Board and Staff of The Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Association, Greater New York Chapter, deeply mourn the passing of our courageous friend Michael Zaslow. Since the day of his diagnosis with ALS (Lou Gehrig's disease), Michael dedicated the strength of his celebrity to mobilizing the print and broadcast communities in spreading awareness of this horrific disease. An admiring media rallied behind Michael, who was supported by his wife Susan Hufford, his family, his longtime television ally Brynn Thayer, an endless list of friends and fans and the ALS Association. Michael's efforts reached untold millions and put him second only to Lou Gehrig himself in raising awareness of ALS. It is with deep appreciation that the Greater New York Chapter salutes this magnificent man whose work will remain as an inspiration to all of us. John L. Ernst Chairman of the Board Dorine Gordon, President Lauri Novick, Executive Director

title: In Peru's Shantytowns, Cholera Comes by the Bucket
description: UP in the Pampas de San Juan de Miraflores, a shantytown sprawled over the arid mountainsides south of this city, Natalia Choccna Flores, who is 4, tells a public health official that she has diarrhea. title: State Curbs Warhol's Foundation
description: After a long investigation of the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts in response to allegations of waste and mismanagement, the State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, announced yesterday that the foundation would have to comply with strict new financial controls. The controls include forming an audit committee, hiring a new chief financial officer and introducing tighter accounting and bookkeeping procedures. The foundation must also open its books to the Attorney General's office for review four times a year rather than annually.

title: Central Bank in Taiwan Cuts Interest Rates Again
description: The central bank of Taiwan cut interest rates yesterday for the fourth time in five months, reducing the benchmark rediscount rate to its lowest level in 12 years. The Central Bank of China lowered two interest rates by a quarter-point each. The rediscount rate was cut to 4.75 percent from 5 percent, and the accommodation rate was cut to 5.125 percent from 5.375 percent, both effective today. The two rates were last reduced on Nov. 12, each by an eighth of a point.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON ENDS COLLABORATION WITH ERGO
description: Johnson & Johnson has terminated its collaboration agreement with the Ergo Science Corporation on products to treat Type 2 diabetes and obesity, Ergo said yesterday. Ergo, a biopharmaceutical company based in Charlestown, Mass., said it was disappointed with the decision and would re-evaluate its strategies on the products. In November, the Food and Drug Administration rejected Ergo's new drug application for its Ergoset product for Type 2 diabetes, also called adult-onset diabetes, but is considering an appeal. Ergo had 1997 revenues of $1.7 million. Johnson & Johnson, the pharmaceutical and health care products giant, had 1997 revenues of $22.63 billion.

title: Blueprints for People, but How to Read Them?
description: The blueprint for making a person is not a set of plans showing what a finished heart or kidney looks like and how all the different organs are plumbed together. It is almost certainly a program, not a description, a series of steps that directs a handful of embryonic cells into progressively more specialized tissues. Interacting with each other through a burst of chemical signals, the cells proliferate and slowly organize themselves into the program's end product, the miracle of a mewling infant.

description: A retail and restaurant complex under the Queensboro Bridge approach at 59th Street and First Avenue is under construction, 15 years after a private developer began trying to build it.

She will be forever missed by all whose lives she touched. Funeral services at Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn, NY, 12 Noon on Wednesday.

description: MARC A. MATSIL personifies an environmentalist cliche: think globally, act locally. When he thinks of global warming, his first thought is the threat that rising water levels pose to Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

description: Clayton (Peg Leg) Bates, a one-legged tap dancer who became a star, died on Sunday in Fountain Inn, S.C., where he was born. He was 91.

description: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee asserted today that his panel had built a ''compelling case'' for the impeachment of President Clinton, and for one last time he called on Mr. Clinton and his lawyers to contest the evidence against the President.

description: Meritor Automotive Inc., the world's largest maker of axles for heavy trucks, agreed today to buy the closely held Euclid Industries, a maker of replacement truck parts and accessories, for an undisclosed amount. Meritor, based in Troy, said Cleveland-based Euclid had sales of more than $100 million in the year that ended on Aug. 31.

description: United Nations arms inspectors are about to begin a week of spot inspections at sites where Iraq is suspected of hiding prohibited weapons, the head of the commission in charge of disarming Iraq said today.

title: At Legal Conclave, Clinton's Pastor Reflects on Morality
description: When the organizers of a conference at the Fordham University School of Law decided on their theme -- ''Rediscovering the Role of Religion in the Lives of Lawyers and Those They Represent'' -- the Rev. J. Philip Wogaman seemed a logical choice as keynote speaker.

title: Fire Galore, Just Not Where It's Needed
description: THE World Wildlife Fund declared 1997 ''The Year the World Caught Fire.'' The fires seemed to erupt everywhere. What did not burn outright appeared to vanish in a planetary pall of smoke. Then, things got worse. Powered by the currents of El Nino, normally humid areas dried and arid sites became wet, both creating fuel.

title: 5 Companies In Korea Plan To Shed Units
description: South Korea's five largest conglomerates pledged today to shed more than half their subsidiaries, bowing to intense Government pressure aimed at reorganizing the economy.

title: When Lightning Strikes on the Ski Slopes
description: Most lightning injuries occur in summer and the majority are suffered by golfers, fishermen, hikers and others enjoying warm weather sports. But according to a report issued by the Lightning Data Center in Denver, winter sports enthusiasts also are at risk, albeit, small.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, ESTHER
description: GINSBURG-Esther. Died December 5th, 1998 at the age of 94. Wife of the late William Ginsburg. Mother of Arthur and Barry Ginsburg. Mother-in-law to Dina Ginsburg and Merle Gross Ginsburg. Grandmother of Ruthie Ginsburg Gotian, Ron, Daniel and Joshua Ginsburg. Step-grandmother of Stewart and Barrett Gross and Elizabeth Gross Rose. Step greatgrandmother of Peter and Emily Gross and Hannah, Sarah Alice, and Benjamin Perelson Gross. Esther was a woman ahead of her time; she was a full-time practicing pharmacist with her husband, Will, in their own pharmacy until their retirement. A woman of strength, tenacity and integrity, a loving wife, parent, grandparent and great-grandparent. We shall miss her. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, December 9th, at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, W. 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Clemens Is in Command As Yanks Enter Talks
description: The Yankees made an initial trade offer for pitcher Roger Clemens yesterday, but according to an American League official, the Yankee bid is not among the two offers the Toronto Blue Jays are weighing seriously. In the end, though, Clemens will dictate where he is traded because of provisions in his contract.

title: Big Problem, Big Problems: Getting to Work on Global Warming
description: A YEAR ago, representatives of more than 150 nations faced a midnight deadline in Kyoto, Japan, for talks on an agreement to cut emissions of the gases that scientists warn may be warming the planet. After delegates caucused, argued, slumped and snored through the night -- and toward lunchtime, a pact was reached when the session's chairman decreed that an important conflict would be dealt with later.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE GERM WARRIORS: A special report.; Iranians, Bioweapons in Mind, Lure Needy Ex-Soviet Scientists
description: Iran is scouring the former Soviet Union to hire scientists who once worked in laboratories tied to Moscow's vast germ warfare program and has succeeded in recruiting some of them to take jobs in Teheran, according to Russian scientists and American officials.

title: Battered Ferry With Regal Past Returns Home
description: When Peter Bevis first laid eyes on her, she was in sorry shape. Once the sleek, silvery queen of Puget Sound, she was washed up, literally. Beached in a muddy Alaskan cove, she had suffered the ignominy of becoming a shrimp-processing plant, and now the rusty, rotting vessel wasn't even good enough for that.

title: Police, and Mayor, Ignore A Protest on City Hall Steps
description: A group of City Council members rebelled against the unusually tight security at City Hall yesterday by holding a news conference on the building's steps, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani only smiled and shook his head as he walked past.

title: Program Bound by Coherent Connections
description: Schoenberg celebrated the modernity of Brahms. Stravinsky, 85 and no longer trusting his powers to compose, expressed his thoughts on death through Hugo Wolf. Connections like this gave Sunday afternoon's concert by the Met Chamber Ensemble an unusual flow of coherence.

title: 3 in Camping Area Killed by Grill Fumes
description: Three Pennsylvania men on a weekend fishing trip apparently succumbed to fumes from a charcoal-burning grill and were found dead at a New Jersey camping area yesterday, Federal park rangers said.

title: N. CAROLINA 77, MARSHALL 46
description: Nikki Teasley scored 15 points in just 22 minutes last night to lead No. 7 North Carolina (10-1) to an easy 77-46 victory against Marshall (1-4) in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: DEXTER RAISES OFFER FOR REMAINDER OF LIFE TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Dexter Corporation said yesterday that it had increased its offer to acquire all the stock of Life Technologies Inc. that it does not already own to $39.25 a share from $37. The move is in response to a group of shareholders who control 16 percent of Life Technologies and have refused to tender their shares, saying the $37-a-share, $426.6 million offer substantially undervalued the company. As of Friday, about 2.25 million shares, or 9.5 percent of the shares outstanding, had been tendered. Dexter, of Windsor Locks, Conn., currently owns 51.5 percent of Life Technologies' shares outstanding. It also extended the offer to Dec. 22. Life Technologies, based in Rockville, Md., makes genetically engineered products. Its shares rose $2, to $39.25, while Dexter was up $1.0625 at $30.3125.

title: Homer No. 70 Put on Auction
description: Mark McGwire's historic 70th home run ball will be put up for bidding early next month by Guernsey's, an auction house in New York.

title: Newborn's Body Found On a Brooklyn Beach
description: The body of a newborn baby was found on a Brooklyn beach yesterday morning a short distance from the spot where a toddler was found dead on Friday, the police said.

title: UBS Considering Sale Of Trade Finance Unit
description: UBS A.G., the Swiss banking giant, said yesterday that it might sell its trade finance unit to focus on money management and investment banking, two areas that, according to analysts, offer higher returns. UBS said selling the unit was ''one option'' it was considering after a review involving its Warburg Dillon Read investment banking operation. The trade finance unit arranges and syndicates credit for exports, has loans of about $5.5 billion and earns about $50 million a year.

title: Former Driver's Sodomy Testimony at Issue : Witness in Anwar Case Seems to Change Story
description: KUALA LUMPUR  A key witness in the trial of Anwar Ibrahim appeared to reverse himself on Monday by stating under cross-examination that he had not been sodomized by the former deputy prime minister.

description: The Supreme Court today entered a long-running tax dispute between two Federal district judges and an Alabama county that has tried for 10 years to impose its occupational license tax on the salaries of Federal judges in Birmingham.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, ABRAHAM
description: FEINBERG-Abraham. The Weizmann Institute of Science, its Feinberg Graduate School and its American Committee join in mourning the passing, at age 90, of a legendary figure in our history. With unique leadership gifts of vision, action and determination, Abe Feinberg was strongly committed to U.S.-Israel friendship and to the Weizmann Institute. For half a century he played a prominent role in rallying American support for Israel. A proud moment came when he accompanied President Chaim Weizmann to his first meeting with President Truman. In 1947, Mr. Feinberg joined the Board of Directors of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science. He remained an active director for 51 years, including service as ACWIS President and Chairman. He was Honorary Fellow and Chairman Emeritus of the International Board of Governors of the Wiezmann Institute and Founding Chairman of its Feinberg Graduate School, established through his efforts in 1958. We shall miss him deeply, and express our warmest condolences to his wife Lillian, daugher Judith and the entire family. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Prof. Haim Harari, President Robert H. Asher, Chairman American Committee and President Feinberg Graduate School Albert Willner, M.D., President American Committee Martin Kraar, Exec. V.P. Prof. Melvin Schwartz, Chairman Feinberg Graduate School Prof. Samuel Safran Dean

description: In a deal that may prove damaging to the Internet's largest bookseller, Amazon.com, the Microsoft Corporation and Barnes & Noble Inc. said yesterday that they had agreed to weave together their on-line products and services.

description: Much of the dread in the dreaded trip to the dentist is being removed: New treatments are bringing patients freedom from drilling, freedom from anesthesia and freedom from pain. Moreover, they appear to be, in their initial stages, safer, more accurate and faster than traditional methods.

description: Amid the recent blitz of scientific studies on the effectiveness of herbal treatments, Dr. Alan M. Dattner, a Westchester County dermatologist, stepped back to take a look at several herbal preparations that have sometimes been used to treat common dermatological problems.
