title: By Design; Looking Golden for the Holidays
description: It is holiday party time, but that needn't mean sequins or Lurex. Maybe a touch of gilded makeup, suggests Jose Parron, makeup director of Barneys New York. ''Today's makeup can result in a subtle sheen, a slight frost or a heavy glitter, depending on your style and courage,'' he said. The products he recommends include Illuminating Powder Foundation by Stila ($42); Copacabana Multiples Stick by Nars for face, lip or eye ($32); Makeup Forever Star Powder for a definite shine ($17), and Flin Flon Lipgloss by Cargo, which is half pink and half gold ($15).

title: Impeachment Point Man Lets Speaker Warm Up
description: As Representative Tom DeLay, the third-ranking House Republican, whips and wheedles his colleagues toward impeaching President Clinton, he seems to be filling the space between the departure of Speaker Newt Gingrich and the arrival of Speaker-to-be Robert L. Livingston.

title: Venezuela's Electoral Revolt
description: Few politicians get a second bite at power as quickly as Hugo Chavez, who won Sunday's presidential election in Venezuela. Six years ago Mr. Chavez led a military coup. It failed, but his messianic assault on the establishment captured the imagination of poor Venezuelans. Mr. Chavez's speeches today are more conciliatory, but he still frightens Venezuela's elite and makes Washington nervous about the future of a country that is now the United States' primary source of oil.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Renada Daniel-Patterson, whose father wants to give her his remaining kidney after the failure of the previous one he donated to her, misspelled the surname of an ethicist at Stanford University. It is Hank Greely, not Greeley.

title: Teacher Is Welcomed After Book Dispute
description: Parents and teachers at a Queens school welcomed a white teacher yesterday who transferred after her use of a book, ''Nappy Hair,'' at a Brooklyn school caused some parents to threaten her.

title: What if a Big Voice Takes On a Tiny Hall?
description: Christine Goerke brought her healthy, happy soprano voice to Weill Recital Hall on Friday night. The music was often newish and American, but there were also the eight Strauss songs (Op. 10), four more by Verdi and ''Le Court Paille'' by Poulenc, the kind of children's-book whimsy the French so dearly love. Ms. Goerke's dark, handsome voice is keeping her young career busy. There is certainly no lack of carrying power here; the voice is even and well managed throughout; and I can't remember an episode of bad intonation all evening.

title: IN WAKE OF BOEING MOVES, NORTHROP PLANS MORE JOB CUTS
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation, one of the Boeing Company's largest suppliers, said yesterday that it would cut an additional 1,100 jobs next year as a result of Boeing's plan to slash jet production. Northrop supplies the fuselage for the 747 jumbo jet, which faces the most severe cutbacks. Northrop said last week that it would lose about $150 million in sales next year because of the Boeing cutbacks. The job cuts at Northrop come on top of the 2,600 cuts already announced for next year. Northrop, the big aerospace and military concern, had earlier predicted sales of about $9.36 billion in 1999.

title: VITAL SIGNS: BEHAVIOR; That Sly 'Don't-Come-Hither' Stare
description: It sounds like a catalogue from the nightmare side of the collective male memory: The woman yawns, frowns, sneers, cleans her nails, picks at her teeth, stares at the ceiling and makes an excruciatingly minute examination of her hair's split ends. ''Sorry, what were you saying?''

title: KELLSTROM TO BUY SOLAIR UNIT FROM BANNER AEROSPACE
description: Kellstrom Industries, which overhauls and resells used planes and jet engines, said yesterday that it was buying Banner Aerospace Inc.'s Solair Inc. unit for $57 million in cash. Solair, with 1997 sales of about $72 million, makes products ranging from landing gear to coffee makers. Kellstrom, with sales of more than $180 million and headquarters in Sunrise, Fla., will benefit from the customer base of Solair, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Banner, which leases engines and sells parts, will take a $12.5 million charge related to the sale. Solair accounts for about 30 percent of the revenues of Banner, which is based in Dulles, Va. Last week, the Fairchild Corporation said it planned to buy the 15 percent of Banner that it did not already own.

title: 2 Utility Deals Could Speed Consolidation
description: Two precedent-setting merger deals were announced yesterday in the American electric power industry that could greatly accelerate the consolidation among utilities. The deals are certain to receive careful regulatory scrutiny.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATES, CLAYTON
description: BATES-Clayton (Peg Leg). On December 6th, 1998, at Fountain Inn, SC. A resident of Kerhonkson, NY. World renowned tap dancer, entertainer and former owner of Peg Leg Bates Country Club. He was born October 11, 1907 in Fountain Inn and attained the age of 91 years. He was the beloved father of Melodye Bates-Holden. Funeral Saturday, 11 AM, at Samsonville United Methodist Church, Samsonville, NY. He will be reposed at H.B. Humiston Funeral Home, 30 42nd St., Kerhonkson, NY, Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Interment will be in the Palentown Cemetery.

title: Hospitals Agency Girds Itself for Challenges of Medicaid Managed Care
description: For years, New York City's public hospital system has faced one financial crisis after another. And each time, the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, by far the world's largest public-hospital collective, has scratched its way back to solvency.

title: Caution: He Brakes For Pupfish
description: IT is ecologically insensitive to play favorites when it comes to animals threatened with extinction, but certain creatures do tend to tug at the heartstrings more than others. My favorite was, or, as it turns out, is the Devil's Hole pupfish, a minnow that was the focus of a large legal, environmental and philosophical battle in the 1970's.

description: Two marketers have expanded relationships with roster agencies.

description: A State Supreme Court jury in Queens awarded $26 million yesterday to a family whose child was severely brain damaged during delivery at a city hospital 10 years ago.

title: Interesting Things Come in Twos
description: People who get depressed about their birthdays shouldn't become composers, because in the music world, a birthday can last all year. Gershwin's centenary came and went in September, yet the commemorative concerts continue unabated; and Elliott Carter, who doesn't turn 90 until Thursday, has been feted continuously since the season began. This expansive view of birthdays does, however, make it possible to catch up with one that has been overlooked. John Corigliano's 60th birthday, which was in February, was celebrated in the opening installment of ''Ned Rorem Hosts'' on Sunday afternoon at the 92d Street Y.

title: N.F.L. Seeks a Vote On Instant Replays
description: Concerned over several glaring errors by its officials in recent weeks, including one that allowed the Jets to win Sunday's game against Seattle in the final minute, the National Football League said it would ask owners to vote on an instant replay system for the playoffs and the Super Bowl. A change would represent an unusual in-season adjustment to the procedures that govern games. It signals the acknowledgment of the league that the credibility of its competition is being questioned.

title: Fast Deadline On Options Repricing
description: Companies that want to reprice options because their stock price is depressed, but thought that they had months left to act, scrambled yesterday to get the job done before next Tuesday, when favorable accounting treatment will end.

title: Office Depot Picks Devito/Verdi
description: Office Depot Inc., the office-supply retail chain in Delray Beach, Fla., said yesterday that it had named DeVito/Verdi in New York to handle its account, with billings estimated at more than $40 million. The account had been handled by Wyse Advertising in Cleveland since October 1997.

title: Barnard Students Will Stick With Ms.
description: It was not so very long ago -- before women routinely entered the work force -- that college was sometimes billed as a place where they could earn their ''M.R.S.'' degree.

title: Lessons in Iceman's Prehistoric Medicine Kit
description: A traveler out of the past, the Iceman, whose mummified body was discovered in the Tyrolean Alps in Northern Italy in 1991, has given archeologists and other scientists a lifelike picture of what people wore and ate and carried with them on treks into the Alps 5,300 years ago, at the end of the Stone Age and beginning of the Copper Age in Europe. An anthropologist reported last week that the Iceman was also providing a rare glimpse of prehistoric medicine, including his apparent use of a natural laxative and antibiotic.

title: Between Two West Coast Cities, a Duel to the Last Drop
description: IF Pirandello had written a play about water, he might have set it in a place where the London Bridge looms in one of the driest deserts on earth, where a $250-million water plant was built to desalt a supposedly freshwater river, and where huge pipes, like giant silver straws, rush water to gleaming cities hundreds of miles away.

title: Time Warner and CBS in Pact on Digital TV
description: In something of a surprise embrace, Time Warner Cable and the CBS Corporation announced yesterday that they had signed an agreement for Time Warner's cable systems to carry the digital television signals of CBS's 15 television stations, by adding extra channels to the cable systems.

title: Come January, House Vote May Not Matter
description: A Yale University law professor who is a student of impeachment procedures suggested today that even if the House of Representatives voted this year to impeach Bill Clinton, the House that takes office in January would have to cast at least one more vote on the matter.

title: A String of Legal Aid Losses, Interrupted
description: THERE were a number of times in the last six years when Michelle Fox, a Legal Aid lawyer, could have given up. Instead, she carried on, finally winning freedom for her 29-year-old client, Jeffrey Blake, a Brooklyn man who spent eight years -- almost all of his precious 20's, Ms. Fox says -- in prison for a double murder he did not commit. The judge in the case apologized for ''the entire judicial system.''

title: 2 European Drug Giants Talk of Merger
description: Zeneca Group P.L.C., the third-largest British drug maker, and Astra A.B. of Sweden said yesterday that they were discussing a merger that would be worth at least $30 billion and create the world's fourth-largest pharmaceutical company.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW
description: In a duet that makes oil and water seem like a friendlier mix, Luciano Pavarotti, stiff in white tie and tails, looks straight ahead at the audience, oblivious to Celine Dion right next to him onstage. As they perform ''I Hate You, Then I Love You'' (a duet they also did last year on one of Ms. Dion's albums), he stares in the direction of the teleprompter while singing, ''I could never live without you.'' Meanwhile, she faces him, waving her arms wildly, closing her eyes melodramatically, generally behaving like a lunatic. His hauteur and her overacting have nothing to do with dramatizing the lyrics, but are symptomatic of two singers who probably should not appear on the same continent, never mind the same stage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALEM, JANET M.
description: SALEM-Janet M., age 65, on December 7, 1998. Associate Bond Trader for Morgan Stanley. Beloved sister of Thomas, Dr. James, the late Steven and Vincey. description: In another legal challenge to the City University of New York's new policy on remedial education, six civil liberties groups have accused CUNY's trustees of violating state law because they did not submit the policy to the State Board of Regents for approval.

title: A Greenwich Village Chef Recognizes a Good Thing

So when I saw one of my favorite salads -- flat-leaf parsley with country ham, dried tomatoes and Wisconsin Asiago cheese -- on the menu at Philip Marie, a new American restaurant in Greenwich Village, I thought the chef there must be really good.

title: 15-Year-Old Is Arrested In Bomb Threat at School

description: THE MARK RISES. Germany's currency rose after the president of the European Central Bank reinforced expectations of no interest-rate cut. In New York, the dollar settled at 1.6668 marks, down from 1.6801 on Monday.

title: GLOBAL TELESYSTEMS AGREES TO PURCHASE ESPRIT TELECOM
description: Global Telesystems Group Inc., a company based in McLean, Va., and backed by the billionaire George Soros, agreed to buy a rival, Esprit Telecom Group P.L.C., for $757 million in stock to create a communications network spanning 19 European nations. Global Telesystems will pay 0.1271 share for each Esprit share. It will also assume $228 million in debt. Both companies have been building high-speed networks to carry traffic for businesses and other phone companies across Europe's newly deregulated markets. Global Telesystems, of which Mr. Soros's funds own about 12 percent, rose 12 percent, gaining $5.125, to $46.875, in Nasdaq trading, where shares of Esprit, based in Reading, England, jumped $9.25, to $39.50. The combined company will have a market value of $4.1 billion and about 3,000 employees.

title: OPEN TEXT EXTENDS ITS OFFER FOR PC DOCS AFTER REJECTION
description: The Open Text Corporation, a Canadian software company, extended its bid for PC Docs International Inc. until Friday after PC Docs rejected the offer of stock that had been valued at $112 million. Open Text wants to buy PC Docs to gain more big customers for its line of software that manages corporate computer networks. The company, based in Waterloo, Ontario, last week offered to pay one share of its stock for every four shares of PC Docs. On Monday, PC Docs, a Toronto-based software company, rejected the offer and said that any further communication with Open Text would be unproductive. PC Docs cited the exchange ratio and ''one-sided proposal terms'' among its reasons and called the offer ''opportunistic.''

title: Bic Chooses TBWA For Global Account
description: Societe Bic S.A. in Clichy, France, said yesterday that it had named TBWA Worldwide to handle its worldwide creative and strategy account, with billings estimated at $45 million. The account, for Bic products such as lighters, pens and disposable shavers, had been handled by various agencies around the world.

title: Single-Day, Unlimited-Ride Metrocards to Go on Sale Jan. 1
description: In the long-awaited final installment to the Metrocard program, New York City Transit will offer a one-day unlimited-ride pass priced at $4 beginning on Jan. 1, a senior official of the transit agency said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAX, DOROTHY (NEE SELETSKY)
description: MAX-Dorothy (nee Seletsky). Of Manhattan and Venice, Italy, on Decmeber 5, 1998. Mourned by her long-devoted family; by her husband Herbert; by her sons Adam, Eric and Daniel; by her daughtersin-law Diane and Denise; by Sarah; by her brother-in-law Jerry; and by her five grandchildren. A food enthusiast and scholar, a woman special to love and to know. Donations may be sent to GYNOncology Fund of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital, 425 West 59 Street, Suite 4B, NY, NY 10019.

title: Lavish World of a Union Leader Now Under Fire
description: The office building used by District Council 37 in lower Manhattan has seven elevators -- six public, one private. Most serve the rank and file, taking union members to the rooms where they can file grievances, attend night classes and get information about dental plans. The private elevator, until recently, served the select guests and allies of a union official named Albert A. Diop.

title: Gun Study Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: A Steak to Rival Filet, at a Chuck Price
description: IN food as in life, the truly remarkable often lurks among the merely ordinary. Take, for example, the top blade steak. It comes from the chuck or forequarter of the cow, which usually produces cuts that are flavorful but very tough. Full of connective tissue, these are best cooked by slow, moist cooking methods like braising or stewing.

title: Business Travel; Frequent-flier plans are expected to look more alike next year, and miles may no longer expire.
description: NEXT year will bring less variety among United States airlines' frequent-flier programs and the disappearance of miles that expire, an expert on loyalty programs predicts.

title: Sobbing, Widow of Slain Officer Testifies in Murder Trial
description: The wife of a police officer slain while responding to a report of a robbery broke down in tears during her testimony yesterday at the trial of her husband's accused killer.

title: Amy Fisher Seeks Trial, Citing Sexual Relationship With Ex-Lawyer
description: Amy Fisher is seeking to withdraw her guilty plea and go to trial over the 1992 shooting of Mary Jo Buttafuoco, charging that her former lawyer, Eric W. Naiburg, lied to her and had a sexual relationship with her that clouded his judgment.

title: Accounts
description: * USA Network, New York, the cable television network owned by USA Networks Inc., to Mediacom, New York, the media unit of Grey Advertising, as its media agency of record. Billings are estimated at $25 million to $35 million. The assignment had been handled by Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis. Creative duties are handled in-house.

title: Ban on Type of Abortion Is Struck Down
description: A Federal judge today struck down a New Jersey law banning what abortion opponents call partial-birth abortion, saying that the measure was unconstitutional because it would threaten the health of women by denying them access to the safest medical procedures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUFELD, HARRY
description: NEUFELD-Harry. Beloved husband of Zelda. Loving father of Lauren Behn. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 10am Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNELL, JOHN
description: O'CONNELL-John. The officers and members of the Transport Workers Union of America AFLCIO deeply mourn the death of one of the most capable and wellliked officers in our union's history. John O'Connell served our union for 30 years as International Representative, International Vice President, Administrative Assistant to former International President Matthew Guinan, and Director of Publicity from 1949 until his retirement in 1979. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Genie, sons, John, Jr. and Thomas, and daughters, Maureen and Patricia. Viewing will be at the Moritz Funeral Home, Rt. 303, Tappan, NY (914-359-0890) Wednesday, Dec 9th from 7-9 P.M., and Thursday Dec. 10th from 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Funeral services will be conducted Friday 10 A.M., Dec. 11th at St. Catherine's Church, Western Highway in Blauvelt, NY. Sonny Hall International President Frank McCann Exeutive Vice President John J. Kerrigan Secretary Treasurer

title: Reconstituted Trio Reaches For Harmony Of Approach
description: The Beaux-Arts Trio has been formed yet again, and on Friday night made its New York debut at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Menahem Pressler, of course, remains at the piano: on this occasion not always in perfect technical command, though he could suddenly surprise you with a brilliantly executed piece of fast figuration or a beautiful melody. Tchaikovsky's A minor Trio gave him opportunities for both, and both were welcome in this massively distended piece.

title: Jessye Norman With a String Quartet and Dancers
description: You probably had to be a tenacious admirer of the soprano Jessye Norman to be thoroughly pleased by her recital on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Ms. Norman sang with the exasperating inconsistency that has come to characterize her work at this stage in her long career.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a new accounting rule for repricing stock options referred incorrectly to the corporate affiliation of Yale Tauber, a compensation consultant who was quoted about client interest in the rule. He is a principal of William M. Mercer Inc. (Mercer Management Consulting is a sister company.)

title: Power Failure Stalls San Francisco for 6 Hours
description: A power failure struck San Francisco at the rush hour this morning, cutting service to more than a million people, leaving train commuters stranded under San Francisco Bay, stalling trolleys and electric buses in the streets and forcing businesses, some schools and the Pacific Stock Exchange to shut down.

title: The Election Commissioners' Duty
description: The Federal Election Commission, an autonomous agency of six members appointed by Congress, has a duty today to condemn and punish the illegal fund-raising by President Clinton and Bob Dole in the 1996 election. Both candidates raised and spent millions of dollars in clear violation of election laws in effect for most of this century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMELOCK, HERMAN
description: EMELOCK-Herman. Husband of Anna & the late Shirley. Father of Renee and Stephen. Grandfather, great grandfather and uncle. Graveside service 1PM Wednesday, December 9 Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Blvd., Queens.

title: Immobilizing Lies
description: If President Clinton wants an impeachment vote in the House of Representatives and a possible trial in the Senate, he has got the House Judiciary Committee exactly where he wants it. If, however, Mr. Clinton would like to be less passive about his future, he has to change the direction and content of the committee's deliberations. In practical terms, that means the President must free himself and his defenders from the paralyzing fiction that he did not lie under oath.

title: PALOMAR TO SELL HAIR-REMOVAL LASER UNIT TO COHERENT
description: Coherent Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Palomar Medical Technologies Inc.'s Star Medical Technologies unit for $65 million in cash. Coherent, which makes medical, scientific and commercial lasers, has been the exclusive distributor of Star Medical's laser hair-removal product, called Lightsheer. Coherent is also acquiring Star Medical's patents. Coherent, based in Santa Clara, Calif., is trying to capitalize on the rapidly growing market for both medical and commercial applications of Star Medical's laser-based technology. Palomar, based in Lexington, Mass., produces laser systems for hair removal and other cosmetic treatments.

title: A Day of Furious Crossfire Sharpens the Partisan Edges
description: ''Something is actually happening here,'' Representative Zoe Lofgren announced in a tone of quiet amazement, interrupting the nation's mood of holiday bustle to voice the growing fears of House Democrats that President Clinton could be impeached by Christmas.

title: Philharmonic Announces Season
description: The New York Philharmonic announced plans for its 1999-2000 season yesterday, and six new works, or ''Messages for the Millennium,'' as the commissioning project is called, will be among the most anticipated events.

title: It's Official: N.B.A. Cancels Its All-Star Game
description: For the first time since 1951 there will be no National Basketball Association All-Star Game. It's Day 162 of the lockout. No new bargaining talks are scheduled. Do you think the season is in peril?

title: In Rush to a Vote on Replay, Some Owners Want a Pause
description: One day after the National Football League called for a vote by its owners on whether to use instant replay during the playoffs, it became clear that the short time frame involved could hinder its passage.

title: FOUNDER AND HIS FAMILY OFFER TO BUY OUT ST. JOHN KNITS
description: St. John Knits Inc., a maker of women's clothing and accessories, said late yesterday that its founder and chairman, Bob Gray, and his family had offered to buy the company for about $490 million. The $28-a-share offer represents a premium of about 28 percent over the stock's closing price yesterday of $21.9375, up 93.75 cents. The offer is for the shares outstanding that Mr. Gray and his family do not already own. Mr. Gray has told the company that he has received an equity commitment from Vestar Capital Partners, a private equity investment firm with offices in New York and Denver. Mr. Gray said he wanted to slow the growth rate of the company, which is based in Irvine, Calif., to 10 percent a year from 25 percent a year.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Big Companies Practicing Big Specialties
description: Call it focusing by spreading out.

title: Author of Disputed Book Is Criticized in Brooklyn
description: A community meeting in Brooklyn last night for the author of the book ''Nappy Hair'' turned combative when some people said the book was derogatory and questioned its use in a third-grade classroom.

title: Tinseltown Dreams Face Reality
description: For years, dreams of creating Hollywood-on-the-Hudson have tantalized politicians and entrepreneurs, only to collide with the financial realities of a high-risk industry.

title: Woman and Foster Child Awarded Money by Jury
description: A Federal jury awarded $50,000 in damages yesterday to a woman and the foster child she had been adopting, finding that their constitutional rights were violated when a foster care agency removed the child without notice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, MORRIS, M.D.
description: SIEGEL-Morris, M.D. On December 7, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Miriam. Loving father of Nancy Peress, M.D. and Robert H. Siegel. Cherished grandfather of Alexandra, John, Ari and Loren. Services private.

description: Michael Zaslow, an Emmy Award-winning actor who played a victim of Lou Gehrig's disease on the soap opera ''One Life to Live'' and who struggled with the illness in real life, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 54.

title: Europe Looks Quizzically at U.S. Proposal for NATO Strategy
description: American proposals for a broad new strategic concept for NATO, to counter the global threat from chemical, nuclear and biological weapons, received quizzical responses today from European allies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNAMEE, AGNES
description: McNAMEE-Agnes. Age 89 formerly of New York City died in Saco, ME. A Funeral Mass will be held 10:00 AM, Wednesday at Notre Dame de Lourdes Church, Cutts St, Saco. For info Dennett, Craig & Pate Funeral Home.

title: Distinguished in Its Simplicity
description: AS testament to the modern celebrity of chefs, Mario Batali's name appears in larger type than the title of his new book, ''Simple Italian Food'' (Clarkson Potter, $30). And there is a full-length photograph of Mr. Batali clad in chef's whites and orange kitchen clogs, baring hairy legs.

title: At the Microsoft Trial, a Day for Parrying
description: A lawyer for the Microsoft Corporation failed today to shake a computer-science expert from his argument that Internet software should not be included as part of Microsoft's Windows operating system.

title: German Unemployment Shows Unexpected Rise
description: The number of unemployed workers in Germany unexpectedly rose in November, the first monthly increase this year, raising concern that Europe's largest economy will slow more than forecast. The number of jobless people rose by 4,000, counter to analysts' expectations for a decline of 30,000. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was unchanged at 10.6 percent, the central bank said yesterday.

title: White House Brief Offers A Point-by-Point Defense
description: While President Clinton's lawyers presented a conciliatory defense to the House Judiciary Committee, the White House tonight released a detailed, 184-page legal brief that portrays both the independent counsel and the impeachment process as politically biased and blatantly unfair.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SULLIVAN, CATHERINE, (NEE MCDONNELL)
description: SULLIVAN-Catherine, (nee McDonnell), on December 7, 1998 at her home in Scottsdale, Arizona, at age 81. A long-time resident of Southampton, NY, she was the daughter of the late James F. and Anna Murray McDonnell. She is survived by her loving husband of 58 years Raymond Peter, Jr.; her children R. Peter, Maureen Brookman, Sheila, Kevin, Karen and Sean Sullivan; her grandsons David, Jonathan, and Luke Singer; her brothers James and Morgan McDonnell; and her sisters Sheila Collins, Mary Murnane, Barbara Hennessy, and Margaret Murphy. Friends may call at O'Connell Funeral Home, Southampton, NY, on Friday, December 11th from 24 and 7-9 p.m. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at 11 a.m. on Saturday, December 12th, at Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church, Hill Street, Southampton, NY. Interment immediately following will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Southampton Care Center, 330 Meeting House Lane, Southampton, NY 11968 or Scottsdale Health Care Hospice, 5111 North Scottsdale Road, Suite 275, Scottsdale, AZ 85250, Attn: Peggy Fry.

title: High Court, 9 to 0, Restricts Police Traffic-Stop Searches
description: Issuing a speeding ticket does not automatically give the police the authority to search the car, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today in rejecting the latest invitation from law-enforcement officials to expand the powers of the police in encounters with motorists.

title: At Lowe & Partners/SMS, a co-chairman steps down -- er, make that 'onward and upward.'
description: MARVIN SLOVES, a consummate ''suit'' with a strong creative sensibility, who has been one of the leading figures on Madison Avenue since the 1960's, is stepping down at the shop that he helped to expand substantially in recent years.

title: Manufacturers Are Less Upbeat
description: United States manufacturers are less optimistic about the coming year, expecting revenues will rise at a slower pace than in 1998, while nonmanufacturing companies are more upbeat, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Irreverent McMahon Is Among 13 Entering Hall of Fame
description: Jim McMahon, the able quarterback for Brigham Young University and six professional teams including the Chicago Bears, blended his famous irreverence with maturing humility and candor yesterday as he addressed the topic, ''What Has Football Meant to Me?''

title: Don't Impeach, D'Amato Urges
description: At a farewell party thrown by his staff this evening, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York said it would be ''a grave mistake'' for the Republican Party and the nation if the House impeached President Clinton.

description: HERMAN-Charlotte. Conservative Synagogue of Jamaica Estates mourns the passing of our past Trustee and friend and extends heartfelt sympathy to her family.

title: Metro Business; Cable Access to Internet
description: Cablevision Systems Corporation said yesterday that it would be capable of offering high-speed Internet access over cable modems to about 714,000 homes by the end of the year, up from 370,000 in September.

title: President Urges Open Minds on Social Security
description: President Clinton urged members of both parties today to be flexible as they seek a solution to Social Security's long-term financial woes, but he laid out no specific proposal for one of the most ideologically charged and politically sensitive issues facing the country.

description: FILLER-Juan, M.D. On Dec. 9th 1997. In memory of my husband who is ever loved. Maria

title: F.B.I. Releases Its Sinatra File, With Tidbits Old and New
description: The F.B.I. today released most if its huge file on Frank Sinatra. The file's 1,300 pages contain old rumors about his ties to organized crime, details about a youthful arrest for seduction and adultery and new information about why he escaped military duty in World War II: a perforated eardrum and mental instability.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK ANNOUNCES PLANS TO BUY BACK STOCK
description: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it would buy back up to 18 million shares of its stock. The buyback, which will take place through the end of next year, represents about 2 percent of the outstanding shares of the bank, which is based in New York. Bank of New York, one of the largest banking holding companies in the country, has assets of $63 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, SIDNEY
description: ROSEN-Sidney. Celebrated joyous life for 81 years, 53 of them he shared with his wife Lillian Fisher Rosen. He was beloved and respected by all the people whose lives he touched. He will be deeply missed by his children Judith, Nomi, Beth and Seth, grandchildren Reuben, Amanda, Josh, Emily and Kate; sisters Lucille Daniels and Mimi Staub and his extended family Ralph Smallberg, Mary Ann King, Kathi Rosen, Stanley Fisher, Esther Margolies and Daniel Staub. Services will be held on Wednesday, December 9 at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, at 9:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions can be sent to the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital.

title: Questioning Impeachment as a Tool: A Remedy, Yes, but Never a Punishment
description: Following are excerpts from the statements before the House Judiciary Committee today by a panel of experts on history and the law, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service. The witnesses were called by lawyers for the White House to help it present a case against the impeachment of President Clinton.

title: TV NOTES; Tumultuous Era
description: ABC News is putting a program on the air tomorrow night that is unusual for two reasons. First, a two-hour documentary is rare in broadcast television these days, with the notable exception of PBS. Second, the subject matter, the United States in 1968, sounds almost too familiar.

title: Priest Arrested Carrying Pistol at Kennedy Airport
description: A Manhattan priest was arrested at Kennedy International Airport last night after the authorities said he hid a gun and ammunition in boxes of detergent in his luggage and tried to smuggle them onto a flight to Nigeria.

title: Report Sees Media as Source of New Jobs
description: The media and communications industries -- which include everything from advertising to publishing to computer programming -- will be a major source of new jobs in New York City over the next few years, according to a report released yesterday by the Citizens' Budget Commission, a nonpartisan, business-financed research group.

title: Report Backs Methadone for Addicts
description: A new report published today in the Journal of the American Medical Association recommends the expanded use of methadone to treat heroin addiction, noting that it can help reduce crime, slow the spread of other infectious diseases and reduce the general level of dysfunction suffered by addicts.

title: Deal for Largest Development Site in Times Sq. Falls Apart
description: For someone with a great chunk of property in the middle of a resurgent Times Square, it looked like a perfect deal.

title: Doctor Says DiMaggio's Condition Has Stabilized
description: Joe DiMaggio's condition was so bleak on Monday that his doctor advised that family and close friends be called to his side for his possible death.

title: Mickens, Only 5-8, Plays Big For Jets
description: It was a strange twist. An awful day for Aaron Glenn, one of the National Football League's premier cornerbacks, may turn out to be a blessing for Ray Mickens, Glenn's close friend, Texas A&M teammate and football clone.

title: Ron Alexander Dies at 68; The Times's Whimsical Diarist
description: Ron Alexander, who spent almost three decades as a reporter for The New York Times and made Metropolitan Diary one of the paper's most popular weekly features, died on Monday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 68.

title: J. C. PENNEY TO ACQUIRE 21-STORE BRAZILIAN RETAIL CHAIN
description: The J. C. Penney Company, the second-biggest United States department store company, expanded its push into Latin America, agreeing to pay 40 million reais ($33.3 million) for control of the Brazilian retail chain Lojas Renner S.A. The purchase will add to J. C. Penney's operations in this area, where it operates five outlets in Puerto Rico, two in Chile and two in Mexico. Brazilian retail sales are expected to expand 5 percent next year, according to Sao Paulo's Commerce Federation, though the economy is expected to slow down. Renner, which employs 1,900 staff and operates 21 stores in southern Brazil, generated revenue of $210 million last year.

title: Russian Passion and Barbs, With a Mozartean Twist
description: The British soprano Joan Rodgers, who has worked most prominently in Europe, has an unusual academic background: She graduated with honors in Russian from the University of Liverpool. So Russian works have been a staple of her recital programs, including Sunday afternoon's at Alice Tully Hall, where, with the fine pianist Malcolm Martineau, Ms. Rodgers performed as part of Lincoln Center's ''Art of the Song'' series.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the creation of a biomedical research center by 10 of New York State's academic medical institutions referred incompletely to the location. It will be on the City College campus of the City University.

title: About New York; Music Needed To Complete Mother's Carol
description: CHRISTMAS is in the air, even if the air has been springtime warm. Maybe it was nature's way of getting even with all those stores that hasten the holiday mood ever earlier each year with their displays of Santa dolls shaking their moneymakers among the plastic fir trees and Mylar garlands. If things keep up like this, don't be surprised if they start piping in the Christmas carols in June.

title: Voters as Suspects
description: Not long ago, dead Democrats were supposedly the problem. New York State's Attorney General, Dennis Vacco, and his Republican allies charged that the newly departed might have marched into their old polling spots last month and helped elect Mr. Vacco's Democratic opponent, Eliot Spitzer. When the voting dead turned out to be little more than G.O.P. voodoo, the Vacco camp began looking elsewhere for reasons their candidate lost. Even the normally Republican New York Post mocked the Attorney General in its Sunday headline that said ''Vacco: Aliens Stole My Election.''

description: The severed heads of four kidnapping victims identified as three Britons and a New Zealander -- were found today on the side of a road in Chechnya, the breakaway region on Russia's southern border that emerged undefeated from a brutal war two years ago only to be engulfed by a wave of kidnappings and crime.

title: Rescued Hedge Fund Continues To Generate Profits for Wall St.
description: Long-Term Capital Management, the troubled hedge fund rescued at the height of this fall's stock and bond market turmoil, has continued to generate profits for the Wall Street banks that injected fresh capital in September. But some Government regulators are still investigating the circumstances surrounding the near-collapse of the hedge fund, people involved in the matter said.

title: Knuble, With Nedved's Help, Skating Past Doubts
description: While Petr Nedved has quickly become the toast of Madison Square Garden in his first seven games with the Rangers, the ascension of Mike Knuble, while connected to Nedved, has been much quieter.

title: Having Their Day, or Not, in Court
description: Filmed mostly on location in a tiny, crowded Teheran divorce court, Kim Longinotto's extraordinarily intimate documentary, ''Divorce Iranian Style,'' reminds you that marital discord knows no geographic boundaries. What varies from place to place are only the laws allowing couples to officially dissolve their unhappy unions. In Iran, when a woman wants a divorce the only legal grounds are a husband's insanity, impotence or inability to provide for her financially.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, RICHARD L., JR. (RICK).
description: FRANK-Richard L., Jr. (Rick). Age 56, died at home in New Jersey on December 7. Husband of Rochelle; brother of Linda Frank Sicher; father of Joel Frank and Vali Frank. Grandfather of Nicholas and son of Doris Ansbacher Frank and the late Richard Frank, M.D. Funeral arrangements are private. May his music live on.

title: Unfazed by Excess, the Pundits Chatter On . . . and On
description: The beauty part of the television blowhard's calling is that you never have to say you're sorry. When you are obliged to talk as incessantly as demanded by that line of work, especially on nonstop cable, you are bound to utter foolish, pointless, peculiar things, and the louder, the more authoritative. But neither excess nor error nor eccentricity can stay these spouters from their anointed rounds.

title: Journal; The Closet Candidate
description: In an early campaign spot in his 1994 run for the U.S. Senate, Michael Huffington quoted from William Bennett's ''Book of Virtues'' on the virtues of family. Soon to come were bucolic, sun-dappled spots highlighting Mr. Huffington's togetherness with his celebrity wife, Arianna, and their kids.

title: Trooper Is Indicted In Fatal Car Accident
description: A state trooper who prosecutors say was drunk when his unmarked patrol car slammed into another car in June, killing its driver, was indicted yesterday on a charge of aggravated manslaughter, officials said.

title: 26 Years of Togetherness Without a Baton

This chamber orchestra has been proving since 1972 that an ensemble's internal cohesiveness can yield performances as precise and as supple as those shaped by the sweep of a baton, and while one might quibble with a balance here or there, it is difficult to remain indifferent to the energy, beauty of tone, and gracefulness that this group typically brings to its performances.

title: Long on Sound, Short on Philosophy
description: The introduction to the Hellacopters' song ''Born Broke'' feels deeply familiar, like the hard-rock equivalent of a row house's entrance hall. Playing it at Coney Island High on Friday night, Nicke Andersson sprayed a short squeal of feedback and lined out a guitar vamp. On the vamp's fourth cycle he lunged to the microphone and made a sound as if he'd been belted in the stomach. The whole band, pushed by its startlingly good drummer, Robert Eriksson, joined in on the same thundering riff. Mr. Andersson arrived at the chorus, singing couplets that weren't worth the book of matches they were written on -- like ''your teaching really made me dumb/don't call me slacker, cause I am a bum!'' -- and Mr. Eriksson led back to the verses with a gracefully stampeding one-bar fill.

title: If Lucia's Mad, Other People Are Just Angry

Ruth Ann Swenson, one of the finest coloratura sopranos of her generation, a technically exquisite vocalist who has been gaining steadily in artistic depth, was to sing her first Met performances in this touchstone role, and her recent work suggested that she was poised to join the ranks of great Lucia's from the company's past. The casting of the other roles seemed promising. So, all the Met had to do was assemble a good production team and give Ms. Swenson the support she deserved.

title: Proving That Actions Speak Louder Than Words

But if you ignore it -- that is quite easy to do -- you are likely to enjoy the performance much more. The title comes from Thoreau's famous essay, and Ms. Stoklos's message is that for the next thousand years thoughtful people have an obligation to dissent from any idea or social arrangement that would constrain creative living. She draws part of her text from Thoreau and ties it into ideas of the Brazilian educator and philosopher Paolo Freire. This would draw you to the theater?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, STANLEY J.
description: NORTON-Stanley J., 81, of Naples died December 7, 1998 at Naples Community Hospital, Naples, Florida, after a brief illness. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y., on December 18, 1916, Mr. Norton served as an Army officer in both World War II and the Korean War. He enjoyed a long and sucessful career as an Attorney and advisor to the Heavy Construction Industry. Mr. Norton was politically outspoken and a strong supporter of Conservative political organizations. He was a deeply religious, intellectual and philosophical man with untiring devotion to his beloved wife Noreen and his children Stanley J. Jr. and Noreen, all of whom survive him and will miss him dearly. After living for 35 years in Smoke Rise, NJ, Stanley and Noreen retired to Naples. He led an active, youthful life, enjoying travel and debate in the company of close friends, until days prior to his death. He effected many lives and leaves many friends. His wit, charm and warmth will be sorely missed. Relatives and friends are invited to call at the Fuller Funeral Home, 1625 Pine Ridge Road, Naples, FL., Thursday, December 10th, 6-8 PM. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Williams Catholic Church, 601 Seagate Dr., Naples, FL. Friday December 11 at 10 AM. Interment Naples Memorial Gardens. title: KINROSS GOLD TAKING CHARGE TO WRITE DOWN MINES' VALUE

title: Texas and International Law
description: The execution of Joseph Stanley Faulder, if allowed to go forward as scheduled tomorrow, would seriously damage the United States' ability to protect American citizens arrested in foreign countries. Mr. Faulder, a Canadian citizen, was convicted of murder in Texas and has spent the last two decades on death row. But Texas did not notify him of his right to seek help from the Canadian consulate after his arrest, even though Texas officials knew that Mr. Faulder was Canadian. That failure violated the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations, ratified by the Senate in 1969, which requires that a person arrested in a foreign country be allowed to seek assistance from a consulate post of his own country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, LT. COL. EDWARD ARTHUR, RET.
description: HERTZ-Lt. Col. Edward Arthur, Ret. Aged 72, born October 18, 1926 in Detroit, Michigan; passed away Dec. 2, at home in Canoga Park, California. Upon graduating St. Joseph High School in St. Joseph, Michigan in 1944, he entered the U.S. Army and became a paratrooper in the 11th Airborne Division. After serving in Postwar Occupation Japan, he returned to civilian life in 1947, attending Kalamazoo College and Wayne University graduating in 1951 with a degree in Education. In 1952, he was again called to serve his country, and reentered the Army as a 2nd Lieutenant, serving in the Korean War, during which time he met and married 2nd Lt. Edna J. Dube, a U.S. Air Force Flight Nurse and his wife of 44 years. He remained in the army until 1970 with numerous postings overseas as well as 2 tours of duty during the Vietnam Conflict, where he was awarded the Bronze Star. He is also survived by his 4 children, Barbara Friedmann, Valentina Grossman, Victoria Greenwood and Christopher Hertz. An articulate and well-read man throughout his life, he pursued an eclectic mix of interests that enriched the lives of family and friends. He will be greatly missed.

description: ROSENBERG-Henry, formerly of Rego Park, New York, passed away peacefully at the age of 90 on December 8, 1998 in Houston, Texas. Survivors: Beloved wife of 68 years, Lee Rosenberg, son and daughter-in-law Marvin and Sheila Rosenberg, grandchildren, Gregg and Rana Rosenberg, Pamela Rosenberg and Amy and Andrew Small. Great grandchildren, Ashley, Hayley and Lauren Rosenberg, Jacob, Emily and Joshua Small. Services will be on Friday, December 11, 1998, in Houston. The family requests that for those who desire to make contributions to Rabbi David Rosen's Discretionary Fund at Congregation Beth Yeshurun, 4525 Beechnut, Houston, Texas 77096.

title: Corrections
description: An article Nov. 14 about Representative J. C. Watts Jr. misstated the name of Mr. Watts's Democratic opponent in Oklahoma. He was Ben Odom, not Bruce Ober.

title: CORPORATE EXPRESS TO CLOSE 100 SITES AND CUT 1,700 JOBS
description: Corporate Express Inc. said yesterday that it would close or consolidate more than 100 sites and cut 1,700 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force, to trim costs amid a slump in demand for its office products and supplies. The company said it would take a pretax charge in the range of $65 million to $75 million, primarily for severance packages and lease cancellations. The company, which is based in Broomfield, Colo., said it was being hurt by a lag in demand from financial services and energy-related companies in the Eastern United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOWITZ, NORMAN
description: RABINOWITZ-Norman. Beloved husband of Pearl; devoted father of Naomi and Zoe. Funeral, 11:30, December 11 at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

title: People
description: * Ronald Yue was named to the new post of president for the Asia-Pacific region at Lowe & Partners Worldwide, Hong Kong, part of the Lowe Group unit of Interpublic Group. He had been managing director at HKT Group, Hong Kong.

title: Lowly P.D.A. Stylus Is Going Multimedia
description: With personal digital assistants continuing to add more functions, it was only a matter of time before some company decided that the stylus -- that inkless pen used to write on and access data from P.D.A.'s -- needed upgrading, too.

title: A Snubbed Tom Wolfe Parries With 2 Men of Letters
description: From where did all this fury come? Could it simply be that two of the most celebrated literary icons of our time, Norman Mailer and John Updike, are jealous of Tom Wolfe? In their reviews, both authors struggled mightily and not with tender heart to establish that Mr. Wolfe's new best-selling novel, ''A Man in Full,'' was guaranteed not to be literature. Entertainment, sometimes. Journalism, probably. Art, certainly not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZASLOW, MICHAEL
description: ZASLOW-Michael. The Creative Coalition mourns the passing of our friend and esteemed Board Member, Michael Zaslow. Michael will always be remembered for his grace and dignity, and as a shining leader in the arts and entertainment community. His dedication and longtime commitment to public advocacy has been instrumental in empowering current and future generations. We are honored to have known and worked with him and offer our heartfelt condolences to his family. We will miss him. William Baldwin President The Creative Coalition

title: Bell Atlantic Unit Is in Joint Venture
description: The Bell Atlantic Mobile unit of the Bell Atlantic Company and the Crown Castle International Corporation said today that they had agreed to form a $650 million joint venture to own and operate wireless telecommunications towers.

title: Netanyahu's Waning Wizardry
description: Throughout his career, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has been regarded as a political Houdini, a magician able to square circles, escape impossible traps and remain whole while being sawed into little pieces. But on Monday, Haim Ramon, the Labor Party stalwart, did to Mr. Netanyahu what every ersatz wizard since Oz has most feared: he pulled back the curtain and showed the public how the magic really works.

title: 2 Potential Witnesses Against Gotti Plead Guilty
description: Two former owners of a Manhattan topless club, who are potential witnesses in a racketeering case against John A. Gotti, have admitted in a secret plea-bargain deal with Federal prosecutors that they aided mobsters and committed a raft of financial crimes.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN CLIMBS. Japan's currency rose sharply against the dollar on comments from Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa in support of a weaker dollar. In New York, the dollar traded at 117.82 yen, down from 119.31 yen.

description: LONDON  For advocates of Britain's entry into economic and monetary union, including the government of Prime Minister Tony Blair, things had been going remarkably well in recent months.

description: In a symbolic victory for the City Council, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed yesterday to allow its members to hold news conferences on the steps of City Hall, despite a security crackdown that has drastically scaled back access to the building.

title: Two Officers Are Arrested In 2 Incidents
description: Two off-duty New York City police officers were arrested yesterday in separate incidents, the police said. One was accused of shooting his wife in the face, officials said, and the other was charged with killing his girlfriend in a drunken-driving crash in New Jersey.

title: For First Time, U.N. Calls Anti-Semitism Racism
description: For the first time in more than half a century, the United Nations General Assembly decided today to list anti-Semitism as a form of racism.

title: Lawyer in Clean-Water Suit Assails New York's Tactics
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the Hudson Valley environmentalist, has accused state officials of improperly requesting his personal real-estate records in an effort to embarrass him, saying officials may be trying to discourage his conservation organization from pushing a lawsuit against the city.

description: ISAACS-Norma, 97, of New York City, on Oct 12, 1998. Memorial Service at Dorot Building, 171 W. 85 St. NY, Sat., Dec 19 at 6:30PM.

title: Albright Presses Russia to Limit Aid to Iran for Missile Program
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright pressed the Russian Foreign Minister today for a Russian commitment to limit cooperation with the Iranian missile program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMMERMAN, ROCHELLE COHAN
description: IMMERMAN-Rochelle Cohan, on December 8, in Palm Beach, Fl. Celebrated a joyous life for 86 years. Wife of Irving and the late Samuel Cohan and Gabriel Wishbow. Loving mother of Margot (Stephen) Holland and Gail Reiss. Grandmother of Elizabeth (Alvin) Weiss, Joshua Holland, Jane (Dan) Scheffelman, Nancy (Nick) Booke, and Meg Reiss. Great grandmother of Lena, Will, Henry and Milo. Graveside service at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI, 11:00AM Friday. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Anti Defamation League would be appreciated.

title: Wall St. Living: Still Quiet After the Bulls Go Home
description: AT 8:30 on a Saturday night, the holiday shooting stars suspended above Nassau Street are aglow, illuminating only blocks of rolled-down alumunium security shutters. There are no coffee shops still open, no magazine shops, no bars -- and even more strikingly -- there are no people.

title: Swooning Over a Crooner's File
description: Frank Sinatra's F.B.I. dossier, opened seven months after his death, now makes it clear that some legends resist tarnish better than others. The bureau's tawdry collection of charges, gossip and weirdo conspiracy theories all stamped with dates and the official F.B.I. seal might besmirch a more traditionally wholesome American superstar. But for one who has long been certified as an earlier generation's celebrity tough guy, how much does it hurt to hear that Frank Sinatra was not exactly Pat Boone? O.K., so there are charges about shady associates and that he had, shall we say, an active social life, or even that he was a lefty who was ready, maybe, to rat on his lefty pals.

description: The directors of New York City Transit yesterday amended a proposal for one-day, unlimited-ride Metrocards, which are to be introduced on Jan. 1, to make the passes available at subway token booths.

description: THE proposed $80 billion merger between Exxon and Mobil raises a question: At what point does a company get so big that its size alone becomes a nightmare for consumers?

description: THE world of computer-based reference products is changing. First came the shrink-wrapped boxes with a CD-ROM or two inside. Now that is old hat.

title: Punks Laugh As They Battle Phonies
description: The men in the Offspring are real punk rockers. That's why they can make fun of phonies like the one in ''Pretty Fly (For a White Guy),'' the band's fiendishly catchy new hit. The song derides a white boy who adopts black styles to look tough but ends up a fool in his baggy jeans and fake prison tattoos. While the band performed the song on Tuesday night at Irving Plaza, Guy Cohen, the actor who plays the fly white guy in its video, struck some stupid gangster poses before proving himself an actual punk by stage-diving into the crowd.

title: Hazel Bishop, 92, an Innovator Who Made Lipstick Kissproof
description: Hazel Bishop, who cooked up the first kissproof lipstick (''stays on you . . . not on him'') in a kitchen fitted out as a laboratory, then lost the right to use the name she made famous, died on Saturday at the Osborn Home in Rye, N.Y. She was 92.

description: KATZ-Thelma. Beloved wife of the late Jack; loving mother of Sheila Tick and Daniel Katz; cherished grandmother of Jeffrey Tick, Pamela April, Jonathan Tick, Nicole and Erika Katz and greatgrandmother of Ryan, Micaela, Lexis, Kelly and Tyler Tick; and Jennifer, Jessica and Jake April. title: I'll Always Love You, but Is It Time to Move On?
description: DURING the long months of my first pregnancy, I exhibited the usual range of tender maternal feelings. As I lay awake at night, I hoped that my daughter would be born healthy, with my husband's hair and with a strong aversion to dating boys who rode motorcycles.

title: Metro Business; 2 Traders Sentenced For Insider Trading
description: A former trader at John W. Henry & Company and a commodity futures trading adviser who was his longtime friend were each sentenced this week to 33 months in prison for illegally making $4.7 million by misusing the firm's confidential trading information.

title: Burrell Names A New York Chief
description: Burrell Communications Group in Chicago has named a new president and chief executive for its New York direct-response office.

title: Before High Court, Chicago Defends Approach to Gangs
description: In a spirited Supreme Court argument today, the City of Chicago defended an anti-loitering law that permits arrests not only of suspected gang members, but also of anyone else who, standing with ''no apparent purpose'' on a public street near a gang member, defies a police order to move on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STECHER, DR. EMMA DIETZ
description: STECHER-Dr. Emma Dietz. Died Dec. 6th at age 93, a biochemistry professor for many years at Barnard College, survived by her brother Dr. Richard Dietz, and ten nieces and nephews. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Thursday, 2 PM.

Brown, Inc., Funeral Home, 337 Belleville Ave., Bloomfield, NJ. title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the New York Philharmonic's plans for the 1999-2000 season misidentified the label that is to record a concert performance of ''Sweeney Todd.'' It is Deutsche Grammophon, not Teldec.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the announcement that Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago will run for re-election omitted the name of his predecessor. Mr. Daley first won election in 1989 by defeating Eugene Sawyer, who had been appointed interim Mayor after Harold Washington died in office in 1987. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the number of blacks who have held the post. Mr. Washington was the first of two; Mr. Sawyer was the second.

title: CUNY Wins Ruling in a Dispute Over Graduation Requirements
description: In a victory for the trustees of the City University of New York, a state appellate division panel has upheld the university's right to withhold diplomas from students at a bilingual community college in the South Bronx who did not pass an English writing examination.

title: A Community of Actors, but Hardly Community Theater
description: A man and woman locked in an amorous embrace tumbled again and again across three folding chairs. At first jerky and self-conscious, with each repetition the actors' movements became smoother and more confident. As the choreography of their entanglement was refined, dialogue was added and other characters joined the skit; a slapstick Marx-brothers-style bit emerged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREGMAN, EVELYN
description: BREGMAN-Evelyn. Of White Plains, NY and Fort Lauderdale, FL. Beloved sister of Gladys Gropper, loving aunt of Alan Gropper, Jo and Amy Applebaum and Lynn Haviland. Devoted sister-in-law of Leo Gropper and Lila Applebaum. Contributions may be made to The Dysautonomia Foundation. Services 11:30 AM today at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, NJ.

title: On Grave and Methodical Note, the Defense Rests
description: The White House completed its defense against impeachment before the House Judiciary Committee today with a concession by its top lawyer that ''reasonable people'' might conclude President Clinton had lied under oath.

title: Waste Management Settles Holders' Suit
description: Waste Management Inc., the largest waste disposal company in the United States, has agreed to help set up a $220 million fund to settle a class-action lawsuit that accused a recently acquired subsidiary of falsely portraying its financial condition.

title: Hirschfeld Indicted in Plot to Kill Business Partner
description: Abe Hirschfeld, the New York real estate developer, millionaire and perennially aspiring politician, has been indicted by a Manhattan grand jury in connection with a plot to kill his longtime business partner, his lawyer said last night.

title: Judges Seek Aid in Effort To Remain Independent
description: Judges feel themselves under attack these days, and there is ample evidence that they are: threats of impeachment over unpopular rulings, negative campaigns that mischaracterize the records of state judges who need voter approval to stay in office and legislative struggles over budgets and salaries.

title: Chevron Shares Soar on Speculation on a Sale
description: The shares of the Chevron Corporation rose today after an Internet site that tracks Dutch stocks speculated that the Royal Dutch/Shell Group might attempt a takeover of the company.

title: Briton Won't Free Pinochet, Ruling the Case Can Proceed
description: Britain's Home Secretary today turned down Gen. Augusto Pinochet's plea to be set free, ruling that a Spanish extradition case against the former Chilean dictator could go forward in English courts.

title: Sports of The Times; 13 Years Later, a Marino-Elway Reunion
description: LIKE two old gunfighters who had an insignificant skirmish when they were young, Dan Marino and John Elway are circling each other for only their second shootout, but on Sunday they must first stalk the Jets and the Giants.

description: BUILDING robots has always been a highly mechanical enterprise.

description: A Times Square hotel that has long been criticized by city officials as unsafe was ordered shut yesterday after inspectors found about 200 safety code violations.

In lieu of flowers, contributions to Parkinson's Disease Foundation - Columbia University Medical Center, 710 West 168 Street, New York 10032.

description: DRI International in New York has been awarded two direct-response television assignments with combined billings estimated at more than $10 million.

description: EVERY day, hundreds of blind and visually impaired people in Asheville, N.C., rely on Bob Brummond's radio reading service for their national and local news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTEIN, FELA
description: BLUESTEIN-Fela. Of Upper Montclair, NJ. Member of Hadassah, O.R.T. and Hidden Children. Survived by her husband Sanfurd. Contributions may be made to Hidden Children or New York Holocaust Museum. Services are today, 10:00am at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel 150 Rt 4 East, Paramus, NJ. Interment will be held Sunday, 12 Noon, at Kiryat Shaul Cemetery, Tel Aviv, Israel.

title: Near-Intact Skeleton Offers Clues to Human Tree's Root
description: In a discovery that may answer some of the ''missing link'' questions of human evolution, scientists in South Africa have found what they describe as the best preserved and most nearly complete skull and skeleton yet seen of any very early member of the human family tree.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A flatter yield curve indicates investors may be expecting a significant slowing of the economy.
description: WITH the yield on the 30-year bond below 5 percent again, investors seem to be signaling that they are even happier about the outlook for inflation than they were. But, at the same time, they may be worried anew that the Federal Reserve has not done enough to protect the American economy from being tripped up by the global financial crisis.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of former Senator Albert Gore Sr. of Tennessee on Tuesday misstated the age he had reached when his son was nominated for vice president, in 1992. It was 84, not 82.

title: In America
description: Willie Mays was on the phone, telling a story about himself and Joe DiMaggio that went back nearly half a century.

title: Wishful Thinking in Baghdad
description: By turning international weapons inspectors away from the headquarters of its ruling party yesterday, Iraq showed why the United Nations Security Council should make no move toward lifting economic sanctions. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright was right to warn promptly that Washington will hold up any review of Iraq's status until Baghdad honors its pledge of unhindered access for the weapons investigators. The surprise inspections that began Tuesday, in which U.N. specialists look for hidden materials and records with little advance notification, are particularly important.

title: Trustee Widens Disclosure for Municipal Union
description: Moving to eliminate corruption, the new trustee running District Council 37, New York City's largest municipal union, ordered more financial disclosure from the council's 56 locals yesterday and took initial steps to overhaul the union's election procedures.

title: F.D.A. Assigning Arnold More Work
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Arnold Communications in Boston by naming that shop as the agency of record for its tobacco and other marketing communications programs. The assignment, for which the billings have not been determined, is a one-year contract with an option for four one-year renewals.

title: UMass Threatens, but UConn Prevails
description: Connecticut was tested tonight, but the Huskies remained unbeaten.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, RUTH
description: HYMAN-Ruth. Died on December 8, 1998. Longtime resident of Jamaica Estates. Beloved wife of Supreme Court Justice Harold Hyman. Cherished mother to Edward, Franklin and Myra, grandmother, and great-grandmother. Shiva will be held at the house of Myra and Philip Diamond, 9 Vauxhall Court, Melville, New York.

title: F.D.A. Approves Wider Use of Liver Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved the expanded use of Rebetron, a treatment already on the market for hepatitis C, a viral infection of the liver that can lead to cirrhosis, liver cancer and liver failure.

title: Censure Fits the Offense
description: At long last, the House Judiciary Committee has before it two resolutions -- one for censure and one for impeachment -- that define the choices before Congress and the nation. The censure resolution, drafted by three Democrats, needs more direct language about President Clinton's lies under oath. But it represents a vehicle both for Democrats and for moderate Republicans to deliver what the public properly wants, which is to condemn Mr. Clinton strongly and then allow him to finish out his term of office.

title: CROMPTON AND IMPERIAL IN DEALS WITH CHRISTIAN HANSEN
description: The Crompton & Knowles Corporation, a maker of specialty chemicals, said yesterday that it would sell its food and pharmaceutical ingredients unit to Christian Hansen Holding A/S of Denmark for $103 million, to focus on more profitable businesses. The unit is the biggest United States supplier of molasses. It contributed about 5 percent of Crompton's 1997 sales of $1.85 billion. Crompton also makes products ranging from dyes to insecticides to rubber chemicals. Hansen, based in Horsholm, Denmark, is a biotechnology company. Hansen said it was also buying a food colorings business from a unit of Imperial Chemicals Industries P.L.C., Britain's largest specialty chemicals company, for $55 million.
