description: WILSON-George. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member George Wilson. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: American Steel At the Barricades; With Prices Low, Companies and Labor Unite in a Campaign to Limit Imports
description: This town was once the steel capital of the East, its namesake company turning out girders for the Golden Gate Bridge, Rockefeller Center and the Supreme Court building. But today Bethlehem is best known as a charming tourist spot of historic churches and ubiquitous Christmas decorations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WAGMAN, JOSEPH
description: WAGMAN - Joseph. 12/10/96. Loved and remembered forever. Wonderful memories. Anne, Laura, Robert, Debbie and Mike

title: What Makes Vacco Keep Fighting the Numbers?
description: In politics, the partisan warfare usually ends the day after the election, when candidates metamorphose into courtly ladies and gentlemen, dutifully utter pleasantries about their opponents, and move on. But after a race that he apparently lost by the slimmest of margins, Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco has refused to stand down, even as he suffers repeated setbacks, as he did yesterday, in his stubborn quest for resurrection.

title: Modern Life From Two Angles
description: Ballet Hispanico is known for the vibrant eclecticism of its repertory and dancing. But two pieces presented by the company over the weekend at the Joyce Theater were surprisingly similar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANLEY, BROWN, EDWARD, MD
description: STANLEY-BROWN-Edward, MD. The entire family of St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Center mourns the passing of Edward Garfield Stanley-Brown, M.D. A great grandson of the former President of the United States and a veteran of the U.S. Army in Korea, he was a beloved and revered Director of Pediatric Surgery who upheld our finest traditions of medical excellance in over three decades of service to our hospital. He will be sorely missed. To his wife Jeanne, his daughters Beth Horan and Jill Driscoll, and his entire family, we offer our profound condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman of the Board Sigurd H. Ackerman, MD President Carlton Boxhill, MD President of the Medical Board

title: Essay; Trust the Senate
description: If the House sent the charges against President Clinton to the Senate for trial, said White House Counsel Charles Ruff, it would be ''putting the country through the horror that we all know would follow.'' Trying the President on such charges would be ''a nightmare for the country.''

title: Adubato Fifth Male Coach in W.N.B.A.
description: Yes, he's a man. And yes, he has been around the league a few times as a head coach in the National Basketball Association.

title: Archie Moore, 84, Master of the Ring, Dies
description: Archie Moore, the fighter whose legendary career spanned almost three decades and who won the light-heavyweight championship when he was well into his 30's, died yesterday at a hospice in San Diego. His age, always the subject of speculation, which he helped fuel, was 84.

title: Paperwhite Splendor
description: Q. Last year, I planted 25 Ziva white-flowered paperwhites in three bulb pans. I watered them thoroughly and kept them in a dark, 55-degree room for five to six weeks before bringing them out into a sunny room. The 25 bulbs had 24 flower clusters, about eight per tray, yet bulb catalogues have photos of pots covered with masses of blooms. Are there tricks the pros use to get more flowers?

title: Judge Orders Gymnast's Father to Lie Low
description: The father of Dominique Moceanu was barred from personally contacting or approaching his daughter for one year today, a step the 17-year-old Olympic gymnast said she hopes will enable her to ''move forward with my schooling and gymnastics.''

title: Starr Accuses Clinton of Distorting His Report
description: The independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, today challenged several assertions in the White House's 184-page defense brief, complaining that President Clinton's rebuttal contained ''a series of misrepresentations regarding this office's referral.''

title: Perhaps We Should Be Amazed That It Can Surf the Web at All
description: Since 3Com announced its newest version of the popular Palm Pilot, the Palm VII, it has been criticized by some users for offering only limited Web access. That access, called Web Clippings, allows Palm users to see updated, albeit abridged, information from 22 corporate Web sites through a wireless connection.

title: Century Communications Expects Rise in Cash Flow as It Expands Into New Markets
description: The Century Communications Corporation, a cable-television operator based in New Canaan, Conn., expects cash flow to increase 12.5 percent in the first six months of the current fiscal year as it adds subscribers and expands its businesses into new markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOBILETTI, JOHN B., MD
description: NOBILETTI-John B., MD. The Board of Trustees, the Medical Staff and Administration of Jamaica Hospital Medical Center mourn the passing of John B. Nobiletti, MD, our esteemed colleague, a member of the Department of Family Practice and Treasurer of the Medical Staff. Dr. Nobiletti practiced medicine in Kew Gardens for over 60 years touching the lives of thousands of patients. He served in the United States Army (1942-1945) as a combat battalion surgeon with the Third Armored Division in Europe, from the beaches of Normandy to Germany and was awarded five battle stars, a combat medic's badge and a bronze medal for valor. Dr. Nobiletti's spirit, compassion and good works will continue to inspire all of us. David P. Rosen, Pres. and Chief Exec. Officer Anthony DiMaria, MD, Pres., Medical Staff William Erhardt, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Grandma's House Gets Guided Tours
description: HISTORY arises at unexpected moments. For the descendants of Abraham and Fannie Rogarshevsky, it came between the dill pickles and the corned beef sandwiches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNELL, JOHN
description: O'CONNELL-John. The officers and members of the Transport Workers Union of America AFLCIO deeply mourn the death of one of the most capable and wellliked officers in our union's history. John O'Connell served our union for 30 years as International Representative, International Vice President, Administrative Assistant to former International President Matthew Guinan, and Director of Publicity from 1949 until his retirement in 1979. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Genie, sons, John, Jr. and Thomas, and daughters, Maureen and Patricia. Viewing will be at the Moritz Funeral Home, Rt. 303, Tappan, NY (914-359-0890) Wednesday, Dec 9th from 7-9 P.M., and Thursday Dec. 10th from 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Funeral services will be conducted Friday 10 A.M., Dec. 11th at St. Catherine's Church, Western Highway in Blauvelt, NY. Sonny Hall International President Frank McCann Exeutive Vice President John J. Kerrigan Secretary Treasurer

title: Chase Bank Finds Room for Small Borrowers
description: One of the nation's largest banks has developed a new loan program to help small businesses with loans as small as $5,000 to business owners as diverse as hair designers, yoga instructors, flower arrangers and tea importers.

title: On-Line Shopping: Good, Bad and Growing; Not Every Maker Wants Its Products Sold on the Net, at Least Not by Others
description: WITH on-line sales booming, millions of people are going to try to see if they can cut down on trips to the mall this holiday season and do some shopping over the Internet. Some will end up being disappointed.

title: Glaxo in Egyptian Deal
description: Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. of Britain has agreed to buy Amoun Pharmaceuticals Industries, Egypt's seventh-largest drug company, for an expected 400 million Egyptian pounds ($117 million) and then wrap it into its local operation to become Egypt's biggest drug producer. Glaxo will buy about 90 percent of the family-controlled Amoun, its production plants and the rights to 30 of its products. It will also offer to buy the 10 percent of Amoun held by other investors.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Sun Microsystems' new version of the Java programming language misstated the extent of technical cooperation provided by Microsoft to be sure Java works properly on computers using Windows operating software. Microsoft agreed to add to its own version of Java an element known as J.N.I. to comply with a recent Federal Court order. Microsoft has not agreed to add features to Windows that would enhance the performance of Jini, the Java technology distributed by Sun.

title: Dentsu Considering A Burnett Stake
description: Two of the world's largest agency companies -- the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago and Dentsu Inc. in Tokyo -- said yesterday that they had agreed to proceed with talks to form a strategic alliance that would include the acquisition of a minority stake in Burnett by Dentsu.

title: Chile Recalls London Envoy And Pledges To Fight On
description: The Chilean Government recalled its Ambassador to London today to protest the British Home Secretary's refusal to block a Spanish extradition request for Gen. Augusto Pinochet, Chile's onetime dictator.

title: Greenalls Group Selling Pubs to Nomura Unit
description: Greenalls Group P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it would sell 1,241 pubs to Tudor Street Acquisitions P.L.C., a subsidiary of Nomura International P.L.C., for $:370 million ($612 million). Nomura International is a unit of the Nomura Securities Company of Japan. The sale covers virtually all of the Greenalls tenanted pub division, Inn Partnership, and also includes 22 pubs that will be transferred from the managed pubs business.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Rangers Victimized by Avalanche's Quick Strike
description: The Rangers had not won six consecutive games since 1994 -- the year they won the Stanley Cup.

title: A Vote to Impeach
description: Now that the House Judiciary Committee is concluding its inquiry, all eyes have turned to the 20 or so ''moderate'' Republicans who represent the swing votes that could decide whether the House impeaches the President.

title: IMPEACHMENT COUNTS UNVEILED AS DEMOCRATS DRAFT A CENSURE
description: Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee this evening formally called for President Clinton's removal from office in four draft articles of impeachment accusing Mr. Clinton of perjury, obstruction of justice and abuse of power. The proposed charges were disclosed even before the White House had finished presenting its two-day defense of the President to the panel.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; Nature, Done Up for the Holidays
description: AWAY from the clattering miniature electric trains and the twinkling Christmas tree tickling the glass roof of the Enid Haupt Conservatory came a moment of truth: ''It smells like winter out here,'' said Ashali Bhandari, 7, of Manhattan.

title: Go Cheap Or Buy The Best?
description: SHOPPING for a personal computer can be more confusing than shopping for a car, as was pointed out in this space last week. But it is significantly cheaper, unless one gets a really big computer or a really lousy car.

title: Israel's Supreme Court Ends Yeshiva Student Exemption
description: In a landmark decision that touches a deep divide between strictly religious and secular Israelis the Israeli Supreme Court ruled today that a longstanding exemption for rigorously Orthodox Jewish yeshiva students from army service was illegal.

title: Bank of England Expected to Lower Rate
description: The Bank of England is expected to cut its key interest rate today by at least a quarter-point and possibly by half a point as the latest business surveys show that the economic slowdown is deepening. With European rate cuts setting a new 3 percent benchmark on the Continent, the gap with Britain's main rate of 6.75 percent has widened and threatens to hurt British exporters.

title: Impeachment Driving Small Wedge Into G.O.P.
description: When Representative Henry J. Hyde proclaimed in September that the impeachment of a President could not succeed unless it was bipartisan, Republicans hoped the scandal over President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky would fracture the Democratic Party.

title: At Judiciary Hearings: Jousting, Not Discussion; Is Senate Final Word?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Reports Less Growth In November
description: Economic growth slowed in many parts of the country in November, and inflation remained absent as wage pressures lessened, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Seesaw: Arafat's Up; Clinton and Netanyahu Teeter
description: As President Clinton prepares to fly into the diplomatic sandstorm of the Middle East, it is not just land borders but political boundaries that have shifted, creating a whole new landscape for the three-sided relationship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARK, FRANCES L., DR.
description: STARK-Frances L., Dr. Formerly of Fort Lee, N.J. Died Boca Raton, FL., Dec. 8, 1998. An optometrist in Union City for over fifty years. She served on the N.J. State Board of Optometry & the Fort Lee School Board for over twenty years. She is survived by a daughter Paula Stark Rosenfeld of Boca Raton, and Dr. James Stark of Norfolk, VA. Funeral Service December 10, 10:30AM, at Gutterman-Musicant Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: Oregon's Gay Workers Given Benefits for Domestic Partners
description: In the first ruling of its kind, an appeals court in Oregon ruled yesterday that the State Constitution gave homosexual government employees the right to health and life insurance benefits for their domestic partners.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Officemax to Add Stores
description: Officemax Inc., the third-largest United States office-supply retailer, said today that it would open 25 stores in the next six weeks and will hit its goal of opening 120 stores in its fiscal year ending in January. The company, based in Shaker Heights, said it would have 832 stores in the United States and Puerto Rico by the end of its fiscal year. The company said openings were part of an aggressive expansion plan, which includes opening at least 100 full-size ''superstores'' in 1999, about half of them in smaller-size markets.

title: Cars That Open Up To Computers, Literally
description: Like it or not, computers are on a collision course with cars. On Dec. 5, the British journal New Scientist reported a new automotive use for the infrared port on the popular Palm Pilot handheld organizers. After modifying the Pilot to capture and retransmit infrared signals from a television set, in an attempt to use the Pilot as a replacement for the standard remote control device, a computer journalist discovered that it could also duplicate the signals that control some automobile security systems. After the owner locks the car using a remote control device (typically on the keychain) and walks away, the Pilot could capture the signal, send it back to the car and unlock the doors. According to the Insurance Information Institute in New York, 23.5 percent of all cars built in North America in 1997 had electronic anti-theft systems, though many use radio waves, not infrared, systems.

title: It Sounds Nice, but Can It Fix A Flat Tire When You Need It?
description: Last week the Microsoft Corporation and the Clarion Corporation introduced the Auto PC, a Windows CE-based dashboard computer that uses voice commands to control a digital radio, a CD player, a cellular phone and a navigation system. It also uses voice synthesis to read traffic reports, incoming E-mail and the driver's personal contact directory. The Auto PC is currently available only in California and Washington State, but Microsoft says it will soon be offered nationwide as an option on high-end automobiles, with prices starting at $1,299. PETER H. LEWIS

title: The Drama of Impeachment, From 130 Years Ago
description: As the impeachment proceedings play out in Washington, a Web site offers the spectacle of an earlier impeachment drama.

title: A Pier, Once Ignored, Is Suddenly a Favorite
description: A WHITE elephant when it was built in the 1960's and a lonely spit in the water ever since, Pier 40 is suddenly in the spotlight. Last month, news leaked out that the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and the architect Frank O. Gehry were developing preliminary sketches and a model for a new museum branch that they hoped to build on the 15-acre site in the Hudson River at Houston Street, currently a 2,000-car parking garage.

title: No Offer Was Made by Saudi For Troubled U.S. Hedge Fund
description: Prince Walid bin Talal, the Saudi billionaire businessman known for strategic investments in troubled companies, considered buying the hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management two months ago but never made an offer.

title: An Old Row House Basks in Its Second Youth
description: WORKING with a decorator was kind of like, 'Whoa,' '' said Amanda Sacks, who lives in a newly decorated four-story Victorian town house in Park Slope, Brooklyn. ''Because I'd never actually worked with a decorator before.'' Ms. Sacks, age 9, said she thought the experience was a good one.

title: Strong Club Opening Bids: A Success Story, With Skill
description: More than one-third of experts around the world use strong club systems, and in some countries the percentage is much higher. Hands with 17 or more high-card points, or in some cases 16, open artificially with one club. All or nearly all other openings show weaker hands, usually in the 11-16 range. Two clubs is used for hands with a long club suit.

title: Case Against President Would Fail, Panel Contends
description: A panel of former Federal criminal justice officials offered a new approach today in defense of the President against impeachment: No ''responsible'' prosecutor would bring a perjury case against Mr. Clinton, they said, because the evidence presented by the special prosecutor was insufficient to win a conviction in court.

title: 4 French Companies In Missile Contract Pact
description: The French companies Aerospatiale, Thomson-CSF, Lagardere and Alcatel agreed not to compete with each other for missile contracts, ending a dispute that had threatened to derail France's plans to reshape its military industry. The pact also reverses an earlier accord that would have kept Aerospatiale out of the satellite business after it gave its satellite unit to Thomson-CSF, the four companies said.

description: To the Editor:

title: Putting African Art to Good Use
description: MANY people admire things in our gift shop but can't visualize the pieces in their home,'' said Elsie Crum McCabe, the president of the Museum for African Art in SoHo. ''I really wanted to give visitors an idea of how to live with African art, how to integrate it into their own lives.''

description: IF we ever arrive at that point in history where machines become our masters, it will have all begun with machine vision.

description: The Microsoft trial focused today on an esoteric issue that is crucial to the outcome of the antitrust case: What is a computer operating system?

title: Framing a Vision, Invisibly Maryse Alberti, an Independent Force in Independent Films
description: Until the cinematographer turns up on a movie set, everyone else is putting on a play. The cinematographer (or director of photography) executes the director's vision, lights the scenes, manages the crew and records what happens on film. For many, the work is invisible.

description: To the Editor:

title: Better Business Bureau Says Nuclear Group Ran False Ads
description: The Better Business Bureau told the nuclear industry today to change ads the bureau said falsely claimed that nuclear reactors make power without polluting the air and water or damaging the environment.

title: Zeneca Buying Astra as Europe Consolidates
description: In one of Europe's biggest mergers, the Zeneca Group P.L.C. of Britain announced a stock deal valued around $35 billion today to buy Astra A.B. of Sweden, creating a pharmaceutical giant.

title: Governor Nominates a Second Judge to the State's Highest Court
description: Seizing a chance to reshape a court he has repeatedly assailed as too sympathetic to criminal defendants, Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday nominated Albert M. Rosenblatt, a state appeals court judge and a former Dutchess County prosecutor, to replace one of the state's most liberal jurists on New York's highest court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCQUISTON, ALAN EDWARD (TED) JR
description: McQUISTON-Alan Edward (Ted) Jr, 36, of New York City on December 6, 1998. Survivors include his parents Betsy & Alan McQuiston of Southbury, CT (formerly of Briarcliff Manor, NY), sisters Susanne Brebbia of Sharon, Mass., & Sarah McPhee of Pleasantville, NY, brother John McQuiston of New York City and nephews John Brebbia & Patrick McPhee. Calling hours Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, New York, Friday, December 11, 2-4 and 7-9. Services Briarcliff Congregational Church, Saturday, December 12 at 12:00. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Schleroderma Foundation, 89 Newbury St, Suite 201, Danvers, Mass. 01923 or the Human Rights Campaign, 919 18th Street NW, Suite 800, Washington, DC 20006, would be appreciated.

description: One night in April of 1994, Donte, Ciara, Mariah and Sharlton kissed their mother goodnight, headed for the back rooms of their Cincinnati apartment and fell asleep.

title: Making Light Of a Duchess Given to Night Music
description: ''Powder Her Face,'' the Thomas Ades opera at the Majestic Theater in Brooklyn, is unusual for its good nature. None of the cruelty and pessimism familiar to recent Central European opera here, no rehashes of the news as we have come to know it on our side of the Atlantic. ''Powder Her Face,'' which opened on Tuesday night, is genuinely amused by its characters. It has a good time.

title: Far From the Pleading Crowd: Furby's Dad
description: DAVID HAMPTON knows what he would have done if his parents had presented him with a Furby on his ninth birthday.

title: Red Storm Takes Its Fourth Straight
description: So far this season, St. John's has outrun and outjumped every team it has played. Whether facing Stanford or Hofstra, Purdue or Columbia, the Red Storm's superior athleticism has been obvious. But last night a group of leapers with quick hands, quick feet, quick everything visited Alumni Hall, demanding that St. John's prove it is more than speed and talent.

title: Looking Beyond the Sale
description: To the Editor:

title: Journalists in New Media Meet to Form an Association
description: A journalistic barn-raising of sorts took place in Chicago on Friday, as new media reporters and newsroom expatriates hammered together the framework of a new association of on-line journalists.

title: National News Briefs; Judge Orders Kevorkian To Be Tried for Murder
description: Both Dr. Jack Kevorkian and prosecutors got what they wanted today when a judge ordered him to stand trial for the death of a Michigan man suffering from Lou Gehrig's disease, whom Dr. Kevorkian injected with lethal drugs.

title: Citizens Left and Right Battle at the Grass Roots
description: On one level, the battle over the impeachment of William Jefferson Clinton is being played out in the House Judiciary Committee hearing room and in other Washington power alleys. But it is also being fought at a grass-roots level all over the country, with both those who fervently want the President impeached and those who just as fervently want him left alone trying to find ways to give weight to their wishes.

title: Debt Relief After a Killer Storm
description: Even before Tropical Storm Mitch devastated Nicaragua and Honduras, they were Latin America's poorest nations. While they are still struggling to prevent disease, provide shelter and get food to the victims, those nations and their less-affected neighbors are thinking about long-term reconstruction. They need billions of dollars to rebuild. Creditor nations and international donors must forgive the debts of Honduras and Nicaragua. Washington should also grant the region trade preferences that encourage economic growth.

title: Tracking the Evolution of E-Mail Etiquette
description: AS technologies evolve, so do the manners surrounding their use.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you walk down the street in Pyongyang and ask a child how old she is, you are usually off by three years. She may be 7, but she looks just 3 or 4.''

title: Vacco Fails in Bid For Police Canvass
description: Lawyers for Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco, seeking to head off an election defeat, acknowledged that they had failed in their effort to have the police verify the registration of thousands of New York City voters. The Giuliani administration said it would not deploy the police without a court order, and a judge declined to issue one.

title: New York City Nears Debt Limit, Report Warns
description: New York City will soon hit its borrowing limit unless the Giuliani administration finds faster and more economical ways of paying off debt, according to a new report by the City Comptroller's office.

title: Pettitte Would Go, but Clemens Deal Is Unlikely
description: The Yankees have expressed a willingness to trade Andy Pettitte in a package for Toronto's Roger Clemens, according to a major league executive. The teams, however, are not close to agreeing on the parameters for a deal.

title: Two Moves Indicate Asian Crises May Be Easing
description: In two signs that the global economic crisis is easing, South Korea said today that it was immediately paying back nearly $3 billion in emergency loans that kept it afloat last year, and China successfully raised $1 billion from foreign investors.

title: Bermuda Tourism Account in Review
description: The Bermuda Department of Tourism has placed in review its marketing communications account, which has been handled by two New York-based units of Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Changes in State Divorce Law Seek to Reduce Child Trauma
description: The state's chief judge yesterday announced a series of moves intended to protect children involved in divorces, furthering changes that she noted have reduced the time it takes to get a divorce and the number of cases in the court system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEHLER, EDWIN H.
description: KOEHLER-Edwin H., 98, a New York City Retail Merchant and Investment Banker, died Monday, December 7, 1998 at Mount Sinai Hospital, NYC. A graduate of Massachussets Institute of Technology, he held numerous positions of managership and ownership in various retail operations and towards the later years of his life, he was heavily involved in Investment Banking. He served in World War I, and lived in New York City and Oxford, Connecticut. He was a member of long standing at Temple Emanuel in NYC. His wife of 55 years, Phyllis Beer Koehler, died in 1978. He is survived by a sister, Carol Pforzheimer, a son Philip J. Koehler, four grandchildren, and seven great grandsons. A memorial service will be held at the Campbell Funeral Home, located between 81st and 82nd Streets on Madison Ave, NYC at 11:30AM on Monday, December 14. The family suggests memorial contributions to Temple Emanuel, 1 East 65th Street, NYC 10021.

title: At Judiciary Hearings: Jousting, Not Discussion; Exercise in Alienation
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Achilles' Heel:An 'Asymmetric Shock' to System
description: BRUSSELS  The dismal science has a couple of words for it: "asymmetric shock." The term refers to any serious distortion in a particular country, region or industrial sector that goes against the prevailing cycle in a given economic area  like a boat that remains stuck in the mud when the tide comes in.

title: Prosecutors Question Suharto About His Wealth as Troops Thwart Student Protests
description: As hundreds of soldiers and several small tanks blocked off streets to prevent student protests, state prosecutors questioned former President Suharto for four hours this morning about his wealth and financial dealings.

title: HAUSER TO BUY THREE UNITS OF ZUELLIG FOR $45.8 MILLION
description: Hauser Inc. agreed yesterday to buy three units of Zuellig Group N.A. for $45.8 million in stock to create the largest United States supplier of bulk herbal nutritional products. Hauser, based in Boulder, Colo., will issue 10.05 million common shares to acquire Zuellig Botanical Extracts, Wilcox Drug and Zetapharm. The units had combined sales in the fiscal year 1998 in excess of $125 million. Hauser will get an option to acquire the herbal powders business of Zuellig, which is based in Long Beach, Calif. Hauser will also assume Zuellig debt totaling about $19 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTIAGO, GEORGE
description: SANTIAGO-George. On December 8, 1998 after a valiant struggle against cancer. Survived by his longtime companion Carolyn Topak, mother Josephine, sister Elsie, brother Robert, beloved niece Linda and her husband Tony. Friends my visit at Edward D. Lynch & Son Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Boulevard, Sunnyside, New York. Funeral Mass St. Teresa R.C. Church, Friday 9:30AM. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Ice, So Cruelly Wondrous Even in the Face of Death
description: THE ENDURANCE

description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said today that it planned to reorganize its international business by creating three regional organizations to handle functions now run from its headquarters here.

description: To the Editor:

title: Survivor's Jubilant Devotion, Divine and Down to Earth
description: For Darlene Love, the separation between rock and gospel music is a revolving door, one she passes through easily in her show at Rainbow and Stars, where she is appearing through Saturday. Whether she's singing about a boyfriend who would make everything right or about the assurance of divine love, she projects jubilant, invincible hope with a voice to back it up. Ms. Love sounds as strong now as she did when she sang lead on some of Phil Spector's most memorable productions of the 1960's.

description: One will that will not be found on the Web site created by HERBERT E. NASS -- www.willsofrichandfamous.

title: Virgina Panel Recommends Tough New Penalties on Spam
description: Virginia will not be the first state to pass a law against mass producers of electronic junk mail. But what the state lacked in speed, it may make up with strength, and the impact could be widespread.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 27 about a deal by Visa Gold Resources of Canada to search for sunken treasure in Cuban waters overstated the number of 16th- and 17th-century Spanish galleons believed to have sunk in the Caribbean. Most scholars agree that it is far less than 500, not ''as many as'' 500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUJIKAWA, GYO
description: FUJIKAWA-Gyo. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved life member Gyo Fujikawa. She will be missed by all who knew her.

title: 'Push' Didn't Get the Shove
description: PARIS  Whatever happened to "push technology," the Internet delivery system that two years ago all the digerati said would take over our personal-computer desktops?

title: Clinton Meets 48 in Congress On Future of Social Security
description: President Clinton met with 48 members of Congress from both parties today to discuss how to shore up Social Security, and participants said they had come away optimistic, with some idea about how to edge toward full negotiations.

title: Dripping With Charm, Clinton's 'Clean-Up Hitter' Seems to Soothe Ardent Critics
description: Charles F. C. Ruff, the last of President Clinton's lawyers to appear before the Judiciary Committee and ''obviously, the President's clean-up hitter,'' in the words of one Republican on the committee, managed to serve up an often sarcastic defense of Mr. Clinton so respectfully that the Republicans whose position he was savaging hardly took offense.

title: Charity Plan Aided Wrong N.B.A. Players
description: When the organizers of a Dec. 19 exhibition game with locked-out National Basketball Association players promised to devote some of the proceeds to tapped-out players, mockery was inevitable. Yesterday's decision to reverse themselves was a triumph of sense over silliness.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the jazz bassist Bob Haggart on Friday cited his musical credits incompletely. He wrote the music for the song ''What's New,'' with words by Johnny Burke, and with the drummer Ray Bauduc wrote ''South Rampart Street Parade,'' with words by Steve Allen; he did not just write the arrangements.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Patents column of Business Day on Monday about a technology that lets on-line companies pay commissions for customer referrals from other Web sites misidentified the owner of Travelocity, a site that uses it. The owner is AMR, not Microsoft.

title: Indiana Has Credentials to Look Past Semifinals
description: For the second year in a row, the Indiana University men's soccer team has the most impressive credentials going into the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament semifinals. This is a record-setting 12th appearance in the semifinals for the Hoosiers, who are seeking their fourth national title.

title: Conscience in the Boardroom
description: To the Editor:

title: For Celebrating
description: Whether you want to spend some of your fabulous year-end bonus or simply mark the passing of another year, December is a time of celebrations. Here are a dozen restaurants that can inspire the proper festive mood. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Joseph Stanley Faulder, a Canadian who is on death row in Texas and whose case has drawn attention from the Canadian Government and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, misstated the outcome of a case against Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, an American boxer who spent 19 years in prison and is supporting Mr. Faulder's efforts to avoid execution. Mr. Carter was not acquitted of murder; his conviction was overturned twice, and prosecutors declined to try him a third time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRACHLER, JACOB
description: DRACHLER-Jacob. 89. Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Miriam. Dear brother of Sophie Schwartz. Father of Nina. Grandfather of Adam. Artist, writer, teacher. A most unusual and wonderful man.

title: Aetna Agrees to Buy Prudential Care Unit
description: Aetna agreed to buy Prudential Health Care from the Prudential Insurance Company for $1 billion, creating the nation's biggest managed care company.

title: Bicycling To Praise As Well as Exhaustion
description: There is something magical about complete ignorance of a sport. No one has any expectations of your performance, including yourself. Everything is fresh and new. Even the pain.

title: Odd Landscapes Dotted By Mankind's Mischief
description: Color landscape photography, pressed into service to sell everything from calendars and cigarettes to postcards and environmental causes, is usually not subversive. But the work of Virginia Beahan and Laura McPhee is subtly, slyly that. Using an old-fashioned Deardorff view camera with an 8-inch-by-10-inch format, this photographic team produces detailed and powerfully cinematic images that in enlargements are viscerally appealing. But once the photographers have your attention, they seem to make you look hard at the pictures because something is almost always off balance.

title: Holiday Revelry, Beyond the Rockettes
description: Here is a sampling of holiday celebrations including dance and dramatic events in New York City. Admission is free unless otherwise noted (churches accept donations).

title: Merle E. Gilliand, 76, Chairman Who Led Growth of PNC Bank
description: Merle E. Gilliand, retired chairman and chief executive of the PNC Bank Corporation, who presided over several mergers of the bank holding company over 30 years, died on Tuesday at the UPMC St. Margaret Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 76.

title: Man Admits Robbery And Hostage Taking
description: A Pennsylvania man admitted in Federal court yesterday that he had held a bank teller hostage during an armed robbery in Princeton last November and had got away with a duffel bag stuffed with about $164,000, prosecutors said.

title: Iraq Again Hindering Inspections, U.N. Told
description: The chief arms inspector for Iraq told the Security Council in a letter Wednesday night that the Iraqis have been interfering with inspections at a number of sites. And today Baghdad toughened its stand against allowing entry to the ruling party's offices, in contravention of Council resolutions.

title: Far From South Bend, Less Is Suddenly More
description: When Gus Ornstein arrived in August for the first day of football practice here at Rowan University, a Division III school in southern New Jersey, he asked the equipment manager for a wristband. No problem. The equipment manager cut off the top of a sock and handed it to him.

title: Deutsche Post to Buy Swiss Freight Company
description: Deutsche Post A.G., Germany's state postal service, agreed yesterday to buy the Swiss freight company Danzas Holding A.G. for 1.46 billion Swiss francs ($1 billion) in cash. The German company will pay 590 francs a share for Danzas, Europe's fourth-largest freight company.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK GAINS. Germany's currency strengthened to a six-week high against the dollar as United States stocks tumbled, hurting demand for the American currency. In New York the dollar cost 1.6515 marks, down from 1.6692.

title: Censure Now, Not Later; Due Process Mocked
description: To the Editor:

title: INFINITY SHARES UP 12.5% IN FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: The shares of the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation, the radio division of the CBS Corporation, rose 12.5 percent in their first day of trading yesterday as investors flocked to the radio network, the second largest in the United States. Infinity, based in New York, raised $2.87 billion on Wednesday in an initial public offering. Yesterday, the stock closed at $23.0625 -- $2.5625 above the offering price of $20.50 -- on trading of 52.9 million shares. Investors are betting that CBS's president, Mel Karmazin, 55, will increase the radio division's profits once he takes over as chairman and chief executive of CBS on Jan. 1. Mr. Karmazin sold Infinity to CBS in 1996 for $3.8 billion. After yesterday's trading, Infinity had a market value of $19.4 billion.

title: MORE ON THE HEARINGS
description: HENRY HYDE'S PREDICAMENT -- As chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, the Republican from Illinois finds his entire political career and public image distilled into a single act of stewardship. Page A30.

title: Arts Agency Loses Leader In a Struggle Over Power
description: The president of the New York City Art Commission has resigned, accusing Parks and Recreation Commissioner Henry J. Stern of subverting the public review process by installing 750 elaborate flagpoles, more than 150 plantings and other ornamental works around the city without approval.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWZE, HAMILTON, HAWKINS, GENERAL, US ARMY (RET)
description: HOWZE-Hamilton, Hawkins, General, US Army (ret), 89, of Fort Worth, Texas, passed away Tuesday afternoon at his residence. Funeral services will be at 11 AM Saturday, December 12 at St. Andrew Episcopal Church in Ft. Worth with a graveside service to follow at 10 AM on Wednesday December 16 at Post Cemetery, US Military Academy, West Point, NY. Friends are invited to send gifts if they wish to Army Emergency Relief, Military District of Washington a private charitable organization for emergency help for soldiers' families at 200 Stovall St., Alexandria, VA 22332 or to charities of choice. A native of West Point, NY, a graduate of West Point Academy in 1930, of Calvary School, US Army Command, General Staff College, and the National War College, he saw action in numerous European Campaigns during World War II, served with distinction in Korea, and was the Commander General of The Eighth US Army and Commander in Chief, US forces in Korea, a position from which he retired. After retirement from the Army, General Howze was Vice President of Bell Helicopter Textron and was a prolific writer for military and news publications. He holds the Distinguished Service Medal, the Bronze Star for Valor, the Italian Military Valor Cross, the Korean Order of Merit First Class, and a number of campaign medals. The Great Grandson of Hamilton S. Hawkins, an army surgeon who lost his life at Veracruz in the Mexican War, the Grandson of Brig. Gen. Hamilton S. Hawkins, the son of Maj. Gen. Robert L. Howze, he is survived by his wife Mary Henry Howze, his sons, William G. Howze, Guy R. Howze and his wife Anna, four grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Thompson's Harveson & Cole Funeral Home, 702 8th Ave, Ft Worth, Texas 76104

title: SHARES OF GROW BIZ RISE 32% ON NEWS OF BUYOUT OFFER
description: The stock of Grow Biz International jumped 32 percent yesterday after the company said it had received a $14-a-share cash buyout offer from two of its executives. The company said late on Wednesday that it had received the offer from its chairman, K. Jeffrey Dahlberg, and chief executive, Ronald G. Olson, who hold a combined 67 percent stake in the company. Grow Biz, a Minneapolis-based company that operates more than 1,200 franchises under such names as Play It Again Sports, Once Upon a Child and Retool, said it was reviewing the proposal. The company had 1997 revenues of $88.8 million. The shares of Grow Biz gained $3.25, to $13.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: The New Hoffa
description: James P. Hoffa's election last week as president of the teamsters' union is a disheartening development. Mr. Hoffa, son of Jimmy Hoffa, must be judged on the basis of his own record and alliances, not his father's criminal convictions and alleged mob ties. But there is no disguising that the Hoffa victory signals a comeback for old-line teamster leadership that presided over the looting and disgrace of one of America's biggest unions from the 1950's through the 1980's. For that reason alone, Mr. Hoffa's suggestion that it is now time to end nine years of Federal supervision of the teamsters deserves no serious consideration.

title: A Frozen Setting Frames a Chilling Tale

Though he begins the story innocently enough, Hank Mitchell (Bill Paxton) winds up digging himself ever deeper into a hole that's impossible to escape. However straightforwardly these events are described, they become ever more gripping and unsettling as the film proceeds. When you get the shivers watching this wintry tale unfold, it won't be from the cold.

title: Andreychuk Caps Rally in Overtime
description: By the time they found themselves staring up from a three-goal deficit tonight, the Devils were well aware that their defense in recent games had not been what it once was. But they were also believers that their offense is not what it once was either, and that if they could be scored upon in flurries, they also could score that way.

title: Maximum Term in Slaying of Teacher
description: The 20-year-old man convicted of killing his former teacher, Jonathan M. Levin, was sentenced yesterday to the maximum term of 25 years to life in prison by a judge who denounced him as a ''sadistic and manipulative'' criminal.

title: At Yale, Remembering a Slain Undergraduate
description: A bitter wind carried sobs of grief, mournful farewells and the funereal tones of Bach through Old Campus at Yale today, as several hundred friends and relatives of Suzanne Jovin, the senior who was slain last Friday not far from the university, gathered at Battell Chapel for a memorial service.

title: Animal's Genetic Program Decoded, in a Science First
description: Biologists have for the first time deciphered the full genetic programming of an animal, a landmark achievement both in its own right and as a milestone toward understanding the human genome.

title: Ex-General Is Charged With Lying And Adultery
description: The Army charged a retired two-star general today with 17 counts of misconduct stemming from adulterous relationships he had had with the wives of four officers under his command in a case that forced the Army to revise its retirement policy for senior officers facing charges of wrongdoing.

title: White House Voicing Hope For Censure Deal After Talks
description: The White House, mobilizing a campaign to stop impeachment, has been buoyed by quiet discussions with some leading Republicans on Capitol Hill about a deal under which President Clinton would accept a punitive censure resolution to escape impeachment and trial, officials said.

title: Present-Tense History?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shakespeare Saw a Therapist?
description: Shakespeare meets Sherlock, and makes for pure enchantment in the inspired conjecture behind ''Shakespeare in Love.'' This film's exhilarating cleverness springs from its speculation about where the playwright might have found the beginnings of ''Romeo and Juliet,'' but it is not constrained by worries about literary or historical accuracy. (So what if characters talk about Virginia tobacco plantations before there was a Virginia?) Galvanized by the near-total absence of biographical data, it soars freely into the realm of invention, wittily weaving Shakespearean language and emotion into an intoxicatingly glamorous romance. No less marvelous are its imaginings of an Elizabethan theater fraught with the same backbiting and conniving we enjoy today.

title: Danica Phelps
description: 'Funny Money'

title: FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL AND GERALD STEVENS TO MERGE
description: Florafax International Inc., the fourth-largest United States flowers-by-wire provider, said yesterday that it would merge with Gerald Stevens Inc., the closely held floral retailer. Florafax plans to issue about 26 million shares, valued at $250 million, to Gerald Stevens's owners, who would then control three-quarters of the combined company. The company will use the Gerald Stevens name and trade on the Nasdaq market. Gerald Stevens, founded in January by former executives of Viacom Inc.'s Blockbuster Entertainment unit, has grown by buying retailers and has acquired 72 florist shops since October. Florafax's shares fell 56.25 cents, to $9.75.

title: Fallout From the 'Nappy Hair' Furor
description: The controversy over using the book ''Nappy Hair'' at a Brooklyn elementary school has had predictably distressing effects. Now a principal at an intermediate school in the same district has decided against using two excellent books in the sixth grade, apparently for fear of parental protests.

title: When Meaning Emerges Slowly From Missing Parts
description: Gabriel Orozco, a clear-eyed romantic, is one of the more ingenious artists to come along in years, and if you doubt me I suggest you go to his ambitious new show at Marian Goodman and play a little Ping-Pong.

title: N.B.A. and Union Leaders Conduct Private Meeting
description: In a development that may lead to a break in the five-month stalemate between the National Basketball Association's owners and players, the chief negotiators for the league and the union held a private meeting yesterday in Manhattan, officials on both sides confirmed last night.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Electronic Data Systems Names New Chief Executive

title: For Kanell, Starting May Be a Snap Away
description: Kent Graham knows he could be replaced on Sunday, but he is preparing for the Denver Broncos as he did for each of his three previous opponents.

title: Warwick Baker Adds Gitano Line
description: Fruit of the Loom Inc. in Bowling Green, Ky., said yesterday that it had decided to expand its relationship with Warwick Baker O'Neill in New York by naming the agency to handle advertising for Gitano Jeanswear. The account, with billings estimated at $5 million, had been handled by Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass.

title: MCI Expected To Announce Job Cut Plan
description: Ever since Worldcom Inc. took over the MCI Communications Corporation in September, a rueful joke has been making the rounds at MCI's headquarters in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOBILETTI, JOHN B., M.D.
description: NOBILETTI-John B., M.D. On December 8, 1998. 91 yrs. Retired physician Kew Gardens Queens. Member Medical Board of Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, a staff member since 1937. Beloved husband of Dawn, father of John, Michael, Frank and the late Anne Mary. Grandfather of John III. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Forest Hills, Saturday Dec. 12th at 10:15 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Jamaica Hospital, 8900 Van Wyck Expressway, Jamaica, NY 11418-2897. Other sympathies should be sent to Fox Funeral Home, 98-07 Ascan Ave., Forest Hills, NY 11375.

title: KINDER MORGAN TO BUY TWO COAL TERMINALS FROM AEI
description: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, a fuel-pipeline operator, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy coal-transfer terminals in Newport News, Va., and Charleston, S.C., from the closely held AEI Resources Inc. for $35 million in cash. The acquisition would increase Kinder Morgan's terminals to 24 and would add an unspecified amount to earnings. The company, based in Houston, also owns 5,000 miles of pipes in 16 states that transport refined fuels like butane and propane. Kinder Morgan shares rose 25 cents, to $34.25.

title: Observer; The Great Debate
description: Greatest Nation on God's Green Earth (Statesmanship Dept.):

title: Jackson Pollock
description: 'The Picasso Influence'

title: William Noonan, 66, Ex-Burson Executive
description: William F. Noonan, who helped build Burson-Marsteller into a global leader in public relations, died Nov. 2 at his home in Franklin Township, N.J. He was 66 and suffered from leukemia.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZIFF, CHARLIE
description: ZIFF - Charlie. 12/11/49 - 7/4/92. You're always in my heart. Love, Stephe

title: Mr. Clinton's Mideast Journey
description: President Clinton's trip to the Middle East this weekend, originally intended to nudge along the Wye peace agreement, now looks certain to encounter turbulence. The Wye agreement is bedeviled by delays, mutual recriminations and new violence. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is fighting for his Government's survival.

title: South Korea's Filmmakers Roll Into Action to Protect Foreign-Movie Quota
description: SEOUL  Six years ago Ahn Sung Ki played two of his greatest film roles  one as a North Korean soldier left behind in the South during the Korean War, the other as a South Korean intellectual who volunteered to go to Vietnam as a soldier in the South Korean Army.

title: ILLINOVA SAYS IT IS IN TALKS TO SELL NUCLEAR POWER PLANT
description: The Illinova Corporation said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its Clinton nuclear power plant in central Illinois as part of its plan to concentrate on delivering electricity. The company, based in Decatur, Ill., said that it was talking with the Peco Energy Company and the Entergy Corporation and that three other undisclosed companies were also interested in the reactor, which the company values at $1.6 billion. Clinton has been shut since 1996. Illinova would like to sell Clinton next year, when the Illinois power market begins opening to competition, because it does not think it can operate it profitably.

title: True North goes to court for arbitration on the value of its stake in Publicis Communications.
description: THE Bickersons of Madison Avenue -- Publicis S. A. in Paris and True North Communications in Chicago -- are back in court again as True North has submitted a dispute over the valuation of its stake in Publicis to arbitration.

title: Dominion Resources Warns of Lower Profits
description: Dominion Resources Inc., owner of Virginia's largest electric utility, said today that its fourth-quarter and 1998 earnings would be lower than expected because mild weather had decreased sales.

title: Kimberly-Clark Revises Structure
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, the world's biggest maker of tissue products, said today that it would reorganize along product lines, rather than geographic regions, to help sales and speed the introduction of products worldwide.

title: Dad's a Snowman. (Is Mom Santa?)
description: Warning: Michael Keaton plays a struggling rock musician in ''Jack Frost'' and can be found stomping and singing the blues (''Frosty the Snowman was as bad as he could be. . . .'') even before the credits are over. As the film's eponymous hero, he's one of those dedicated rock-and-rollers who are also great husbands and devoted dads. But the demands of his work sometimes keep him away from his son, Charlie (Joseph Cross). The film is about what happens after Jack dies in a Christmas Eve automobile accident and returns to his family as a large, wisecracking marshmallow man parked on the front lawn.

title: One Man's View From the Front of the Train
description: STAN FISCHLER learned almost everything he knows about subways by the time he was 12, standing on the jump seat of the Brighton BMT with his friend Howie, flying through Flatbush, their heads stuck out the front window, the wind streaming over their faces and the wheels click-clacking to the rhythm of Gene Krupa's drumming in ''China Boy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SROUR, TOUFIC
description: SROUR-Toufic. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Toufic Srour, beloved father of our devoted Members and Parents in the Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School, Marco & Melanie Srour. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, JOHN J.
description: WALSH-John J. On December 9, 1998, of Garden City, N.Y., loving brother of George and the late Lillian Seaman and the late Catherine Seaman. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews and beloved grandnieces and grandnephews. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th St., Garden City, Friday 25PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial at St. Josephs R.C. Church, Garden City, Saturday 9:45AM. Interment, Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, N.Y.

title: Seeing Spacey Will Be Pricey
description: The $100 ticket is back.

title: Mayors Accuse State Of Shortchanging Cities
description: New York State is shortchanging its cities, towns and villages $2.3 billion a year by cutting the amount of local aid specified in state law, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and two upstate Mayors said yesterday.

title: Shock of the Surreal In a Digital World
description: The ineffable slow motion with which events unfold in ''Monsters of Grace,'' the ''digital opera in three dimensions'' that opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night, would be enough to explain why the piece has taken eight months to get here since its opening in Los Angeles: 10 miles a day is about the speed of the thing. It seems that the project, the latest collaboration between Robert Wilson and Philip Glass, creators of ''Einstein on the Beach,'' is also being realized at this snail's pace. In Los Angeles, only 7 of the 13 images in Mr. Wilson's scenario could be shown, as intended, by means of computer-animated film (the rest were staged). Now all 13 are up and running, though some of them still look decidedly sketchy.

title: The Lights Of Freedom
description: A Hanukkah menorah consisting of miniature Statues of Liberty might strike some as irreverent kitsch. But to the Museum of Jewish Heritage, the entwined symbolism couldn't be more appropriate.

title: ATTRACTIONS
description: Museums and Sites

title: Literary Allusions to Feather the Nest
description: Not since Alfred Hitchcock put poor Tippi Hedren through all that nasty pecking have so many unwelcome birds crowded into a single landscape. In '' 'Hope' Is the Thing With Feathers,'' the new drama by Frank Pugliese and the latest offering from the Drama Dept., there are avian visitors galore. True, they appear mostly as poetic conceits rather than physical creatures, but they are dominating, noisy things all the same, chattering up a symbolic storm.

title: 4 Professionals Perform Pro Bono for Pro Musicis
description: The Pro Musicis Foundation, which was founded in France in 1965, holds annual auditions for young musicians and presents its winners in recitals in several cities around the world. It also fosters a current of noncareerist altruism in its musicians: in addition to the public concerts, Pro Musicis arranges for its players to perform in prisons, hospitals and homes for the elderly.

title: In Upset, Chicago Board of Trade Elects New Chairman
description: In a move that could reassert the power of floor traders fearful their positions could be eroded by the 24-hour electronic age, members of the Chicago Board of Trade voted Wednesday to unseat their chairman.

title: The V Files: The Invisible, Alien and Dead
description: DENNIS C. (for Can't Get Me Out of Office) VACCO has been sprucing up his image. Until the last few weeks, Mr. Vacco was destined to be best known as the New York Attorney General who lost Ellis Island to New Jersey. Now he may go down only as the politician who did not get it when he heard the fat lady sing. In a year or two, who will remember?

title: A Fashion Statement Draped in Cubism
description: Some exhibitions have hard acts to follow. ''Cubism and Fashion,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute, is saddled with at least two. One is last year's big winter show at the institute, an over-the-top survey of Gianni Versace. This exercise in elegant kitsch was exhilarating fun, but it had roughly the same relationship to serious design that the motorcycles in the Guggenheim's dazzling summer show had to real art.

title: U.N. Gives Rights Awards to People Working at the Grass Roots
description: Over the last quarter-century, the United Nations has given its highest award for human rights work to the greatest names and institutions that shaped the movement. Eleanor Roosevelt, who steered the United Nations into human rights, won one of the first awards, posthumously, in 1968.

title: Livingston Is Silent On Vote on Censure
description: Despite increasing pressure on Representative Robert L. Livingston, the incoming Speaker of the House, to indicate whether he would allow a censure vote against President Clinton on the House floor, he maintained his public distance on the topic today.

title: Proceeds Won't Go To Players
description: Besieged by negative publicity, the organizers of an exhibition game that would help to benefit financially strapped National Basketball Association players have decided instead to give all proceeds of the game to charitable organizations.

title: A Pollock Priced At $6.5 Million
description: Looking at the Jackson Pollock canvases at the painter's retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in New York has a special resonance for the actor Ed Harris. Mr. Harris, who has spent hours at the show and read numerous books on Pollock's life and career, has been consumed for years with the artist. Now, he is going to do something about it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUENHUT, AD
description: GRUENHUT-Ad. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Men's Club mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member Jerry Gruenhut and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Haskel Lookstein, Rabbi Joshua Lookstein, Assistant Rabbi Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Volvo Excels in Whiplash Test
description: A NEW seatback and head restraint design by Volvo significantly reduces the sudden neck motions that often cause whiplash injuries, according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

title: Both Parties Work to Gather Retiring, Ailing and Far-Afield Members for Decision
description: With President Clinton's fate in the House hanging on a razor-thin margin of perhaps one or two votes, Republican and Democratic leaders are scrambling to insure that a handful of ailing, retiring or traveling lawmakers are present for next week's historic vote on impeachment.

title: Ericsson to Eliminate 10,000 More Jobs
description: Ericsson A.B., the Swedish company that has been aggressively reorganizing its business to resist growing competition in its key cellular phone business, said today that its fourth-quarter profit would be 15 percent to 20 percent lower than expected and that it would cut 10,000 more jobs because of flagging demand for its phones and public switching systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, LEO QUINCY
description: GOLDBERG-Leo Quincy. Died on December 8, in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old. He was predeceased in 1993 by his wife of 45 years, Esther. He is survived by his son Joseph Goldberg, daughter-in-law Rona and their children Marissa, Jaclyn and Michael and his daughter Mindy Goldberg-Tamarkin, son-in-law Cary Tamarkin and their son Eli. Quincy leaves behind the legacy of a life committed to the pursuit of social justice. He was an early leader in the trade union movement followed by a career in social work, creating community mental health clinics through Maimonides Hospital. He lived a passionate life and will be deeply missed.

title: Spots of The Times; Here's How A Captain Operates
description: SOMETIMES captains lead by example, even if it costs them two minutes in the penalty box. Last week, Trevor Linden of the Islanders creamed Ulf Samuelsson of the Rangers because he felt Ulf was doing ugly things, if you can imagine that.

title: Censure Now, Not Later
description: To the Editor:

title: Owners to Start Meetings As Clemens Saga Winds On
description: The Toronto Blue Jays' efforts to trade Roger Clemens will be the headline event at the baseball winter meetings, which begin today in Nashville.

title: Spending Ourselves Into Oblivion
description: The stock market rebound hasn't made it any easier for me to sleep at night. What concerns me is not the possibility that stock prices are vastly inflated (overall, I don't think they are), but that the wealth created by the market boom has become vital to the day-to-day workings of the American economy.

title: Op-Art
Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOTKIN, SARAH A.
description: SLOTKIN-Sarah A. Artist and teacher. Beloved and loving wife of Aaron and mother of Deborah Orin and Mark. Died December 9 at age 86. She loved life and she painted with joy. We loved her and we will miss her. Services Sunday, December 13, at 12 noon, Gramercy Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue, Manhattan.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 14.

title: Study on a Late Term Abortion Finds Procedure Is Little Used
description: At a time when the political fight over abortion centers on a late-term method that anti-abortion groups call partial-birth abortion, a new study by a nonprofit research group has estimatedin a comprehensive survey how often the method is used.

title: He's Degraded, Not She
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Westin Plans to Run Times Square Hotel
description: Tishman Realty and Construction announced yesterday that Westin Hotels and Resorts would operate the planned $300 million, 860-room hotel to be built on Eighth Avenue between 42d and 43d Streets.

title: Times Square Preachers Sue Over Denial of Sound Permits
description: A group of street preachers who have been a loud and boisterous presence in Times Square for years sued New York City yesterday, accusing the Giuliani administration of trying to stifle its message.

title: Ogres and Victims Dance in Savage Webs of Tyranny
description: The rise of Fascism in the early 1930's inspired nightmare visions in the work of many European artists. Not the least of them was Joan Miro (1893-1983), who saw his native Spain savaged by the dictator Francisco Franco. In 1938, working in Paris, Miro produced a powerful series of eight small-scale etchings known as the ''Black and Red Series,'' which responded -- as had Picasso's painting ''Guernica'' a year earlier -- to the agonies of the Civil War that put Franco in power.

title: When Libraries Aren't Free to All
description: Go to the public library and borrow a book: most Americans give it little thought.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Wednesday about ''Woody Guthrie's American Song,'' a revue presented by the Melting Pot Theater, misspelled the given name of a musician. He is Joshua Martin, not Joshus.

title: Wallwork Curry Adds a Partner
description: Wallwork Curry in Boston said yesterday that it had changed its name to Wallwork Curry Sandler to reflect the appointment of Rick Sandler as partner and president. Mr. Sandler 50, joins the agency from Hawley Sandler in Boston, where he had been co-founder and partner; that agency's other partner, Shervin Hawley, will head the shop.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend.* denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Watergate Veteran Leads Fractious Group
description: As he presides over the Judiciary Committee's Democrats, speaking in a deliberative cadence, Representative John Conyers Jr., the ranking minority member, projects a quiet tone and almost uninterested demeanor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBY, DONALD L.
description: JACOBY-Donald L. Born June 5, 1925; lifelong Brooklyn resident and longtime Judge in the Criminal Court, Brooklyn; died December 10, 1998 of cancer. Graduate of University of Wisconsin and Harvard Law School. Survived by his sister, Judith Stone; three nephews, Jonathan, Harlan, and Michael Stone; and five great-nieces and great-nephews, all of Connecticut. Memorial Service at Lawrence Funeral Home, Darien, CT, Sunday, December 12, 3-4PM. Contributions may be made in his name to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461

title: In Winter, a Chilling Tale
description: A downed plane carrying $4.4 million in cash and three men who find it provide an irresistible hook for ''A Simple Plan,'' based on Scott B. Smith's best seller. Exactly how this chance event escalates with deadly intensity is at the heart of this quietly devastating thriller from Sam Raimi, the cult horror director making a flawless segue into mainstream storytelling. Bill Paxton, below right, and Billy Bob Thornton expertly play brothers caught up in the consequences of their sudden windfall, piling on layers of complicity and betrayal until the film rises to a near-biblical level of punishment for its characters' transgressions. When you get the shivers watching this wintry tale unfold, it won't be from the cold.

title: For the First Time, Astronauts Enter International Space Station
description: The first people entered the international space station today, beginning an era that in a few years should lead to permanent human occupation of the mammoth research outpost 250 miles above the Earth.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Organs of Cows? Young Art Sells

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUSINS, VIVIAN
description: COUSINS-Vivian. On December 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Loving mother of Debbie, Amy and Abby. Doting grandmother of Joanna, Gabrielle and Danielle. Rest in peace. Services will be held today 8:30am at the ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Censure Now, Not Later; It's Our Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: SWISHER'S PLAN TO GO PRIVATE SENDS ITS SHARES SOARING
description: The shares of Swisher International Group, the world's largest cigar company by units sold, jumped 30 percent yesterday, after the company said it would buy back all of its shares for $9.50 each and go private. Swisher, which makes Swisher Sweets and King Edward brand cigars, rose $2.0625 a share, to $8.875. The company, based in Darien, Conn., said late on Wednesday that a subsidiary, the SIGI Acquisition Corporation, would buy the 5.8 million Swisher shares that it does not already own, spending about $55.1 million. Cigar companies have struggled this year as the cigar fad has faded.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Commodities' Price Slide Victimizes Economies of Several Nations
description: The recent drop in the price of oil and natural gas and the continuing decline of other commodity prices at year's end is putting renewed pressure on many of the emerging-market countries at the center of the global financial crisis.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Life was so much simpler before they found that dress, wasn't it?''

title: The Immortality of Art
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Heat-Seeking Hearts Hurtle Through an Icy World
description: An honest mistake is what you could call ''Lettres d'Amour,'' a new work for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: Mixed Reviews, With Doctors Giving Thumbs Down
description: Aetna and health care providers have different views about how its acquisition of Prudential Health Care will affect patients and doctors.

title: Election Panel Refuses to Order Repayments by Clinton and Dole
description: In a unanimous vote, the Federal Election Commission rebuffed its own professional staff today and refused to order multimillion-dollar repayments from the 1996 Presidential campaigns of President Clinton and Bob Dole, the Republican nominee.

title: On My Mind; On Cleansing America
description: We know three things for certain, and standing in the muck of Bill Clinton's character amidst the remains of his Presidency, it helps cleanse us to think about them.

title: Milk Processor Campaign Extended
description: The nation's milk companies said yesterday that they had voted to extend for five years the extensive and expensive Milk Processor Education Program, the effort to encourage greater milk consumption through the popular ''milk mustache'' campaign.

title: After a Sterile Upbringing, Vegetable Photography
description: ''I am your guardian buzzard,'' declares the actor in black plumage.

title: Minor Trade and Small Feud Occupy Mets While Waiting on Henderson
description: The Mets were waiting to hear from Rickey Henderson's representatives last night about their offer of a one-year deal with an option for a second year. While he waited, General Manager Steve Phillips completed a minor trade for a 21-year-old prospect. And Manager Bobby Valentine did not wait at all when the subject of one of his former players, Todd Hundley, was broached.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARK, FRANCES L.
description: STARK-Frances L. Funeral Service December 11, 10:30AM, at Gutterman-Musicant Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: Court Bars Use of Computers For Random Checks on Drivers
description: The police in New Jersey are not allowed to use computers in their squad cars to conduct random checks on a driver's personal information, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: Asia Satellite Gets New Owners
description: Societe Europeenne des Satellites, the No. 3 commercial satellite operator, and Citic, China's biggest investment company, have bought control of Asia Satellite Telecommunications Holdings Ltd., forming a broadcast network that stretches from Western Europe to Southeast Asia. Societe Europeenne, whose Astra network beams TV pictures into almost half of Europe's homes, and the state-owned China International Trust and Investment Corporation paid $372 million for a 68 percent stake from Cable and Wireless P.L.C. and Hutchison Whampoa Ltd.

title: Two Hospitals Fined For Excessive Hours
description: The State Department of Health has fined Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center in the Bronx and University Hospital in Syracuse $16,000 each for allowing medical residents to work hours that exceed state limits.

title: Jets Forgo High-Tech Offense For Old-Fashioned Fade Pass
description: In this season of constant attack, the Jets have left defenses strewn about the field, often confused. And yet, in the midst of this high-tech offense producing 26.7 points a game, they have revived an old-fashioned play: the fade pass. It is becoming a weapon in the form of a pass into the end zone to Keyshawn Johnson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYFF, LOUISE M.
description: RYFF-Louise M. December 2, 1998. Age 91. Beloved wife of the late Hawley B. Humphrey. Cherished aunt, godmother, cousin, friend and inspiration to many. A memorial services will be held Saturday, December 12th, 4PM at the West End Presbyterian Church, 165 W 105 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the West End Presbyterian Church Memorial Fund or to a charity of your choice.

title: 2 Ulster Leaders Accept Nobels And Trade Remarks at Ceremony
description: The Protestant leader of Northern Ireland, David Trimble, accepted his share of the 1998 Nobel Peace Prize today and warned militant Roman Catholics against delays in turning over their arms caches.

title: Bank of England Cuts Key Rate by Half-Point
description: Citing persistent ''deterioration across the economy,'' the Bank of England lowered its benchmark interest rate today by half a percentage point, the third cut in as many months and the second consecutive time it did so by a half-point.

title: Effort Grows To Discredit Lewinsky
description: Saying that some of the proposed impeachment charges hinged on conflicting ''he said, she said'' versions of what went on between President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky, Democrats stepped up their efforts to undermine Ms. Lewinsky's credibility today, citing inconsistencies in her accounts of the affair and her taped statement to Linda Tripp that she had lied her entire life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, DR. BURTON
description: WHITE-Dr. Burton. We mourn the passing of the father of our esteemed member, Liane Wolff and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: Prospero On a Bayou Before The Storm
description: For its next reality special, maybe NBC could produce a live, on-air book-burning. That would be right in line with what they've done to the classics this season. For a blip of time, after the success of several bookish, special-effects-laden films (''Gulliver's Travels,'' ''The Odyssey'' and ''Merlin''), the network turned to literature for inspiration. That may sound high-minded, but the results might have played better as a satire called ''Books Go Hollywood.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRUDO, RICARDO, M.D.
description: CRUDO-Ricardo, M.D. The Medical Staff of North Shore University Hospital at Plainview mourns the loss of its respected colleague and friend Ricardo Crudo, MD. The community has lost an outstanding physician and we have lost a friend. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his family. Ric will be missed by all. Deborah Tascone, RN, MS Vice President/Administration Alan Mensch, MD Medical Director Morris Rabinowicz, MD Chairman/Medical Board Lawrence Katz, MD President/Medical Staff North Shore University Hospital at Plainview

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Design; A Suit Makes Them Older and Wiser
description: FORGET the Fountain of Youth. The Ford Motor Company says it has found value in the opposite -- a suit of clothes that makes its wearer feel old, with stiff joints, dim vision and weak muscles.

title: Excerpts From Lawmakers' Statements
description: Following are excerpts from the statements of members of the House Judiciary Committee tonight as they considered impeaching President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL AT 12-YEAR LOW. Crude prices fell 3.7 percent to the lowest levels since March 1986 on a growing oversupply and less demand, linked to unusually warm weather. The January contract fell 44 cents, to $10.72 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTNER, MARIAN
description: KUTNER-Marian. Wife of the late Simon Kutner. Life long resident of New York City. Died on December 3, 1998. She just celebrated her 92nd birthday. A loving wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She was creative and enjoyed doing both oil painting and enameling. Her enthusiasm for swimming was an inspiration to her children and grandchildren. The shares of the company, which is based in Akron, Ohio, fell $12.25, to $15, with 5.6 million shares changing hands. Telxon restated second-quarter results after a review with its auditors. It now plans to recognize $14 million of sales in the third quarter that it had counted toward second-quarter revenue. It had a loss of 5 cents a share for the quarter ended Sept. 30, instead of the profit of 22 cents it reported in October. The company also expects an unspecified third-quarter loss.

Big Bear also said that the Blue Range board had received no acceptable alternative bids and that Blue Range managers and directors would be tendering their shares. Under the offer, Big Bear will swap 11 Big Bear shares for every Blue Range share tendered to its offer, an exchange that valued Blue Range at about $194 million (Canadian) on the day of the offer. Big Bear will also assume $105 million in debt. Blue Range resisted the offer and said it expected a higher bid, but no other suitor emerged.

He served with distinction as a Rabbi in Philadelphia, Warren, Ohio, and Kew Gardens, N.Y., as a member of the Rabbinical Assembly and its Law Committee, and as a leader of the Beth Din of Queens, N.Y. In recent years, he was active in the founding of the Union of Traditional Judaism. Toward the end of his life, he celebrated the completion of his ninth cycle of Daf Yomi.
