title: Limits Seen on Ability to Repair Schools
description: Even if the New York City Board of Education can raise the $11 billion that it has requested to repair and expand its schools, hundreds will at best be upgraded to ''fair'' condition over the next five years, school officials said yesterday.

title: Speaker Avoids Censure Topic
description: As the House Judiciary Committee voted tonight to impeach President Clinton, Representative Robert L. Livingston, the incoming Speaker of the House, continued to avoid specifics on the topic.

title: Taking Gershwin Seriously In a Laid-Back Sort of Way
description: ''My point of view about George Gershwin is very strict and strange,'' Kurt Masur, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, said recently at a news conference to announce plans for the orchestra's 1999-2000 season. ''I treat Gershwin as a serious composer,'' he explained, adding, ''I don't want to use him as a ticket-seller.''

title: Wolters Kluwer to Split Stock 4 for 1 Next Year
description: Wolters Kluwer N.V., Europe's biggest tax and legal publisher by revenue, said yesterday that it would split its stock 4 for 1 next year, restating share value in euros to conform with Europe's new single currency. Shareholders will receive four shares with a nominal value of 0.12 euro for each existing share with a nominal value of 1 guilder. The split will occur a few weeks after a shareholders meeting on April 15. Wolters Kluwer said its American depository receipts would also be split 4 for 1 at that time.

title: Katmandu Journal; When Life as a Goddess Ends, Life as a Girl Begins
description: The little girl became Nepal's official living goddess the day before she turned 4, a grandly ceremonial event that made her parents enormously proud, for a divine spirit was about to enter their daughter and she would be worshiped by the nation, carried around on a gilded chariot and bowed down to, even by the King.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, HENRY S.
description: WERNER-Henry S. The Board of Directors and members of the Ocean Beach Club mark with deep saddness the death of long time member and dear friend, Hank Werner. He was regarded by all to be the finest of gentlemen and will be greatly missed. Sandy Paskin, President Laurie Lowenstein, Secretary

title: Citizen Activists on Human Rights
description: Fifty years ago this week, the United Nations adopted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the Genocide Convention. The world of 1948, impressed by the Nuremberg Tribunals, seemed ready to enforce international laws to prevent new acts of genocide and crimes against humanity. But nothing happened -- until 1993, when the international tribunal for Bosnia became the first of several new attempts to enforce these laws. One important reason for the change is the participation of citizen-activists, who have initiated some of the cases and played a major role in shaping the new courts.

title: A South Carolina Conservative Bucks His Party
description: Representative Lindsey O. Graham has always had a renegade streak in him, which he displayed today when he became the lone Republican to vote against the second article of impeachment.

title: For One Day, Comity Visits A Committee
description: As the impeachment votes neared, oddly bipartisan tinges of sadness glimmered at times within the House Judiciary Committee. A hurriedly jotted note of consolation -- ''Don't worry, this is a strong country'' -- was quietly dispatched in mid-debate by a sympathetic Republican to an agonizing Democrat.

title: Salt Lake Officials Face Query Into Fund
description: The disclosure of a scholarship fund in Salt Lake City is generating considerable activity on the shores of Lake Geneva.

title: Hasek Again Shuts Out the Rangers, and They Get Testy
description: Goalie Dominik Hasek of the Sabres gets lots of shutouts. Some are spectacular, the kind that have prompted voters to award him the Vezina and Hart trophies for the last two seasons as the best goalie and the most valuable player in the National Hockey League.

title: Love, Fond Memories and a Driving Jazz Score
description: Alvin Ailey poured pent-up feelings about the black Southern church services and religious lessons of his childhood into ''Revelations,'' a work about black American culture and history that became, in effect, a statement of belief in the universality of the human experience. Judith Jamison's ''Hymn,'' created four years after Ailey's death and her appointment as artistic director of the Ailey troupe, expresses what may be her equivalent to ''Revelations.''

title: Accountant Pleads Guilty To Role in Export Scheme
description: A New Jersey accountant admitted yesterday that he helped set up phony companies in the United States under a scheme intended to cheat the government of Argentina out of millions of dollars in export subsidies, officials said.

title: Too Serious to Sing About?; Sometimes Ads Are as Crucial as Reviews
description: ''Come look at the freaks!'' exhorted the opening song in ''Side Show,'' the 1997 musical by Henry Krieger and Bill Russell about a pair of Siamese twins. It was a call that most Broadway audiences chose not to heed. Though it drew a clutch of ecstatic notices and a devoted cult following, ''Side Show'' had a short and unhealthy life of less than three months. The inevitable question arose: Had the production's creators crossed into dark territory best left unexplored by the ''light'' musical?

title: Impeach or Don't, but Let's Move On Now; There Is No Bar
description: To the Editor:

title: Owner of Queens Restaurant Is Slain While Delivering Food
description: It was the last run Li-Rong Lin had planned to make for the night, delivering a $10 dinner to a customer not far from his Chinese restaurant in Hollis, Queens.

title: Vacco's Fight to Keep Job Draws Increasing Fire From Fellow Republicans
description: Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco is coming under increasing criticism from fellow Republicans as he continues his fight over last month's election. Some of them are openly suggesting that it is time for him to concede -- though he still has the Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, in his corner -- and to acknowledge his Democratic rival, Eliot L. Spitzer, as the next attorney general.

title: Political Costs Widen in Mexico Bank Bailout
description: Although at heart a bookish economist, Guillermo Ortiz rose to become one of the most powerful people in Mexico and as Finance Minister won acclaim for steering the country through the fiscal equivalent of a Category 5 hurricane.

title: Brown's Comeback Complete With Giants
description: At this time two years ago, Gary Brown was doing nothing. He had quit pro football, and he had no job, no ambition and no recriminations. Fortunately for him and the Giants, he also was bored.

title: PANEL, ON PARTY LINES, VOTES IMPEACHMENT; CLINTON VOICES REMORSE, INVITES CENSURE
description: After a passionate debate that was by turns solemn with history, fiercely partisan and sometimes sorrowful, the House Judiciary Committee voted along party lines today to impeach President Clinton and remove him from office for perjury and obstruction of justice.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the documentary-film maker Henry Hampton on Nov. 24 misidentified the leader of the ''Bloody Sunday'' civil rights march in Selma, Ala., in 1965, the event that inspired Mr. Hampton's Emmy-winning survey of the civil rights movement, ''Eyes on the Prize.'' The march was led by John Lewis of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee; the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. led a second march two days later.

title: Puerto Rico Rallies to Vote On Shift in Political Status
description: On a balmy evening this week, the caravan of dozens of cars snaking around the working-class neighborhoods of Carolina, a city east of here, brought its deafening honking, sirens, music and shouts of ''Equality for Puerto Rico!'' right to Jose Manuel Molina's doorstep. Mr. Molina, 65, and his wife, Blanca, 61, rushed out of the house and began hollering, in delight.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Top Japan Brokerage Firm Reduces U.S. Business

title: A Bit of Legend, a Dollop of Judaism
description: On West 42d Street, imaginary Greek gods and goddesses with names like Candora, Pectorus and Hernia are dancing and singing. In the East Village, conflicted young Jewish men named Steve and Nick are dancing, singing and praying that they can resolve their relationships with two non-Jewish women. Visits to the two shows in which these characters appear -- ''Delphi or Bust'' and ''Jews and Jesus'' -- give very different impressions of the current state of the original Off Broadway musical.

title: Excerpts From House Judiciary Committee Debate on Article II
description: Following are excerpts from the House Judiciary Committee's debate today on Article II of its impeachment resolution against President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: Retail Sales Surprisingly Strong And Producer Prices Fall Again
description: Despite weak demand for cold-weather merchandise, retail sales were stronger than expected in November, a sign that consumers felt comfortable about the economy as the holiday season began.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMHI, RALPH
description: KAMHI-Ralph. Beloved father of Marc, Sherry and Elaine. Beloved grandfather of Amy, Carolyn, Michele, Peter, Lauren, Joanna and Reid. Dear brother of Betty, Sarah, Stella, Joe, Julie, Renee and Leona. He never met a man he didn't like. Funeral I.J. Morris, Dix Hills, NY, Sunday, 1:00 PM.

title: Only Chile Can Judge Me, Pinochet Tells British Court
description: Making his first appearance in public since his arrest two months ago, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator, sternly told a London court today that he did not acknowledge the right of any court outside his own country to consider charges against him.

title: Impeach or Don't, but Let's Move On Now; Coat of Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect in Embassy Bombings Moves Closer to Extradition
description: A German official said yesterday that American officials had indicated that they would not seek the death penalty for a suspected aide to Osama bin Laden, which could clear a major hurdle to win the man's extradition from Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MURRAY A.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Murray A. On December 9, 1998 at home after a long illness. Beloved husband of Gladys of 57 years. Loving father of Sandy and Brianne, Robert and Barbara, Richard and Marianne. Adored grandfather of Aaron, Joshua, Jennie, Toby, Michael and Brian. Brother of Harold Goldstein and Edith Schwartz. Illness could not dim his smile or stop his teasing way. He handled his illness with great dignity. He loved us and we loved him. We know he will be missed by all whose lives he touched. Funeral Friday December 11 at 10am at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Boulevard, New Rochlle, NY. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to a charity of your choice.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Baylor Knocks Off Santa Barbara
description: BAYLOR 92 U.C. SANTA BARBARA 72

title: Gatti Steals Limelight and Aims for Show
description: It is not often that a world championship fight does not get top billing on a card, but convention is tossed out when Arturo Gatti fights.

title: Momentous, Yet Banal
description: By word and deed, in answering pollsters' questions and in casting mid-term ballots last month, a majority of the voters of America have made it pluperfectly clear that they do not wish to see President Clinton removed from office through the impeachment process.

title: Virginian Acts as Bridge To Moderate Republicans
description: Representative Rick Boucher, a southern Virginia Democrat on the Judiciary Committee with a deportment as temperate as his politics, seems a poor fit on a committee where members with an overdeveloped sense of outrage have few inhibitions about expressing such feelings.

title: Man Gets Nine Months In Cross-Burning Case
description: The last of four defendants in an Easter morning cross burning at the home of a racially mixed couple was sentenced to nine months in jail yesterday, the Cumberland County Prosecutor's office said.

title: REVLON SELLS ITS STAKE IN COSMETIC CENTER TO YORK
description: Revlon Inc., the biggest maker of mass-market cosmetics in the United States, said yesterday that it had sold its 85 percent stake in the retailer Cosmetic Center Inc. to a partnership controlled by York Management Services Inc. in return for a limited interest in the new company, Prestige Holdings I.L.P. Revlon, which is based in New York and controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, will take a fourth-quarter charge of about $33 million related to the sale. Cosmetic Center, based in Colombia, Md., had 60 mall-based stores and 193 outlet stores as of Sept. 26.

title: Networks Take a Back Seat to Cable
description: Faced with a daylong debate on articles of impeachment against the President of the United States, only the third such debate in the nation's history, the three big broadcast networks responded yesterday with a collective shrug, and the message: Wake us when they're voting.

title: Fans Soar as Jets Zoom Upward; Long Island Faithful Have Hearts Set on the N.F.L. Playoffs
description: ''So these two guys are sitting at a bar,'' said an old gambler who gave his name only as Kenny to his friend Bobby Hingard, a Jets fan who was sitting at that very same bar in the Double H Pub, over by the Mineola train station.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about celebrations of a Shiite Muslim holiday in Tabriz, Iran, referred incorrectly to 12 descendants of the Prophet Mohammed. They are called Imams, or religious leaders, not prophets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTFRIED, SOL.
description: GOTTFRIED - Sol. Graveside funeral services for Sunday, December 13th at Beth El Cemetery in Paramus, NJ at 1:00 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPS, DR. ERIC C.
description: RAPS-Dr. Eric C. Adored son of Nathan and Cecile, beloved brother of Mitchell (and Anne), and cherished husband of Maureen and father of Daniel. Shiva at the home of Anne and Mitchell Saturday night through Tuesday. Please omit flowers. Contributions in Eric's memory may be made to Hatzalah, 1340 East 9th Street, Brooklyn, NY 11230

title: Impeach or Don't, but Let's Move On Now; Threat to the Nation?
description: To the Editor:

title: Journal; The Oprah Gap
description: Like a yearlong standoff between nagging parents and an adolescent who won't do his homework, the disconnect between the media gasbags and the public goes on and on. This week, despite the insistent talking-head lectures about the ''historic'' import of it all, the audience for impeachment hearings on CNN dwindled to one-third the size of that for the Clinton grand-jury testimony. It may take a graphic video of the President and Monica Lewinsky not having sex while not being alone in the White House to get the nation's viewers to tune in now.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The signficance of the oath cannot or must not be cheapened if our proud boast that we are a government of laws and not of men is to mean anything.''

title: Panel's Vote Arrives In Unsettling Flurry
description: Bill Clinton and Henry Hyde, usually so astute about managing the media, bungled what should have been their moments of televised drama yesterday. On a half-hour's notice, the President arrived in the Rose Garden and gave a speech that echoed one of his least successful moments during his impeachment crisis, the non-apology apology he delivered after his grand jury testimony on Aug. 17.

title: Impeach or Don't, but Let's Move On Now; Of Mud and Molasses
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULVANERTY, MARY (MOLLIE) NEE BREEN
description: MULVANERTY-Mary (Mollie) nee Breen, on December 7, 1998, in San Rafael, California. Born June 20, 1909 at Lyreboy, raised at Gortnagreenare, Kilgobnet, County Kerry, Ireland. Loving spouse of the late Thomas. Devoted mother of Father Thomas, John and Ann Baker, beloved grandmother of Catherine and Mary Mulvanerty, and of Sarah and Breen Baker, dear sister of Deborah O'Shea, Catherine Shea, Nora Clifford, Michael Breen, Anne Hannon and of the deceased John Breen, James Breen, Jeremiah Breen, Breda Flynn, Joan McHugh and Nuala Stack. Esteemed aunt of many nieces & nephews. Mass Monday, 10:45AM, at St. Raymond's Church, Bronx, New York. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Sports of The Times; Where Charity Begins
description: IN the most significant lockout news of the week, pro basketball players announced a charity game in Atlantic City. They were then criticized for waffling on the beneficiaries. At first, it was said that the proceeds would go to charity, with some going to players who have been financially pinched by the lockout.

title: Contrition Without Confession
description: It is hard to fathom what gain Bill Clinton thought he could achieve yesterday in restating his remorse over the Monica Lewinsky case while still dodging the core issue of his deceitful testimony under oath. The disconnection between Mr. Clinton's appearance at the White House and the legal and constitutional charges bearing down on him in Congress could not have been clearer. Moments after he once again failed to acknowledge that he had lied under oath, House Judiciary Committee Republicans approved the first of four articles of impeachment on the panel agenda. The article revolves around alleged perjury.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HOGS DOWN 6.7 PERCENT. Prices fell on speculation that a fattened herd of near-record size would prolong a glut for months. The February contract fell 2 cents, to 28.075 cents a pound. Hog futures are down 63 percent this year.

title: Clinton's Surreal Week: Light a Tree, Shake a Hand, Try to Keep the Job
description: This is what it's like to be Bill Clinton these days:

title: Union Inquiry Looks at Charity's Tie to Reputed Mobster
description: Everyone knows what not to do with a gift horse. But who knows how to handle charity from a hood with a heart of gold, a reputed mob figure with a reported penchant for violence who wants to donate $1 million he has raised for medical research?

title: DiMaggio Revives From Coma, But Hopes Are Still Tenuous
description: After lapsing into a coma overnight, Joe DiMaggio revived this afternoon, moving his head and squeezing his doctor's hand. But the doctor said DiMaggio's condition remained very serious and could change at any time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEMPERT, PAULA VIAL
description: LEMPERT-Paula Vial. On December 10, 1998, after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Lucien Vial, the late Joseph Bernham and the late Henry Lempert. She escaped the Holocaust and came to the United States. Through much personal endeavor she was very successful in business and real estate. She will be missed by the many friends she acquired over the years, and by devoted employees. Funeral services 3PM Monday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: PETERSEN TO ACQUIRE MAGAZINES FROM CURTCO FREEDOM
description: The Petersen Companies agreed yesterday to acquire six magazines from Curtco Freedom Group for $60 million. The magazines are Home Theater, Home Theater Buyer's Guide, Home Theater Interiors, Digital Home Entertainment, Portable Computing and Mobile Computing and Communications. The acquisition also includes the Home Theater Magazine Entertainment Expo and Sales and various World Wide Web sites related to the publications. Petersen publishes special-interest magazines.

title: Tokyo Appears Close to Taking Over a Big Bank
description: The Government appears to be on the verge of nationalizing a second large Japanese bank, Nippon Credit Bank, in a move that may foreshadow a wider cleanup of the banking system and a tougher stance by financial authorities.

title: U.S. Says Palestinians, Too, Fail to Observe Peace Accord Fully
description: While Israel has frozen its compliance with recent peace accords, the Palestinian Authority is not fully complying with its own commitments, senior American and Israeli officials said today.

title: Governor Pataki's Wise Choice
description: The choice of a judge for the state's highest court is among the most important decisions a governor makes. This week Gov. George Pataki chose well, nominating Albert Rosenblatt, a widely respected New York State Appellate Division judge to a seat on the state's Court of Appeals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMBERG, ALVIN G.
description: BLUMBERG-Alvin G. Husband of Enid Feist Blumberg and the late Anita Blumberg. Father of Richard (Jewel) Mendell, Alan (Patty) Mendell, Guy Blumberg, Brian (Yvette) Feist and Robert (Mariam) Feist. Grandfather of eleven. Son of the late Sadie and Joe Blumberg. Brother of Babe and Norma Blumberg, Phyllis and the late Dr. Jerome Blumberg. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday 2-5pm, with service Monday 9:45am. Interment to follow at Beth El Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

description: To the Editor:

title: Spacecraft Is Launched to Look for Water on Mars
description: The first of two NASA science probes embarked from here today on a 416-million-mile voyage to Mars, launchedby a Boeing Delta 2 rocket.

title: Impeach or Don't, but Let's Move On Now; History Will Judge
description: To the Editor:

title: Honoring Grappelli by Imitating His Techniques
description: Stephane Grappelli's violin playing was at home in the swing of the 1930's but transcended eras with its restless energy. Even in ballads, of which he was a paramount performer, he manufactured an obsessive, refined tension, repeating short phrases in something like a patrician's elegant stammer, then tagged them with fast, wide-interval endings, concluding solos with whistling harmonics high up on the neck. He died last year at the age of 89, and on Thursday night players gathered at Carnegie Hall in a program called ''The Grappelli Legacy: Swing and Beyond'' to honor his work, performing music associated with him and his most famous collaborator, the Gypsy guitarist Django Reinhardt.

title: Corrections
description: The On the Road column in Weekend yesterday about visiting Washington misspelled the surname of a former mayor there. He is Marion Barry, not Berry.

title: Impeach or Don't, but Let's Move On Now; Moderates Are Heroes
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNY Poised To Require Core Courses
description: Led by a conservatively oriented board of trustees, the State University of New York appears ready to overhaul its undergraduate education by adopting a new core curriculum for all students.

title: CENTRAL RESERVE LIFE ADDING CONTINENTAL GENERAL
description: The Central Reserve Life Corporation agreed yesterday to purchase the Continental General Corporation from the Cincinnati-based Western and Southern Life Insurance Company for $84 million. Central Reserve expects to have total annualized revenue of more than $600 million with the acquisition. Central Reserve said it expected the insurance administrative functions of Continental General and its 325 employees to remain in Omaha after closing. Continental General had assets of about $425 million at Sept. 30 and had revenue of $180 million in the year-to-date period.

title: PROLOGIS TO ACQUIRE FRENCH DEVELOPER FOR $317 MILLION
description: Prologis Trust, the largest owner of industrial and warehouse properties in the United States, agreed yesterday to buy the French developer Garonor S.A. for $317 million. Garonor owns 5.25 million square feet of warehouse and industrial space, mainly in Paris and in Marseilles, France's largest port. Prologis, a Denver-based real estate investment trust, is attempting to win the business of the world's biggest warehouse users by expanding both in the United States and overseas. It has invested $650 million in Europe since July 1997, and last month it agreed to buy Meridian Industrial Trust for $1.32 billion, making it the market leader in Atlanta, Dallas-Fort Worth and San Francisco.

title: Fallen Angels In Energetic Theatricality
description: Ishmael Houston-Jones deals with angels in ''Specimens,'' performed on Thursday night at P.S. 122, but not the kind featured on holiday greeting cards. Instead, the five dancers in the new full-evening piece are of the fallen sort, or so it seemed, flung by Mr. Houston-Jones into a shadowy, irrational world.

title: Impeach or Don't, but Let's Move On Now; Acceptable Lies
description: To the Editor:

title: Voodoo Priest And 2 Others Are Indicted In Burning
description: A voodoo priest in New Jersey and two other people were indicted yesterday on charges that they conspired to kill a Long Island woman who was burned in a religious ritual that she sought as a means of driving away evil spirits, officials said.

title: Impeach or Don't, but Let's Move On Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton's Two Worlds
description: This week -- in the holiday season, on the cusp of the second Presidential impeachment vote ever in the House -- the polar ends of Bill Clinton's Presidency stretched further apart than they ever had.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: A. Stephens Hutchcraft Jr., 68; Was Chief of Kaiser Aluminum
description: A. Stephens Hutchcraft Jr., a senior executive of the Kaiser Aluminum Corporation, died on Nov. 25 at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 68 and lived in Danville, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXMAN, JACK
description: WAXMAN-Jack. On 12/11/98. Beloved brother of Charles & Barbara Weber. Loving uncle of Laurie. Cherished by relatives and friends. Services Sunday 12:30 PM, Louis Hirsch & Sons, 1225 Jerome Ave., The Bronx. Interment Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, NJ.

title: Lawyers in Early Tobacco Suits to Get $8 Billion
description: The lawyers who represented the first states to settle with the tobacco industry over health care costs were awarded $8.2 billion in fees yesterday, the richest legal payday in the nation's history.

title: Ousted From a Wall at City Hall, Koch Cries Foul
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's relations with his predecessors at City Hall, Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins, have long been strained.

title: Next Up for Jets: Game of Tug-of-War
description: It has the trappings of a memorable game, one of the most memorable in the long history between the Jets and Dolphins. Yet, Coach Bill Parcells is concerned that an itty-bitty play, a turnover, a miscalculation, will end up leading to either victory or defeat in the first-place battle between these two teams on Sunday night in Miami.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, RONALD M.
description: ALEXANDER-Ronald M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Ronald M. Alexander, associated with The Times from 1970.

title: Pigskin Widow
description: BALLS

title: Knife Attacks On Pet Horses Stun a Town In Arkansas
description: Sugar was the first horse to die. A 12-year-old roan, her owner found her in her stall, dead of stab wounds.

title: IN MY... ATTACHE CASE/MICKY ARISON
description: HE runs the world's biggest cruise line, a fleet of floating resorts loaded with everything including the kitchen sink. But Micky Arison, chief executive of the Carnival Corporation and owner of the Miami Heat of the N.B.A., likes to travel light.

title: Suitable for Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Introduction
description: Most readers savored Warren Hoge's report on Prince Charles and rated him finally ready for prime time. Others predicted that Charles's story would be a remake of his uncle the Duke of Windsor's, co-starrin Camilla as the divorcee non grata.

title: Art Takes Over Where Science Began
description: PRISCILLA MANNING PORTER of Washington is known for her fused glass, graceful bowls and plates, colorful stars in windows and fanciful animals. But one might just as easily find her, or one of her many apprentices, stalking the meadows looking for ferns, wildflowers and other greens. They pick specimens, fold them into the pages of news magazines, lay them flat under Miss Porter's living room carpet, and then walk on them until all the juices are dried out and the weeds are dry and flat.

title: December 6-12; Canadian's Execution Halted
description: Joseph Stanley Faulder was 30 minutes from a lethal injection in the Texas death chamber when the United States Supreme Court delayed his execution. Mr. Faulder is a Canadian and his Government had appealed for his life because he was not allowed to seek assistance from the Canadian counsel after his arrest in 1977 on charges of murdering an elderly woman.

title: More Than a Menorah
description: After the eight days end, Jews who celebrate Hanukkah usually stuff the nine-pronged candelabrum in the closet to gather dust till next year. But now, said Debbie Schwab, director of retail operations at the Jewish Museum gift shops, ''people want to use their menorahs all year round.''

title: Victory Takes Toll On Holik
description: There was less than eight minutes to play today, and the Devils trailed the Colorado Avalanche by a goal. That might lead you to believe that the Devils had their opponents right where they wanted them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, MATILDA
description: ROBBINS-Matilda. Born October 19, 1906, died December 8, 1998. We mourn the loss of our dear mother, sister, mother-in-law, grandma, and great-grandmother, who passed away at the age of 92, in Hallendale, FL. She was the beloved ''bride'' of the late Harry Robbins, devoted mother of Dr. John Robbins, Dr. Anthony L. Robbins and Mr. Marc Robbins; cherished grandmother of Robert Robbins, Daniel Robbins, Ellen Taxman, Dr. David Robbins, Philipe Robbins, Dr. Rebecca Robbins, Nadine Robbins, Maureen Fischer, Brian Robbins, Randi Robbins, Leah Robbins, Jonahthan Robbins, Deborah Robbins, and Jessica Robbins; loving greatgrandmother to 16 great-grandchildren. In the forefront of the family business until the day she died, her gentle humor, courage, firm resolve, love and abiding generosity remain with us forever. ''Tillie'' was devoted to her family and friends. She was an accomplished pianist, an ardent reader, and with Harry, regularly attended the opera and theater. We shall miss you, Grandma, with all our hearts. ''What a rare find is a capable woman, her worth is far beyond that of rubies.''

title: Adieu to a French Replica
description: Call it French architectural deconstructionism. On Tuesday, a 30-foot replica of the Eiffel Tower erected outside La Maison Moderne, a small housewares boutique on West 19th Street east of Seventh Avenue, was grudgingly dismantled by the store's owner, Kein Cross, after a dispute with his landlord.

title: Turkish Delights, Especially Seafood
description: LONG Island should be teeming with reasonably priced seafood restaurants. Instead, they can be counted on one hand. Piri's Grill is one of these rare finds. The Great Neck newcomer provides the added enticement of the hard-to-resist Turkish appetizers called mezes.

title: Azaleas? No! A Christmas Cactus? Yes!
description: I CONFESS to a general dislike of flowering plants used as decoration for the winter holidays. Possibly this is because I've always lived in a temperate zone with four distinct seasons. Winter is by rights the bloomless one.

title: Name Check Finds No Signs Of Vote Fraud
description: In his latest effort to overturn his apparent defeat in the November election, State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco has challenged the votes of Elias Alvarez, Susan Linder, Edleena Alexander and 100,000 others in New York City, asserting that they had moved or were otherwise ineligible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRETTER, JOSEPH
description: TRETTER-Joseph. Born in Austria on September 12, 1918, passed on December 10, 1998. Owner of Commuter's Cafe, World Trade Center. Beloved brother of Hermann and the late Ignatius, John and Victor. Dear brother-in-law of Mary, Agnes and the late Theresa Tretter. Cherished friend of Karen and Helen Schiele, and Joseph and John Domitrowitsch. Loving cousin and uncle of many cousins, nieces and nephews. Visitation at the Westchester Funeral Home, Eastchester, Saturday and Sunday 2:00-4:00PM and 7:00-9:00PM. Mass of Christian burial Monday, December 14th at Annunciation Church, Crestwood at 10:00AM. Interment Holy Mount Cemetery.

title: OPINION; A Working Woman's Weapons
description: THE fusion of illicit passion and raw power wasn't invented in the Clinton White House. It merely became an impeachable offense. Like the rest of America, the Long Island workplace has always been a place for affairs that centered around men of authority and women who wanted a piece of their power. In and by itself, the fact that it occurred just outside the Oval Office shouldn't have affected this age-old custom. Yet Bill Clinton's instant global humiliation, and the reaction from Congress, has threatened to chill the practice as male executives, and women who want to be, pause and consider their own potential for disaster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDOLF, LIESE (NEE) EDERHEIMER
description: RUDOLF-Liese (nee) Ederheimer passed away peacefully in Philadelphia on Dec. 5, 1998 at age 92. Wife of the late conductor, Max Rudolf, beloved mother of William Rudolf and Marianne Goldberger, grandmother of Leonard, Paul, Margaret Coffey, Malka, Erica Weiss and Laura, beloved greatgrandmother of ten. Funeral arrangements will be private. Oliver H. Bair, Company

title: The Nation: In Hot Pursuit of Minutiae; The Sound of One Law Breaking Down
description: IN theory, the independent counsel statute was supposed to be a legal traffic light, blinking red and green at the crossroads of law and politics. It would stop frivolous charges against high-level officials, but serious accusations would be waved on to an outside prosecutor. In recent days, however, the statute's already overloaded circuitry seems to have blown a fuse.

title: Conundrums of Being Black in Britain
description: AN exhibition at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven that showcases three emerging artists from England takes up a vast amount of gallery space. But there are few objects in it and it seems pared down, especially considering how many hands were involved in bringing it about: the catalogue introduction includes a veritable roll call of the Yale community.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, ABRAHAM R.
description: KAPLAN-Abraham R. Of Sands Point, NY, and Pomano Beach, FL, died Saturday, December 12, 1998, in Florida, in his 90th year. He was predeceased by his wife of 61 years Bertie Kaplan. He is survived by his wife Barbara Janoff Kaplan, two sons Morton and Don Kaplan, both of NY, and four grandchildren Gregory, Jennifer, David and Lynn. Funeral service Monday, at noon, Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY, 718445-0300. Burial at Mr. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on page 10 of the Travel section today, about Cairo, misstates the admission fee of a mosque and the hours of a church in some copies. The Mosque of Amr ibn al-As charges $1.80 admission; it is not free. The Hanging Church is open 11:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Sunday and Friday, not 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Selected Poems: 1960-1990

title: Frostbite Racers Take to Water Just for Chill of It
description: Sailors on Lake Michigan make a practice of hauling their boats in before the lake ices up in early December. But with the unusually mild weather this year, Chicago's frostbite racers, whose season ended before Thanksgiving as always, are in a meltdown about all the good sailing they are missing.

title: MUSIC: The Good, the Bad, the Rare: '98 Boxed Sets; VARIOUS ARTISTS: 'THE PERFECT BEATS -- NEW YORK ELECTRO HIP-HOP AND UNDERGROUND DANCE CLASSICS 1980-1985'
description: WITH every year's crop of boxed sets, musicians and recording companies go deeper into their archives, hoping to tempt collectors as well as gift- givers. For many musicians, a boxed set is still mainly a summation of past releases with a few rarities thrown in. Some releases take the large storage capacity of CD's as reason to forget selectivity, boxing whole catalogues of recordings in giant sets. Recording companies have also taken heart from the big sales of ''The Beatles Anthology'' series of unearthed recordings. An increasing number of boxed sets present material that used to be the province of bootleggers: live shows, alternative takes and unreleased songs, as if recording companies are rushing to release everything they own before the millennium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECK, JOAN
description: BECK-Joan. A longtime columnist for the Chicago Tribune, died December 10, in Lake Forest, IL. Her children Christopher Beck and Melinda Beck Neger, her son-in-law Peter Neger, and granddaughters Emily and Hillary Neger will miss her deeply and will always remember her love and inspiration. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Northwestern University, for the National High School Journalism Institute, 2020 Ridge Ave., Evanston, IL 60208.

title: When Gift of Wine Says More Than Its Package
description: IT is easy to fall into despair on a dreary day in December when the world is lighted by a 25-watt sun and one is hopelessly behind. It is time to make a list and check it twice, then start penciling in wines as gifts.

title: Christine Burke, Louis Vetrone
description: Anna Christine Burke and Louis Joseph Vetrone were married on Friday evening at SS. John and Paul Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Michael O'Leary performed the ceremony.

title: When Islanders Return And Find a New World
description: MISSING the smells of Long Island, that was almost painful,'' said Andrea Aussems. ''Mowing the lawn, summer barbecues, crunchy leaves, winter festivals, Jones Beach. You forget how wonderful these things smell until you spend time in the tropics, where if anything smells, it's probably not a good thing.''

title: Three Kerrymen Know How to Get a Pub Right
description: A verse from the Irish ballad ''The Kerry Dances'' laments the loss of ''our youth too soon.'' So it's somewhat fitting that three Kerrymen crossed the Atlantic from Ireland and established a bar named Tir Na Nog, Gaelic for ''land of eternal youth,'' which opens tomorrow at 5 Penn Plaza (Eighth Avenue between 33d and 34th Streets).

title: An Island Where the Treasure Is Seclusion
description: For a man who has been left by his wife, there may be no better place to get his head together than this sequestered patch of sand in the Great South Bay, near Fire Island.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: IF it isn't one ''Christmas Carol,'' it's another. In Connecticut's professional theaters this season, ''Christmas Carols'' have included four performances at the Stamford Center for the Arts of New England Lyric Operetta's streamlined Scrooge story set to a Gilbert and Sullivan score.

title: Conflicting Signals on Corporate Earnings
description: THE corporate earnings pre-announcement season is opening on a sour note with bad news from the likes of Merck, Coca-Cola, Boeing, Newell and Sears, Roebuck, as well as from several utility companies that have been hurt by the unseasonably warm weather.

title: Giving Solace to Children Made Orphans by AIDS
description: Mufasa Rogers is normally a sweet-tempered 3-year-old, but last Sunday he was feverish and exhausted. When the time came to relinquish his hand-held bells halfway through the tree-lighting ceremony at the Incarnation Children's Center, he surrendered to a fit of pique.

title: Rowan Cannot Conquer Its Nemesis, Mount Union
description: As Rowan Coach K. C. Keeler watched the Profs lose their fourth national championship game in six years today, he was not wallowing in his own frustration, he said. He was thinking about those who would not get another opportunity.

title: Clear the Platforms Before Adding Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: What We Look Up to Now
description: There is a certain irony in a status symbol whose logo is ''What Would Jesus Do?'' (''Jewelry for Jesus,'' by Emily Nussbaum). One is tempted, of course, to ask if Jesus was into status symbols. And most of the teen-agers queried about the jewelry talked about collectibility, variety of style and color, even exclusionism. (Would the items do well here, in the Haight-Ashbury, as ''What Would Jerry Do?'') Interestingly, though, one girl, Jaclyn Bromley of Amarillo, Tex., actually spoke of using the bracelet as a means of dealing with difficult situations. Referring to a party where ''there was drinking and stuff,'' she reported that it helped her to think ''what would Jesus say or do if he was there right now?'' One can't help wondering what this young girl was getting herself into.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAVEN, BABETTE
description: CRAVEN-Babette. The staff of the Billy Rose Theatre Collection at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts mourns the death on November 29th of their friend and colleague Babette (Babs) Craven who was a loyal volunteer for over 40 years. Her gentle nature, her devotion to theatre and her boundless knowledge will be deeply missed by all of us who worked with her.

title: Ms. Mendelson And Mr. Berger
description: Stephani Mendelson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Mendelson of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Richard Jay Berger, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon Berger of Holmdel, N.J. Cantor Donna Faye Dower officiated at the Crestmont Country Club in West Orange, N.J.

title: In the Region / Westchester; Rent Squabble Shuts a White Plains 'Incubator'
description: WESTCHESTER'S first high-technology incubator, designed to nurture small companies in a supportive environment with reasonable rents and flexible lease terms, closed last month as a result of a pending court case against the center's operator for nonpayment of rent.

title: Paper-Loving Culture Welcomes a Master's Work
description: CREATIVE ideas that evolved in Alan Shields's rambling old farmhouse studio on Shelter Island are currently the focus of a museum in Fukushima, Japan, where the Center for Contemporary Graphic Art has mounted a major retrospective of the artist's works on paper.

title: Message: Sweet-Talking Spaghetti Sauce
description: When you think about it, sauce is mostly sauce. It's the label that makes the difference. A multimillion-dollar business, packaging is the most lucrative form of design work in the United States. We asked the designer Tibor Kalman (shown below the jars) to pretend he was pitching these labels to various manufacturers. We wanted to know how he thought they would have tried to sell the designs, as well as to get a view of the messages the labels are trying to communicate.

title: SOAPBOX; You Deserve a Brake Today
description: THE New Jersey Highway Authority runs the Garden State Parkway and the PNC Bank Arts Center. The Highway Authority said in its annual report that it met last year's financial needs with the help of ''successful entrepreneurial efforts'' to boost nontoll revenue. We know the Authority previously brought in gobs of nontoll revenue by selling PNC Bank the right to put its name on the Garden State Arts Center. So why not sell naming rights to the entire Garden State Parkway? The parkway would get a multimillion dollar infusion of money from some enterprising company and could add to the pot by doing creative entrepreneurial things with its new corporate name.

title: Working: Surface Tension
description: A Look at a designer's desk is the professional equivalent of peeking nto his medicine cabinet. You get a glimpse into the private, everyday world of the man or woman behind the glossy magazine spreads and snappy packaging. Designers are often stereotyped as fanatical neatniks. In fact, they have just as much clutter in their offices as the rest of us -- it's just more interesting clutter: stones, shells, model racing cars, photographs, fabric swatches, tiles, perhaps a beloved drafting pencil or fountain pen.

title: Safir Says DNA Proposal Would Cut Property Crime
description: With violent crime down sharply, Police Commissioner Howard Safir has proposed taking DNA samples from everyone arrested in New York City -- from subway turnstile jumpers on up -- so that the police can use new technology to lock up career criminals like burglars and car thieves.

title: 25 Ways to Slice a Universe
description: With a few thinly veiled jabs at its rivals in the mutual fund rankings business, a new logo and even a new name, Lipper Inc., formerly Lipper Analytical Services, disclosed its revamped fund classifications last week.

title: Streetscapes / The Alameda, Broadway and 84th Street; A Stretch of Neighborhood Stores Turns Upscale
description: THERE are A-level retail tenants sprinkled up and down Broadway, but an unusual strategy by the owner of a 1915 apartment house at the northwest corner of 84th Street is creating a mini-stretch of Madison Avenue on what is otherwise just a neighborhood street.

title: A Megachurch Takes Shape in Bloomfield
description: IN suburban Bloomfield, just north of Hartford, with a population pushing 20,000, almost everyone spent some time -- and many, a great deal of time -- watching a giant church take form this year. ''I'm a church watcher,'' confesses Bainie Wild, executive assistant to the town manager. ''Everyone in town is a church watcher. It's so new, and different, and BIG.''

title: Bosses to Love and to Lean On
description: Not all bosses have big egos, big mouths and tight fists. Many are softies who will go the extra mile to help an employee, even if there is nothing in it for them. What acts of kindness, or workplace heroism, has your boss performed? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

description: THE people coming toward me in the Geneva airport looked healthy, incandescent, graceful, the way humans are supposed to look, the way they looked before cars and soap operas. There was only one explanation: They'd been skiing.

title: Q&A/Lester B. Adler; Mission to Tighten Teen-Age Driver Laws
description: A 16-YEAR-OLD Pleasantville boy, driving on the Saw Mill River Parkway in August, was killed in a one-car accident. The police said inexperience contributed to the fatal crash, which injured four passengers. Later that month, a 16-year-old Scarsdale youth was killed in a crash on the Bronx River Parkway, in which some of his friends were seriously injured. Go back a year, two years, a decade, and there will be reports of similar car accidents involving teen-age drivers.

title: The Fresh Prince

If the Queen were to succumb, the new King would not last until his coronation. It would be Edward VIII all over again, with Tony Blair in the Stanley Baldwin role.

title: PULSE; French-Fry Fever
description: After a long day of shopping, cell-phoning and dieting, a svelte young lady of fashion likes nothing better than to sit down in front of a big plate of: (a) chopped endive, (b) steamed tofu, (c) greasy french fries. The answer seems to be (c), as frites have become the dish du jour at chic bistros around town. ''Down with salad -- I'm sick of living a fat-free existence,'' said Marissa Acocello, a slender cartoonist who had french fries and French wine for lunch recently at Cafe Noir on Grand Street.

Friends may call at Lacerenza Funeral Home, 8 Schuyler Ave, Stamford, CT Sunday Dec. 13, 2-4 and 6-8. Mass of Christian burial Monday, December fourteenth 11 AM St. Maurice Church, Stamford, CT. title: Trash Plan Is Praised, But Faces Opposition

The point is underlined by fierce opposition in New Jersey and Brooklyn to giant transfer stations proposed in those locales by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Underwater Vows
description: For couples who don't mind having a few fish at their wedding, the Jalousie Hilton on St. Lucia offers its Dive Wedding package, which allows scuba enthusiasts to marry in the Caribbean. The ceremony is in Jalousie Bay, with the couple exchanging vows on a slate for writing underwater. Also present will be the best man, maid of honor and someone to communicate with the officiant (who is on land). The three-night package, starting at $1,117 a couple, includes accommodations, the ceremony and an underwater rehearsal. Call (800) 445-8667.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, A. BURTON
description: WHITE-A. Burton. Physician, lifelong resident of New York, longtime resident of Great Neck. Died on Dec 10, 1998. He is survived by his beloved and loving wife, Hannabelle, his children Jonathan, Randolph and Liane Wolff, his five grandchildren Aude, Clemence, Anne-Laure, Aaron and Ilan and sister Vivian Churgin. He served his country and his community in so many ways, including as an Officer in the U.S. Air Force, as President of the Great Neck Democratic Club, as Chairman of the Nassau County Board of Health and in various capacities with the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons. He will be deeply missed.

You might think he has an easier time the month before, when he is spotted in malls, smiling with children on his knee, emitting endless ''Ho! Ho! Ho's!''.

description: The provocateur Philippe Starck once called himself the Baader-Meinhof of design; but Rabelais is more like it. With hotel interiors, chairs, housewares and industrial objects that are at once refined, plebeian and enticingly witty, the 49-year-old Parisian has established himself as the most profoundly open-minded designer at work today. Other designers talk of the significance of the everyday object; Starck comes up with the $30 toilet brush.

title: Still Boasting at 50: 'Party of the Year'
description: Dec. 7: The Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art celebrated its 50th anniversary ''Party of the Year,'' the museum's largest annual benefit. This year, it raised more than $1.5 million and drew 3,150 guests. The first party, in 1948 at the Rainbow Room, was attended by 400 and raised $20,000. Irene Lewisohn and a group of her theater friends founded the institute in 1937 as the Museum of Costume Art, at 16 West 46th Street. They had been collecting costumes since the 1920's for their Neighborhood Playhouse, on Grand Street. When Seventh Avenue was cut off from Paris by the war, they opened the collection to the fashion industry. At first, the party was a fashion industry event, with live pageants. The collection moved to the Met in 1946, and the first party held in the museum was in 1960, the year the institute became a full-fledged department. It wasn't until 1972 with the arrival of Diana Vreeland and her extravagant exhibitions that the party evolved into the city's top social event. Since Ms. Vreeland died in 1989, the eight galleries have been cut back to three and the party's guest list has begun to shift back to members of the fashion industry, with fewer movie stars and society guests.

WARREN E. LEARY

title: A Mexican Atmosphere in Port Chester
description: THE festive decor at Mary Ann's in Westchester is alone worth the price of admission. Giant ceramic cactuses flank the entrance; a Mayan-style figure guards an indoor fountain. Brilliant blues, yellows and terra cottas color the walls, or what one can see of them under all the Mexican crafts that cram the place -- pierced-tin lighting fixtures, tiled table tops and ceramic masks, candle lamps and all sorts of ornamental sculptures. Wherever one looks, something interesting catches the eye.

title: Born in the Ruins of War, a School Flowered
description: FIFTY years ago, the creation of a film school in war-ravaged Poland might have seemed a folly. But for a country whose geographical and political existence has been truncated for centuries, art becomes a means to sustain national identity. And film is, as Lenin put it, the most important art in 20th-century Europe.

description: MANY real estate stories these days, whether of the rich, the poor or the middle-class, seem to center on the same dilemma -- the frustration of looking and looking and not finding.

description: Diana Lisa Maria Vargas and Richard Scott Gable are to be married today at Oheka, the Otto Kahn house in Cold Spring Hills, N.Y. The Rev. Gerald Heinen, a Roman Catholic priest, is to officiate, and Rabbi Jerry Heller will take part in the ceremony.

title: Frogs Without Hope
description: Gahan Wilson turns his pictures into thousands of words in THE CLEFT: And Other Odd Tales (Tor/Tom Doherty, $23.95), a collection of meticulously eccentric stories. But the illustrations are definitely the icing on this devil's food cake of a book. The best story is the tenderly heartbreaking ''Frog Prince,'' about a poor little creature with a recurring dream about a kingly father and a spell that until broken holds him fast in the loneliness of his watery world: ''Frog watched from his lily pad, confident that the magic would work on its own, that his salvation was approaching.'' Salvation, alas, is not an option for most of Wilson's characters. Spiders devour the curious, sea gulls wreak vengeance on the guilty, cats claw their owners to death -- and what people do to people is even worse. The title story, about monks decorating the precipitous route to their mountainside shrine, is a brisk lesson in human folly. In ''The Power of the Mandarin,'' a fictional character undoes a real-life foe, thinking: ''The idiot had discovered Evan Trowbridge's strength, which was implacable hatred, but he had shared, and therefore missed altogether, his weakness, which was a lack of sufficient imagination.'' Happily, this is a weakness that Wilson doesn't share. Andrea Higbie

title: BOOKEND; Confessions of (an) Abridger
description: The first books I ever abridged were romances, novels as fantastic as Jules Verne with their relentless, requited love. At that time, in the early 1980's, I had begun writing fiction myself and was on the lookout for work that wouldn't be all that taxing, leaving certain parts of my brain fresh for plot development of my own. I ended up working for a small publisher in New Jersey, where I condensed remaindered novels that arrived by the cartonful. On the florid covers, couples sprawled all over each other, dressed in late-70's fashions -- a tumble of sideburns, flared pants and bare midriffs. Books were selected using a complex type-size-to-page-number ratio: large type size plus short page count was the ideal. Victorian novels, with their pesky sense of history, frequent hansom rides and miniature type, were avoided. Plots were incidental -- they all had the same plot anyway -- and 10 of these novels were eventually jammed into two digest-size magazines.

title: Masters: Philip Johnson's Starck Choice
description: When I began work on my first design show, ''Machine Art,'' at the Museum of Modern Art, 65 years ago, I chose two objects to illustrate my thought on design, which was defined by functionalism. One object was a ship's propeller, which we thought was the obvious choice to hang in front of the museum when the show opened in 1934. Amelia Earhart, whom we asked to judge the show, was elated. To her it was fitting. The sinuous curves of the propeller were practical and beautiful. The other object was a ball-bearing wheel, which appeared on the cover of the show's catalogue.

title: Backtalk; Heard All the Latest Conspiracy Theories Rocking Sports?

I'd probably give the film a jokey title, ''Hoop Schemes'' or ''We Got No Game,'' so as not to scare off the Shaq and ''Space Jam'' crowd who could wander into the theater by mistake. But this would be a serious piece of work about a conspiracy so pernicious it would need an Independent Referee to untangle.

It was a gritty urban street corner where the men wore black turtlenecks and corduroy coats, while the long-haired women, many of them smoking, wore boots and beads. A young man strummed a guitar in front of the Kettle of Fish restaurant (with lox and cream cheese listed on the menu at 75 cents). Nearby were the Cafe Figaro, the Bitter End and posters for concerts by the Lovin' Spoonful and Buffy Sainte-Marie.

''For Sale -- Cheap,'' the sign on its windshield said. I hit the brakes in the middle of Route 10. My spouse had to go into high gear to prevent me from losing my marbles in some regrettably expensive way.

title: Judgment: Where Do You Hang the 747?
description: Then she fantasizes about objects, and she does often, Paola Antonelli dreams of adding a Boeing 747 to the firmament of design at the Museum of Modern Art. Possessed of a deep utilitarian beauty that Antonelli likens to that of a camel -- ''it has that hump'' -- the plane, she says, ''is beautiful because of how it looks, how it works and what it represents. It made people feel anybody could fly.'' The 747 hasn't yet been inducted into the Modern's design collection. But if and when it is, it won't be hanging from the ceiling on West 53d Street. Antonelli, an associate curator in the museum's department of architecture and design, envisions an ambitious expansion beyond the museum's walls. The 747 would become an airborne adjunct of the collection. Flight attendants would hand out complementary design magazines along with beverages and a light snack. A MOMA accession number, the ultimate status symbol, would be emblazoned on the plane's glistening aluminum alloy skin.

Some releases take the large storage capacity of CD's as reason to forget selectivity, boxing whole catalogues of recordings in giant sets. Recording companies have also taken heart from the big sales of ''The Beatles Anthology'' series of unearthed recordings. An increasing number of boxed sets present material that used to be the province of bootleggers: live shows, alternative takes and unreleased songs, as if recording companies are rushing to release everything they own before the millennium.

title: 'Porgy' and Music's Racial Politics

Is it Poulenc's ''Dialogues of the Carmelites''? Shostakovich's ''Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District''? It could be either, but the opus in question is Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess,'' which shares with those mighty works enough visceral dramatic sweep and power, musical invention and craft, vocally and theatrically meaty characters, and mythical resonance to match any of Verdi's middle-period operas.

That's how he has always regarded being a principal; it was like being captain of a ship, he said. This may be why, while waiting for my mother to emerge from life-support, he urges us to read his Patrick O'Brian sea stories as he recalls his own voyages.

But on Day 162 of the National Basketball Association lockout, the league canceled its Feb. 14 All-Star Game in Philadelphia and stirred expectations that the entire season is close to being wiped out.

title: New Haven, a City Of Beer Making (Until Prohibition)

That's how it seems in ''New Haven Breweries,'' an exhibition at the New Haven Colony Historical Society that traces beer making in the city back to Colonial times. Period photos, artifacts (even a circa-1890 beer, still unopened) all bear witness to the years when a giant statue of Gambrinus looked down on the city.

title: The Misuse of Impeachment
description: With the House now headed for a vote on impeachment, it is essential to cut through the constitutional distortion that developed during the Judiciary Committee debate. One of the most dangerous notions is that impeachment by the House is an acceptable functional substitute for censure -- the equivalent of a stinging grand-jury indictment or a rebuke that can be passed in anticipation that the Senate will not remove the President.

title: The Cost of Getting High-Rollers Rolling

But a limo operator says the increase will only hurt struggling drivers and fleet owners, not wealthy gamblers or casinos.

title: Who Needs Snow?

The idea, seen in Paris earlier this fall, turned up in New York in casual sportswear, including on a few men, left and top. While the all-white look, a favorite in this fall's collections, is an eye-catcher on Fifth Avenue, don't forget red, still America's favorite color and a great uplifter for the holiday blues.

title: Only the Lonely
description: Ernst Lubitsch's period comedy THE SHOP AROUND THE CORNER (1940) is a heartwarming and sentimental story of budding love in a Budapest store where the staff manager, James Stewart, begins a sweet, secretive courtship of a sensitive young woman, played by Margaret Sullavan. The picture cleverly keeps their identities separate until the end, and a splendid cast brings the employees and their personal relationships warmly to the fore. Stewart and Sullavan are superbly evocative as the determined but confused pen pals. Frank Morgan as a store owner and the other players, including Joseph Schildkraut, fill their roles with excellence - THURSDAY at 8 P.M. on Turner Classic Movies.

title: Sorority Sisters
description: Solomon accuses Julia Margaret Cameron of misogyny and sentimentality because the women Cameron posed as saints, angels and fairy-tale beauty queens were just the ''maids who dusted her curtains and served her tea.'' But that is precisely the point. Unlike Cameron's shots of ''illustrious'' men of the period, these portraits needed no celebrity faces to enhance their impact. Instead, they captured a universal condition -- the complex comedy and tragedy of being female in Victorian England. Cameron's ''Queen of the May'' ranks as one of the most brilliant and empathetic studies of the rewards and punishments of female beauty in the history of photography.

title: The Fresh Prince
description: I appreciate Warren Hoge's effort at British understatement when he refers to Prince Charles's personal life as including ''tape recordings of stunningly graceless sexual small talk.'' Those recordings were much more than graceless; they were the fantasies of a very sick personality. I was not alone in believing, after reading excerpts from those tapes, that Charles needs professional help, and not a public relations firm. I wish the monarchy no ill will but merely prefer it fades into obscurity.

title: In the Region / Long Island; Redeveloping Lockheed's 93 Acres in Nassau
description: A FORLORN air pervades a sprawling 1.5-million-square-foot brick building fronting on Marcus Avenue here as the last of 500 employees who work here for Lockheed Martin prepare to move to Uniondale. The historic structure -- a portion of which served as the United Nations headquarters from 1946 to 1951 -- is to be completely vacated by mid-January.

title: Iran Discontent Rises as Oil-Based Economy Falls
description: For nearly two months now, the 7,500 workers who punch in every morning at the Iran Tractor Manufacturing Company have found themselves with almost nothing to do.

title: BEST SELLERS: December 13, 1998
description: Weeks

title: The Fresh Prince
description: Hoge's article was not enhanced by the large and unattractive cartoon of the Prince on the cover, exaggerating his features in a very unkind way. It did not prepare the reader for an enjoyable and fair-minded account of Prince Charles's accomplishments and the public esteem he has earned.

title: When the Bat Took Flight
description: THE BAT WHISPERS

title: School Expansion
description: In addition to building a high school on a 23-acre site in Hartsdale, the Solomon Schechter School of Westchester, a 33-year-old Conservative Jewish elementary school in White Plains, is planning to open another elementary school in the northern part of the county.

title: What We Look Up to Now
description: Real status is completing the New York Times crossword puzzle the day it arrives -- without help -- and telling your friends that it was a snap. Everything else is just conversation.

title: Don't Call Them 'Urban Pioneers'
description: IN the shadow of an abandoned RCA factory building, its windowpanes cruelly poked out, is John Giannotti's house, its own front windows dressed in red velvet and the lead mullions of the fan light above the door perfectly intact from 1810. Here, Mr. Giannotti can be especially mindful of Walt Whitman's comment that in his life ''Camden was originally an accident,'' but one he was grateful to have happen to him.

title: Cabs to the Strip
description: To the Editor: The vital statistics box with ''What's Doing in Las Vegas'' (Feb. 15) quoted a $22 cab fare from the airport. Based on this information, we paid $20 to get from the airport to our hotel on the Strip on Nov. 10. We were told by the hotel captain that the price should have been about $10, and this was confirmed by the local taxi companies. We were taken via the freeway, a much longer route.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Turn of River in Stamford, Conn.; Diverse Neighborhood, With Golf Course
description: OF Stamford's 12 distinctive neighborhoods Turn of River is one of the smallest, most diverse and most convenient -- a location of choice for people who want the country, the supermarket, the golf course, and the Merritt Parkway within minutes of their front doors.

title: Public Funds at Stake
description: A County Department of Social Services employee was arrested late last month in connection with the theft of $11,800 in public funds. The employee, Michelle D. Williams, 33, of Mount Vernon, a data entry clerk for the Mount Vernon District Office of the Department of Social Services, is accused of submitting fraudulent applications to the department for child assistance money for the day care of her daughter by using the fictitious identity of Mikayla Williams.

title: New Rules On Dish Antennas
description: THE Federal Communications Commission has issued two new orders that more clearly define the extent to which local governments, landlords and co-op and condominium boards can control satellite-dish installation.

title: All Should Contribute To School Taxes
description: Jim Panos may sullenly accept the fact that he will now only have to pay $5,000 in annual school taxes thanks to Governor Pataki's Star program ''rebate'' of $1,000. But by the same token he should be thankful that the working parents of these same school children pay for Mr. and Mrs. Panos's Social Security benefits, which in all probability is greater than $5,000. Mr. Panos, there is no free lunch for anybody these days.

title: MUSIC: The Good, the Bad, the Rare: '98 Boxed Sets; VARIOUS ARTISTS: 'FROM MINSTREL TO MOJO -- AN AUDIO HISTORY OF AMER-ICAN POPULAR SONG PRESENTED THROUGH RARE RECORDS, 1893-1946'
description: WITH every year's crop of boxed sets, musicians and recording companies go deeper into their archives, hoping to tempt collectors as well as gift- givers. For many musicians, a boxed set is still mainly a summation of past releases with a few rarities thrown in. Some releases take the large storage capacity of CD's as reason to forget selectivity, boxing whole catalogues of recordings in giant sets. Recording companies have also taken heart from the big sales of ''The Beatles Anthology'' series of unearthed recordings. An increasing number of boxed sets present material that used to be the province of bootleggers: live shows, alternative takes and unreleased songs, as if recording companies are rushing to release everything they own before the millennium.

title: Mobile Technology Center for Teachers' Sakes
description: LOOKING more like an oversized ice cream truck than a fully loaded transport to the next millennium, a new mobile technology van, built from an old school bus by the Suffolk County Organization for the Promotion of Education, sat parked beside the entrance of the Roanoke Elementary School in Riverhead the other day.

title: Police Say Brooklyn Man Fired Gun at Officers
description: A man fired on two police officers who were trying to break up a gunfight in Brooklyn early yesterday, the authorities said. He was arrested and charged with the attempted murder of a police officer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IANNIELLO, PAUL
description: IANNIELLO-Paul. Of Laguna Hills, Calif. Formerly of Rockville Centre, N.Y. On December 10. Beloved husband of Lynne. Father of Geoffry and Richard, grandfather of Jesse, Laura and Abby.

title: The Importance Of Internship
description: Q. I am a business major with a concentration in information systems. I hear that the job market is very good, but I do not have internship experience. Should I graduate on schedule to enter that market, or wait a year to complete an internship?

title: An Immoderate Republican Voice Urges Moderation on Impeachment
description: Representative Peter T. King is not unique among members of Congress for having supported the Irish Republican Army. But, as far as anyone can tell, he remains the only Congressman to have called himself ''the Ollie North of Ireland.''

title: Prof. Jack Farris, 77, Author of Poetry, Novels and Plays
description: Jack Farris, a novelist, playwright and retired professor of English, died on Nov. 26 at a hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 77 and had recently moved to Rockville, Md., from Lockesburg, Ark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNE, CATHERINE (NEE MULCAHY)
description: BROWNE-Catherine (nee Mulcahy). Longtime Cedarhurst resident, on December 11, 1998. Wife of Thomas L., Sr. Mother of Thomas L., Jr., Catherine Noel Blair, Kevin P., Marian, and Christopher. Grandmother of five. Dear sister of Helen Wilt. Reposing Sunday, 24 and 7-9 PM, at Meserole Funeral Home, Inwood. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 9:45 AM, at St. Joachim R.C. Church, Cedarhurst. Interment Holy Rood R.C. Cemetery, Westbury. Contributions to Our Lady of Hope Fund for the Elderly will be appreciated.

title: Former Biblio's Back as a Lotus Land for Hungry Readers
description: After nearly a year of walking past the vacant storefront at 317 Church Street, neighborhood residents were back inside last week week, sipping lattes, eating mesclun salads and thumbing through magazines.

title: Silicon Alley's Byways and Boulevards
description: TUCKED away in old manufacturing buildings in the Flatiron District, in SoHo or on the West Side near Hudson Square -- and with an important concentration downtown -- new-media companies are becoming an important factor in commercial real estate in the New York area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHAN, DAVID LEOPOLD
description: NATHAN-David Leopold. Beloved and cherished son of Michelle and Steven Nathan, brother of Laurie, Tamara, Andrew, and Alize, friend of many. We love you dearly. May you stay in the light. Memorial service December 14, 7PM at Ansche Chesed.

title: Variations: A Cover Story
description: To come up with a cover, the magazine tried an experiment, asking some of the country's top designers to solve the same design problem -- to capture in one ''poster'' the message of its special issue: the shock of the familiar. The teams -- experimental and traditional, from ''packaging,'' corporate-image creation, print advertising, television and CD design -- were told the theme and given the headline the editors had written. Below are six cover ideas, including the winner, and the thinking behind the solutions. In the end, the editors and the art director chose the one with no image at all -- just an unadorned type cover that by inverting the logo forced the reader to see the cover, itself a familiar object, in an entirely new light. While the magazine found much to admire in the other submissions, the Morla design told the story in the simplest, most pleasing way. You might disagree; the fun of these pages is letting you decide for yourself.

title: MUSIC: The Good, the Bad, the Rare: '98 Boxed Sets; VARIOUS ARTISTS: 'THE ROLLING STONE WOMEN IN ROCK COLLECTION'
description: WITH every year's crop of boxed sets, musicians and recording companies go deeper into their archives, hoping to tempt collectors as well as gift- givers.
