title: A Family-Owned Publishing House Finds Something Extra's the Charm
description: FOUR years ago, during the Christmas season, Peter Pauper Press here published a miniature book called ''Angels Are Forever.'' The tiny (3 1/4 by 4 inches) 80-page volume, filled with aphorisms about angels, was selling reasonably well. Then Evelyn Beilenson, a co-owner and co-publisher with her husband, Nick, of Peter Pauper Press, had a sort of divine inspiration: add a little ribbon bookmark with a 24-carat gold-plated charm attached.

title: THE NATION: Senate Rules; If Impeachment Seems Strange, Just Wait for the Trial
description: PICTURE this for high drama:

title: Ending State Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Uncertainty At Next Step
description: A touch of dignity and a heavy dose of uncertainty surround the capital today, as what seems to be the only city in America that takes impeachment seriously looks toward a House vote on articles calling for President Clinton to be removed from office.

title: The Secrets of Leaves and Signals of Buds
description: BY now everyone has seen enough of leaves -- raked, blown, stacked by the curb and so on. Yet leaves are a vital part of our lives, with much to be learned about and from them.

title: Iron Drizzle
description: COUNTRYOF MEMORYBy K. C. Frederick.240 pp. Sag Harbor, N.Y.:The Permanent Press. $24.

title: GURU: Eliza Petrescu; Where Eyebrows Go Up and Down On Command
description: ELIZA PETRESCU, an eyebrow designer, doesn't stand on ceremony, or even bother with hello. ''We are going to have to let those eyebrows grow!'' she said, greeting a new client who seemed to be expecting a more genial ''good morning.''

title: A Final Defeat for Democrats As a Weary Committee Retires
description: The Democrats on the impeachment committee agonized in their final defeat tonight, accusing Republicans of attempting a legislative coup and seeing their hopes for the Scarlet C, as in censure, rebuffed as the alternative to removing President Clinton from office.

title: Going, Going . . . : Ice Time With a Pro
description: IMAGINING the brief notoriety he might achieve if he showed up on ''Baywatch,'' Neal Thomas, a New York banker, leaped into the bidding at a charity auction for the Franciscan Sisters of the Poor Foundation last week at Mickey Mantle's Restaurant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, JULIAN ROY
description: KLEIN-Julian Roy. On December 8, 1998. Beloved son of Natalie and Louis Klein. Associate Director of Network Sales from 1962 to 1986, Alumni of Dartmouth College, and Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday, December 16, 9:45 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the U.S. Navy Relief Fund or the State of Israel.

title: Moving Targets
description: To the Editor:

title: Center on Genocide Is a Good Start
description: To the Editor:

title: Brown Becomes The Richest In Baseball
description: Pitcher Kevin Brown became baseball's first $100 million player today when he agreed to a seven-year contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: BENEFITS
description: Symphonic Youth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISHOP, HAZEL
description: BISHOP-Hazel, Rye, NY. December 5, 1998. Age 92. Beloved aunt of Randa Bishop, Las Vegas, NV; Arthur Lipper, Delmar, Calif.; A. Michael Lipper, Summit, NJ. Memorial service St. Bartholomew's Chapel, Park Ave at 50th St, NYC, April 9, 1999, at 10 AM. Graduate Barnard College, research chemist Socony/Mobil, founder of Hazel Bishop, Inc. Developed first long lasting lipstick, financial securities analyst, adjunct professor at Fashion Institute. Donations to St. Bartholomew's Church in lieu of flowers would be appreciated.

title: PANEL COMPLETES IMPEACHMENT VOTES AND DEFEATS DEMOCRATS' CENSURE BID
description: The House Judiciary Committee completed action today on its bill of charges against President Clinton, approving a fourth article of impeachment to stand alongside the three it voted on Friday.

title: Accident Report Shows Overhead-Bin Danger
description: Many people fear airplane accidents, but they may be focused on the wrong source of injury. A recent study indicates that thousands of people are hurt annually in events that do not even meet the aviation authorities' definition of an accident. By contrast, in 1997, the latest statistics available, the National Transportation Safety Board listed 2 deaths and 21 serious injuries in what it considered accidents.

title: Fire Claims Artist's Trove
description: It was a rainy evening two days after a fire destroyed Security Self Storage on Bay Street, and Scott LoBaido sat in the Cargo Cafe, across from the burned-out building where he stored his artworks and often created them. Mr. LoBaido, 33, had searched all day for a new space, but was pessimistic about finding a spot to match his old accommodations.

title: What We Look Up to Now
description: As a ''privileged white male'' of ''famine Irish'' ancestry, with a working-class family history, I have achieved the status of having an M.A., Master's of Philosophy and Ph.D., and for all this grand status, I cannot get a serious interview for a full-time teaching position (''Being Post-Paglia,'' by Daniel Mendelsohn).

title: The Nation; Gridlock in the Wild Blue Yonder
description: ON Dec. 2, a US Airways passenger jet landing at La Guardia Airport came within 50 feet of a corporate plane preparing to take off. It was one of three times in the Northeast this month in which planes came too close together, which might lead peak-season passengers to wonder what's going on up there. A lot: air traffic nationally and in the Northeast has never been more congested.

title: Norma Rae Goes Electronic
description: Though the picket lines at ABC headquarters on the Upper West Side and the Federally mediated negotiations between the union and management seem like standard fare for labor disputes, the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians and the network have also opened a new front in their battle. Both sides have taken to the Web to get their views across.

title: What We Look Up to Now
description: I found your issue on status engaging (Nov. 15). I was disheartened, however, that you failed to inquire into the ''paths to prestige'' in our nation's penitentiaries. Regular and brimming packages of food from caring moms, the seduction of any one of the few female employees and really nice sneakers rank high.

title: Despite Depth as a Team, Americans Miss the Gold
description: This year's United States Olympiad team followed the philosophy of the New York Yankees in fielding strength at every position with a very strong captain, too, Larry Christiansen of Boston. Unlike the World Series-winning Yankees, however, the chess players had a narrow miss and had to be content with the silver medals.

title: Police Deny Running New Brunswick Brothel
description: The business on the renovated third floor of the dilapidated warehouse here advertised itself as Pleasure Dome 121 in newspapers and adult entertainment magazines, and in the few months it was open this summer it never seemed to have a problem with the authorities. The reason, county prosecutors say, is that the two men who ran the business were local police officers.

title: Truck With Scouts' Christmas Trees Is Stolen
description: The police were searching yesterday for a truck containing about 100 Christmas trees that was stolen from a Boy Scout troop Friday night.

title: Winning the Recruiting Bowl
description: To the Editor:

title: Craft: From Eureka to Your House
description: The shape on the computer screen turns in space, a soft gray sculpture rendered in what looks like powdered graphite. This is, for now, merely a Platonic, digital ideal of a chair. But soon it will exist in real space, a stackable, casual, inexpensive chair of virgin polypropylene and steel tubing. Its progress from sketch to store, from concept to object, is an exemplary tale of design today, with new technologies, new materials and new meanings playing large roles.

title: Pottery as Therapy: A Workshop to Revive Skills
description: IF Dr. Janet Gonzalez had her way, she would never get her fingers dirty, even in a pottery class. But she was working on a wall plant holder, and that required her to wet her fingers, then press two slabs of clay together.

title: The Junior League And Its Volunteers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMBERG, ALVIN G.
description: BLUMBERG-Alvin G. Husband of Enid Feist Blumberg and the late Anita Blumberg. Father of Richard (Jewel) Mendell, Alan (Patty) Mendell, Guy Blumberg, Brian (Yvette) Feist and Robert (Mariam) Feist. Grandfather of eleven. Son of the late Sadie and Joe Blumberg. Brother of Babe and Norma Blumberg, Phyllis and the late Dr. Jerome Blumberg. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday 2-5pm, with service Monday 9:45am. Interment to follow at Beth El Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: An Easy Appetizer: Baguette and Toppings
description: THIS is the time of year when people like to line their stomachs with a little something early in the evening. The cocktail hour stretches longer during the holidays as people sometimes fit in two or even three parties before dinner. While tortilla chips and salsa are all very well, it is possible to be a little more ambitious without spending a lot of time.

title: DATABANK: December 7 - 11; Earnings Warnings Depress Blue Chips
description: In a market driven by earnings, the gear shift for blue-chip stocks was in reverse last week. Coca-Cola, the most recent big company to warn that its profits would not meet analysts' forecasts, led a tumble in the Dow Jones industrial average that reached 111 points by midafternoon on Friday. But the Dow bounced back smartly, trimming its loss to 19.82 points and closing at 8,821.76, after President Clinton said that he would address the nation on television later in the day.

title: Orphaned By AIDS
description: About 28,000 children in New York City have been orphaned by AIDS since the epidemic began. Some have the virus themselves. ''These children may be New York City's best-kept secret,'' said Dr. Stephen Nicholas, director of the Incarnation Children's Center in Manhattan.

title: MUSIC: The Good, the Bad, the Rare: '98 Boxed Sets; VARIOUS ARTISTS: 'THE ATLANTIC NEW ORLEANS JAZZ SESSIONS'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBELLE, ANTONINA ''MAMA'' (NEE MIRLES)
description: LOBELLE - Antonina ''Mama'' (nee Mirles) of Lodi, NJ, on December 11, 1998. Beloved wife of Francisco. Devoted mother of Carlos Jimenez and wife Beverly, Frank, Joseph and Bertha ''Bert.'' Dear sister of Aurora and Rosaura Mirles. Grandmother of Christopher Jimenez. Funeral Monday, 10 AM, at the Aloia Funeral Home, Garfield, NJ, followed by a 11 AM Mass at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Lodi. Interment St. Mary Cemetery, Saddle Brook. Visiting Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family will accept memorial gifts for National Kidney Foundation, 1250 Broadway, Suite 2001, NYC 10001.

title: Word for Word/Lucky Luciano; How to Get Ahead by Busting Heads, Breaking Fingers and Dressing Neatly
description: LIKE a grand piano-sized floral arrangement at a mob funeral, historical respect has finally been laid before the memory of Charles (Lucky) Luciana, who changed his surname to Luciano as a rising young mafioso because he somehow thought it was easier to spell. Last week, Time magazine included the ur-Godfather, who consolidated the blood-feuding gangsters of the Prohibition era into a centrally supervised criminal syndicate that became known as the Mafia, on its list of the 100 ''most influential business geniuses of the century.''

title: Commodity Deflation And Trade Angst
description: When the Labor Department reported on Friday that wholesale prices fell in November, much of the reason could be found in a continuing slump in commodity prices, especially for energy. Two widely followed commodity indexes, compiled by Goldman, Sachs and by the Commodity Research Bureau, hit their lowest levels in decades. Other than precious metals, which were already deeply depressed when 1998 began, every major commodity sector is off at least 16 percent for the year so far. Crude oil slipped below $11 a barrel, with no end to the decline in sight even though OPEC countries agreed to extend production curbs that were due to expire.

title: The Big Career Overshadowing The Right Career
description: OPERA singers keep showing up in the wrong places. Sometimes they are good singers: Cecilia Bartoli, appearing as Susanna in the Metropolitan Opera's ''Marriage of Figaro''; Renee Fleming, very nearly appearing in the Met's ''Traviata,'' and Patricia Racette, who did appear there. Sometimes they are not good enough: Marcelo Alvarez, for example, opposite Ms. Racette, as Alfredo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ESTHER
description: COHEN-Esther. On December 10, 1998, at the age of 94. Esther came to this country from Poland alone as a young girl. The center of her life was her family and the state of Israel. She was the beloved wife of the late Morris Cohen; the devoted mother of Renee and Ralph Blumenthal and Herb and Ellen Cohen; the adoring grandmother of David and Karen Blumenthal, Robert and Helene Blumenthal, Meryl and Jim Orlando, Sharon and Bill Levin, Steven and Lisa Cohen and Rich Cohen; the proud great-grandmother of Michael, Jill, Seth, Lindsay, Ryan, Jessica, Danny, Matt, Madeline, David, Ethan and Emma. An avid Zionist, Esther worked tirelessly for the state of Israel, continuously raising money for Hadassah, The United Jewish Appeal and B'nai B'rith. She was honored by the state of Israel for her years of continuous service. Her tremendous spirit, fierce pride, devotion to her family and her kliskels will be missed by her family and friends. Services will be held Sunday, 10 AM, at Weinstein West End Funeral Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn. Contributions in Esther's memory may be made to Hadassah.

title: Patriots Yes, Stadium Maybe Not
description: ESPN's satellite dishes line one of the main roads like a dealership for pre-owned flying saucers, but here in the armchair-quarterback capital of America, residents are as leery as the rest of their Connecticut neighbors about the state's plan to build a stadium for the New England Patriots.

title: Apparent Bias Crimes Lead to Man's Arrest
description: One man was arrested and another was being sought in what appeared to be two bias crimes Friday night, the police said.

title: Environmental Suit
description: Federated Conservationists of Westchester County, a 30-year-old environmental group, has filed suit against the county, the town of Mount Pleasant and New York State for allowing a parking lot at a train station to be built on what they contend is county property that had been parkland. J. Henry Neale, a lawyer for the environmental group and one of nine appointed members of the county's Parks, Recreation and Conservation Board, said Federated Conservationists wants the parking lot turned back to woods or, if that is not possible, it wants Mount Pleasant to give the county comparable land for its parks system.

title: Nicotine at Night
description: In a city where smokers are corralled into corners like diseased ponies, Circa Tabac is an unabashed stronghold of tobaccophiles. A cigarette lounge that opened recently on 32 Watts Street (Thompson Street), it is geared to ''discerning cigarette smokers and European tourists,'' said Lee Ringelheim, an owner. It allows patrons to eat, drink and smoke in a setting that's not like a bar. With beige walls and lace curtains, it feels like a neighbor's living room or a tea parlor, but the Parisian rolling-paper posters, the 100 or more brands of cigarettes for sale and the display case of holders and lighters all whisper, ''Light up.'' A photocatalytic converter neutralizes the smoke, infuses a heady mix of fresh air and keeps the place from smelling like a smoky high school bathroom.

title: In the Middle of Wrapping Season, Here Comes Christo
description: THE SETTING -- Rizzoli bookstore on West 57th Street on Thursday, when Christo, famous for wrapping the Reichstag in blue, and tropical islands in fuschia, signed copies of ''The Umbrellas, Japan-USA 1984-1991.'' The lavish book, with a lavish price ($750), documents the project he and his wife, Jeanne-Claude, created with large blue umbrellas in Japan and, simultaneously, yellow ones in California. But some admirers wondered about Christo's on-again, off-again plan to put thousands of gates in Central Park. Apparently, it's on again.

title: A Tangled Case, for a Barge and Basketball City
description: It's a good thing that Pier 63 Maritime, at West 24th Street and the Hudson River, is actually a floating barge, because it may well have to float somewhere else soon.

title: On Amtrak, Full Speed Ahead
description: AMTRAK is pleased with itself this fall. It considered Thanksgiving week, usually its heaviest travel period of the year, a success, apparently with a record rider total -- the figures were still being added last week. And on the Monday after the holiday weekend, it dedicated two more of its fancy new trains in the Pacific Northwest.

title: Guide for the Perplexed
description: I was going rafting in India and needed clothing and gear right away. So off I went, as so many outward-bounding pilgrims of Manhattan do, to Paragon Sporting, downtown's high temple of trekking consumerism. In no time at all, I found a sleeping bag by Mountain Hardwear that weighed only three pounds and was as cute as a Teletubby when shoved into its little stuff-sack. It was the perfect sleeping bag, the Platonic ideal, the Form itself, of what I had envisioned for my trip to the foothills of the Himalayas. And if, in addition to its weight and size, this particular sleeping bag featured ''contoured hood, tuck stitching, double zipper snag guards and slant baffle construction,'' among other countless offerings, I didn't have to know about it. It was light. It was small. It was on sale. Good. End of story, and thank you, Paragon.

description: Leaders of the 15 European Union countries today put off until next year decisions on changing budget and decision-making procedures to prepare for the admission of formerly Communist nations.

title: Many Brake Lights On the Economic Road
description: Signs abound that both the American and the global economies are slowing.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about margin maintenance rules for Internet stocks, citing the example of a purchase with money borrowed from the broker -- that is, on margin -- misstated the value of equity held by an investor. If the investor bought a $100 share of stock on 50 percent margin and the stock price fell to $70, the investor's equity would be $20, not $35.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, BESS.
description: FOX-Bess. Almost 90. On November 24th, 1998. She would smile at everyone she passed on the street to say hello. We say good-bye for her. Donations may be made to The Brooklyn Botanic Gardens. 1000 Washington Ave., Brooklyn, New York 11225. Jack, Joel, Judy, Nancy, Jeffrey

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with a review of the exhibition ''Made in America'' at Hopkins House in Haddon Township misstated the name of an artwork by Ruth Borgenicht. It is ''Basket of Bulbs,'' not ''Baby Bulb.''

title: Lawton Chiles, Populist Florida Governor, Is Dead at 68
description: Gov. Lawton Chiles, a homespun centrist politician from the middle of Florida who served three terms as a Democratic Senator and was elected to two terms as governor, died yesterday at the Governor's Mansion in Tallahassee. He was 68.

title: Rail Plan Splits Scenic Montana Area
description: In the 1970's, a rush for coal shattered the quiet of eastern Montana. As giant shovels gouged the rolling grasslands in search of the mineral, ranch families and communities were torn as well, bitterly at odds over whether to accept the windfall from coal companies and give up parts of their ranches, or to join environmentalists and fight the assault on their way of life.

title: Gore Has Been Grazing In Bradley's Backyard
description: For most presidential contenders, this is a time to be touring dairy farms in Iowa or sipping hot cider in New Hampshire, the states that stand like sentries at the gateway to the 2000 primary season. Fail here, their inscriptions might read, and you will never reach the White House.

title: Sorority Sisters
description: Both Julia Margaret Cameron and her art deserved better than the testy assessment offered by Deborah Solomon (Culture Zone, Nov. 22). Cameron, a Victorian woman who loved photography, produced some of the most beautiful portraits in the history of this art form. Indeed, ''Victorian'' is the operative term here, and Cameron's attitudes toward the roles men and women played in her time should not be brought up for political chastisement in 1998, especially when it is suggested that she lionized her male sitters and then just dragged her maids before the camera for ''swooning melodramatic things involving flowers.'' In patriarchal Victorian England, I wonder just how many ''famous'' women were available to be identified, let alone photographed.

title: Bronx Teacher Is Suspended After Taking Bibles to P.S. 5
description: A Bronx elementary school teacher has been suspended on charges that he distributed religious books and promoted Christianity in his classroom. The teacher, Simpson Gray, says he is being unfairly singled out for his beliefs.

description: Serious fans of Asian cooking, including chefs in training, may be interested in two small-group cuisine tours next year, one to India and one to Vietnam and Hong Kong.

title: Downtown Birmingham Offices Become Apartments
description: IN 1986, when the Birmingham Historical Society offered tours of the first loft apartments carved out of a couple of low-rise former retail/warehouse buildings, large numbers of curious people turned out to see what a new concept for this old industrial city -- downtown living -- would be like.

title: Village's Landmark Dreams

So the board of this 685-unit co-op, situated on some 37 acres of rolling parkland where Main Street meets the Grand Central Parkway, has asked the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission to designate it as such.

title: Color Their World
description: Children need to learn, and they need to play. While school districts have built educational facilities for children with disabilities, those children also need playgrounds. The Cape May County Special Services School district needs to replace its old playground, on its campus in Cape May Court House, with one up to code for children using wheelchairs, crutches and walkers. There is no money for it in the district's budget, though, so the district is appealing to public generosity for the $40,000 it will cost. There have been various fund-raising activities, but the chief draw is a coloring book created by some of the children the playground will serve, pupils at the George E. Bailey Middle School. The theme of the book, titled ''Children of All Kinds,'' is that whatever their differences, all children need love. The book, ($4.95) is sold at stores in the area and by telephone at (609)465-2724, extension 777. Donations so far have come to about $20,000; organizers hope to have the playground up by September.

title: In Mexico, Rival Parties Pass Accord On Bank Aid

title: MUSIC: The Good, the Bad, the Rare: '98 Boxed Sets; BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN: 'TRACKS'

For many musicians, a boxed set is still mainly a summation of past releases with a few rarities thrown in. Some releases take the large storage capacity of CD's as reason to forget selectivity, boxing whole catalogues of recordings in giant sets. Recording companies have also taken heart from the big sales of ''The Beatles Anthology'' series of unearthed recordings. An increasing number of boxed sets present material that used to be the province of bootleggers: live shows, alternative takes and unreleased songs, as if recording companies are rushing to release everything they own before the millennium.

He may be the heartbeat of the Rangers, as his coach has said, but Harvey needs to skip a couple of beats for his gratuitous attempt to beat up Vaclav Varada of the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, BRIAN GERARD
description: HART-Brian Gerard. Age 42. Born March 28, 1956. Died December 12, 1998. Graduated from Brandeis University, 1979, BA in Russian Studies. Buffalo Law School, 1986. He wrote for the Law Journal. Brian was an attorney at the New York law firms of White & Case, Simpson & Thatcher and Chadbourne & Park, a bright and varied career. Brian studied in the Soviet Union, worked at the American Embassy in Moscow, and as an attorney he advised on environmental issues in Tajikistan under a Fulbright Fellowship. An avid and lifelong runner, Brian completed three marathons, including both the Boston and New York Marathons while in remission from leukemia. Brian loved hiking in the White Mountains. There was no question on geography and World War II he couldn't answer. A devoted father of two beautiful children, Robert, 8, and Julia, 6, Brian never failed to provide love and laughter with his playful antics. Fiercely devoted to Karen, his one true passion for 20 years, lover, wife and best friend forever. Brian was a devoted son to Eddie and Virginia Hart of Ashland, MA, and a devoted brother to Eddie, Candy, Scott, Dennis and Chris. Shiva will be at the home of Karen Hart at 91 Central Park West, Apartment 9C, Sunday, December 13, from 12 to 6, and Monday, December 14, from 12 to 8. Donations can be made to the Save the Children Foundation.

title: Through Prague to Lhasa
description: A man returns to his childhood home in Prague after many years and nervously climbs the stairs to his father's empty study. On the desk he finds a mysterious red-lacquered box, which was off limits to him as a child. He unlocks it with a rusted key, and finds inside ''pages and pages of fragile paper covered with faded handwriting and fine drawings and maps blending into the text, all of it barely holding together, like brittle autumn leaves.'' It's a diary kept by his father when he was lost in Tibet in the 1950's -- and ground zero for all the magical stories that later captivated his son. That is the swift and surefooted set-up for the enchanting TIBET: Through the Red Box (Frances Foster/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25) by Peter Sis, best known as a writer and illustrator of children's books. His father, a documentary filmmaker drafted by the Czechoslovak Army and sent to China to teach and make movies, was stranded in Tibet during the construction of a highway across the Himalayas. His diary, embellished with factual notes in the margins, is interwined with Sis' own recollections of his father's encounters with nomads, yetis, lamas who fly like kites -- and with a magical blue lake where the fish have human faces. His wanderings culminate in a visit to the Forbidden City of Lhasa, where he tries to warn the Dalai Lama of the threat posed by the coming highway: ''It might well bring hospitals, electricity and technology, but little roads will then go to the lake, to the Valley of the Yetis, to the caves and monasteries. What will it take away? It might take more than it brings.'' All this is accompanied by exquisite illustrations of his father's adventures, finely detailed mandalas and dreamlike images that provide a rich counterpoint to the simple, direct text. Younger readers will be transported by the folk tales and the artwork, but this is more than a ripping yarn: with its mystical underpinnings and the muted sadness that washes over the whole enterprise, it is a personal account of a son still struggling to understand the absence of his father, and poetic testimony to the power of the imagination to transfigure reality. Scott Veale

title: An 'Electra' Powerfully Current
description: THEATERGOERS who admired Diana Rigg's grand, actressy, haute-couture appearance in the Euripides ''Medea,'' which came to Broadway from London in 1994, are in for a shock when they see the ''Electra'' now at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. This production also has its quota of high-fashion, post-modern effects, but neither these, nor the occasional tin-eared line, can get in the way of the primal intensity of the Sophocles text. Played without an intermission, ''Electra'' runs only a little more than 90 minutes, while leaping the centuries with the speed of light-years.

title: MUSIC: The Good, the Bad, the Rare: '98 Boxed Sets; 'THE COMPLETE BLUE NOTE BLUE MITCHELL SESSIONS (1963-67)'
description: WITH every year's crop of boxed sets, musicians and recording companies go deeper into their archives, hoping to tempt collectors as well as gift- givers. For many musicians, a boxed set is still mainly a summation of past releases with a few rarities thrown in. Some releases take the large storage capacity of CD's as reason to forget selectivity, boxing whole catalogues of recordings in giant sets. Recording companies have also taken heart from the big sales of ''The Beatles Anthology'' series of unearthed recordings. An increasing number of boxed sets present material that used to be the province of bootleggers: live shows, alternative takes and unreleased songs, as if recording companies are rushing to release everything they own before the millennium.

title: Cairo
description: Now that summer's heat is a distant memory, Cairo presents a kinder face, with mild, dry winter weather that encourages exploration. And this year, the Western holidays coincide with Ramadan, the Islamic holy month of daytime fasting. The fast is meant to teach appreciation for human suffering, but at night, the holiday has a distinctly festive air.

title: Muse, Interrupted
description: I remember the sadness I felt in 1956 when I picked up Stars and Stripes and read that Tanaquil Le Clercq had contracted polio in Denmark during the New York City Ballet's European tour (Holly Brubach, Nov. 22). I had seen the company only a few weeks before in Stuttgart, where Le Clercq danced ''Afternoon of a Faun.'' The audience did not breathe during her performance, stirred slightly in their seats at its conclusion and then rose clapping and cheering in an ovation that lasted a long, long time. She deserved every minute of it.

title: Where Iron Gives Way to Beauty and Games

The curse that reduced New York's landscape architects to creating Disney versions of Central Park has been at least temporarily lifted. At last, a designer and his client have waked up and recognized that people expect cities to address a fundamental question. What time is this place?

title: The Fresh Prince

Who wouldn't go a little crazy living such a peculiar life? Despite his doubts, he makes the best of his circumstances, and he actually performs his ill-defined ''job'' exceptionally well; the irony here is that exactly the same could have been said of his late ex-wife, Diana. Perhaps they had more in common than we thought. Were it not for the Prince's enduring love for Camilla Parker Bowles, King Charles and Queen Diana could have made quite a formidable team for the 21st century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIDER, ALFRED L.
description: KLEIDER-Alfred L., 71, physicist died November 29, 1998. He was among the earliest developers of laser technology. He had, and was involved with numerous patents including CCD Tubes (Charge Coupled Devices, the heart of early video cameras) night vision scopes and a wire detection system for low flying helicopers to avoid power lines. Alfred was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1927 and was the grandson of labor leader Lena Fried. He served in the Navy in the Pacific during WW II, and attended the University of Oklahoma, Norman, receiving a MS degree in Engineering Physics. His work in industry inlcuded positions with Hughes, Honeywell & RCA. He then worked in elctro-optics and lasers at Fort Monmouth, NJ from 1972-1991. An avid downhill skier and notorious punster he especially enjoyed travel. Alfred and his dear wife Sonya traversed the U.S. often, hiking, camping, sightseeing and they toured extensively in Europe and the Near East. He took great pleasure in photographing their travels and showing Sonya, Israel. Recently he taught computer skills to senior citizens at Senior Net in Ewing, NJ. Alfred is survived by his wife Sonya, sons Barry and Leonard, and grandson Jeremy, stepchildren Myron Moss and Aleta McClelland and stepgrandchildren Daniel and Kian.

title: Lessons in Peace From the Horrors Of Baroque Battles
description: FOR more than 250 years, until the carnage of our own century, the Thirty Years War of 1618-1648 set the standard in Europe for bloodshed, fanaticism and brutality. Confusing in its chronology and appalling in its deliberate assaults on civilian life, the war fully deserved its reputation as one of the darkest episodes in Western history. Starting primarily as a bitter religious struggle, it gradually became a naked clash for power among increasingly aggressive states of Europe and ravaged much of modern-day Germany. For one distinguished historian, Veronica Wedgwood, writing in the appeasement-stricken England of the 1930's, this ''futile'' struggle was ''the outstanding example in European history of meaningless conflict.''

title: Let Your Fingers Do the Clubbing
description: ''Thank you for calling Clubfone,'' a recorded voice booms. ''For dance, press 1. For comedy, press 2. For live music, jazz, blues, cabaret and piano bars press 3. . . .'' Inspired by the success of Movie Phone, Wendy Freid, 32, formerly a marketing director at a computer company, started 777-CLUB last month. The 24-hour night-life phone line, a k a (212) 777-2582, provides information about 200 places in Manhattan that pay for the listings. They change periodically and vary from ''new openings and cool happenings'' to sports bars and breweries. After making a selection, callers can press 9 for more information: addresses, telephone numbers, attire, cover charges and details on the kind of crowd to be expected on a given night.

title: A Magnificent Forest Deal
description: What is perhaps most exhilarating about the $76 million agreement to save about 300,000 acres of forests and wetlands in New York, Vermont and New Hampshire is the quality of the land itself. Almost a third of the vast acreage to be sold by Champion International would become a vital preserve, protecting wildlife and watersheds, as well as areas of surpassing natural beauty. These lands feature 13 mountain peaks in New Hampshire, sensitive wetlands and river frontage in northeastern Vermont and 29,000 acres within New York's Adirondacks that include one of the most majestic boreal forests in the country. These woods also serve as habitat to dozens of creatures from the showshoe hare to the amazing carnivorous sundew plant that dines on some of the northern forest's most irritating insects.

He handled his illness with great dignity. He loved us and we loved him. We know he will be missed by all whose lives he touched. A friend's elderly father was dying and both family and doctor had agreed not to tell him. Troubled, Dr. Komp went to her grandmother to seek advice. She recalls her grandmother saying, ''If it were me that's not what I would want. I would not want anyone to lie to me.''

It is the part of Atlanta where, 10 to 15 years ago, a new breed of restaurants with younger chefs began challenging more venerable Continental places like Pano and Paul's and Nikolai's Roof.

title: Williams Rewarded for Sticking Around and Runs Away With the Heisman

title: Place: And the Walls Came Tumbling Down
description: From downtown Pittsburgh, the new building across the river, encircled in the early morning mist, looks magical. Built in the shape of a wave, it snakes along the Allegheny, mimicking its form, but made of aluminum and startlingly clear glass. The two bridges leading to the building look like bookends, their supports cut from the same sandstone as the base of the building, which seems to grow out of the banks of the river.

The show may or may not be listed as ''A Christmas Carol: the Musical,'' as in the Theater at Madison Square Garden spectacle in New York, starring Roger Daltry, but always, there is music -- by classical, Broadway or pop composers.

title: Homage: Balthus Rocks
description: With just a year to go before the end of the decade, it seemed a safe-enough time for the experts on fashion photography to begin publishing books on the look of the 90's: images designed to evoke the joyless junkies in the photos of Nan Goldin and Larry Clark. They should have waited. In the sort of capitulation usually reserved for hemlines, cutting-edge fashion photography is suddenly overrun with images designed to recall famous paintings. Many of the same photographers who captured the red-rimmed rawness of heroin chic are now capturing the mood of some of the great works of art.

title: Crime
description: Harold Adams is not a flashy writer; but in his quiet way, he applies his spare, unruffled style to the creation of a modest kingdom of the imagination where the landscape has a comforting familiarity, where values seem certain and where characters come and go with the confident step of people who know they belong here. In NO BADGE, NO GUN (Walker, $22.95), as in earlier books in this offbeat series, the stranger in this land is Carl Wilcox, an itinerant sign painter and sometime sleuth who wanders across South Dakota during the Great Depression, settling in a town just long enough to get the lay of the land, spruce up the drugstore or dance hall and maybe solve a murder.

Some releases take the large storage capacity of CD's as reason to forget selectivity, boxing whole catalogues of recordings in giant sets. Recording companies have also taken heart from the big sales of ''The Beatles Anthology'' series of unearthed recordings. An increasing number of boxed sets present material that used to be the province of bootleggers: live shows, alternative takes and unreleased songs, as if recording companies are rushing to release everything they own before the millennium.

title: A Sunday Afternoon For Baroque Recitals
description: SOLOISTS from Yale Opera and the musicians of the Norwalk Symphony will gather at 3 o'clock this afternoon in the Norwalk Concert Hall for a performance of Gian-Carlo Menotti's opera ''Amahl and the Night Visitors.'' The orchestra and soloists -- Sean O'Donnell in the title role, Barbara Lemay as his mother, and Stephen Wilder, Thomas Dickinson and James Creswell as the Three Kings -- will be conducted by Jesse Levine.

title: O'Keeffe's House
description: To the Editor: We have just visited Georgia O'Keeffe's house at Abiquiu, N.M. We write because we find some of the comments in ''An Artist's Adobe'' (Nov. 8) likely to mislead visitors. First, groups of 20, such as ours, are not able to see the interior of the house. We were limited to gazing in the windows. Visitors might want to check on the rules for tours of the interior. Our guide, by the way, was also Monica Bittman, and she did well in her explanations.

title: Louis Delgado, 55, Playwright Who Overcame His Addiction
description: Louis A. Delgado Jr., a playwright who wove his experiences with drug addiction and his life on the street into his work, died on Dec. 1 at Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 55 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: December 6-12; Eight Clones From One Cow
description: Japanese scientists say they have cloned a cow with a success rate at least as good as obtained with test-tube fertilization. The researchers began by gathering cow cells from a slaughterhouse, picking up tissue from a cow that had just been killed. Using cells that clung to the cow's eggs and cells that lined its fallopian tubes, they created embryos that they put in surrogate mothers. The mothers gave birth to eight calves that were genetic replicas of the dead cow. Four calves died at or shortly after birth. The remaining identical quadruplets, the scientists say, are alive and well. GINA KOLATA

title: The Traffic Downtown Seems Worse Than Ever. Is the Verrazano the Villain?
description: IT'S another weekday afternoon rush hour in lower Manhattan, and Canal Street is gridlocked. Eastbound lanes are clogged with cars, trucks and buses headed for the Manhattan Bridge. Westbound lanes are choked with vehicles aiming for the Holland Tunnel. On northbound and southbound arteries -- Hudson and Varick Streets, the West Side Highway, even Broadway -- traffic has congealed into a horn-honking, sputtering mass. It's no better on the narrow side streets that lead to the tunnel, like Broome, Watts and Spring.

description: Big conglomerates with bold design ideas continue their steady march across the world, seeming more and more like an implacable cultural army fighting to ensure that everyone from Minsk to Caracas drinks the same soda, wears the same pocket T-shirt and buys the same minimalist lamp. title: THEATER; Murder and Bigotry in the South: The Story of a Lynching in 'Parade'
description: AROUND 7 A.M. on Aug. 17, 1915, the Cobb County Sheriff's Department in Marietta, Ga., received the news. ''Leo Frank's hanging to a limb down here near Frey's Gin,'' announced the caller. ''Retribution!'' After two years of appeals, the convicted murderer of 13-year-old Mary Phagan was dead.

title: Garden of Delights For a Happy Few; Las Alamandas, on Mexico's Pacific coast, is designed for seclusion
description: SOMETIMES, it's better not knowing places like Las Alamandas exist. My life was perfectly satisfactory before I discovered there was a remote beach resort halfway between Puerto Vallarta and Manzanillo where milelong stretches of Pacific coastline could be reserved for private dinners by candlelight; where smiling white-shirted butlers would quietly handle special requests for everything from fresh armadillo meat to imported Lucky Charms, and where a single night's stay could cost more than a month in a Manhattan apartment.

title: Leveling the Trading Field
description: For Mark Cuban, president of Broadcast.com, a soaring initial public offering on Nasdaq in July was more than just an opportunity to market his shares. He turned it into a chance to market his services -- namely, the broadcasting of audio and video on the Internet.

title: Education Officials Propose Diverting State Money From a Plan to Reduce Class Sizes
description: New York State education officials are proposing to drop the state's funding for the first year of an ambitious three-year plan to reduce the size of kindergarten through third-grade classes across the state, especially in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORT, HILDA
description: NORT-Hilda. On December 9, aged 89. Emigrated from England in 1932, lived happily in New York for over 60 years. Mourned by sister and family in U.K., friends in U.S., especially Kelly Waering and beloved dog Zeus. Thanks to staff of St. Vincent's Hospital for their help at this sad time. Memorial service at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison at 71st, Tuesday, December 15, 11 AM. Donations to American Red Cross.

title: Mirages

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL / Cadillac Escalade; 6 Degrees of Sport Utility Separation
description: PLACARDS in New York City subway cars used to advertise a paternity testing service. If you called DAD-SEARCH in a certain area code, the people there would help you determine who fathered your children. A valuable service, certainly, but could they trace the DNA of your car?

title: What We Look Up to Now
description: Forgive me, but I think you missed us in rural America. Status is being off the grid, plenty of clean water, enough acres (yours or the national forest's) so you can walk all day without seeing or hearing anyone, good horses for riding the back country, smart dogs that come when you call, air that puts perfume to shame, the sound of Canada geese going over the lake at dawn and a full pantry at the start of winter.

title: THEATER; A Sorry Chapter, A Source For Song
description: WHEN I called my mother to tell her I was doing a musical with the director Harold Prince, she was delighted. Then, a beat later, she said, ''Oh, God! It's Leo Frank, isn't it?'' In one form or another, that reaction has followed me right through several drafts, two directed readings and one extended workshop -- in short, the six years I have been working on ''Parade.''

title: The View From/New Rochelle; What the Wise Men Saw: A Star? Maybe
description: THE Star of Bethlehem, said to have guided the Three Wise Men to the birthplace of Jesus, may not have been a star at all. In fact, in all probability the bright object in the sky was actually three objects, a conjunction of the planets Mars, Jupiter and Saturn, Dr. Martin Steinbaum said. Dr. Steinbaum is an astronomer, professor of astronomy and science education at Iona College here, and the recently retired director of space science for the New Rochelle school system. He is also the author of ''The Star of Bethlehem,'' a planetarium show, which marks its 28th season this month.

title: Bonne Annee

The celebration takes place on the Champs-Elysees, which is closed to traffic up to the Arc de Triomphe and filled with revelers on New Year's Eve. A large digital clock counts down the minutes and, instead of ticker tape, the French mark the midnight hour by popping Champagne corks.

title: For a Child, a Forest Of Dangers at Home
description: LOSING a child is a fate so wrenching that the mere thought of it can tie a parent's stomach in knots. It can leave one tongue-tied too, given that there's no better word for it than the lawyerly predeceased. A spouse can be widowed, a child orphaned, but how can one convey the singular grief of the mother and father who must bury their young?

title: The Muse of Shakespeare Imagined as A Blonde
description: MANY things about William Shakespeare's life and work are shrouded in mystery, but the mystery of what scholars call his lost years is one of the most intriguing of all. What did Shakespeare do between 1585, when he is known to have left his home in Stratford-on-Avon, and 1592, when he re-emerged in London, described as an ''upstart crow'' in the account of a rival playwright? And how did he make the enormous artistic leap between his early plays, flawed works like the bloody ''Titus Andronicus,'' and his romantic masterpiece, ''Romeo and Juliet,'' first performed in 1594?

title: Do They Do Windows
description: LONG before there were Web pages and television commercials, there were retail window displays. ''Just Windowdressing?'' -- an exhibition at the Municipal Art Society -- shows there's more than meets the eye when it comes to these fixtures of New York street life. Some 100 images chronicling their evolution through the 20th century reveal how they have been used not only to sell, but also to make political and social commentary and to put artistic trends on display, Jane Stubbs, the curator, said.

title: A Defiant 90-Year-Old Who Belongs to Two Continents
description: ELLIOTT CARTER has never looked the part of a rugged individualist, nor has he played the part of the grand old man of American music, yet he certainly fits both descriptions. Having just turned 90, he is pleasantly plump, walks surprisingly quickly with a cane and dresses in Ivy League tweeds. He has the manner of a kindly great-grandfather, but he is feistier than ever, and the music he writes, with undiminished power, remains defiantly personal and uniquely trans-Atlantic.

title: Charging It, to the Tune Of $145 Million an Hour
description: Speaking of credit cards, the holiday season is when the plastic gets hot enough to melt. Americans will put an estimated $97.3 billion on credit cards, and an additional $13.2 billion on debit-check cards, between Thanksgiving and Christmas, according to Cardweb Inc., a research firm in Gettysburg, Pa. Those figures would be up sharply from the same 28-day period last year, when Cardweb estimated $88.2 billion in credit card spending and $8.8 billion in debit card spending.

title: A Fight for the Right to Relax in Houses on Stilts
description: It is not a mirage, which might be expected in this city of man-made islands and cruise ships that resemble floating metropolises. Brightly painted wood-frame houses sit on stilts in the middle of Biscayne Bay, as if a relic of old Florida were making a final, defiant stand just east of glassy, downtown Miami.

title: Ring Out Prohibition Before the Next One Gets Here
description: Circa Tabac, a new Art Deco bar at 32 Watts Street (near Thompson Street), has the look of an old New York hotel and the feel of the Prohibition era. But Brian Michels, a co-owner, promises that a password is not needed for entry.

title: Giving Away a Film's Ending: It's Not Happy
description: The camera focuses in tightly as Rob, finally free from drugs and jail and now staying at a friend's house, goes to a market in Newark's Ironbound and picks up a live chicken for dinner. It's his original, charmingly mischievous response to criticism that he is not contributing much to the household. Moments later, when the woman of the house peers inside the grocery bag he hands her, she utters exactly the kind of astonished shriek that pranksters aim for. Energized, the camera records the ludicrous moments that follow, as the chicken scrabbles around the kitchen floor and the woman shrinks against the sink.

title: More Women Are Running the Family Firm

Recording companies have also taken heart from the big sales of ''The Beatles Anthology'' series of unearthed recordings. An increasing number of boxed sets present material that used to be the province of bootleggers: live shows, alternative takes and unreleased songs, as if recording companies are rushing to release everything they own before the millennium.

title: The Science of Silicone Implants
description: A court-appointed panel of experts has concluded that existing scientific evidence does not show a link between silicone breast implants and systemic disease. Federal Judge Sam Pointer Jr., who is overseeing breast-implant lawsuits in the Federal courts, convened the panel to advise him on medical evidence surrounding implants. His approach was unusual in that he sought expert testimony independent of either side in the litigation. That strategy may also be useful in other complex cases where juries and judges are forced to choose between battling experts who may be biased.

The marathon retrospective took four hours to go from solo guitar fantasias to jokey, low-impact duets to a highly organized rock trio, and there was something extremely collegial -- maybe even domestic -- about the whole thing. The evening felt like a long visit to Mr. Lucas's apartment, while he stood on a chair and reviewed his accomplishments.

STB, based in Richardson, Tex., jumped $1.4063, to $7.1875. 3Dfx, which had third-quarter revenue of $33.3 million, manufactures the graphics accelerators that make computer games look realistic or three-dimensional.

description: Oneok Inc., a natural gas utility in Tulsa, Okla., said late yesterday that it would buy the Southwest Gas Corporation to expand in the Western United States. Oneok put the total price of the deal at $890 million in cash and $910 million of Southwest's debt. Oneok is paying $28.50 a share in cash, a 20 percent premium over Southwest's closing share price yesterday of $23.75. The combined company will serve 2.6 million customers in five states. Southwest, based in Las Vegas, Nev., supplies gas to 1.2 million customers in Arizona, Nevada and California. Oneok supplies gas to 1.4 million customers in Kansas and Oklahoma.

title: OPEN TEXT WITHDRAWS OFFER FOR PC DOCS GROUP

The stock deal was valued at $112 million when it was announced on Dec. 1. Open Text said a deal would enable it to gain more large customers for its line of software that manages corporate computer networks. PC Docs rejected the offer, citing ''one sided proposal terms.'' Open Text has acquired several software companies to broaden its line of products from Internet-searching software to programs that organize information on corporate networks, called Intranets.

description: MCCOMBS-A. Parks, M.D. Age 96 of Sarasota, FL. Passed away December 13, 1998. She was born March 2, 1902, in Charlotte, NC, and moved to the Sarasota area 23 years ago from NYC. She interned at Bellevue Hospital, then joined her Aunt, Dr. Connie Guion, in private practice in NYC. She was an Assistant Professor of Medicine at Cornell Medical College 1955-68. Director of the Medical Department of the N.Y. Infirmary from 1955-60, and Consultant in Medicine to the N.Y. Infirmary from 1960-76. She received her Bachelor of Science degree from Connecticut College in 1925, and her M.D. from Cornell University Medical College in 1929. She was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. Listed in ''Who's Who of American Women'' and active in many medical associations during her career. She is survived by several cousins, including Ann W. Haskell of Charlotte, North Carolina. Services and burial will take place in Charlotte, NC at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to a charity of the donor's choice. description: The Connecticut Legislature plans to vote today on a deal that would bring the New England Patriots to Hartford in 2001. The team comes with a considerable price tag. The state is promising to build a $375 million downtown stadium and a $15 million practice field, which the Patriots will occupy rent-free for 30 years. In addition, the taxpayers will subsidize the millionaire owner Robert Kraft up to $13 million a year if the Patriots fail to sell a certain number of luxury boxes and club seats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZWALD, MORRIS
description: SCHWARTZWALD - Morris. Of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY, and South Egremont, MA, died December 12, 1998. Beloved husband of Rita. Devoted father of Mark, Robert (Terese) and Kenneth. Loving grandfather of Amy, Alan and Michael. Dear brother of Joseph (Frankie) and good friend to many. A remarkable man who faced his death as he lived his life, with courage and dignity. Private graveside service.

title: Doctor in a Clown Suit Battles Ills of His Profession
description: Dressed in a clown costume of fiery red, orange and yellow, Patch Adams reflected one recent afternoon on the movie that is about to make him famous and on other topics, including the most terrible disease in the world.

description: To the Editor:

title: On Regulating Derivatives; Long-Term Capital Bailout Prompts Calls for Action
description: Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, called on some of Wall Street's leaders in the summer of 1994 with a warning.

title: Big Contributor to Democrats Receives 5 Years of Probation
description: Johnny Chung, a prolific donor to Democrats and a frequent visitor to the Clinton White House, was sentenced today to probation and community service for his involvement in illegal campaign contributions in the 1996 election.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the ''At the Movies'' column in Weekend on Friday about the new film ''Shakespeare in Love'' misstated the given name of one writer. He is Marc Norman, not Zack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITHLINE, DIANE
description: SMITHLINE-Diane in Sausalito, CA, December 13, 1998. Devoted and loving wife of Neil Smithline for 35 years and loving mother to her three boys Adam, Todd and Scott; loving mother-in-law to Nancy and special friend to Catherine; life-long friend and companion to her beloved mother Edna Barrabee Grace and her brother Kent Barrabee; cherished relative of her niece, nephews, cousins and other family; adoring mother to her beloved Chelsea and Cleo; a very special friend to many wonderful people; and family therapist, poet and chronicler of life. Friends are invited to attend a remembrance of her life and spirit at Temple Rodef Shalom at 170 North San Pedro Rd in San Rafael on December 16, 1998 at 10:00 A.M. Memorial donations to the Living/ Dying Project, P.O. Box 357 Fairfax, CA. 94978, where Diane volunteered for many years.

description: To the Editor:

title: Angolan Rebels Still Break Diamond Embargo, Rights Group Says
description: The sale of diamonds is still underwriting the war by Angolan rebels, and a United Nations embargo aimed at cutting off that income is not working, a report said today.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Rabbi Yosef Kazen, who established an Internet presence for the Lubavitch movement, misspelled the surname of his brother-in-law, the development director at the Lubavitch world headquarters, and omitted the director's title. He is Rabbi Moshe Kotlarsky, not Kotlarksi.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES SAYS PROFIT WILL TRAIL ESTIMATES
description: Republic Industries, the nation's largest automotive retailer, warned investors yesterday that fourth-quarter profits would fall 5 cents short of analysts' estimate of 27 cents a share because of weak car sales and delays in closing a number of acquisitions. Republic Industries' stock fell $1.3125 a share, to $13.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Separately, Republic Industries, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., announced that it would buy 31 auto dealers in five states for about $240 million. The company said it expected the dealerships -- which are based in California, Florida, Georgia, Illinois and Minnesota -- to contribute about $1.1 billion in revenue to its operations.

title: By Design; Diamond Days Are Here Again
description: Maybe it's the time of year. Maybe it's the time of the century. Whatever the reason, stores report that diamond jewelry is selling, from a few tiny stones on a chain to elaborate necklaces. So the entry of Robert Lee Morris into the fine jewelry field seems to be well timed.

title: Children and Violent Video Games: A Warning
description: It's almost Christmas. Do you know what your children are playing? Might they perhaps be ripping out the spines of their enemies, perpetrating massacres of marching bands and splatting their screens with sprays and spurts of pixelated blood?

title: Lawmakers Urge Making Patriots Give Up Right to Sell Proposed Stadium's Name
description: Legislative leaders' hopes for trouble-free passage of a stadium deal with the New England Patriots were set back today when several Democrats said they would fight for the state to retain the right to sell the stadium's name, which could be worth tens of millions of dollars.

title: SAN DIEGO GAS AGREES TO SELL POWER PLANT
description: The San Diego Gas and Electric Company, an electric utility owned by the Sempra Energy Company, agreed yesterday to sell a power plant to Dynegy Inc., based in Houston, and NRG Energy Inc., a subsidiary of the Northern States Power Company, based in Minneapolis, for $356 million as part of the deregulation in California's electricity market. Dynegy and NRG Energy are paying almost four times book value for the plant in Carlsbad, Calif., and some additional capacity. This is the third power-plant acquisition by the Dynegy-NRG Energy joint venture. San Diego Gas, California's third-largest electric utility, plans to focus on delivering power over its transmission lines.

title: Hillary Clinton Tiptoes Through Praise in Gaza
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has been hailed here as a champion of Palestinian statehood, walked a careful diplomatic line in public appearances today, praising Palestinian national aspirations while avoiding comments that could be considered a call for sovereignty.

title: In the Park With the Baby
description: To the Editor:

title: Graham Aims to Keep Starting Job
description: In the wake of Kent Graham's performance in the Giants' 20-16 upset of the Denver Broncos, Coach Jim Fassel acknowledged today that he might have a competition at quarterback between Graham and Danny Kanell when training camp opens next summer.

title: Movement After Polio, In a Program of Subtext
description: Sefa Jorques has clearly thought about the subtexts of the program she presented on Saturday night at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center. ''In stillness we can perceive how subtle movement can be,'' Ms. Jorques writes in a program note. The notes also include biographical material about Ms. Jorques's battle in infancy with polio, from which she has recovered. And she addressed near-stillness and deformity in her hourlong program of solos.

title: Sports of The Times; Giants Show Jets Super Is Possible
description: NEARLY three weeks ago, the day after the rookie wide receiver Randy Moss of the Minnesota Vikings had riddled the Cowboys with three touchdown receptions on Thanksgiving, Bill Parcells was holding his daily news briefing in Jetsworld when an impertinent question was asked.

title: Marriages Saved by Illusions
description: As fuel for the opera stage, hatred and power madness can be sufficiently volatile. But for variety and sheer efficiency, there is nothing like love, with its complexities, nuances and potential for conflict. In an inspired pairing that ended its run on Sunday afternoon, the Manhattan School of Music Opera Theater yoked together Holst's ''Savitri'' and Bernstein's ''Trouble in Tahiti,'' two one-act operas that approach the subject from virtually irreconcilable viewpoints.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPS, ERIC COREY, M.D.
description: RAPS-Eric Corey, M.D. The medical staff of Beth Israel Medical Center join with the Alan and Barbara Mirken Department of Neurology in acknowledging with sadness the death of Eric Corey Raps, M.D., brother of our colleague and friend Mitchell Raps, M.D. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the Raps families. Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President and CEO Susan Bressman, M.D., Chairman of Neurology Jerome S. Breslaw, M.D., President, Medical Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, FLORA
description: ROBERTS-Flora. Died December 12, 1998. Dramatic rights representative. Survived by her sister, Janet Sovin, her brother, David Roberts, five nieces and one nephew. Service on Thursday, December 17, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison and 81st Street.

title: QUINTILES TO PURCHASE RESEARCH CENTER FROM HOECHST
description: The Quintiles Transnational Corporation took steps yesterday to expand its clinical and preclinical drug development by announcing plans to buy a research facility in Kansas City, Mo., from Hoechst Marion Roussel Inc. for $93 million. Hoechst Marion Roussel, which will retain the majority of the buildings on the property, will transfer 540 employees to Quintiles and pay Quintiles $436 million over five years to support and complete current development projects. Quintiles, based in Durham, N.C., provides product development and marketing services for the pharmaceutical, biotechnology and medical device industries. Hoechst Marion Roussel, a subsidiary of Hoechst A.G., is based in Bridgewater, N.J.

title: Dell and Thompson Are Suing Each Other
description: A big computer marketer and its former agency are suing each other.

title: Pfizer to Raise Dividend
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that it would raise its quarterly dividend next year to 22 cents a share from 19 cents, its 32d consecutive annual dividend increase. Pfizer -- the maker of such strong-selling drugs as the impotence medicine Viagra, the high-blood-pressure drug Norvasc and the antidepressant Zoloft -- said the dividend would be payable March 11 to shareholders of record on Feb. 12. Shares of Pfizer fell $3.25 a share, to $111.625, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A. Leon Higginbotham Jr., Federal Judge, Is Dead at 70
description: A. Leon Higginbotham Jr., who called himself ''a survivor of segregation'' and became one of the country's most prominent African-American judges, died yesterday in Boston. He was 70 and died after a stroke for which he had been hospitalized on Saturday.

title: Looking Beyond Vote in Puerto Rico After 'None of the Above' Is Top Choice
description: Puerto Rico's pro-statehood Governor said today that he would continue pressing Congress to address what he termed Puerto Rico's ''colonial'' situation despite a referendum in which most voters seemed to indicate they did not want change.

title: Teaching vs. Preaching
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Settlement by AT&T In Pricing Inquiry
description: AT&T Corporation's cellular-phone arm has reached a settlement with New York stemming from an investigation into the company's advertising and disclosure practices, New York's Attorney General said.

title: Judge Frees a Palestinian Who Refused to Testify on Terrorism
description: A Palestinian man jailed for eight months after he refused to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating terrorism was ordered freed yesterday by a judge who concluded that further imprisonment would not change the man's mind.

title: A Pilgrimage to Madame Chiang Kai-shek's Estate
description: The auctioneer had planned a small open house here for special clients who had expressed an interest in buying some of the belongings of Madame Chiang Kai-shek.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWERIN, FREDERICK WOODBURY
description: SCHWERIN-Frederick Woodbury, 89, died at home on November 19, 1998, in Palm Beach, Florida. An avid swimmer, golfer and polo player, Freddy retired to his beloved stretch of ocean in Palm Beach after a 45 year career on Wall Street, most recently as senior partner of Schwerin Stone & Co., members of the NYSE. Survived by children, nephews, grandchildren and great-grandchildren who remember an elegant man with a ready smile, a patient ear and a true love of life and those around him.

title: Final Four's Next Move: Charlotte
description: After three years at Davidson and then four years at Richmond, the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's tournament's semifinals and final will be played the next two years at Ericsson Stadium in Charlotte, N.C., the home of the Carolina Panthers of the National Football League.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, STELLA K.
description: ABRAHAM-Stella K. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a great Jewish matriarch, who was venerated by her family and the Jewish communities of Long Beach, NY; Toronto; and Miami Beach and Palm Beach. Beloved mother of Judith Abraham (and Dr. Edward L.) Steinberg, S. Daniel (and Ewa) Abraham, and Jeremiah (and Geula) Abraham, Stella Abraham was revered for her deep involvement in religious life in Long Beach. The Stella K. Abraham Girls High School in Hewlett, an eminently successful Orthodox school, was named in her honor. She was a grand lady, gracious and charitable, who cherished her Orthodox heritage, which she imbued within the hearts and lives of her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. She took great pride in the achievements of her entire family, and delight in their leadership roles in the world Jewish community, especially at Yeshiva University, where S. Daniel Abraham-honorary trustee and honorary alumnus-and Dr. and Mrs. Edward L. Steinberg are Benefactors. They have been in the forefront of advancing higher education through the S. Daniel Abraham Israel Program and other visionary projects. May her memory serve as a source of enduring blessing to the entire Abraham family, and may they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: When Bars Say 'No' To Smoking
description: In the line of duty, bartenders are exposed to more than their share of other people's troubles -- and other people's cigarette smoke. But while customers continue to pour out their woes at neighborhood pubs, at least in California they aren't smoking while they do it. The state banned smoking in bars as of last Jan. 1.

title: After Tobacco Deal, Lawyers Seek Payoff
description: A few months ago, Patrick J. Coughlin, a San Diego lawyer involved in a lawsuit against R. J. Reynolds, was thinking of asking for a $50 million fee for his firm, in a case that the cigarette maker had settled for $10 million.

title: A Popular Spirit of Christmas Past
description: A long line of people snaked around the lobby of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Sunday hoping to get into the first of two performances that evening by Pomerium, the estimable Renaissance a cappella vocal ensemble, now in its 26th year. Both concerts were sold out, and it's not hard to understand why. Pomerium has won a loyal audience for stylistically informed and vocally lustrous performances under its founding director, Alexander Blachly. Moreover, the setting for this program of Renaissance music for the Christmas season was ideal: the 13-member group performed before the museum's celebrated Neapolitan Christmas tree in the lovely sculpture garden.

title: Long-Lost Bones Offer Clues to Earhart Enthusiasts
description: Sixty-one years after the plane of Amelia Earhart disappeared over the Pacific Ocean while she was seeking to fly around the world, people still clamor for hints about her fate and, once again, something has turned up to whet their appetites.

title: Point by Point, Committee Conclusions
description: Following are excerpts from talking points that the Republican staff of the Judiciary Committee gave to its 21 Republican members to help make their case as the House considers articles of impeachment. A copy was obtained by The New York Times. Headings were revised from the original.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about United Nations arms inspections in Iraq misspelled the name of a London-based Arab-language newspaper that interviewed Secretary General Kofi Annan. It is Asharq al-Aswat, not Ashraq al-Aswat. The article also included an incorrect rendering from the newspaper for a comment by Mr. Annan. In discussing the chief arms inspector, Richard Butler, Mr. Annan did not tell Asharq al-Aswat that Mr. Butler's diplomacy ''is seasonal.'' The newspaper said that it had erred in transcribing Mr. Annan's remarks and that he had called Mr. Butler's diplomacy ''seasoned.''

title: Seagram Plans To Shed Assets
description: The Seagram Company, which last week completed its $10 billion purchase of most of Polygram N.V., plans to sell as much as $1 billion in assets in the next two years as it focuses more on the entertainment business.

description: The figure of Jackson Pollock -- action painter, dancing dripper, sullen rebel -- was formed in Hans Namuth's camera. Namuth's camera helped make Pollock famous, Namuth's camera was blamed for Pollock's demise and, after Pollock died in a car crash in 1956, Namuth's camera tried to catch the artist in his coffin. (The funeral home didn't allow it.)

title: U.N. Chief Says U.S. Goes Too Far in Calling for Iraqi's Ouster
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan distanced himself from the Clinton Administration's policy on Iraq today, saying American calls for the overthrow of President Saddam Hussein went beyond a Security Council resolution on what is demanded of Iraq and ran contrary to the opinion of other United Nations members.

title: Samsung Electronics Is Raising Money Again
description: The Samsung Electronics Company of South Korea has turned to its shareholders for more cash for the third time this year, announcing yesterday that it would seek to raise as much as 520 billion won ($430 million). Samsung, like many Korean companies, is under Government pressure to reduce its debt-to-equity ratio to 200 percent by the end of next year or face a cutoff in loans from the Government.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''All autobiographies embellish to a greater or lesser extent.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGENTHAU, EMMY LOU
description: MORGENTHAU - Emmy Lou. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Emmy Lou Morgenthau, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of her passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to her life. May all who loved her be comforted. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Tagliabue & Co. to Debate Instant Replay
description: The proposed revival of instant replay for the National Football League playoffs this season will depend on a conference call to be held today by Commissioner Paul Tagliabue, his senior staff and the league's competition committee.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; For Goldman, A 4th Quarter To Forget
description: The old snapshots of Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin tell the story. In his days as rising star and then chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, Mr. Rubin was usually pictured cheek-by-jowl with traders on the crowded bond floor, in shirt-sleeves, a phone to his ear. The private partnership he helped build has long had a seat-of-the-pants management style that makes some Wall Street competitors seem timid.

title: Polls Aside, G.O.P. Stance on Impeachment Hardens
description: As the House vote on impeachment drew closer, the ranks of Republicans supporting President Clinton's impeachment grew today and in a more ominous sign for the White House, some of the few Republicans who have long been on the record against the impeachment drive began to waver.

title: Live, Nude And O.K. With City Hall
description: IT surely would have been, how to put it, invigorating to watch Nicole Kidman taking it all off in midtown on Sunday night. But even the blockaded City Hall is easier to get into than Ms. Kidman's newly opened Broadway show, ''The Blue Room.'' So the search for revealed truth led by default to another part of midtown, an establishment known as the Playpen.

title: THE NOVICE; Yoga That Mixes Sweat With Serenity
description: Two words come to mind when considering the practice of power yoga. The first, inevitably, is ''oxymoron.'' Yoga is commonly thought of as an activity designed to evoke a sense of serenity and what aficionados of the practice call mindfulness, a meditative focusing on the present moment.

title: Polls Find Most Americans Still Oppose Impeachment and Now Frown on the G.O.P.
description: The remarkable divide between the American public and House Republicans has not budged even after the House Judiciary Committee's votes last week recommending the impeachment of President Clinton. Overwhelmingly, people do not think Mr. Clinton should or will be impeached this week, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Saturday about a concert tribute to the legacy of the violinist Stephane Grappelli on Thursday at Carnegie Hall misspelled the given name of a violinist who was making his hall debut. He is Federico Britos, not Frederico.

title: A Tough but Responsible Solution
description: While no longer a member of Congress, as the Republican Presidential candidate in 1996 I do have more than a passing interest in the pending impeachment proceeding.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL UP SHARPLY. Crude oil futures leaped as officials from Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico raised hopes the nations would cut output further. In New York, oil for January delivery rose 50 cents, to $11.29 a barrel.

title: Some of the Old Language That Is Now Null and Void
description: When the Palestine National Council affirmed today that articles in the 1964 P.L.O charter calling for the destruction of Israel were null and void, it put a symbolic seal on a vote by the council on April 24, 1996, which supported ''canceling the articles that are contrary to the letters'' of mutual recognition between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization before the 1993 Oslo accord.
