title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEAVER, JOHN P.
description: CLEAVER-John P., 79, died on December 11, 1998 at home in Little Compton, R.I. following a brief illness. He leaves his wife of 52 years, Elizabeth (Ruth) Cleaver; three children, three grandchildren, a brother, William Cleaver and seven nieces and nephews. A Memorial service will be held at 12:00, January 9, 1999 at the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, Rhode Island. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Princeton-Blairstown Center, The Armory, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, or The Little Compton Agricultural Conservancy Trust, Town Hall, Little Compton, R.I. 02837. For information, The Potter Funeral Home, 81 Reed Road, Westport, Mass.

title: 2 Million Residents Are Asked to Save Water
description: With reservoir supplies for 2 million people in northeastern New Jersey about 26 percentage points below normal, the state's Environmental Protection Commissioner declared a drought warning yesterday and appealed for water conservation.

title: Made To Order For a Jazzy Clarinetist
description: When it comes to making new music a natural part of the concertgoing experience, few orchestras in the United States can match the record of the New York Youth Symphony, now in its 36th season, which presented a rewarding program on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CABOT OIL AND GAS CORP., Houston, an oil and gas exploration company, agreed to buy onshore southern Louisiana properties from Oryx Energy Co., Dallas, for about $72 million in cash.

title: Drug Ads Lure Patients Into Jargon-Strewn Territory
description: How many of these words do you understand? Hepatic microsomal enzyme induction, altered lacrimation, menorrhagia, hyperkinesia, hypoesthesia and angioneurotic edema. If your doctor prescribed a drug and warned you about such side effects, would you want to take it? Yet, these are among the scores of possible adverse reactions listed in tiny print in a many-thousand-word ''brief summary'' on the back side of a consumer magazine advertisement for a popular prescription drug. The front of the advertisement depicts an obviously pleased woman peering at a blue sky and suggests that you ''ask your doctor for a trial of once-a-day Claritin,'' a nonsedating antihistamine that can relieve the symptoms of seasonal nasal allergies.

title: Agency of Chinese City Misses a Debt Payment
description: The Guangzhou International Trust and Investment Corporation, a financial arm of the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou in Guangdong province, missed a $5 million payment on a letter of credit last week. Jason Chan, an official in the finance department of the corporation, said the corporation was struggling to find cash needed to repay foreign debts worth ''less than $100 million.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, CONSTANCE E.
description: JACOBSON-Constance E., on December 14, 1998. Devoted & loving wife, mother of three, grandmother of six. Was a school teacher in East School & a successful realtor in Long Beach. Always an inspiration to her children, grandchildren to follow their dreams and strive for success. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the American Cancer Society.

title: Woman Chosen to Head G.M.'s Saturn Division
description: Facing a shrinking small-car market and struggling to repair its once-legendary labor relations, General Motors' Saturn division appointed an expert on sport utility vehicles and factory management today to become chairwoman and president on Jan. 1.

title: Original Sin: Eden Sprouts Irreverence
description: Strange and many are the ways in which humankind addresses the mysterious forces that govern its time on earth. There's prayer, of course, and burnt offerings and fasting and animal sacrifice and snake handling. Then there are, to borrow a phrase from John Milton, the ''quips and cranks and wanton wiles'' that Paul Rudnick offers up in in his seriously silly theology treatise of a play, ''The Most Fabulous Story Ever Told,'' which opened last night at the New York Theater Workshop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBERG, HAROLD
description: STERNBERG-Harold, 89, died December 10th. He was the son of Ethel Sternberg & the great basso Cantor, Joseph Sternberg. He was born in Odessa, Russia, October 22, 1909 and came to America in 1927. He was first a Hebrew teacher, but soon worked on the Broadway stage performing in all of George Gershwin's shows. He was a favorite of Gershwin who dubbed him ''Chaliapin'' because of his magnificent basso voice. Later he joined his wife, singer/cantoress, Fraydele Oysher of the Yiddish stage, as her leading man. In 1937 he joined the Metropolitan Opera where he became Head of the Chorus and remained with the opera for 40 years. He was also a union leader and activist in the American Guild of Musical Artists. He was choir conductor for his brother-in-law, the renowned Cantor, Moishe Oysher. He is survived by his wife, Fraydele, his daughter, singer Marilyn Michaels Wilk, his son, Michael Sternberg and his grandchildren, Mark Wilk and Joanna Sternberg. Also survived by brothers, Cantors Ralph Sternberg, Solomon Sternberg and sisters Etta and Lotta Sternberg and Ida Rollin.

description: Grudgingly, but with a hint of admiration, Bill Parcells said today that his playoff-bound Jets were ready for Buffalo on Saturday, a game that could launch them to a division title.

description: Adding its voice to a movement that would link the year 2000 with a biblical concept of financial relief for the poor, the World Council of Churches called today for canceling the foreign debts of impoverished nations.

description: ROSE-Charles. The Eastern District Association marks with deep sadness the death of our respected colleague and dear friend Charles Rose. We will not forget his tireless pursuit of justice and love of life.

description: SNYDER-Joan P., 70, died Sunday at her residence in Guilderland, NY. Widow of Sidney Snyder. Survived by her three daughters, Elizabeth Walker of Marlboro, VT, Ann Buhr of Mill Neck, NY, Linda Barber of Altamonte, NY, granddaughters, Allison and Carolyn Barber. Memorial Service on Thursday at 11 A.M. at Marlboro Vermont Meetinghouse. Visiting at Ker, Westerlund Funeral Home, on Wednesday, 7-9 PM.

title: A Glib Man, Oddly Quiet
description: Since his days as an undergraduate, his oldest friends say, Bill Clinton has believed that he could talk his way out of almost any predicament. He has usually been right.

title: RJR Nabisco Plans Cuts in Both Tobacco and Food Units
description: Hurt by economic weakness abroad and the impact of the smoking-litigation settlement, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that it would close plants and cut 15.6 percent of its worldwide tobacco work force, as well as restructure and reduce jobs in its food business.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SIDE EFFECTS; For Skaters, Fresh Ice Can Mean Foul Air
description: A truck being driven around inside a large enclosed space a dozen times a day does not sound like a prescription for good air quality. But it is what happens daily at indoor ice rinks, often causing nitrogen dioxide levels to reach worrisome levels, a study of 19 public rinks in the Boston area has found.

title: When the Patient, Not the Doctor, Becomes the Hero
description: Admiring critics have made much of the fact that ''Wit,'' this season's hit off-Broadway play about terminal cancer and chemotherapy, is actually not very sad. Instead, they have used words like funny, tough and diamond-sharp. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOM, JOSEPH M.
description: THOM-Joseph M. Died December 14 in his home in Setauket, LI. Born in New York City October 22, 1919. Master's in Library Science from Columbia University and a Master's in Political Science from NYU, both on the G.I. Bill. Married his late wife Lillian R. Thom in 1945 after going AWOL at the Plaza Hotel before going overseas to serve in the Signal Corps with the rank of Sergeant. He and his wife moved to St. Louis where he was head of reference services at Washington University then to Ohio where he was Documents Librarian at the Atomic Energy Commission. With Lillian and his children, Janice and Eric, came to Setauket from Waverly, Ohio in 1960. He worked in the Port Jefferson schools as librarian at both the high school and junior high. His work in public education and TV was recognized by both the State Education Dept and WNET. In retirement he sailed, traveled with his partner Nancy Anderson, worked with the Democratic Party and catalogued the Yiddish collection at the JCC. He is survived by his children, Eric of Seattle, Janice of Queens, his loving companion, Nancy Anderson of East Northport, his brother-in-law Leonard Berkowitz and special family, Pat Meaney of Saratoga and Dan Steves of San Franciso. His beloved Fred the Cat will live with Nancy. He is loved by many and will be missed. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to NARAL, ACLU, NOW, Suffolk County Jewish Community Center of Commack or the American Cancer Society. Services will be held at O.B. Davis Funeral Home, Route 347, Port Jefferson Station on December 16 at 9 A.M.

Each of these mammals has a long, sticky, worm-like tongue, no teeth to speak of and scimitar claws. Each has bulging salivary glands, a stomach as rugged as a cement mixer and an absurd, extenuated, hairless snout that looks like a cross between a hot dog and a swizzle stick.

The company did not name the potential bidder. Enron owns 53.5 percent of Enron Oil and Gas, also based in Houston, which has a market value of about $2.3 billion. Enron shares fell 43.75 cents, to $53.4375. Shares of Enron Oil and Gas rose $2.625 each, to $15.50. Enron Oil and Gas explores for and produces natural gas and crude oil. description: THOM-Joseph M. Died December 14 in his home in Setauket, LI. Born in New York City October 22, 1919. Master's in Library Science from Columbia University and a Master's in Political Science from NYU, both on the G.I. Bill. Married his late wife Lillian R. Thom in 1945 after going AWOL at the Plaza Hotel before going overseas to serve in the Signal Corps with the rank of Sergeant. He and his wife moved to St. Louis where he was head of reference services at Washington University then to Ohio where he was Documents Librarian at the Atomic Energy Commission. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, STELLA K.
description: ABRAHAM-Stella K. On her 102nd birthday, Baruch Dayan Emet, the beloved wife of the late Dr Samuel Abraham and loving mother of Judy Steinberg, Daniel Abraham, Jerry Abraham and the late Roy Abraham. Cherished mother-inlaw, adored grandmother, great grandmother and elder sister. Grandma Stella was an extraordinary, unforgettable woman whose long and distinctive life was an ongoing inspiration to her family and a remarkable source of blessing to the Jewish people and the world. The radiant matriarch of our family, she was for us the very embodiment of the Eishet Chayil, a woman of valour who was blessed with uncommon goodness, unflagging strength, deep wisdom, a profound faith and trust in God and Ishah Chashuvah, a woman of dignity in every sense, possessed of both inner and outer beauty. An outstanding daughter of the Jewish people and of the Jewish faith, Grandma Stella's life was filled with Torah and Mitzvot, as she devoted herself to helping others, in particular inspiring the young women of the Stella K. Abraham High School for Girls, of whom she was so proud to walk in her footsteps and like her to strengthen Jewish life, both near and far. Her memory will live not just in the causes and institutions that bear her name, but in our hearts forever. Shiva is being observed at the Herring residence, 1495 Bay Boulevard, Atlantic Beach until Monday morning. Services at 7am (Sunday at 8am) and 4:15pm. In Toronto shiva will be observed at the Abraham home from Saturday night til Monday.

title: For Us Not Him; Vote No On Impeachment
description: Just about any citizen who follows the news could write the one-paragraph synopsis of what history will make of William Jefferson Clinton, a man blessed with great talent and afflicted with a mysterious passion for lying. But as the members of the House of Representatives gather in the Capitol, our thoughts must turn to the question of what history will make of this Congress's handling of its impeachment powers. That judgment will hang on whether the designated Speaker, Robert Livingston, produces a result that depends on something other than the fact that he can muster the votes to do what he chooses. Mr. Livingston and his political id, Tom DeLay, should know that only in the recording of battles does history applaud the unmitigated application of power. Was it one of those warm chocolate cakes with a runny center? No. Its main component was ginger, a delightful surprise. It was a warm fallen ginger souffle, with a heady fragrance and flavor. One bite of the tender, spice-infused cake, with a hint of molasses, made me think of an old-fashioned Christmas. The warm cake, topped with rum raisin ice cream and a squiggle of chocolate, was as evocative of the holiday season as a steaming pudding with hard sauce or a rich mince pie. With the recipe of Bill Lipscomb, City Grill's pastry chef, in hand, this ginger dessert can push fruitcake out of the picture. FLORENCE FABRICANT

Abraham, matriarch of the illustrious Abraham family, mother of our dear friend and benefactor, S. Daniel Abraham. Each generation is blessed with relatively few individuals with the vision, the passion, the selflessness and the means to have an effect on the larger community. Only a fraction of these succeed in actually effecting change. Stella of blessed memory has gone even further. As is evident from the daily lives of the people she and her husband raised, and the institutions they so generously support, Stella has dramatically and permanently transformed the entire Jewish community. Stella's passing on the festive days of Chanukah is a tribute to her kindling of pure oil during a wholesome lifetime which will all but miraculously ignite the hearts and souls of Jews throughout the world for generations to come. We express our deepest sympathy and heartfelt condolences. title: A Modernist 'Messiah' Calls on the Saints
description: Hearing Handel's ''Messiah'' at St. Thomas Church on Tuesday evening, sung with a combination of devotional serenity and fervor by a red-robed choir of men and boys arrayed before a vast wall of carved saints, a listener could easily mistake the work for an official part of the Episcopal Christmas liturgy. Its libretto, fashioned from biblical excerpts, begins with prophecy from Isaiah, traces the sweep of Jesus' life, and ends with doctrinal thoughts on redemption. And parts of the music -- the choruses ''Since by Man Came Death'' and ''Worthy Is the Lamb,'' for example -- show the degree to which Handel, transplanted to England from Germany, had absorbed the accents and cadences of the Anglican church music that Purcell wrote a generation earlier.

title: Take Broadway to the Center of the Universe
description: In the opening sequence of Nora Ephron's new film, ''You've Got Mail,'' a cyber-romance starring Meg Ryan and Tom Hanks, zoomy computer-generated images of spinning planets show Manhattan -- specifically the Upper West Side -- as the center of the universe. Designed by Milton Glaser, Walter Bernard and Mirko Ilic, the animation is a stylish, three-dimensional ode to Manhattan, which travels up Broadway between West 72d and 83d Streets, where Meg Ryan's character lives. Since Upper West Siders are quick to spot phoniness, the designers sent a photographer to shoot every single building on both sides of Broadway. Not every building made the final cut. ''We deleted some blocks that were boring,'' Mr. Ilic said. The result is a dreamy, autumn-hued abstraction of the city, which gets more lifelike as the sequence progresses. The colors were inspired by the 1932 painting ''Virgil and Dante in Union Square'' by Isabel Bishop. The designers sought verisimilitude, but their virtual Upper West Side improves on the real thing. ''We eliminated the people, the noise, the litter,'' Mr. Glaser said. ''It's probably a more benign and harmonious West Side than there will ever be.'' PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

title: Jakarta Aide, Seeing Unrest, Asks Slowing Of Reforms
description: A senior Indonesian Cabinet minister called today for a slowdown of democratic reforms, warning of widespread unrest unless the country's economic problems are solved first.

title: Art Deco in the Sand
description: When Todd Oldham, the fashion designer, was asked to draw plans for the interior of the Tiffany Hotel in the Art Deco Historic District of Miami Beach, he went to South Beach, half a block away, and with his bare feet in the sand figured out the palette. ''I saw the colors of the ocean, eight or nine shades of blues and greens, the colors of the cresting waves and the way light filters through the palm fronds,'' he said. The hotel, at 801 Collins Avenue, is now open, its 52 rooms brightened with air-brushed tile, pale ash desks inlaid with mosaics and pillows covered with woven ribbons. For an avocado-and-pomegranate velvet pouf that sits in the lobby, left, Mr. Oldham took colors from the hotel's original terrazzo floor. Blue water shading to green inspired the plates, inset, and for the center of the table, the designer celebrates ''the lowly daisy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, JOSEF CHAIM

He will never be forgotten. Shiva is being observed through Sunday at the home of Mona and David. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: U.S. Decision to Act Fast, and Then Search for Support, Angers Some Allies
description: President Clinton's decision to strike Iraq tonight without the customary round of consulting allies drew sharp criticism from Russia and France, the two countries most reluctant to use force against Saddam Hussein.

title: Thais Fail to Sell Many Loans, A Blow to Financial Recovery
description: Thailand's effort to raise money for its stalled economy by auctioning off billions of dollars in loans has fallen flat, and the authorities here acknowledged today that foreign investors were not ready to return.

title: The Potter in the Bowl
description: For the ceramist Bennett Bean, a rip in a pot was a happy accident. ''I was throwing bowls one day, and one of the lips tore, and it changed the whole way you proceed from outside to inside and back again,'' Mr. Bean, 57, said. His bowls, which are thrown on a wheel, burnished, cut and assembled, pit fired and then painted with gold leaf and fixed with polyurethane, cost $4,000 for a 1978 gourd-shape vessel to $20,000 for his new bowl (left). ''Bennett Bean: Terra Incognita,'' a show of 29 pots, is at Barry Friedman, 32 East 67th Street, through Jan. 30.

title: Critics Give 'Private Ryan' Their Top Award
description: War won out among the New York Film Critics Circle yesterday as that group chose Steven Spielberg's fiercely immediate World War II epic ''Saving Private Ryan'' as the best film of 1998. ''The Thin Red Line,'' the year's other, prettier and more contemplative World War II film, was another winner, for both John Toll's cinematography and for direction by Terrence Malick, the maverick 1970's filmmaker who had been AWOL for two decades. The split between these dueling battle dramas might have been the biggest surprise of this year's voting had the group not also -- to the astonishment of some of its 31 members -- chosen Cameron Diaz as best actress for her performance in ''There's Something About Mary.''

title: G.O.P. Splits Bitterly Over Timing of Assault
description: Republicans in Congress were bitterly divided tonight over the air strikes against Iraq, and the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, fiercely attacked President Clinton's policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, ROSE ZEIDEN
description: JACOBSON-Rose Zeiden. Of Louisville, KY. Died December 15. She was the widow of Abe Jacobson, beloved mother of Jay of Minneapolis, Kenny of Brewster, NY, Harry of Louisville, and sister of Sam Zeiden of Oceanside, CA; the best mother-in-law, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt and great-aunt on earth. Her total devotion to her community reflected her sense of gratitude rather than a quest for recognition. Memorial services at Herman Meyer Funeral Home in Louisville, Thursday, Dec. 17. Rose Jacobson would be delighted with memorial contributions to Green Chimneys Children's Services, Caller Box 719, Brewster, NY 10509.

title: Blunting the Hard Edge of Truth
description: At an October conference called ''The Claims of Memory,'' the novelist Cynthia Ozick is reported to have said, ''The aims of the imagination are not the aims of history.'' These words come to mind in the case of the Nobel peace laureate Rigoberta Menchu. A new book by the anthropologist David Stoll now refutes a number of claims in Ms. Menchu's widely celebrated memoir, ''I, Rigoberta Menchu,'' published in 1983. These include her assertions that the adversaries in her family's land disputes were wealthy landowners of European extraction, that she witnessed mass executions by burning, and that, as a young woman, she worked as a laborer and political organizer.

title: Corrections

title: U.S. Attack on Iraq Ripples Through World Financial Markets
description: The United States attack on Iraq late yesterday sent ripples through world financial markets and was expected to weigh on American stocks when markets opened today.

description: The money manager Donald Yacktman has said that a ''preliminary tally'' of votes cast by shareholders showed that an overwhelming majority support his effort to win control of the Yacktman Fund and Yacktman Focused Fund he manages.

description: CHRISTMAS is a crap shoot. People give each other gifts: a) they like them, b) they don't. What odds.

description: The Microsoft Corporation is finding itself increasingly isolated within the computer industry over its view of the natural relationship between Internet software and operating systems, testimony presented today in Federal court showed.

title: Clinton Could Not Count On All His Allies in Vote
description: If the House of Representatives votes to impeach President Clinton, as seems almost certain, three of the six Democratic Senators from the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut say they would probably vote to acquit him after a trial before the Senate next year. The other three would not say how they might vote.

title: A Community Center That Is Inviting To Its Young Guests
description: What do young people like? Basketball courts, computer laboratories, paints to paint with, a stage to perform on and a kitchen for lunch. These amenities, and more, will be incorporated into the Williamsburg Community Center, at 195 Graham Avenue in Brooklyn, next door to Thelma Martinez Park. ''The idea of the center is to be a magnet for youth,'' said David Burney, director of design for the New York City Housing Authority, which chose Pasanella & Klein Stolzman & Berg Architects, in Manhattan, to design the center. ''It can't look like a school or a fortress.'' It doesn't. Wayne Berg, a partner in the firm, said, ''It looks like a glass building, and the perforated-aluminum screen looks like a panel around it.'' The glass will allow light to pour into the steel-framed building; the screen will stop anyone from tossing a rock through the glass. The center, budgeted at $6 million, is scheduled to open in 2001.

title: CHITTENDEN SET TO ADD VERMONT FINANCIAL
description: The Chittenden Corporation plans to acquire the Vermont Financial Services Corporation in a $454 million stock swap transaction. Chittenden said yesterday that the merger agreement called for the exchange of 1.07 Chittenden common shares for each common share of Vermont Financial. Chittenden said it would issue about 14 million shares to pay for the nontaxable pooling of interests. Chittenden, based in Burlington, Vt., said the acquisition would increase its assets to $4.2 billion. Chittenden owns Vermont National Bank in Brattleboro, Vt., and United Bank of Greenfield, Mass.

title: Albany Closer to a Deal To Allow Charter Schools
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders in Albany reached the outlines of a compromise yesterday on an ambitious plan to establish scores of charter schools across the state with limited government and union regulation, officials close to the negotiations said last night.

title: Sinuous, Elegant, Playful Plastic
description: In 1949, when Giulio Castelli, a chemical engineer in Milan, founded his company, Kartell, plastic wasn't chic to have around the house. Today, Kartell opens its first American store at 45 Greene Street (near Broome Street), and among the high-style plastic furniture it will introduce is the Dolly folding chair, designed by Antonio Citterio with Glen Oliver Low. The chair, introduced to Europe last year, is made of glass-fiber-reinforced polypropylene and comes in all plastic ($210), with a wood seat ($227) or an upholstered seat ($252). Like many Kartell designs, it has a playful flexibility: it opens and closes, goes indoors or out, in a bedroom or home office.

title: Boise Cascade to Cut Jobs
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation, the fifth-largest United States papermaker, said on Tuesday that it planned to take a pretax charge of $40 million, or 42 cents a share after tax, in the fourth quarter to cut 400 jobs, or about 2 percent of its work force. The revamping will involve closing a research center in Portland, Ore., cutting 55 jobs. Other cuts will come from manufacturing and corporate staff. It expects the moves to save about $70 million, before tax, by the end of next year. It has been struggling with falling prices for uncoated white paper.

title: Sports of The Times; It's All About Cash, Not Color
description: THE players were angry. The labor dispute had gone on longer than anyone had believed possible, and some were taking it personally. There was a feeling among them that the owners, who were locking them out, did not necessarily have the highest opinion of their ability to hang together and that they were being dismissed as just a bunch of dumb jocks.

title: 56 Are Indicted in Thefts Of Kennedy Airport Cargo
description: Law enforcement officials yesterday shut down a major theft ring that they said stole millions of dollars in merchandise from warehouses around Kennedy International Airport, moving against a crime that officials say saddles customers with incalculable hidden costs on many everyday purchases.

title: Editorial Notebook; Have Yourself a Tacky Little Christmas
description: I know a house where Santa Claus was hung by his heels from a beam every Christmas. I know the house because my family lived in it. One December my brother stuck a stuffed Santa upside down overhead in the living room, just to get it out of the way, and because it happened once it became tradition and was made to happen again and again, until my parents moved to a house without a living-room beam.

title: Release the Back And Hop In
description: ''The sleeper sofa is usually an ugly sofa with an uncomfortable bed inside,'' said Massimo Iosa Ghini, an architect and furniture designer in Bologna, Italy. ''Single,'' as he calls his spare and simple design for Flou, an Italian bed manufacturer, is not. ''It's a bed equipped with a mobile back,'' Mr. Iosa Ghini explained. The steel-frame single bed has a handle under the seat to release the back and convert the sofa into a bed. Remove the fabric cover, turn back the duvet and hop in. The bed, introduced in Europe last year but new to the United States, sells for $3,326 to $3,784, depending on fabric. That does not include a mattress, which costs $650 to $1,200. The sofa is at DDC-Domus Design Collection, 215 East 58th Street. Allow 12 weeks for delivery.

title: Language Lessons, Object Lessons
description: THE last time I traveled to Mexico, I was armed with only a little English-to-Spanish phrase book to guide me through the streets of Merida. On a street corner, my husband announced that we had to find the city zoo because he had suddenly remembered from a previous visit that the exhibition of hairless dogs ''had a haunting quality.'' Thumbing through the book in search of words to ask for directions, the best I could find was a translation for ''Can you direct me to a dentist? My teeth are bleeding.''

title: South Korean Scientists Say They Cloned a Human Cell
description: South Korean scientists said today that they had cloned a human cell from an infertile woman, creating a four-cell embryo that theoretically could have grown into a genetically identical replica of the woman. But they said that because of the legal and ethical implications of their work, they stopped the experiment and did not try to create a human clone.

It's not always a matter of being vaguely polite (or not) to the adults who took you along.

description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc. agreed yesterday to sell about a 30 percent stake for $1 billion to an investor group led by the financiers Leon Black and Thomas Lee, giving it cash to help repay $1.7 billion of debt coming due. Patriot American, a Dallas-based real estate investment trust, a hotel company and owner of the Wyndham Hotel chain, said the group would make the investment through the purchase of convertible preferred stock. The group will be entitled to six of 15 seats on the board. Patriot's shares rose 68.75 cents each, to $7.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares have fallen 70 percent this year as the company struggled with its expansion, which included the purchase of seven hotel companies in the last year.

title: CONSOLIDATED CIGAR HOLDINGS GETS TAKEOVER BID
description: Consolidated Cigar Holdings Inc., the cigar company controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, received a takeover bid yesterday of $17.85 a share, a total of $531 million, from Seita S.A., the French tobacco maker. Consolidated Cigar's stock climbed $1.50 to close at $17.375. Mafco Consolidated Group Inc., a unit of MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., has agreed to put all of its 65 percent equity interest in Consolidated Cigar behind Seita's offer. Sieta will also assume $199 million in debt from Consolidated Cigar. Consolidated Cigar has 5,400 employees worldwide and operates eight plants.

title: Leading, Under A Cloud
description: If there was ever any doubt that lying can be an impeachable offense, it has been erased by the latest confrontation with Iraq.

title: Hand-Woven Pages
description: ''Woof'' (Harry N. Abrams, $18.95) is a spiral-bound book that is, in fact, a paper kaleidoscope. It's the creation of Madalyn Eastuf, an artist in Dallas, and is based on the warp and the woof of textiles. Each of the 32 pages, die cut and woven by hand, was inspired by a traditional fabric pattern, from Amish quilts and Navajo blankets to Fair Isle sweaters. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENNON, LAURA
description: LENNON-Laura. Left us on December 15, 1998. Beloved wife to Bernd Allen; loving sister of Esther Natter, Irving Natter, Elaine Yates and Seymour Yates; adoring mother to Marissa Allen, Brian Lichtenstein, and Floella Allen; incredulous grandmother to Jamie; and ''Auntie Mame'' to nephews and nieces Mitchell, Douglass, Betsy, Peter, Martha, Eric, Cynthia (Heather). An attorney and linchpin of the real estate community, she always strove to achieve the impossible. Her spirit and panache will be missed. Donations may be made in her name to the Fund for Blood and Cancer Research (Center for Lymphoma), P.O. Box 179, 525 East 68 Street, NYC 10021.

title: For Back-Seat Potatoes
description: GIVEN how screen-saturated our world has become, it shouldn't be a surprise that the family car now comes with a video monitor so that back-seat passengers don't have to rely on the passing landscape -- plain old reality -- for entertainment. The recent commercial for an Oldsmobile minivan, the first car with factory-installed video entertainment, was just an affirmation of the inevitable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUTZ, EDWARD O. ROBERT
description: LUTZ-Edward O. Robert M. Carr, William Herman and the present partners and staff of Lutz and Carr CPA's extend heartfelt condolences to Alice, Terry, Richard and William. Eddy Lutz was a founding partner of Lutz and Carr CPA's and will be remembered for his inspirational leadership, devotion to scholarship and dedication to the advancement of professional management in the American Theater. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Edward Lutz Fund, C/O Booklyn College, Fund #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNER, MARK WOOLMAN
description: HORNER-Mark Woolman. Died as a result of a homicide at his home in San Antonio, Texas, on Dec. 14, 1998. He was born in Bar Harbor, ME., Aug. 24, 1973. He was a graduate of the Juilliard School of Music and was Principal Trombonist of the San Antonio Symphony. A service under the care of the Acadia Friends Meeting will be held at 1:00 PM, Dec. 19, 1998, at Saviour's Episcopal Church, Bar Harbor, ME. Contributions may be made to the Mark Woolman Horner Music Scholarship Fund at the Bar Harbor Bank & Trust, P.O. Box 400, Bar Harbor, ME. 04609.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Around the U.S., Cynicism And a Showing of Support
description: If President Clinton was trying to divert attention from his personal problems by bombing Iraq on Wednesday, he succeeded.

title: Defense Secretary Returns to House to Defend President's Decision to Attack Iraq
description: With Congressional Republicans wary about today's raids on Iraq, the White House tonight dispatched the most prominent Republican in the Clinton Administration -- William S. Cohen, the Secretary of Defense -- to offer personal testament from the well of the House of Representatives to the integrity of the attack.

title: Sign of Success: 'Read it Again!'
description: They left out Peter Rabbit! In arguably the most stylish children's book of this season of books for the young, ''The 20th Century Children's Book Treasury,'' an anthology of ''celebrated picture books and stories to read aloud,'' there's no ''Tale of Peter Rabbit.'' Which is rather like not having a Faulkner novel on the list of the 20th century's best books in English.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GADDIS, WILLIAM
description: GADDIS-William. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of literature.

title: Camelot: The Realm On Line
description: KING ARTHUR, in legend the greatest king of Britain's Dark Ages, has had a lot heaped on his Round Table. However thinly supported by fact, his story is a wellspring of British pride, a medieval justification of the monarchy and an epic of Christian symbolism. It is also an inspiration for just about every video and computer pastime featuring swords and sorcery.

title: Minnesota Mining Expects Earnings Decline of 10%
description: Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, one of the nation's industrial and manufacturing giants, warned today that slumping global sales and a slowdown at home would probably cut fourth-quarter earnings 10 percent from the comparable quarter a year earlier.

title: Union Director Says He Won't Initiate Talks
description: A defiant Billy Hunter said he had no intention of calling David Stern to restart talks and predicted that there would not be a resolution to the National Basketball Association's labor dispute before Christmas.

title: Metro Business; Errors for Mobile Phones
description: Bell Atlantic Mobile phone customers in the New York region with voice mail service have been hit by a software bug that causes a false ''mail waiting'' message to be sent, the company said yesterday.

title: Software Users' Rights (Hah!)
description: BAD SOFTWARE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINBOTHAM, A. LEON, JR.
description: HIGGINBOTHAM-A. Leon, Jr. The partners, associates and staff of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison express profound sorrow at the passing of our Senior Counsel, Judge A. Leon Higginbotham, Jr., a great lawyer, wise jurist, dedicated public servant, admired colleague and beloved friend. Judge Higginbotham will long be remembered for his deep commitment to social causes, his wise counsel and his many accomplishments. His death is a profound loss to all who knew and loved him and to the nation at large. We extend our deepest sympathies and condolences to his wife, Evelyn, his sons, Stephen and Kenneth, his daughters, Nia and Karen, and all the other members of his family.

title: Defense Does the Trick
description: When the Islanders ended their seven-game losing streak with a 1-0 victory over the Sharks in San Jose Tuesday night, they did so by playing the prototypical road game: a low- risk, defense-first style.

title: 2 Officers Accused of Lying to Investigators in Louima Case
description: Two New York City police officers were charged yesterday with lying to Federal investigators about the conduct of another officer who has been accused of torturing a Haitian immigrant in a Brooklyn police station.

title: War and Impeachment
description: After hearing for months about Bill Clinton's ability to compartmentalize issues, the country and the world now have to match that difficult trick. By attacking Iraq as House members gathered in the capital to consider his impeachment, Mr. Clinton could not avoid the impression that he is blurring the boundaries that must separate America's foreign conduct from its domestic political turbulence. But that accusation would in large part be unfair. The confrontation with Iraq has played out on its own timetable and happened to reach a decisive point on the eve of the House impeachment debate.

title: Honoring Immigrants, and How They Lived
description: RUTH ABRAM'S life is the story of how personal hurts grew into a museum that no one ever imagined.

title: K-Tel Asset Plan Approved
description: K-Tel International Inc.'s board approved a plan today to issue equity to meet the $4 million tangible-assets requirement for listing on the Nasdaq stock market. As of Sept. 30, K-Tel, based in Calabasas, had net tangible assets of $450,000. K-Tel said it planned to raise about $15 million to $20 million of added equity to meet long-term capital requirements. K-Tel shares rose $1.1875 today, to $13.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITWIN, SHIRLEY GOLDRING
description: LITWIN-Shirley Goldring. Of Great Neck, NY. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel L. Litwin. Loving mother of Jane Zimmerman and Robert Litwin. Devoted mother-inlaw of Ronald Zimmerman and Carol Litwin. Adoring and adored nan of Deborah and Eric Ribner, Michael Zimmerman, Jody Litwin and Amy Litwin. Dearest sister of Lorraine Schneidman. Caring sister-in-law of Elmer, Milton and Sylvia Litwin. Services were held on Wednesday at ''Temple BethEl of Great Neck.'' In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to North Shore University Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACHMAN, DR. FREDERICK R.
description: LACHMAN-Dr. Frederick R. We mourn the passing of Dr. Frederick Lachman, noted Jewish scholar, author and historian, on December 15, 1998 at the age of 96 years. In deep sorrow, Lieselotte Lachman widow. The Board of Directors of ''Aufbau'', and The American Federation of Jews from Central Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SMITH, DAVID
description: SMITH-David. December 17, 1995. Dear Daddy, we all miss you. Love, Your Famil

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Seeking an Even Exchange; Small Firms Say Group That Oversees Nasdaq Favors Giants
description: Bigger is better. That seems to be the view of Frank G. Zarb, chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, the nation's largest self-regulatory organization and parent of the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Speed of Cloning Advances Surprises U.S. Ethics Panel
description: Just 18 months ago, a national ethics commission recommended to President Clinton that there be a three- to five-year moratorium on human cloning research. The members argued that nothing would be lost by such a ban, since it most likely would take at least that long to know whether cloning could succeed.

title: Can Dole Proposal Transcend Party?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Technophiles, Visions of Cyberplums
description: CIRCUITS asked several people by E-mail and telephone what electronic gadgets they would most like as gifts. Some of the respondents are very fond of new technology, while others are still devoted to quill pens, or, to be fair, typewriters. Here are their replies:

title: Economic Scene; In the health care business, size can ultimately benefit patients.
description: AETNA INC.'s proposed purchase of the health care business of the Prudential Insurance Company of America has touched off concern among doctors and consumers, but Aetna's large size could ultimately benefit patients.

title: Computers Now Helping to Screen for Troubled Teen-Agers
description: IN a school office cubicle, beneath walls plastered with hot-line lists, philosophical poems and a poster of a sunflower, two people sit on hard plastic chairs, a slight 14-year-old girl shyly pouring out her innermost demons to an earnest young man she's only just met.

title: Netanyahu Is Seeking Way to Soften a Fall
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu all but conceded that he expected his Government to fall on Monday and threatened to call new elections so he could avoid the humiliation of being evicted from office. He added that he would try one last time to get a majority of Parliament to stand behind his tough posture toward the Palestinians. His Cabinet said it would not hand over more West Bank land to the Palestinians on Friday, provoking an angry Arab response.

title: Japanese Trade Surplus Shrank in October
description: Japan's current account surplus was smaller than expected in October as recession caused Japanese companies to spend more on financial, insurance and other services provided by foreign companies.

title: Controlling Stake Is Sold In Top Noodle Maker
description: Salim Group, once Indonesia's largest business empire, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell control of the world's biggest noodle maker for $570 million in cash and stock.

title: Let Them Read Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy Ending House Arrest Of Rebel Chief Of the Kurds
description: An appeals court in Rome freed a Kurdish rebel leader from house arrest today, further inflaming a bitter diplomatic dispute between Italy and Turkey.

title: Quintiles to Buy Envoy for $1.7 Billion in Stock
description: In its third acquisition to be announced this week, the Quintiles Transnational Corporation, the nation's largest provider of clinical drug trials, said yesterday that it would buy the Envoy Corporation for $1.7 billion in stock.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS TO EXPAND ITS A.T.M. NETWORK
description: The American Express Company announced plans yesterday to expand its automatic teller machine network throughout the United States by acquiring A.T.M. networks from Zions Bancorp, Electronic Data Services and Americash for undisclosed terms. It said the transactions added 2,000 machines from E.D.S., as well as 140 Zions A.T.M.'s in seven Western states and 650 Americash A.T.M.'s in shopping malls and supermarkets. American Express, the New York-based financial and travel-services giant, said these purchases would let card holders gain access to cash and other services from more places. American Express said 13 million card holders had access through 200,000 A.T.M.'s worldwide.

title: People, People Who Need People
description: Everywhere Bill Parcells has been in the National Football League, every team that Parcells has coached, David Meggett has been there.

title: Toys That May Not Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: Luck, Be a Microchip Tonight
description: IT had been a routine Sunday at the Palace Station Hotel and Casino, a rambling Las Vegas institution more popular among the locals than among the millions of tourists who flock to the city's more extravagant hotel-and-casino resorts. But when a 67-year-old woman, a regular at the Palace, plunked the last three silver dollars of about 300 she played that evening into a rather ordinary-looking slot machine, what followed was anything but routine.

title: IMPEACHMENT VOTE IN HOUSE DELAYED AS CLINTON LAUNCHES IRAQ AIR STRIKE, CITING MILITARY NEED TO MOVE SWIFTLY
description: Furious and fractured, House Republicans tonight postponed the impeachment vote against President Clinton for perhaps a few days because of the bombing campaign against Iraq, even as the odds against the President began to look insurmountable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, DEBRA
description: HERMAN-Debra. Passed away on Dec. 15, 1998 in Las Vegas, NV. Beloved wife of the late Philip Herman. Mother of Marc Schorr and Ilene (Lark) Teitler. Adored sister of Skee Taubin. Loved by her daughter-in-law, Jane Schorr and her step-children, Richard and Kathy Herman, Lauren & Steven Schwartz, and Mindy and Jimmy Grossinger. A wonderful grandmother to Seth, Courtney, Billy, Rachel, Scott, Jared, Brandon and Jessica. Graveside services will be held at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, Queens, NY, on Friday December 18 at 1 PM. Memorial donations to Nathan Adelson Hospice in Las Vegas, NV. will be greatly appreciated.

title: Rochester Man Is Sentenced To Death for a 1996 Slaying
description: A Rochester man convicted of committing a murder during a kidnapping was sentenced to death yesterday. It was second death sentence handed down by a jury since capital punishment was reinstated in New York in 1995.

title: Articles of Impeachment
description: William Jefferson Clinton has undermined the integrity of his office, has brought disrepute on the Presidency, has betrayed his trust as President, and has acted in a manner subversive of the rule of law and justice, to the manifest injury of the people of the United States.

title: Protesting Critics' Zeal Over Clinton
description: TO find out how the Holocaust and Bill Clinton's sex life could wind up in the same thought, you will have to climb into the mind of Representative Henry J. Hyde, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. This man who would bring down the President actually made the connection.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; U2, ''THE BEST OF 1980-1990/THE B-SIDES'' (Island).
description: This nostalgic effort may be viewed as a cautionary move by a middle-aged band unsure of its next move, but it shines for showing one of this era's greatest groups in its dazzled, daring youth. The hits still soar, and may sound grandiose to today's humbled rock fans, but the joy comes in those B-sides. It's a thrill to hear the Edge feeling out his signature guitar style, and Bono wrestle with his messianic urges. These tracks offer a look at U2 in all its yelping earnestness, and makes one long for the days when reaching for more was a rocker's best hope. ANN POWERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, MILDRED
description: BAKER-Mildred. My treasured friend and unique connection to the history of our century. Craig Rutenberg

title: Indonesia's Leader Warns of 'Disintegration' From Strife
description: Student demonstrators clashed with soldiers today in a burst of gunfire, stone-throwing and clouds of tear gas as President B. J. Habibie warned that continued protests could lead to ''the disintegration of the nation.''

title: JETS SAID TO AVOID POISON GAS SITES
description: American and British forces are taking care to avoid hitting Iraqi factories suspected of producing chemical and biological weapons, Pentagon officials said today. They added that the damage at military, intelligence and communications targets has been extensive.

title: Others May Pay Price of Partisanship Over Iraq; Waiting on the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Coltec Says That Crane's Suit Against Merger Has No Merit
description: Coltec Industries, before agreeing to merge with B. F. Goodrich never received a formal purchase offer from the Crane Company, raising serious doubts about Crane's interest in the company, Coltec's chief executive said yesterday. As a result, Crane's lawsuit seeking to block the deal is without merit, Coltec said.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Holiday Albums; THE BEACH BOYS: ''ULTIMATE CHRISTMAS'' (Capitol).
description: The first half of this collection mines familiar Beach Boys territory, with the harmonizing purveyors of California sunshine singing of snowmen and Santa on their 1964 ''Christmas Album.'' The second half gets strange, compiling for the first time songs recorded for a never-released 1977 Christmas album. Because the album was a failed attempt by the band to get out of its contract with Warner Brothers, it is full of quickies: unused studio scraps with new seasonal vocals, wonderfully mournful solo songs by Brian and Dennis Wilson and instrumental tracks from older Beach Boys albums topped by new lyrics. Suddenly, the band's version of ''Peggy Sue'' becomes ''Christmas, Christmas, Christmas time is here again.'' NEIL STRAUSS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, STELLA K.
description: ABRAHAM-Stella K. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Samuel Abraham. Beloved mother of Judy Steinberg, S. Daniel Abraham, Jeremiah Abraham and the late Roy Abraham. Matriarch of an exceptional family, who taught by example. She personified the true ''Aishes Chayil'' dedicated to her children, her grandchildren and her great grandchildren. She was involved in many charitable efforts in a most dignified and loving manner. A friend of over half a century - her life was truly a blessing and she will be missed by her family and all who knew her. Dr. Bernard Lander President Touro College

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, MELVIN
description: EVANS-Melvin. The HewlettWoodmere Public Library mourns the loss of Melvin Evans, our former attorney. His invaluable counsel played a leading role in the beautiful new building that continues to enrich our community. Farewell, dear friend.

title: All Is Well and Heroic In Greenspan's World
description: Bud Greenspan knows what's happening in the real world of Olympic politics. The film maker knows that Mark Hodler, a Swiss member of the International Olympic Committee's executive board, has alleged that agents have offered to sell I.O.C. members' votes for payments from cities bidding to play host to the Olympics. He knows that the Salt Lake Organizing Committee has said that during its successful bid for the 2002 Winter Games, it paid nearly $400,000 in scholarships for relatives of I.O.C. members.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Holiday Albums; WOMEN OF THE CALABASH: ''THE KWANZAA ALBUM'' (Bermuda Reefs Records, 225 Lafayette Street Suite 814, New York, N.Y. 10012).
description: Long before Zap Mama arrived from Europe, New York City had Women of the Calabash, the trio of singing percussionists. The women treat Kwanzaa as an occasion for a trip through the African diaspora, from the choral anthem of the African National Congress to Yoruba chants to Zimbabwean mbira (thumb piano) music to steel-drum calypso. The percussion is crisply recorded, whether it's calabash rattles or drums or balaphon (African marimba); the voices harmonize with hearty precision. Spoken introductions to some tunes make the album slightly didactic, however; they should have been relegated to liner notes. JON PARELES

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON IS BUYING A RIVAL'S SKIN CARE BUSINESS
description: Johnson & Johnson, the health care products giant, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the skin care business of S. C. Johnson & Son Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., sells products like Neutrogena face wash and shampoo. It is looking for a bigger share of the $47 billion global skin care market. The dermatological brands of S. C. Johnson, a closely held company based in Racine, Wis., include the Aveeno oatmeal skin-care line, Pentrax dandruff shampoo and Rhuli anti-ich cream. It also makes household cleaning, home storage and insect-control products. Johnson & Johnson's stock fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $80.

title: U.S. Said to Intend to File Civil Fraud Charges Against Livent
description: Federal regulators intend to file civil charges against Livent Inc., the Broadway theater producer, and some former employees for securities and accounting fraud, according to documents the company has filed in bankruptcy court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOZOL, ROBERT DAVID
description: KOZOL-Robert David, December 15, of Brookline, MA. Cherished husband of Clara (Shapiro) Kozol. Devoted son of the late Frank L. & Mildred H. Kozol. Adored father of Eric John, Lauren Eve, Kenneth Arthur and father-in-law of Lisa (Hutcheson) Kozol. Dear brother of Joel A. and Lee H. Kozol. Loving grandfather of Jacob Daniel Kozol. Services at Temple Israel, corner Longwood Ave. and Plymouth St., Boston, MA on Friday, December 18 at 10:00 AM. Memorial observance through Monday, December 21 at his late residence. In his memory, donations may be made to the Leukemia Society of America. For more information contact Stanetsky Memorial Chapels, Brookline, MA.

title: Rival Seeks Reimbursement
description: The official who headed the Swedish bid that lost the vote to play host to the 2002 Winter Olympics said yesterday that he wanted Salt Lake City organizers to reimburse the expenses of their rival cities if the group is penalized by the International Olympic Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, PHILIP
description: GOLDSTEIN-Philip. Passed away Dec. 17, 1998 in Florida. Beloved husband of Ann, devoted father to Steven and Matthew, beloved father-in-law to Jane and Maggi. Lovingly devoted grandfather to Brian, Seth, Eric & the late Jeffrey Goldstein, caring brother to May and Lorraine. He was adored and respected by countless members of his extended family as well as his devoted friends. He will be remembered for his kindness, keen mind, compassion and unbridled integrity. Services to be held on Sunday, December 20, 10 AM, at Boulevard - Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. 516-295-3100. Contributions to the Jeffrey A. Goldstein Foundation, 986 Middle Bay Dr, Baldwin, New York 11510.

title: Was a United China Worth Any Sacrifice?
description: Talk about absolute power! When an assassination attempt is made on the life of the first Chinese Emperor, Ying Zheng (Jiang Wen), while he is traveling through the countryside, his order to have everyone within three miles of his party killed is instantly and unquestioningly obeyed. Does this make Ying (who is known today as Qin Shi Huangdi) one of history's all-time worst monsters? Not according to ''The Emperor's Shadow,'' which portrays Ying as a shrewd but misguided idealist who believes that the securing of his power to realize his dream of a united China is worth any sacrifice.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; ERIC B. AND RAKIM: ''PAID IN FULL: THE PLATINUM EDITION'' (Island/Polygram).
description: Exaggeration runs rampant in hip-hop circles, but this 1987 album really did change things. Eric B.'s turntable-generated backgrounds represented the beginning of heavy sampling on hip-hop records, and Rakim's quick, unblustery rapping developed the form beyond the flat-footed rhythms of schoolyard rhymes; this is still a primary source for new hip-hop. CD No. 2 collects the remixes of these tunes from the period, including Coldcut's well-known version of ''Paid in Full''; it's interesting how dated they now sound, next to the real thing. BEN RATLIFF

title: New One-Day Metrocards to Be Aimed at Infrequent Riders
description: After a spirited dispute over whether a new $4 one-day Metrocard should be offered primarily to tourists or as a discount pass for commuters, transit officials decided yesterday to aim the card at infrequent bus and subway riders.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Holiday Albums; ''CHRISTMAS WITH SHIRLEY CAESAR'' (Word/Epic).
description: The proselytizing is overt and proud on the Christmas album by the gospel singer Shirley Caesar, whose gutsy soul belting has never been diverted to secular music. Though she doesn't preach until the final song, she intersperses familiar Christmas songs with newer ones that remind listeners about prophecy and salvation. There's no stopping her grit and fervor in arrangements that are rooted in the chugging momentum of 1960's and 70's soul with the added gleam of modern keyboards; she turns ''It Came Upon a Midnight Clear'' into a slow-rolling soul ballad. Even when she's backed by an orchestra and singing Schubert's ''Ave Maria'' in Latin, Ms. Caesar still sounds like a down-home believer. JON PARELES

title: Others May Pay Price of Partisanship Over Iraq; Abuse of Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Judge Freezes Assets Of Head of H.M.O.
description: A New Jersey State judge yesterday froze about $5 million in assets of a doctor who heads a troubled health maintenance organization and ordered him to post a bond of $840,000 while regulators review the company's financial records, officials said.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; ''THE BEST OF THE ORB'' (Island).
description: When the Orb's ''Little Fluffy Clouds'' single was released in 1991, the loopy track, with its percolating beat, odd sounds and spoken-word sample of Rickie Lee Jones rhapsodizing about desert skies, introduced a new concept in pop. The Orb called its mix of underground dance beats and psychedelic rock ''Ambient House,'' and it inspired the many-tendriled genre called electronica. This double-disc set collects the singles from this pioneering group, which had commercial success before drifting into headier experiments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JOHN L. JR.
description: MURPHY-John L. Jr. Formerly of Brooklyn, New York. Passed away on December 2, 1998, in Cleveland, Ohio. He was a professional engineer for the bureau of the Budget-Office of the Mayor of New York City. Loving husband of Joan L. (nee Piasecki). Dear brother of James A., of Great Barrington, Massachusetts.

title: Price of Crude Oil Plunges As Iraqi Output Continues
description: With the air strikes on Iraq causing no damage to its ability to pump and ship oil, prices plunged yesterday, wiping out a large part of the gains of the last week.

title: Fedex Pilots Union Announces A Tentative Pact With Company
description: The pilots union at Federal Express said tonight that it had reached a tentative agreement on a labor contract that would improve pay and work schedules at the world's largest overnight delivery service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, HAROLD
description: WEISS-Harold. Devoted husband of Leatrice, father of Richard and Robert & Marcy Katz. Grandfather of eight. Funeral 1 PM today at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla.

title: AT THE MOVIES; Inner Life, Outer Madness
description: Ever since the witty war film ''King of Hearts'' demonstrated with hilarity that ''crazy people'' locked up in asylums may well be saner, or at least more humane, than those outside, movies have occasionally flirted with the notion of whether we should trust the guard or the inmate. Think of ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' or even ''The Dream Team,'' films that were both poignant and comic.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Nov. 23 with an article about K-Tel International misstated one of its 1996 financial results. The company reported a $750,000 loss that year, not $750,000 in net income.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Holiday Albums; VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''TO LIFE! CHANUKAH AND OTHER JEWISH CELEBRATIONS'' (Rhino).
description: Every year, a token collection of Jewish holiday music or two is released, but this is one of the few with the potential to be kept in a household for years, pulled out each holiday by family members familiar with nearly every note.

title: Rawls, 63, Still Glitters As Stars Flickers Out
description: Lou Rawls has straddled as many musical worlds as any pop singer, having come out of gospel and settled comfortably into the area where blues, soul, jazz and pop converge. And at Wednesday's opening night show at Rainbow and Stars, he demonstrated his mastery with one suave swoop, seguing late in the show from ''Send In the Clowns'' to ''I'm Your Hoochie Coochie Man.''

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; NICO: ''THE CLASSIC YEARS'' (Chronicles).
description: From her first single, Nico -- the German model, singer, actress and socialite of the 1960's and 70's -- began carving herself into a beautiful edifice of ice: ''I'm not saying that I care/I'm not saying I'll be there when you want me,'' she says without emotion in her husky, nicotine-stained monotone. Though best known for singing on the first album by the Velvet Underground after Andy Warhol pushed her on the band, Nico also recorded some seminal solo music, ranging from elegiac originals to stirring numbers by others like ''These Days,'' written for her by Jackson Browne. These first 10 years of her 23-year music career are the focus of ''The Classic Years,'' and though calling them ''classic'' may not be accurate, they are definitely her best years and a good place for the Nico neophyte to start. NEIL STRAUSS

title: UMass Optimistic About I-AA Final
description: Top-seeded Georgia Southern rolled up an average of 498.3 yards a game and forged a 14-0 record in reaching the Division I-AA championship game tomorrow against Massachusetts.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Seton Smith: Pale Guide to Transparent Things'

title: Limerick (Stab City, No Less) Rebounds
description: This 1,000-year-old city is losing its inferiority complex.

title: G.M. Tries to Increase Appeal of Electric Car
description: THE General Motors Corporation sent a top technology executive here recently to promote the latest version of its EV1 electric car, which has new batteries that are supposed to double the driving range to 140 miles between charges.

title: Everything in Its Own Time
description: With his decision to order substantial air strikes against Iraq, President Clinton has finally taken a course of action that should have been pursued earlier this year. Not that this will result in a change of regime in Iraq, nor an end to its efforts to hide or acquire weapons of mass destruction. But the operation will send a clear signal to would-be proliferators that the United States will continue to lead the global effort to stop the spread of these horrific weapons.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Monday about the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's performance of ''Ascension,'' choreographed by Troy O'Neil Powell, misstated the choreographer's surname in a later reference. He is Mr. Powell, not Mr. O'Neil.
