description: LEVY-Estelle. Mom, you're with us every day. Andrea

title: Others May Pay Price of Partisanship Over Iraq; Playing Us Like Fiddles
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, DR. ARTHUR M.
description: KAHN-Dr. Arthur M. Beloved husband of Natalie. Devoted father of Michael and Susan Kahn, Robbie and Adam Hoffman. Dear brother of Susan Greenfield. Cherished grandfather of Daniel, Allison, Ross and Luke. Services Friday at 12 Noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, L.I.

title: U.S. Journalist Slain in Mexico, Autopsy Shows
description: American reporter Philip True, who disappeared while hiking through rugged mountains in western Mexico, was killed by being hit over the head and choked, Mexican forensic examiners said today. Earlier reports said he had died in an accidental fall.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Holiday Albums; ''BABYFACE'' (Epic)
description: Even playing the obvious Christmas repertory, Babyface's loose, funky and very Southern band sounds appropriately joyous. There are no special guest turns from Whitney Houston, Eric Clapton or other solid-gold elves who have received gifts from the songwriter's workshop, but the vocal group Take 6 makes an appearance to sing background vocals in ''I'll Be Home for Christmas.'' Better this than a hundred dewy-eyed orchestral Christmas records. BEN RATLIFF

title: Excerpts of Remarks by Livingston and Gephardt
description: Following are excerpts from comments on the floor of the House today by the Speaker-designate, Representative Robert L. Livingston, Republican of Louisiana, and the minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Martyr's Requiem Invokes Justice
description: The tree is a sermon in itself. A big, sturdy oak with serpentine limbs, it's the first thing the audience sees in ''Parade,'' the solemn, high-reaching new musical directed by Harold Prince that opened last night at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Holiday Albums; SARI AND MARI KAASINEN, ''CAN WE HAVE CHRISTMAS NOW?'' (Northside).
description: The playful petulance of this album's title suits its stars, the two sisters who lead the formidable all-female vocal group from Finland called Vartinna. The spare arrangements on this collection of traditional and contemporary carols leave much room to enjoy the clear, heady voices of the Kaasinen sisters. Listeners unfamiliar with Finnish can avoid the banal lyrics that characterize most modern holiday songs, and concentrate on the simple yet rich gifts of these young singers as they wax merry and melancholy. ANN POWERS

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''JAMES BROWN'S ORIGINAL FUNKY DIVAS''  (Chronicles).
description: The two CD's in the set cover the 1960's and 70's and show off the flock of women associated with James Brown, in whatever capacity. Some had minor hits, others didn't, but by the time we reach the 70's, the band -- usually the J.B.'s, and usually led in some manner by Brown -- was about making music as good as dance music got at that time in America. The singers -- including Lyn Collins, Vicki Anderson, Sugar Pie Desanto, Kay Robinson, Marva Whitney, Tammi Terrell -- sing over the almighty groove of the band. To hear Brown at the same time there's the intense ''James Brown, Say It Live and Loud: Live in Dallas 8.26.68'' (Polydor/Chronicles), a live session that captures the band at its best. PETER WATROUS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, ROSE H.
description: FREEDMAN-Rose H. Devoted wife of the late Nathan, beloved mother of Sidney (Nancy) and George, grandmother of Amy, Carrie and Gerry, great-grandmother of Jonathan, Alexander, Rena. Services 10AM Friday at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 No. Sta. Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: The Swords! That Key! Those Teeth!
description: Evidently the people who came up with the George Washington exhibition now at the New-York Historical Society had two things in mind. First, they were moved by the assumption that despite the more than two centuries in which the Father of Our Country has been wildly lauded and lionized, few of us really know him, or like him very much. Then they concluded that this state of affairs might be changed if they showed us stuff like his false teeth and his letters to his tailor ordering new breeches.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: U.S. Closes 38 Embassies In Africa as a Precaution
description: The United States has closed 38 embassies in Africa for at least two days to protect employees against possible terrorist reprisals for the American air strikes on Iraq, Administration officials said today.

title: For Solitary Diners
description: With its emphasis on families and togetherness, the holiday season can leave people who are on their own feeling especially lonely. All the more reason to treat yourself to a good meal at any of these restaurants that do well by solitary diners. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Theaters Fight Pirating of Films
description: When reached on his cell phone, Bill Shannon was in Brooklyn helping the police shut down another video piracy operation. ''It was one of the bigger ones,'' he said. ''A lab and warehouse, 173 VCR's, 7,000 pieces of finished product. There were 10 arrests.''

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Alison Wilding

title: The Electric Home-Drive Acid Test
description: TEST-DRIVE an electric car, and at first the sensation of quiet overwhelms all else -- except, perhaps, the anxiety about how much energy remains in the batteries.

title: Senate Passes Charter Plan For Schools
description: After gaining potent leverage with a threat to veto a legislative pay raise, Gov. George E. Pataki won approval early this morning of a plan that would alter the state's educational landscape by authorizing the creation of autonomous public schools.

title: The Critics Now Ask: After Missiles, What?
description: In 1991, the American-led attack on Iraq was perceived the world round as a wondrous demonstration of military skill. Almost eight years later, with Saddam Hussein unbowed, unrepentant and untamed, the high-tech bombings are generating far more questions than awe.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; THE CREATION: ''THE COMPLETE COLLECTION, VOLS. 1 AND 2'' (Retroactive).
description: One of the great lost British bands of the 60's, the Creation, at its best, holds up to early Who and Kinks (with whom it shares a producer, Shel Talmy). On the crest of mod and psychedelia, the Creation strove for lustrous pop yet gravitated toward the rough and unkempt, making for clatteringly addictive songs like ''How Does It Feel to Feel'' and ''If I Stay Too Long.'' These two disks collect just about everything this band of bad boys with good harmonies ever recorded in its deciduous existence from 1965 to 1968. Despite (or because of) the band's explosive temperaments, constantly changing lineups and tendency to borrow melodies and lyrics from contemporaries, the songs here are all strong yet it will take more than this to change the band's legacy from that of a 60's footnote to a garage rock classic. NEIL STRAUSS

title: On My Mind; What Clinton Can Do
description: Bill Clinton has one great service he can offer to his country, only one now -- swift resignation.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; VARIOUS ARTISTS, ''BRESIL, 1914-1945'' (Fremeaux/available from Roots and Rhythm, 888-766-8766).
description: Here are two CD's-worth of music essential to understand the explosion of creativity that occurred in Brazil, the United States and Cuba during the first few decades of the century. Included is the first samba recorded; along with another boxed set, ''Samba 1917-1947'' (which includes music by Carmen Miranda). ''Bresil'' shows the complicated cultural synthesis in Brazil that allowed all this beautiful music to exist. PETER WATROUS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JANIS, DENNIS
description: JANIS-Dennis. 12/18/54-12/19/93. Happy Birthday, Blooks. I miss you more than you'll ever know. Love, Nina

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERPOOL, ANN WEST
description: VANDERPOOL-Ann West. On December 14th, 1998 Ann West Vanderpool, nee Ann West Wheeler from Providence, Rhode Island, who was the beloved wife to the late Wynant D. Vanderpool, Jr. She is survived by three children: Stuart H. Johnson III of New York City, Thomas W. Johnson of Baltimore, Maryland, and Willow Johnson of New York City, her sister Elizabeth Wheeler Belshaw of Princeton, New Jersey, and five grandchildren. The funeral service will be held at Christ Church Georgetown, 31st and O Streets, N.W. at 11:00 a.m. Monday, December 21, 1998. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in Ann Vanderpool's name to The Corcoran Gallery of Art, Director's Office, 500 17th Street, N.W., Washington, DC 20006 or to the National Symphony Orchestra, John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Washington, DC 20566 Attn: Development Office. Interment private.

title: So Bright You Might Say It Glows
description: The spirit of Christmas resides in Brooklyn, at 7823 12th Avenue in Dyker Heights. There, in a four-bedroom brick row house, Peter and Janet Marcolini have hung, strung and sprung a dazzling array of decorations for a quarter century, each year noticeably more than the year before. They may be running out of space, but they will never run out of heart.

title: October Trade Deficit Narrowed
description: The trade deficit in goods and services narrowed in October, and improved international demand for American products signaled that a recovery might be near for the nation's exporters.

title: Royal Philips to Reduce Shares by 8%
description: Royal Philips Electronics N.V., Europe's largest maker of consumer electronics, will reduce the number of its outstanding common shares by 8 percent, the company said in a statement today.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; 2PAC: ''GREATEST HITS (Amaru/Death Row/Interscope).
description: The back of this record is emblazoned with the logos of two formerly embittered rival labels: the controversial record company Death Row, run by Suge Knight, who was driving the car 2Pac was shot to death in two years ago, and Amaru, the label headed by 2Pac's mother, Afeni Shakur, who has accused Mr. Knight of withholding money from her son and encouraging him to lead the life style that led to his death. If the two wanted to make more money from 2Pac's legacy, they should have released two separate volumes of greatest hits instead of packaging this in a double CD. It also would have been interesting to include more than just songs from 2Pac's six albums and two unreleased tracks, like 2Pac's early work with Digital Underground. Criticisms aside, this is still a tight compilation, cutting out some of the dross on 2Pac's albums and representing the complexity of his work, which simultaneously celebrated the gangsta life style (as in ''2 of Amerikaz Most Wanted'') while apologizing for it (as in the wrenching ''Dear Mama''). NEIL STRAUSS

title: Case of Millionaire's Murder Is in the Details, Experts Say
description: The defense lawyer for the mother and son charged with murdering an Upper East Side millionaire predicted an easy acquittal yesterday, but legal experts said the trial would be closely fought, focusing on what prosecutors say is a wealth of details in an elaborate fraud scheme.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (Jazz, Too)
description: Christmas songs are the great survivors of popular music. Holiday disks are once more bulging on the shelves. Some of the fare is old wine tricked out in new bottles, with a swing or reggae Christmas, some of it is determinedly traditional. Pop stars and ambitious unknowns shower the market with their versions of carols and seasonal songs. Whether your taste runs to Babyface or the Beach Boys, Celia Cruz or Celine Dion, you can find a rendering of holiday music filtered through their distinct sensibilities.

title: INSIDE
description: Pinochet Wins a Round In Extradition Case

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''ETHIOPIQUES, VOLS. 1-4'' (Buda Musique/available from Roots and Rhythm 888 766-8766).
description: What a series! Every volume has its share of the deep trance music of the dance. The music ranges from full bands to women vocalists with light drum and violin backing. There are electric keyboards and accordions, and vibrato-laden singing. It's obviously related to the Arab music from a bit further north of Ethiopia, and influenced by Western pop and jazz (the fourth volume is called ''Ethio Jazz & Musique Instrumentale.'' The recordings start in 1969 and run through the 1990's. Some of it sounds rural, some profoundly urban. The liner notes explain the political context within which it was all made. PETER WATROUS

title: Others May Pay Price of Partisanship Over Iraq; An Odd Judgment
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Arabs Assail Dictator and Bombing
description: Like many of the Arab-Americans in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, Yasser Madbouly said yesterday that he was sickened to see his adopted country launch missile strikes on Iraq.

title: Mayweather's Father Is His Biggest Booster
description: Before Floyd Mayweather Jr. challenged Genaro Hernandez for the World Boxing Council superfeatherweight title, Floyd Mayweather Sr. predicted that the bout would be an easy one for his son. Sure enough, the younger Mayweather forced Hernandez to quit following the eighth round and won the title.

title: Winstar and Williams Plan 2 Transactions
description: Winstar Communications Inc., which provides wireless local phone services, said yesterday that it would buy part of the Williams Companies' nationwide fiber optic network for $640 million to connect Winstar's local networks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILGORAJ, RUBIN
description: BILGORAJ-Rubin. Surrounded by the love of his children Norberto and Nizza, her husband John and grandchildren, Dahlia, and Daniel, and his faithful Victoria and Ana. Rubin Bilgoraj has serenely passed on to join his beloved wife Irma. Services 9 AM Friday, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERRY, ELLEN BRUCE
description: TERRY-Ellen Bruce, 78, of Palm Beach, the daughter of former Ambassador and Mrs. James Bruce. Attended Greenwood School in Baltimore, Md., and The Spence School in New York. She had homes in Princeton, New Jersey, and Palm Beach, FL. She was a member of the Society of the Four Arts, the Bath and Tennis and Everglades Clubs in Palm Beach and the Bedens Brook Club in Princeton. She is survived by her husband, Robert Lee Terry, children, Robert Lee Terry Jr., Ellen Terry Benoit and Prescott leBreton Terry; six grandchildren and a sister, Miss Louise Este Bruce of NYC. Memorial service at a later date. Donations can be made in memory of Mrs. Ellen Bruce Terry to the Nature Conservancy, 6860 North Fairfax Drive, Suite 100, Arlington, VA 22203-1606, Attention: Member Services.

title: Inside Art
description: A Digital Dialogue With Michelangelo

title: Assorted Itinerants on a Desolate Southwestern Road
description: The biggest mystery about ''Outside Ozona'' isn't the identity of the serial killer who cuts out the hearts of his female victims. (The murderer, who is obvious from the moment he appears, is shown doing his dirty work roughly halfway through the film.) The wonder is why reputable actors agreed to appear in a movie whose plodding screenplay, by J. S. Cardone, who also directed, has the feel of an earnest, immature play-wrighting exercise.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL IN $141 MILLION DEAL FOR SAND RIDGE
description: First Financial Bancorp, a bank holding company, said yesterday that it would buy the Sand Ridge Financial Corporation for about $141 million in stock as it expanded in the Midwest. First Financial, based in Hamilton, Ohio, said the purchase was a tax-free exchange and should be completed by next year. Sand Ridge, a privately held company whose headquarters are in Highland, Ind., has assets of $527 million, 5 units and 227 employees. First Financial, with assets of $2.8 billion, operates 16 community bank subsidiaries with 105 units in Ohio, Michigan and Indiana. Its shares rose $1.125 each, to $28.625.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; BOBBY BLAND: ''GREATEST HITS: VOL. 1 (THE DUKE RECORDINGS) AND VOL. 2 (THE ABC-DUNHILL/MCA RECORDINGS'' (MCA).
description: The first of these two individually sold disks is prime Southern soul of the 1960's, but not at all its common stock. Mr. Bland's Jekyll and Hyde approach to singing -- now a seductive purr, now a gargling scream -- may have been heavy-handed, but the bands that recorded with him on the Dallas-based Duke label so splendidly shadowed his dynamics that these records constantly transcend their genre; each one is a chugging, compelling little drama. Vol. 2, a quantum leap in studio sophistication, chronicles Mr. Bland's 1970's work: slow, urbane, dark-night-of-the-soul stuff. BEN RA TLIFF

title: Critics From Paris to Kuwait, but a Friend in London -- Low Profile for Arab Allies
description: Even Arab governments that joined with the United States against Baghdad in early 1991 have offered almost no public support for the attack on Iraq. The reactions from countries like Egypt, Qatar and Syria have ranged instead from regret to concern to outright condemnation. Even Kuwait, which was liberated from Iraqi occupation by the Persian Gulf war, has stopped short of endorsing the military action.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; SPIRITUALIZED: ''LIVE AT THE ALBERT HALL'' (Arista/Dedicated).
description: Religion, music, love, sex and drugs are all ways to fill a terrifying void, and Spiritualized seeks the same release in all of them. Jason Pierce's songs are grand drones and crescendos, drawing on the legacy of the Velvet Underground, Pink Floyd and U2. Yet while he makes music that aspires to be monumental, his voice and lyrics are weary and desperate. This double album, with the band abetted by an orchestra and a gospel choir, gives the songs ample room to unfold. As the music slowly works up to peaks of exaltation and chaos, it grows even harder to distinguish rapture from annihilation. JON PARELES

title: On Stage and Off; A Full Pot Of Drama
description: With holiday vacations looming, producers were wrapping up a bundle of deals this week. The result is a clear picture of the spring season. And it can be summed up in a single word: plays. Lots of them.

title: Spanish Judge Said to Strengthen Case
description: The Spanish judge who issued the arrest warrant for Gen. Augusto Pinochet in October expects to present an even stronger case against the former Chilean dictator when England's Law Lords reconsider his immunity from arrest, a Madrid court official said today.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Holiday Albums; SHAWN COLVIN: ''HOLIDAY SONGS AND LULLABIES'' (Columbia)
description: If one has to be sentimental about the season, this is the soundtrack to go with. Ms. Colvin's voice, with its practiced emotionalism, cracks and curves in the right places. It's not all well-known Christmas music -- she sings ''Christmas Time Is Here,'' ''Love Came Down at Christmas,'' ''Silent Night'' and ''Little Road to Bethlehem'' -- but there's also ''Rocking'' and ''In the Bleak Midwinter.'' The production sounds full and rich, a modern pop record with strings and horns. PETER WATROUS

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'The Choice'

title: A Speaker's Swan Song In Celebration of Politics
description: Capitol politicians had barely steadied their nerves this morning after the wrenching agenda shift from impeachment to Iraq when Speaker Newt Gingrich rose to address the House in the waning hours of his once formidable political powers.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; CHARLES MINGUS: ''THE COMPLETE 1959 COLUMBIA RECORDINGS'' (Columbia Legacy).
description: Consisting of two albums, ''Mingus Ah Um'' and ''Mingus Dynasty,'' along with a disk's worth of alternate takes, the set offers up Mingus at a particularly high point in his career. His bluesy workouts, including ''Better Git It in Your Soul'' and ''Slop,'' are vital and roaring, and the classic ballad ''Goodbye Porkpie Hat'' represents another, more melancholic aspect to his composing. It's essential music, standing in the perfect ground between traditionalism and experimentation. PETER WATROUS

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about Mattel's plans to acquire the Learning Company included one product incorrectly among those made by Mattel. G.I. Joe is made by Hasbro.

title: Bitter Clash on Timing of Impeachment
description: House Republicans raised the ghosts of Watergate and Vietnam today to justify their decision to move ahead with the impeachment debate on Friday in the face of Democratic protests and continuing American military strikes against Iraq.

title: Times Company Promotes Two
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that Raymond E. Douglas had been promoted to corporate chief information officer and that Ellen Taus, the company treasurer, had received the additional title of vice president. Mr. Douglas had been vice president for systems and technology. Ms. Taus has been treasurer of the company since 1997.

title: Accounts
description: * One-on-One Sports, Northbrook, Ill., to Rosen Group, Chicago, to handle its consolidated account including creative duties and direct mail that had been handled by the Leap Partnership, Chicago, part of Leap Group. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: The Actor's Life for Them: Auditions and Rejections
description: Woe is the actor's life: judgment, rejection, humiliation.

title: Folksbiene, Reopened, Focuses On Conflict
description: Starting its 83d season, the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater is in the throes of change. Not only has it lost its longtime home as a result of the fire in the Central Synagogue last summer, it has also undergone a change of administration. The seemingly irrepressible and indestructible Zipporah Spaisman has retired, giving way to two artistic directors, Zalman Mlotek and Eleanor Reissa.

title: Finding Patients' Courage
description: As an example of unvarnished courage, it would be hard to beat 16-year-old Nargess Nateghi, who has spent all her life fighting cystic fibrosis. The drugs that have kept her alive have stolen her hearing and damaged her kidneys. Now her only hope of survival is a lung transplant. During an interview, this young woman seems to understand the severity of her plight yet retains a remarkable composure.

title: Union Official Is Expected to Resign
description: Officials of District Council 37 said yesterday that Robert F. Myers Jr., its longtime treasurer, was expected to announce his retirement this week for medical reasons. Mr. Myers has had two strokes over the last several years, although union officials said his health has improved recently.

title: Others May Pay Price of Partisanship Over Iraq; A Rush to Judge
description: To the Editor:

title: Critics From Paris to Kuwait, but a Friend in London
description: British planes joined United States forces bombing Iraq today, but other European allies kept their distance. Most, including France, blamed President Saddam Hussein for making military action inevitable.

title: Earth Temperature in 1998 Is Reported at Record High
description: The earth's average surface temperature in 1998 is the highest by far since people first began to measure it with thermometers in the mid-19th century, the World Meteorological Organization reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANTON, HELEN LAFETRA
description: STANTON-Helen LaFetra. Died peacefully at her home on December 15, 1998, age 98. She was the widow of Louis Lee Stanton. Mother of Ann S. Warden, Louis L. Stanton Jr. and the late Dixon LaFetra Stanton. Also survived by ten grandchildren and 13 greatgrandchildren. Service to be held at 1:30pm on Saturday, December 19th at St. James's Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and 71st. Street, NYC.

title: Television Coverage of Impeachment Debate
description: Impeachment proceedings in the House are scheduled to begin at 9 A.M. today, with a session to set the ground rules of the debate, which is to begin at 10 A.M.

title: Will G.O.P. Be Casualty Of Its Own Missile Fire?
description: The polls show Americans do not want President Clinton impeached. And they show that the public is squarely behind the President's bombing of Iraq.

title: War at Home and Abroad
description: At a time when its members would normally be in holiday recess, Congress is wrestling with its two most solemn responsibilities -- whether to impeach the President and whether to support his decision to send American troops into combat. Democrats made a strong case against starting the impeachment debate while American forces are attacking Iraq. But in discussing that issue, the Democrats were also playing to an emerging theme in popular opinion that the impeachment process is being guided by Republican muscle rather than sober judgment. ''There is something about this whole process that shows a lack of judgment, a lack of proportionality, a lack of common sense,'' warned the Democratic whip, David Bonior of Michigan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GARSON, EUGENE
description: GARSON-Eugene On Sunday, December 20 at 2PM, at The New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Holiday Albums; SPIKE JONES: ''LET'S SING A SONG OF CHRISTMAS'' (Verve/Polygram).
description: At first you may be shocked that this isn't the loony Spike Jones you know and love. But then the craziness peeps in; after some straight, wholesome numbers, there's ''Jingle Bells'' sung in pig latin. First and foremost, it's a 50's period piece for those into retro Americana; George Rock's goofy little-boy voice in ''All I Want for Christmas (Is My Two Front Teeth)'' wouldn't crack up most children whose sense of humor has been sharpened by the speed gags of ''The Simpsons.'' But what shines through is the work that went into this album, the laborious arrangements of unfamiliar songs. (Ever heard ''Wouldn't It Be Fun to Be Santa Claus's Son?'' Neither had I.) BEN RATLIFF

title: For Wells, A New Holiday Uniform
description: David Wells was the picture of happiness.

title: Court Curmudgeon Bids a Typical Goodbye
description: IT is possible that Justice Burton B. Roberts, the departing chief administrative judge of State Supreme Court in the Bronx, has learned from his friend Tom Wolfe, who modeled the irascible judge in ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' after him, that literarily speaking, it is always more effective to show than to tell. Thus, Justice Roberts may simply be trying to help out the reporter by displaying a flash of his famous temper.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Shot Fired by Detective Hits Fellow Officer's Vest
description: A detective searching for a shooting suspect in a Bronx apartment house was slightly wounded yesterday when a bullet fired by a fellow officer went through a basement wall and hit his bullet-resistant vest, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORAK, NATHAN
description: BORAK-Nathan. Died December 14. A man of charm, wit and gentle dignity. Widower of Isadora Strunsky, devoted father of Andrea and Jonathan, loving grandfather of Joshua Ordman, Antonia Ordman and Kiria Borak. Services Sunday at noon, Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Memorial donations may be sent to the James Education Fund, Yale Medical School, 333 Cedar Street, New Haven, CT. 06520.

title: Others May Pay Price of Partisanship Over Iraq; The Bombing Delusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; ''PIXINGUINHA 100 ANOS'' (BMG Brazil).
description: Pixinguinha, born and named Alfredo da Rocha Vianna Jr. a century ago, took Brazilian dance music to Europe in the 1920's; impressed by the fox-trot orchestras he saw, he came back and added saxophones and trombones to the mandolins, guitars, flutes and percussion already in his band. His lively, tightly arranged small-group ''choro'' music bears similarities to early 20th-century Cuban bands and even American pre-jazz: it involved intricately entwined sprouts of melody and it was rooted in European dance forms: quadrilles, waltzes, habaneras. The 28 recordings on this double CD start in 1923 and stretch to the 70's (some are versions of his songs by other performers); they feature romantic singers, early samba rhythms, and a strikingly sophisticated vision of popular music. BEN RATLIFF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAVSKY, ANNA
description: WARSHAVSKY-Anna. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of a major benefactor who established a generous scholarship fund to enable many children to study in Ramaz. The accomplishments and good works of these children will be a living memorial to her devotion to Torah and Jewish education. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Princ. David N. Kahn, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Despite Earlier Statement, Lott Says He Supports the American Air Raids in Iraq
description: Although a statement he issued Wednesday was universally interpreted as accusing President Clinton of ordering air strikes in Iraq to divert attention from impeachment, Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, insisted today that was not what he meant.

title: ADOBE'S STOCK RISES 15% AS EARNINGS BEAT EXPECTATIONS
description: The stock of Adobe Systems Inc. rose 15 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of desktop publishing software, reported fourth-quarter earnings that beat Wall Street's expectations. After the financial markets closed on Wednesday, the company reported net operating earnings of 76 cents a share for the quarter ended Nov. 27, beating analysts' expectations of 64 cents. Adobe's shares rose $5.7344, to $43.875, in heavy Nasdaq trading. Adobe, based in San Jose, Calif., has been repurchasing shares since September 1997, when its board authorized a buyback of up to 15 million shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, RUTH
description: GORDON-Ruth. Beloved mother of Barbara Schneider and Ron Gordon. Loving mother-in-law of Helga Gordon and Ron Schneider. Cherished grandmother of Andrew, Bettina, David, Jennifer and Patty. Adored ''GG'' of her great granddaughter Molly. Services are Sunday at 1:30PM, at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NYC. Donations in her memory may be made to Village Center for Care, 607 Hudson Street, NYC 10014.

title: Security Bolstered in City Amid Fears of Reprisals

Twelve versions of ''Jingle Bells,'' all singing animals. There's a clucking chorus in ''Chicken Feed Bluegrass,'' quacks in ''Duck Ellington,'' croaks in ''Froggy's Christmas Crooning.'' You get the picture. They all come together for ''The Swingin' Barnyard Christmas Extravaganza,'' which might make some members of the family feel a little dirty, especially if there's a lot of gift-wrapping detritus strewn around the house. What are we, living in a barn? BEN RATLIFF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: SILBERSTEIN-Sylvia, philanthropist, talented artist, and dedicated wife, mother, grandmother and friend, passed away Thursday, Dec. 17, 1998. Born in Hammond, Indiana on December 2, 1915, to Samuel & Jennie Kleinberg Levin, Sylvia was an alumni of Indiana University where she met her husband and fellow alumni William Silberstein. They subsequently married in 1937, and lived in Hammond until 1950. She and her family moved to Scarsdale in 1950 and to Rye, New York in 1968. Sylvia will be most remembered for her great sense of humor, buoyant spirit and constant smile. Her charm was contagious and she was adored by her many friends. Sylvia was noted for her culinary expertise, her love of classical music, the theater, tennis & was often consulted for her vast knowledge of travel due to her extensive world travel. Sylvia was a longstanding member of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club since 1955. She possessed sound business acumen and helped her husband found Sealectro Corporation in Mamaroneck, New York. She was also very active in the creation of various philanthropic programs. In 1984, Sylvia and her husband established the first fully endowed athletic scholarship at Indiana University and thereafter two additonal endowed athletic scholarships. Their other philanthropic endeavors include the William & Sylvia Silberstein Aging and Dementia Research Center at New York University Medical Center, the William & Sylvia Silberstein Cardiac Center at White Plains Hospital Center, and most recently, the William and Sylvia Silberstein Pavilion at White Plains Hospital Center. Sylvia supported many other charities including Cystic Fibrosis and U.J.A. amongst others. Her generous philosophy was apparent during World War II when she was President of Hammond, Indiana chapter of B'nai B'rith and she established a welcoming committee for all servicemen's trains providing food and other nourishment to them. Sylvia is survived by her husand, William of Rye, New York, her daughter Betsy Levinson of Stamford, Connecticut; her son Bruce and his wife, Carolyn, of New York City; her son, Sigmund of Boca Raton, Florida, and six loving grandchildren, Beth, Lori and Debra, Jill, Michael and Matthew; and a sister, Arlene Pascal of Highland Park, Illinois. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Silberstein Cardiac Center at White Plains Hospital Center, or The Silberstein Aging and Dementia Center at New York University Medical Center. A service will be held at 12:00 Noon on Friday, December 18th, at the Congregation Emanu-el, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, New York.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''DEAD AND GONE, VOLUMES 1 AND 2'' (Trikont, Kistlerstrasse 1, Postfach 901055, D 8150 Munich, Germany).
description: Brilliantly compiled, these CD's are more than just collections of songs about mortality. As a whole, they form a unified composition, a meditation on the way different cultures respond artistically to death, a statement on grieving and a declaration of superb musical taste. Like a deft free-form radio show, these CD's follow Albert Ayler with Robert Wyatt with a funeral in a village in Ghana. Moody, atmospheric and moving, they segue Cassandra Wilson into the Geto Boys, and slowly march through dirges from Lou Reed, Billie Holiday, Lydia Mendoza, Tom Waits and brass and vocal groups from Mexico, Albania and Serbia. It may not seem like joyous holiday fare, but it's a perfect way to reflect on those less fortunate. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; GANG OF FOUR: ''100 FLOWERS BLOOM'' (Rhino).
description: Gang of Four (1978-1995) was a band of grouchy Marxists in love with rhythm, noise and cultural analysis. Furious about war and oppression, and suspicious of consumer society and its profit-driven blandishments, Gang of Four took its pleasure from dissonance and propulsion. Its songs are schematic constructions of rugged backbeats and guitar jolts, topped by intellectual one-liners like ''We've all got opinions, where do they come from?'' The two disks in this compilation each mix early and later songs, with the band gradually accepting melodies and turning from drums to drum machines while keeping its edge. Especially in some previously unreleased live performances the music's determined angularity still sounds bracing. It's the obvious blueprint for bands like Rage Against the Machine, showing how to have your critique and dance to it, too. JON PARELES

title: An Aging Actor's Dangerous Liaison in Mexico
description: In May 1988 the Tony-winning British-born actor George Rose was murdered in the Dominican Republic, where he maintained a home. At first the police called the death an accident. But further investigation revealed that Rose, best known for his performances on Broadway in ''The Pirates of Penzance'' and ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' had been beaten to death and that his body had been placed in a car that was then pushed into a ravine to create the appearance of a crash.

description: Expanding the definition of what makes a river a public waterway, New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that rivers surrounded by private property can be open to the public if they have a recreational use.

title: ONEX OF TORONTO AGREES TO ACQUIRE LCS INDUSTRIES
description: The Onex Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire LCS Industries, a provider of data-processing services for marketing and telecommunications companies, for $97.3 million in cash. Onex, a Toronto-based diversified holding company, said its Customerone Holding Corporation subsidiary would make a tender offer directly to shareholders for all of LCS's shares at $17.50 each. LCS Industries, based in Clifton, N.J., had 1997 revenues of $100.6 million. Onex has interests in automotive parts, airline catering and computer businesses. The shares of LCS rose $1.75 each, to $17.25.

The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Eryk Spektor, a generous contributor and fervent supporter of Israel who served as a trustee of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, a predecessor of UJA-Federation. title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; CHARLIE FEATHERS: ''GET WITH IT'' (Revenant, Box 198732, Nashville, Tenn. 37219-8732).
description: Charlie Feathers, who died this year, was the great lost rockabilly singer. He helped forge the Sun Records sound, wrote the Elvis Presley hit ''I Forgot to Remember to Forget'' and recorded some of the wildest three-minute vocal outbursts of the 1950's, full of whoops and sputters and hiccups. Behind the vocal antics, his songs describe seething resentment, unbridled lust and a pitiless fatalism. This two-CD set collects his commercially released songs from 1955 to 1962, as he changed from a hillbilly to a rockabilly singer, and unreleased demo tapes that are quieter, with an eerie, implacable conviction. JON PARELES

Together, they reaffirm that Christmas songs are the great survivors of popular music. Somehow they manage to stir affection despite endless renditions both amateur and professional.

description: This album of songs about the holiday season is tailor-made for existing Cyndi Lauper fans, since it largely consists of originals that tap into her most popular qualities. There's the goofy kitsch of ''Christmas Conga,'' the wide-eyed but risque story song ''Minnie and Santa,'' and the moody ballad ''Home on Christmas Day,'' which teeters between the bittersweet and the maudlin. Ms. Lauper still has the voice that could break a thousand hearts, and her version of ''Three Ships'' is lovely, but she needs stronger material, even on this novelty effort. ANN POWERS

description: Two decades since the beginning of hip-hop, there is finally an adequate compilation of female rappers, providing an alternate history of a genre with a stereotype of misogyny. In this world, strong wills win out over muscle, with old-school rappers like Roxanne Shante, the Real Roxanne and Sparky D crushing their male counterparts (and each other) with smart, savage, squeaky raps. Instead of filling these CD's with the obvious names -- Salt 'n' Pepa, Foxy Brown -- the creators of this compilation play favorites, stuffing the collection with excellent boasts, insults and intelligence by Ms. Shante, the Conscious Daughters, Queen Latifah and Bahamadia. title: Joblessness at 5.5% In Troubled Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong's unemployment rate rose to a record 5.5 percent in the three months through November as the city sank deeper into its worst recession in more than a generation. The unemployment rate for the August to October period was revised to 5.2 percent from 5.3 percent. Economists are predicting that the jobless rate will peak at between 7 percent and 9 percent at the end of 1999 or in early 2000.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; MARIANNE FAITHFULL: ''A PERFECT STRANGER'' (Island).
description: Marianne Faithfull's second career began in 1979 when the former model and 1960's pop starlet returned with a ravaged voice and new songs about betrayal, rage and bitterly won knowledge. Over the next two decades, she sang her own unsparing songs along with disillusioned tidings from rock songwriters, Kurt Weill and Tin Pan Alley. This two-CD collection includes four previously unreleased songs, including Bono's ''Conversation on a Barstool'' and a version of John Lennon's ''Isolation'' that cuts to the bone. Her tone has rasped across dance rhythms and hovering guitars and shimmering synthesizers, asking not for sympathy but for the truth, no matter how bleak. JON PARELES

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; ''LADIES AND GENTLEMEN: THE BEST OF GEORGE MICHAEL'' (Sony).
description: This two-CD retrospective is selling millions worldwide, yet in a strange reversal of the cliche, all George Michael can do in America is get arrested. The disco crooner's recent detention for indecent exposure earned him more attention stateside than he has had since the early 1990's. His long fight with Sony, no longer his label, certainly hurt him, but this set reveals another reason he might have dropped out of favor here. From ''I Want Your Sex'' to the new ''Outside,'' in which Mr. Michael brazenly endorses al fresco eroticism, these songs focus on the delights and difficulties of promiscuity. The ballads portray Mr. Michael reaching shamelessly for love, and the lush music breathes seduction. The dance numbers, their rhythms more intimate than aggressive, detail the more pragmatic aspects of getting down. Some tracks drag, and others overdo, but mostly Mr. Michael finds true inspiration in the bedroom. Mainstream America can be prim about such matters. This music makes a good case for loosening up. ANN POWERS

title: Man Arrested In the Slaying Of an Officer 21 Years Ago
description: For 21 years, the police have kept open the murder case of Officer Ronald Stapleton, who was ambushed by two men outside a Brooklyn disco, stabbed in the eye and shot twice in the stomach with his own revolver.

title: Diner's Journal
description: You know by looking at the dining room that the Tonic is an attractive new restaurant. But reading brings you more useful information. It takes only a glance at the menu to realize that the chef has a varied American background and favors strong flavors. And even a cursory reading of the wine list tells you that the person who put it together has very good contacts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERRIGONE, RICHARD A.
description: KERRIGONE-Richard A., 52. Died December 15th, 1998 at his home in Edwards, CO. Mr. Kerrigone was the President of the NASDAQ trading firm, William V. Frankel & Co. of Jersey City, NJ. Born in Brooklyn, he lived in Ridgewood, NJ before making his residence in Colorado 5 years ago. Son of the late Benedict and Inez Kerrigone, he is survived by his wife, Jacqueline of Ridgewood, son, Anthony of NYC, daughter, Catherine of Denver, CO, brothers, Ben of Kiawah Island, SC and Mike of Brooklyn, sister, Theresa of Princeton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the Gilda Club, 195 West Houston Street, NYC 10014.

title: Reveries, the True Calling
description: Time takes a sabbatical when Rufus Wainwright sings. Most of his songs float above languidly strummed guitar chords or homey piano shuffles, circling until he alights on a yearning chorus. And his voice, with an apparently infinite breath supply, sustains phrases in a pure legato, a moan that pays no attention to gravity. At the Bowery Ballroom on Tuesday night, he had a handful of songs that strolled forward like conventional rock tunes. But reveries are his true calling.

description: KAHEN-Florence. Beloved wife of Harold. Mother of Deborah Kayman, David Kahen, and the late Daniel Kahen. Grandmother of Noah Kayman and Gabriel and Joanna Kahen. She enriched our lives with her aesthetic sensibility, her gourmet cooking, her gardening and her thoughtfully selected gifts. At her express direction, the funeral is private. The family will observe Shiva, beginning Saturday evening, in the house she graced for 46 years. Her favorite charity was Camp Ramah, affiliated with The Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

title: At UConn, Another Knee Injury
description: Sue Bird sat in a folding chair to watch the University of Connecticut women's basketball team practice on Wednesday, with crutches by her side and a disappointed look on her face. Bird tore the anterior cruciate ligament in her left knee during a drill on Monday, and the freshman will miss the rest of the season.

title: STAPLES AGREES TO BUY CLARICOM FOR $140 MILLION CASH
description: Staples Inc., the No. 2 United States retailer of office supplies, said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Claricom Holdings Inc., a provider of telecommunications services, for $140 million in cash as part of a plan to expand sales to small businesses. In addition, Staples will relocate 58 older stores in California and the Northeast to larger sites. Staples, based in Westborough, Mass., said it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $57 million for relocation costs. Shares of Staples rose 18.75 cents, to $39.8125. Claricom, based in Milford, Conn., provides paging, video conferencing and other services, with estimated 1998 sales of $200 million. It is owned by its senior executives and the investment firms Bain Capital and Triumph Capital.

description: PARDES-Frances. The Association of the Alumni of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, would like to acknowledge the death of Frances Pardes and extend heartfelt condolences to her sons, Dr. Herbert Pardes, Vice President of Health Sciences and Dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Steven Pardes and daughter Elaine Samson. description: A series of mistakes, misunderstandings and oversights by school personnel allowed an abused 9-year-old girl -- who later died -- to slip through the New York City school system's attendance safeguards, officials said yesterday.

description: The separate trials of two prominent democracy advocates for inciting subversion of the state opened and closed quickly this morning, with the families of both defendants protesting their inability to hire defense lawyers.

title: Washington, Man And President
description: Evidently the people who came up with the George Washington exhibition at the New-York Historical Society had two things in mind. First they were moved by the assumption that despite the more than two centuries in which the Father of Our Country has been wildly lauded and lionized, few people really know him, or like him very much. Then they concluded that this state of affairs might be changed if they showed stuff like his false teeth (left) and letters to his tailor ordering new breeches.

title: At the U.N., Tensions Of Cold War Are Renewed
description: In the last two days, as United Nations arms inspectors abruptly left Iraq and military strikes began, divisions in the Security Council have reverted to cold war patterns, diplomats said today.

description: BASEBALL

title: Albanians in Kosovo Town Hide, Fearing Vengeance for Killings
description: Ethnic Albanians abandoned the streets of this western Kosovo town today, fearing vengeance for the killings of six Serbian youths in a cafe this week.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Holiday Albums; CELINE DION: ''THESE ARE SPECIAL TIMES'' (550 Music/Epic).
description: Like a multinational corporation, Celine Dion has a diversified product line on her Christmas album, from an orchestral ''Ave Maria'' to Jose Feliciano's ''Feliz Navidad'' to remakes of Elvis Presley and John Lennon to duets with Andrea Bocelli and R. Kelly, Phil Spector-style stomps and gooey ballads. She sings in English, French, Spanish and Latin. What she doesn't have is any sense of humor or natural grace.

title: Additional State Subsidy To Revitalize British Opera
description: The British Arts Council announced today that it would increase its subsidy to the struggling Royal Opera House by more than $21 million over the next three years, a move the opera said would allow it to reinstate a portion of its canceled 1999 season and to charge less for tickets when it returns to its refurbished headquarters next December.

title: Stern Sends Players Holiday Letter of Different Sort
description: In an attempt to portray the National Basketball Association as a good-faith bargainer and sway more than 400 players, Commissioner David Stern has mailed out a nine-page document detailing the owners' latest collective bargaining proposal to the union's membership.

title: Mildred Baker, 93, Administrator And Trustee of Newark Museum
description: Mildred Baker, an arts administrator and trustee emeritus of the Newark Museum, died on Dec. 9 at the Florence Nightingale Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 93 and was a longtime resident of the Chelsea Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMODICA, SALVATORE J.
description: DIMODICA-Salvatore J. The family of Salvatore J. Dimodica announces with much sorrow the death of a brave man after a long battle with cancer. Sal was a gentle, charitable man. Currently a resident of Ft. Lauderdale, he was predeceased by his wife of 45 years, Claire (Orlacchio), as well as son Paul. Born 11/19/11 in Portland, CT, Sal spent many years in Middletown before relocating to New York. When he retired in 1977 as Executive Vice President of Sterling Bancorp he became a part-time resident of Ft. Lauderdale, then a permanent Floridian. He is survived by sisters Lucy Magnano and Jennie Fortuna, of Middletown, as well as grandchildren Cara, David (Ann), Therese, Kristen and Sheri, four greatgrandchildren, nieces and nephews and his constant companion, Sandra Greenfeld. For information contact D'Angelo Funeral Home, Middletown, 860-347-0752.

title: Anguished Existential Cries That Rattle Sacred Icons
description: In Velazquez's 1650 painting of Pope Innocent X, the worldly pontiff sits calmly in his regal chair, radiating confidence and power. Three hundred years later, as portrayed by Francis Bacon in ''Study After Velazquez'' (1950), Innocent X is a frantic figure in his surplice and biretta, trapped behind a drab gray curtain that hangs in stiffened folds. A helpless prisoner, his mouth is open in a horrifying scream. Bacon's forceful, iconoclastic appropriation makes the Pope a victim, no longer the supreme interpreter of God to man but a symbol of existential anguish, caught up in the era's cataclysmic events.

title: Back Home, Clinton Critic Is Told to Ease Up
description: Amid the many skeptical voices about the timing of the air strikes against Iraq, few were blunter or quicker on the draw than that of Gerald B. H. Solomon, the chairman of the House Rules Committee and the Representative from this gentle land of horse farms and mineral spas. ''Never underestimate a desperate President,'' he declared, as cruise missiles began to rain on Baghdad. ''It is obvious he is doing it for political reasons.''

title: Puzzling It Out at Citigroup; Commercial and Investment Bankers Try Working Together
description: Citigroup, shaken by leadership turmoil in its early days as America's largest financial services company, has sped up the integration of its banking units in a headlong effort to prove that commercial bankers and investment bankers can mix.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYKOFF, FREDA S.
description: BOYKOFF-Freda S. of Somers NY Dec 16, 1998. Wife of Peter, mother of Franklin Michael, sister of Lawrence and Armond Siegel. Grandmother of two. Services were by Beecher Funeral Home.

title: White House Panel Urges Voluntary Political TV Advertising
description: A bipartisan commission appointed by the White House to recommend what television broadcasters must do in exchange for their free licenses to use thousands of new channels is to submit its report today with watered-down voluntary measures on political advertising and on educational or public-affairs programs.

title: After Making a Deal for Palffy, Isles Score and Win in Overtime
description: The offense-starved Islanders, humbled by a recent seven-game losing streak and faced with a trade moratorium, decided today that enough was enough.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Holiday Albums; VINCE GILL: ''BREATH OF HEAVEN'' (MCA).
description: Warning: Vince Gill may be a country singer but this is not a country album. Read the fine print: ''A Christmas collection, with Patrick Williams and his Orchestra.'' It includes 10 of the expected warhorses and the title track, a ballad written by the singer Amy Grant. To paraphrase something Frank Zappa said about one of his own records, you should not listen to this record. You should pour it on your Christmas-morning pancakes. BEN RATLIFF

title: Deal Allows Partial Return Of Preachers To Times Sq.
description: The city has agreed to allow a group of street preachers to return to Times Square in a partial settlement of a dispute in which the group had contended that the Giuliani administration was trying to stifle its right to free expression.

title: Microsoft Says It Didn't Alter Internet Site
description: Stung by a Government witness's testimony that the Microsoft Corporation had sabotaged a program designed to gather evidence against the company, lawyers for the software giant today offered the court an unusual written explanation.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; LINTON KWESI JOHNSON: ''INDEPENDANT INTAVENSHAN'' (Island).
description: The pairing of Mr. Johnson, a Jamaican-born political poet living in London, with Dennis Bovell's Dub Band resulted in some of the great records of the 1980's and some of the great political music in any period. There were no weak links: tight, pulsing reggae with horns, Mr. Bovell's wise dub mixing (he never let the music get lost in a fog) and Mr. Johnson's linear morality tales about police brutality and English racism, read in a calm, professorial, West Indian voice. This double CD anthology collects the best of the albums ''Forces of Victory,'' ''LKJ in Dub,'' ''Bass Culture,'' and ''Making History'' and some singles; dub versions are interweaved with their straight prototypes. BEN RATLIFF

title: On the Highway to Impeachment, Several Exit Ramps Still Beckon
description: As Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee propelled the nation down the superhighway toward impeachment, they sped past a number of exits, places where history, tradition or a different understanding of the Constitution offered a path to another outcome.

description: ''Hellbent'' is the word for Republicans at this eerie moment, and what they are hellbent on is the destruction of President Clinton.

description: The American public overwhelmingly supports the military action in Iraq and accepts President Clinton's explanation about its timing and its purpose, according to four national polls taken on Wednesday evening after the bombing began.

description: Russia recalled its ambassador to Washington today for consultations as a protest for United States' air strikes against Iraq, Moscow's angriest riposte against American policy since the end of the cold war.

title: Fairy Tale? Musical Comedy? Nope, Biblical Epic
description: As a film bearing Dreamworks's great expectations and the scrutiny of so many religious advisers, ''The Prince of Egypt'' is one animated biblical epic with understandable jitters. What it meant to achieve, a new breakthrough for the animator's art and a sacrosanct yet frisky entertainment for viewers large and small, may have been as impossible as it sounds. But ''The Prince of Egypt'' is a well-made work with much to recommend it, even if its worthiness is not the brightest flare on the movie horizon this season.

title: A Snowy February, 1868: How a Distant Postwar Drama Played Out
description: When impeachment came, after long months of legislative stalemate and partisan struggle over how to rebuild the Union, it came swiftly. No long-winded preliminaries in committee hearings. No careful testing of the political waters back home.

title: More Reports Of I.O.C. Favors Emerge in Utah
description: The son of a leading International Olympic Committee member from Africa worked as an intern at City Hall while Salt Lake was attempting to become the host city for the 2002 Winter Games, the mayor's office said today. The admission raised more questions about the extent to which an effort was made to sway votes in landing the Olympics.

title: Contract Dispute Cancels Carnegie Hall Concerts
description: Concerts scheduled for tonight and tomorrow at Carnegie Hall have been canceled because of a contract dispute between the management of the New York Pops and the musicians who play in the orchestra.

description: A North Korean vessel that intruded deep into South Korea's waters was pursued and sunk this morning after a firefight with South Korean forces, South Korean officials said today.

title: TRIZECHAHN BUYS OFFICE PROPERTIES AFTER SELLING MALLS
description: The TrizecHahn Corporation of Toronto said yesterday that it had completed the sale of its United States shopping mall holdings for $2.5 billion and had reinvested $1.5 billion of the proceeds in office properties. TrizecHahn agreed to sell the 20 malls in April to Westfield America Inc. of Los Angeles and to the Rouse Company of Columbia, Md. Among of the office properties it bought are 12 buildings from the Equitable Life Assurance Society for $561 million. It also bought Laing Properties Inc., a unit of the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company of Britain, which owns nine office and warehouse properties, for $300 million, and the Silver Spring Metro Plaza in Silver Spring, Md., for $91 million.

title: Funds for Smaller Classes
description: The New York State Board of Regents has proposed spending $394 million in additional state aid next year to help students primarily in impoverished and rural school districts reach the state's more rigorous learning standards. It also wants $491 million more for operating and building aid to schools throughout the state. The plan is sound. But the Regents are misguided in recommending that $75 million of the increased aid come from money that would otherwise be used for reducing class sizes in kindergarten through third grade.

title: U.S. General Defends Chats At Panmunjom
description: PANMUNJOM  The U.S. general in charge of military negotiations with North Koreans in this truce village has defended informal gatherings with North Korean Army officers, saying that cutting off such contacts would close an important channel for easing tensions.

title: Making the Very Walls Part of the Sculpture
description: As far as New York is concerned, it may be a case of too much too late for Reinhard Mucha, the famous yet elusive German sculptor and installation artist. His second New York exhibition, in the form of simultaneous shows at the Chelsea galleries of Luhring Augustine and Murray Guy, provides the city's first in-depth look at his art.

title: A Spirited Defense of Clinton Thrusts Gore Into the Spotlight
description: With bombs falling on Iraq and an impeachment vote nearing in the House, Vice President Al Gore has taken an unusually visible role in defending President Clinton and the military actions that have provoked skepticism from many Republicans.

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; MARVIN GAYE: ''MIDNIGHT LOVE AND THE SEXUAL HEALING SESSIONS''  (Columbia/Legacy).
description: Marvin Gaye was torn between confession and commercialism when he made ''Midnight Love'' in 1982, his last studio album before his father shot him dead in 1984. He chose his commercial side, returning to the come-ons that had served him so well with ''Let's Get It On,'' and ''Sexual Healing'' gave him both the hit he wanted and another indelible song. This two-CD set, pairing the original album with alternate versions and outtakes of its songs, reveals some of the changes Gaye made; altering rhythms, editing, bringing out hooks and replacing lyrics about trouble and uncertainty with promises of pleasure. Hearing vocal parts by themselves for some songs shows that Gaye never left doo-wop behind. But the best part of the expanded album is that it provides extended versions of Gaye's supple, undulating grooves, an ingenious and constantly mutating blend of electronics, funk, Caribbean rhythms and deep soul. JON PARELES

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Hits and Live Albums; TOM WAITS: ''BEAUTIFUL MALADIES: THE ISLAND YEARS (Island).
description: As a general rule, label compilations like this are generally an effort to squeeze more money out of the catalogue of an artist who has left the record company. If this one is an exception, it's only because Mr. Waits produced and compiled it, sequencing the songs sonically and thematically instead of chronologically. It collects tracks from each album he recorded for Island, beginning in 1983, which represented a stylistic shift for the stertorous Mr. Waits expanding his skid-row cabaret with more difficult and unconventional yet more focused, inventive and theatrical material. Though the CD makes a good companion to the earlier ''Asylum Years'' collection, for Tom Waits fans, ''Beautiful Maladies'' is just familiar songs in a new sequence. And for the newcomer, a much better place to start would be a fully realized Waits album on Island, like ''Rain Dogs'' or ''Bone Machine.'' NEIL STRAUSS

It's party music, joyous and rocking; there's a lot of talk of beer and food. Jesus comes up a bit, and what a good night it is to party and dance. As kitschy as it is, there's so much fun on the record, the kitsch vanishes, and what's left is good will. PETER WATROUS

title: Pop Go the Holidays (With Jazz, Reggae and Rap) -- Holiday Albums; ETTA JAMES: ''12 SONGS OF CHRISTMAS'' (Private Music)
description: The famously bawdy Etta James turns surprisingly reverent on her Christmas album, which turns standard songs from ''Winter Wonderland'' to ''O Holy Night'' into suave after-hours jazz arrangements, most of them by the pianist Cedar Walton. Ms. James sings rarely heard verses of songs like ''Jingle Bells,'' and she shares solo space with Mr. Walton, Red Holloway on tenor saxophone and George Bohanon on trombone. Though she growls a little, she never belts; she makes the songs seem cozy and intimate. Her voice is bluesy and nonchalant until she reaches songs like ''Joy to The World,'' in which she sounds downright devout. JON PARELES

Hastings, Democrat of Florida, on the articles of impeachment against President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency. Mr. Hastings was subsequently convicted by the Senate and removed from the bench.

description: William Box Cook, associate director of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago, died on Tuesday at his home in Chicago. He was 48.

title: About New York; Fire Shows That All Pain Starts at Home
description: THE reports of a fire on Vandalia Avenue in Brooklyn jolted Ricco Sanchez into reality. Forget the near-numbing talk about Presidential impeachment or the almost emotionless descriptions of the smart bombs and surgical strikes in Baghdad. Fire? That's big news in Mr. Sanchez's part of the world. His grandmother lives on Vandalia Avenue, and he wasn't sure if the flames had ripped through her building or the one next door.

title: Both Sides in Ulster Carve Out Crucial Accord on Cabinet
description: For the first time since Ireland was partitioned in 1922, leaders of Northern Ireland's Protestant majority and its Roman Catholic minority agreed early today to specific reforms that will give Catholics more power in this British province.

title: Surprise Drop in Rates By Hong Kong's Banks
description: Hong Kong banks announced yesterday a surprise quarter-point cut in interest rates that demonstrated a rare show of independence from United States credit policy. The reduction in the bank prime rate to 9 percent from 9.25 percent is the fifth this year, for a total of 1.25 percentage points. The move came amid calls for an easier credit policy from some quarters as Hong Kong continues to endure a deep recession.

title: Leonard Rieser, 76, Opponent Of Arsenal He Helped Create
description: Leonard Moos Rieser, a physicist who helped usher in the nuclear age with the Manhattan Project and crusaded to curb the arsenals it spawned, died on Tuesday at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, N.H. He was 76 and lived in Norwich, Vt.

title: Plan to Bury Nuclear Waste in Nevada Moves Forward
description: The Energy Department reported today that it had found ''no show stoppers'' so far to block its plan to bury much of the nation's nuclear waste in the Nevada desert near Las Vegas and that it was on schedule to make a formal recommendation to the President by 2001.

title: Allianz and Munich Re To Trade Some Holdings
description: The German insurer Allianz A.G. said yesterday that it had reached agreement with the reinsurer Munchener Ruckversicherungs-Gesellschaft A.G., or Munich Re, on a previously announced restructuring. Allianz will receive Munich Re's holdings of some 15 percent of Allianz of America and nearly 4 percent of Allianz Lebensversicherungs A.G., its domestic unit. In return, Munich Re will take on shares representing nearly 6.5 percent of Allianz's Ergo Versicherungsgruppe A.G. subsidiary and around 6.9 percent of the American Re Corporation.

David E. Schwab II, Chairman Leon Botstein, President

title: Comments on the Speaker-Elect

title: DUKE TO BUY AUSTRALIAN COMPANY'S POWER UNIT
description: The Duke Energy Corporation, the largest utility holding company in the United States, agreed yesterday to buy the Broken Hill Proprietary Company's power unit for $315 million in cash. The acquisition is Duke's second in Australia this year. The company will acquire power plants with a total capacity of 400 megawatts and an 11.8 percent interest in a 600-mile gas pipeline in western Australia. The transaction is expected to be completed early next year. Duke, based in Charlotte, N.C., has investments in more than 50 countries.

title: Queens Jury Spares Convicted Killer From Death Penalty
description: After deliberating for three days, a Queens jury yesterday spared the life of a 26-year-old man who was convicted of murdering three women and trying to kill two others.

title: With Blustery Bravado Through a Saxophone
description: The saxophonist James Carter isn't a self-styled avant-gardist; he doesn't associate much with that stripe of jazz musician, and he's clearly interested in communicating with his audience on a gut level. But for a musician with so much talent, his lack of the long view is puzzling. Over the past five years he has built a jazz career on wrecking houses with oversize bluster, as he plays music that borrows styles ranging from New Orleans music to swing to free. And his continued interest in the physical intensity coming from his own horn, as opposed to small-group craft, is starting to seem like a self-conscious bid for obsolescence.

title: The Folks on Catfish Row in Concert
description: Claims for ''Porgy and Bess'' as the greatest opera by an American composer never feel quite right. For one thing, they presume a category -- American opera -- that has few binding characteristics and even fewer outstanding constituents. Those claims also imply that there is a difference between opera and musical theater, whereas every measure of ''Porgy'' insists that there really is not. Then again, Gershwin's achievement declines comparisons. It is incomparable, and certainly during the six decades and more since it was first produced, nothing with which to compare it has come along.

title: Memo From Moscow; Impeachment Over Sex? Try Genocide or Treason
description: If Russians are perplexed by the prospective impeachment of President Clinton over his testimony about extramarital sex -- and they are, to a man and woman -- perhaps they can be forgiven. Their own Parliament, you see, is trying to impeach President Boris N. Yeltsin over accusations of genocide, treason and abetting murder. And almost no one gives it a second thought.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR WEAKENS. Political uncertainty over the probable House vote to impeach President Clinton diminished foreign investor demand for the dollar. It fell to 115.61 yen from 116.13, and fell to 1.6641 marks from 1.6681.

description: ''I think the vast majority of Americans share my approval and pride in the job that the President's been doing for our country.''

title: The House Comes to Order
description: No minds were changed, no impulse to substitute censure for impeachment suddenly seized the Republicans, but at least the bitterly partisan debate that rang through the House chamber yesterday was relatively dignified. Having backed the country into this grim corner, the Republicans did their best to cloak their partisan enmity in constitutional trappings. Some of the speeches, including Henry Hyde's impassioned defense of the rule of law, were stirring. But even moments of soaring language could not alter the granite fact that the misconduct at issue does not warrant the impeachment and removal of President Clinton.

title: Boat Capsizes Near Miami; 8 Cubans Die
description: At least eight people were killed late Thursday night and nine were still missing today after a pleasure boat carrying 26 Cubans capsized off one of the keys that make up Biscayne National Park, Coast Guard officials said. The officials described the incident as a probable case of immigrant smuggling.

Wolf, PhD. who served as research professor in the Department of Psychiatry. title: Transparent Enough To Hide Behind
description: Transparency is not just for glass, water and lies anymore. There are transparent cities, transparent economies, transparent countries. Musical performances and compositions are praised for their transparency. And some cosmologists even call the earliest glimpse of the universe ''the moment of transparency.''

On Thursday at Madison Square Garden, 1998's zippiest pop playthings turned on for a bewitched, almost entirely teen-age audience at the Jingle Ball, the annual festival of hits sponsored by the radio station Z-100.

description: As the acrid, rueful and righteous debate went through the hours today, the House stood poised to do what even some of its own Republican leaders once considered unimaginable: impeach a Democratic President on a near party-line vote against the will of the electorate.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES WILL CLOSE FIVE PLANTS
description: Flowers Industries, the maker of Famous Amos cookies and Mrs. Smith's pies, said yesterday that it would take a $70 million charge in the fourth quarer to close five plants. The company. based in Thomasville, Ga., said the charge would amount to $40 million, or 40 cents a share, after taxes. The plant closings are expected to result in cost savings of $16 million in 1999 and about $6 million annually thereafter. Flowers is the majority owner of the second-biggest cookie maker in the United States, the Keebler Foods Company, and also operaties Flowers Bakeries and Mrs. Smith's Bakeries. After the plant closings, the company, which has annual revenues of more than $700 million, will have 34 production facilities.

title: Sweetener Gets Approval, a Scientist Says
description: A Government advisory group has voted to give a clean bill of health to the artificial sweetener saccharin, which, despite its pink-packeted presence on restaurant tables everywhere, has been classified since 1981 as a suspected cause of cancer.

title: Memorial for Joe Baum
description: A memorial tribute to the late Joseph H. Baum, the innovative restaurateur behind New York restaurants like Windows on the World and the renovated Rainbow Room, will take place at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, on Monday at 4 P.M. Among those scheduled to speak at the tribute to Mr. Baum, who died on Oct. 5, are the banker David Rockefeller, the designer Milton Glaser, the restaurant critic Mimi Sheraton and the architect Hugh Hardy. The public is invited.

title: Albany's Slapdash Deals
description: ''There's gray smoke -- actually it's gray tilting toward white,'' Gov. George Pataki quipped during a break in negotiations over New York State's charter school legislation. Likening his backroom talks with legislative leaders to the secretive manner used by the College of Cardinals to select a new pope was distressingly apt. The Governor pushed through legislation empowering nonprofit groups to open taxpayer-financed charter schools without any hearings or the debate it deserved. New York will now join more than 30 states with charter school statutes, and Mr. Pataki will have a policy that appeals to conservatives should he choose to run in G.O.P. Presidential primaries in 2000.

title: U.S. Reports Mixed Results on 89 Targets in Iraq
description: On the third day of the air assault on Iraq, the Pentagon said today that it was able to confirm that only 18 of its 89 targets had been severely damaged or destroyed, despite waves of bombers and more laser-guided cruise missiles than were hurled at Iraq during the Persian Gulf war in 1991.

title: Swiss Company Will Cut Jobs and Shed 2 Units

SGS, a Geneva-based company that once earned as much as three-quarters of its profit monitoring imports and exports, said the reorganization would result in a 1998 loss of about 300 million Swiss francs ($222 million). It expects a profit of as much as 100 million francs next year.

title: Journal; Let It Bleed
description: Surreal, unreal, mind-blowing: these are words of the 60's, and it's no wonder they returned to vogue this week. Not since a tottering Presidency, a divisive war, assassinations, civic unrest and bitter partisanship overloaded the American psyche in 1968 has there been a spectacle to match this moment. ''Split-screen America'' we call it now. It's not happenstance that split-screen technology also became a Hollywood fad in movies like ''The Thomas Crown Affair'' in 1968. When society cracks, the mind follows, and artists must concoct new forms to keep pace.
