title: BORG-WARNER TO ACQUIRE A TURBOCHARGER CONCERN
description: Responding to a growing worldwide demand for diesel engines, the automotive-parts maker Borg-Warner Automotive Inc. plans to acquire the Kuhlman Corporation, a supplier of turbochargers and other auto parts, for $39 a share, a total of $660 million. Borg-Warner said Kuhlman's $300 million electrical transformer and wire and cable businesses would be sold, because the operations were outside its ''strategic focus.'' Under the agreement, Borg-Warner, which is based in Chicago, will pay a combination of cash and $150 million in stock. It will also assume a portion of Kuhlman's debt. Kuhlman's stock jumped $5.875 a share, to $37.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Borg-Warner's stock was down 81.85 cents at $50.75.

title: To the Barricades, 25 Years Later
description: ''All the legitimacy of a coup d'etat,'' is how the novelist E. L. Doctorow described the impeachment proceedings against President Clinton at a rally of artists and intellectuals at New York University this week.

title: Taylor Surrenders to Police
description: Lawrence Taylor, the former Giants linebacker, turned himself in to the police in Teaneck, N.J., on Thursday to face charges of drug possession and the possession of drug paraphernalia, the authorities said yesterday. Taylor surrendered at Teaneck police headquarters without incident and was released on his own recognizance after posting a $2,500 bond, said Capt. Paul Tiernan of the Teaneck Police Department.

title: Struggling L.I.U. Seeks New Identity
description: They are struggling to learn a new offense. They shoot free throws as if the ball were a boulder. And the electricity that had surrounded them the past two seasons has fizzled.

title: Topics of The Times; Reading William Gaddis
description: The difficulty William Gaddis presents to a reader is this: learning to follow the mercurial glance of a writer who gives you no warning where he will look next but who always looks with rapt attention and who commands raptness in the language itself.

title: Be Tough on Iraq And on Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. ROUNDUP
description: ATLANTA

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANTON, HELEN LAFETRA
description: STANTON-Helen LaFetra. Died peacefully at her home on December 15, 1998, age 98. She was the widow of Louis Lee Stanton. Mother of Ann S. Warden, Louis L. Stanton Jr. and the late Dixon LaFetra Stanton. Also survived by ten grandchildren and 13 greatgrandchildren. Service to be held at 1:30pm on Saturday, December 19th at St. James's Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and 71st. Street, NYC.

title: KING PHARMACEUTICALS TO BUY 3 DRUGS FOR $362.5 MILLION
description: King Pharmaceuticals Inc., a maker and marketer of brand-name and generic drugs, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy three drugs from Hoechst Marion Roussel Inc. for $362.5 million. King, based in Bristol, Tenn., said it had agreed to buy the United States rights to Altace, a drug used to reduce blood pressure; AVC, a vaginal anti-infective cream, and Silvadene, a cream for treating burns. Net sales for the three drugs were $91.3 million in 1997 and $71.5 million in the first nine months of 1998. Hoechst Marion Roussel, a unit of the German pharmaceutical group Hoechst A.G., will retain the rights to Altace outside the United States.

title: Stolen-Property Inquiry Ends With 12 Arrests
description: A dozen Cumberland County residents have been arrested and accused of being members of a criminal enterprise in which stolen goods were sold over the counter at four bodegas in South Jersey, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: New Trustee of City Union Upbraids Top Officials
description: The newly appointed trustee of New York City's largest municipal union lashed out at the union's top officials yesterday, saying they had engaged in large-scale, unrestrained spending, including more than $300,000 in unexplained credit card expenses and the creation of what he called a $2 million slush fund.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits in Weekend yesterday with a television review of ''Health Diary'' on WLIW, Channel 21 on Long Island, misstated the show's starting time. It is today at 3:30 P.M., not 3.

title: Race a Factor in N.B.A. Dispute?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Battle Finds a Small Community Split
description: The guys sitting around the dinette tables at V.F.W. Post 3500 on Big Bend Boulevard, silently swirling their foam cups of beer, stared up at the eerie green picture on the television screen behind the bar. ''Here we go again,'' someone said. There were flashes of white light in the night-vision sky over Baghdad and a sound like firecracker pops followed by deep rumbles.

title: Be Tough on Iraq And on Clinton; The Pandora Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: Full Strength Against Ukraine
description: The United States women's national team, one of the favorites to win the Women's World Cup next summer, will be back at normal strength for tomorrow's exhibition rematch with Ukraine, four days after a lesser version took the field. The regulars had threatened to skip tomorrow's game unless their two-year-old contract with the United States Soccer Federation was altered.

title: Topics of The Times; Judge Higginbotham's Path
description: The son of a cleaning woman and a laborer, raised in a segregated New Jersey town, A. Leon Higginbotham Jr. rose to become a respected Federal appellate judge and legal historian. His productive career following his 1993 retirement from the bench spanned the worlds of Harvard University, where he taught, and the corporate boards on which he served, including that of The New York Times Company.

title: 3 Firefighters Die Trying to Rescue a Woman in Brooklyn
description: Three New York City firefighters who were trying to rescue an elderly woman from her top-floor Brooklyn apartment were killed yesterday when a fireball engulfed them as it swept through the narrow hallway, fire officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PULLIS, JAMES (KNOWN TO FRIENDS AS JP)
description: PULLIS-James (known to friends as JP). On December 18, 1998. Beloved brother of Gerard, Roger, John, and George. Cherished uncle of Roger Jr., Christopher, John, Thomas, Theresa, Timothy, Matthew, Patricia, Antoninette, Genevieve and Meg. Loyal friend to many. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Saturday 2-5 and 7-9PM and Sunday 2-5PM. Funeral mass is at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, on Monday, at 9:30 A.M. Interment to follow at St. Charles cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the T.J. Martell Foundation for Leukemia, Cancer and AIDS Research, 6 West 57 Street, New York, N.Y. 10019.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM FALLS 5.5 PERCENT. Prices dropped from a five-month high, hurt by speculation that Russia, the leading producer of the metal, had increased year-end shipments. The March contract fell $18.10 an ounce, to $308.80.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. Malvin dear, your life's accomplishments, your kindness, loyalty and love, are our legacy; never to be forgotten. We love you. Audrey, Irik and Jaar-mel

title: Man Accused of Abusing Boys He Met on Internet
description: A Howard Beach man who the police say used the Internet to lure young boys to a Long Island park has been charged with two counts of sexual abuse, the police said.

title: 3 Networks Offer Stations Soap Operas And Debate
description: The House impeachment debate commanded the full attention of the big broadcast networks and the all-news cable networks for most of yesterday morning, but eventually gave way to occasional reports from Iraq and ultimately, for most network stations, to the attraction of soap operas.

title: A Silver Lining Can Emerge From a Bid Made in Futility
description: Every bridge player has had the following unhappy experience. He or she is about to be declarer, and even before the lead is made, it is obvious that the contract is ridiculous. There may be a silver lining. If the vulnerability is favorable, it will be profitable to go down, even by quite a few tricks, if the opponents can make a game.

title: Clinton's Ratings Take Dip in West Bank
description: When President Clinton came to town this week, Tanya Ghattas took her four children, gave them American flags and went out to greet the unusual visitor.

title: Waiting and Worrying At a Busy Army Base
description: All along the thin ribbons of blacktop that connect Fort Stewart with the rest of the world, homemade signs hang from the pines to welcome home soldiers returning from postings overseas. The welcomes, to ''Leigh'' and ''Boo-Hoo'' and others, are painted in giant letters on bedsheets, so that the returning husbands, wives, mothers, fathers and sweethearts cannot possibly miss them as they drive in.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend yesterday about the musical ''Parade,'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center, used the name of the character instead of the actor in a reference to the role of the factory janitor. The character, Jim Conley, is played by Rufus Bonds Jr.

title: BASKETBALL: COLLEGE MEN
description: S.E.C. Reprimands Two for Comments

title: Restitution and the Problem of Stolen Art
description: It is hard to escape the questions -- ''Why so late?'' and ''Why only now?'' -- that Elie Wiesel asked in a speech at the opening of the recent Conference on Holocaust-Era Assets, held at the Holocaust Museum in Washington. His questions reflect the vigorous effort to sort out the assets, including missing or stolen artworks, that once belonged to Jews who died in the Holocaust. But the pungent implication in Mr. Wiesel's words is this: What has kept the world, until the past few years, from committing itself to the burden of disentangling the global effects of Hitler's spoliation?

title: Public Anger In Moscow Is Tempered In Private
description: Despite Moscow's anger over the bombing of Iraq, and the recall of its Ambassador from Washington, Russian officials' private conversations with Americans reflect a desire to take the edge off the acrimony, senior American officials said today.

title: WITH PARTISAN RANCOR, A BITTER HOUSE DEBATES THE PRESIDENT'S IMPEACHMENT
description: For the first time since Feb. 24, 1868, three years after the United States emerged from an awful Civil War, the House of Representatives debated the impeachment of a President today.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP TO ACQUIRE RAMAPO FINANCIAL
description: Valley National Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Ramapo Financial Corporation of Wayne, N.J., for $99.6 million in stock. Valley National, also based in Wayne, will pay 0.425 share for each Ramapo share. Valley National has $5.3 billion in assets and operates 105 branches in Passaic, Morris and Essex counties in New Jersey. Ramapo Financial is the parent of Ramapo Bank, which has $331 million in assets and eight branches. The shares of Ramapo Financial jumped 33 percent, to $10.875, in Nasdaq trading, gaining $2.75 a share. Valley National's shares fell $1.375, to $27.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: The Thirst to Finish First: Is It the Jets' Turn Again?
description: It has never happened quite this way for the Jets, to be standing just 60 minutes away from a division crown. But a victory this afternoon in Buffalo against the Bills will propel them to a division title for the first time since their last year in the American Football League, back in 1969.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACHESON, DAVID
description: ACHESON-David, 83 yrs of Essex, Connecticut, died on December 18. Husband of Jane (Hickman) Acheson. Funeral Sunday, December 20th, at 2 P.M. at the Essex Congregational Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, MURIEL
description: BERGER-Muriel. Beloved mother of Jeffrey and Carin Baskin. Loving sister of Dr. Robert Bernstein. Cherished grandmother of Bernie, Meredith, Danny and Rebecca. Services Sunday, 1 PM, at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York. Intement following at Beth Moses Cemetery.

title: Talking Heads on Network TV Upstage Those in the House
description: The television screen showed the House of Representatives more than three-quarters empty. And if Congress wasn't watching, why should we? The House floor was meant to be the site of history-making drama, but the action yesterday was all off-stage. It was definitely on camera, though, captured in the talk of reporters and commentators who helped shape the political spin and strategies.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSTRIES, Middlebury, Conn., a maker of telecommunications equipment, will lay off 200 employees, or 14 percent of its work force, and restructure its business to focus more on network access and broad-band markets.

title: The Devils Let Their Defense Slip
description: After scoring five or more goals in five straight games, the Devils regressed on offense tonight. They played below their standard defensively, as well, and the result was that their 10-game unbeaten streak at Continental Arena ended in a 5-2 loss to the Calgary Flames.

title: An All-Star Team of Balloonists Sets Out to Conquer the World
description: A 160-foot-high balloon piloted by an all-star team of long-distance balloonists rose from its launching pad yesterday at Marrakesh, Morocco, to begin a voyage that the balloonists hope will take them around the world in 10 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, JOHN E.
description: HOFFMAN-John E., 83. Of Roslyn Heights, on December 17, 1998. Devoted husband of Joan. Loving father of Philip, Hilde Agatstein and Julien. Beloved grandfather of Gregg, Justin and David. Dear father-in-law of Henry and Diane. Cherished uncle to his nieces and nephews, friend to many. The family would appreciate donations in his name to the NYC Ballet or The Central Park Conservancy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTON, EMANUEL
description: PASTON-Emanuel. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Devoted father of Frances, Kenneth and Edward. Dear brother of Mary Zaretsky, Frances Levison and the late Sadie Levison, Dora Rosen & Simon Paston. Loving grandfather of Craig Mitchell Paston and Lorrie Alice Paston. Services on Sunday 10AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Dry Toes In Watery Fancies
description: By performing three works by Alvin Ailey on Wednesday night at the City Center, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater gave a good impression of its founder's choreographic range. The evening concluded with the ever welcome ''Revelations,'' Ailey's danced interpretation of spirituals. But before that came revivals of two contrasting pieces, ''The River'' and ''Masekela Langage.''

title: CLINTON REPORTED AS VERY TROUBLED
description: Mindful as ever of his standing in history, President Clinton is said by associates to feel devastated about a scar he now regards as inevitable: impeachment on Saturday by the House of Representatives.

title: Religion Journal; Mandela's Note in Praise of Missionaries
description: Early generations of Christian missionaries from Europe and the United States often fared poorly in the popular media. They have been depicted in novels and films as arrogant or, worse, tools of colonial adventurers.

title: Chinese Reminded: No Opposition Allowed
description: In a pointed speech delivered to Communist Party members in the Great Hall of the People, President Jiang Zemin made clear today that China's economic reforms were not a prelude to Western-style multiparty democracy and that those who challenged the party's supremacy would be quashed.

title: House Voting Comes First
description: Viewers of today's crucial Jets-Bills game at 12:30 P.M. on Channel 2 could experience interruptions from CBS News's coverage of the impeachment vote in the House of Representatives.

title: The Debate on Articles of Impeachment Against President Clinton
description: Following are excerpts from the House debate today on article of impeachment against President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Alltel Buying Top Phone Company in Nebraska for $1.5 Billion
description: The Alltel Corporation, a telecommunications company based in Little Rock, Ark., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Aliant Communications Inc., a Midwestern telephone company, for $1.5 billion in stock.

title: Distinct Phrases Wrapped in Silence
description: A good way to understand the music of the singer and pianist Shirley Horn is to isolate her phrases, to listen to the way each of her utterances comes out fully formed and distinct. When she sings she lets silence frame the improvisations; the phrases hang there to be absorbed, each with its own melody and its own texture.

title: The Adultery Wars
description: After the famously adulterous theologian Paul Tillich died, someone said about him, ''He wanted to be counted in on every human failing.'' What I love about the eulogy is that it manages empathy and morality at once. Adultery is a very human desire, as well as an all too human failing.

title: Major Importer Is Accused of Smuggling Caviar
description: Uncovering what it called a caviar smuggling scheme worth millions of dollars, the Federal Government yesterday indicted three men, two of whom run a distributing company that supplies caviar to retail shops and restaurants in New York City, as well as throughout the country.

title: Setback for Unit Of Time Warner
description: Time Warner Inc., the world's largest media company, said yesterday that its Time Warner Entertainment partnership and other parties had lost a $197 million jury verdict related to its former interest in the Six Flags Over Georgia theme park.

title: Young and Fightless, They Wait for a Chance at the I.B.F. Heavyweight Championship
description: David Tua and Hasim Rahman are in the no-man's land of boxing's heavyweight division. They are young, they hit hard and no one who has a world title or who has designs on winning a world championship wants to fight them.

title: U.N. Is Urged to Plan For Nuclear Inspections
description: When the bombing of Iraq ends, arms control experts say, the United Nations Security Council should not abandon inspections but should quickly reimpose rigorous monitoring in every area of weapons development.

title: White House Tries to Stifle Any Whispers Of Resigning
description: The White House is already bracing for a new battle: tamping down anticipated pressure on President Clinton to resign.

title: Hustler Behind Sex Story
description: It was, in some ways, perhaps inevitable that the publisher of Hustler magazine, Larry Flynt, would immerse himself in the infidelities of President Clinton and other Washington politicians.

title: Corrections
description: A map in Business Day on Oct. 26 with an article about the gradual changeover to digital television misstated the affiliation of WITF in Harrisburg, Pa., which was among the first to broadcast digitally. The station telephoned this week to say that it is affiliated with PBS, not ABC.

title: Things Are Going From Bad To Better for the Islanders
description: When the Islanders embarked on a four-game West Coast trip after losing seven straight games, their playoff outlook was bleak and their collective attitude was bleaker.

title: Crew Assails Albany Accord On Opening Charter Schools
description: Hours after Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature agreed on a charter school plan coupled with a cherished pay raise for lawmakers, the New York City Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, railed against the school plan today, warning that it was ''fraught with peril.''

title: Howard W. Chalk, 76, Former Ad Executive
description: Howard Wolfe Chalk, an advertising executive, died on Dec. 12 at Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. Mr. Chalk, a resident of Cortlandt Manor, N.Y., was 76.

title: Amid It All, Finding Time For Festivity
description: The President, some of his aides say, no longer picks up the phone late at night as frequently as he used to to reach out to friends. One, who once talked to him daily, hasn't heard from him since Thanksgiving. Another tells members of Mr. Clinton's inner circle that the President is down and urges them to call him and get his political fires burning again.

title: Amgen Wins One Against Johnson & Johnson
description: Amgen Inc., the world's leading biotechnology company, won all rights to a once-a-week version of its $3 billion anemia drug in an arbitration battle with Johnson & Johnson, the companies said today.

title: Sentences Handed Down In Police Burglary Ring
description: Two former Palisades Park police officers who ran a burglary ring out of police headquarters were sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court here.

title: Be Tough on Iraq And on Clinton; What's the Truth?
description: To the Editor:

title: No Davis Cup for No. 1 Sampras
description: Pete Sampras does not consider himself a political animal, but after bypassing 1998 Davis Cup duty as part of his successful quest to finish the year at No. 1 for a record-breaking sixth straight season, he has confirmed that his 1999 Davis Cup policy will again be hard-line: he will not play.

title: A Primer on the Styles of Ailey
description: The ''Ailey Classics'' program, presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Thursday night at City Center, is a good introduction to the company, its repertory and the art of Alvin Ailey, who created the dances. The program, which will be repeated tonight at City Center (131 West 55th Street), also offers new insights into familiar works, raising some questions along the way.

title: Everyone Is Always on Nature's Side; People Just Can't Agree on What's Natural and What's Not
description: When people look for nature without adornment, they often end up in Alaska, the American Eden. But five years ago, the Governor of Alaska said something was horribly out of whack in the wilds of the Last Frontier State. There were too many wolves, he felt. Wolves eat moose, the preferred prey of human hunters. To keep more moose alive so they can be shot by predators on two feet, wolves had to be killed, the Governor said.

title: Be Tough on Iraq And on Clinton; Credit for Honesty,
description: To the Editor:

title: I.O.C. Begins Mending a Possible Tear in Integrity
description: There have long been allegations, suggestions and assumptions of corruption among the International Olympic Committee, whose oligarchic, undemocratic structure and penchant for choosing the host city's finest hotel has hardly helped discourage such chatter.

title: Russia Has Some Good News For Those Who Bought Bonds
description: Russia's Finance Ministry today clarified the terms for its restructuring of 281 billion rubles ($13.5 billion) in defaulted Treasury debt, indicating that some investors will receive more cash than initially expected.

title: Nasdaq Leads Advances on All Markets
description: Investors seemed nonchalant yesterday as the debate on the impeachment of President Clinton got under way and the bombing of Iraq continued. Stocks rose, with the Nasdaq index surging 2 percent to a new high, while the other major indexes rose modestly. Bond prices inched higher while the dollar slipped.

title: Ethics Panel to Begin Bribe Investigation
description: The organizing committee for the 2002 Winter Olympics today empowered its ethics panel to begin investigating whether bribes were offered to secure the Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHAN, JAMES
description: BOHAN-James. Firefighter 4th Grade. Ladder 170, formerly Engine 262, F.D.N.Y. Suddenly on December 17, 1998 in the line of duty. Devoted son of John and Margaret (nee Condon) Bohan. Loving brother of Maurice. Loving grandson of Maurice Condon of Loughill County Limerick, Ireland. Also survived by his loving finacee Audrey Frlic, his aunts and uncles Jimmy and Maureen Bohan of Dublin, Jim and Mary Callaghan, Eddy and Kathleen Bohan, Pete and Kathleen Vaughn and Brigid and Timothy O'Sullivan and cousins Eamon, Pauline, Betty and Marie Bohan, Jimmy, Eddy and Pat Callaghan, Michelle, John and Edward Bohan, Shelia Vaughn and Mary, Katy, Julia and Timothy O'Sullivan. Reposing at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 710PM. Funeral Monday. Mass at Saint Margaret's Church, Middle Village (times will follow). Interment Mount Saint Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory to the FDNY-Cornell Burn Unit would be appreciated. ''Jim will be dearly missed by his brothers of Engine 257, Engine 262, Ladder 170 and Battalion 58.''

title: A Senate Trial Can Be Both Political and Fair
description: As the prospect of President Clinton's impeachment trial looms, senators have been speculating about how to behave if they must conduct such a trial. Even before the House Judiciary Committee voted on articles of impeachment, several senators had invoked the ideal of the impartial juror as an exemplar. ''We may have to sit as jurors,'' Senator Robert Byrd, a Democrat from West Virginia, said in October in response to White House efforts to prevent an impeachment inquiry. ''Don't let it be said that we allowed ourselves to be tampered with.''

title: Ramadan Fast: Pillar of Islam
description: Ramadan, the holy month of dawn-to-dusk fasting in the Islamic calendar, begins this weekend, the exact timing depending on the sighting of the new crescent moon.

title: Sports of The Times; Still Special After 30 Years Of Pure Effort
description: RICARDO and Donna Thornton stood proudly in the East Room of the White House on Thursday evening. They snapped photos, renewed acquaintances, accepted congratulations. Ricardo teased his son about the fit of his first tuxedo. He said Ricardo Jr. was playing basketball and eagerly looking forward to beginning a football career next year in the eighth grade.

title: One Gutsy Solution For Receiver Shortage
description: There has been a clamor for Giants Coach Jim Fassel to open up the offense and take some unconventional risks as the season winds down. Giants fans may soon be getting their wish.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about the deportation of immigrants from the United States misstated the period in which 106,000 immigrants with criminal convictions were deported. It was 1997 and 1998, not 1998 alone. As the article said, the figure represented a 52 percent increase from the previous two years.

title: Secret Papers Gall Democrats
description: House Democrats complained today that some Republicans who were undecided on impeachment had been shown sealed documents that the Judiciary Committee received from the independent counsel.

title: Tomorrow's 'Jurors' Insist They Are Barely Spectators Today
description: Senator Mike DeWine, Republican of Ohio, was not exactly glued to his television today as the House debated impeaching a President, for what would be only the second time in history. The small Sony in Mr. DeWine's spacious Capitol Hill office was not even turned on for most of the afternoon while the Senator presided over a marathon staff meeting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, STANLEY
description: SIEGEL - Stanley. Huntington, Long Island on December 11, after a swift illness. Buried December 13. Much loved husband of Eve. Father of Reva, Fred and Laura. Uncle to Julia, Solange and Diane, in-law to Paul, Abe, Mimi. Veteran of the Air Force. Graduate of Penn State and MIT, Manager at Sperry/Unisys, 40 year member of the Huntington Jewish Center, and enthusiastic member of the YMCA. We loved him and he loved us. We'll miss him.

title: Honing In on the True Holiday Spirit
description: Christmas is fast approaching and Chuckie, the paranoid spectacled toddler in Nickelodeon's ''Rugrats,'' detects disturbing pattern in the holiday frenzy. ''First,'' he says in a hushed voice to his best friend, Tommy, ''it gets really, really cold. Then the grown-ups start acting real nice and smile all the time, and that's not the worstest part. . . .''

title: In Place of People Buried Alive, Wooden Effigies
description: IN the fifth century B.C., Confucius questioned the practice of burying people alive alongside the dead in funerary rituals, calling it a waste of human life. But it was not until 100 years later that the Chu people of Southern China abandoned human sacrifice, replacing the living in such rituals with carved and lacquered wooden figures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRANE, LOUIS JOSEPH, DDS
description: CRANE-Louis Joseph, DDS. Age 89. Of Lauderhill, FL. Formerly of Larchmont, N.Y., and Bronxville, NY. On Thursday, December 17, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Margaret (nee Wagner). Loving father of Dr. Frederick (Betty), Dr. Edward (Carol), and Carol Gerber (Bernard). Adoring grandfather of Judith and Robert, Laura Crane Gelblum (Ehud) & Peter, Cynthia Tomlinson (Richard) and Julie Gerber. Devoted brother of the late Frederick Crane and the late Benjamin Crane. He loved life, his family, his work and his music. Services 12 Noon on Sunday, December 20, at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, New Jersey. Contributions in his memory may be made to United Jewish Appeal.

title: The View From/The Manger at St. John's Episcopal Church, Stamford; It's No Christmas Pageant Without Live Sheep
description: THE Christmas story is so much better when you have your hand on a sheep, said a little girl to Dora Odorenko, the animal's owner.

title: Art and Science Sing The Body Transparent
description: LATE in the 19th century, writers and artists, harassed by realism and the tyranny of fact, began to call for introspection, reliance on emotion, investigation of fantasy and dream. As early as 1858, Baudelaire railed against photography and art's slavish reproduction of nature. ''Each day art further diminishes its self-respect by bowing down before external reality,'' he said, adding that ''nevertheless, it is a happiness to dream.''

title: New Chronicler of the Rich and Famous
description: THERE is a certain type of person who routinely sends urgent E-mails at 2 A.M. and insists she cannot think unless she is wearing black. In this particular case, she is a magazine publisher.

title: Business Backers Still Cheering G.O.P.
description: Republicans are already debating whether their impeachment drive will backfire in the 2000 elections. But they appear unlikely to suffer defections by business leaders who back them. ''I'm proud of the Republicans, in the face of the polls, doing what they think is right,'' said Robert Mosbacher, President Bush's Secretary of Commerce and a Houston oilman. David H. Koch, a senior officer of Koch Industries, the nation's second-largest private firm, says an ouster of President Clinton, far from rattling the economy, might aid it. ''After Nixon was removed from office, there was a huge improvement in morale,'' he said.

title: Most Moderate Republicans in Northeast Vote With Party
description: By the time the voting was over in the House today, the vast majority of the moderate Republicans from the Northeast had locked arms with their more conservative colleagues from the South and West to support the impeachment of President Clinton.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Nov. 29 about biographical investigation of historical figures through DNA and other high-tech methods misstated the name of the library at Amherst College, where Emily Dickinson's poems and letters are being re-examined. It is Frost Library, not Foster. The article also misidentified the college attended by Alfred Lord Tennyson and a classmate, Arthur Henry Hallam, whose relationship has been debated by scholars. It was Trinity College at Cambridge, not Balliol at Oxford.

title: Sports of The Times; The Coach's Teary Title: 'By No Means Do I Feel That We're Done'
description: WITH his blondish hair and his green parka still damp from a sideline shower of ice, Bill Parcells addressed his troops in the Jets' locker room. And soon his eyes were damp.

title: A Fearless Confession Heard Round the World
description: EARLIER this year, a conference of dance scholars retired from a long day's meeting to an oyster house, where the oyster lovers set out to seduce the skeptics into sampling the delicacy. A quotation from the modern dancer Isadora Duncan's autobiography, ''My Life,'' persuaded the final holdout. ''You know what Isadora wrote, don't you?'' said a clever historian. ''That she began to dance in her mother's womb, in response to her mother's diet of oysters and Champagne, the food of Aphrodite.''

title: Offstage Drama Of 'Wit' Goes On
description: THIS year, the singularity of the professional nonprofit theaters' best work in the state went on informing the nonprofit theater in New York, reflected the continuing double standards of the lords of the commercial sector and converged with other theater events, in Connecticut and elsewhere. Here's how some winners did it.

title: Alcohol and Drug Use by Teen-Agers Declines Some, Report Says
description: After rising since the early 1990's, the use of marijuana and other drugs by teen-agers may be ebbing, however modestly, according to a new survey that is considered the most reliable gauge of substance abuse among secondary school students.

title: Israel Battles New Foreign Foe: Music
description: On city streets and in their living rooms Israelis are awash in American popular culture. McDonald's restaurants, Tower Records stores and Blockbuster Video shops dot the urban landscape, and MTV and ''Seinfeld'' reruns are on cable television.

title: When History Had Secrets
description: A Very Private Woman

title: Members Only
description: Forbidden Fairways

title: Printmakers Great and Small
description: WHAT do a monoprint of a chicken, a wood and fabric sculpture of a woman holding a dodo bird and a charcoal drawing of the West Side Highway have in common? All are original works in two shows sponsored by the Brooklyn Arts Council. The ''Printmakers' Portfolio'' is a selection of several hundred prints by internationally known artists as well as emerging artists. A holiday show of small works will offer a wider variety of prints, including lithographs, etchings and wood and linoleum cuts. ''We're trying to nurture the local printmakers,'' said Agnes Murray, the council's master printmaker. Another major goal is to offer affordable art; prices range from $20 to $400. Artists include Gregory Frux, Selina Trieff and a young Russian artist, Asya Dodina, whose linoleum cut print ''Winter'' is above.

title: Cause of Brown Tide Still Undetermined
description: In a letter published Dec. 6, Bill Smith expressed disappointment that his hypothesis for the cause of Peconic Bay's brown tide was not mentioned in the article on the scallop industry (''Years of Brown Tide Leave Scallops Scarce,'' Nov. 29). Mr. Smith has a long-held belief that tritium accidently released by Brookhaven National Laboratory and excess nitrogen from the watershed combine to cause brown tide.

title: One Screen Could Not Capture It All
description: Anyone watching could have hit the mute button and still absorbed the most distilled, revealing image on television yesterday: the line of Bill Clinton's uncharacteristically clenched jaw as he stood on the South Lawn of the White House, listening to Vice President Al Gore insist that the President would serve out his term. And when Mr. Clinton spoke, his reddened eyes were at odds with his unemotional delivery. Surrounded by Democrats from Congress in what amounted to a media-ready support group, his was the face, though not the words or voice, of a man who has taken in terrible news.

title: Airlines Meeting Deadline for Grounding the Noisiest Planes
description: Airplane noise has gotten a lot softer, according to the Federal Aviation Administration, and a 10-year program with that in mind is approaching a pianissimo finale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, JERROLD A.
description: LIEBERMAN-Jerrold A. Formerly of Kings Point, NY, and Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Bernice (nee Sosnow). Devoted father of Zabrina Beth Lieberman, Seth Mitchell and Kristina Lieberman, and Daryl Howard Lieberman. Adored Poppy of Cari Elizabeth. Services Sunday, 1 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: OPINION; New Hope for Two-Party System
description: IN all the hullabaloo surrounding the defeat of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato by Representative Charles Schumer, the gnashing of teeth over a perceived future shortage of oversized checks cut with Federal funds and the querulous inquiries about the potential effectiveness of the Senator-elect, one significant fact has been overlooked: the Long Island Republican Party's maximum effort this year wasn't enough to offset new and vigorous Democratic strength that may presage a sea change in Island politics.

title: Lethal Chemistry At Harvard
description: The research for the Ph.D. is the first project, not the last, in the lifetime of a scientist. It is supposed to demonstrate that the candidate, previously qualified by a highly competitive admission procedure, top grades and searching written and oral exams, has the ability to do significant original work. Every good research topic is not a good thesis topic, because unlike the former, the latter must have a foreseeable end in a reasonable time. An adviser who urges or even allows his students to undertake projects whose ends cannot be foreseen or that are clearly beyond the scope of a graduate program ought not to be supervising doctoral students.

title: December 13-19; Happy Christmas, Merry New Year
description: In China, a growing passion for things Western has in recent years meant a special interest in Christmas, especially among fashion-conscious young people.

title: Other Choristers Raise Their Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: A History of Silence

title: Q. & A.
description: Subletting Apartment In a Co-op

title: Livingston Urges Clinton to Follow Suit
description: Representative Robert L. Livingston, who rocked the House on Thursday with his revelation that he had had adulterous affairs, stunned the Capitol again today by saying that he would not serve as Speaker and would quit Congress in six months.

title: Snapped Up: Tinsel Trees And Ornaments Of Yore
description: Jennifer Anderson, the manager of Berkshire Vintage Furniture on Ninth Avenue at 13th Street, was busy on Monday unpacking 12 boxes of ornaments from the 40's and 50's, from celluloid reindeer to a string of Japanese-lantern Christmas lights. She was stocking the vintage ornaments, she said, because lots of people had been asking for them. ''They've been coming in telling me it's the hot thing, and I believe them,'' Ms. Anderson said.

title: Iraqis Are Called Masters of Concealment
description: Even the smartest bombs have trouble undercutting Saddam Hussein's ability to make new weapons of mass destruction because the Iraqis are masters at hiding their assets, United Nations weapons inspectors and other experts say.

title: H.W. Treleaven, Nixon Consultant, Dies at 76
description: Harry W. Treleaven Jr., an advertising executive and early political consultant who is credited with creating the ''Nixon's the One!'' slogan for the 1968 Presidential campaign, died Dec. 9 at the Sarah Neuman Nursing Home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 76 and lived in Manhattan and Amagansett, N.Y.

title: Introduction
description: Philip Weiss's article on tabloid history drew mail from exasperated readers maxed out on scandal,new and old. But dozens were riveted by Stephen S. Hall's story of the suicide of a Harvard science student. Many attributed his death to the chemistry of depression, rather than to the chemistry lab.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Two Interesting Reds

title: Lethal Chemistry At Harvard
description: Hall's article was haunting. I have just completed a book chapter on the suicides of competitive athletes and was struck by the similarities in the lives of competitive athletes and graduate students -- the competitive climate, the needy reliance on approval from mentor or coach, the sacrifices created by the reach for the elusive prize.

title: Excerpts From the House's Final Debate on Impeaching President Clinton
description: Following are excerpts from the final day of debate on the articles of impeachment against President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: In L.A., Looking for Comfort at Banana Bungalows
description: I HAD landed in Los Angeles, and I was craving comfort. I'd just staggered off a full Continental Airlines 757 in which I'd spent six hours with my head scrunched into my Hello Kitty inflatable neck pillow, struggling to blot out the nonstop chatter of two office colleagues on their way to a convention. My book -- Mike Davis's ''Ecology of Fear'' -- was perhaps not the best one to be diving into before a stay in L.A. It's a study of the city's precarious ecological and social history, and the chapters had titles like ''The Dialectic of Ordinary Disaster'' and ''Maneaters of the Sierra Madre,'' about, respectively, earthquake patterns in Southern California (worse than you think), and mountain lion habitats in the Santa Monica mountains (you don't want to know).

title: Moral Hazard
description: Sometimes a financial phrase kicks around the news, and we all act as if we understand it.

title: Goal Production Is Scarce as the Devils Salvage a Tie
description: Jacques Lemaire, the Devils' former coach, was watching from the stands here tonight, and it might have had something to do with the team's offensive production. The Devils, who had scored 28 goals in five games before Friday night, scored just one tonight, but it was enough for a 1-1 tie against the Montreal Canadiens, who have gone without a victory for nine games, their longest such streak in six years.

title: A Visual High Style For Hip-Hop Voices
description: IT'S a hot night in Las Vegas. Casino signs gleam as a voice in the distance bellows: ''Party people, it's about that time. . . .'' Trumpets blast. Puff Daddy, decked out in a suit that appears to be made of aluminum foil, cocks one finger in the air, John Travolta style. The hips of dancers, dressed in skimpy money-green body suits, start to twitch in time as a funky bass line begins. Puffy's partner, Mase, pulls up in a shiny black Mercedes. Fireworks explode. The chorus coos seductively, ''Bad, bad, bad, bad boy, you make me feel so good.''

title: All Aglow With Christmas
description: IF Christmas needs a carnival barker, Ron Merriman is available. His house with 38,000 winking colored lights, 30,000 feet of garland, 500 animated dolls and Christmas tunes piped right out to the sidewalk, is at least for the month of December, the greatest show on earth for a child or for anyone with some child-like spirit.

title: Fear Cruises the Ramble
description: The air in Central Park was thick with moisture on Wednesday night, and it was hard to see even a few yards. The brightly lit towers along the park's perimeter cast the winding, tree-lined paths into even greater shadow. At first it seemed that the Ramble, a 37-acre area in the center of the park between 72d and 79th Streets, was deserted. But then shadows began to emerge, shadows of dozens of men who were wandering about or sitting quietly on benches.

title: We Think We'll Never See An End to Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKEND; Found in Translation
description: Isabelle de Courtivron is involved in the development of bilingual-bicultural studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Stowe
description: Stowe may not be the most efficient or best-laid-out ski resort in the Northeast, but it is surely the most romantic -- and the one that comes closest to fulfilling fantasies of what winter in Vermont should look like. From the classic white-steepled church in the 200-year-old Stowe Village, to the snug country inns and charming shops along the Mountain Road, to the rime-encrusted summit of 4,393-foot Mount Mansfield, Stowe is steeped in authenticity. And at a time when instant ''towns'' are being erected at ski areas across the country, that quality has more appeal than ever.

title: Giants Want to Be on the Winning Side of the Game Ball for 1,000th Game
description: Since the Giants have played 999 regular-season games, maybe it is no surprise they have played so many games remembered by quirky and theatrical nicknames or for the weather conditions or their peculiar endings.

title: POSTINGS: Rentals at 75th Street; 3-Building Complex Rising on First Ave.
description: Construction has begun on a three-building luxury rental complex -- linked by an off-street landscaped courtyard -- on the east side of First Avenue between 75th and 76th Streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, JOHN E.
description: HOFFMAN-John E., 83. Of Roslyn Heights, on December 17, 1998. Devoted husband of Joan. Loving father of Philip, Hilde Agatstein and Julien. Beloved grandfather of Gregg, Justin and David. Dear father-in-law of Henry and Diane. Cherished uncle to his nieces and nephews, friend to many. The family would appreciate donations in his name to the NYC Ballet or The Central Park Conservancy.

title: Roger Highfield
description: Q: You say that mushroom-induced hallucinations may have contributed to the myth of Christmas. How?

title: Children's Books: Bookshelf
description: YOUNG MARY OF NAZARETH. By Marianna Mayer. Morrow. $16. (All ages) This account of the girlhood of the Virgin Mary is drawn from apocryphal and traditional sources, and the 24 color illustrations include many well-known images from European art.

title: Once-Corrupt Teamster Local Has First Election in a Decade
description: A candidate running on a platform of fighting corruption was elected Friday as president of a New Jersey teamsters' local long considered to be one of the most corrupt labor organizations in the nation, in the local's first vote in a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEREGI, BILL JOHN
description: SEREGI-Bill John. On December 16, 1998. Born in Budapest, Hungary in 1903. Came to America in 1951. Master jeweler for 77 years. Beloved husband of Lily for 70 years. Devoted father of Ann and Larry. Loving grandfather of Ellie & Lewis. Also survived by nieces and nephews Veronica and Leslie Szikla; George and Georgette Dankner & their families. Services Sunday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the B'nai Zion Foundation, 136 East 39 Street, New York City 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVMAN, MOSES
description: BRAVMAN-Moses. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with sorrow the death of Moses Bravman. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his loving wife Cecelia, his devoted son Irving and daughter-in-law Rose, granddaughter Elizabeth (Jonah) Turk and great-grandchildren Noah, Sarah, Rebecca, Daniel and Gideon. We hope that your loving memories of times together will bring you comfort during this time of sadness. Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman Daniel A. Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 20, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Lethal Chemistry At Harvard
description: I was disturbed by Stephen S. Hall's article (Nov. 29), not only for the suicide of a promising graduate student but also for the microcosm of graduate education it tragically portrays.

title: SOAPBOX; Point of Procedure
description: THE latest Band-Aid in the never-ending story of New Jersey automobile insurance reform was the passage of the Automobile Insurance Cost Reduction Act in May. A primary thrust of this legislation is to reduce the cost of medical care resulting from car accidents by 25 percent. After a public hearing and comment period, the commissioner of the Department of Banking and Insurance filed final regulations on Nov. 30 ''not requiring additional public notice and comment.''

I figured they would never feel the worse for surrendering such a pittance, but the pennies would net me $1.5 million, then a veritable fortune.

Following refreshments and some prom-style across-the-gym-floor checkings-out, everyone went upstairs to see an apt film, ''Lonely in America.'' Tirlok Malik, who produced and acted in this movie about a forlorn Indian immigrant looking for love in New York, was host for the event and led an informal discussion afterward.

title: When Dry Cleaners Lift Stress
description: JOE and Kevin, the lively young Koreans who took over Young's Cleaners at Third Avenue and 17th Street last year, have been working in the shadow of the previous owner, Jong Chung, a former chemist dubbed Dr. Stain. A magician, Dr. Stain could make red wine disappear from wedding dresses, even indelible ink from my shirts. Very thin ladies came from the Upper East Side to beseech Dr. Stain to save their blouses. That man could lift the blotch off the Presidency. But after his daughter received her medical degree and his son a Ph.D., he moved to California to be near them and to return to inventing, his true profession. He left few potions and incantations behind, much less a forwarding address.

The Mahler tradition of the orchestra is, after all, uniquely rich. Like those of the Vienna Philharmonic and the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam, it was set in motion by Gustav Mahler himself as conductor, but unlike those others, it was not short-circuited in the 1930's and 40's by the anti-Semitic fallout from Nazi annexation or occupation.

Kneeling, with his back to the wall and one leg bent beneath him, he strained to breathe rhythmically while keeping his face from contorting into what Danny Poole, his instructor, disdainfully called ''a weight lifter's grimace.''

title: In Garden, a World's Fair of Flowers
description: When the 39-acre Queens Botanical Garden was built in 1939 for the World's Fair, its creators proclaimed it a classic Western European garden. But four years ago, the trustees of the garden decided to reshape its goals to better reflect the reality that Queens, as the 1990 census showed, had evolved into the most ethnically diverse county in the nation. So the garden developed new lecture series and programs aimed at attracting people from the three main immigrant communities of the neighborhood: Chinese, Koreans and Latin Americans. It also added plants that are important to those groups, like peonies for the Chinese, rose of Sharon for Koreans and bougainvillea for Latin Americans.

title: Sorority Sisters
description: I agree with Deborah Solomon that an exhibition of the best work of Julia Margaret Cameron would include her portraits of men (Culture Zone, Nov. 22). However, as a Victorianist who has just finished writing a screenplay about Cameron's life, I believe Solomon has misunderstood Cameron's character. She was not ''the sort of woman who craved the company of powerful men but had little use for women.'' One of seven sisters, Cameron was close to many women. It was beauty she worshiped, not power. She admired Tennyson for his poetry, not his poet laureateship.

The stockings are made from the store's trademark navy blue pinstripe flannel, trimmed with white collar and bow tie. (A casual version, above, in red herringbone with shearling, sold out.) Since Thanksgiving, 55 stockings have been bought. They are sold stuffed, and the price depends on the filling. The most expensive order was a $5,300 stocking, packed with a cashmere coat, a briefcase and other accessories. Vincent Mancuso, the house tailor turned Santa's helper, hand stitches each in about two hours. Mr. Mancuso hopes to have time after hours to sew up some children's versions for his two grandsons, but he and his wife will make do with the usual store-bought.

It saw an orderly, if misguided use of the constitutional process. It brought passage of two articles of impeachment against President Clinton on a brutal party-line vote that defied the will of the American people. It brought the abrupt resignation of Representative Robert Livingston, a Republican leader who had failed to seize his opportunity to lead his party from the thicket of blind partisanship. Yet, with both the White House and the majority party in Congress locked in a crisis of leadership, one element remained unchanged. The way back to stability is adoption of a censure resolution that condemns Mr. Clinton for lying under oath, but allows him to remain in office.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION; In Alexandria's Basement
description: The French archeologist Jean-Yves Empereur worked at the excavation of Alexandria, the Egyptian city founded by Alexander the Great in 331 B.C., for more than 25 years, as he details in the lavishly illustrated ALEXANDRIA REDISCOVERED (Braziller, $60). In spite of the somewhat lackluster telling, Empereur's stories about the excavations are fascinating, particularly those about the underwater dig of Fort Qait Bey, a find that uncovered details about the Pharos lighthouse, one of the seven wonders of the ancient world. Empereur does excel in illuminating the difficulties of uncovering a lost city that industrialization continually encroaches upon. With limited financial means and tough physical conditions, Empereur writes, ''the Alexandrian experience can also be wearisome: one has to confront various obstacles, such as the hostility of the developers who have quite other interests at heart than the enhancement of their cultural heritage.'' Today, for instance, only engravings and old maps indicate where Cleopatra's Needles, now located in London and in Central Park, once stood in Alexandria. ''People lost no time in erecting buildings in their place,'' Empereur writes. ''Do the guests of the Hotel Metropole realize, I wonder, that they are sleeping on the spot where almost two millennia ago the monumental entrance markers of the Caesareum stood?'' Sandra Mardenfeld

title: What Welfare-to-Work Really Means
description: One Saturday morning this fall, a 54-year-old Bronx woman who has spent more years on welfare than she can remember answered a small-type summons from the city government, the second that she has received this year. ''Dear Sir/Madam,'' it began. ''You are being called in to evaluate your employability.'' She stuffed two doctors' letters into a worn envelope, filled a plastic bag with prescription pills and enlisted her son as an interpreter. They traveled to a drab building off Union Square, where they waited for an hour in hard plastic chairs until a caseworker summoned them to a cramped cubicle. ''The reason we called you in,'' he began, ''is everybody on public assistance is required to work.'' The son, a jobless 21-year-old, answered through a mouthful of gum: ''Well, we got letters from her doctors saying she's not really able to work.''

title: The Face of Eco-Terrorism

He was 25, and he was a student at Marylhurst University, where he was majoring in social science. He was renting a house with a few other activists, and he had just split off from a local group, People for Animal Rights, to help found a kind of umbrella group called the Liberation Collective, the motto of which is, ''Linking social justice movements to end all oppression.'' Today, though, Craig Rosebraugh stands out in Portland -- among activists, at least -- as the guy who spoke up on behalf of the Earth Liberation Front, a group that, through Rosebraugh, took credit for burning down a mountaintop ski resort in Vail in October in the name of preserving a lynx habitat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFIN, JOCELYN CRANE
description: GRIFFIN-Jocelyn Crane. The trustees and staff of The Wildlife Conservation Society mourn the passing of their colleague and friend, who died in Concord, MA. on December 16, 1998. She was a zoologist and historian of human gestures in art. After graduation from Smith College in 1930, she joined the staff of the New York Zoological Society's (now Wildlife Conservation Society) Department of Tropical Research and began collaborating with William Beebe, beginning with research on deep sea fishes, based in Bermuda. Later she managed the Society's tropical field stations in Venezuela and Trinidad and was senior research zoologist with the Society's Institute for Research in Animal Behavior. She was an internationally recognized ethologist concentrating on the behavior of tropical animals, jumping spiders, praying mantises, butterflys and especially fiddler crabs, which she studied on many excursions around the world leading to her great monograph Fiddler Crabs of the World. During her retirement she turned to art history, obtaining a Phd degree from the Institute of Fine Art, New York University. She is survived by her husband, Donald R. Griffin of Lexington, MA. David T. Schiff, Chairman Board of Trustees Wildlife Conservation Society

title: How the Small-Cap Premium Went Into Hiding
description: THE trip from gown to town can be a bumpy one. Just ask anyone who has invested in small-capitalization stocks. According to a number of impressive academic studies, small-company stocks have significantly outperformed their larger-cap brethren over the long term -- a pattern known as the small-cap premium. Yet in the real world over the last 15 years, despite spurts of outperformance, small caps have generally lagged behind.

title: The Firs Are Flying
description: It's Christmas, that rare time when Manhattan actually abounds with trees. This year, here's what New Yorkers are pining for:

title: The Gospel, With Sugar on Top
description: HE always wanted to fly the skies. But when his boyhood dream of becoming an airline pilot was thwarted, Mark Bontempo found another route to the heavens: selling candy and clothes emblazoned with verses from the Scriptures.

title: December 13-19; Koreans Clone Human Cell
description: South Korean scientists said they had cloned a human cell from an infertile woman, creating an embryo that theoretically could have grown into an identical replica of the woman. But because of the legal and ethical implications of their work, they said, they stopped the experiment and did not try to create a human clone. The research has already caused controversy. Korean groups are calling for a ban on such experiments. SHERYL WuDUNN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPS, ERIC, MD
description: RAPS-Eric, MD. The Department of Neurology at Mt. Sinai Medical Center extends its heartfelt condolences to our friend and colleague Dr. Mitchell Raps on the death of his brother, Dr. Eric Raps. Eric was an esteemed member of the neurology community. He will be deeply missed. Sincere condolences are also extended to Eric's parents Cecile and Nathan Raps, his wife Maureen and son Daniel. C.W. Olanow, M.D. and the Department of Neurology

title: The Neediest Children
description: Most of us wrestle with our consciences and our wallets this month, trying to live up to our sense of what the holidays should ideally mean. Everyone wants to feel generous, openhearted, and yet that feeling can be hard to attain for the simple reason that Christmas is for many of us a holiday in which we merely add to each other's abundance. We give out of habit to those who do not need rather than to those who do, when, in fact, the emotion this season has come to embody can best be found in an act of generous compassion. To rectify the need of others is never a selfish act, no matter how good it makes you feel. It is always an act of self-forgetting, the very release we seek this time of year.

title: Lethal Chemistry At Harvard
description: All chemistry graduate students at Harvard know that E. J. Corey's lab is a demanding and sometimes stressful place to work. They choose to work there in spite of this reputation. However, unhappy students, even advanced ones, can and sometimes do change labs without adverse effects. It was Altom's choice to work for Corey and remain in his lab in spite of his concealed dissatisfaction. Your article makes it seem as though Corey picked Jason Altom to work for him. This is untrue. It was Altom's choice.

title: The Mother of All Tonkas
description: After 18 months of development, Caterpillar's new 797 mining dump truck will be the largest truck in the world when it rolls out early next year. The 797 can carry 50 Christmas trees the size of the Norway spruce currently on display at Rockefeller Center and still have, literally, tons of room left. Specifically designed to work in open-pit mines, the primary role of the truck is transporting minerals to crushers and removing ''overburden,'' a layer of earth that covers valuable minerals and can be up to 150 feet thick. With its 360-ton payload capacity, the 797 nearly dwarfs its closest rival, a 320-ton truck made by a rival Japanese manufacturer, Komatsu. Roughly the size of a four-story brownstone, this life-size Tonka toy is sure to be on the wish list of every mining executive. Here's a look at the ultimate utility vehicle.

title: Where Forgotten Eagles Have Found a Roost
description: Readers of your article, ''From East to West, an Island of Landmarks'' [Nov. 15] might be interested in knowing that two other granite eagles from the original Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan can be found on Long Island. They adorn the entrance to the sports gymnasium at the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, placed on guard there in 1965. The academy's waterside campus is open to visitors daily, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: The World; In Cuba, the Grinch Takes a Holiday
description: A WEEK before Thanksgiving, while Americans were busy planning turkey feasts, people in Havana were already showing off their new plastic Christmas trees.

title: Prison Van Is a Link For Families
description: It was past midnight, early on a Saturday, but even the children in the cluster of people standing outside Junior's Restaurant on Flatbush Avenue looked wide awake. They were going to see their fathers, something many had not done in a long time.

title: New London's Feisty Newspaper, The Day
description: TWO and a half years ago, when the staff of The Day newspaper in New London showed up at Foxwoods Casino in Ledyard to do the daily drop off, they were promptly escorted off the reservation, newspapers and all.

title: Muse, Interrupted
description: I especially appreciated Holly Brubach's article (Nov. 22) on Tanaquil Le Clercq. I heard about her, in 1945, from her father, Jacques Le Clercq, with whom I became good friends when I was stationed in Toulouse, France. He told me, over copious drafts of eau de vie, that he had a child who had been picked for a very selective ballet school. He said that he had known Tanaquil would be a dancer because, at age 4 or so, she had burned her hand on the kitchen stove but instead of merely screaming she had pirouetted about, singing, ''This is the dance of the lady who has just burned her hand on the stove.''

title: On Floor of the House, Culture War Explodes
description: Following are excerpts from comments on Representative Robert L. Livingston's announcement today that he would resign from the House, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Lori Marlan, Julian Rose
description: Lori Jan Marlan is to be married this afternoon to Julian Rose at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Robert Lennick is to officiate.

title: Maura Levine, Lloyd Mandell
description: Maura Dawn Levine, a lawyer, and Lloyd Lewis Mandell, an investment manager, were married last evening at El Conquistador resort in Las Croabas, P.R. Rabbi Michael Ehrlich officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, STELLA K.
description: ABRAHAM-Stella K. The Boca Raton Judaic Fellows Program mourns the loss of the beloved mother of Daniel S. Abraham, Judith Steinberg, and Jerry Abraham. Through the generosity of the Abraham & Steinberg families, hundreds of people have been exposed to their Jewish heritage in an exciting, tolerant environment. The Daniel S. Abraham and Dr. Edward Steinberg endowment of the Senior Kollel Fellow Chair has created bridges of tolerance through the teaching of Torah throughout the South Florida Jewish Community. There is no doubt that their commitment to guarantee the eternality of the Jewish people was motivated and nurtured by the matriarch of the family. Beloved by her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren, Stella embued the spirit of the Maccabees and her light will continue to shine through the actions of her family. Rabbi Kenneth Brander Dean Aharon Ungar, President

title: A Painter and Her Patron: Two Modern Women
description: VISITORS to the women's pavilion at the 1893 world's fair in Chicago winced at the huge mural of cavorting women and naked babies emblazoned atop a high wall. The canvas, 58 feet long by 14 feet tall, by an obscure Philadelphia spinster named Mary Cassatt, was drenched in vivid color and light, a new ''impressionist'' style few Victorian Americans had seen. It was a ''singular failure,'' one critic wrote.

title: Streetscapes/The Norwood Section of the Bronx; For an 1890 Reservoir Keeper's House, a New Use
description: TO Isaac Barkey, who lived there for more than half a century, the 1890 reservoir keeper's house is an unhappy memory of unfinished dreams. To the Mosholu Preservation Corporation, which will move into the stone building at Putnam Place and Reservoir Oval East in the Norwood section of the Bronx, the stone building is a bright opportunity for the future. Built as part of a little-known adjunct to the Croton Aqueduct water supply system, the keeper's house is a curious shell of a building, now at an important turning point.

title: In the President's Home State, a Sense of Sorrow and Satisfaction
description: The House vote calling for Bill Clinton's impeachment went unheard at Bennett's, a camping and military surplus store that has been a fixture in downtown Little Rock since 1870. There were no televisions, no radios, and no reason for them.

title: Indian Barbecue That Lures Aficionados
description: THE aroma of cloves, cinnamon, coriander, ginger and chilies fills the air. A bearded, turbaned chef from New Delhi juggles skewers of chicken, lamb and seafood in a hooded, open kitchen. Gentle, deferential (though sometimes lax) servers in their native garb deliver warm, fried, cracker-like sheets of complementary pappadam (made from peppery lentil flour) and moist pita wedges to tables filled with diners of Indian heritage.

title: Tips: Grease for the Gears of City Life
description: WHEN toting up expenses to determine New York City's sky-high cost of living, don't forget to include the tip.

title: December 13-19; Unraveling the Hiss Case
description: Was Alger Hiss a spy, or was he steamrolled by McCarthyism? That question has gnawed at the country for half a century, and despite seemingly damning evidence from Soviet archives, there's no firm answer. Now, in yet another effort to nibble away at this mystery, a group of scholars has asked a Federal judge to unseal grand jury records of the Hiss perjury case. Even as they did so, though, one historian conceded that the puzzle would probably remain unsolved. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: A Perilous Parallel for Rubin
description: Call him the prisoner of 15th Street.

title: Toy Makers Scrambling Just to Stay In Place
description: ATTENTION: just five more days until Christmas. But even as children of all ages and sizes cram the malls in a final frenzy, there are signs of unrest in toyland.

title: Cool, Stark Furniture To Wear Around the House
description: Debra Lachance is busy. She recently opened Area Id Moderne, a furniture store featuring vintage and new items, at 262 Elizabeth Street, near Houston Street, and she also owns Style Industrie, a fashion trade show held twice a year at the Jacob K. Javits Center.

title: BENEFITS
description: Making Their Debut

title: In Some Churches, Christmas Is a Movable Feast
description: Christmas was still a week away, but the spirit of Christmas Eve prevailed Thursday night at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Gale Minot, Sandy Noble
description: Gale Winslow Minot was married on Friday to George Warner Noble at the Chilton Club in Boston. The Rev. Timothy E. Crellin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: A Song in the Air, and Pizza on the Menu
description: For more than 100 years, Lock 8 on the Morris Canal was home to the E.C. Peer General Store, which provided a place to stop for food and rest to canal boatsmen and other travelers.

title: Wall Street Waves Off Washington
description: Will President Clinton's constitutional travails derail the stock market's freight train in the weeks ahead?

title: A Truck for the Power-Hungry
description: IN the 40's, the Dodge Power Wagon was a famously rugged truck born in the military and adapted for civilian duty. Now Chrysler has revived the name for a show vehicle that combines handcrafted luxury with aggressive styling and an immense 7.2-liter diesel engine.

title: Olympic Champion Says He's Through
description: The Olympic champion Jean-Luc Cretier of France announced his retirement yesterday in Val Gardena, Italy, after a spectacular fall in a World Cup downhill race.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHAFFER, MARGARET
description: SCHAFFER-Margaret. September 1901-December 1993. In loving memory. Always in our hearts. Love, your family

title: Another 'Superstar' in Another Land
description: A BLOOD-RED banner, unfurled in rude, defiant control of the stage, flaunts a swastikalike symbol, black on white, at its center. It is the first eye-popper as you go, startled and hesitant, to your seat at the Helen Hayes Performing Arts Center here. Could this be ''Springtime for Hitler,'' live and in color?

title: The Card-Carrying Angst of the Dysfunctional Shopper
description: AS holiday shoppers clogged the thoroughfares last week, clutching glossy bags emblazoned with status names, one 59-year-old lawyer confided her innermost feeling: guilt.

title: After 27 Years, the Little School Is Told to Say Bye-Bye
description: A downtown institution, it was Manhattan's first preschool south of Chambers Street, known for its diverse mix of children, affordable tuition and nurturing atmosphere. But after 27 years, it looks as if Pace University's Little School, with 32 3-and 4-year-old students, will be shutting down next spring, to the dismay of many neighborhood residents.

title: Truth, Fiction and Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: After 7 Years, Work Begins
description: Seven years ago, Edward A. Watkins looked around his neighborhood in the Parkchester housing development and saw deteriorating schools, kids hanging out on the street with nothing to do and few services for the elderly. He decided the neighborhood needed a community center, and approached the pastor of the local parish, Mgsr. Charles M. Kavanagh, for help. Last week, Mr. Watkins finally saw his plan come to fruition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHAN, JAMES
description: BOHAN-James. Firefighter 4th Grade. Ladder 170, formerly Engine 262, F.D.N.Y. Suddenly on December 18, 1998, in the line of duty. Devoted son of John and Margaret (nee Condon) Bohan. Loving brother of Maurice. Loving grandson of Maurice Condon of Loughill County Limerick, Ireland. Also survived by his loving finacee Audrey Frlic, his aunts and uncles Jimmy and Maureen Bohan of Dublin, Jim and Mary Callaghan, Eddy and Kathleen Bohan, Pete and Kathleen Vaughn and Brigid and Timothy O'Sullivan and cousins Eamon, Pauline, Betty and Marie Bohan, Jimmy, Eddy and Pat Callaghan, Michelle, John and Edward Bohan, Shelia Vaughn and Mary, Katy, Julia and Timothy O'Sullivan. Reposing at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 710PM. Funeral Monday. Mass at Saint Margaret's Church, Middle Village, 9 AM. Interment Mount Saint Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory to the FDNY-Cornell Burn Unit would be appreciated. ''Jim will be dearly missed by his brothers of Engine 257, Engine 262, Ladder 170 and Battalion 58.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYER, FAY (NEE FARBER)
description: REYER-Fay (nee Farber). December 15, 1998. Wife of the late Edward A. Reyer. Beloved mother of Dr. William (Nina) Reyer Esq. and Neil (Suzi) Reyer. Loving grandmother of Stephanie, Rachel, Nikki, Eric and Brittney. Contributions in her memory may be made to Chandler Hall, 99 Barclay St, Newtown, PA. 18940. Services and interment private. For information contact Goldsteins Rosenbergs Raphel-Sacks 1-800-622-6410

title: Sorority Sisters
description: I am baffled by the outrage Solomon feels after attending several exhibits of art with exclusively female subjects. Does she believe that exhibits of folk art create the impression that acknowledged masters like Rembrandt and Picasso are insignificant? Does she believe that concerts of Salieri's music turn listeners against Mozart? Would she denounce a retrospective of Hollywood tear-jerkers because it did not include a few manly films by John Ford?

title: Truth, Fiction and Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: SOMETHING ABOUT WAYNE
description: *Norman Bates is getting all the attention lately, but there's a case to be made for Wayne as the official name of scary guys. *The recent arrest of a serial-killer suspect named Wayne Adam Ford chillingly evokes other unsettling Waynes. *Among them: John Wayne Gacy, the killer clown; Wayne Williams, the Atlanta child murderer; Larry Wayne Harris, the accused biological terrorist; Wayne Boden, Canada's ''Vampire Rapist''; and John Wayne Glover, the Australian ''Granny Killer.'' *Not in the same league, but still perplexing: Marilyn Manson's keyboardist, Madonna Wayne Gacy; John Wayne Bobbitt; and Wayne, the mean brother on ''The Wonder Years.'' *Coincidence? Lorenda Bardell, president of the Vancouver-based Kabalarian Philosophy, a group that tries to analyze how names relate to personality, says Wayne ''creates very caustic moods which prevent harmony in close associations.''

title: Poles and Jews Feud About Crosses at Auschwitz
description: Crosses large and small are going up outside the Auschwitz death camp, filling a field just beneath its barbed-wire-topped wall and driving a new wedge between Poles and Jews.

title: Sports of The Times; After Further Review, The Jets Are Champs
description: UPON further review, if only for the benefit of the viewers at home, Victor Green dropped the ball. The interception that snuffed out Doug Flutie and the Buffalo Bills was nothing more than a drop, a game-clinching turnover lost to the turf.

title: In Los Angeles, Set-Dressing the Subway
description: WHEN the Red Line subway station on the corner of Beverly Boulevard and Vermont Avenue opens here next year, the first thing commuters will see is a giant outcropping of sandy-colored rock that straddles the entrance. Looming ominously over the escalators down to the trains, it looks like a leftover from the desert scenes in ''Raiders of the Lost Ark.''

title: The World; Germs, Atoms and Poison Gas: The Iraqi Shell Game
description: SOMETIMES past is prologue. As Iraqi officials in 1995 led United Nations arms inspectors to a large cache of documents hidden on a chicken farm near Baghdad, a red photograph album stood out. At first glance, the album, like the half million pages of other papers in the shed, seemed to cast light on Iraq's secret drive to obtain germ, chemical and nuclear arms and missiles.

title: Buses Seen as No Idle Matter
description: The south side of East 56th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, has served for years as a layover spot for the many commuter buses that start routes on East 57th Street, to the annoyance of many store owners and residents. Now things are worse than ever, they say.

title: After Another Head Injury, Isles' Jonsson Heads Home
description: Kenny Jonsson, the Islanders' top defenseman and best all-round player, sustained what appeared to be his second concussion in a month during Friday night's 2-2 tie with the Anaheim Mighty Ducks when Travis Green clipped him on the head with a flying elbow.

title: The Gentle Art Of Persuading Shoppers
description: IT began innocently. On a recent Saturday, I was waiting at the counter at Troy, the pristine, so-hip-it-hurts furnishings store in SoHo, where my loved one, John Goodfriend, is the manager. I was waiting for John to finish up while a never-ending stream of holiday shoppers eddied around me. Waiting. Waiting. Finally, in frustration, I approached an absolute stranger and spoke the fateful words: ''Is there anything special you're looking for?''

title: The Nation: Social Insecurity; Poof! You Can Retire Rich.
description: IMAGINE you could save the Social Security system from bankruptcy by raising every American's retirement check -- without increasing taxes.

title: December 13-19; Lord Lloyd Webber for the Defense
description: Does it often seem that Andrew Lloyd Webber is everywhere? Well, it's more serious than you thought.

title: For Gugliotta and Timberwolves, the Party's All but Over
description: For the past two years, fans of the Minnesota Timberwolves could not help but dream. They saw one of the league's best young point guards playing with two All-Star forwards -- one in his prime, the other with gigantic potential -- and envisioned playoff run after playoff run, with at least a few of them ending in championships.

description: Blood

title: After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help
description: FOR Jaytin Bhaghat, 12, of Merrick, the thought of writing poetry for a class assignment was overwhelming. But his attitude changed after a private, two-hour tutoring session with a Hofstra University English literature major.

description: BREAKFAST ON PLUTO

title: The Life And Soul Of Parties
description: THERE'S nothing like bumper stickers for delivering unwelcome messages: ''Stuff Happens,'' ''What Goes Around Comes Around,'' ''You're Never Too Old to Learn.'' Such depressing examples of popular philosophy make a person doubt the value of the First Amendment.

title: Safir Warns He'll Fire Officers Who Drink and Misuse Guns
description: In response to recent incidents of off-duty police officers committing suicide or otherwise firing their weapons after drinking alcohol, Police Commissioner Howard Safir warned this week that he would fire any officer who misused his gun while intoxicated.

title: Correction
description: An entry in the Guide column last Sunday about a dinner for the needy on Christmas Day from noon to 4 P.M. misstated the location. After the section went to press, the site was changed to the Hillside Church of the Christian and Missionary Alliance, 448 Bedford Road, Armonk; it will not be at the Ramada Inn.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption and credit are omitted in some copies today from the film listings on page 44 of the Arts & Leisure section. The photograph, by Melinda Sue Gordon for Universal Pictures, shows Robin Williams in ''Patch Adams,'' which opens on Friday.
