description: Best Bet

title: December 13-19; Netanyahu Threatens To Force Elections
description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu threatened to call new elections to avoid the humiliation of being tossed out of office by Parliament. But he said he would try one final time to get a majority of Parliament to stand behind his tough posture toward the Palestinians.

title: Rock and Roots
description: Every artist started somewhere. Patti Smith, the rock-and-roll musician and poet, started in South Jersey. She writes about where she came from and where she went in ''Patti Smith/Complete,'' a compilation of all her lyrics, plus reflections, drawings, poetry and around 150 black-and-white photographs. The book contains reminiscences of the artistic life in New York: sharing a room in the Chelsea Hotel in New York with the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, say, or playing duets with Bob Dylan. But she also remembers that before her flight to the big city, a music teacher in South Jersey who played opera recordings inspired the 9-year-old Patti Smith to become a singer. She continues to pay tribute to her hometown by contributing proceeds from book-promotion appearances at places like the club CBGB in New York to the James H. Johnson Memorial Library in Deptford Township. The next such event is to be at the Barnes & Noble in Deptford on Jan. 22. ''Patti Smith/Complete'' (Doubleday) is $35.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about the closing of a carousel at Riverbank State Park on the Hudson River at 145th Street misstated the title of Diana Chapin, an official in the city department that commissioned the carousel. She is First Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, not Commissioner.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MELCER, PAULINE
description: MELCER-Pauline. December 13, 1916-December 22, 1994. Four years gone, may God rest my dearest Peshie, you live with me always. Your Herbie

title: Americans Benumbed By the Crisis In the Capital
description: Many Americans voiced anger, disgust and frustration with the proceedings. Some radiated grim satisfaction. But as President Clinton's long, painful journey from scandal to impeachment ended yesterday, most Americans were just benumbed, inoculated by the seemingly endless months of lies, legalisms and disillusionment with politics, Washington-style.

title: Malaysia's Leader Rides Out Turmoil, Helped by Anger at Gore
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad appears to be serenely back in control of events in Malaysia after three months of political turmoil that included a public scolding by Vice President Al Gore.

title: At the Big Board, The Story of 'A'
description: While the New York Stock Exchange can only watch from afar the frenzied activity these days in Internet stocks, which generally trade on Nasdaq, the Big Board is ground zero for intense speculation of another kind: Which company is going to get ticker symbol ''A''?

title: Individuals, Not Institutions, Hold Most Foreign Stocks
description: For years, institutional investors were the ones that ventured abroad. Now, according to a study by Citibank, the banking subsidiary of Citigroup, it is individuals who hold the lion's share of foreign stocks.

title: Republicans Look to 'the Coach' to Heal the House's Wounds
description: When Dennis Hastert was first elected to Congress from Illinois in 1986, he quickly became a protege of Robert H. Michel, the moderate, gentlemanly Republican who led the party in the House in the years before it won control of Congress in 1994.

title: Union Scandal Could Produce A Tougher Negotiating Stance
description: Against all expectations, the corruption scandal at New York City's largest municipal union could end up transforming the union into a more formidable adversary in coming contract negotiations with the city, labor experts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, CARYN, M.D.
description: HALPERN-Caryn, M.D. The column is too short, the borders too narrow to fully tell the story of a life so big: the life of Caryn Keller Halpern, M.D. To all who knew her, she was a skilled pediatrician, a devoted wife and mother, and an intuitive artist. To all who loved her, she was a source of continual joy, energy, inspiration, and love. Born in New Jersey, Caryn graduated from Downstate Medical School at The State University of NY. Her internship, residency, and fellowships included The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, The Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, and Sloan Kettering. In 1974, Caryn moved to Dallas on a fellowship with the Pediatric and Oncology Department of Children's Medical Center, and in 1976 she began her private practice in Pediatrics and Internal Medicine, in which she was active until 1977. Prior to her illness, Caryn was planning to pursue a Scottish Rite Fellowship in Attention Deficit Disorders. Among those who miss Caryn most are the family members she loved so dearly: husband Bill Sechrest, daughters Keller and Edyn, sons Brett, Trent, and Clay, and father Milton Halpern. In keeping with Caryn's passion for life and children, please make donations to the Children's Cancer Fund of Dallas, Inc, in memory of Caryn K. Halpern-Sechrest, 12720 Hillcrest Rd, Suite 120, Dallas, TX 75230.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSEN, JOANNE
description: POSEN-Joanne. Our beloved daughter-in-law. Cherished wife of our son David. Loving mother of our grandson Jimmy. We will miss you terribly. Bonnie and Martin Gregge Carol and Jack Posen

title: The Anti-Trump
description: It would not be correct to say that jerry i. speyer has the most toys of any real-estate developer in New York; he does, however, have the best toys. Last year, in partnership with the Travelers Group and Lehman Brothers, he bought the Chrysler Building, for $220 million. Two years before that, he came within an ace of buying Rockefeller Center, and eventually settled for a small stake, in partnership with Goldman, Sachs; David Rockefeller; Gianni Agnelli; and Stavros Niarchos: it is Speyer, however, who is charged with restoring the property to its former glory. Speyer built, and owns, the second-tallest building in Europe, the 62-story Messeturm, in Frankfurt. He has also built, and still owns, a mahogany-toned granite office tower at 520 Madison Avenue, not to mention major commercial buildings in Houston, Chicago, San Francisco, Washington, Miami and Berlin. He is in the process of building two more structures in Berlin and one in Sao Paulo, a retail complex in Yonkers and an apartment building on lower West End Avenue. His company, Tishman Speyer Properties, owns a total of 36 million square feet of space; Speyer places the market value of the company's holdings at $10.5 billion. His friend Bernard Mendik, who plies the same trade at a more modest level, says, ''Right now, Jerry is the No. 1 real-estate developer in the world.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, MARTHA
description: GOLDBERGER - Martha. The Board of Governors and members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Martha Goldberger, and extend to the members of her family our sincere condolences. Joel Langer, President Marvin Leffler, Secretary

title: Amid Bombs, a Tired Capital Keeps Its Cool
description: Iraqi antiaircraft gunners fired hundreds of rounds tonight in a series of spectacular bursts that lit up the sky with red, white and orange flashes.

title: Keeping Chamber Playing Alive
description: FOR the virtuoso, fiddling with others interrupts the solitude of practice, and, for better or worse, exposes the artist to diverse musical views. Compatible personalities may ignite a piece of chamber music -- just as clashing ones may strangle it -- and provide an unforgettable experience for audience and players.

title: Cross-Country Cuisine
description: ALTHOUGH some people might find it strange to head for a shopping mall to have a special dinner, many do just that to get a table at the Napa Valley Grille. Curious about how a restaurant can successfully bring the flavors and styles of the Napa Valley to tables in the Garden State Plaza, I went to the mall to see for myself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, SYLVIA
description: ROBBINS-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother of Rita. Loving mother-in-law of Arthur. Cherished grandmother of Glen and Harris.

title: One Dad's Redemption; Does Ben Middleton's Private Revolution Herald a Public Shift?
description: AS Benjamin Middleton Jr. and his son approach the corner of Marcus Garvey Boulevard and Hancock Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, their pace quickens. Casting an edgy glance around and noticing the drug dealers on their usual turf, Mr. Middleton automatically shifts his hand from his son's head and loops it protectively around his shoulder.

title: Looking Closely at the Meadowlands From Far Away
description: Robert Sullivan wrote his acclaimed book ''The Meadowlands'' not as a New Jerseyan in defense of native soil but as a Jersey expatriate, living 2,500 miles away, in Portland, Ore. He wrote in the book, published earlier this year: ''I would walk into the woods outside of the city where I ended up living and see beautiful trees and huge mountains topped with spectacular glaciers that altogether only made me miss the world's greatest industrial swamp.''

title: In a High-Tech War, CNN and E-Mail From Home
description: The bombs may be sophisticated, but the sentiments scribbled on them are not.

title: Turtle Watch
description: To the Editor: In his article ''Turtle Watch in Costa Rica'' (Oct. 25), John Alden fails to mention the negative, and possibly catastrophic, effect of development on the very fragile ecology of the Baulas Marine National Park. Loggerhead females now avoid, and lay fewer eggs on, sections of the beach adjacent to ecotourist lodging. Encroachment, well-intentioned or otherwise, on this tiny but vital beach area compromises the survival of the magnificent turtles Mr. Alden and his family enjoyed.

title: A Farewell for Gretzky Leaves Rangers Chilled
description: In the days preceding Wayne Gretzky's last game here at the storied Maple Leaf Gardens, anticipation built like a gathering storm. But in the end tonight, the Toronto Maple Leafs stole Gretzky's thunder, jumping to a 4-0 lead in the first period and beating the Rangers, 7-4.

title: Water Main Break Disrupts Subway Service
description: A water main break in the Financial District yesterday afternoon shut down parts of the Nos. 2 and 3 subway lines for three hours and forced the closure of several blocks of Williams Street, the authorities said.

title: A Man About Town
description: In midtown, the spirited and photogenic Santa showed off a few of his many talents. He was spotted swing dancing, carrying his mighty tuba and, by Bergdorf Goodman, cavorting with Mrs. Claus and some of the store's workers. title: Word for Word/Samuel L. Clemens, Journalist; When Congress Last Rose to Impeach, Mark Twain Rose to the Occasion
description: MARK TWAIN may well have said that history doesn't repeat itself; it rhymes. Or maybe someone else did. In any event, in early 1868, while awaiting publication of ''The Innocents Abroad,'' the 32-year-old writer found himself witness to a curious piece of history that proves the point -- the first impeachment of a President.

title: Animal Photo Show, Subject of Neglect
description: IT doesn't take Dr. Dolittle to understand why a show of animal photographs is sure to be popular and endearing, but it may surprise many people to learn that animals are a relatively new subject for photography. In its early phase photography meant mostly portraiture or landscape; animals rank low on the list. This is not true for painting: consider Stubbs's horses or Delacroix's tigers, and dog portraiture is almost an industry.

title: Feasts as Fund-Raisers Mark the Season
description: FEASTS have appeal, and this is the season for them, say those who organize benefits to raise money for worthy organizations.

title: Razor Thin, But Larger Than Life
description: THE CBS sitcom ''Everybody Loves Raymond'' now regularly beats Fox's ''Ally McBeal'' in the Monday night Nielsens. Recently, an executive producer of ''Raymond,'' Philip Rosenthal, expressed his delight to Entertainment Weekly with a notable shortage of grace, semantic and otherwise. Asked how he accounted for the superior ratings, Mr. Rosenthal said, ''Everyone on our show has no problem eating.'' Sore winners are bad enough; boorish ones should guffaw to themselves in private.

title: CULTURE ZONE; Thou Shalt Do Soundtracks
description: Pop music used to mistrust Hollywood. Even after the success of ''Saturday Night Fever,'' performers were still so skittish about appearing on soundtracks that Jerry Bruckheimer had a hard time getting anybody to commit to a movie he was producing called ''Flashdance.'' The soundtrack that nobody wanted went on to sell six million copies. In the early 90's, ''The Bodyguard'' sold 16 million, and now nearly every major label has a division dedicated to placing its artists in movies.

title: Lethal Chemistry At Harvard
description: While investigating the suicide of Jason Altom, Hall searches for the unnoticed clue that would have predicted the graduate student's death. Hall wants to believe that if someone at Harvard had seriously gone looking, then he could have been saved.

description: Is this a Harry Thomason creation, that is, ''If you can't be as good as they were, then bring them down to your level''? Or is it all part of a vast left-wing conspiracy?

His hand-tailored men's and women's clothing, many pieces made from cashmere and gabardine, include coats from $500 to $4,000; men's suits, $650 to $2,000, and dresses, $250 to $1,200.

title: Habitats/Clock Tower Building in Brooklyn; To Dumbo, With Love
description: YOU wouldn't think it would be, but the traffic on the bridge is riveting. Sitting in the spare loft, which is all white and gray, one finds it impossible not to look, to watch the cars hurtling by. The occasional subway train seems lighter above ground, as if freed by some mysterious constraint imposed by life below. Like a huge canvas, the bridge fills the living-room window.

title: The Peninsula Hotel: A Touch of Hong Kong
description: Visitors to the Peninsula New York who crave a sense of the hotel's former Beaux-Arts trappings can gaze up at the lobby's magnificent wedding cake ceiling. But not much else from the past is on view at the 23-story hotel, which closed for renovations in January and reopened quietly last month. The lobby, lined with marble floors and Oriental carpets, is still grand. But with paintings by Helen Frankenthaler and Robert Motherwell and a new palette of creams, blacks and pale golds, the hotel has become more contemporary. After 10 years as part of the Peninsula Group, the building that started life in 1905 as the Gotham Hotel on 55th Street just west of Fifth Avenue bears a striking resemblance to the Peninsula Hong Kong, provided you don't look out the windows.

title: Tan in a Packet
description: Self-tanning creams streak, turn orange and are so difficult to apply that fans of fake tans often have salons apply the creams for them. Now they can try Tantowel, a travel-size towelette with self-tanning lotion. ''It's something to carry in your pocket or throw in your bag, so you can tan when you're on the go,'' said Darian Braun, a Las Vegas-based investor, who developed the product after his mother survived skin cancer six years ago. It's been available since September at Ricky's drugstores. One $2 towelette provides enough coverage for the face and neck. A head-to-toe tan takes four or five packets. After a couple of hours, the tan emerges. Despite Tantowel's strong smell of coconut, it is less of a savage island tan than a rosy glow.

title: Murder and Other Social Ills
description: It is no easy task to hold a reader's attention when a novel's outcome is obvious from the very first page. But Susan Isaacs has such a knack for entertaining her reader with the details of American pop culture -- from brand names and television shows to the most fashionable neuroses -- that it's easy to be distracted from the predictability of her plot. In her eighth novel, RED, WHITE AND BLUE (HarperCollins, $25), Isaacs has taken on a formidable project: to write a multigenerational family drama that is also a romantic comedy and a murder mystery and a serious consideration of weighty issues like anti-Semitism and assimilation -- all without losing her sense of humor or her eye for the entertaining detour. At the center of the novel are Charlie Blair, an F.B.I. agent from Wyoming, and Lauren Miller, a reporter for a Long Island newspaper called The Jewish News. It is clear from the start that Charlie and Lauren are lovers-to-be; they are also distant cousins, several generations removed. The story of their common ancestry, which reads like a tale of ''city mouse-country mouse'' ad-libbed by a Jewish grandmother, makes up the first half of the novel. It begins in the late 19th century with the arrival of Lauren and Charlie's great-great-grandparents on a ship in New York harbor and follows the divergent paths of the family's two halves in Wyoming and New York -- all the way up to the present. In the novel's second half, Lauren and Charlie are at last brought together after a series of it-could-only-happen-in-a-novel coincidences surrounding their investigation of Wrath, an anti-Semitic, white supremacist hate group in Wyoming. Never mind the preposterousness of this subplot. ''Red, White and Blue'' is nothing if not a delightful diversion. Nora Krug

title: 'Jesus Christ Superstar' In Revisionist Staging
description: A BLOOD-RED banner, unfurled in rude, defiant control of the stage, flaunts a swastika-like symbol, black on white, at its center. It is the first eye-popper as you go, startled and hesitant, to your seat at the Helen Hayes Performing Arts Center here. Could this be ''Springtime for Hitler,'' live and in color?

title: BROWSING THE WEB'S NEWSSTAND
description: When you visit a city, the local newspaper can give you a feel for what the people there are talking about, shopping for, living in. Weather forecasts can be vital on a vacation, theater and movie listings can take you out of the rain, and the doings of the local sports teams provide a conversational entry with strangers.

title: The Nation: Battles Joined -- A Country at War, Both Abroad and at Home; Behind the Urge to Impeach
description: THE House Republican drive to impeach President Clinton, in the face of considerable evidence that the American public is firmly in Mr. Clinton's corner, would appear to be either astonishingly principled or stunningly ill-advised. It is hard to recall a moment in the nation's history when Congress so completely defied public sentiment, disregarding warnings about the political repercussions.

title: Beethoven's Hair Tells All!
description: Is using new scientific evidence to reinterpret history, with safeguards to ensure accuracy, any different from using a newly discovered diary or packet of letters? New sources mean new interpretations. Why are we afraid of facts? Is reading a diary not invasive? Rejecting objective evidence is the equivalent of historical malpractice.

title: Fine Company On a Desert Isle
description: IT was a phone call from one dream island to another. I sat in my Manhattan apartment talking to a former New Yorker who now runs a hotel on Salt Cay in the Caribbean. It turned out that he did indeed have room available in his Mount Pleasant Guest House where I could stay while I did some scuba diving.

title: Perspective; A New Plan For Reform In College Athletics
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association recently created a 27-member working group to conduct hearings on Division I basketball. The issues to be addressed in the coming months range from the image of intercollegiate basketball to the number of athletes leaving college early to enter the National Basketball Association draft. If the working group is truly concerned about student-athlete welfare, it will do well to begin its deliberations by examining a professional basketball league being proposed by Paul McMann, a professor of accounting at Babson College outside Boston.

title: Screaming Yellow
description: ''The ball seems to pop out like a Godzilla movie,'' said Bill Gray, the equipment editor at Tennis magazine, speaking of Competivision sunglasses, which were recently introduced by Bolle. They are designed to help tennis players focus on the ball. A special filter in the lens makes yellow more vivid and other colors blend into a black-and-white monochrome, separating the court background from the ball. The high-tech specs, available at sporting goods stores nationally, cost $119, or $145 with a prescription adapter. They are meant to fight glare, but can also be worn indoors. Hayden Ashton, left, a tennis pro who works at the Midtown Tennis Club, tried them during an afternoon of lessons. ''I don't usually have any trouble seeing the ball,'' he said. ''But wearing these you can't miss.'' They are also handy around the office if you are looking for a legal pad, yellow stick-on notes or that missing highlighter.

title: A Conjunction of Aspiring and Risen Stars
description: FOR the virtuoso, fiddling with others interrupts the solitude of practice, and, for better or worse, exposes the artist to diverse musical views. Compatible personalities may ignite a piece of chamber music -- just as clashing ones may strangle it -- and provide an unforgettable experience for audience and players.

title: A Dresser for the Ages
description: There's a beauty in dirt,'' says Sandy Powell, who this year designed the costumes for the glam-rock extravaganza ''Velvet Goldmine'' and the romantic Elizabethan romp ''Shakespeare in Love.'' ''When I go to the movies, I think, Why is that dress so clean? The boat is going down and they look perfect. You want to have beauty in a film, but if something looks a bit worn, a bit soiled, it usually has more depth.'' Powell, who projects a mix of toughness, certainty and enormous passion, pauses for a moment, dunking her croissant into a huge cup of cafe au lait at Le Gamin, a restaurant in Manhattan. Powell is in New York for the premiere of ''Goldmine,'' but as usual she is also working: designing for ''The End of the Affair,'' a movie based on the Graham Greene novel that will star Ralph Fiennes and Julianne Moore. ''It's all sex,'' she says. ''The movie is set during the war in London, so I've been looking at underwear from the 40's. The costumes will be simpler than what I've done recently, but any period can be interesting.'' She pauses again, breaking into a smile. ''I've never really been attracted to designing for the boy or girl next door.''

title: Getting a Better Grasp Of American History
description: TO understand American history one must recognize the central role of slavery, says Dr. David Brion Davis, the Sterling professor of history at Yale and a Pulitzer Prize-winning scholar on slavery and abolition. Dr. Davis is the director of the Gilder Lehrman Center for the Study of Slavery, Resistance and Abolition, the nation's first research center to focus on slavery in the New World, which was recently established at Yale. The centerwas endowed by two Yale graduates, Richard Gilder and Lewis E. Lehrman, who share a passion for American history.

title: A Good Man Taken Over by an Irish Gangster
description: BRENDAN GLEESON bears an uncanny resemblance to Martin Cahill, the maverick Dublin gangland boss whom he plays in John Boorman's new movie, ''The General,'' which opened Friday in New York. Yet there was another, more subtle, reason for casting the burly Irish actor as the mobster. In order to convey why Dubliners came to admire this hardened criminal, murdered by the I.R.A. in 1994, Mr. Boorman needed a likable Cahill. And Mr. Gleeson is very likable. But he also has what the veteran director calls ''essential goodness,'' which is why he almost turned down his biggest movie role to date.

title: Three More Reasons To Hail a New Russia
description: MOMENTOUS political shifts always breed unintended consequences, and frequently the changes are cultural. So when the Soviet Union collapsed a decade ago, it stood to reason that artistic ground would begin to shift. Indeed, one of the happier consequences of that nation's disintegration has been the reappearance in the West of the Russian singer.

title: The World; In Latin America, the Strongman Stirs in His Grave
description: ALL across Latin America, presidents and party leaders are looking over their shoulders. With his landslide victory in Venezuela's presidential election on Dec. 6, Hugo Chavez has revived an all-too-familiar specter that the region's ruling elite thought they had safely interred: that of the populist demagogue, the authoritarian man on horseback known as the caudillo.

Immortalized in films like ''Desk Set'' (where single ''girls'' Katharine Hepburn and Joan Blondell tipsily moon about men), these annual debaucheries were not just the invention of Hollywood, but the real thing in offices all over Manhattan.

title: December 13-19; Charges in Disappearance Of Manhattan Woman
description: Prosecutors charged the lead suspects in the disappearance of an elderly Manhattan woman with murder, setting the stage for a trial next year that would be one of the rare cases where a murder is prosecuted without the victim's body being found. Sante Kimes, 64, and her son Kenneth, 24, carried out a sophisticated scheme to defraud Irene Silverman of her ornate Upper East Side mansion, according to an 84-count indictment. And they left a detailed paper trail, including notes about the scheme and a forged deed transferring the mansion to a corporation they control, according to the charges. DAVID ROHDE

description: Melissa Errico, the actress, was married yesterday to Patrick W. McEnroe, the tennis player, at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in New York. Msgr. Thomas P. Leonard performed the ceremony.

description: To the Editor: In Terry Trucco's article on the Grand Princess, she said, ''Though many people book cruises through travel agents, I called the Princess cruise line directly.''

description: Starting Jan. 1, reservations for the 22 most popular camping areas in the National Park System may be made up to five months in advance.

description: To many of the staunch conservatives who have disdained Bill Clinton from the start, the impeachment of the President brought unwavering approval but little cheering.

description: OVER the last decade the 614,000-square-foot Willingboro Plaza went from a vibrant regional shopping center to a ghost town -- 13 shuttered buildings spread over 56 acres at the western edge of the Burlington County Township of Willingboro.

Dr. John Reumann, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church in New York.

title: Pay for Play
description: FAYEZ AZEEZ sat in the bleachers with butterflies in his belly. While his teammates slipped out of their business suits and into gym clothes, Mr. Azeez came ready to play, wearing a sweatsuit embroidered with his team's name, Standard & Poor's, and a look as serious as that of a Game 7 pitcher in the World Series.

title: Where Everybody Knows The Martini's Name
description: Ivy, a nightclub featuring a dance floor and several theme rooms, opened last month at the site of the old China Club in the Beacon Hotel basement at 2130 Broadway, at 75th Street.

title: A Niche Business: Dorms for New York Students
description: THE QE2 was docked at Casablanca in 1989 when Jeanie Bowers Scott, then performing on board as an opera singer, received a call from her husband, George. ''I bought a building for $13 million,'' he said, ''and when you get back we are moving in with a bunch of college students.''

title: The Case For Time Off
description: Q. I work for a small company with 30 or so employees. People who have been with the company a year receive only four days of sick and vacation time combined. All of us feel overworked and underpaid. How can we get the owner to give us more time off?

title: Last Dance at the Rainbow Room
description: ALAN RICHMAN is pretty plugged in when it comes to restaurants. After all, he's the food and wine critic of GQ magazine. But hearing that the Rainbow Room will soon be closed to the public for all but Friday night, Sunday brunch and the occasional holiday was news to him.

title: Jordan Fills Tall Order As Pirates Rally to Win
description: For nearly 30 minutes of its 63-52 victory over Northwestern today, Seton Hall sent one defender after another into the post in what was mostly a vain effort to stop the Wildcats' 6-foot-11-inch Evan Eschmeyer. But after a 3-point play by Eschmeyer, a sixth-year senior, pushed the Wildcats ahead of the Pirates, Seton Hall Coach Tommy Amaker gave the assignment to the 6-6 senior Duane Jordan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITALNY, ETHEL Z.
description: SPITALNY-Ethel Z. Of Aventura, Fl. On December 17, 1998. Beloved wife of Melvin. Devoted mother of David Kahn (Linda), Daniel Kahn (Nancy) and Debra Brun. Adored grandmother of Lesley Berkowitz (Steven), Hillary and Wendy Kahn, Stefanie and Jamie Kahn, Jeffrey Schwartz (Debbie) and Andrew Schwartz (Heath). Also greatgrandmother of Amanda Schwartz, Ben and Sam Schwartz. Loving sister of Edward Zornberg (Flo), Sylvia Posner and Rose Goldberg. Ethel was a successful businesswoman and, most recently, was an inspiration to many as President of the Junior Auxiliary of the Miami Jewish Home and Hospital at Douglas Gardens. She had style and class and will always be remembered. Funeral services on Sunday, December 20th, at 12:30 P.M., at Plaza Memorial in New York City, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Different Kind of Cargo Makes Market Neighbors Wonder
description: Trucks are always being loaded and unloaded along Foster Avenue around East 86th Street, near the Brooklyn Terminal Market, people who work there say. Garages and shipping companies line the avenue, which is really a six-lane highway with two service roads.

title: Three Big Approaches To One Huge Topic
description: READERS with an appetite for historical and literary portraits of New York City, need look no further than these recent books. All three, a 1,383-page narrative, a literary anthology and a photographic compilation, deliver comprehensive, although different approaches, to a huge topic.

title: Color Vision
description: Race Men

title: Japanese-American Museum Is Expanded
description: A pavilion opening next month at the Japanese American National Museum in Los Angeles will feature galleries and a library where visitors will have computer access to photographs and documents. The addition triples the amount of exhibition space at the museum, which is in the Little Tokyo Historic District downtown.

title: Chess; Growth in Computer Analysis Means Longer Hours of Study
description: You hear a lot of complaints from tournament players nowadays about what a burden it is keeping abreast of the latest developments in opening practice. That's true, but it isn't anything new. The Spanish priest Ruy Lopez was already analyzing the opening named after him in 1561. By the late 19th century, some openings required research of 20 moves or more.

Bradley & Son, Funeral Directors, Chatham.

description: On the Craft Trail

title: Why the Rare Winter Drought, and What Next?
description: After five months of searingly dry weather, there are more rocks than water dividing Pennsylvania from New Jersey. There literally isn't enough water in the Delaware River to float a boat.

title: Ivory Tower Retirement Power
description: T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F., the private pension fund for teachers, urges schools to put new hires into their retirement plans from Day One, even though its own employees have to wait five years before they qualify for benefits. But that seeming contradiction doesn't bother John H. Biggs, the fund's chief executive. Professors at many institutions often have to switch jobs to reach the Holy Grail of tenure, he reasons, leaving fewer years for accumulating benefits. ''It's important to get them in right away,'' he said. By contrast, many T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F. workers are clerical workers or people right out of high school or college, who haven't yet settled on a career. ''It's a different job market,'' he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTEL, MICHAEL D.
description: HARTEL-Michael D. Of NYC, and Easton, MD, formerly of Westport, CT. Founder and CEO of Omnimark, Inc., of Hartel Catalano & Gornick, Inc., and of BakerHartel Advertising, on Tuesday, December 15, 1998, in Tampa, FL, of a heart attack. He leaves his loved children Steven, Christopher, Michael, Jennifer and his two grandchildren. A famly service will be held in Westport, CT. He is deeply mourned by his partner Barbara Eveland, and by his friends and associates who will hold a memorial service for Michael at Omnimark. Details are now being determined.

title: Washington Residents Seek Action On Vote Suit
description: The District of Columbia has requested immediate action on a lawsuit against the Federal Government seeking voting representation in Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENTE, ELLIN F.
description: ENTE-Ellin F. Age 71. Of Westport. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Howard K. Ente. Beloved mother of Stephen P. Ente and Douglas E. Ente, loving mother-in-law of Gail, adored and adoring grandmother of David, Brian, Frances, and Karin, much loved sister of Sally F. Brodio, brother-in-law of Dr. Gerald Ente, and aunt of Katherine Pearlman, Emily Chadbourne, Margaret Munves, Peter Ente, William Ente, and a friend and mentor to many. She will be deeply missed and never forgotten. Services will take place Monday, 1 PM from Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Rd., Westport, CT, with interment at Willowbrook Cemetery.

title: The Tamale Follies
description: Having a father who cooks is not always easy. But for the Najars of Glendale, Calif., that was the least of it. Their dad, Leo, is a doctor who grew up in Mexico, and was determined that his own six kids dream big, all-American dreams and speak nothing but English. Yet even a fierce assimilationist like Leo can experience the occasional cultural lapse. Like on Thanksgiving, when he would calmly inoculate the bird with several syringes of cognac, or at Christmas, when the scent of tamales, rather than balsam and gingerbread, would come wafting from their house.

title: F.Y.I.
description: A Singular Invention

title: The Talk of Impeachment Draws a Crowd in Princeton
description: Anyone who believes that the impeachment drama is somehow only a Washington event, with purely inside-the-Beltway sensibilities that leaves the rest of us exempt, should have seen the anti-impeachment rally organized Tuesday by Princeton Democrats on the university campus.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Historic District Plan Advances in Roslyn Heights
description: WHEN a builder applied to the Town of North Hempstead for a variance that would enable him to knock down an 85-year-old house done in the Arts and Crafts style in Roslyn Heights and build two houses in its place, neighbors banded together and raised $1,500 to defeat the proposal.

title: Against the Dark, Insights on Life In the Shortest Days
description: AT first it seems like black humor to schedule an exhibition about the Day of the Dead, a popular and profound celebration in Mexico, during the Christmas season. But the show is full of engaging artifacts and altars displayed against bright pastel-colored walls and it underscores the ancient practice of, during the shortest days of the year, beating back the darkness.

title: Toss and Turn
description: Days shorten, holiday cheer strains, millennial angst is in the air, but Will Shortz's ''Toss and Turn'' word puzzle (Nov. 29) brought me fun, plain and simple. Thanks.

description: IN New York City, if you see an attractive stranger across a crowded bus or in an elevator, you'd have as much chance of seeing that person again as you would of dropping a diamond ring on the sidewalk and finding it there an hour later.

title: From Factory to the Top of Saturn
description: EVER since General Motors was formed through a series of mergers early in this century, executives have often risen to the top without ever managing a factory, relying instead on personal friendships commonly made while serving in the company's powerful treasury office in New York.

title: Clinton's Top Defender Rallies Troops at Front
description: As defiant as the day she blamed the Monica Lewinsky scandal on a ''vast right-wing conspiracy,'' Hillary Rodham Clinton went to Capitol Hill this morning and blasted the impeachment process as unfair and politically motivated. She told House Democrats that the President would continue to fight and that they should, too.

title: California Dreaming, Christmas Wishful Thinking
description: IT is little short of astonishing that at a time when most people are obsessed with music of the last week, and classics may be no more than a year old, listeners still plug into several centuries of musical tradition every holiday season. Mall Muzak includes medieval, Renaissance and Baroque tunes (''O Come, O Come Emmanuel,'' ''What Child Is This,'' ''Joy to the World''), carols from the last century (''Hark, the Herald Angels Sing,'' ''It Came Upon a Midnight Clear'') and hits from just about every decade through the 1960's (''Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer,'' ''Jingle Bell Rock'').

title: When Parents' Good Intentions Go Bad
description: ANN DEPUY thought she was doing what was best for her daughter. ''She was 1 1/2 when I was divorced,'' said Ms. Depuy, a New Canaan resident, ''so I always felt that she needed more than she did in terms of nurture, toys, and things that might bring her happiness. And I think I went really over the deep end, as her Dad did too.''

title: Mad Tidings
description: In the velvet darkness of the bedroom, it could be any time, any place. She rises and walks with unerring steps to the bathroom, only then switching on a light, but does not confront the mirrors. Instead, she showers, standing out of the spray to gently, and with circular motions, massage on Chanel Multihydroxy Active Body Polisher. The BHA and AHA will delicately exfoliate her skin; the exclusive ingredient, Nutrifirm, will moisturize and firm. After rinsing, she lathers with Shiseido 5S Refreshing, a total wash with the scent of orange extract and lemongrass. She inhales deeply to gather in the aromatherapy benefits.

title: An Internet Stock Made for Thinkers
description: YOU can surf the World Wide Web without one bit of Microsoft code on your desktop, or one bit of Netscape Communications, for that matter. You need never venture near Yahoo, America Online or any other self-described portals. But every time you log into the Internet, you are touched by the products and technology of one company: Cisco Systems.

title: Under Sail Through the Grenadines
description: THIS was supposed to be a homage to catatonia. This was going to be a description of how one can do nothing so intensively in the southeastern Caribbean that vacations there work like juice concentrate; a week in the Grenadine Islands can have the recharging effect of, say, two weeks in Florida. I had expected a primitive poultice for burnout, one that I could recommend to all my brethren who feel pressed when they wake up, stressed as they eat, pushed to produce faster and more, faster and more. I thought the remedy was simply stopping.

description: A solid majority of Americans want the Senate to resolve President Clinton's impeachment case without a trial and without removing him from office, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. A majority of the respondents disapprove of the House's decision to impeach Mr. Clinton but, now that it has done so, believe he should be punished no further, the poll showed.

description: President Clinton has adopted a two-track approach to his pending impeachment trial in the Senate, preparing to mount a vigorous legal defense while seeking to reach a compromise on a resolution of condemnation that would allow him to keep his job, White House officials said today.

description: If Zolton Williams had been typical of last spring's graduates at Columbia University Law School, he would now be applying for admission to the bar. But Mr. Williams is not typical.

description: LEVITT-Harold. Of Teaneck, NJ. On December 18, 1998. Beloved husband of Rose (nee Levine). Devoted father of Peter and Susan. Dear brother of Leon Levitt. Loving grandfather of Annie, Michael and Lily Levitt, Matthew and Nora Whelan. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday, 3 PM. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINKMANN, DONALD GERHARD
description: BRINKMANN-Donald Gerhard. Son of the late Gerhard and Helen Brinkmann was born in Riverside, CA. He is survived by his brother, John Brinkmann and a niece and nephew of Riverside, CA. Beloved companion of Mark Weinrod. Don was an inspirational and talented partner of the firm of Gensler Architecture Design and Planning Worldwide. Don was educated at Cal State Polytech College in San Luis Obispo and was a 1969 graduate in architecture of the University of California, Berkeley. He spent 13 years of his professional career as a designer and associate in the San Francisco office of Skidmore Owings and Merrill. Donald joined the New York office of Gensler in 1982 and was made partner in 1985. As the design leader for the firm, his project experience spanned the country and the globe with projects in San Francisco, Minneapolis, Buffalo, Miami, Washington, DC, New York, London and South America. Donald was inducted into the Interior Design Hall of Fame in 1991, and won many design awards for his creative and classic design solutions for law firms, financial institutions, corporations and consulting firms. He recently completed projects for Baron Capital in New York, QVC in Pennsylvania (headquarters), and the Swiss Re. American Headquarters in Manhattan. He was the designer on current projects for Christie's, Bank Boston, Sao Paolo and the American Kennel Club in New York. He succumbed to heart failure following a stroke in New York University Hospital on December 19. A memorial service is planned for early January. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the FIDER (Foundation for Interior Design Education and Research) for a scholarship in the name of Donald Brinkmann, c/o Gensler, Suite 500, 1 Rockefeller Plaza, NY, NY 10020. For information contact John Krtil Funeral Home 212-744-3084.

title: For Ellsworth, Sitting On Bench Is Purgatory
description: On the field today, Percy Ellsworth spent much of the day with his teammates celebrating around him, high-fiving and hugging after his pair of interceptions and nearly another one. And in the locker room afterward, he was the center of attention, too. But for every happy comment from the third-year safety, there seemed to be a bit of frustration seeping through.

title: 2 Boxers Furious After Losing
description: Hasim Rahman and Angel Manfredy claimed to be victims of crimes in the ring in Miami on Saturday night. Both believe they were robbed. But they would have a better chance of getting assault charges filed against their opponents than theft charges against the referees.

title: Media Talk; Embattled Writer to Meet With Anti-Drug Group
description: In an effort to settle the $10 million libel lawsuit filed against him by the drug prevention group DARE over articles he wrote about the organization for Rolling Stone and The New Republic, Stephen Glass has agreed to tell the group what he knows about the two publications' editing and fact-checking processes.

title: Allahabad Journal; Caste and Campus: India's Ivy Is Overwhelmed
description: In its celebrated, brainy heyday, Allahabad University was known as the Oxford of India. Among its graduates are three former Prime Ministers, one former President and the current Minister of Education -- an illustrious alumni roster that now seems ironic for a college majoring in stagnation with a strong minor in chaos.

title: Zambia Announces Deal to Sell Copper Mines
description: After two years of on-and-off negotiations, a deal to sell state-owned copper mines in Zambia has finally been reached, the Finance Minister has announced.

title: Top Dissident Gets 13 Years After Trial In Beijing
description: After a three-hour trial, the most prominent democracy advocate remaining in China was sentenced to 13 years in prison today on charges of seeking to overthrow the state.

title: Reverberations From a Devastated Dream
description: Lillian Hellman was someone people seemed to love or hate (sometimes simultaneously), and the latest book about her, ''A Likely Story: One Summer With Lillian Hellman'' by Rosemary Mahoney, is one that people seem to love or hate, but not simultaneously. Ms. Mahoney, 37, whose ''Whoredom in Kimmage: The World of Irish Women'' was nominated for the National Book Critics Circle Award in 1993, spent two months before her senior year in high school working for Hellman; and when she wasn't washing dishes or answering the phone, she kept a journal about what became a summer from hell at the hands of the great lady of American letters.

A Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated on Tuesday, December 22, 1998, at 10:30 AM, at the Church of the Good Shepherd, Rt. 402, Blooming Grove, PA, with Rev. Healey and Rev. Law as celebrants. Final interment will be at the convenience of the family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, SAMUEL
description: LEVY-Samuel. The officers and members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of their dear friend and fellow member Samuel Levy. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife, Marie, his children and other members of his family. Samuel Weinberg, President

title: What Now? Doubts About U.S. and U.N. Policy on Iraq Increase
description: While American officials went on television today to assert the military achievements of four nights of air attacks against Iraq, there is considerably less clarity about American strategy now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAYSON, MARJORIE
description: JAYSON-Marjorie. Age 94, of Hastings-on-Hudson. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Loving mother of Phyllis Parrott. Cherished grandmother of Jayson Parrott. Dear sister of Happy Wine and Jessie Wilson. Visiting Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave, Dobbs Ferry (Exit 17, Saw Mill). Funeral 3:30 Tuesday, First Reformed Church, 18 Farragut Ave, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

title: Off-Peak New Yorkers
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Educational, Not Gender Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Tale of a Cranky Londoner Is an All-American Charmer
description: Quite dapper in a Victorian frock coat, period chalk-stripe trousers and a black top hat, Gerald Charles Dickens, great-great-grandson of the great, great novelist, pointed his walking stick at the audience gathered here at the local library.

title: Pinching Pennies in a Land of Copper
description: Five months ago, the copper mine where Mario Olivares had dug, drilled and hammered for the last six years shut down under the pressure of collapsing world copper prices. From a monthly salary of more than $400, he now earns less than a dollar a day selling flavored ices from his wooden shack.

title: Often Pugnacious Parcells Shows a Pensive Side
description: Bill Parcells, that old softie, wiped his eyes, celebrated with a chicken pot pie for a late-night supper and then went to bed Saturday, having taken his third National Football League team to a division title.

title: PARTIES IN SENATE SPLIT ON ISSUE OF WHETHER TRIAL IS MANDATORY: SETTING NEW STAGE
description: A day after the House impeached President Clinton, Senators from both parties pledged today to restore civility to the proceedings even as they quickly divided largely along party lines over whether the President must face a Senate trial or could be subject to censure.

title: Corrections
description: The introduction to a grouping of articles in Arts & Ideas on Dec. 12 about the suitability of serious subjects for musicals referred incorrectly to Andre Bishop, the author of one reminiscence. He is the artistic director of Lincoln Center Theater, not Lincoln Center itself.

title: Helping Out A Mother Fighting A Disability
description: Olive Cesar, 35, felt chest pain on the morning of Aug. 13, but she ignored it and drove from her apartment in Brooklyn to her nurse's aide job on Long Island.

title: Uganda's Helping Hand to Congo Rebels Raises Questions About Motives
description: There is a certain touchiness among Ugandan soldiers posted here in Congo about what they are doing in the middle of someone else's rebellion.

title: Treasury Sets Sale of Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on both the outstanding three-month and six-month bills was 4.37 percent.

title: Louis K. Sher, 84; Exhibited Foreign Films
description: Louis K. Sher, a movie exhibitor who pioneered the showing of foreign films, died on Nov. 25 in Phoenix, Ariz. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADDEN, LORETTA GARDNER, ESQ.
description: MADDEN-Loretta Gardner, Esq. On December 19, 1998. Dear wife of Brian. Loving mother of Kaitlyn. Beloved daughter of William J. and Frances Madden. Loving sister of William F., Mary Frances Garry, Edward, Christopher, and the late Regina Cammarosano. Reposing McLaughlin Funeral Home, 9620 Third Ave, Bklyn, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9. Mass of the Resurrection, St. Andrew's R.C. Church, 10 AM, Wednesday. Interment Resurrection Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Bishop Kearney High School Scholarship Fund (60 St and Bay Pkwy, Bklyn) in memory of Loretta and Regina Madden. For information, 718-439-6640.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review of ''The Blue Room'' last Monday misstated the origins of the play's co-stars. Nicole Kidman was born in Hawaii, not Australia, although she does have dual citizenship, and Iain Glen is Scottish, not English.

title: Micron Spot Goes To Internet First
description: Micron Electronics Inc. in Nampa, Idaho, is introducing a commercial that is to appear first on the Internet and then on television. The spot, created by Bam in Austin, Tex., will feature Jeri Ryan, who plays the character Seven-of-Nine on the series ''Star Trek Voyager.''

title: Sole Gay Synagogue Finds Itself Robust at 25
description: In 1973, Jacob Gubbay, a Jew from India, placed a tiny classified advertisement in The Village Voice that read ''Gay Synagogue: Friday Night Service.''

title: Media Talk; Financial Columnist's Comments Start a Debate
description: When the money manager, columnist and television commentator James J. Cramer spoke about the fledgling Internet data broadcasting company Wavephore on the Dec. 2 episode of the CNBC stock market program, he probably did not intend to spur a debate on the ethics of commentators in the financial media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBICI, JUDITH L.
description: OBICI-Judith L. (Age 48.) On December 19, 1998, of New York. Loving wife of Geoffrey Obici and mother of Danielle Rivera and stepmother of Christopher Obici. Twenty nine year employee and vice president at Citibank. She illuminated the true meaning of friendship, love, kindness and mentor throughout her short lifetime. Viewing Monday and Tuesday at the John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, New York. Funeral Mass at St. John the Evangelist, on Wednesday, at 10 AM, with interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: GE Capital And Goldman Buy Thai Debt
description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc., in conjunction with the GE Capital Corporation, has agreed to pay 23.6 billion baht, or $645 million, for about a third of the loans left over from Thailand's unsuccessful auction last week of assets seized from defunct financial companies.

title: After Mastering the Universe, Back to the Homework
description: It is time to take up childish things.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 2 about the building of the new Tate Gallery of Modern Art in London misspelled the surname of a British artist who is becoming internationally known. She is Gillian Wearing, not Waring.

title: On the Streets Near the White House, a New Subplot to Life as Usual
description: The morning after impeachment, the capital city stirred back to life in its familiar Sunday ways. Deacon Gary B. Pledger, an alumnus of the homeless contingent living across from the White House, had the chili and cornbread cooking for his church's weekly homily-and-handout spread for his old buddies.

title: Columbus Returns as 600-Ton Tourist Magnet
description: Police Officer Adan Vargas Maldonado tried to picture what a 30-story-tall bronze statue of Christopher Columbus would look like.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, ROBERT E.
description: DAVIS-Robert E. Of Cheshire, CT. Formerly of Southbury, CT, NYC, and Yonkers, NY. On December 18, 1998. Predeceased by first wife Margaret Mary Davis and son Frederick R. Davis. Survived by his wife Ruth Esing Davis, one stepdaughter, Nancy Kaufman, two grandchildren, three greatgrandchidren, two step-grandchildren and two step-great-grandchildren. Reposing Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Ave, Hawthorne, NY, on Tuesday morning, 11-12 noon, where funeral services will be held at 12 noon. Interment Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Economists Simply Shrug As Savings Rate Declines
description: Americans should be saving like crazy. Baby boomers -- the oldest in the group of 78 million who were born between 1946 and 1964 are due to retire in a decade or so -- are now in their prime earning years. The after-tax return on investments has rarely been better and the proliferation of 401(k) plans, individual retirement accounts and other tax-favored saving plans has made thrift more painless than ever.

title: Less Pressure From Wall St. For Cutbacks In Newsrooms
description: The financial news bulletins from the newspaper industry since the summer have had a depressingly familiar ring to journalists who lived through the brutal advertising recession of the early 1990's or the run-up in newsprint prices three years ago. Since September, staff reductions have been announced at The Wall Street Journal, at The Dallas Morning News and twice over at The Los Angeles Times. From midsummer on, advertising revenue was down unexpectedly in markets like Boston, Dallas, Los Angeles and San Jose.

title: After the Attack on Iraq
description: Initial Pentagon assessments of the four-day air campaign against Iraq suggest that Saddam Hussein suffered heavy but not irretrievable losses. It may take Iraq as long as a year to restore its ability to deliver biological and chemical weapons against potential targets in the Middle East. If that estimate holds up, the time should be used to reinforce diplomatic support for sanctions and future military action, if needed. It should also be used, if possible, to reconstitute an effective program of inspections and monitoring of weapons facilities inside Iraq. Baghdad's current refusal to allow meaningful United Nations inspections may not be the last word on the subject.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVMAN, MOSES
description: BRAVMAN-Moses. Adored and adoring husband of Celia for 67 wonderful years. Devoted father of Irving and his wife Rose, doting ''Papa'' to his ''Goldschatz'' Elizabeth and her husband Jonah, and a truly ''great'' great-grandfather to Noah, Sarah, Rebecca, Daniel and Gideon Turk. He gave much joy and took much joy in his life. Ninety-four years was not long enough. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him.

title: Different Giants Odysseys, But Reaching Same Point
description: KENT GRAHAM and Conrad Hamilton work on opposite sides of the football and sit at opposite ends of the Giants' locker room. Their careers lie at opposite poles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRUCHT, LUCICA
description: FRUCHT-Lucica. The first Romanian political refugee was a courageous intellectual and powerful political person. Lucica was a friend to political people and was a friend of people from Free Europe Radio. She was as an friend of the honorable family of Manuila Popa Thedoru, Dr. Zaharia Lupovici. Lucica was a woman of taste in arts and fashion. Lucica, rest in peace.

title: Media Talk; Former Journalist Is Cited With Contempt
description: A former reporter for a Southern California newspaper has been cited with contempt and sentenced to jail for refusing to disclose a source to the authorities. If an appeals court upholds the citation, he would be the first journalist jailed for protecting a source in more than two decades in California, a state generally seen as having the strongest so-called shield laws for journalists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEMKO, FRANCINE S.
description: TEMKO-Francine S. On Friday, December 18, 1998. Francine S. Temko, wife of Stanley L. Temko, mother of Richard J., Edward J. and William D. Temko, sister of Louise Bookstaver and Maxine Margolin. Also survived by five grandchildren. Interment private. A memorial celebration will be held at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to The Legal Aid Society, 666 11th Street NW, Washington, DC 20001-4589.

title: The Most Seasoned Players Show Undiminished Skills
description: More than half the members of the American Contract Bridge League are at least 55 years old and are therefore eligible to play in events restricted to senior players. These events are becoming more and more popular and significant. In the recent Fall National Championships in Orlando, Fla., the Senior Knockout Team Championship attracted 34 entries and lasted 5 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAUGHAN, REV. WILLIAM T., C.M.
description: GAUGHAN-Rev. William T., C.M. On December 17, 1998. Assistant Adjunct Professor, Department of Sociology/Anthropology, St. John's University and Parish Priest at St. Ignatius Loyola, Hicksville. Loving brother of Dr. Dorothy DeBoer of Chicago and devoted uncle of Daniel DeBoer. Dear friend of Deadre McVey. Family will receive friends at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Hicksville, today from 9:30 AM to 11 AM. Funeral Mass to follow 11 AM. Interment Maryhill Cemetery, Niles, Illinois. Donations to St. Vincent DePaul, c/o St. Ignatius Loyola, 129 Broadway, Hicksville, NY 11801, would be appreciated.

title: 2 Arrested as Cuban Refugee Rescue Ends
description: Coast Guard rescue teams looking for 6 people missing since a speedboat carrying 21 Cuban refugees capsized have called off the search and charged two men with alien smuggling.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the General Motors Corporation's appointment of Cynthia M. Trudell as chairwoman and president of its Saturn division misstated the dates of her service at G.M.'s transmission factory in Ypsilanti, Mich. She was a manufacturing engineering manager and later an operations manager there from 1987 to 1990, not 1981 to 1990. From 1981 to 1987, she was a manager at G.M.'s transmission factory in Windsor, Ontario.

title: Paul Gitlin, 83, Pioneering Literary Agent to Stars
description: Paul Gitlin, a lawyer and literary agent who brokered multimillion-dollar deals for authors in the early 1970's, died on Wednesday. He was 83.

title: Antonio Ordonez Dies at 66; Matador in Hemingway Book
description: Antonio Ordonez, a leading bullfighter in the 1950's and the last survivor of the dueling matadors chronicled by Hemingway in ''The Dangerous Summer,'' died on Saturday in a Seville hospital. He was 66.

title: Wondering About Victory In the War on Terrorism
description: If you have lost track, amid the unfamiliar names and murky allegations of who is supposed to have done what in the year's terrorist bombings in East Africa, tonight's ''Investigative Reports'' provides a sketchy guide. Drawn mainly from American sources, ''Death to America: The Terrorism Trail'' lays out the evidence and suspicions of what has become the case of the United States of America vs. Osama bin Laden.

title: Perquisites And Total Autonomy
description: The International Olympic Committee has 102 male members and 12 female members. It has princesses, princes and a sheik. It has four generals from Africa, two brothers from Mexico and a lot more bona fide businessmen and lawyers from all corners of the world than bona fide Olympic heroes like the French skier Jean-Claude Killy, the Dutch judo athlete Anton Geesink and the Czech gymnast Vera Caslavska.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The American people are good, but the leaders are bad. They are cowboys. It is all about Monica.''

title: Democrats Stand By Clinton, but It Isn't Personal
description: One message from the House for President Clinton on Saturday was that he was blessed with the stalwart loyalty of his fellow Democrats.

title: First Surviving Set Of 8 Babies Is Born
description: A 27-year-old Houston woman became the mother of the only known living set of octuplets, giving birth yesterday to five girls and two boys. Another girl was born on Dec. 8.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Dissecting a Ritual Prayer to Learn Its Profundity
description: KADDISHBy Leon Wieseltier588 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50.

title: Standards Are a Calling For Bold SUNY Trustee
description: When Candace de Russy taught a course called ''America and Historical Decline'' a few years ago at the New School for Social Research, her favorite author was the Spanish philosopher Jose Ortega y Gasset. She was taken with his lament over the decline of European civilization, the decline of standards and the lack of leadership by the passive elite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERTOFF, LIVIA (NEE EISEN)
description: CHERTOFF-Livia (nee Eisen). Of Delray Beach, FL. Formerly of Elizabeth, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Dr. Gershon B. Chertoff, devoted mother of Michael Chertoff, dear mother-in-law of Meryl, loving sister, and most precious grandmother of two grandchildren. Funeral services at ''Kreitzman's Memorial Home,'' 1500 Morris Avenue, Union, NJ, on Monday, at 1 PM.

Adored friend of Leon Horne. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89 St., Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Senate's Role as 'Saucer' Defines Clinton Strategy
description: President Clinton's strategy for survival depends on the differences between the Senate and the House, differences intended by the framers of the Constitution and at least as evident today as they were when the Senate acquitted President Andrew Johnson in 1868.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARRON, JUDITH
description: ARRON-Judith. The entire Board of Trustees of Carengie Hall joins us in paying tribute to Judith Arron, a woman of great courage, leadership and vision. Her immeasurable contribtuion to this great hall and her generous, unbounded spirit will now become part of the legacy of Carnegie Hall, and will continue to be felt for generations. Our deepest love and sympathy go to her husband Ronald, her sons Joseph and Edward, and her family. At the request of her family, donations may be sent to the Bone Marrow Transplant Program at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center, and to Carnegie Hall. Isaac Stern, President Sanford I. Weill, Chairman The Board of Trustees of Carnegie Hall

title: U.S. Declares It Might Need More Strikes on Iraq Soon
description: The Clinton Administration warned today that Iraq might quickly try to rebuild its programs to develop chemical and biological weapons after last week's furious air strikes, and that additional American strikes might be needed soon.

title: The executive changes keep on coming at agencies like Messner Vetere and D.M.B.& B.
description: THE year may be winding down, but executive changes at agencies show no signs of following suit. There were shifts late last week at shops including Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, Partners & Shevack/Wolf, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications and Digital Pulp.

title: A Major Merger Shakes Up the World of Rock
description: Right now is not a good time to be in a rock band. The reason is Seagram's $10.4 billion acquisition of Polygram from Philips, which became official on Dec. 10. In the process of consolidating Seagram's Universal Music Group with Polygram's music holdings (which jointly account for some 25 percent of the United States and European music markets), Seagram executives have pledged to unload enough assets to save $300 million a year.

title: Essay; No Sore Winners
description: ''Your representative owes you, not his industry only, but his judgment; and he betrays, instead of serving you, if he sacrifices it to your opinion.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, STELLA KRONOVET
description: ABRAHAM-Stella Kronovet. Dr. and Mrs. Abraham welcomed us at Havdalah in Long Beach fifty years ago. Our family grew up with Danny, Judy, Jerry and Roy z'l, rejoiced with them and shared their sorrow. A visit to her in Toronto was a special experience. May they, their wonderful spouses, grandchildren and their families find consolation in Jerusalem. Els Bendheim and Family

title: N.B.A. Players Say a Settlement Is Near
description: As if the season were nearing the halfway point, Karl Malone has been running hills, lifting weights and playing pickup games with Utah Jazz teammates. His feelings about the labor dispute resemble those of most of his locked-out peers -- he thinks the owners' offer is fair, and he believes there will be a season.

title: E-Mail Virus Preys on Microsoft Word
description: Computer security experts are warning clients about a new software virus that is spread by E-mail, infects Microsoft Word files and has already caused several networks to crash.

title: Singer-Dancer's Imperative: He's Gotta Get to Broadway
description: Can a limber, starry-eyed boy from Covington, Ky., find happiness as a dancer and singer on the stages of Las Vegas and on Broadway? Lee Roy Reams's autobiographical cabaret show, ''Gotta Sing, Gotta Dance,'' at the Firebird Cafe, answers that question with an emphatic yes.

title: Grey Advertising And Lexmark Split Up
description: Grey Advertising in New York and Lexmark International, the maker and marketer of laser and ink jet printers, are mutually parting ways after three and a half years, citing creative differences. As a result, the company's corporate and product advertising account has been placed in review.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Prospectus; A growing number of Silicon Alley companies are helping nonprofit groups distribute the benefits of technology.
description: THREE days after their company managed one of the most successful initial public offerings in the short history of the Internet, brothers Jack and Murray Hidary, the founders of New York-based Earthweb, made a private donation of $10,000 to a nonprofit group known as Mouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTERS, HAROLD G.
description: WALTERS-Harold G. On December 18, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Margaret (nee Donnelly). Devoted father of Margaret Heffernan, Christine Morgan, Paula Porcaro and Mark Walters. Loving grandfather of eleven grandchildren. Beloved brother of William Walters. Retired Principal of P.S. 108, Ozone Park, NY, New York City Public Schools. Visiting Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 6140 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park, NY, Monday, 7-9, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass Saint Margaret's RC Church, Wednesday, 10:30 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Busy Debut For Rookie
description: According to Giants quarterback Kent Graham, the rookie wide receiver Brian Alford was the team's ''secret weapon'' in yesterday's victory over the Chiefs.

title: Compressed Data; An Old Hand at Start-Ups Moves On From I-Village
description: When photographers took pictures of the three founders of I-Village, the New York Internet service for women, they often tried to place Robert Levitan in the center. This proved to be a repeated annoyance to Candice Carpenter, the company's chief executive, and Nancy Evans, its editor in chief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPERST, LAURENCE
description: KAPERST-Laurence. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, its Sisterhood and Men's Club mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted members Robin Kaperst and Stuart Kaperst, and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: 2 Big Media Accounts Placed in Review
description: Two large media accounts have been placed in review. One is for the Sprint Corporation, with billings estimated at $200 million to $250 million, while the other is for Glaxo Wellcome Inc., with billings estimated at $150 million.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: A Woman Who Likes to Do Her Solo the Hard Way
description: The Wendy Osserman Dance Company brought a brief solo and a longer group piece to Dance Theater Workshop on Friday night. Of these two works choreographed by Ms. Osserman, the sharply focused solo proved more effective than the rambling ensemble.

title: Now U.N. Is Left to Ponder Inspections and Sanctions
description: After four days of air strikes against Iraq, the Security Council plans on Monday to begin assessing the damage done to all three legs on which its relations with Baghdad stand -- economic sanctions, arms inspections and a relief program intended to aid Iraqis suffering under an economic embargo.

description: REIN-Mark Alan. 2/12/44 to 12/21/88. Forever in the hearts of his family

title: Market Confidence Is Now Up in the Air
description: As President Clinton stood in the Rose Garden on Saturday afternoon, denouncing the ''poisonous venom'' of Washington and declaring that ''we have a lot to do before we enter the 21st century,'' a few downcast members of his staff clustered together just beyond the circle of cameras and reporters.

title: Enrique Martinez, 72, Dancer At American Ballet Theater
description: Enrique Martinez, a ballet dancer and rehearsal director at American Ballet Theater who staged the classics for ballet troupes in North and South America and Europe, died on Nov. 17 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 72 and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Countdown to '60 Minutes II'; CBS Executives Ready a Clone of Their Golden Brand
description: Ask Jeff Fager, the 44-year-old executive producer of ''60 Minutes II,'' whether he has long dreamed of becoming the next Don Hewitt at CBS News, and he shakes his head.

title: Patents; Wearing a computer may be more fashionable when the processor isn't part of the ensemble.
description: WEARABLE computers are considerably less geeky than they used to be. But the day when the average American wears one as nonchalantly as a Walkman CD player is still several years in the future.

description: Following is a list of the 13 Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee who have been appointed as managers, or prosecutors, for the Senate's impeachment trial of President Clinton. They are listed in order of seniority.

description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Adobe's new products don't banish analysts' skepticism just yet.
description: AFTER a bruising year and a large-scale revamping, Adobe Systems Inc. delivered higher-than-expected earnings and strong revenue for its fourth fiscal quarter. But while praising the company's improved management and new products, analysts generally retained a cautious outlook on Adobe's stock.

title: INSIDE
description: Terror Suspect Sent to U.S.

title: Networks Battle Nielsen as Young Viewers Turn Up Missing
description: Reports of a drastic falloff in the 18- to 34-year-old television audience this season, costing the broadcast networks tens of millions of dollars, have touched off an angry debate between the networks and the company that provides the measurements they live by.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, ALICE WATERS
description: GRANT-Alice Waters. Passed away peacefully on December 18 at home in Hobe Sound, FL. She joined her beloved husband, Donald who died on November 28, 1998. Their extraordinary marriage lasted for over 66 years. Her humor and generosity touched all who knew her. She never forgot a birthday, admitting to only 39 of her own. Not only skillful at the bridge table, graceful on the tennis court and the dance floor, she was also an enthusiastic and creative hostess. She brightened the lives of friends and family alike. Loving mother of Sheila (deceased), Michael D. Grant Jr. of Greenwich, CT, Thomas W. Grant, and Patricia G. Warner, both of Locust Valley, NY. Grandmother to 10 grandchildren: Andrew, Luke, Michael, Bettina, Mimi and Tim Grant Jr., Alexander, Kate, Michael and Alice Warner (deceased). Motherin-law to Elizabeth L. Grant, Mary I. Grant and Douglas A. Warner III. A memorial mass will be held on Friday, March 5, 1999 at 4 PM at St. Christopher's Church, Hobe Sound, FL. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested memorial be made to St. Jude's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105-1905, and the Jupiter Island Clinic, PO Box 375, Hobe Sound, FL 33475.

title: Interpublic Group Announces 3 Deals
description: The acquisition spree by the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York is continuing with the purchases of an agency, an agency office and a corporate communications company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Vikings' Rout Sends Jets Home for Playoffs
description: The biggest Minnesota Vikings fans, for about 32 hours anyway, were sitting in their homes more than 1,000 miles away, scattered throughout the New York area. They were the Jets players and coaches. J-E-T-S. Vikings, Vikings, Vikings?

description: Representative Dennis Hastert has gone suddenly from being an anonymous middle-level legislator to the presumptive Speaker of the House, less because of who he is than because of who he is not.
