title: Editorial Observer; The Brave New World of Sex-Drenched Politics
description: When a young radio talk-show host in Georgia interviewed me about a book I wrote on the history of political gossip, I was befuddled by his repeated requests that I compare ''Richard Nixon's sexual indiscretions with Bill Clinton's.'' It took me a while to realize that he thought Watergate had been about sex. When the anti-impeachment camp said that nothing Mr. Clinton did compared to the evils of Watergate, he concluded it meant that Mr. Nixon had been a much more active adulterer.

title: Players in Clinton's Rise Put Bruised Feelings Aside
description: David C. Leavy graduated from Colby College in Maine six years ago and leapt into Presidential politics: field director in the Maine caucuses for the campaign of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. Within the year, Mr. Leavy had a desk up the hall from the Oval Office, making him a charter member of the cocky and optimistic class of young men and women who lifted Mr. Clinton to victory in 1992.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOR, SHIRLEY (NEE FORSTER)
description: KANTOR-Shirley (nee Forster). Of Englewood Cliffs, NJ. On December 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Harry. Devoted mother of Marilyn Byron, Jay and Barry. Dear sister of Joseph Forster. Loving grandmother of Mark, Eric, Jason, Lindsay, Brett and Rachael. Services were held Sunday at ''Wien & Wien,'' Englewood, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, EDNA
description: FOX-Edna. Age 93, of New York City. Beloved wife of the late Philip Fox. Cherished mother of Millicent Buckner. Adored grandmother of Pamela and David Levine and Jacqueline and Steve Barr. Treasured great-grandmother to Noah, Emma and Cassidy. Also survived by her brothers, sister, nieces and nephews. Services Monday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: More Attacks on Iraq Possible
description: The U.S. warned that Iraq may try to rebuild its weapons programs and that additional American strikes may be needed soon. Page A12.

title: Homeless Deaths Are Rising in San Francisco
description: More homeless people died in San Francisco in the last 12 months than in any year since tracking began in 1985, an increase that has alarmed and frustrated advocates for the homeless and city health workers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, THOMAS J.
description: DOYLE-Thomas J. Of Flushing, on December 18, 1998. (Retired Patrolman, NYPD.) Beloved husband of Marie (Retired, NYPD). Devoted father of Thomas, Michael, Christopher and the late Timothy. Dear grandfather of Kathleen and Christina. Visiting 2-5, 7-9 PM, Monday, at Cassidy Funeral Home, 156 Willis Ave, Mineola. Funeral Mass 10 AM, Tuesday at Holy Family R.C. Church, Flushing. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Compressed Data; Schwab Backs Away From Some Internet Trades
description: In the volatile and warp-speed world of on-line trading, Charles Schwab & Company has blinked.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: A Time to Heal Our Nation
description: It is proverbial that old men plant trees as an act of faith, precisely because they know they won't themselves live to sit under their shade. In this spirit, we believe the time has come to put aside political differences and plant seeds of justice and reconciliation.

title: Iraq, After Saddam
description: The real question in the Middle East isn't whether the bombing of Iraq was called for. It is what will happen after the missile attacks, which were intended to destabilize Saddam Hussein's regime and to help usher in a new Iraqi government.

title: In a Venezuelan Prison, Every Cranny Holds a Clan
description: The prison here is called a center for rehabilitation, but perhaps nowhere in Venezuela do the words have less meaning than inside its gate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, REV. JOHN JOSEPH, S.J.
description: KING-Rev. John Joseph, S.J. Beloved brother of Carol King and Richard J. King. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel in Loyola Hall at Fordham University, on Monday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, and Tuesday 3-5 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Fordham University Church, Tuesday, 8 PM. For information contact Farenga Bros., Directors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINBOTHAM, JUDGE A. LEON, JR.
description: HIGGINBOTHAM-Judge A. Leon, Jr. Earl G. Graves and ''Black Enterprise'' Magazine deeply mourn the passing of Judge A. Leon Higginbotham, Jr., one of the great jurists of our time. He was a truly outstanding leader and role model for our entire nation. For African Americans, his loss is felt even more deeply. A tireless soldier for justice, civil rights, and equal opportunity, he will be sorely missed and impossible to replace.

title: Censure Stirrings in the Senate
description: After the polarizing impeachment proceedings of the House, it is heartening to see the Senate already taking a more measured, less partisan approach to Bill Clinton's serious misconduct. An early and partial sampling of Senate sentiment yesterday suggests there are the makings of a bipartisan deal that would bring this matter to a just and speedy resolution by severely censuring Mr. Clinton while allowing him to complete his term. For the first time since impeachment barreled out of control in the House, there may actually be some leaders in Congress willing to negotiate an endgame agreement with the White House.

title: F.C.C. Mulls Wider Commercial Use of Radical Radio Technology
description: The Federal Communications Commission is considering changing its regulations to permit the use of a radical and controversial communications technology that has the potential to make vastly more efficient use of the increasingly precious radio spectrum.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Sports of The Times; A Career Game Ball for Jets' Leon Hess
description: IT'S known as the game ball, the actual pebble-grained leather football representing a team's triumph. As the Jets' owner, Leon Hess had been awarded a few game balls by his team through the years, but none as treasured as the ball from the 17-10 triumph at Buffalo that assured the Jets of finishing in first place for the first time in 29 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RENEE L.
description: COHEN-Renee L. Of New Rochelle, NY, died on December 19, 1998. She was 69. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Her fight and will to live lives on in all those who were touched by her. Survived by husband Jerome; sons Carl and Scott; daughter Lynne; son-in-law Yehuda; grandchildren Dahna, Rony and Leam. We will miss her immensely. She always taught us how to laugh, not to cry, so even though she's gone, she will never die. The family will receive friends 12 PM, today, at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd, New Rochelle, NY, with the service to follow at 1 PM. Interment will be held at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations be sent to Memorial SloanKettering Research Center, Box E1275, York Ave, NY, NY 10131-0112 or Gilda's Club, 275 Main St, White Plains, NY 10601. For information call George T. Davis Funeral Home, 914-632-0324.

title: Germany Sends Embassy Terror Suspect to U.S.
description: Germany today extradited to the United States a man suspected of playing a central role in the organization that the American Government says bombed its Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in August.

description: In the penultimate week of their regular season, these Giants behaved and played like a new team, as if confidence and know-how had slipped through the transom of the locker room door and drifted from player to player.

description: * Midas Inc., Chicago, to Carat New York, part of the Carat North America unit of Aegis Group P.L.C., to handle the media buying portion of its account, which had been handled by TN Media, New York, a unit of True North Communications. description: The job pays only about $165 a year, plus a case of Spanish sherry. It is meant to be a great honor, but is often considered faintly embarrassing. In the last 15 years it has required an unironic belief in the grave national importance of events like the wedding of the Duke of York and Sarah Ferguson, also known as Fergie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEENAN, DAVID B.
description: KEENAN-David B. Of Mt. Kisco, on December 19, 1998. Beloved husband of Norene. Loving father of David B., Thomas W., Cheryl Keenan and Diane Spreitzer. Dear father-in-law of Josh Brand and John Spreitzer. Adored grandfather of Steven and Kevin Spreitzer. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, December 22, at 4 PM, at the Mt. Kisco Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the American Cancer Society or the Mt. Kisco Presbyterian Church.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ASRELSKY, RACHEL HOLLISTER, KATE
description: ASRELSKY-Rachel HOLLISTER-Kate In loving memory of our daughters, Rachel and Kate, and all the 268 co-victims of Pan Am 103/ Lockerbie Air Diaster, December 21, 1988. ''Born of the sun, they traveled a short way toward the sun and left the vivid air signed with their honor.'' Hope Asrelsky & Babette Hollister

title: Danspace Project, 25, Looks Back Nostalgically
description: Venerable is not the word one would most readily choose to describe the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, that luminous little home for spirited new dance. But the project is 25 years old, an anniversary it celebrated on Saturday night in the first installment of ''Silver Series.'' The series, which will continue with five more programs through June, brings together dancers and choreographers who performed at the project, in many cases shaping contemporary New York dance history with their work.

title: Livingston Not Prepared For Whirl of Last 32 Days
description: As part of his preparation to become Speaker, Robert L. Livingston was reading a book by the master, former Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill's ''All Politics Is Local.''

title: Mel Fisher, 76, a Treasure Hunter Who Got Rich Undersea
description: Mel Fisher, a former chicken farmer who became a Horatio Alger figure among undersea treasure hunters, died on Saturday at his home in Key West, Fla. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, ALFRED
description: HILL-Alfred. Age 79, of Margate, FL. Much beloved husband of Blossom, adored father of Gari and Ira Dansky, cherished grandfather of Rachel Dansky and Lyssa and Stephen Weiss, dear brother of Rita and Selwyn Lande, loved uncle of David and Judy Lande, and a wonderful friend to all who knew him. His family and friends will greatly miss this kind and gentle man. Services Monday, 11 AM, at Temple Beth El, 350 Roxbury Rd, Stamford, CT. Interment following at Temple Beth El Cemetery.

title: Republicans Prevail With a Costly Victory
description: As he sat in the House listening to Representative Robert L. Livingston say he would never be Speaker, even ''the Hammer'' cried.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHTER, JEANNETTE (NEE STEINWAY)
description: RICHTER-Jeannette (nee Steinway). December 19, 1998, at age 99. Private services and interment were held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWFORD, BETTY H.
description: LAWFORD-Betty H. December 19, 1998, in West Palm Beach, FL. Widow of Charles Edward Lawford. Survived by her sister, Margo Stevens of Naples, FL, and two Stevens nephews, Bob and Tim. For we devoted friends, she will always be the wordsmith whose humor never failed us and our top notch croquet maven. Bravo, Betty. At her request no services will be held.

title: Blair Says Use of Force Is 'Global Reality'
description: In a tough-talking assessment of the air attacks on Iraq, Prime Minister Tony Blair urged doubters and critics today to understand the new ''global reality'' that modern diplomacy must be backed up by force.

title: Judith Arron, 56, Who Led Carnegie Hall's Rebirth, Dies
description: Judith Arron, the executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall since 1986, died on Friday at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center in Denver. She was 56 and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: 2 B-1's Join Iraq Combat And Gain Vindication
description: After three decades of controversy, $30 billion and a series of mishaps, one of the nation's most costly and most troubled combat aircraft -- the B-1 bomber -- flew into combat for the first time this week.

title: Compressed Data; Astronauts Get Mail; Microsoft Gets a Foothold
description: The E-mail revolution has breached another frontier -- space.

title: A Game, And Not A Mission
description: Some of the marquee value of Monday night's Denver-Miami game is gone, courtesy of last week's stunner at the Meadowlands. Yet the game is not lacking for drama, at least with the Dolphins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, DAVID S.
description: JACKSON-David S. Died on December 20, at age 96. Husband of Freda. Survived by his daughters Linda, wife of Andrew Segal, and Nancy, wife of Paul Godwin. He also leaves grandsons Edward Segal and William Segal.

title: How Republican Determination Overcame President's Popularity
description: It appeared to be the ultimate comeback in a career marked by seemingly miraculous political resurrections. The night of Tuesday, Nov. 3, was a time of celebration at the White House. Bill Clinton had again defied the odds, embarrassed the experts and vanquished his political enemies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, MILDRED ''MITZI'' (NEE SALIT)
description: BARON-Mildred ''Mitzi'' (nee Salit). On December 18, 1998, in Maryland. Wife of the late Dr. Herbert Friedberg and the late Edward Baron. Mother of Barry S. Friedberg and Esther Stulman. Mother-in-law of Charlotte Moss Friedberg and David Stulman. Loving sister of Morton Salit and Minna S. Williamowsky. Devoted sister-in-law of Sylvia Salit, Dr. Ben A. Williamowsky, Naomi, Wilbur and William Baron, and Ruth Goldman. Grandmother of Ben and James Friedberg and Amanda Wright. Survived by many loving nieces and nephews, great-nieces and nephews. Services and interment were held in in Baltimore, MD, on December 20. Contributions may be directed to Johns Hopkins Neuropsychiatry, c/o Dr. C. G. Lyketsos, Osler 320-The Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, MD 21287. For information call Sol Levinson & Bros, Inc, 800338-1701.

title: Dissidents in Mexican Army Hold Protest Against Government
description: In a broad display of internal division that has no precedent in modern Mexican history, several dozen dissident soldiers, led by a lieutenant colonel, have emerged to issue public criticism of Government economic policies and civilian control of the military as well as of reputed abuses by military courts.

title: The Big City; Capital Sweats As New York Swings
description: JERROLD NADLER knew where duty lay Saturday when his colleague, Robert L. Livingston, resigned from the House of Representatives after confessing to adultery. Mr. Nadler, a Democrat from Manhattan, promptly rose on the House floor to denounce ''a developing sexual McCarthyism.''

title: Yes, in Our Back Yards
description: To the Editor:

title: Battered but Unbowed, Patriots Make Playoffs
description: So many New England Patriots have spent nearly as much time on ice in the training room as on the field this season. Today against the San Francisco 49ers, the Patriots entered with more players ailing and out, chief among them quarterback Drew Bledsoe (broken finger), receiver Terry Glenn (broken ankle) and linebacker Willie McGinest (pulled groin). That is three starters contributing zilch, two of them Pro Bowlers. Glenn, too, is Pro Bowl caliber, the Patriots' best deep pass-catching threat.

description: Call it the ''Full Monty'' wager.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Compressed Data; Holiday Web Shoppers Find Gridlock.com
description: Consumers dreaming of an E-Christmas free of the hassles of crowds have been rushing on line to shop in record numbers. While Internet merchants are delivering plenty of convenience, they are offering up plenty of E-reality as well. In the past weeks, some of the best-known sites have experienced slowdowns and even interruptions in service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, HEDY (NEE LEHMANN)
description: LOEB-Hedy (nee Lehmann). Of New York City. On December 21. Age 94. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Devoted mother of Paul, Ernest, Johanna and the late Betsy Kay and Marianne Loeb. Loving grandmother of five and greatgrandmother of six. Services Tuesday, 11AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to one's favorite charity.

title: Irate Rappers Give Journalists A Combat Beat; Music Press Is a Target Of Violence and Threats
description: In a new music video, a black editor of a hip-hop magazine tears through a dusty animal range, stalked by Ice Cube, a titan of gangsta rap. The rapper, wearing a scowl, eventually slays the journalist, then mounts his taxidermic head on a wall with that of so-called playa hataz (player haters), people who begrudge the success of others.

title: Marino Carries Dolphins; Broncos Look for Answers
description: Striking a balance between the run and the pass was Miami's mantra this season. The Dolphins would sink or swim on their running game, they decided. Their coach, Jimmy Johnson, said he had seen enough of Dan Marino throwing, throwing and throwing some more and Miami being unable to run the ball. So, it was run or bust.

title: ROHM & HAAS TO BUY LEARONAL FOR $460 MILLION
description: The Rohm & Haas Company, a chemicals concern, agreed yesterday to buy Learonal Inc. for $34 a share, or about $460 million, to expand in the printed circuit board segment of the electronics materials market. The offer represents about a 27 percent premium to Learonal's closing price of $26.8125 on Friday. Learonal, which reported $242 million in sales for the fiscal year ended Feb. 28, will be combined with Rohm & Haas's Shipley Company unit. Learonal, based in Freeport, N.Y., also makes chemicals that are used in making semiconductor packaging. Its shares rose $6.875, to $33.6875. Rohm & Haas, based in Philadelphia, rose $1, to $29.625.

title: Sports of The Times; Henderson Runs in Dykstra's Shadow
description: IN the decade previous to this one, New York's most celebrated baseball leadoff hitter was not the one referred to by Mets General Manager Steve Phillips as ''arguably the best leadoff hitter in the history of the game.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 5 about the ethical quandary posed by a father's offer to donate his one remaining kidney to his daughter misstated the source of the phrase that contains the words ''do no harm.'' The phrase is from Hippocrates' work ''Epidemics,'' not from the Hippocratic oath.

title: Man Is Given Life Sentence In '92 Killing Of Ex-Officer
description: A man convicted of second-degree murder in the 1992 killing of a retired police sergeant was sentenced yesterday to the maximum term of 25 years to life in prison by a State Supreme Court judge who called him a ''miscreant.''

title: 4 Who Said Yes On Impeaching Call for Censure
description: A handful of moderate Republicans who voted to impeach President Clinton appealed to the Senate today to consider censuring him instead of convicting him, as many lawmakers scrambled to find a way to avoid a lengthy, embarrassing Senate trial.

title: Williams Is Cleared to Return After Career-Threatening Injury
description: Center Brian Williams, who was the Giants' best offensive lineman until a freakish training-camp injury sidelined him before the 1997 season, has been cleared to resume his football career by the team's doctors, Coach Jim Fassel said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, SAM
description: LEVY - Sam. The Solomon Schechter School of Westchester community notes with deepest sorrow the passing of Sam Levy, devoted trustee. Sam's dedication and generosity played a pivotal roll in the creation and development of our school. Our deepest sympathy to Marie and his family. M. Mac Schwebel, Chairman, Board of Trustees James M. Dubin, Vice Chairman, Board of Trustees Elliot D. Spiegel, Headmaster

title: DOCUMENT MANAGER RENEWS PACT WITH HOSPITAL ALLIANCE
description: The Standard Register Company, a provider of document-management products and services, said yesterday that it had renewed a five-year contract worth $700 million with Premier Inc., the nation's largest hospital purchasing alliance. Under the agreement, Premier will receive business forms and the option of using Standard's Internet-based electronic commerce and document management service. Standard Register, based in Dayton, Ohio, is a business data management company with 12-month revenue of $1.28 billion. Premier, based in San Diego, handles a total of about $10 billion in purchases annually for about 1,800 hospitals around the United States.

title: For the Historic Event, an Unconventional Front Page
description: Headline sizes seen two or three times in a generation were on display Sunday in the country's major newspapers, as editors and reporters strove to make their coverage match, in its sweep, its depth and its manner, the gravity of the second impeachment of a President in American history.

title: Waiting for Other Shoe to Drop in Japan
description: The Japanese Government's proposed national budget aims to lift the economy out of recession, but its vast size underscores the pressing worry that a big spending spree now will break the official coffers later.

title: U.S. Plans to Keep Up Pressure on Saddam : 'Cat and Mouse' Over
description: PARIS  With United Nations arms inspectors no longer able to function in Iraq, the Clinton administration intends to apply open-ended, direct military pressure on the Baghdad regime until the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, finds a way to clear his country's record on clandestine weapons, a senior American official said Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCARDAPANE, FELIX ARTHUR, M.D.
description: SCARDAPANE - Felix Arthur, M.D., 101 years of age, died Saturday, December 19 at St. Francis Hospital, Poughkeepsie, NY. Dr. Felix Scardapane was born in Mafalda, Abruzzo, Italy, on December 10, 1897. His parents were Elinda and Nicholas Scardapane. Dr. Scardapane lived in Brooklyn, NY and practiced family medicine for 45 years. Subsequently, he moved to Dutchess County, where he provided medical services for Central Hudson,St. Francis Hospital Emergency Dept. and the Poughkeepsie school system. He married Marie DeLuca in 1926 who pre-deceased him in 1993. He is survived by his children, Felix Jr. of Red Hook, NY, Marie Catania of Tampa, FL, Rita Ingegno of Hyde Park, NY, and Joseph of Seattle, WA. He has nine grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. His contributions were many, his love and devotion to life was umparalleled. We hope now he finds peace. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Francis Prepatory School, Queens, NY. Viewing at the Louis DeLuca Funeral Home, Tuesday from 29PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, 9:45AM, at St. Athanasius RC Church. Interment to follow St. John's Cemetery.

title: Managing Asthma With Aid of Computer
description: The National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute has created a new Web site to help physicians, researchers and asthma patients. The Asthma Management Model System was started this month and is designed to keep researchers, health care professionals and the public abreast of developments in asthma management.

title: Caution Urged When Seeking Whiter Teeth
description: A variety of new procedures and products are becoming available for whitening teeth, but some authorities question the effectiveness and safety of some of the items. Manufacturers insist that the products are both safe and effective.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINKMANN, DONALD GERHARD
description: BRINKMANN-Donald Gerhard. Son of the late Gerhard and Helen Brinkmann was born in Riverside, CA. He is survived by his brother, John Brinkmann and a niece and nephew of Riverside, CA. Beloved companion of Mark Weinrod. Don was an inspirational and talented partner of the firm of Gensler Architecture Design and Planning Worldwide. Don was educated at Cal State Polytech College in San Luis Obispo and was a 1969 graduate in architecture of the University of California, Berkeley. He spent 13 years of his professional career as a designer and associate in the San Francisco office of Skidmore Owings and Merrill. Donald joined the New York office of Gensler in 1982 and was made partner in 1985. As the design leader for the firm, his project experience spanned the country and the globe with projects in San Francisco, Minneapolis, Buffalo, Miami, Washington, DC, New York, London and South America. Donald was inducted into the Interior Design Hall of Fame in 1991, and won many design awards for his creative and classic design solutions for law firms, financial institutions, corporations and consulting firms. He recently completed projects for Baron Capital in New York, QVC in Pennsylvania (headquarters), and the Swiss Re. American Headquarters in Manhattan. He was the designer on current projects for Christie's, Bank Boston, Sao Paolo and the American Kennel Club in New York. He succumbed to heart failure following a stroke in New York University Hospital on December 19. A memorial service is planned for early January. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the FIDER (Foundation for Interior Design Education and Research) for a scholarship in the name of Donald Brinkmann, c/o Gensler, Suite 500, 1 Rockefeller Plaza, NY, NY 10020. For information contact John Krtil Funeral Home 212-744-3084.

description: They waved sparkling wands. They chanted healing messages to the universe. They lit a small fire and burned offerings in the name of renewal. And then the police came.

title: Success for a Troubled Troupe
description: The future looked bleak for Donald Byrd and his modern-dance company, Donald Byrd/The Group, this time last year. ''The Harlem Nutcracker'' was a major critical and popular success, but the company's national tour of the lavish production was foundering. As costs climbed, bills went unpaid. Some performances had to be canceled. It looked as if the Group might go under in the wake of what Mr. Byrd described as ''a disaster.''

title: Allstate Buys Insurer Units
description: Allstate agreed here today to buy the two insurance units of the Leucadia National Corporation, buttressing its individual life insurance and retirement savings businesses. The terms of the deal, which is expected to close in the second quarter of 1999, were not disclosed. Allstate, the largest publicly held American insurer of homes and automobiles, ranked 23d last year among life insurers.

title: Another Tough Bird Lands at the Lake
description: The swans had a new king on Saturday afternoon at the Neil Simon Theater. Keith Roberts, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, made his debut as the Swan in Matthew Bourne's imaginative reinterpretation of ''Swan Lake.'' The production retains Tchaikovsky's music, but the familiar steps have been replaced by new choreography in which the usual swan maidens are now swan men.

title: By Design; Ties With Substance
description: Every action has a reaction. The newest men's shirt collars, which are wider and longer, demand a chunky knot, so along come beefy neckties of wool and cashmere fabrics, many in suiting patterns like herringbone and plaid.

title: I.M.F. Cuts World Growth Outlook to 2.2%
description: The International Monetary Fund lowered its projection for 1999 world economic growth today for the second time in three months, citing deteriorating situations in Japan, Russia and Latin America.

title: The Mystique of the Maya With a Subtle Difference
description: Of the many empires and cultures that flourished in pre-conquest Mesoamerica, the Maya have enjoyed the best press. The European travelers who rediscovered their ruined cities imagined them idealistically as a spiritual, artistic and pacific people. They were, it was said, the Greeks to the Aztecs' Romans. To this day, their majestic temples at Palenque, Uxmal, Chichen Izta and Tikal are among the most admired pre-Columbian sites.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times last Tuesday with an article about similar evolutionary paths taken by differing species misstated the origins of three animals. The agouti is native to South America, not Africa; the duiker is from Africa, not Oceania, and the muntjac is from Asia, not South America.

title: UNISYS TO HIRE 6,500 AS COMPUTER SERVICES EXPAND
description: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that it would hire about 6,500 people next year to expand its growing computer services business. With Unisys experiencing nearly 10 percent turnover annually, the new hires will increase the 33,000-member work force by 10 percent, Unisys said. Most of the new workers will maintain and install computer networks for the company's business customers. Computer services account for about two-thirds of the Unisys revenue, with the rest coming from computer sales. Unisys dismissed 11,900 employees in 1994 and 1995 as it struggled with mounting debt and losses.

title: PANOLAM TO ACQUIRE PIONEER PLASTICS FROM RUGBY GROUP
description: Panolam Industries, a building-materials maker, agreed yesterday to buy the Pioneer Plastics Corporation from Rugby Group P.L.C., a building-products producer in Britain, for as much as $175 million. The buyer, which is owned by Genstar Capital L.L.C., a private investment firm based in the United States, will pay $160 million in cash and as much as $15 million more depending on the profitability of Pioneer and Panolam in the years 1999 through 2003, Rugby said. The company is Britain's fourth-biggest maker of materials used for building interiors. Panolam is the leading producer in the United States and Canada of low-pressure laminates, which are sheets of building material used for counter tops, kitchen cabinets and doors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGHERI, CHRISTOPHER B.
description: DEGHERI-Christopher B. The Board of Trustees, Sisters of Charity, Hospital Auxiliary, Administration, Medical Staff and Hospital Staff of Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center of New York mourn the the passing of our esteemed friend & former member of the Board of Trustees. Mr. Degheri was appointed to the Board of Trustees of Saint Vincents Hospital in 1983 and served unitl 1994. During these years, Mr. Degheri, through his role as Trustee of the Edward and Theresa O'Toole Foundation, generously awarded Saint Vincent's with significant grants which enhanced patient care. In addition, Mr. Degheri, provided insightful counsel and leadership for the many projects with which he had been involved in. His dedication to quality healthcare and his constant concern for Saint Vincent's patients were a testament to his commitment to Saint Vincents and the Sisters of Charity. Mr. Degheri's understanding of Saint Vincent's missions made him an invaluable partner in our efforts to enhance patient care to all who turned to the Hospital in need. His generosity and compassion will continue to live and inspire Saint Vincent's staff and will benefit the many patients who come to the Medical Center every day. With great sadness we extend to his wife Dolores, his daughter Christine, and the entire Degheri family, our love, prayers and deepest condolences. Thomas A. Coleman, Chairman, Board of Trustees, Karl P. Adler, MD, President Chief Executive Officer, of Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center

title: When Holiday Treasures Pose Dangers to House Pets
description: Cappy is a lovable but naughty 32-pound cocker spaniel with an insatiable appetite. So it should not have surprised his owners when, two days before Christmas, he raided the wrapped gifts under the tree and ate an entire 12-ounce box of chocolate-covered coffee beans. His owners returned from a holiday party to find him racing about the house, his heart pounding rapidly. An emergency visit to an all-night veterinary clinic revealed that in his haste to devour the treats before he was discovered, he had swallowed the beans whole, avoiding more serious consequences like seizures from the stimulants in the dark chocolate and coffee.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Network Solutions soars, despite the coming loss of its exclusive accord for Internet domain names.

Everyone knows, after all, that sometime next year this Herndon, Va., company will lose its exclusive Government contract for registering the popular Internet domains of .com, .net and .org -- the monopoly that accounts for virtually all its revenue.

title: Bearing Gifts Into the Dark Streets of Poverty

Christmas Eve service ends at South Presbyterian Church here, most people will head back to warm, festive homes, some to sleep, some to become groggy Santas, preparing -- with ribbons, bows and imagined stealth -- for the vast transfer of merchandise just hours away. But two dozen or so will instead climb into vans and head 20 miles south to spend several hours with the homeless on Manhattan's streets.

title: DELL COMPUTER TO PRE-INSTALL AMERICA ONLINE SOFTWARE
description: The Dell Computer Corporation, the top direct seller of personal computers, said yesterday that it would use America Online Inc.'s on-line service as the default Internet provider on its consumer computers sold in the United States and Canada. Dell began to ship America Online's software on computer disks with its Dimension and Inspiron computer systems yesterday. Early next year, Dell's computers will be pre-installed with the America Online service. Terms were not disclosed. America Online has signed agreements with other PC makers like the Compaq Computer Corporation to feature it as the default Internet provider. Dell said America Online would feature links to Dell's World Wide Web services.

title: Body Is Identified as Missing Brooklyn Doctor
description: The search for a popular Brooklyn doctor ended yesterday and a murder inquiry began after the doctor's relatives identified his body, which was found bound and beaten last week in a vacant lot, the police said.

title: In This Battle of the Sexes, the Females Win
description: Cuckoldry is the fate of males the animal kingdom over. In study after study of species after species, the idea that females are naturally devoted to their one and only mates, even as the males wander, has fallen to growing evidence that many of the world's supposedly monogamous females are guilty of their share of indiscretions.

title: Israeli Vote Holds Little Palestinians Can Praise

His selfless devotion and cheerful encouragement will be sorely missed. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Esther, his parents, family, and friends. Abraham Rachlin, Chairman Joel Weintraub, M.D., President

title: Joint Venture Set in Drugs
description: The biotechnology company Isis Pharmaceuticals Inc. and a unit of Zeneca Group P.L.C. of Britain have joined forces to develop and market cancer drugs. Under the three-year agreement announced yesterday, Zeneca Pharmaceuticals, a maker of prescription drugs, and Isis, based in Carlsbad, Calif., will research and develop drugs based on the so-called anti-sense therapy developed by Isis. The therapy uses synthetically designed DNA chains that block the production of proteins causing disease. Isis values the collaboration at more than $40 million. Zeneca will develop any potential drugs and will have exclusive worldwide rights to market drugs from the venture.

title: Freed U.N. Worker Describes 317-Day Chechnya Abduction
description: After 317 days in captivity in Chechnya, a French aid worker was recently freed by Russian commandos in a gunfight that killed three kidnappers.

title: Letter on Shift to Censure
description: Following is the letter from four Republican Representatives, Sherwood Boehlert of New York, Michael N. Castle of Delaware, Benjamin A. Gilman of New York and James C. Greenwood of Pennsylvania, sent to Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader. The letter was made public by the authors.

description: A police chase in Newark ended yesterday with 28 people injured, one critically, when the car being chased slammed into another car and then a bus, the police said.

description: SUBWAY trains, you may have noticed, are packed day and night. So are buses. But the focus this time is below ground.

description: Earth was not supposed to be a tourist attraction on the way to the Moon. But as T. S. Eliot suggested, the real meaning of exploration is to get back to the starting point ''and know the place for the first time.''

description: Ha-Lo Industries, a promotion and marketing company, said yesterday that it had acquired the Siebel Marketing Group in New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Where Does the Time Go? Forward, Physics Shows
description: In Lewis Carroll's mirror world of ''Through the Looking Glass,'' it seems perfectly logical that the White Queen, who lives backward, first bandages her finger, then begins to bleed, then screams, and finally pricks her finger. On paper, if not in real life, the physics governing many natural phenomena permit time to run either forward, like a swimmer jumping from a diving board, or backward, like a reversed movie in which the swimmer leaps from the water and lands on the board.

title: Kazakhstan Braces for Economic Crisis to Reach Its Borders

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARRON, JUDITH
description: ARRON-Judith. As Artistic and Executive Director, she led Carnegie Hall through an extraordinary period of growth and has left an indelible stamp on its future. The New York Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall have been inextricably linked in their great past, and both share this tremendous loss for the world's classical music community. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband Ronald, her sons Edward and Joseph, and to her entire family. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Deborah Borda Executive Director

title: A CONVERSATION WITH: George Schaller; Battling Hoof Rot and Other Ills in Mongolia
description: Dr. George Schaller, the director of science for the Wildlife Conservation Society, the group that runs the Bronx Zoo, has studied animals in the wild for more than 45 years, from the birds of Colville River, Alaska, to the mountain gorillas of Zaire and the giant pandas of China. He discussed biodiversity and his current field work -- trying to gauge the impact of an epidemic of bacterial hoof disease on the vast herds of gazelles on the Central Asian steppe -- in a telephone interview from a campsite near Choybalsan in eastern Mongolia.

The price index fell seven-tenths of a percent from November 1997, the first such drop since 1975. The index fell six-tenths of a percent from October, when prices rose just one-tenth of a percent from October 1997.

title: MOTOROLA BUYS PHONE RESEARCH UNIT FROM LUCENT

About 300 of the original 500 workers at the unit, based in Piscataway, N.J., went to Motorola, while 160 will be dismissed and 40 resigned, Lucent said. Motorola took over the division, which conducts research and development on wireless phones, a week ago. The Wall Street Journal first reported the deal yesterday. The unit was left over from Lucent's joint venture with Royal Philips Electronics N.V., which ended in October.

Horton Inc., one of the largest home builders in the United States, agreed yesterday to buy a smaller rival, Cambridge Properties, for $55 million in stock, plus $100 million in assumed debt. The closely held Cambridge is the largest home builder in Chicago. Under its Cambridge Homes division, it builds single-family homes and retirement communities. It closed on 1,079 homes generating $215 million in revenue in its fiscal year ended Nov. 30. D. R. Horton, based in Arlington, Tex., had $2.2 billion in revenues in its fiscal year ended Sept. 30. Shares of D.R. Horton rose $1.625, to $20.625.

title: LEVITZ FURNITURE TO CLOSE 27 STORES AND CUT 1,000 JOBS
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporation, struggling to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings, said yesterday that it would close 27 of its 90 stores and eliminate 1,000 jobs, or about 25 percent of its work force. Levitz said it would also shrink its warehouse system down to 17, from 65 sites, and continue efforts to freshen up its dowdier stores. It will also open at least 15 stores, including at least three or more in the 1999 first half. Levitz, based in Boca Raton, Fla., has been operating under Chapter 11 of United States bankruptcy law since September 1997. The restructuring marks the first major move by Levitz's new chairman and chief executive officer, Edward L. Grund.

title: As Octuplets Remain in Peril, Ethics Questions Are Raised
description: The two sons and six daughters born to a Houston area woman remained in critical condition at Texas Children's Hospital tonight, sedated and incubated -- all eight of them together weighing just a breath over 10 pounds.

title: For J-E-T-S, It's B-U-Y, S-E-L-L, C-O-N-S-U-M-E
description: As Woody Allen thawed out after a 200-year slumber in the film ''Sleeper,'' the Jets have awakened from a lengthy torpor to find fans packing their stadium, people snapping up their merchandise and their coach assuming mythic heights.

title: Drugs, Sports, Body Image And G.I. Joe
description: Which classic American doll has been a staple of childhood from the boomer babies onward, has won iconic, if politically freighted, status in our culture, and possesses a waist so small and hemispheric projections so pronounced that no real adult could approach them without the help of potentially dangerous body enhancement therapies?

title: Reduce Population
description: To the Editor:

title: Sir Alan Lloyd Hodgkin, 84, A Nobelist in Nerve Research
description: Sir Alan Lloyd Hodgkin, an English biophysicist who shared the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1963 for helping to explain how nerve cells transmit impulses between the the skin to the brain, died Sunday at the age of 84.

title: Iraq Rebuffs France on Plan for Compromise on U.N. Weapons Inspections
description: Iraq today rejected suggestions that it might change its decision to end cooperation with United Nations weapons inspectors if the composition or leadership of the inspection teams were changed.

title: Can 'the Coach' Change Tactics?
description: Battered by the resignations under fire of House Speaker Newt Gingrich and Speaker-to-be Robert Livingston in just two months, House Republicans have picked a little-known, untested Midwesterner to serve as their next Speaker. J. Dennis Hastert, a former high school wrestling coach, has a reputation as a conciliator and technocrat who can work with members of both parties. Such qualities could do much to help the next Congress rise above the partisan rancor of the last year -- but only if Mr. Hastert shows his independence from the mean-spirited tactics of his chief backers, especially Tom DeLay, the Republican whip.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're in a real jam. We're already over the Himalayas and there's no place to land. We have to keep going into China, and once over Chinese territory they could order us to land, or might even shoot us down.''

title: Rather Be a Fish?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Prepare For Unknown Opponent, And Love It
description: The Jets began preparing for two teams yesterday -- the New England Patriots, whom they face in the final game of the regular season on Sunday, and Jacksonville, which could well be the Jets' opponent in the second round of the playoffs.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: An Exiled Chinese Activist Speaks Out
description: A Chinese dissident who arrived in New York on Sunday accused the Government in Beijing yesterday of ''trampling on human rights'' and said he had been beaten while in captivity.

title: Baghdad Frozen in Time By Years of Sanctions
description: At one newsstand in downtown Baghdad, a magazine on display reports that the Prince of Wales has been seen with Lady Diana Spencer and speculates that a romance might be blossoming. At another the prize offering is a maintenance manual for the 1988 Oldsmobile.

title: U.S. Says 85% of Iraqi Targets Were Hit
description: In the fullest military assessment since the bombing of Iraq ended, the American commander who led four days of strikes said today that American and British forces hit 85 percent of their targets and badly damaged the Republican Guard.

title: Songwriting Challenge of Historic Proportions
description: For Jason Robert Brown, setting out to write the music and lyrics for ''Parade'' was hard, but not for the reasons one might expect.

title: CHINA SENTENCES 3 FOR THEIR DISSENT
description: By sentencing three of the country's most prominent democracy campaigners to long prison terms, China has taken its harshest step yet in its current crackdown on organized political opposition.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Manila Journal; First Lady's Squawk Hints at Dictator's Nest Egg
description: In the pre-Christmas bustle of this teeming city, a ghost of the Philippine past has suddenly re-emerged.

title: Court Tells Giuliani to Release Budget Data
description: A state judge has ruled that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani must provide more information to a public agency that scrutinizes the city budget, saying that his efforts to withhold facts and figures from the agency were illegal.

title: NETANYAHU AGREES TO NEW ELECTIONS SOMETIME IN SPRING
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today accepted the inevitability of his Government's downfall, striking a deal with the political opposition to hold new elections sometime next spring.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Friday with a review of the film ''Trouble on the Corner'' misstated an actor's surname. As stated in the review, the actor playing Jeff, the psychologist, is Tony Goldwyn, not Goldman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARTANY, ALEXANDRE H., M.D.
description: VARTANY-Alexandre H., M.D. On Dec. 19, 1998, beloved husband of Margaret, devoted father of Haik & Nadja, loving grandfather and beloved brother of Evlyn. A funeral service will be held at the Saint Vartan Cathedral, 34th Street and Second Avenue, on Saturday, December 26, 1998, at 11:30 A.M.

title: Now, Focus Turns to Constitutional Order; Diminished Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Now, Focus Turns to Constitutional Order; Weakened Authority
description: To the Editor:

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Pollution Runs Through It

title: A Predator Returned to the Wild Discovers It Is Now Prey
description: Last spring, Bobby Fite peered down the sight of his .22 magnum rifle at what he thought was a coyote stalking two newborn calves near his house here.

title: Australia Fund Manager In British Acquisition
description: AMP Ltd., Australia's biggest fund manager, said yesterday that it would buy the National Provident Institution of Britain for $:1.3 billion ($2.2 billion) in cash. The deal is aimed at putting AMP into Britain's independent financial adviser network. AMP will pay $:510 million for the good will associated with National Provident, Britain's seventh-largest pension provider. It will also inject $:800 million into the business.

title: U.S.-Europe Trade War Looms Over Bananas
description: After six years of trans-Atlantic skirmishes, the Clinton Administration fired the first real salvo in its banana war with the European Union today -- announcing sanctions on European luxury goods that if imposed would chill the blood of shoppers along Rodeo Drive and wandering the aisles at Balducci's.

title: Apparel Retailer Drops 2000 Bug Claim
description: In a setback for computer users looking for deep pockets to help pay the cost of Year 2000 problems, J. Baker, an apparel retailer, has dropped its claim that Andersen Consulting, the designer of a computer system Baker installed in 1991, is liable for the system's Year 2000 defects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PULLIS, JAMES. J.P.
description: PULLIS-James. J.P. created a warm family atmosphere for all his wayward friends. We are forever grateful that he came into our lives. Marrie Schmeelk

title: Ewing Fights for Union, Then Plays Santa
description: Patrick Ewing's day began in a midtown hotel, where he dispelled any notion of a rift within the players union. By nightfall, he was standing on a street in Harlem signing autographs for children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, YEHUDI ARYEH
description: COHEN-Yehudi Aryeh. On December 17, 1998. Died peacefully at home after a long illness. He was Professor Emeritus of Anthropology at Rutgers University. He is survived by his daughter, Lisa Peet, grandson, Gideon Peet, and sister, Hadassah Gordis. He was the son of the late Meyer and Nehama Cohen and brother of the late Rabbi Gerson D. Cohen.

title: PATTERNS
description: No Rest on 7th Ave.

title: Metro Business; Theater Workers Unionize
description: Stagehands, wardrobe and other workers at the Roundabout Theater Company have voted overwhelmingly to join the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees. Its stagehands voted 37 to 0 to join, its wardrobe workers 23 to 0, and its makeup and hair stylists voted 5 to 1 to unionize. The Roundabout operates three theaters, Studio 54, Stage Right and Laura Pels. Its current productions include Cabaret, Little Me and Impossible Marriage. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

title: Politics and Peace in Israel
description: The campaign to choose Israel's next government began yesterday, more than a year ahead of schedule. That will mean regrettable new delays in peace talks with the Palestinians. But the elections, to be held sometime early next year, will give Israeli voters a chance to reinforce the wobbly Middle East peace effort.

title: Holiday Toast With Oil and Water
description: The pairing of Claiborne Cary and Phillip Officer at the Garrick Gaities, a cozy new cabaret in the Hotel Mayfair (242 West 49th Street, Manhattan) demonstrates the folly of randomly throwing two performers together and expecting magic.

title: Banana Wars
description: The United States and the European Union are headed toward an avoidable collision over bananas. Yesterday, in retaliation for European restrictions on banana imports, the United States announced a list of European imports that will be subject to 100 percent tariffs -- ranging from cashmere sweaters to plastic purses.

title: A Priestess of Zen Adornment
description: You may admire Kazuko's work, but don't call her a designer. ''I don't design,'' she said emphatically the other day. ''I make things.''

title: Judge Orders Embassy Bomb Suspect Held Without Bail
description: A man accused of conspiring with Osama bin Laden appeared in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday after his extradition from Germany and continued to deny any connection to terrorism, his lawyer said after the hearing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUTZ, EDWARD O.
description: LUTZ-Edward O. The Brooklyn College community mourns the passing of Professor Emeritus of Economics Edward O. Lutz. His fifty years of service to the college is deeply appreciated and will be long remembered. Vernon E. Lattin, President Brooklyn College

title: Tenors' Promoter Jailed in Germany For Tax Evasion
description: Matthias Hoffmann, the German promoter who turned the Three Tenors concerts into a worldwide extravaganza, was sentenced yesterday to five years and eight months in prison for tax evasion.

title: South Korea Auctions Big Load of Weak Assets
description: South Korea stepped ahead of its Asian neighbors in the race to find foreigners to buy bad loans yesterday, selling to a United States fund almost all of $470 million of debt and foreclosed property offered at auction.

title: Spitzer Selects Law Deputies, Noting Lack of Political Clout
description: Eliot L. Spitzer, the Attorney General-elect, appointed several veteran prosecutors yesterday to fill senior positions in his inner circle when he takes office on Jan. 1.

title: DNA: Bar Code for a Police State?
description: To the Editor:

title: Transfer Rejected Again For Killer of 13 in '49
description: A Camden County judge ruled yesterday that a 77-year-old man who shot and killed 13 people during a 20-minute stroll through his neighborhood in 1949 should not be moved to a less secure psychiatric hospital.

title: A Portuguese Cheese Makes Friends
description: ON the menu it hardly seemed a dish of note: a spot of cheese, some dried fruits and roasted almonds.

title: Student Is Charged With Setting Fires in Manhattan High School
description: A 14-year-old male student at Stuyvesant High School was arrested yesterday and charged with setting three garbage-can fires in the school that forced the evacuation of more than 3,000 students in each case, fire officials said.

title: Duke Sends Wildcats A Message For March
description: How this game was to be played was decided early, barely eight minutes after tip-off. The decision was dictated from the Duke sideline when Kentucky's Saul Smith, all 6 feet 2 inches of the coach's son, hurtled himself into the 6-8 Shane Battier to block what look like a certain dunk. It was a foul -- a hard foul.

title: Iraq Is Down But Not Out
description: Iraqi officials have said that United Nations weapons inspectors will never set foot in their country again, and the United Nations Security Council has just begun what is likely to be a lengthy debate on the future of Unscom, its special commission on Iraq. So when I left Iraq last week with the rest of the Unscom inspectors, it may have been for the last time. Now seems an appropriate moment to ask: Did the American air strikes last week achieve what Unscom could not -- the disarming of Iraq?

title: Rutgers Finds Way To Defeat A Nemesis
description: It was not a conference game for Rutgers, or a tournament game with the season on the line. Still, with every shot they made, every defensive stand they mounted, the Scarlet Knights pumped their fists in excitement. For a meeting with Princeton is a test that the Knights have failed too often for them to take it lightly tonight.

title: City and State Agree to $900 Million Deal to Keep New York Stock Exchange
description: With a holiday cheer that belied six months of sometimes tense negotiations, New York City and state officials announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement with the New York Stock Exchange to build a trading complex and office tower just east of the market's historic home on Wall Street.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: International Mussels

title: Journal; Larry and Lucy
description: For those who just can't wait for Larry Flynt to expose the sex lives of some more G.O.P. ''big fish'' in the next Hustler, there's a titillating tidbit in the ''Men of the Year'' issue of Time. In an interview, Lucianne Goldberg laughingly recalls a tell-all book proposal from the ancient, pre-Monica past in which a ''very famous Republican name'' would not take off his glasses ''even when he was buck naked, performing a particular sex act. . . .'' Time deletes the Republican name Ms. Goldberg merrily provided, but surely someone will pass her dish on to the rest of us soon enough.

title: Leaving Rates Alone, Fed Shifts to Neutral as Sense of Crises Eases
description: The Federal Reserve voted today to hold interest rates steady, judging that three rate reductions in the fall had given the economy a big enough kick to keep it growing at a healthy pace into the new year.

title: David Jackson, 96, Ex-Governor Of the American Stock Exchange
description: David S. Jackson, a member of the American Stock Exchange for 73 years and an exchange governor from 1965 to 1968, died Sunday, a son-in-law, Andrew Segal, said. Mr. Jackson was 96 years old.

title: Shift in S.& P. 500 Listing
description: America Online Inc., the No. 1 on-line service, will replace Venator Group in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index effective after the close of trading on Dec. 31, S.& P. said. Internet stocks have been among this year's best performers, and the industry has experienced explosive growth in the last few years. The 500-stock index, the benchmark against which professional money managers are judged, currently has no Internet stocks. America Online, with a market capitalization of $63 billion, will be larger than all but 38 of the companies in the S.& P. 500. Venator, formerly the Woolworth Corporation, has a market capitalization of $924 million.

title: To Allay Fears, Bank of Japan Defends Its Financial Stability
description: Fending off weeks of criticism that the Japanese central bank's financial strength is eroding, the bank's governor said today that it had one of the world's safest pools of assets, second only to that of the United States Federal Reserve.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a dispute between Jews and Catholics over crosses outside the Auschwitz death camp misspelled the surname of Poland's Prime Minister. He is Jerzy Buzek, not Burek. The article also misspelled the surname of a historian who commented on the dispute. He is Jerzy Jedlicki, not Ledlicki.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; S.E.C. Charges Grace and 6 Former Executives With Fraud
description: Federal securities regulators accused W. R. Grace & Company and six of its former executives of fraud yesterday, saying that the company had deceived shareholders over five years by falsely reporting earnings.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The Japanese currency fell as bond yields rose, threatening Government plans to revive the nation's economy. In New York, the dollar traded at 116.65 yen, up from 116.21 yen on Monday.

title: G.E. of Britain Wants Separate Military Unit
description: The General Electric Company P.L.C., Britain's second-largest military contractor, said yesterday that it would split its aerospace and military businesses from the rest of its operations as it continues merger talks with other military companies. The military business includes missile controls, submarines and satellites. The company also makes home appliances, phone equipment and telecommunications switches.

title: Accounts
description: * Scottish Tourist Board, Edinburgh, to SKC Advertising, Harrison, N.Y., a unit of New Paradigm Communications, to handle the creative part of its account, which had been at Givner & Chiles, New York. Wilson Media Group, New York, will handle the media part, which had been at Delsey Group, Elmsford, N.Y. Billings were estimated at $1.3 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MALLEY, THOMAS, JR.
description: O'MALLEY-Thomas, Jr. age 60 died December 19th, 1998 in Indianapolis. He was an attorney and a member of the New York Bar Association. He worked for the Federal Government until his death for The Dept. of Housing and Urban Development. He is survived by his wife, Rosemary O'Malley, & a daughter, Margaret O'Malley. He was a graduate of Le Moyne Law School in NY City. Services will be held on Wednesday, December 23rd at 11:00 am in the St. Thomas Aquinas Catholic Church. Burial is in Oaklawn Memorial Gardens, Indianapolis.

title: A Nobu Where You Can Just Drop In
description: MAINE lobsters do not make good sashimi.

title: Atlanta Favors Are Told As Panel Begins Inquiry
description: The United States Olympic Committee sought to reassure nervous corporate sponsors yesterday that irregularities would be cleaned up in the bidding process for the Winter and Summer Games, naming George J. Mitchell, the former Senator from Maine, to head its investigation into allegations of vote-buying in Salt Lake City for the 2002 Winter Games.

title: 3 Tenors' Promoter Is Guilty in Tax Case
description: Matthias Hoffmann, the German promoter who turned the Three Tenors into a worldwide sensation, was sentenced yesterday to more than five years for tax evasion. The court in Mannheim, Germany, said prosecutors were also investigating the tenors -- Luciano Pavarotti, Jose Carreras and Placido Domingo.

title: G.O.P. to Seek A Tax Break On College
description: The Republican leaders of the State Senate say they intend to push a far-reaching plan through the Legislature that would, for the first time, provide a tax deduction for the payment of college tuition.

title: STATE'S TOP COURT VOIDS PLEA SYSTEM FOR CAPITAL CASES
description: In the first major test of New York's reinstituted death penalty, the state's highest court struck down most of the law's plea-bargaining provisions yesterday, saying that they were unconstitutional because they encouraged defendants to plead guilty rather than risk a death sentence by going to trial.

title: Borden Consolidates At Campbell Mithun
description: The Borden Foods Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis by consolidating creative duties for its American brands at the agency.

title: Flood of Gifts Offered for Houston Octuplets
description: As the eight babies born to a Houston woman on Sunday struggled to survive as the first known living octuplets, donors from around Texas and across the country today pledged money and goods to help the new family.

title: Acteal Journal; Where Killings Defiled a Church, No Forgiveness
description: For six days, only the dogs and chickens were left living in Union Progreso, a village near here at the foot of a mountain in the southern state of Chiapas. But this week the farmers, their wives and their children -- 163 people in all -- came out of hiding, even though they are terrified that their neighbors will sneak into town and kill them in their sleep.

title: UPN Begins Agency Search
description: UPN, the broadcast television network owned by the Chris-Craft Corporation and Viacom Inc., has begun a review to find an outside agency to handle advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINGER, ELIZABETH L.
description: KLINGER-Elizabeth L. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great grandmother, a founder of ''Parents Magazine''. A gracious, generous woman whose zest for life, and love of family and friends endeared her to all who knew her. She is survived by sons, Lawrence and Harold, daughters-in-law, Ina, Nancy, grandchildren, Elaine and Paul & great grandchildren, Jacob and Kaitlin. Services at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th St., Thursday, Dec. 24 at 11:00

title: Standard & Poor's Downgrades Toshiba Long-Term Debt Rating
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its long-term credit ratings today on the Toshiba Corporation's debt, saying the company's efforts to strengthen itself financially will likely be hurt by a swift erosion in cash flow and adverse global market conditions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITTEN, CHICKIE
description: WITTEN-Chickie, age 84, on December 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Morris Witten. Loving mother of Joan Nash and the late Dr. Jay Witten. Adored and adoring grandmother of Meredith, Bradley, Matthew, and Russell. Dear sister of Lee Fishman. An Eyshes Chayil who brightened and enriched our lives. Services were held Sunday, December 20th at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont.

title: Don't Let Iraq Off Nuclear Hook
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a letter last Friday from Walter Hoffman referred incorrectly to the joint American-British bombing of Iraq. The writer meant to recommend that the United Nations form a rapid deployment force so that the United States and Britain do not try to be the world's self-appointed police officers, not the United States and the United Nations.

title: Shoppers Get Awards; Malls Get Loyalty
description: Malls around the country, in a growing move to stem shopper defections to the Internet, catalogues and their competitors down the highway, are enticing customers this season by giving them something new: a reward for shopping.

title: Rhythm Makers Taking The World's Pulse
description: Percussion can be thrilling. Ask anyone who has seen ''Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk,'' Savion Glover's Broadway paean to tap dancing. Or ''Stomp,'' which consists basically of performers pounding big sticks on the stage floor. And a movie about a musician on tour can be fascinating. See Barbara Kopple's ''Wild Man Blues,'' which follows Woody Allen, clarinetist, on his European travels. So ''Zakir and His Friends,'' a 90-minute percussive travelogue with the tabla player Zakir Hussain, had possibilities.

title: Caviar Palaces: Solemn to Affable
description: CAVIAR at home is a pleasure; caviar in restaurants is a statement. Eaten in the privacy of your own abode, caviar is a special treat, a way of being good to yourself and those you love. But eaten in public, caviar becomes a declaration, and where you choose to indulge says a great deal about you.

title: CHUBB TO PURCHASE A 27% STAKE IN HISCOX OF BRITAIN
description: The Chubb Corporation, the 14th-largest United States property-casualty insurer, said it had agreed to buy 27 percent of the shares of the British insurer Hiscox P.L.C. for about $:87 million ($146 million). Chubb will buy 38.9 million shares in Hiscox for 225 pence a share from Trident, a venture capital company. Hiscox shares rose 22.5 pence, to 170. Chubb shares fell 75 cents, to $64.875. Chubb, based in Warren, N.J., said it had no intention of taking over Hiscox.

title: Walking the Beat From Macy's to Sears; More Police Departments Assign Officers to a Private Domain, the Mall
description: Michael Dalia has spent 21 years with the Woodbridge Police Department, and he was not inclined to take any chances with the little girl sticking her head through a railing on the upstairs level of the Woodbridge Center mall, even if her mother was over on a bench just a few steps away, chatting with a friend.

title: Slovakian Fare Hearty Enough to Chase a Chill
description: FOR those not familiar with Slovakian cuisine -- and that is no doubt a sizable group, as there are precious few Slovakian restaurants in New York -- here is a quick overview of what you will find: lots of cabbage, lots of potatoes, lots of vinegar, lots of cheese and cream, lots of bread, lots and lots of meat.

title: How One Play Altered Giants' Season
description: If the Giants had one more victory today, they would be headed to Philadelphia this weekend needing only a victory for a playoff berth, and they would not need help from another team to earn it.

title: DNA: Bar Code for a Police State?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dark Day for the Pagans, As Police Prevent Ceremony
description: For the pagan set, this year's celebration of the winter solstice was brewing with all the right energy. They had called out to Mother Earth while on the ferry to Staten Island. Sure, the forgotten borough was not the mythic Celtic paradise of Avalon, but its beaches were an acceptable stand-in for their annual rites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPLEBY, JOSEPH
description: APPLEBY-Joseph. Died December 22, 1998. Loving son of Doris and the late Aaron; dear brother of Jean; brother-in-law of Edward Baltzly; fiancee of Deanna Knauth. Also survived by many loving uncles, aunts, cousins and friends. Interment is at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARRON, JUDITH
description: ARRON-Judith. The Metropolitan Opera deeply mourns the death of our colleague Judith Arron, executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall. A creative and dedicated administrator, she demonstrated great artistic vision and commitment by leading Carnegie Hall through an unprecedented period of growth and development. She will long be remembered for innumerable achievements which will have a major and a lasting impact on the musical life of our city. We remember with particular gratitude her essential collaboration in forging the success of the Met orchestra series at Carnegie. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Ron, a member of our orchestra, and to all her family and friends. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: Hearty Insulation for Winter
description: EVEN when the weather is warmer than usual, there's something about December that makes me think of stew. I'm a confirmed soup aficionado, but this is the time of year when a stew, in all its density, seems the best defense against even the threat of winter.

title: Yale Professor Facing Charges In Boy's Assault
description: A Yale University professor awaiting trial on a Federal charge of possessing child pornography was charged Monday with sexually assaulting a 13-year-old boy.

title: Defining Goal in Iraq
description: A major theme of American policy toward Iraq has been the increasing sentiment in Congress and the White House that Saddam Hussein should be overthrown. Yet there is deep division between Congressional Republicans and President Clinton over how aggressively Washington should pursue that goal.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times on Dec. 15 about varied forms of hepatitis referred incorrectly to the progression of hepatitis E. That type of virus causes illness on its own, regardless of whether the patient is infected with another form of hepatitis.

title: Ex-Firefighter Arraigned In Shooting of Officer
description: A former New York City firefighter was arraigned yesterday on an 18-count indictment in the Dec. 10 shooting of a Suffolk County police officer who, prosecutors have said, was saved by her bulletproof vest.

title: Popping Open a Bottle of Pure Poetry
description: TWO weeks ago, Sherry-Lehmann & Company, the New York wine merchant, offered its customers a taste of Taittinger's Comtes de Champagne, a premium wine from the superb 1990 vintage. Even an experienced Champagne hand was surprised at what happened.

title: Most New York City Students Will Fail New Graduation Tests, Report Says
description: Unless drastic improvements are made, the New York City school system will fail to insure that students in its worst schools pass new, tougher high school standards imposed by the state, a report from a watchdog group says.

title: Commercial Real Estate; TV Station Moves From Old Hotel to New Studio
description: At 7 A.M. on Dec. 14, officials threw a switch, and New York's public television station, WNET, began broadcasting from its new location on the west side of midtown, at 10th Avenue and 33d Street.

title: City Hospitals Lose Funds In Pataki Veto
description: Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed a bill yesterday that sought to give New York City's public hospital system $100 million to help pay for its swelling ranks of uninsured patients.

title: In Poll, Public Says Clinton Scandal Wasn't '98's Most Compelling Event
description: The first impeachment of a President in 130 years was the stuff of monster headlines, followed intensively by a mesmerized segment of the population, but the public at large found President Clinton's impeachment less compelling than a dozen other news events in 1998, a survey has found.

title: In Alsace, a Pastry With Heart and History
description: CHOUCROUTE GARNI, with its pungent, pale blond sauerkraut crowned by sausages and rose-pink cuts of pork, is the most famous dish of Alsace. But kugelhopf, a high, fluted, circular coffee bread, is perhaps even closer to the hearts of Alsatians, as I rediscovered on a late fall visit to that endearingly folkloric French province on the Rhine. Kugelhopf beckons from every bakery window the year round.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HOG FUTURES RISE. Hog futures rose more than 4 percent after the Government said it would expand its pork-purchasing program to try to help end a glut. February hogs rose 1.25 cents, to 29.52 cents a pound.

title: Jordan Accepts Suharto Relative, Ex-General
description: A son-in-law of former President Suharto has been offered citizenship in Jordan, the official Antara press agency has reported.

title: R&B FALCON SAYS MOBIL CANCELS $146 MILLION CONTRACT
description: The R&B Falcon Corporation, the fourth-largest United States drilling contractor, said yesterday that the Mobil Corporation had canceled an offshore drilling contract valued at about $146 million because of R&B's equipment and personnel deficiencies. R&B Falcon said it would take legal action to enforce the contract, which was to run through 2000. The cancellation comes as oil prices touch 12-year lows, causing oil companies to slash spending budgets and affecting how they handle rig contracts, said James Stone, a Schroder & Company analyst, who added that Mobil was under pressure to cut costs.

title: Sports of The Times; Nurturing The Dream For Valvano
description: WHEN Pam Valvano took her husband Jimmy's pants to the dry cleaners, she would often find index cards on which he had written notations, or the cards might be scattered here or there in their home. Some had to do with recruiting he planned as head coach of the North Carolina State basketball team in Raleigh. Others may have been about a speaking engagement, or a play he had devised, or a saying he had run across and wished to share.

title: Italian Steel Supplier To Build Plant in Egypt
description: Danieli S.p.A., Italy's No. 1 maker of equipment for the steel industry, signed an agreement yesterday to build a factory in Egypt as it seeks to strengthen itself in a shrinking market. The factory, to be built with the Egyptian steel and ceramic conglomerate EZZ Heavy Industries for $740.5 million, will produce 1.2 million tons of steel products a year and will open by the end of 2001.

title: Allan D'Arcangelo, 68, Painter of Pop Images
description: Allan D'Arcangelo, a painter known for pared-down images of highways and road signs that neatly split the difference between Pop Art and Minimalism, died on Dec. 17 at Beth Israel North in Manhattan. He was 68 and lived on an 80-acre farm in the Catskills, near Kenoza Lake, N.Y.

title: Brief Rest in a Times Square Preacher's Rant
description: STACY WILLIAMS stood on his soapbox in Times Square on Monday evening and let the world know he was back. ''You white people are the nastiest, lowdown, wicked creatures ever to walk the earth,'' he bellowed, his arms thrashing the air. His roar cut through police sirens, car horns and even the thick shell of cynicism coating the few New Yorkers in the throng of out-of-towners.

title: Too Few Dollars, No Real Exposure
description: The failure of the American Basketball League was foretold almost from the beginning: it never had enough money, investors, marketing or television exposure to compete with the better capitalized Women's N.B.A.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARTANY, ALEXANDRE, M.D.
description: VARTANY-Alexandre, M.D. The Medical Staff at Metropolitan Hospital Center/New York Medical College notes with deep regret the passing of their friend and colleague, Alexandre Vartany, M.D., on December 19, 1998. Dr. Vartany served on the staff of Metropolitan Hospital Center for thirty-two years as a pediatric surgeon, most recently as an Associate Professor of Clinical Surgery and as an Emeritus Attending. Dr. Vartany was a dedicated physician who was held in high esteem and regard by his colleagues, staff and patients. His dedication to the patients of the East Harlem community was unwavering. Dr. Vartany's presence and guidance will be sorely missed and his colleagues wish to express their deepest sympathy to his family.

title: Economic Recovery Seen for Philippines
description: The Philippine Government predicted today that the nation's economy would be the first in Asia to emerge from recession, expanding as much as 3.1 percent in 1999 as better weather increases farm output and higher state spending encourages growth.

title: Dow and S.& P. Advance, but Nasdaq and Russell Drop
description: Stocks were mixed in fairly light trading yesterday, but Treasury prices posted their biggest decline in six weeks, pushed down by a flow of money from bonds to stocks and a selloff of Japanese bonds..

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAPAKIN, HARMON
description: ZAPAKIN-Harmon. Coordinating Council of Cooperatives, Coordinated Housing Services and 1st Rochdale Cooperative Group join the cooperative community in mourning the passing of our colleague, a true giant. For 40 years, Harmon quietly made a difference in the quality of life for countless New York Cooperators. Our heartfelt sympathy to his dear wife, Dorothy, beloved sons, Randy and Alan, and their families.

title: Arts in America; The Mountain as Muse, Glacial, Menacing or Not So
description: Mount Rainier looms large in this city, a snowy peak that lends its spectacular beauty to Seattle but also, truth be told, adds a touch of Northwest noir to the landscape. She is, after all, a volcano. Rainier has such a presence that when the city's famous clouds lift, people offer this simple report to one another: ''The mountain is out.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHEVINS, BARBARA
description: SHEVINS-Barbara. Nineteen years have gone by yet there is never a day without your laughter, without your amazing friendship, and without taking strength from you. All who knew you, and forever hold you in their hearts, are truly blessed

title: Too Much of a Good Thing
description: It is tempting to regard the eight babies born to a Houston mother as a holiday season miracle, the fruit of a woman's fervent desire to have children and of modern medicine's ability to assist reproduction in those otherwise unable to conceive. Who does not root strenuously for the survival of the world's only known living octuplets as they cling tenuously to life in a neonatal intensive care unit? But this is not an event that should be overly sentimentalized or glamorized. It is instead a mixed blessing, illustrating the limitations of high-tech medicine as it strives to bring sound, healthy babies into the world without generating a crowd of fragile newborns.

title: Clemens Withdraws Demand For Trade
description: Roger Clemens, the elite pitcher who had demanded that the Toronto Blue Jays trade him and then have his new team extend his contract for huge dollars, backed off yesterday, more or less.

description: BOORSTEIN-Lucille. July 18, 1927 to December 23, 1996. In loving memory of Mom. Amy, Mark and Bill
