description: Spirit of Keeping?

title: Privacy Rights in the Car and the Home
description: The Supreme Court's unanimous ruling this month denying the police blanket authority to search a car after ticketing the driver for a minor traffic violation, such as speeding, was an important victory for privacy rights. At issue was an Iowa law that extended the power police now have to conduct a warrantless search when a driver is arrested. The new law allowed such searches even in routine traffic stops where there was no arrest and no suspicion of any criminal activity. Had the Court gone the other way, such intrusions -- unnecessary to insuring officer safety or preserving evidence -- would have become widespread.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURTH, ALFRED
description: FURTH-Alfred. On December 21, 1998. Beloved husband of Beatrice and the late Margot. Loving stepfather of Jay & Bruce and fatherin-law of Marsha. Cherished grandfather to Heather & Adam. Dear brother-in-law of Lillian and Lewis Ballin, and uncle of Karyn, Andrew and Ronald. Services Thursday, at 9:30 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Beth El Cemetery, New Jersey.

title: Student Journalists
description: Those wondering what teen-agers think about the impeachment debate might ordinarily rely on polls, surveys or the occasional newspaper story. CNN, however, is letting some high school students tell part of the story on national television this week, in an unusual outgrowth of a program that it has designed with Turner Learning to help young people learn to be television journalists.

title: Day of Reckoning in 4th Grade: State Exam Tests Young Nerves
description: In any other year, this would be a light week in Roz Sacharoff's fourth-grade classroom, with Christmas-around-the-world lunches and holiday songs the order of the day.

title: Miscellany
description: * Interbrand Group, New York, a unit of Omnicom Group, acquired Avalos & Bourse Communicacion Visual, Buenos Aires, which will be renamed Interbrand Avalos & Bourse. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Civilian Reactors Could Be Used to Make Warhead Material
description: Facing shortage of a crucial component of nuclear warheads, the Energy Department announced today that it would use three of the Tennessee Valley Authority's electricity-producing reactors to make the material tritium.

title: Man and Girl Charged In String of Crimes
description: A man and a 14-year-old girl who were arrested in the Bronx on Monday and accused of holding two other teen-age girls hostage were charged yesterday in a string of crimes, including a killing, that occurred over the weekend.

title: Devils' Ailing Brodeur May Sit Out Tonight
description: The Devils, seeking to resume their winning ways after a loss to Calgary and a tie with Montreal, are trying to cope with injuries to three key players, including goalie Martin Brodeur.

title: NTL TO BUY EASTERN GROUP TELECOMS FOR $153 MILLION
description: NTL Inc., the big cable company in Britain, agreed to buy Eastern Group Telecoms for $:91 million ($153 million) to extend its national phone network across the south and east of England. NTL, based in New York, said it would pay $:60 million in cash and $:31 million in new NTL preferred stock for Eastern Group, which is owned by the Texas Utilities Companies of Dallas. NTL is third to Cable and Wireless Communications P.L.C. and Telewest Communications P.L.C. in competition for television and phone services in the British cable market. The Eastern Group deal is the latest union of smaller European telecommunications networks. Shares of NTL fell 75 cents, to $57.

title: BASF-Hoechst Drug Work
description: BASF A.G. and Hoechst A.G., Germany's No. 1 and No. 3 drug and chemical makers, said today that they would develop a drug to treat chronic heart failure and high blood pressure. BASF's pharmaceutical unit, Knoll A.G., and Hoechst's drug unit, Hoechst Marion Roussel, will work together.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am really scared. I want to get into a very good college. You must know the name of it: Harvard.''

description: THERE are those few who are actually on a first-name basis with the royalty of rock 'n' roll, who can talk truthfully about trips with Mick or Keith, dinners with Mariah or Shania and parties with Pete or John or Jewel. (Well, maybe Jewel is an exception, because everyone would by definition be on a first-name basis with a one-name celebrity.)

title: A Strike by Musicians Silences Two Orchestras
description: The Little Orchestra Society has become the second of New York City's orchestras to cancel its holiday concerts because of a contract dispute between its management and the freelance musicians who fill its ranks, leaving musicians and managements accusing each other of dampening holiday spirits.

description: The BellSouth Corporation lost its court challenge to legal restrictions that prevent it and other regional Bell companies from entering the $70 billion long-distance business until they open local markets to competition.

title: The Red Storm Rolls On Against F.D.U.
description: Yes, St. John's routed another overmatched neighbor last night at Alumni Hall. Yes, the Red Storm has been impressive in forging a seven-game winning streak. And, yes, it continues to hone its full-court assault.

title: Iraqi Cultural Elite Pine for Old Days
description: In his spare time, Dhia al-Quasi still likes to recall the night in 1986 when an audience of actors, directors and theater professors from around the world greeted his production of ''King Lear'' with a rapturous standing ovation.

title: Alitalia Plans to Spend $2.6 Billion to Expand
description: Italy's national airline, Alitalia S.A., plans to spend 4.3 trillion lire ($2.6 billion), through 2000 to expand its operations. The airline, which will be privatized in the spring, will invest 80 percent of the money in new aircraft. Alitalia plans to increase its fleet to 166 from the current 148 aircraft by 2001.

title: Chabrol's 50th Feature: What Are His Enigmatic Scam Artists Doing?
description: Claude Chabrol devotes his 50th feature, ''The Swindle,'' to the suave trickery that has been so alluring throughout his long career. It centers upon the wily teamwork of Isabelle Huppert and Michel Serrault, who play veteran con artists with a most cryptic connection.

title: His Public Faults Lawmaker Who Voted to Impeach, Then Leaned to Censure
description: For Theoni Katis, it was bad enough that her Congressman, Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, voted for impeachment on Saturday. She opposed the vote, and was disappointed in it.

title: Rack of Lamb: Simple, Festive
description: RESTAURANTS make such a show of rack of lamb that many people assume there's some trick to cooking it. But all you have to do is trim the excess fat and roast at extremely high heat. With really good lamb, all you need for flavoring is salt and pepper.

title: Nice Try, No Reward As A.B.L. Goes Dark
description: It sneaked in and nabbed the majority of gold-medal players fresh off the 1996 Olympic podium and handed out six-figure salaries for their stars. It savored the coup of being the first to capitalize on women's basketball as it hit the pop chart and defied gravity by launching a dunk contest.

title: MATRIA HEALTHCARE TO BUY GAINOR MEDICAL MANAGEMENT
description: Matria Healthcare Inc., the largest United States provider of obstetric care in the home, said yesterday that it would buy Gainor Medical Management for about $130 million to expand into the treatment of diabetics. Matria, of Marietta, Ga., will pay about $85 million in cash and $45 million in preferred stock for the closely held Gainor, which is based in McDonough, Ga. It could pay an additional $35 million in subordinated notes, in 2000, depending on the company's performance in 1999. Matria, which had revenue of $144.5 million last year, said Gainor would have revenue of $98 million this year. Gainor manages medical treatment of employees for self-insured companies.

title: No Flying? No Kin? Whatever
description: It was never clear who brought the octopus. But there it was among the array of objects carried to the stage by audience members for Ivan Karamazov (Howard Jay Patterson) to juggle. The audience chose its three favorite objects by applause. And soon the octopus was being tossed in the air along with a metal rack and a white takeout-food container said to contain chicken and rice. Ivan did manage to keep the objects in the air for a count of 10. If he hadn't, he would have received a pie in the face. Because he did, he received a standing ovation instead.

title: Ace in Talks With Cigna To Buy Unit
description: Ace Ltd., a fast-growing Bermuda insurance company, is negotiating to buy the large commercial insurance business of the Cigna Corporation, a leading health insurer, both companies said yesterday.

title: RJR NABISCO UNIT ADMITS SMUGGLING
description: A unit of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal criminal charges stemming from a scheme to smuggle cigarettes into Canada through an Indian reservation in upstate New York and agreed to pay $15 million in penalties.

title: Computer Glitch to Delay Jobless Benefits for Some
description: At least 11 states will miss next month's deadline to fix computers used to pay unemployment insurance, but the states are making stopgap arrangements to avoid any interruption of benefits, Federal officials said today.

title: Anger Rises Over Plans For Ontario
description: Canadians live in a big country graced with an abundance of unspoiled places. And many of them want to keep it that way.

title: France Seeks New U.N. System for Monitoring Iraqi Weapons
description: In the wake of the British and American bombing of Iraq, France proposed today that the United Nations should set up a new system for monitoring Iraq's arms programs and let it export oil, but make sure none of the revenue is used to buy weapons.

title: Meeting Mr. Right Before the Reaper
description: Her head twisted painfully to one side, her dark brown eyes casting defiant sidelong glances at the world, and speaking in dragged-out syllables delivered in semi-intelligible moans and groans, Helena Bonham Carter gives what may be the stunt performance of the year as Jane, a feisty young woman dying of A.L.S. (Lou Gehrig's disease) in ''The Theory of Flight.''

title: NBC Set to Air N.Y.C. Marathon
description: The New York City Marathon, which has been carried since 1994 by Channel 11, will move next November to Channel 4. The contract is for five years.

title: At the U.N., a Pinch Hitter; Holbrooke's Benched for Now
description: With the opening here this week of a debate that could change the way the world does business with Iraq, the Clinton Administration's choice to lead the American delegation is still under investigation by the Justice Department.

title: From Kidding Opera to Rewriting It
description: In the current Broadway revival of Leonard Bernstein's ''On the Town,'' there's a hilarious sendup of a pretentious, boozy voice teacher called Madame Maude P. Dilly, played with gusto by Mary Testa. In the scene, the character Ivy Smith, who works as an exotic dancer at Coney Island but harbors higher aspirations, has come for her weekly lesson. Madame Dilly puts Ivy through the whole rigmarole of whoops, shouts and scales that constitute the vocal warm-up regimen of opera singers. For good measure, she throws in a stern admonition about dedication to art:

Burial at Beth Moses Cemetery. For info call Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel 609-883-1400.

title: PATRIOT AMERICAN ADOPTS SHAREHOLDER RIGHTS PLAN
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc. adopted a plan yesterday that would let existing shareholders buy stock cheaply in the event of a takeover attempt, making any acquisition much more expensive. The Dallas-based real estate investment trust, one of the biggest United States hotel companies and owner of the Wyndham chain, said the plan was not adopted in response to any known imminent takeover attempt. The company also said the plan was not related to its sale last week of a 30 percent stake for $1 billion to a group led by the financiers Leon Black and Thomas Lee, giving Patriot cash to help repay $1.7 billion of bank debt and other obligations coming due.

title: More Refugees Are Crossing the Yalu, Risking Capture and Jail Terms : Famine Driving North Koreans to China
description: DANDONG, China  The Chinese police commander leaped up from his chair in a coffee shop near the banks of the Yalu River, said he had a report on his cellular phone that six North Koreans had just been picked up on the Chinese side, and rushed out.

title: Paul Smucker, 81, Ex-Chairman And Catalyst at Jelly Company
description: Paul H. Smucker, the former chairman of the jelly company in Orrville, Ohio, that bears his family's name, died last Thursday at his home in Orrville. He was 81.

description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the largest local phone company in the United States, says it will not seek approval to enter the $8 billion-a-year New York State long-distance market until the first quarter, later than expected.

description: An errant spacecraft that was to be the first to orbit an asteroid will instead fly past its intended target on Wednesday, but scientists said today that they still held hopes of completing the original mission in 2000.

description: The Canadian transportation-equipment maker Bombardier Inc. said today that it had received a $580 million order for 25 of its new 70-seat regional jets from Horizon Air, a unit of the Alaska Air Group Inc. Delivery is scheduled to begin in the second quarter of 2002, the Montreal-based Bombardier said today. Alaska Airlines is based in Seattle.

title: N.B.A. Negotiators Entering 11th Hour for a Deal
description: Fearing that it will hurt negotiations with the players union, Commissioner David Stern has steadfastly refused to issue a so-called drop-dead date that would signal the cancellation of the entire 1998-99 National Basketball Association season. But as the league's contentious labor dispute motors toward its sixth month without resolution, it appears that such a date is within days of being announced.

description: The Omnipoint Corporation, a cash-pressed provider of wireless phone services, said today that two equipment makers and an unnamed lender would provide $375 million to help build a network spanning the Northeast and Florida.

title: Clinton's Foes Outnumbered But Steadfast
description: In virtually every major poll taken in recent weeks, the people who believe that President Clinton should be removed from office show up in the minority. But they are clearly resolute in their opinion, with most saying that the President lied both under oath and in his famous early pronouncement to the nation that he ''did not have sexual relations with that woman,'' and that such lies are automatic grounds for dismissal.

title: With the Consent of China, Balloonists Fly On
description: With a tense marathon of diplomatic maneuvers behind them and a fair wind at their backs, the three crew members of the ICO Global Challenge balloon floated over China yesterday, more hopeful than ever of becoming the first balloonists to circle the world nonstop.

Memorial donations may be made to the Junior Sailing Program at the Tred Avon Yacht Club, P.O. Box 337, Oxford, MD. 21654.

title: Police Union Loses President To Resignation
description: The president of the city's largest police union, facing criticism for failures at the bargaining table and the union's connection to a racketeering scandal, resigned yesterday and turned the job over to a handpicked successor.

title: Sears of Britain Rejects Proposals From Suitor
description: Sears P.L.C. of Britain announced yesterday that it had rejected takeover proposals from Medinbond Ltd., saying the offers undervalued the company. Philip Green, a buyer and seller of retail businesses, formed Medinbond to make the bids. His latest offer, of more than 300 pence a share, would value Sears at about $:458 million ($774 million).

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with a review of the Wendy Osserman Dance Company misidentified one of the two performers in ''Re:Sisters'' at Dance Theater Workshop on Friday. The dancer at the right was Despina Sophia Stamos, not Stefanie Nelson.

title: Kotite Is Able to Look Ahead in Pleasure
description: The Jets have been winning so decisively, Rich Kotite was saying, that the Super Bowl ''is up for grabs.''

title: About New York; Charity Santas And Hustlers: Poles Apart
description: ''SANTA needs help,'' Juan Lebron shouted to the people slowly shuffling past him on 49th Street near the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree. He was working the crowd as an elf for the Volunteers of America, taking instant pictures of passers-by posing with the more or less jolly old gent. ''Put your donation in the chimney, then you can take a picture with Santa. Santa needs your help.''

title: Inquiry Into Frito-Lay Finds No Wrongdoing in Marketing
description: The Justice Department has closed its investigation into the competitive practices of the Frito-Lay unit of Pepsico Inc. with no finding of wrongdoing.

description: For the on-line shopper at Amazon.com, it all looks so easy this holiday season.

title: Long Wait for Trial Of Suffolk G.O.P. Chief
description: The Suffolk County Republican leader, John Powell, is unlikely to face trial until 2000 on Federal charges that he extorted payoffs from garbage haulers at a public landfill and conspired to deal in stolen trucks, lawyers in the case said yesterday.

title: Bangalore Venkata Raman, Indian Astrologer, Dies at 86
description: Bangalore Venkata Raman, one of India's most respected astrologers, died on Sunday, suffering a heart attack as he edited The Astrological Magazine, the monthly publication he founded 62 years ago. He was 86.

title: UNITED RENTALS' SHARES RISE AFTER PREFERRED STOCK SALE
description: Shares of United Rentals Inc., a company that rents cranes, bulldozers and other construction equipment, rose 13 percent yesterday after it sold $300 million of preferred stock to affiliates of Leon Black's Apollo Management L.P. to raise cash for acquisitions. United Rental shares climbed $2.9375, to $25.1875. The stock has gained 30 percent this year but is down from a high of $48.0625 in July. The preferred shares bought by Apollo, the investment firm based in Purchase, N.Y., can be converted into 12 million shares at $25 each, or a stake of about 15 percent in the rental company based in Greenwich, Conn., said Robert Miner, United Rental's vice president of finance.

title: First Tally Falls Short Of an Ouster
description: After a few days of sounding out Senate sentiment, Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader, said flatly today that the Senate did not currently have the votes to convict President Clinton and remove him from office. He also said he thought there was bipartisan support for censure.

title: U.S. Help for Mexican Military Has Not Curtailed Drug Traffic
description: An ambitious United States effort to help train and equip Mexico's armed forces to pursue drug smugglers is in a shambles, officials of both countries say, souring American relations with an ally that Washington has worked intensely to court.

title: Female Detective Commander Takes Job in Massachusetts
description: Deputy Chief Jane Perlov, who was the first woman to command a borough's detectives in the New York Police Department, will leave the city next month to take the highest-ranking public safety job in Massachusetts, officials announced yesterday.

title: 3 Workers Hurt in Collapse of 4-Story Building
description: Three construction workers were injured in Brooklyn yesterday when part of an abandoned four-story apartment building that they were demolishing suddenly collapsed.

title: Angola's Exhausted People Confront War's Agony Again
description: In this small town in eastern Angola there is little doubt that a war that was dormant for nearly four years has begun again.

title: Israeli Blocs: Humpty-Dumptys Right and Left
description: If there was anything that brought unity to the fractious Israeli Parliament, it was bringing down Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in the overwhelming majority vote on Monday to dissolve the Government two years early.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGHERI, CHRISTOPHER B.
description: DEGHERI-Christopher B. of North Beach, N.J. formerly of Closter, NJ on December 21, 1998. Beloved husband of Dolores (nee Mudd). Devoted father of Christine Cleary and father-in-law of Thomas Cleary. Brother of Ramon. Loving grandfather of Lauren, Sean and Shannon. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly on Sunday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 10 AM St. Mary's Church, Closter. Interment Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Tenafly. Memorials to St. Vincent's Hospital, N.Y.C., Washington Theological Union, Washington, D.C., St. Peter's College, Jersey City, N.J. or St. Francis Center, Brant Beach, N.J. would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, DAVID S.
description: JACKSON-David S. Died on December 20, at age 96. Husband of Freda. Survived by his daughters Linda, wife of Andrew Segal, and Nancy, wife of Paul Godwin. He also leaves grandsons Edward Segal and William Segal.

title: Diversity Rules Threaten North Carolina Charter Schools That Aid Blacks
description: When state legislators in North Carolina were debating charter schools two years ago, some feared a re-emergence of the white-flight academies that had sprouted in the South a generation earlier in response to school desegregation. So lawmakers threw in a clause requiring the schools to ''reasonably reflect'' the demographics of the school districts they serve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, HAROLD
description: EDELMAN-Harold. Age 75, on December 21, 1998. Architect and artist. Beloved husband of Judith; loving father of Marc and Joshua; grandfather of Gabriel, Daniel, Sarah, and Benjamin. Dear brother of Edna Friedman and Paul. In lieu of flowers donations to Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center. There will be no funeral. A memorial gathering will be announced.

title: KING PHARMACEUTICALS TO BUY THREE DRUGS FROM HOECHST
description: King Pharmaceuticals Inc., a prescription drug concern based in Bristol, Tenn., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire three products from Hoechst Marion Roussel, the pharmaceutical company of Hoechst A.G. of Germany, for $362.5 million. The acquisition includes United States rights to Altace, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor; worldwide rights to A.V.C., a vaginal anti-infective cream, and rights to Silvadene, a burn cream. The products had net sales of about $91.3 million in 1997 and $71.5 million in the first nine months of 1998. As part of the deal, King will enter into a six-month transition services agreement with Hoechst Marion Roussel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINSTEIN, HANK

title: THE CHEF
description: FOIE GRAS, plump, extraordinarily rich duck liver, is an expensive, elegant indulgence. It's also surprisingly versatile. I prepare it year-round, changing its accompaniments with the seasons. This summer, I paired slices of sauteed foie gras with roasted peaches and red-wine vinegar; in late fall, its partners were poached quinces and pomegranate sauce. And for New Year's Eve, I've created this dish of seared foie gras, roasted pears, honey, rosemary and aged balsamic vinegar.

title: Pataki Assails Republicans in Washington for 'Blunders'
description: Declaring that Republicans in Washington had undermined the party with a series of ''horrible blunders'' this year, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that elected officials from beyond the nation's capital were more in tune with Republican ideology and better suited to help the party regain the White House in 2000. Mr. Pataki announced that he would travel the nation to offer alternatives to the ''failed strategies'' his party had embraced.

title: Service Takes a Holiday; These Days the Customer Isn't Always Treated Right
description: At the Container Store, a Dallas-based chain that specializes in storage products and closet organizers, employees do far more than ring up sales. They are trained to think of themselves as counselors or problem-solvers -- whether the issue is a shared closet that must house one spouse's 34 pairs of shoes or a child's room spilling over with an unmanageable number of toys.

title: A Book Does Justice to the Martini
description: IT was the early 1980's, a time before Lounge, and the martini looked to be on its last legs. Undeterred, a martini lover and classics professor named Lowell Edmunds wrote a treatise on his favorite drink, exploring its multiple meanings, explaining its ambiguous messages and tracing its intricate history. His book, ''The Silver Bullet,'' was a landmark, the first serious work on America's greatest cocktail, but for years -- the very years in which the martini has regained its former glory -- it has been out of print.

title: Don't Let Iraq Off Nuclear Hook

title: Beauty and Destruction in Pacific Battle
description: A thrilling sense of deja vu accompanies the lush Edenic images that provide ''The Thin Red Line'' with its prologue in paradise. Even if they could be watched without knowledge of their provenance, they would be instantly identifiable as the work of Terrence Malick, whose 1970's ''Badlands'' and ''Days of Heaven'' were the most beautiful and elusive films of their time. Mr. Malick's subsequent two decades in cinema limbo may have turned him into a figure of hype-inviting mystery, but it's immediately obvious that they have not dimmed his visual genius. It's as if a familiar voice had never left off speaking as, at long last, Mr. Malick's huge new opus begins.

title: BANKAMERICA IN $333 MILLION BA MERCHANT DEAL
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the part of BA Merchant Services Inc., a credit card processing company, that it did not already own for about $333 million in cash. BankAmerica, based in Charlotte, N.C., will pay $20.50 for each of the San Francisco-based BA Merchant's 16.2 million class A shares, a 17 percent premium to Monday's closing price of $17.5625. BankAmerica already owns all of BA Merchant's class B shares, representing 67 percent of its capital. BankAmerica shares fell 50 cents, to $60.0625, while BA Merchant shares rose $2.25, to $19.8125. In November, BA Merchant rejected a $252 million, $15.50-a-share offer from BankAmerica.

description: A CAVIAR connoisseur is someone who relishes the various. Bursting between the tongue and the roof of the mouth, caviar never tastes the same. Its flavor varies from fish to fish, region to region, season to season. That is part of its allure.

description: The impeachment vote on Saturday morning, one of the most extraordinary news days of at least the decade, drove up viewing levels for virtually every television news outlet that covered it, but not to the extent that some other major news events of recent vintage did, including the death of the Princess of Wales, or the verdict in the O. J. Simpson trial.

title: A Senior Overcomes The Odds
description: Those who have cystic fibrosis are not expected to be varsity athletes. Kathryn Waldo is an exception. She is a senior forward for the Northeastern women's team and she has played all four seasons for the Huskies, exhibiting considerable determination and skill.

title: The Senate Edges Toward Censure
description: The Senate seems inclined to treat Bill Clinton's misconduct in a fair and responsible way, provided the President will let it do so. Though Senate sentiment has not yet coalesced around a specific plan, both Republicans and Democrats are talking of censure as the most appropriate punishment. For the last couple of days Mr. Clinton and his aides have seemed in better touch with political reality. They can help keep the Senate on a conciliatory course by dispensing with the legal quibbling that has helped bring his Presidency to the brink of destruction and by continuing to send receptive signals about censure.

description: As usual, I didn't start holiday shopping this year until the mound of catalogues in my living room reached chair height. Speed-leafing through these paeans to yuppie gewgaws, I paused at a funky-looking wish book from Semplex of U.S.A., one of the country's leading specialty houses, serving amateur winemakers since 1962.

description: The three-man crew of the ICO Global Challenge yesterday became the first balloonists to cross the Asian continent from one end to the other and the first to fly over the towering Himalayan range.

title: Guerrillas Fire Rockets Into Israel
description: Muslim guerrillas in Lebanon fired Katyusha rockets into Israel today, wounding 13 people. The attack was retaliation for the killing of a Lebanese woman and six of her children in an Israeli bombing raid on suspected guerrilla targets on Tuesday.

It was a pleasure to know Stan. He will be sorely missed by his friends and family and by everyone who appreciated his zest for life. We extend our deepest sympathy to Rachelle and the Dinstein family.

title: A Business Card That Says a Lot
description: Business cards have become crowded with Web page and E-mail addresses, cellular phone numbers and other contact information, but a New York company has found a way to include pictures, graphics and a resume, among other things. How, you ask? Well, the extra material isn't on the card, it's embedded in it.

title: Take Two Giggles, Twice Daily: Physician, Squeal Thyself
description: In ''Patch Adams,'' Robin Williams plays a medical maverick who finds no situation too grim for a guffaw. He develops the theory that the best way to treat a dying patient who wants one last safari is to shock the man out of a sound sleep with balloon animals, for example. Naturally, the establishment is slow to appreciate Patch, to the point where he winds up making a heartfelt courtroom-style speech in defense of his methods. Here's a film for anyone who'd like to hear Mr. Williams declaim, ''If we're going to fight a disease, let's fight one of the most terrible diseases of all: indifference!''

description: One night, David Foster had a dream. It was more of a realization, actually, but he calls it a dream. He was thinking about niches, and what kind of gaps there are in popular music that need to be filled.

title: Spring Fever Arrives in Winter
description: There is a tendency to dismiss the significance of college basketball games in December, to not acknowledge that the season is in full swing until after the student athletes wearing helmets and pads conclude the holiday bowl season and the last bite of football is taken from the collegiate pigskin. College basketball coaches encourage this illusion.

title: Justice Department Begins Investigation of Salt Lake Bid
description: The Federal Government announced today that it had begun an investigation into the awarding of the 2002 Winter Olympic Games to Salt Lake City, bringing the F.B.I. into a situation that until now had been largely limited to arguments inside the sports community over gifts made to the people who selected host cities for the Games.

title: Enter the Computer-Generated Condo and Walk Around
description: LET'S say you're a developer with a pile of rubble where a new building is going to be. Today's market for luxury condominiums may not last forever. How do you move those multimillion-dollar three bedrooms before you can say, ''The stock market's down 512 points again''?

description: Here beside the ruins of one of history's greatest cities the frustrations of modern Iraqis seem especially poignant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARRON, JUDITH
description: ARRON-Judith. The American Symphony Orchestra League mourns the passing of Judith Arron. She began her career as Assistant to League President Helen Thompson, and recently she served on the League's Board of Directors. Throughout, she championed the highest standards of artistic excellence and her commitment to the art of music was uncompromising. Her unstinting advocacy for American orchestras, her passionate belief in the power of music education, and her unbridled determination to make music central to the lives of everyone were Judith Arron's gift to us all. On behalf of all American orchestras, the American Symphony Orchestra League extends condolences to her family and to the Carnegie Hall community.

title: TENDER LEAVES DEXTER WITH 71% OF LIFE TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Dexter Corporation, a specialty chemicals company, said yesterday that it had raised its stake in Life Technologies Inc. to about 71 percent after completing a $39.125-a-share, or $447 million, tender offer, short of the 100 percent it intended to buy. Dexter, based in Windsor Locks, Conn., made an unsolicited $420 million bid in July for the 48 percent of Life Technologies that it did not already own. Life Technologies, based in Rockville, Md., rejected that bid, and Dexter took the offer to Life Technologies shareholders. In its latest offer, Dexter dropped its requirement that it gain at least 80 percent of shares outstanding for the tender to be completed. Dexter shares rose 6.25 cents, to $30, while Life Technologies was unchanged at $39.25.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page E1 in the Arts section today about the New York String Orchestra Seminar for young musicians refers incorrectly at one point to the day of an all-Mozart program to be presented by seminar participants and alumni at Carnegie Hall. As noted earlier in the article, it is tonight at 7, not tomorrow night. A second concert is to be presented at the hall on Monday night at 8.

title: Alex Kelly Avoids Trial In 2d Rape
description: Alex Kelly, once a star high school athlete in Darien, Conn., who became an emblem of suburban recklessness after he was convicted in 1997 of raping a teen-age girl a decade before, pleaded no-contest yesterday in a second rape.

title: IRVINE APARTMENT RETAINS ADVISER TO EVALUATE OFFER
description: Irvine Apartment Communities Inc. said yesterday that its board had hired Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company to evaluate a $540 million offer from its chairman, the billionaire developer Donald L. Bren, to take it private. On Dec. 1, Mr. Bren, through his closely held Irvine Company, offered $32.50 a share for 83 percent of Irvine Apartment's common shares. At the time, the offer represented a 19 percent premium. Irvine Apartment, a real estate investment trust based in Newport Beach, Calif., has since risen 16 percent. It gained 12.5 cents, to $31.875 yesterday.

title: Well-Read on Web
description: DENIS DUTTON spotted a window of opportunity on the World Wide Web, but instead of opening a portal for the masses, he installed a porthole for intellectuals.

title: Turning a Building Into a Billboard
description: There was a time when, if an outdoor advertiser wanted a display, it would rent prominent space for a big billboard. But new lighting technologies -- some powerful enough to turn a whole building into a billboard -- have pushed advertising into a different dimension. Now almost anything can be advertised upon. (Expect new laws.)

title: How to Hide It In Plain Sight
description: IMAGINE the morning after. It's time to stow the stuff that was in the stockings. But the reality of living in New York is that you often have to store your stuff in plain sight. Decorative storage boxes can address all kinds of clutter. They now come in myriad shapes, clad in materials from toile de jouy to hand-painted paper. And there's nothing that doesn't seem intelligently organized once you've stored it in a nice box.

title: Cell Phones in a Scene of Smoke, Chaos and Distress at South Park Towers
description: As the searing black smoke that killed four people rolled up the stairwells and hallways of South Park Towers, there were surreal moments for many of the residents. Huddled in their apartments, they watched their building burn on television and took cellular phone calls from worried friends and relatives on the fire truck-clogged street below.

title: Credit Ratings Lowered At 7 Japanese Banks
description: Daiwa Bank Ltd., Sumitomo Bank Ltd. and five other big Japanese banks had their credit ratings cut by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which said yesterday that most of these lenders faced mounting bad debts and ''substantial'' net losses.

title: Preussag to Buy 24.9% of Thomas Cook
description: Preussag A.G., which has transformed itself from a steelmaker into Europe's No. 1 tourism company, agreed yesterday to buy 24.9 percent of Thomas Cook Group of Britain and plans to take majority control next year to gain a foothold in Europe's second-biggest market for package tours.

title: Endless Summer and Endless Winter

With ''Alpine Interiors,'' below left, by Beate Wedekind, readers are all huddled up inside hand-hewn wooden rooms with tiny windows: these are warm places in cold climates. Go on to ''Tuscany Interiors,'' by Paolo Rinaldi, and you move into spacious halls paved with marble: cool places in warm climates.

title: The Bidding Intensifies

title: Agency Finds Racial Bias In Baltimore's Police Force
description: In a highly unusual racial discrimination case, the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has determined that black officers in the Baltimore Police Department have been disciplined more harshly in recent years than white officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEW, SEK JIN, M.D., PH.D.
description: CHEW-Sek Jin, M.D., Ph.D., F.R.C.S. The Glaucoma Foundation profoundly regrets announcing the death of Dr. Sek Jin Chew, 39, Professor of Ophthalmology at the Singapore National Eye Center and Deputy Director of the Singapore Eye Research Institute, Singapore. A brilliant ophthalmologist and scientist, Dr. Chew was a key member of the Scientific Advisory Board of The Glaucoma Foundation and played indispensible roles in its research program and Annual Think Tank on Optic Nerve Regeneration and Rescue. He was a pioneer in myopia research and was President of the Myopia International Research Foundation. Professor Chew received his Ph.D. in Neuroscience from Rockefeller University and was the recipient of numerous scientific and humanitarian awards. Despite suffering from brain cancer for the past two years, Dr. Chew maintained his usual vigorous pace of research, teaching, and patient care. He is survived by his wife, Esther. Condolences may be sent c/o of the Glaucoma Foundation, 33 Maiden Lane, New York, NY 10038. Joseph M. La Motta, Chairman Robert Ritch, M.D., Medical Dir. John W. Corwin, Executive Dir.

title: Whatever You Want in Vinyl
description: Lots of people make vinyl flooring, but Amtico International, the British company that makes the Op Art design above, claims it can realistically fake anything from wood to glass to zebra skin. Not only that, but it can assemble any custom design -- say a logo or a child's name -- in parquetry. (Pieces arrive taped together.) Standard patterns range from $5.50 to $7.50 a square foot; custom flooring costs more. For dealer information: (404) 267-1900.

title: Outbreak of Food Poisoning Leads to Warning on Hot Dogs and Cold Cuts
description: Investigators from the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention who are looking into an outbreak of food poisoning that has sickened 40 people and killed 4 in 10 states since August have warned consumers on the storing and cooking of hot dogs and cold cuts.

title: Repair Records Are Checked for Clues in Fatal Brooklyn Fire
description: With all the required inspection reports missing, New York City investigators are focusing on repair records as they try to solve the mystery of why a sprinkler system in a Brooklyn high-rise was apparently turned off years before a fatal fire last week that cost three firefighters their lives, officials said yesterday.

title: DONALDSON, LUFKIN BUYS PHOENIX HOME LIFE PROPERTIES
description: The Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company said yesterday that it had sold a portfolio of commercial properties to a real estate fund managed by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. for $310 million. Details on the properties and the financial terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Shares of the New York-based Donaldson Lufkin rose 50 cents, to $39.

description: Concerned that sentiment in the Senate is running toward censure and against a full impeachment trial, conservative Republicans in both houses of Congress said today that they wanted to hear a thorough airing of the evidence and arguments from the prosecutors and President Clinton.

description: A day after the women's American Basketball League folded a third of the way through its third season, officials would not talk yesterday about what would happen to its 90 players and whether those players would be paid.

description: The number of killings reported so far this year in New York City has fallen to 606, putting the city on a pace to end the year with fewer homicides than it had in 1964, when the Beatles played ''The Ed Sullivan Show,'' the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge opened and a woman named Kitty Genovese was killed in Queens.

description: Commissioner David Stern will recommend on Jan. 7 that the National Basketball Association owners cancel the entire season unless a new collective bargaining agreement is reached by then, a development that leaves two weeks for a resolution to the league's costly and calamitous labor dispute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMSON, ROSE
description: TOMSON-Rose, of Bloomingburg, NY. A self employed playwright in NYC and formerly of Great Neck, NY, died at her home December 22, 1998. She was 86. The daughter of the late Israel and Celia Lynnchitz, she was born on April 13, 1912 in New York City. She was the widow of New York State Supreme Court Justice Bernard Tomson. Survivors include a son Louis Tomson of Albany; two daughters, Susan and Elizabeth Tomson both of Bloomingburg, New York. A sister Claire Barrens of San Diego, CA.; five grandchildren, Daniel Tomson, Anders Tomson, Sara Cordin, Alison Coleman, and Alexandra Tomson; one great granddaughter, Anika Tomson. She was predeceased by a son Steven Tomson and predeceased by two brothers, Jack Lynn and Sam Lynnchitz. Graveside service will be held on Thursday, December 24, 1998 at 11:30 A.M. at Beth Moses Cemetery in Pinelawn, New York.

title: Economic Scene; The banana war between the United States and Europe is more than a trivial trade spat.
description: FEW Americans care whether Europe buys bananas from Ecuador, Guatemala or Honduras. So many wondered whether the Clinton Administration recklessly started a trade war when it announced this week a list of European luxury products -- ranging from cashmere clothing to chandeliers -- that it vowed to tax into extinction if the European Union did not open its borders to bananas from Latin America.

title: Former Police Officer Convicted of Murder
description: A former Westchester County police officer was found guilty of second-degree murder yesterday for the execution-style killing of a man shot at the wheel of a car. The ex-officer, James DiMaria, 30, who was also convicted of criminal possession of a weapon, could be sentenced to a maximum of life in prison for the death of Cesare Mollo, the Bronx District Attorney, Robert Johnson, said. Acting Justice Robert Straus of State Supreme Court in the Bronx set sentencing for Jan. 12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANNUM, GERTRUDE L.
description: GRANNUM-Gertrude L. Was born on Dec. 3, 1912 to Editha and Hugh Grannum in Brooklyn, NY, she graduated Julia Richmond H.S. and went on to Brown Business School. She was one of 15 children, well-known by her sense of humor and wit, and extensive collection of teddy bears. She worked at the Internal Revenue Service in the Criminal Investigation Unit until her retirement in 1991, after 18 years of outstanding service. During this time she received numerous awards and recognition for her dedication and commitment to the Department. She is survived by her siblings Anita Freeman, Kathlyn Hilton, Mildred Zaky, Dorothy Crowley, Alberta Zuber, Horatio, Randolf, Charles, and Clifford Grannum, sisters-in-law Hazel and Betty Grannum, brother-in-law Harold Crowley, and a host of nieces and nephews, grand nieces and nephews, and great grand nieces and nephews. Gertrude will be missed by all and truly made a significant impact on the lives of her family members, especially her nieces and nephews. May God bless her.

title: Fighting Off the Flynt Virus
description: Joe Lockhart, President Clinton's press secretary, strained the holiday bonhomie in the White House press room this week when he mentioned ''a news magazine'' preparing to publish sordid details about Republican lawmakers. ''News magazine?'' a chorus of reporters howled, as Mr. Lockhart smiled and amended his comment to simply ''magazine.'' He was talking not about U.S. News but about Hustler, Larry Flynt's monthly smut magazine. Nevertheless Mr. Lockhart's misstep, if that is what it was, laid out a serious problem for today's journalists. Far too many readers and viewers believe, wrongly, that Mr. Flynt's sleaze empire is just another branch of the established media.

description: AFTER years under Congressional siege -- and a spring rally by conservatives to annihilate it -- the National Endowment for the Arts, whose budget was finally secured in September, may understandably be looking for steady ground to tread. But under a new chairman, William J. Ivey, who has said he believes the endowment should be as important as the Department of Defense, the N.E.A. is marching, not slinking, to the front lines in its support of the arts.

title: CHEVRON BUYING RUTHERFORD-MORAN FOR $91 MILLION
description: The Chevron Corporation, the fourth-largest United States oil company, agreed yesterday to buy the Rutherford-Moran Oil Corporation for $91 million in stock and $302 million in assumed debt to enter the natural gas market in Thailand. Rutherford-Moran, based in Houston, said last month that it would run out of cash and credit by January and was in talks to be acquired. While low crude oil prices have hurt the San Francisco-based Chevron along with all other oil companies, its chief executive, Kenneth T. Derr, said last week that the depressed environment could be an opportunity for large, well-financed companies like Chevron to acquire oil and gas assets at bargain prices.

The chain's employees earn unusually high salaries, but, in turn, the 29 outlets can charge steep prices to watch their costumed workers perform in glitzy arenas or on television.

title: Stepmommy Dearest? Not at All
description: In ''Stepmom,'' Julia Roberts plays the nicest person ever to wear black at a downtown photo shoot. She's a talented photographer so nice that she seems more interested in her boyfriend's children than in the man himself (Ed Harris). She's definitely too nice to have broken up his marriage to the suburban mama lion played by Susan Sarandon, in a story with enough suds to take care of all your 1999 laundry needs. What could be worse for this woman than learning she has terminal cancer? You know what: getting used to the prospect of Julia Roberts taking her place.

title: Virginia L. Radley, 71, a SUNY President
description: Virginia L. Radley, who as the first female president of a state university college in New York created a general education division and an honors program on the Oswego campus, died on Sunday at her home in Poestenkill, near Albany. She was 71.

title: Holiday for Strings; An Annual Christmas Seminar for Young Musicians Offers Them Coaching, Camaraderie and Carnegie Hall
description: For the last 30 years concertgoers in New York, particularly those with an abiding interest in the future of musical performance, have observed a tradition that has become nearly as intrinsic to the holiday season as tree lighting, window displays and sidewalk Santas. On Christmas Eve a few thousand listeners make their way to Carnegie Hall to hear the young participants in the New York String Orchestra Seminar perform the works they have been studying during a 10-day series of classes, coaching sessions and rehearsals at the New School. Many concertgoers return a few days later to hear a second program. (This year's is on Monday.)

title: ADELPHIA AGREES TO BUY VERTO FOR $127 MILLION
description: Adelphia Communications Inc., the seventh-largest United States cable operator, said yesterday that it planned to buy Verto Communications Inc. for $127 million in stock plus $32 million of assumed debt, adding to its Pennsylvania operations. Adelphia said it had signed a definitive agreement to buy the closely held Verto, which has 56,000 subscribers in the Scranton, Pa., area. It will issue three million shares of common stock. Adelphia said the Verto operations should generate revenue of $25.7 million next year. Adelphia shares fell 18.75 cents, to $42.375.

title: Smugglers' Helpers
description: How earnest and public-minded it sounded when tobacco company executives warned early this year that the attempt to jack up cigarette prices through the pending national tobacco bill would inevitably lead to smuggling and a black market. No less than Steven Goldstone, the chairman and chief executive of RJR Nabisco, warned that it was virtually impossible to stop a determined batch of smugglers, given that 14 million cigarettes can fit into a single truck. Mr. Goldstone called it ''irresponsible'' to ignore the smuggling that neighboring countries had experienced when they raised cigarette taxes.

title: MBNA IS BUYING PNC BANK'S CREDIT CARD OPERATIONS
description: The MBNA Corporation, the nation's third-largest credit card lender, said yesterday that it would buy the credit card operations of the PNC Bank Corporation, which is exiting the business. MBNA will pay $443 million, a 15 percent premium, for PNC's $2.9 billion in credit card receivables. MBNA declined to put a price on the other part of the sale. The deal includes PNC's American Automobile Association affinity-branded credit cards. MBNA signed a long-term agreement to market the cards for PNC Bank and the American Automobile Association. PNC Bank will continue to market consumer loan and deposit products to American Automobile Association members through PNC Bank.

The tub, made by American Standard, starts at $1,100, comes in 16 colors and with two types of large feet: the brass ball-and-claw (shown) or a simpler curve. Faucets are extra; for the names of dealers: (800) 524-9797.

title: Attention Drivers: New Inspection Stickers May Be Outdated
description: Bill Lorenzo, a freelance artist from Sunset Park, Brooklyn, drove his gold Ford Tempo to an inspection station on Tuesday. Before the station's mechanics would give his vehicle its yearly checkup, they stopped him dead in his tracks, warning him that the inspection sticker he would receive would not have the expected expiration date of Jan. 1, 2000, but Jan. 1, 1991, instead.

description: ''I may get sentimental when they play the Marseillaise, but for all the practical things, I see myself as a citizen of Europe. I like the life style in France, but I don't make my living there.''

title: 4 Who Died Attempting An Escape From Fire
description: They were connected only by fear and a fateful attempt to escape a fire that raged several floors below: a book publisher, a financial analyst, an elderly woman and a secretary who all scrambled into a stairwell full of smoke and perished in the thick haze.

title: To Put A Spring In Your Step
description: ''It looks like a gigantic futon, but it feels like walking on marshmallows,'' said Claudia Gould, the director of Artists Space in New York, who was talking about a new type of flooring used in ''A Pale Soft Plane,'' an installation by Craig Konyk. Mr. Konyk, an architect in New York, built his tilted floor of strangely impressionable, doughy green slabs and invites visitors to take off their shoes, put on slippers and cavort.

G.M.'S DELPHI AUTOMOTIVE TO OFFER 17.7% STAKE TO PUBLIC
description: The Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation, the auto parts unit of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that it planned to sell 17.7 percent of its common stock in an initial public offering. The parts manufacturer, based in Troy, Mich., will seek to sell 100 million common shares, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Underwriters, led by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, plan to market the shares at $14 to $18 each, the filing said. Delphi estimated in the filing that it would raise about $1.53 billion after expenses, assuming a share price of $16.

title: Judge Approves a Formula For Splitting Tobacco Cash
description: In a case pitting New York State against New York City, a judge approved a revised formula last night for sharing the more than $25 billion from the national suit against the tobacco industry.

title: Led by Intel, Stocks Rise as S.& P. 500 and Nasdaq Hit Records
description: Stocks barreled ahead yesterday with two main gauges setting records and a third, the Dow Jones industrial average, posting a gain that left it just 1.9 percent shy of uncharted territory.

title: BUILDING ONE SERVICES PLANS SHARE REPURCHASE
description: The Building One Services Corporation, a building-management services company, said yesterday that it had teamed up with the financier Leon Black to buy back about 78 percent of its shares for $900 million. The Washington-based company and Mr. Black, head of Apollo Management L.P., will offer to buy back from shareholders as much as 34.5 million of its shares for $25 each, a 52 percent premium to Tuesday's closing price of $16.50. The transaction will leave Mr. Black with about a 40 percent stake in the company. Building One said it had decided to join with Mr. Black to address a fall in the company's shares from a 52-week high of $25.375 in March and to raise cash to make more acquisitions. Shares of Building One rose $3.5625, to $20.0625.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK AGREES TO BUY BALLARD MEDICAL
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, the world's largest maker of tissue products, agreed yesterday to buy Ballard Medical Products for $764 million in stock to expand its stable of disposable health care products. Kimberly-Clark will pay $25 a share for each of Ballard's 30.5 million shares. Ballard, of Draper, Utah, makes disposable products like respiratory suction catheters and defibrillator pads. Kimberly-Clark said the acquisition would increase the size of its medical products by about 40 percent outside the United States. Kimberly-Clark, based in Dallas, rose 62.5 cents, to $53.875, while Ballard fell $1, to $24.125.

title: The Defense Rests: Holik Scores 3 Goals
description: In the world of the Devils, where defense is often top banana, a hat trick is a rarity. There was only one for New Jersey last season and none in the first 30 games this season. Bobby Holik ended that spell tonight by scoring the Devils' last three goals and leading them to a 4-2 victory over the St. Louis Blues at Continental Arena.

title: China's Diversionary Tactics
description: Last Saturday, when Liu Niachun, a prominent dissident, left his Chinese prison cell and arrived in the United States, many Western reports said he had been ''freed'' or ''released.'' One year ago, after 18 years in a Chinese prison, I, too, was ''released'' and sent here. A Chinese official said that if I ever set foot in China again, I would immediately be returned to prison. I cannot identify any legal principle that explains how my expulsion or Mr. Liu's could be construed as a release.

title: Lord Soper, Whose Pulpit Was Hyde Park, Dies at 95
description: The Rev. Lord Soper, a Methodist minister and Labor peer who was the most famous and longest-running soapbox orator at Speakers' Corner in Hyde Park, died on Tuesday in London. He was 95.

title: The Limits of China's Reform
description: Beijing's leaders are running dissidents through a revolving door. This week three leading democracy activists, Xu Wenli, Wang Youcai and Qin Yongmin, were given 11- or 12-year sentences for subversion after sham trials lasting only a few hours each. Two of the men had no lawyers. But the Government tried to quiet international criticism by releasing another dissident, Liu Nianchun, into exile in the United States after serving 30 months in a labor camp. After a few signs of limited political liberalization this year, China's Communist leaders are reverting back to form.

title: New Yorkers: Naughty and Nice; Crowded Subways

title: Construction Monitor Joins Spitzer Staff
description: Peter Pope, who has served as the top internal investigator of the School Construction Authority since 1996, said yesterday that he would resign at the end of the year to become a top aide to Attorney General-elect Eliot L. Spitzer.

title: U.N. Fails to Reach Consensus on Iraq Policy
description: The Security Council, struggling to rebuild the fragile unity among members that was shattered by the American and British bombing raids in Iraq last week, met today to thrash out a statement broadly outlining a policy toward President Saddam Hussein.

title: Can Mommy and Daddy Come Out to Play?
description: FOR baby-boomers who love the television shows of their childhood, the scene on Tuesday evening at Restoration Hardware, a home-furnishings store on lower Fifth Avenue, was pure ''Twilight Zone.'' Circling a tall Christmas tree and sofa, and heaped high on a coffee table, were stacks and stacks of toys introduced in the 1940's and 50's, like a holiday that had been kept on ice: tin speedboats, gyroscopes, Shoot the Moon games, Slinkys and yo-yos.

title: New York's Highest Court Cuts Fees for Defense Lawyers in Death Penalty Cases
description: In an action long sought by Gov. George E. Pataki and other proponents of the death penalty, New York State's highest court yesterday sharply reduced the fees paid to court-appointed lawyers who represent poor defendants in capital murder cases.

title: Jewish Students Assured Bus Service on Christmas
description: The Lakewood Board of Education and a bus company reached a compromise yesterday after the district sought a court order to force drivers to transport students to the town's 18 Orthodox Jewish schools on Christmas Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, HAROLD
description: EDELMAN-Harold. Age 75, on December 21, 1998. Architect and artist. Beloved husband of Judith; loving father of Marc and Joshua; grandfather of Gabriel, Daniel, Sarah, and Benjamin. Dear brother of Edna Friedman and Paul. In lieu of flowers donations to Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center. There will be no funeral. A memorial gathering will be announced.

description: RYBAKOV-Anatoli. Russian writer. On December 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Tatiana Rybakov. Dear father of Irina (Alexander) Kolchinsky and Aleksey Rybakov. Adored grandfather of Maria, Daniel and Art. Services Sunday, December 27, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Allahabad University in India misstated the number of India's universities and colleges in some copies. There are 10,000, not 1,000.

title: Ravi Shankar's Daughter Negotiates Two Worlds
description: At first glance, she could be a shining example of a modern California girl. She studies in honors classes as a senior at the public high school in Encinitas, Calif., and she's applying to top-tier colleges like Brown University and the University of California at Berkeley. She speaks five languages and takes classical piano lessons. She has written for the school newspaper, acted in school plays and become a community representative in her high school's feminist club. She goes out dancing to techno and trance music and listens to R&B, British pop and a little heavy metal. She fights with her mother over curfews. And she's addicted, she says, to exchanging E-mail with her friends.

title: In Coordination for the Euro, Italy Cuts Key Interest Rate to 3%
description: The Italian central bank reduced its benchmark interest rate half a percentage point today, to a record low 3 percent, completing the alignment of rates among the 11 nations joining the European single currency at the start of next month.

title: Music to Feed New Player: Some Free and Some Legal
description: SOMETIMES the future works just the way it's supposed to. Soon after I got a Rio PMP300, the portable player for MP3 music files, I went to a Metallica concert. The band played songs by Diamond Head, a band whose original lineup made albums between 1979 and 1983; as a critic, I wanted to double-check what it sounded like. Since I don't have any Diamond Head albums, I went on line to the Ultimate Band List Web site (www.ubl.com), searched for Diamond Head and found a site with a few Diamond Head songs as MP3's.

title: Agencies try to pick hits from the fall television schedule so advertisers can place their bets.
description: NETWORK executives like Peter Roth, the recently departed president of Fox Entertainment, or Warren Littlefield, who left a comparable position at NBC in October, are not the only people whose careers and reputations ride on their ability to pick hits for the fall television schedule.

title: Metro Business; Buyers Are Selected For State Properties
description: The Pataki administration has named preferred buyers for four properties on Long Island and in Queens that once held institutions for the mentally ill and retarded, including the former Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center, the largest undeveloped tract in western Suffolk County.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROHN INDUSTRIES, Peoria, Ill., a manufacturer of cellular phone equipment, agreed to acquire Pirod Holdings Inc. of Plymouth, Ind., a closely held telecommunications equipment maker, for $30 million in cash and $50 million in assumed debt.

title: In a Game, Crime Pays, If You Are Organized
description: Popular simulation computer games like Sim City and Civilization reward players for building strong, smoothly running communities. Now comes a new strategy game that also rewards the occasional murder, extortion plot and torching of local businesses.

title: Results in Tobacco Litigation Spur Cities to File Gun Suits
description: First the states sued the tobacco companies and recovered hundreds of billions of dollars in smoking-related Medicaid costs. Now more than a dozen cities either have sued the gun industry or are preparing to, in a growing campaign to ultimately win in court the handgun controls that gun interests have kept them from winning in state legislatures and Congress.

title: Icy Storm System Sweeps the Country; South Is Hit Hard
description: Freezing rain coated highways today with a thin, sometimes invisible cape of ice that stretched from central Texas to the Carolinas as frigid winds swept out of the northwest and pushed their way toward the Gulf of Mexico.

title: In the Rough With Makers Of Golf Clubs; Sales Decline as Products Fail to Attract New Buyers
description: Perhaps it is no coincidence that as the cold war ended, the golf-club war began. In their quest for the ultimate ball launcher, club manufacturers turned to the space-age materials, computer-aided design techniques and laid-off engineers of their Southern California neighbors, the aerospace companies. And they guard their secrets just as closely.

title: Out of Africa and Into a Rangers Sweater
description: His name sounds more like that of a distance runner than a hockey player. His background sounds like it, too; born in Zaria, Nigeria, where ice is rare and hockey players rarer.

title: Some Classes Canceled By Teachers' Strike
description: About 350 teachers and other employees in the Mercer County Special Services School District walked off the job yesterday in a dispute over salaries and benefits.

description: UNGERLEIDER-Evan Lee. Age 4. Of Wayne, N.J. On December 23, 1998 from Tay-Sachs Disease. Cherished son of Jeff and Shari. Dear brother of Justin. Dear grandson of Susan and Irwin Ungerleider and Stanley Michelman and the late Lenore Michelman. Devoted nephew and cousin. title: Apple's Store on the Web Is Closed for Renovations
description: It was the week before Christmas, and all through North America consumers were snatching up Apple Macintosh computers as fast as Apple could make them. So why, then, did Apple close its on-line store for the holidays?

title: Post Office Spurring the Pony Express Into the Next Century
description: IMAGINE a new communications technology: It is not necessarily secure, it requires people to leave their desks to use it and delivery can take days. Oh, and large attachments cost extra.

title: An Air of Mystery Surrounds the Abrupt Resignation of Biogen Chief
description: James R. Tobin, the president and chief executive officer of Biogen Inc., resigned abruptly and mysteriously yesterday, sending the stock of the biotechnology company down 8 percent in heavy trading.

title: Essay; Assad's Attack
description: Not since the takeover of the U.S. Embassy in Teheran has American territory been so egregiously invaded as last week -- and nobody in the distracted Clinton Administration seems to care.

title: Lessons of Gymnastics Have a Place on the Slopes
description: She does not call her pupils dead frogs when they fail to execute a particular move, nor does she envelop them in bearhugs when they do. But the former Olympic gymnast Phoebe Mills brings a wealth of experience as a world-class competitor to her new role as a snowboard coach at Okemo Mountain here.

title: Belgium Convicts 12 for Corruption on Military Contracts
description: A leading French industrialist and a former Secretary General of NATO were among 12 defendants convicted by Belgium's highest court today on corruption charges involving two military contracts in the late 1980's.

description: A car belonging to the man wanted for questioning in the October killing of a Buffalo doctor who provided abortions has been found at Newark International Airport, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN SELLS 56% STAKE IN EUROPEAN UNIT
description: The Safety-Kleen Corporation, a hazardous waste recycling and disposal company, sold a 56 percent stake in its European unit to senior managers and the British investment company Electra Fleming Ltd. for $154 million. Safety-Kleen was formed in March by the combination of Safety-Kleen and Laidlaw Environmental Services Inc. The companies said at the time that they wanted to sell the European business, which has annual revenue of about $120 million. The unit's managers will have a 12 percent interest in the European unit, while Safety-Kleen and Electra Fleming will each own 44 percent.

title: Crack Chestnut, Add Sugar Rum Cherry
description: ''The Nutcracker'' can take many surprising forms. But the best of them remain tributes to good cheer. An especially pleasant reinterpretation is ''The Harlem Nutcracker,'' in which Donald Byrd choreographically transplants the action from 19th-century Germany to 20th-century New York. Tchaikovsky's music undergoes its own metamorphosis, for the production is set to the jazz arrangements Duke Ellington and Billy Strayhorn made of some of the familiar tunes and to additional music composed and arranged by David Berger.

title: Cyberpaths Leading Toward the Joys of Reading
description: ONE of the most common complaints about computers is that they can take the place of reading. That is not a new complaint. Each time a new distraction has arrived -- comic books, television -- the same fear has been trotted out. Now it's the computer that looms over children, enticing them to stare aimlessly at a screen for hours.

title: 'New Labor' Strategist, a Blair Confidant, Quits Over a Loan
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair's closest confidant, the architect of the Labor Party's 1997 election victory, resigned today over his failure to disclose that he had received a loan from someone who came under investigation by his own department.

title: Clinton Extols the Quality of Mercy
description: President Clinton practiced charity and pleaded for mercy today in his first foray out of Washington since the House impeached him last weekend.

title: On-Line Samurai Transform an Ancient Game
description: THE Asian board game of Go was the game of the samurai. Among noble accomplishments for Chinese gentlemen, Go ranked with calligraphy, poetry and music. For centuries, Go has been used as a tool to teach military strategy. It is the game from which Japanese businessmen draw metaphors.

title: Wire It, and They Will Come
description: SCORES of Iowa middle-school students were squirming on a recent afternoon as they inspected tumors inside a colon as part of a career-information seminar about the medical profession. The students, however, were not even in the same room as the diseased colon -- or the same county, for that matter. The hundred or so middle schoolers were spread out all over the state, at six different schools.

title: Internet Music, To Go
description: THE Diamond Rio PMP300 personal music player, one of the most significant new products to appear in 1998, comes in a box that promises ''Internet music in the palm of your hand.''

title: Frigid Air Brings Out Warm Clothes and Spirit
description: As if Santa Claus himself were controlling the temperature, it has suddenly become cold enough in the New York region to make a white Christmas possible, if not likely.

title: Moderate's Ins and Outs In an Impeachment Vote
description: Facing a tableful of politicians at a Capitol Hill club last week, the waitress picked out Representative Christopher Shays and exclaimed, ''You're the guy that I saw on TV. You're the guy that had that meeting.''

title: Jobless Rate Rises In South Korea in Month
description: South Korea's unemployment rate rose for the first time in four months in November as students sought jobs ahead of graduation.

title: A Child Dreams of a Room, And the Dream Comes True
description: WHEN Maya Bogdanow, 9, moved into a new bedroom, she wanted exotic beaded curtains that glittered like rubies and sapphires in front of her bed. ''My friend, she has them at her house,'' Maya said. ''And I liked the idea. They're pretty. I can tie them back any way I want. And they're noisy. You can hear them whenever people come in.''

description: Orders for durable goods rose more than expected in November and consumer confidence remained high during December, data released today showed, suggesting the economy would enter the new year on a strong note.

title: The War as Art: NBC Borrows From a Game
description: ON screen, a Tomahawk missile rushes over the ocean. It is the Persian Gulf at night, and there is cloud cover, but you can see the texture of the waves. From the starboard side, the camera rolls around the circumference of the missile to follow it from behind. And you can see the flare, a flash of light from the rocket's rear and a misty condensation trail, reflected in the water.

description: To the Editor:

title: With a Bit Of British Reserve
description: If contemporary design has an impresario, it must be Sir Terence Conran, the man who for three decades has been orchestrating books, stores, restaurants, exhibitions and now a museum featuring all of the above. Sir Terence is the chairman of the Design Museum in London, the source of the new ''Design Museum Book of 20th-Century Design,'' written by Catherine McDermott (Overlook Press, $65). Each page glorifies one object, grand or humble, from the detergent-refill container, left, to Le Corbusier's city of the future, La Ville Radieuse. At the museum (through Jan. 31) is the 1998 selection of contemporary objects chosen by a civilian, not a curator. This year's selector is David Constantine, a photographer and director of the Motivation Charitable Trust and a quadriplegic who relies on inventive industrial design. Sir Terence himself selected the items for ''Cool Britannia,'' a roundup of new British design at the Philadelphia Museum of Art through March 7. The tool kit, above, is there, along with items like soccer shoes.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Some Expect Pacificare's Rosy Picture Will Change
description: Pacificare Health Systems seems insulated from the problems of the rest of the managed care industry. While the majority of H.M.O.'s are losing money covering the elderly under Medicare, Pacificare, the nation's largest Medicare H.M.O., is solidly profitable. The company is even telling Wall Street analysts that it should be able to increase its earnings by about 25 percent in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZALCBERG, ISRAEL
description: ZALCBERG-Israel, 76. On December 24, 1998. Beloved father, grandfather, brother and friend. Services Sunday, 10:45 AM, at Wellwood Cemetery.

title: 30-Year Mortgage Rate Up
description: The benchmark 30-year fixed mortgage rate rose to 6.77 percent from 6.69 percent in the week that ends today, from the previous week, according to a weekly survey of mortgage rates from Freddie Mac. That is the highest rate since the week ended Nov. 27, though it remained below 7 percent. The latest report also showed the average rate on a one-year adjustable-rate mortgage rose to 5.58 percent, from 5.55 percent the previous week; the 15-year mortgage rate rose to 6.41 percent from 6.35 percent.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed today through Monday for Christmas, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: The Moment That Matters
description: If you have ever fallen in love, you know what it means to live in a land where all the songs are suddenly true. There are times when Christmas is like that, too. Not at first, of course, not when Thanksgiving is still a week away, and the outside thermometer sticks at 60 and the first Christmas catalogue is already months old. Not when you think about the shopping left to do and, worse, the wrapping. When the season has barely begun and you see a late-night clip of George Bailey running the length of Bedford Falls, overcome with joy, he seems a little more keyed up than he did the year before, and you can't help thinking, ''That won't last.'' The same goes for Alastair Sim and his bed-curtains. You realize one afternoon that you've never heard anyone say ''Bah, humbug!'' and really mean it.

title: 2 Are Accused of Bearing Away Gifts
description: A family in Queens got an early-morning visit yesterday, but it wasn't Santa Claus who was sneaking into their house.

title: No Chance of Tenure
description: Like Frankenstein, ''The Faculty'' plunders the crypts of cinema for its body parts. Here are the paranoia and parasitism of ''Invasion of the Body Snatchers.'' There are the slimy, sharp-toothed creatures of ''Alien.'' And over there are the movie-wise teen-agers of ''Scream.''

title: Visions In Glass: America's Angels
description: When the Union Congregational Church building in Worcester, Mass., a rather loose interpretation of Notre Dame in Paris, was vacated and sold to a developer in the mid-1980's, its stained glass windows were removed and stowed. Chief among them was the ''Angel of Praise,'' a wonderfully crafted, opalescent Victorian vision in pinks, mauves and turquoises of a full-length female angel in flowing robes, designed in 1896 by Henry Landon Parkhurst of New York.

title: CROPS DEVASTATED
description: A brutal four-day freeze has destroyed more than a third of California's annual citrus crop, inflicting upwards of a half-billion dollars in damage and raising the prospect of tripled orange prices in supermarkets by next week.

title: Back in Hot Springs, Few Townspeople Are Cooling on Clinton
description: In a week when temperatures in the 20's with low gray clouds, sleet and whipping winds made this central Arkansas city where Bill Clinton grew up uncommonly cold and gloomy, many residents' feelings about the President would surely warm his heart.

title: Mercedes Unit Picks Chief
description: Mercedes-Benz U.S. International, a unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G., named Bill Taylor as its president and chief executive yesterday to replace Andreas Renschler, 40, who was named this month to lead global executive development for DaimlerChrysler. Mr. Taylor, 48, has been operations vice president for the German auto maker's first United States assembly plant. Prior to joining Mercedes-Benz, he held manufacturing management jobs with the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Ford Motor Company.

title: French Far-Right Party Likely to Split as Le Pen Expels 7 Aides
description: A split of France's far-right National Front party appears likely after the party's founder, Jean-Marie Le Pen, had his former deputy and six other party leaders expelled from its executive body this week.

title: HRPT PLANS $200 MILLION OFFERING FOR ELDERLY HOUSING
description: HRPT Properties Trust, the real estate investment trust, said yesterday that it planned to spin off a one-third stake in its housing division for elderly people to its shareholders, and sell a separate one-third interest to the public. HRPT, which owns about $3.1 billion in assets, hopes that by splitting apart its elderly people properties from its office and commercial real estate holdings, its stock should get a better valuation on Wall Street. It plans to raise about $200 million in the initial offering to buy 14 new living communities for the elderly, which will be leased to Marriott International Inc. on a long-term basis.

title: GPU TO BUY ARGENTINE COMPANY FOR $435 MILLION
description: The owner of the Pennsylvania Electric Company agreed yesterday to buy Emdersa, an Argentine electricity distribution holding company, for $435 million. GPU, based in Morristown, N.J., is the parent of GPU Energy, which includes the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, the Metropolitan Edison Company and Pennsylvania Electric. The company said it had bought Emdersa to pursue a strategy of becoming a leading owner of electricity infrastructure assets. Emdersa combines three electricity distribution companies: Edesa, Edelar and Edesal, which have operations in the Argentine provinces of Salta, La Rioja and San Luis. The units have a total of 335,000 customers in northwest Argentina. GPU's shares rose 6.25 cents yesterday, to $43.9375.
