Large places and small ones -- even places that don't have music for the rest of the year -- herald the change of the calendar with live performances, always an effective way to create a sense of occasion. Dancers and punks, be-boppers and salseros, headbangers and brooders can all find music to suit their pre-millennial predilections this New Year's Eve. Clubs are likely to be packed, and promoters know it; on New Year's Eve, prices rise as inhibitions fall. Off the bandstand, it's not a good night for improvisation. title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about 33 people who were charged with trespassing while celebrating the winter solstice on a Staten Island beach referred incorrectly to the position of the Sun relative to Earth on that day. The winter solstice in the northern hemisphere marks the moment when the angle between the Sun and Earth's axis reaches its widest -- that is, when the North Pole is at its maximum point from the Sun. It does not mark the moment when the Sun is farthest from Earth. That distance has no influence on the timing of the seasons.

title: Popular Tax-Free Health Plans Spark Holiday Rush to Doctors
description: For many Americans, December is a month for compulsory shopping sprees, with the urgency escalating as Christmas approaches. But for Olivia Hewitt, the seasonal panic goes beyond choosing between a Furby (if she could find one) or a Barbie for her niece. Instead she wondered, ''Should I get a fourth pair of glasses, have my teeth cleaned again, do a marathon session with my therapist or try acupuncture?''

title: Having a Deep Impact On Vikings' Success
description: The play is called ''dot left slot hound right divide'' and it is not your ordinary football play. That's because it is often called for Minnesota Vikings wide receiver Randy Moss, who is not your ordinary football player.

title: Some Voters Are Making Party Switch
description: In a small but perhaps telling sign of the political fallout from the House impeachment vote, a handful of local election officials in various parts of the country say a surprising number of people have officially changed their party registration to Democrat from Republican.

title: Emilio F. Mignone, 76, Dies; Argentine Rights Campaigner
description: Emilio Fermin Mignone, who became a leading campaigner for human rights in Argentina after his daughter was among the thousands who disappeared in the military regime's ''Dirty War'' two decades ago, died of cancer on Monday in Buenos Aires. He was 76.

title: MORE DATA SOUGHT ON BARNES & NOBLE-INGRAM DEAL
description: The Federal Trade Commission is seeking additional information from Barnes & Noble Inc. about its proposed $600 million purchase of the Ingram Book Group. Barnes & Noble received the F.T.C.'s request for additional information about the proposed acquisition 11 days ago, said a company spokeswoman, Mary Ellen Keating. The proposed deal is opposed by the American Booksellers Association, a trade group for independent retailers. Opponents argue that Barnes & Noble's acquisition of Ingram, the largest United States book wholesaler, would give it power to shut off supplies to Ingram customers.

title: LIBERTY ASSOCIATES TO ACQUIRE SOURCE W UNIT FROM CBS
description: Liberty Associates, a diversified technology company, said yesterday that it was buying Source W Media from the CBS Corporation. The purchase price was not disclosed. Source W said its management would remain in charge of the 130-employee company, which provides printing, Internet applications, digital publishing and warehousing services. CBS, formerly the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, is in the process of selling Westinghouse industrial businesses to concentrate on its media holdings. Shares of CBS were unchanged at $30.5625.

title: America Flunks Civics
description: The impeachment of their President was not exactly the Christmas present most Americans expected (or wanted) this year. This is the time of year when we sing of peace and harmony, not of discord and strife. The rancorous ugliness of our public life seemed even uglier in contrast to the holiday spirit of our private lives.

title: Christmas Sermons to Spotlight Forgiveness Rather Than Clinton
description: President Clinton's impeachment was unlikely to figure prominently in Christmas Eve and Christmas Day sermons, according to clergy members interviewed yesterday who said they planned to preach instead on themes like hope, light and new beginnings as a way of addressing the holiday's Christian meaning.

description: CASS-Claire. Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary mourn the loss of a cherished member of the Jewish community, loving mother and grandmother, and sister of Max Grill, a YU Benefactor and honorary alumnus, who endowed the Max and Marion Grill Deanship at RIETS. Condolences also to her sister, Betty Fiebert, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. title: Under Shadow of Antitrust Case, Microsoft Tries to Maintain Its Edge
description: On the pine-covered campus with its man-made waterfall, much remains the same at Microsoft's world headquarters. The sodas are still free. Employees are encouraged to take breaks by congregating on the many basketball courts or around whimsical game machines, all part of what is known at Microsoft as the ''Sneak ernet,'' the face-to-face contact that company officials say is vital, even as people here spend much of the day communicating via computer.

title: Weak Link Appears In Fire Safety Rules
description: Two fires in the last week that killed three firefighters in Brooklyn and four residents in Manhattan have focused attention on fire safety in high-rise residences. In the last 20 years, the city has added rules like self-closing doors and fire-rated concrete block construction, but the fatal fires showed that those measures can be undone by human error.

title: Sports of The Times; Not So Wonderful: The N.B.A. Has Gone To Pottersville
description: THERE is no George Bailey in this holiday tale, no central figure who is, spiritually, the richest man in the pro basketball lockout. There are only those so spoiled by wealth, so drunk with fame, that they have forgotten to whom they owe their wonderful life.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption yesterday about a news conference on the dissolution of the American Basketball League misstated the given name of a player for the Seattle Reign. She is Kate Starbird, not Karen Starbird.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International; Toyota Seeks a Cozy Spot in Europe
description: RECESSIONS are chilling Japan and much of the developing world, but it's springtime in Europe for the Toyota Motor Corporation. Toyota has invested heavily here in this decade, and its planning is about to pay off. When European Union quotas on Japanese imports end in 12 months, Toyota will be ready with new models, expanded factories, more dealers and its high-margin Lexus luxury brand.

title: Bin Laden Denies Role in Embassy Bombings
description: Osama bin Laden, whom the United States intelligence authorities consider one of the world's most dangerous terrorists, has denied that he had any role in the deadly bombings of two American embassies in Africa.

title: Revisiting 'Church Unusual,' Reviving a Common Bond
description: Early on a Sunday morning almost a decade ago, I picked my way warily through the ruined streets of East New York, Brooklyn, bound for the church that would change my life. I did not know then, of course, how St. Paul Community Baptist Church would transform me. I knew only that I intended to write a book on the congregation and its pastor, the Rev. Johnny Ray Youngblood.

title: Chase-American Express Dispute Settled
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a settlement with the American Express Company, two days after the charge card giant filed a lawsuit in Federal court in New York contending that Chase used false advertising and deceptive acts in marketing its platinum credit cards.

title: Debris in Heating Equipment Suspected as Cause of Fire
description: Investigators said yesterday that they were looking into whether a blaze that killed four people in an Upper West Side high-rise Wednesday morning was caused by debris wedged in the vents of a built-in heating and cooling unit.

title: Nod to Olmsted And the Ice Age
description: The Public Art Fund has big plans for the southeast entrance to Central Park, officially known as the Doris C. Freedman Plaza. The nonprofit Art Fund has orchestrated projects like the water tower that the English artist Rachel Whiteread cast in resin and installed on a SoHo roof this summer. For the last year and a half, it has been working with Andrea Zittel, the American installation artist, on a project for the park.

title: No Progress From Private N.B.A. Talk
description: Without lawyers, players or a public announcement, Commissioner David Stern and the union director, Billy Hunter, held a secret meeting Wednesday night in an attempt to salvage the National Basketball Association season.

title: Baseball to Fine Beeston Over Clemens's Contract
description: Roger Clemens may still be traded, or maybe he won't be, but his agreement with the Toronto Blue Jays has put Major League Baseball in the embarrassing position of taking disciplinary action against its No. 2 official, Paul Beeston.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS. Coffee prices dropped on expectations that delayed exports from Latin America would reach this country next month, a time of weakening demand. In New York, March arabica fell 3.65 cents, to $1.1410 a pound.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: ''Give us time,'' Danny Meyer says about his newest restaurant, Tabla. ''We're still working on the lighting. We're trying to fix the sound.'' He gestures around the room at the green walls and glowing red wood floor, looking slightly pained.

title: Arena Picks 26 For Training Camp
description: Bruce Arena, the United States men's national team coach, this week invited 26 players to a nine-day training camp next month in Florida. Arena, the former coach of D.C. United of Major League Soccer, selected seven of his former players and, in all, 14 players selected have played for Arena before, either with D.C. United or for Arena when he was the coach of the 1995-96 United States Under-23 (Olympic) team.

title: A Convulsive Beauty That Defies the Laws Of the Natural World
description: The year 1998 in the galleries could not have ended better than with the small, provocative and hugely rewarding mixed exhibition at Cheim & Read. Organized and commented upon by Jean Clair, the director of the Picasso Museum in Paris, the show is strong on sheer astonishment. It has no one focus, but darts back and forth through the history of ideas.

title: Mr. DeLay Goes Out of Bounds
description: Just as the move to censure President Clinton is gaining momentum in the Senate, the House Republicans' chief hatchet man has arrogantly tried to block its progress. Tom DeLay, the majority whip, is inviting senators who oppose a lengthy trial over removing Mr. Clinton from office to view some mysterious evidence against the President that has not been made public or disclosed to the White House but is available only to House members. This claim of secret evidence is an insult to due process and an improper intervention into Senate deliberations. The Senate's obligation is to weigh evidence in the open and stick to the official case brought by the managers of the impeachment case.

description: LIND-Dr. John K., Columbia Univeristy, Professor of Dentistry. Died at home Wednesday, Dec. 23, after a long battle with heart disease & lung cancer. His beloved companion, Deena Wolfson survives Dr. Lind. Other survivors include a son and daughter from his marriage to Violet Lind, a resident of New Rochelle, NY, John K. Lind, Jr., of Cleveland, Ohio, and Patricia Lind Migliore of Fairfield, CT, and four grandsons, John K. Lind III, Michael Thomas Lind, Christopher Ryan Lind, and Patrick Taylor Migliore. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. on Sunday, December 27th from 3-7 PM. A Mass of Christian burial will be held on Monday, 11:00 A.M., at St Ignatius Loyola Church on Park Avenue. Donations in his name may be made to P.E.A.C.E Foundation, c/o William Wood, S.J., Jesuit Seminary & Mission Bureau, 39 East 83rd Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: Confusion Over the Puerto Rican Vote
description: The only clear message from the recent plebiscite in Puerto Rico is that the question of the island's political future remains deeply divisive. Congress's failure to sponsor orderly balloting that would give the island's 3.8 million voters a meaningful say about their political status has not helped.

title: TV Weekend; Making Peace With the Past On a Journey Across Vietnam

description: Advocates for the poor, who had hoped to force New York State officials to provide food stamps to thousands of able-bodied legal immigrants, lost a lawsuit this week when a judge upheld the state's denial of such assistance.

title: Intel Gets a Think3 Stake
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's largest computer-chip maker, bought an undisclosed minority stake in Think3 Inc., the closely held maker of computer-aided design software said today. Think3, formerly known as Cad.Lab, also said it had secured $17.5 million in financing through Robertson, Stephens & Company's Omega Ventures. Think3's software designs objects, from home appliances and engine parts to children's safety products and custom cars. Both companies are based in Santa Clara.

title: Facing Up To an Alter Ego
description: JAN SCHLICHTMANN, a lawyer who specializes in cases involving pollution and the environment, is having trouble keeping things straight. There is the reality of his own life, and then there is the slightly spruced-up version, the Hollywood version that opens on Friday.

title: Japan Unemployment Rate Hits Postwar High of 4.4%
description: Japan said today that its unemployment rate rose to a postwar record of 4.4 percent in November, equaling the United States jobless rate for the first time.

title: Happy Borrower From the World's Rituals
description: TODAY may be dedicated officially to the Man from Galilee, but as millions of Americans plug in their Christmas lights and fire up their Yule logs, Donna Henes knows they will be paying homage to a much older tradition. For Ms. Henes, an ''urban shaman'' and rituals consultant from Brooklyn, the Christmas lights -- and Hanukkah candles for that matter -- are descended from primordial ceremonies marking the winter solstice, the darkest day of the year. ''The Christmas tree is essentially nature worship,'' said Ms. Henes, who had to stop herself from using the P-word -- pagan -- because ''people have a problem with it.''

title: Rock, Rhythm-and-Blues And Pop Music; Where to Dance the Last Night Away, or Just Listen
description: This New Year's Eve, while everyone else is ready to party like it's 1999, musicians will be busily at work. Large places and small ones -- even places that don't have music for the rest of the year -- herald the change of the calendar with live performances, always an effective way to create a sense of occasion. Dancers and punks, be-boppers and salseros, headbangers and brooders can all find music to suit their pre-millennial predilections this New Year's Eve. Clubs are likely to be packed, and promoters know it; on New Year's Eve, prices rise as inhibitions fall. Off the bandstand, it's not a good night for improvisation. Would-be revelers are advised to make reservations early. Below, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times survey the New Year's Eve possibilities. (A * denotes a highly recommended concert.) title: Unwrapping Gifts of Holiday Songs Under a Met Tree
description: The three fine musicians of the Aureole ensemble, playing flute, viola and harp, are regular visitors to the Metropolitan Museum's Christmas tree. And on Tuesday evening they were there with the soprano Heidi Grant Murphy to present a program of Christmas songs and lullabies (two genres that overlap in such numbers as ''I Wonder as I Wander''), interspersed with instrumental pieces. Among them was happily included a movement from the great work written for their combination, the Debussy Sonata. They played it beautifully, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, NANCY
description: GALLAGHER-Nancy. On Dec. 23, 1998. Retired librarian and teacher, NYC Public Schools. Beloved sister of Ellen Kearney and Patrick Gallagher. Devoted aunt of Nancy, Mary, David, Brian, and Colin. Funeral Mass St. Patrick's Church 10:15 Monday. Visiting Schaefer Funeral Parlors, 4th Ave & 42 St, Brooklyn, Saturday and Sunday, 25 and 7-9 P.M. (private parking). Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: KENETECH SHARES SURGE ON $245 MILLION SALE OF PLANT
description: Shares of the Kenetech Corporation, a power-plant developer, surged 79 percent yesterday after it sold its interest in a Puerto Rico plant project for $245 million to Edison International Inc. Shares of the San Francisco-based company rose 15 cents, to 34 cents, in trading of 754,100 shares, more than 18 times the three-month daily average. Edison International, California's second-biggest electric company, said on Wednesday that its power-plant unit had agreed to buy Kenetech's 50 percent stake in a Puerto Rico plant project being jointly developed with a unit of the Enron Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORCE, MARTIN
description: FORCE-Martin, 90, in Houston, Texas, Tuesday, December 22. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice Stein Force, devoted father of Eden Force Eskin and Lani Weirnick, father-in-law of Robert Eskin and Robert Weirnick. Grandfather of Darren Weirnick, Blake Eskin, Devra Eskin, and the late Marisa Weirnick. Teacher and mentor, Chairman of the Physical Education Department, Bronx Science H.S. and Commerce H.S., member of First Faculty of Taft H.S., camp counselor and Director, including Camp Echo Lark. An athlete, coach, and tennis pro. Donations may be made to Seven Acres Senior Care Service; 6200 N. Braeswood; Houston, TX. 77074.

title: Weighing Power In Foreign Films
description: Of late, domestic films have made a drab lot on video. Not so the foreigners. On Tuesday, for example, Fox Lorber issued ''Lola Montes'' (1955), Max Ophuls's last film, with Martine Carol as the 19th-century Mexican circus performer and collector of men from Franz Liszt to the King of Bavaria. And from New Yorker this week comes ''La Promesse,'' Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne's exceedingly powerful film about a 15-year-old boy (Jeremie Renier) whose loyalties are torn between a domineering father and the family of a laborer from Burkina Faso whom the boy's father has exploited.

title: Rock, Rhythm-and-Blues And Pop Music; Where to Dance the Last Night Away, or Just Listen
description: This New Year's Eve, while everyone else is ready to party like it's 1999, musicians will be busily at work. Large places and small ones -- even places that don't have music for the rest of the year -- herald the change of the calendar with live performances, always an effective way to create a sense of occasion. Dancers and punks, be-boppers and salseros, headbangers and brooders can all find music to suit their pre-millennial predilections this New Year's Eve. Clubs are likely to be packed, and promoters know it; on New Year's Eve, prices rise as inhibitions fall. Off the bandstand, it's not a good night for improvisation. Would-be revelers are advised to make reservations early. Below, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times survey the New Year's Eve possibilities. (A * denotes a highly recommended concert.) title: A Restless Explorer Of Early Abstraction
description: Of American early modernist painters, John Marin is one of the most esteemed, but he is not among the most memorable. That may be partly because he specialized in the relatively modest medium of watercolor. But more important, unlike Marsden Hartley, Georgia O'Keeffe or Edward Hopper, he was not a strong image maker. He mirrored the vitality of the city or nature by painterly means learned from Cezanne, the Fauves, the Cubists and Kandinsky. But it is his sophisticated play with abstraction and the process of painting rather than imaginative vision or emotional resonance that distinguishes his art.

title: Holik Adding Offense To Renown for Defense
description: Bobby Holik was the most faithful student of the former Coach Jacques Lemaire's defense-first philosophy the last five years. But Holik, a pugnacious center from the Czech Republic, has become the biggest weapon in the Devils' offensive arsenal this season under the direction of the new Coach Robbie Ftorek, especially since serving a two-game suspension by the league last month.

title: KORN/FERRY TO SELL 35% OF STAKE IN INITIAL OFFERING
description: Korn/Ferry International, the world's largest executive search firm, plans to sell 35 percent of its common stock in an initial public offering, the company disclosed. The Los Angeles-based recruiter will seek to sell 12.5 million shares for $13 to $15 apiece, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. While Korn/Ferry initially filed for an initial offering in August, the filing did not give details of the planned offering. If Korn/Ferry sells shares at the estimated price, it will give the company an implied market value of as much as $536 million. Korn/Ferry could raise as much as $187.5 million if shares sell for $15 each. That is about 18 percent less than the $230 million the company had estimated it would raise.

title: RAYOVAC TO BUY LATIN AMERICAN BATTERY MAKER
description: The battery maker the Rayovac Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase ROV Ltd., a privately held battery maker in Latin America, for $120 million. The acquisition of ROV, its fourth since Rayovac went public in November 1997, will give Rayovac worldwide control of the Rayovac brand rights, with the exception of Brazil, the company said. ROV, a spinoff of Rayovac's international operations, had 1997 sales of $84 million. Rayovac, based in Madison, Wis., had sales of $495.7 million for the year ended Sept. 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIND, JOHN K., DR.
description: LIND-John K., Dr., Columbia University, Professor of Dentistry, died at home on Wednesday, December 23rd after a long battle with heart disease and lung cancer. Dr. Lind was born in New York on April 18, 1931, the son of Hazel Taylor and Thomas Lind. He was a graduate of St. John's College and Columbia University, School of Dental and Oral Surgery. His career in dentistry spanned forty years, with time divided between teaching and a private practice at 501 Madison Avenue in partnership with Drs. Boaz Shattan and Michael Shulman. At Columbia he rose to the rank of clinical full professor. His special interest was the diagnosis and treatment of systemic diseases with manifestations in the oral cavity including oral cancer. Dr. Lind's private practice included an eclectic mix of patients from all over the world and from every walk of life. Notable among his patients were Greta Garbo, Errol Flynn, Arthur Miller, Marilyn Monroe and General Carlos Romulo of the Philippines. He was a long time resident of New Rochelle, N.Y. and New York City, and a member of many fraternal, charitable, scientific and social organizations: President of Sigma Tau Alpha, Skull and Circle, Anucron Kappa Upsilon, Grandmaster of PSI Omega, Sigma Psi Scientific Society, P.E.A.C.E. Foundation Board of Governors, and 4-term President of Bonnie Briar Country Club in Larchmont, New York. His beloved companion, Deena Wolfson, Survives Dr. Lind. Other survivors include a son and daughter from his marriage to Violet Lind, a resident of New Rochelle, NY: John K. Lind, Jr. of Cleveland, Ohio; and Patricia Lind Migliore of Fairfield, CT; and 4 grandsons: John K. Lind III, Michael Thomas Lind, Christopher Ryan Lind, and Patrick Taylor Migliore. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Sunday, December 27th from 3 to 7 PM. A mass of Christian burial will be held on Monday at 11 AM at St. Ignatius Loyola Church on Park Avenue. Donations in his name may be made to P.E.A.C.E. Foundation, C/O William Wood, S.J., Jesuit Seminary & Mission Bureau, 39 East 83 Street, New York, New York.

title: Chico Mendes's Legacy
description: Chico Mendes was not an environmentalist in the traditional sense. It was only three years before his murder, which was 10 years ago this week, that he met environmentalists and learned with amazement that the Amazon Forest mattered to those far away. As head of Brazil's National Council of Rubber Tappers, his concerns were the tappers who were being forced off their land and killed in disputes with invading ranchers. But Mr. Mendes probably did more than any other person to preserve the Amazon. Although it has been burning faster than ever since his death, his ideas and organizational skills have led to new policies and ways of thinking about the forest that provide the basis for hope.

title: Editorial Observer; For the Chief Justice, the Trial of a Lifetime
description: One of this holiday season's most sought-after books is an out-of-print 1992 tome on impeachment called ''Grand Inquests.'' Just before Christmas it was the 37th most requested title on Amazon.com, the on-line bookstore, and there was a double-digit waiting list at the midtown branch of the New York Public Library to check it out. Indeed, demand is such that William Morrow's Quill division plans to re-issue a paperback version of the book next month. This interest probably owes less to the timeliness of the book's subject matter than to the job held by its amateur-historian author, Chief Justice William Rehnquist. But readers looking for clear signals on how the Court's conservative leader would preside over a Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton will probably be disappointed.

title: Former Salesman Settles
description: A Credit Suisse Group affiliate's former salesman agreed on Thursday to pay $50,000 to settle Federal charges that he made misrepresentations about an investment fund. The Securities and Exchange Commission said Sean P. Brennan, a former vice president for CS First Boston Investment Management Group, distributed misleading marketing materials about the fund, ''willfully'' violating Federal antifraud laws. Mr. Brennan settled the case without admitting or denying the allegations. He was barred from the industry, but has the right to reapply in five years, the S.E.C. said. Neither Mr. Brennan nor his lawyer could be reached for comment.

description: Russian oil production fell 1 percent this year, less than expected, as the ruble's plunge offset low world oil prices and provided producers with cash to maintain output, a Government official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, DR. URSULA
description: STEINBERG-Dr. Ursula. A longtime plastic and reconstructive surgeon in the Plainfield, NJ area died on December 24, 1998, at home with her children by her side. A survivor of Nazi Germany, Dr. Steinberg and her parents escaped in 1933 and found refuge in Holland and then Shanghai, China, before immigrating to the United States in 1949. Dr. Steinberg received her undergraduate degree from Hunter College in 1952 and her medical degree from Women's Medical College of Pennsylvania in 1956. In 1962, she completed her general surgery and plastic surgery training at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, NY. An avid skier, hiker and marathon runner, Ursula is survived by her loving daughter Vivian J. Steinberg and son Gregory Steinberg, his wife Kristin Koe and their two sons Joshua and Jacob Steinberg, and her ex-husband Nathan Steinberg. In lieu of flowers the family request donations be made to the Muhlenberg Foundation, Park Avenue and Randolph Road, Plainfield, New Jersey 07060 in her memory. Funeral services will be held Sunday at 12 noon at the Higgins Home for Funerals, 461 Somerset Street, North Plainfield, New Jersey. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

Along with speed-metal and gangsta rap, it was one of music's dystopian reactions to the Reagan years, a way to confront a feeling of powerlessness in the face of malevolent forces.

title: A New Year for Campaign Reform
description: In this holiday season, Americans are feeling anything but festive about their politics. But the raging debate over President Clinton is only one factor in the public's growing alienation from a system more attuned to partisan tactics than the general good. A separate blow to public faith has arisen recently, with the virtual nullification of nearly a century of laws seeking to curb campaign fund-raising. Last summer, the House passed campaign finance reform legislation, only to see it die in the Senate. As a result, the nation's two biggest political parties have completed their transformation from representing popular constituencies to serving as fund-raising machines that cater to special interests.

title: Our Moments Have All Been Seized

And maybe it has to do with the end of our millennium fast approaching, and the profound implication that someone else's millennium is beginning. But whatever the reason, now -- by which I mean our experience of the present moment, that ever-passing, uncertain platform upon which we recognize ourselves to be alive, and appraise how life seems -- that now feels under attack. Wittgenstein wrote that he who lives in the present lives in eternity. But I'm sure he didn't have in mind a present (or an eternity) like this one.

And Edmund Clerihew Bentley (1875-1956), who was famous as the author of ''Trent's Last Case,'' gave his middle name to a ragged little verse form that came into being, it is said, during a chemistry class the young Bentley was attending at St. Paul's School:

title: Missing Mastroianni: Why He Meant So Much
description: MARCELLO MASTROIANNI seemed to grow weary of the world long before the world grew weary of him. How else can one explain why his death in 1996 at the age of 72 was not just an irreplaceable loss to movie lovers, but seemed shockingly premature? He'd played older than he was for so long -- this existential Everyman of modern European cinema, whose career spanned five decades -- that when he finally took off the old age makeup he outwitted mortality by seeming younger than he actually was. And then, his gracefully slouching figure, a favorite alter ego for directors as disparate as Fellini and Angelopoulos, had inhabited so many valedictory films that we couldn't believe it when, in his last film, Manoel de Oliveira's ''Voyage to the Beginning of the World'' (1997), he actually said goodbye. Playing an aging director returning to the scenes of his youth, Mastroianni's face was lined, his body ravaged from the pancreatic cancer that would take his life, but he had looked much older 15 years before. In Ettore Scola's ''La Nuit de Varennes'' (1982), he was only 58 when he played the wistfully geriatric Casanova, powdered and peruked, hunched over a stick as he tried to convince women he was but a shadow, a mere representation, of his former self. As the dancer who comes out of retirement in Fellini's ''Ginger and Fred'' (1986), a robust and graceful 62-year-old Mastroianni plays a befuddled and creaky Pippo, relying on his partner (Giulietta Masina) to keep him in step till he finally topples to the floor. Back as far as 1960, as the genial gossip columnist in Fellini's star-making ''La Dolce Vita,'' he was 36 going on 65 -- a disenchanted observer of the ''scene,'' too jaded to rise to the occasional invitation to become a human being again.

title: Scene on the Street: What It Takes to Get a New York Double Take
description: Shy and soft-spoken? Spend a lot of time looking at your shoes? Steer clear of this city, where a papaya seller wears his politics on his storefront and a grocer won't let even the astronomically ordained length of the day dampen his advertising concept. Turning the common into the quirky can also earn a New York double take; an artist turns a street into a baseball diamond, and passers-by suddenly morph into Paul O'Neill rounding first even as they scurry to the A train or the analyst. But New York is so jammed that oddities happen -- like the macabre juxtaposition of a funeral home and an ad for Combat. And yes, even New Yorkers get tired of making noise and scenes. Yet when they do they still manage to keep their brass. A young man wants to share his love of Italian movies? No problem. Rent some films, prop a projector on a garbage can, run an extension cord to a lamppost and, voila, ''Cinema Under the Stars.'' FRANCIS FLAHERTY

title: Sex, Lies and Videotape, Videotape, Videotape
description: 1. THE BILL CLINTON SHOW -- No fictional drama could possibly compete. During the first Presidential impeachment of the 20th century, television became more than the playing field; it was an active participant, as the voracious 24-hour news channels pushed the story along. Think of how powerfully Bill Clinton's sex-and-lies scandal was molded by these endlessly replayed images: Monica Lewinsky, in her black beret, standing in a rope line to greet the President; Mr. Clinton wagging his finger at the public and saying words we now know by heart: ''I did not have sexual relations with that woman, Miss Lewinsky.'' In September, for four straight hours television viewers watched the videotape of the President's testimony before the grand jury (in polls, his approval ratings rose); last week, audiences were the witnesses as the House of Representatives voted to impeach him (in polls, his approval ratings rose). We have lost count of his televised apologies. The scandal highlighted the Jekyll and Hyde nature of the 24-hour news channels: the influential CNN and MSNBC and the tag-along Fox News Channel. At their best, they offered a comprehensive yet intimate view of the Clinton Presidency in the process of unraveling; in their tackiest moments, they became the Psychic Friends Network of politics, with blather like ''What is Hillary feeling?'' Yet their incessant talk and presence continue to define this unimaginable historical drama. Next to the impeachment, even the green-glowing night images of missiles landing in Baghdad seemed familiar.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Masters of the Universe
description: Infants, as the French ethnologist Alain Epelboin observes in the preface to BABIES CELEBRATED (Abrams, $39.95), are the ''tyrant-kings'' of most cultures, and some 200 color photographs in this glossy volume prove his point well. With the guidance of 16 cultural anthropologists, the authors, Beatrice Fontanel and Claire d'Harcourt, explore -- in words and in photographs collected from numerous sources -- the many ways that anxious parents around the world clothe, feed, soothe, transport, bathe and otherwise protect and placate the fussiest members of their societies. Readers will find no end of exotic traditions: diapers made of yak hair and camel dung, the smoke ''baths'' given to Australian aborigine babies, the smearing of soot and yak butter on the infant's fontanel in Tibet. Here, too, are the elaborate predecessors of the Snugli: fur-lined in Siberia, beaded in Senegal, gorgeously embroidered in Guizhou, China. The authors note that a pervading concern in these societies, as in our own, is the fragility of small children. In many parts of South America, Africa and Asia, where infant mortality is high, babies are viewed as ''vagabond souls'' who may, at any moment, wander out the door of earthly life. Hence, in Burkina Faso, Vietnam, Yemen and elsewhere, necklaces, bracelets and cords are strung around a baby's body as a means of tying the child to life. Some readers, particularly parents, may find practicality behind the symbolism -- the bright red pompoms adorning the headgear of Yao babies in Thailand, for example, may attract good fortune but also serve as effective head bumpers. Coins, beads and shells dangling from baby carriers and clothing, used to ward off evil in many cultures, provide a comforting distraction as well. Suzanne MacNeille

The Warner Brothers Studio Stores are selling ''Wizard of Oz'' merchandise, which includes a pillbox with an enamel portrait of Judy Garland as Dorothy ($10). title: Start Amaryllis Bulbs, Protect Plants
description: It is not too late to start amaryllis bulbs for late winter bloom. Choose large bulbs and plant in rich potting soil with one-third to one-half of the bulb above the soil. Keep soil damp but not wet, and move to a bright window as soon as growth appears. Temperatures of 55 to 60 degrees will produce the strongest flower stalks. When blooming is complete, cut back the flower stalk to its base, and leave the plant in a sunny window until it can be planted out in spring.

title: Heart of Modern Art, Pollock, Beats Loudest
description: 1. JACKSON POLLOCK -- It's possible to second-guess this show at the Museum of Modern Art -- to question, say, whether the classic years are too tendentious or the last pictures, like ''Blue Poles,'' are shortchanged. But great exhibitions are supposed to make you think twice. This is a landmark survey of a painter whose value, which remains difficult for many people to grasp, goes to the heart of what makes modern art modern. Art exhibitions don't usually have the dramatic pace of theater, but this one does. The climax comes with the big drip paintings, when the size of the gallery expands to match the scale of the pictures and the effect is a little like arriving at a precipice: as the space opens up, one has a sense of being on the edge of something amazing. Because it's as cogent and beautiful as it is, the show (organized by Kirk Varnedoe and Pepe Karmel, on view until Feb. 2) ought to convert Pollock skeptics.

title: PULSE: Family History And Chronicles of the 21st Century; Bound Time Capsule
description: The turn of the century calls for more than a flimsy plastic album of Kodak moments. Barneys New York is offering the ultimate family scrapbook, impressively titled ''The Family History and Chronicle of the 21st Century,'' but more commonly called ''The Millennium Book'' by Barneys. This encyclopedia-weight volume is hand-bound in durable English goat skin, made from acid-free materials and designed to last forever, barring flood or fire -- and provided that customers can get their hands on one. The $165 book, which includes sections to enter family history, traditions, genealogical information, important dates, trends, even prices of consumer items, has sold out three times since November. ''Genealogy is hot,'' said Eric Foner, the DeWitt Clinton Professor of History at Columbia University. ''The end of the century may be exaggerating that trend.'' Steven Spielberg was recently seen buying five of them. Maybe his next movie will be called ''Saving Private Moments.'' ELLEN TIEN

title: When Tougher Standards Have a Negative Effect

I have three children in three different public schools -- elementary, middle and high school. This year in response to the new requirements, all three of them are showing worrisome signs of stress. They all work long and hard and for the most part they are doing very well academically, but I wonder at what cost.

title: A Enduring Commitment To Latin American Art
description: MEASURED in miles, the distance between the house where Benjamin Ortiz grew up and the place where he works, the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport, could be called negligible. But in terms of accomplishment, he has traveled far. Mr. Ortiz attended public schools in the city and then Housatonic Community-Technical College, working, while still in school, at the Barnum Museum. Now he is in his third year as the Discovery's curator of art and collections -- a rare example, in our transient society, of a local boy who made good and stayed home.

title: December 20-26; Relief for Angina
description: One injection of an experimental drug directly into the heart through a small incision in the chest has greatly relieved, even eliminated, the chest pain of angina that standard drugs and bypass surgery had failed to control, according to preliminary findings from two continuing studies in the United States and Germany. One drug is gene therapy to produce a protein called vegF, for vascular endothelial growth factor. The other drug is a protein called FGF-1, for fibroblast growth factor.

title: Krishna Couture
description: The prices alone are a religious experience. At Govinda's, a Hare Krishna-owned boutique in West Los Angeles, the seekers are local fashion and film people on a quest for gauzy shirts, long saris and other hot Hindi wear at church-basement prices: $20 for a skirt, $40 for a pashmina scarf. ''It's the new chic place where everyone goes to shop,'' said Jeanne Yang, a fashion stylist. ''There's a spiritual aspect to the clothing that appeals to people. And the soft pastels are in keeping with what designers are showing for spring.'' The incense-scented store on Venice Boulevard opened 15 years ago, but with this year's popularity of swami style, it has become a shopping destination. Sharon Stone bought white cotton separates and shawls, along with saris for upholstering her dining room chairs. Only 20 percent of the customers are affiliated with the Hare Krishnas. ''They're not necessarily into the religion,'' said Tadit Beca, the store manager (right, helping a customer). She joined the Krishna temple 26 years ago. ''I guess they feel the place has good karma.'' Sales have doubled in a year. She makes six expeditions to India a year to stock up. Kate Garner, a Los Angeles-based fashion photographer, whose work has appeared in Harpers Bazaar, W and Spin, bought a gray skirt, meant to be worn under a sari. ''It has a drawstring and a little frill along the bottom,'' she said. ''It looks like it could be Helmut Lang because of the color. And it was only $20. I wear it with a T-shirt and silver Birkenstocks.'' JOANNA BOBER

title: Down and Out in the New Russia: The City; Who the Heck Is Buck Wiley and Why Is He Leaving?
description: Two years ago, my little brother opened the first American-style health club in Russia. Jake was 25 when the billboard was hoisted over eight lanes of traffic on Leningradsky Prospekt, renovations were completed on a vast space in Lenin's crumbling Palace of Young Pioneers and Gold's Gym Moscow flung open its glinting glass doors on Thanksgiving Day. His gym was described in Business Week and Forbes. He was profiled in The Wall Street Journal. Jake and his two 31-year-old partners -- Paul Kuebler, a former Arthur Andersen accountant from California, and Vladimir Grumlik, a Russian fitness enthusiast and entrepreneur -- had raised enough money from private investors to fill the hangar-size arena with an army of Stairmasters and treadmills, as well as massage rooms, saunas, solaria and a beauty salon. Two bars poured cappuccinos and bodybuilding drinks, a cafe served burritos and chicken-breast salads and past the aerobics studio and squash area were tennis courts of imitation grass and a basketball floor built by Nike. At the grand-opening ceremonies, nearly 2,000 members and sightseers ogled the pec decks and bench presses, egged on by live Russian rock bands, Moscow Circus acts and an exhibition of dunks and three-pointers by the former Red Army basketball team. Meanwhile, Jake and his partners strode among the revelers in freshly pressed tuxedoes, dazed at the magnitude of what could suddenly be done in the former Soviet Union.

title: Pedal Pumpers
description: Bicycles haven't really changed much in 150 years or so, despite periodic claims of revolutionary developments. Essentially, the rider cranks the pedals in a circle, and that makes the wheels go around. Now, Byung Yim of TRB Systems in Livingston is offering what might be called an anti-revolutionary change: he has developed a bike whose pedals go up and down instead of around. Mr. Yim, who previously made golf accessories, says the pumping motion mimics walking or jogging, which is easier on the legs and back -- an appeal to aging baby-boomers -- and is more efficient at transferring power to the bike. The bikes began appearing in television infomercials a few weeks ago. They start at $450 for a child's bike, which can be adjusted to work the traditional way as well, up to $599 for an adult's mountain bike. The bikes are not sold in stores but are available from TRB at (888) 872-2200 or from the company's Web site, http://www.trbsystems.com.

title: Kansas City: Refining a Midwest Cuisine
description: DESPITE what you may have heard, you don't have to be a barbecue fanatic to eat well in Kansas City. True, residents are justly proud of their world-class barbecue joints and steakhouses, and many a meal involves mashed potatoes, biscuits and gravy. But possibilities extend into more sophisticated realms. The already lively dining scene in this prosperous metropolis has been energized by the brand-new Lidia's, an ambitious restaurant with roots in New York and Trieste. Storefront ethnic restaurants are popping up everywhere, but what's most notable is how well the new American style of cooking stands up to more famous American restaurants on either coast. Kansas City chefs defer to no one in refining local styles while seeking out the best regional farm products as well as ingredients flown in from around the world. Even the toniest places, however, shun nouvellishly small portions for Midwestern largesse.

title: 'Nyah, Nyah -- Gotcha!'
description: This space has been hijacked this week by the Gotcha! Gang, a growing legion of readers who take preternatural delight in exposing the grammatical errors of the resident columnist. Their motto: ''No Haven for the Maven.'' (Excuse me; its motto.)

title: New Political Party
description: A new political party in Scarsdale is challenging the village's long-standing one-party system. Les Levin, former national director of community planning for the Council of Jewish Federations in Manhattan, a nonprofit organization, is leading the effort to form the Scarsdale Democracy Project, a nonpartisan party, which will hold an open primary in January for registered voters.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: AT the top of this week's movie menu are worthy adaptations of two Broadway musicals, a fine political drama and a memorable account of wartime heroism.

title: That Certain Sparkle
description: Outside California, the nation's single best sparkling wine is made in, yes, Albuquerque, N.M. For 11 vintages, Gruet, the American branch of Gilbert Gruet & Fils, a small French Champagne house, has symbolized class. A best buy is Gruet nonvintage brut, sold for $11 at Heights Chateau, at 131 Atlantic Avenue (near Henry Street) in Brooklyn. Dry, feathery light, sleek, creamy and featuring a long aftertaste, it is one smart New Year's aperitif.

title: The Nation: Curves Ahead; Escalating Speed Limits From Fast to Faster
description: LONG after Americans stopped husbanding gasoline and keeping the speedometer at 55, policy makers here clung to a national maximum speed limit, arguing that it saved lives. But that limit, an artifact of the 1973 Arab oil embargo that was very unpopular after the price of gasoline dropped, was eliminated three years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGGERT, JOSEPH R.

He is survived by his five children, Hester Weeden, Amanda Stukenberg, Joseph Eggert, Elizabeth Eggert, Edward Eggert; his five grandchildren; his sister Amanda Colton, and Rita McGovern. title: Strip Steaks
description: The New York, New York casino hotel in Las Vegas features numerous Manhattan architectural icons on its exterior. Now, there's another famous facade from New York just across the street: the green-and-white turn-of-the-century exterior of the Smith & Wollensky steakhouse.

title: Into the Breach
description: BIG corporations dominate the New York skyline with their swaggering processions of office towers. For most New Yorkers, however, it is the smaller companies that define the city's styles and rhythms. This is a town packed tight with people who have the money and the attitude to demand special goods and services, and with entrepreneurs more than happy to indulge them.

title: Down and Out in the New Russia: The Countryside; How Do You Succeed in A Cashless Society?
description: The derevnya, a word that embraces both village and countryside, carries almost mystical connotations for Russians. Most still have roots in some remote cluster of listing log houses, where perhaps an aged mother lives, her hands and face deeply etched by the endless struggle against the frigid land. It is here, in the timeless landscape of snow, birches and golden cupolas, that Russia most fully reveals its paradoxical blend of squalor and science, mud and music. Whether under czars, Bolsheviks or reformers, the derevnya has always been the last line of defense against ideologies, invaders, chaos and hunger.

title: Restless
description: It's around 2 o'clock on Halloween morning, four hours outside of Cleveland on Interstate 80, and Sean Penn, who is behind the wheel of a rented Olds 88, is saying what he has been saying for days, weeks, years. ''This is it,'' he says. ''I'm not going to act in movies again.'' In Hollywood, which is the place where he has said this the most, it is understood less as an announcement of a retirement he never quite sticks to than as a frequently repeated existential declaration of his unhappiness with the movie business and the films it makes now. Jack Nicholson, a close friend of Penn's, says: ''He won't quit. But let him whirl around, saying he's quitting. Sean is brilliant, but, of course, we know that's no solace for anybody.'' Warren Beatty, another close friend, says: ''He's not going to give up acting. What Sean means is that he would like to give up the thought of making the brand of picture that opens big on a Friday night.'' Many in Hollywood also understand that Penn -- who, for all his world-weariness, is only 38 -- may be the best actor of his generation, and also the most influential, a role model for the likes of Matt Damon and Edward Norton. And for all his talk of quitting he has been very busy this year, with roles in two new movies -- ''Hurlyburly,'' a dark drama about the male psyche, based on a play by David Rabe, and ''The Thin Red Line,'' the much-heralded return of the director Terrence Malick, whose last movie was ''Days of Heaven,'' in 1978. Penn is also starring in a Woody Allen movie now being completed in and around New York, a period piece in which Penn plays a jazz guitarist. Penn, who has never played the guitar, learned the fingering for 30 songs in two months. ''I have these nightmares,'' he says, lighting an American Spirit cigarette somewhere in Pennsylvania in the middle of the night. ''I'm trying to play a solo and my fingers can't find the strings.''

title: MASS MILLENNIAL MOVEMENT
description: MILLENNIUM mania has taken a steely grip on the fancies of men and women whose usual idea of ushering in a new year is to share a good bottle of wine at home with family members and a few close friends and struggle to keep awake until midnight.

title: Rome is preparing for a holy year filled with Papal pageantry and perhaps more tourists than the city has ever seen
description: BENEATH the soaring porch of St. Peter's Basilica, toward the right, is the towering bronze Holy Door, surmounted by inscriptions in Latin and Greek. Striking the door three times with a ceremonial hammer next Christmas Eve, Pope John Paul II, clad in white and gold vestments, will usher in a millennial Holy Year that will last until early 2001.

title: Victorian Violence: The Hard-Boiled Charles Dickens
description: LET'S see, it's got bloated corpses floating in the river, a savage killing on the waterfront and an eerie visit to the city morgue, where the body of a murder victim lies ''in an advanced state of decay.'' There are also lurid incidents of sexual stalking, child abuse, criminal conspiracy, extortion, fraud and theft. Not to mention a missing will, a disappearing heir, a relentless police inspector and bizarre villains who ply their shady trade in an atmosphere thick with moral decay and social corruption.

title: A New Thing in Gambits Undergoes Early Testing
description: The ancient pawn sacrifices for attack -- the King's Gambit, the Queen's Gambit, the Budapest Gambit, for example -- occur mostly on the second move of the game, the earliest point at which one could make such an offer. But nowadays the Dilworth Gambit is played on the 11th move, the Mackenzie Gambit on the 16th move and several nameless gambits in the King's Indian Defense in the middle game. It is getting harder and harder to invent a new gambit early in the play. Almost everything has been worked over.

title: Grading On the Curve
description: SPORT utilities or sports cars? I'll take the latter, though today's four-wheel rockets are so good that roads in the Northeast -- with low speed limits, radar traps and darting deer -- cannot really test their capabilities. But even when driven mildly, new Porsches and BMW's stood out, as did more practical, less pricey machines.

title: Preparing the Versatile Cod, a Kind of Chicken of the Sea
description: WHEN I was growing up in England, cod was a dish for invalids or schoolchildren. It was also popular deep fried, wrapped in newspaper, and served with chips and a splash of malt vinegar to cut the grease. You certainly did not see it often on the menus of fancy restaurants. But since then chefs have become increasingly inventive with this fish. It is extremely versatile, with large, firm flakes, keeps its texture well and goes with almost as many different types of seasonings as chicken. (At this time of year, the quality is particularly good, too.)

A new study by Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a management consulting firm in Bethesda, Md., found that those companies that grant the largest number of stock options substantially underperformed their stingier peers.

But the more remarkable news in language circles may really be that millions of American teen-agers continue to study French, despite -- and let's be gentle about this -- the fading significance of France and the French language.

title: Those Blue M & M's Were Just the Beginning
description: As we hurtle headlong into a new year and draw that much closer to a new millennium, it's probably better if we don't all clash. The Color Marketing Group, an international association of 1,500 color designers from all manner of consumer and commercial industries, expects that the hottest colors in consumer products this year will be shades of blue -- blue moon, blue planet and Cancun Blue, to be exact -- partly because of a rising demand for nature-based colors. According to the group's news release, ''cooler, lighter product colors'' reflect ''the positive attitudes generated by the strong U.S. economy.''

title: Fighting for Jacob

Now it appears they may be able to recoup their expenses through a medical malpractice suit. If I had their money and their son, perhaps I would do the same. But that wouldn't make it right.

title: December 20-26; Balloonists' Saga
description: Christmas found three of the world's greatest balloonists down in the Pacific Ocean, half way to their goal of circling the Earth non-stop. In at least 22 previous attempts at global circumnavigation, no balloonist had ever come this close to success. The 160-foot-high ICO Global Challenge ended its voyage when it hit a low-pressure system over the ocean. Still, its crew -- Richard Branson, Per Lindstrand and Steve Fossett -- will be accorded a special place in ballooning archives. They managed not only to avoid all the countries where hostile governments would have forced them down but fought their way through storms, uncooperative winds and exhaustion. ''I am sorry to have let people down,'' Mr. Branson said, speaking to his London headquarters. MALCOLM W. BROWNE

For a very pleasant side trip, I would add the Anzo-Borrego Desert State Park. It is a gem, and there are wonderful views of the Salton Sea on the way there and back.

''It will be a real shame,'' said Mr. Windsor, head of retail operations at Thomas Cook, the British travel services company, to see venerable European currencies like the French franc, the Spanish peseta and the Italian lira just disappear. Travelers, he said, ''see using foreign notes and coins as an exciting and integral part of their holidays.''

In her first days as the new director of the Connecticut State Museum of Natural History at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, museum staff and science department colleagues observed her as television and print reporters from around the world recorded and analyzed the most high-profile scientific discovery of her career.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Strains of Occupation
description: First published in France in 1986 as ''Le Pierrot Noir,'' Roger Grenier's spare and elegant novel, ANOTHER NOVEMBER (University of Nebraska, cloth, $40; paper, $12 ), is a meditation on personal and political loyalties. The unnamed narrator reminisces about Pau, in southwestern France, where he and his friends grew up at the time of the Spanish Civil War. When World War II comes to France, the stresses of the Occupation bring out the essential characteristics of each individual, particularly those of Charles Merlin, the richest boy in town and the most spoiled. Charles's collaboration with the Nazis is not so much an ethical collapse as a confirmation that morals are as nothing to him when measured against his personal comfort. In contrast, the narrator performs admirably in the Resistance (as did Grenier in real life), but his heroism is related in an offhand manner, as if it were not a choice but something inevitable -- ''It wasn't much.'' Seamlessly translated by Alice Kaplan, the novel is built around the recurring image of a carousel at the St. Martin's fair, which comes to town every November. Among its other attractions are a Pierrot figure who wears black silk instead of the star-struck lover's lunar white and, conversely, a boat ride with gondolas that are painted white rather than the jet black of the Venetian originals. These devices suggest that life is not what it seems; yet the melancholy tone of ''Another November'' appears to exist not because a thing can prove to be its opposite but because in the end there are no surprises. William Ferguson

title: Apocalypse Now. No, Really. Now!
description: With 1999 almost on us and the year 2000 starting to awaken, growl and plod fatefully toward the camera lens, you can count on 12 months of panicky millennial excitements. The personnel are certainly out there, ready to go. According to a 1997 Associated Press poll, nearly 1 in 4 adult Christians -- upward of 26 million people -- expect Christ to return in their lifetimes, fulfilling the complicated End Times scenario that many people glean from prophetic Bible texts like Revelation and Daniel. The Christians are joined by lesser but impressive numbers of apocalyptic others, with their own scripts of doom and redemption. Ted Daniels, a folklorist in Philadelphia whose Millennium Watch Institute has monitored millennial activity for years, says that his database alone holds the names of more than 1,200 self-proclaimed prophets.

Rehnquist is an anomaly: a powerful man whose public image is so fuzzy he can walk the halls and grounds of the Supreme Court, where he has served for 27 years, without attracting a tourist's second glance.

title: STYLE; Great Scot
description: Who better to wring out the old year and ring in one-triple-nine than a Scotsman who can belt out a lascivious rendition of ''Auld Lang Syne?'' Scottish men, you see, were the first modern cross-dressers, and as they invented whisky too, they're the perfect party animals. Which brings us to Alan Cumming, native of Dundee and emcee of the Broadway show ''Cabaret.'' Cumming afforded 1998 its juiciest mix of allure and sleaze; the evils of pleasure, and vice versa. He simply put on his makeup, glitter and fish net and prowled around the fringes of erotica with such satyric gusto it was hard to believe it was strictly show-biz.

description: IN five days, one Westchester community will lay claim to the first baby of the New Year. But for 40 consecutive years, beginning in 1910, that boasting right belonged to New Rochelle. There, in a palatial estate on Mount Tom Road, in the southern part of the city, not only the county's, but the country's, official New Year's baby was born -- usually sometime in September.

title: Easy to Pack, Harder to Understand
description: ISSEY MIYAKEISSEY MIYAKE is easy to pack. This is often the first thing a smart woman will tell you when you ask her why she wears Miyake's clothes. You can roll his dresses into a ball, they take up practically no room in your luggage, they weigh almost nothing, and when you arrive at your destination you just unroll and wear them. You can brown bag it around the world.

title: In Kente's Dancing Colors, Signs of Pride and Identity
description: KENTE cloth's iconic powers are both considerable and quite possibly singular. For centuries, Asante and Ewe royalty in Ghana have worn gloriously colored kente of fine silk on state occasions. The garments have lent a grandeur to the festivities, and more important, they have been a means for chieftains to proclaim their authority and wealth. Small wonder that kente has become an almost universal totem of black identity.

title: Tents at Taliesin West
description: To design better buildings, Frank Lloyd Wright believed that his apprentices should experience the environment first-hand. So apprentices at his Taliesin West studios in Scottsdale, Ariz., have lived in tents that they can customize according to their own talents. Now, those dwellings are open for tours as part of a visit to Taliesin West. The shelter tour is offered on Saturday at 1:15 P.M. through April 15. It costs $25 a person and reservations are suggested. Other tours are offered daily. For information, call (602) 860-2700.

title: And Off To Market They Go
description: For some city people, a distinctly rural look has become a tradition for Saturday morning shopping at the Union Square Greenmarket. This month, the Greenmarket is especially festive, as dedicated shoppers prepare for the holidays, ready to fill wicker-basket backpacks to the rim. Among the temptations are fresh vegetables, fruits, cheeses, chicken potpies and milk in bottles. A duck was also on the premises the other day, being serenaded by a violinist; but he is the pet of the man following him and was not for sale. The scene included cabbage roses, paperwhites, and one woman wearing a medieval-style jester's hat. Another wore an Indian-pattern poncho. The market stays open through the winter but quiets down after New Year, coming to life again with the spring's first blooms.
