title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOYDA, LOUIS ANDREW
description: HOYDA-Louis Andrew, of Fairfield, CT and Chatham, MA passed away on December 22, 1998 at the age of 66. He was born February 7, 1932, a single child of Louis and Mary Hoyda and resided in New York City moving to Connecticut in the 1950's. He was a veteran of the United States Army. He graduated from the University of Bridgeport and embarked on a memorable career. Until recently, Lou was a partner of 12 years with Thorndike Deland Associates, an executive search firm in Manhattan. He was a member of the Union League and Williams Clubs and the Black Rock Yacht Club. In addition to his long loved wife of 43 years, Edie, he is survived by his family: Bradford and Christine Hoyda and their daughter Olivia of Darien, CT; Missy and Jackson Smith of Chatham, MA; Christopher Hoyda of Boston, MA., and Amy and Carl Kuehner and their daughter Alexandra (Lexi) of West Norwalk, CT. A memorial service will be held Friday, January 8, 1999 at 1 PM at The First Church Congregational at 148 Beach Road in Fairfield, CT. The family will greet friends at the church prior to the service. A private interment will take place in Chatham, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Bridgeport Hospital Foundation, Urology Equipment Fund, P.O. Box 5000, Bridgeport, CT 06610 or Friends of Chatham Waterways, Box 472, Chatham, MA. 02633.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVKOWITZ, DR. JACK
description: LEVKOWITZ-Dr. Jack. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of its devoted member Helene Levkowitz. May his entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Fear of Fashion: An Art Historian's Battle With Repressed Desire
description: A COUPLE of years back, I was invited to a party for a conceptual artist and decided to dress in theme. Because the artist does the kind of work that leaves most people scratching their heads, I wore a Moschino dress with the neckline appropriately configured as a question mark.

title: Immigrants Find the Island a Mixed Blessing; A Life Looking Over Shoulders In a Land Of Freedom
description: AT first glance, the one-story East Patchogue house where Jose and Rosa Ramos live with their son is the picture-perfect love nest of a young couple pursuing the American dream. But an air of anxiety pervades their $950-a-month rental, which they share with two other relatives. Mr. Ramos is subject to arrest at any time.

title: Color-Blind Audiences
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Smoke Detectors
description: Local 107 of the Uniformed Fire Fighter's Association in Mount Vernon has a holiday gift for residents: a free smoke detector and installation, if needed.

title: Children's Hospital
description: The Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla is planning to break ground this summer for its Children's Hospital and Trauma Center, said Dr. Michael Gewitz, professor of pediatrics at New York Medical College and director of pediatrics at the Medical Center.

title: Public Space, Private Space And Anti-Space
description: 1. KIASMA -- Steven Holl's new museum of contemporary art in Helsinki takes its name from a neurological configuration that links perception and conception. That's a good point of departure for an art museum, and Holl has turned his into a major urban event. He has carved a set of powerfully sensuous galleries within a curving shell that animates what was formerly a dead zone in the Finnish capital's core.

title: Yes, Jaws Dropped, and Hearts Beat Faster
description: 1. LEVINE'S DVORAK -- The year's striking musical moments often came during events ostensibly about other things. James Levine's Met Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall in mid-November advertised Milton Babbitt's new piano concerto, but it was a performance of Dvorak's G major Symphony that made the jaw drop and the heart beat faster. Here was a locus of points: the sophistication of a big-time orchestra, the dead-on contact with late 19th-century style, and a simple sympathy with the dancing and singing of rural Central Europe.

title: Different Worlds
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Shows That Have Outlived the Fruit Fly
description: Remember ''The Brian Benben Show,'' the sitcom about a disgruntled demoted television newsman? Of course you don't. CBS killed it in October, about a minute and a half into the season. It was about the same time that Fox pulled the plug on ''Costello,'' its new comedy about a tough-talking Boston barmaid. Other new series met the same fate or just went ''on hiatus.'' (Right. Like ''Brooklyn Bridge,'' which CBS put on hiatus in 1992.)

title: The Catbird Seat
description: Birnbaum ends his article with a pecking order of disabilities. Might I add that courtesy trumps discourtesy?

title: A Common-Sense Mezzo And Star in the Making
description: IN an era when charm is a virtue too much lacking in the arts, it is no wonder that the Austrian mezzo-soprano Angelika Kirchschlager has caused heads to turn. She is, after all, a beguiling presence. With her sparkling persona and fresh good looks, she has delighted audiences throughout Europe and the United States. Yet her success stems from more than just beauty and breeding. She is a singer with the right stuff: a sumptuous, rather light-toned voice, which she uses intelligently and judiciously.

title: A First Night, but Not a Last
description: This year, 14 communities in New Jersey are celebrating New Year's Eve with First Night, an alcohol-free arts festival. As in the past, the festivities offer something for everyone, including music, dance, theater, art, circuses, poetry, comedy, petting zoos, fireworks, ice skating, face painting, henna hand painting -- get the point?

title: From Street Dance To Classical Ballet To Broadway
description: IN an advertisement now running for ''Fosse: A Celebration in Dance,'' the ballet and modern dancer Desmond Richardson stands in profile, his hands on his hips, a bowler perched at a raffish angle on his head. One leg is straight and the other bent. He wears ballet slippers. Sheathed only in tights and a vest, his remarkably muscular body looks sculptured. In the show (now in previews at the Broadhurst Theater, where it opens Jan. 14), he assumes this pose in ''Mr. Bojangles,'' a tender tribute to dancers past their prime.

title: 2 Key Aides Of Pol Pot Said to Emerge From Hiding
description: Two of the last three longtime aides of the late Khmer Rouge leader, Pol Pot, have given up the fight and emerged from their jungle hideouts in the hope of becoming ''ordinary citizens,'' the Government announced today.

title: War Stories, on the Beach and in the Home
description: 1. 'SAVING PRIVATE RYAN' -- Steven Spielberg took the enormous risk of recreating the experience of World War II combat and reminding contemporary audiences of all the patriotism, shock and horrific sacrifice that it entailed. And in a film year otherwise devoted to the darkest visions of American life, he touched a long-buried, fundamental nerve. This wrenchingly visceral war epic was also a bravura visual achievement, with the swiftness and economy of its storytelling and the terrifying, furious immediacy of its battles. Audiences were rightly stunned by so fierce and meaningful a re-examination of the American character under fire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, YEHUDI A.
description: COHEN-Yehudi A. On December 17, 1998. Died peacefully at home after long illness. He was Professor Emeritus of Anthropology at Rutgers University. He is survived by his daughter, Lisa Peet, grandson, Gideon Peet, and sister, Hadassah Gordis. He will be missed as well by his friends, colleagues and former students.

title: December 20-26; Catching a Smuggler
description: A subsidiary of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation pleaded guilty to Federal criminal charges and admitted that it had helped a smuggling ring funnel millions of cigarettes into Canada in the mid-1990's. The guilty plea, by RJR's Northern Brands International unit, marked the first time that a tobacco company had been convicted of complicity in the shadowy world of international cigarette smuggling. Prosecutors said the smuggling helped the company get around high Canadian taxes meant to discourage cigarette smoking, and critics said the conviction could undercut the industry's efforts to block an increase in cigarette taxes in the United States. CHRISTOPHER DREW

title: Minds at Stake
description: To the Editor:

title: Impeachment Puts Spotlight on 'Guardian' of the Senate
description: Amid the roiling confusion over how the impeachment drama in the Senate will end, there is for some in the capital a consoling certainty: Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia will be at hand to press the Senate to act with an eye to upholding its dignity before history.

title: Corrections
description: A contents entry in the Book Review today places ''Shaking a Leg: Collected Writings,'' by Angela Carter, in the wrong category. The book is nonfiction.

title: A Bittersweet Relationship With Herself; Bravely, Yet Wistfully, Facing Life After Surgery and Stares
description: IN June, when the day comes, Laura King will stand in the lobby of New York University Medical Center, her nerves on fire, and watch the white stretch limousine glide to a stop. After 16 years of waiting, Laura has imagined every moment of the day when she will leave the hospital one last time. After 14 operations and more than 75 hours under the scalpel, the wait will be over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, DR. SONDRA
description: WEINER-Dr. Sondra. Beloved and devoted wife of Dr. Melvyn. Beloved and devoted mother of Bruce (Susan), Dr. Robert (Andrea), Dr. William (Lois), Dr. Nancy Tice (Dr. Harold). Grandmother of Elizabeth, Daniel, Stephanie, Rachel, Rosie, Ashley and Erica Weiner and Benjamin and Hannah Tice. Services Sunday, 2 PM, at Boulevard-Riverside, Hewlett, 516-295-3100. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Some Hair Is Happy to Be Nappy
description: AFTER Noliwe Rooks's grandmother suffered a stroke in church, the family gathered around her in the hospital, worried that she might not recover. Ms. Rooks had not seen her aged grandmother in almost a year, and she leaned close to whisper encouragement.

title: Liberties; Talk Lang Syne
description: When it comes to New Year's Eve, I am firmly in the camp of pink champagne and black cha-cha heels.

title: A Titan Passes; Provocations Abound
description: 1. JEROME ROBBINS -- Among the titans, Robbins was arguably the most original of choreographers. He regarded the New York City Ballet as a continuing experiment, and his death in July robs the company of a major creative voice that influenced its profile for 50 years. Along with Michel Fokine, George Balanchine, Antony Tudor and Frederick Ashton, Robbins was one of the 20th century's greatest ballet choreographers; he was not just the greatest American-born ballet choreographer. Nonetheless, he was American and his genius distilled the mood of his times, no matter how obliquely. His achievement on Broadway was brilliant, but his most profound commitment was to ballet. Robbins's gift was for the startling image with the ring of truth.

title: Fighting for Jacob
description: When life-endangering diseases threaten their children, parents will embrace any morsel of hope. Today, however, we hang tenuously from the thread that connects ''hope'' and ''science.'' Research into the human genome moves forward and will succeed, but those who are in need cannot wait. Winerip's article poignantly portrays Richard and Jordana Sontag's devotion to protecting their child and Dr. Margretta Seashore's professional commitment to this same value.

title: The Threat of Germ Weapons Is Rising. Fear, Too.
description: AMERICAN troops in the Persian Gulf are vaccinated against deadly germs. So are Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who are probing a growing number of biological incidents. So are some White House officials.

title: A Fanfare For the Vanities Of 1998
description: SIMPLY living through 1998 proved quite a learning experience for many investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON STACKELBERG, ELLEN BIDDLE
description: von STACKELBERG-Ellen Biddle. Of NYC (born 1912), Salisbury, CT, as well as 15 years in Germany, died peacefully in her home of 38 years in Albany, VT. Ellen, youngest of three children of Nicholas Biddle and Elizabeth Leroy Emmet, will be deeply and sadly missed by her children Olaf Patrick, Elizabeth Emmet, John Roderich and Nicholas Temple, her twelve surviving grandchildren, two great-grandchildren, and her eight nieces and nephews. Services Albany, VT, January 2, 1999, at 2 PM.

title: December 20-26; A Standoff Over Bananas
description: A tip to holiday party-givers: If you are planning on serving pecorino Romano cheese, stock up now. Same thing goes for those who just can't make it through the next few months without another gold-nibbed Mont Blanc pen.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Grown Up All Wrong

title: It's Never Too Early for the Millennium
description: WITH its multitude of million-dollar mansions dating from the 1920's and 30's and with the Gilded Age that they evoke -- not to mention the plenitude of old money in town -- Greenwich in many respects projects the image of a community where time has been standing still for a long, long while.

title: The View From/White Plains; Aging That Brings Honor to Those Who Grace Others' Lives
description: THE numbers themselves and the conclusions they invite are inescapable: if you are, say, 85, no matter how good your physical and mental condition, you will probably not live more than another decade at best. Aging brings with it a variety of indignities, from minor to dreadful, but for many, the most devastating of all is the inevitable march of time toward death.

title: Who Needs Christmas Gifts?
description: BY the day before Christmas, I'd bought hardly any presents. I admit that this was nothing new. I've never been a good shopper, especially on demand. But this year for the first time I could put my shopping failings in perspective and even feel a touch of serenity right up to the final hour.

title: Ms. Temkin, Dr. Hendrickson
description: Ann Temkin and Dr. Wayne A. Hendrickson are to be married today in Torrington, Conn., at the home of the bride's mother, Joann Temkin. Rabbi Jo David is to officiate.

title: Forget the Movie. Listen to the CD.
description: IT'S unlikely that the movie ''City of Angels'' will be celebrated at any of the forthcoming Hollywood awards programs. The movie, a remake of Wim Wenders's 1988 film, ''Wings of Desire,'' stars Nicholas Cage and Meg Ryan, opened on April 10 to bland reviews and grossed a respectable $55 million. Then, as all films that fail to endear themselves to critics and vast crowds, it was shoved aside by a new crop of movies. By late June, it could no longer be found in theaters.

title: HOCKEY; Nedved Helps Rangers Charge Past Carolina
description: Just when it appeared the Rangers were about to duplicate their pre-Christmas frustrations against the Carolina Hurricanes at Greensboro Coliseum tonight, Petr Nedved broke between two defenders and scored.

title: Celebrating in Norwalk
description: As more communities across Connecticut hold First Night celebrations, Norwalk will mark its fifth First Night on Thursday, beginning at 1 P.M. with an afternoon of children's entertainment and workshops. The final event is a three-hour party ending at midnight at the restored Victorian South Norwalk railroad station.

title: Slower Days for Value Stocks
description: If it seems as if your value stocks are spinning their wheels, it probably isn't a reflection of your stock-picking prowess. Last month, the difference in 12-month performance between the S.& P./Barra Value and S.& P./Barra Growth indexes was the largest in 11 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLIFKIN, SAMUEL
description: SLIFKIN-Samuel. The Yeshiva University Museum family extends its sincerest condolences to Lois Brandt, Director of Development, on the passing of her beloved father, Samuel Slifkin. May his memory always be for a blessing. Erica Jesselson, Chairman of the Board Sylvia A. Herskowitz, Director

description: ORRIN EVANS: 'CAPTAIN BLACK'

title: Fever Dreams
description: Charity Stories.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BEYOND THE LIMBO SILENCE

title: Preserving New Music Just Because It's There
description: EXECUTIVES from the major classical-music recording companies often speak about their work with a sense of mission. But it is hard to discern much mission at this time of market glut, as the major labels seem to flail about, desperately trying to figure out what will sell. The glut comes not just from further reduplications of the standard repertory by heavily promoted new performers but also from countless reissues of almost anything, and gimmicky collections like ''The Best of Tchaikovsky'' or ''Ten Tenors in Prayer.''

title: A Town Where Sumo Has Caught On in a Big Way
description: Sumo wrestling, the Japanese sport best known for the girth of its players, has a home in New Jersey at the Judo and Karate Center in Cranford. Yoshisada Yonezuka, who started the martial arts school 32 years ago and his sumo team 7 years ago, says the only other sumo teams in the United States are in Hawaii and Los Angeles. One member of his team, Emmanuel Yarbrough, a native of Rahway, won the 1995 world championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYEROWITZ, JAN
description: MEYEROWITZ-Jan. Composer dies, age 85, in Colmar, France, December 15th, 1998. Known as a humanist of impressive culture, he was a great pianist, conductor, musicologist and composer. A student of von Zemlinsky, Malipiero, Casella, Respighi both in Berlin and Rome, he was afterwards the assistant of Boris Goldovski in Tanglewood (Boston Symphony). He is notably the author of eight operas, two based on texts by Langston Hughes (''The Barrier'' met with great success), and of symphonic and choral works (directed by Dimitri Mitropoulos with the Philharmonic of N.Y.). His loyalty to ''tonality'' characterized him. He was a professor of both Brooklyn College and City College, N.Y. He gave very popular radio lectures in Cologne and Munich in Germany, where he recently received the famous J.W. Stamitz prize. Jan retired in Alsace, France, birthplace of his wife Marguerite, who survives him. She was a professor of French musical diction at the Juilliard School of Lincoln Center.

title: Full of Hot Air
description: You may be next. You may be one of the unsuspecting diners lured into eating the rich, buttery foods you once forswore. Under the seemingly light and foamy facade of frothed soups and sauces lurks a hearty foe -- cream.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHERTY, RANDOLPH
description: DOHERTY-Randolph Jr. age 61 of Mountain Lakes, NJ and Santa Fe, New Mexico, formerly of Englewood, NJ. Died suddenly on December 18, 1998. President of the Benjamin Eastwood Company in Paterson, NJ, he attended Phillips Andover Academy and William College in Massachusetts and the Columbia University School of Business in New York. He is survived by his fiancee, Greta Tibbetts of Ridgewood, NJ & his sister Ruth Doherty Reed of Englewood, NJ. Memorial service Saturday, January 16, 11:00 AM, at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 215 Boulevard, Mountain Lakes, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association, 2550 Route #

title: Early Birds Get The Passports
description: IT'S Dec. 27. Do you know how old your passport is? Or where it is? January, when business is slow at the passport office, is a good time to renew if the passport expires anytime in 1999 and you plan to travel outside the country. Many countries will not admit travelers with passports that have less than six months' validity left.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNSON, MARK ANTHONY
description: BRUNSON-Mark Anthony On December 23, in New York City. Beloved son of Ann Brunson of Mesquite, TX, and Phillip Brunson of Dryden, NY. Loving brother of Bruce Brunson and Allison Weaver. Cherished uncle of Erica Weaver. Also survived by a wide circle of loving and devoted friends. A celebration of his life will be held at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 33 Spring St., NYC, on Tuesday, December 29, at 6 PM. In lieu of flowers, his family would appreciate donations, in memory of Mark, to be made to Miracle House, PO Box 30931, New York, NY 10011-0109, 212-462-8097.

title: Germ Weapons: In Soviet Past Or in the New Russia's Future?

title: Correction
description: A front-page picture caption on Saturday about a political rally in Indonesia misidentified a woman shown gesturing with her right fist aloft. She was a supporter of the opposition leader Megawati Sukarnoputri, not Ms. Megawati herself.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LINDAUER, EDNA STRICH (LEVY)
description: LINDAUER-Edna Strich (Levy). June 17, 1899-December 28, 1963. Always remembered by her son, Eugene; never forgotten by her late daughter, Caryl

title: In Drive on Dissidents, China Gives 4th Severe Sentence in Week
description: Dealing out the fourth lengthy prison term to political dissenters in a week, China today convicted a man for ''providing intelligence to hostile foreign organizations'' because he gave an interview about farmer protests to the United States-financed Radio Free Asia, a human rights group said.

title: Patents; Ringing in the new year with a little assistance from some freshly minted inventions.
description: NEW YEAR'S EVE this year may not mark the beginning of a new millennium, but it is still a big event for lots of people. Anyone planning a celebration may appreciate a little help from inventions that were patented earlier in the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, FLORENCE
description: BERMAN-Florence Resident of NYC almost all her life, she left on Tuesday, December 22, 1998, at age 93. Beloved mother of Gerald Weinstein and loving grandmother of Daniel Weinstein and his wife Anne. She will be missed.

title: 2 Bates Offices Get New Accounts
description: Two offices of Bates USA, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C., have been awarded accounts with combined billings estimated at $13 million to $18 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Merchants and Analysts Predict Solid Holiday Sales

title: Fire in New Rochelle Leaves Families Homeless
description: As many as 50 families may have been left homeless last night as a fire tore through a large apartment building at 21 Fountain Place.

title: TV Guide Investigates A Failed Investigation
description: In a departure from its usual editorial fare, TV Guide -- the coach-potato's weekly bible that is owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation -- is running a four-part, 20,000-word investigative series about CNN and the Tailwind debacle of last summer. It is a far cry from a recent cover story, ''The Spellbinding Witches of Charmed,'' an article about a television program starring Shannen Doherty as a witch.

title: Merwin F. Kaminstein, 63, Retail Executive
description: Merwin F. Kaminstein, a former retail executive, died on Dec. 21 at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. Mr. Kaminstein, a resident of Boston and Bonita Springs, Fla., was 63.

title: An Arts Leader for Whom 'Anything Is Possible'
description: Elma Lewis, 77, tried not working, on orders from her doctors. ''I went down to 98 pounds and almost died when they made me not work,'' she said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHS, MARTIN
description: SACHS-Martin. 71. December 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Rita. Father of Patricia and Candi. Brother of Sylvia Rosenberg. Grandfather of Katharine Schreiber, Benjamin, Jeremy and Cassandra Sachs-Michaels. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to God's Love We Deliver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELBIRT, JACOB
description: ELBIRT-Jacob. The Federation of Wolynian Jews in USA mourns with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved, longtime President. His spirited determination to perpetuate the memory of the Eastern European Jews killed during WW II was instrumental in building the Heichal Yehadut Wolyn-Yad Vashem in Israel which will serve as a place of learning about the Holocaust for generations to come. He was a passionate supporter of the State of Israel and the UJA. Jack was a member of the Prime Minister's Club in Israel and was an inspiration to all of us. His wisdom, leadership and friendship will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the bereaved Elbirt family. Committee of the Federation of Wolynian Jews in USA

title: Essay; For a 'Citizen's Privilege'
description: What can we do to transform the messiness of 1998 into the improvement of our national life in the New Year? How can we make lemonade out of this lemon of a Presidency?

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Greeting Cards At Your Fingertips
description: Felicia Lindau wants to help everyone whose new year's resolution is to ''be a better friend'' and, in the process, make a viable business. Amid this year's holiday bustle, she opened Sparks.com, which she bills as the ''world's largest greeting card store.''

title: Islanders' Lachance: Healthy, Scratched
description: There are games when Scott Lachance is outstanding, when he flashes the skills and instincts that for years have made him one of the Islanders' most reliable defensemen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTELLO, REV. MSGR. LAWRENCE D.
description: COSTELLO-Rev. Msgr. Lawrence D.Pastor Emeritus, Corpus Christi R.C. Church, Mineola, NY, on December 24, 1998. A Knight of Malta and veteran U.S. Army, Msgr. Costello served in the parishes of Our Lady of LourdesWest Islip, St. Edward ConfessorSyosset and St. Mary's-Manhasset. Dear brother of Maureen C. Durkin, Sr. Celestine Costello OSU, Regina C. Morini, Dolores C. Carlin, Joseph M. Costello and the late Raymond B. Costello, Jr. Also survived by 18 nieces and nephews and several grandnieces and grandnephews. Mass of Transferral 8 PM, Monday; Concelebrated Funeral Mass 11 AM, Tuesday, Corpus Christi Church. Interment St. Lawrence O'Toole Cemetery, Brewster, NY. Donations to the Corpus Christi School Development Fund appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICK, ARON M.
description: PICK-Aron M. 52, of Montvale, on Thursday, December 24, 1998, while vacationing in Nassau, Bahamas. Beloved husband of Alayne (nee Buchwalter). Devoted father of Rebecca and Naomi. Mr. Pick was a founder and Chief Executive Officer of Nydic Open MRI of America. He received a Juris Doctor from Boston University School of Law and a Bachelor of Arts from New York University. Mr. Pick was a member of the New York Bar. Memorial Service will be held Monday, December 28, 1998, at Temple Emanuel, 4:30 PM, 87 Overlook Drive, Woodcliff Lake, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association, 800-AHAUSA1.

title: N.B.A. Officials Say Players Union Turned Down the League's Final Offer
description: The possibility of canceling the National Basketball Association season loomed larger yesterday after Commissioner David Stern said he presented the league's final offer to Billy Hunter, executive director of the players union, and was turned down.

title: Smallest Octuplet Dies; Others Remain Critical
description: The smallest of the week-old octuplets, born to a Houston woman, died early today after the infant's heart and lungs gave out and mechanical respiration failed, according to Texas Children's Hospital in Houston.

title: The Jets Bury a Bad History and the Patriots
description: They took the field before a roaring crowd feeling like division champions -- the first time the Jets could say that in 29 years -- and then they went out today and played as if they had been doing this sort of thing all their professional lives.

title: Selective French Homage To Jewish History; Scant Mention of Holocaust in a New Museum
description: In a country already crowded with museums dedicated to every imaginable topic, it was at the very least strange that until now France had no Jewish museum worthy of the name. After all, more Jews live in France than any other European country except Russia. France also has an outstanding moral debt to a Jewish population decimated by wartime deportations from occupied France to Nazi death camps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'FLAHERTY, EILEEN
description: O'FLAHERTY-Eileen. On December 26, 1998. Retired school teacher, NYC Board of Education. Loving aunt of Kevin and Robert. Also survived by many greatnieces and nephews. Visiting Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9:30 AM, Our Lady of Angels Church.

title: Iraq a Pediatrician's Hell: No Way to Stop the Dying
description: The greatest misfortune that has been visited on three-year-old Isra Ahmed was not contracting leukemia. It was contracting leukemia in Iraq at a time when the country's medical system is all but paralyzed as a result of economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations eight years ago.

title: Decline in Otters' Number May Be Sign of Danger to Species
description: Southern sea otters, the playful darlings of the central California coast, appear to be diminishing in number at a rate that perplexes and worries scientists.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Computing's Next Wave Is Nearly at Hand; Imagining the Future in a Post-PC World
description: At a private meeting with executives of the Intel Corporation in July 1995, William H. Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, sounded a warning. As the companies pursued their joint vision of making desktop machines that could store and crunch ever-increasing amounts of digital data, Mr. Gates predicted that they would face a looming challenge.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Observations for this column may be sent to Metropolitan Diary, Style Department, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York 10036. Please include your name, address and daytime telephone number (required); upon request, names may be withheld in print. Letters become the property of The Times and cannot be returned. They may be edited, and may be republished in all media.

title: On Christmas, It's A Terrible Rating
description: People would rather spend Christmas Day with Michael Jordan than Jimmy Stewart, television ratings show.

title: An Irish Writer Redeems Black Sheep
description: Although novelists have written plays, and playwrights have written novels, it is rare for a writer to be equally adept at both arts, with one definite exception being Samuel Beckett. But at 43, Beckett's countryman Sebastian Barry seems well on his way to such an accomplishment.

title: Discounted Urns And No Overhead
description: At age 35, Russel D. Harmon has made a career of shaking up the funeral industry. In 1994, he founded Affordable Funeral Services, a renegade discounter in an industry accustomed to markups ranging from 300 percent to 1,000 percent and sometimes more. Two years ago, he sold Affordable to Service Corporation International of Houston and took a job as an executive there.

title: Revenue and Profit to Rise at DaimlerChrysler
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., the world's fifth-largest auto maker, said today that its 1998 combined sales would rise significantly and that profit would exceed last year's figures of the combined Daimler-Benz A.G. and the Chrysler Corporation.

description: To the Editor:

title: All in the Timing
description: Yesterday, I unearthed a 1998 datebook that's as pristine as the day I bought it last December. I've got half a mind to give it another go in 1999. Or perhaps I'll pass it to my 7-year-old son (he loves the lists of holidays and metric conversion tables) as I did with my equally blank 1997, '96 and '95 editions.

title: Jets Prepare For Playoffs
description: The Jets have three days off with the bye week. But Coach Bill Parcells is bringing them back on Thursday, New Year's Eve, for the start of three days of workouts. Next week they will have four days to prepare.

title: FREE-FOR-ALL: A special report.; ALBANY IS FAILING IN EFFORT TO LIMIT CAMPAIGN DONORS
description: More money than ever is pouring into New York campaigns, but the system of regulating these funds to curb their influence on politics and policy has all but broken down.

title: Good-Times Budgeting in New York
description: The boom on Wall Street and rippling prosperity in the region have again brought a bounty of budget surpluses to New York City and New York State. The good times guarantee, in turn, that the New Year will begin with temptations at City Hall and the State Capitol to spend the money on expanded programs and tax cuts. But as Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki put the final touches on budgets due in January, they need to remember that deficits and mounting debts remain a long-term threat to the fiscal health of the city and state. The surpluses of today should be husbanded as a cushion against the day when the economy turns down.

title: Lights, Camera, Lots of Action; Multiplex Plan Raises Concerns in Brooklyn Heights

title: Sound Advice From the Senate
description: Though the Senate has had little more than a week to ponder the articles of impeachment against Bill Clinton, it has already done much to restore a sense of proportion and reason to the case. Bipartisan sentiment seems to be rapidly gathering around the idea of strongly censuring Mr. Clinton rather than removing him from office, and doing so with dispatch when the new Congress convenes next month. Reaching that outcome will require the cooperation of the White House and strong leadership in the Senate to prevent the impeachment case from being kidnapped by conservative Republican senators who would like to drive Mr. Clinton from the White House against the public will.

title: The Perjury Precedent
description: President Clinton lied. He must admit it. No respectable Senate deal is possible unless he does, no matter how hard that may be. Everything he did was legal, the President has insisted, because his private definition of critical words -- ''is,'' ''alone,'' ''sexual relationship,'' whatever -- transformed his misleading answers into literal truth. Too bad, he says, if his questioners were fooled. That is just how the justice system works.

title: Editorial Notebook; Snow on the Sotol and Lechuguilla
description: In the southwestern corner of Texas, farther west than Santa Fe and farther south than Tijuana, lies El Paso, a raw-edged city built largely -- so it seems from the air -- of sheet-metal shoe boxes. The Rio Grande snakes through the desert from Las Cruces, past the stacks of Smeltertown, and there it becomes the border between the United States and Mexico, between the large-scale geometry of El Paso's industrial sector and the broken mosaic of Ciudad Juarez. On a clear winter day, a belt of brown smog tracks the boundary between Texas and Chihuahua.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAVLIS, ANTHONY GEORGE
description: PAVLIS-Anthony George. On December 24, 1998 at Jacksonville, FL. Husband of Blanche U. Pavlis. Survived by her, by sons Paul, George, Alfred; daughters Maria and Ruth and nine grandchildren. Funeral Services will be held 11 AM Wednesday, December 30, at St. John the Divine, 3860 Atlantic Avenue, Jacksonville. Interment follows at Evergreen Cemetery. Mr. Pavlis was born in 1912 at Kipseli, Greece, and graduated from the Royal Hellenic Naval Academy. He served with the British Navy in World War II and retired with rank of Captain from the Greek Navy in 1953. In the United States he joined the Stavros Niarchos shipping firm in New York where he was president of Transoceanic Marine. The family resided in Greenwich, CT. He retired in 1984 and moved to Jacksonville with his wife.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYMONDS, GEORGE W.D.
description: SYMONDS-George W.D. Died at home on December 25, 1998. He is survived by his wife Margaret P. Symonds and sons George D. and David P. Symonds; daughter Frances S. Riggs; granddaughters Adrienne and Margaret Symonds and grandsons Tristan and Cooper Riggs. He is a graduate of Kent School (1930) and Yale University (1934). He is survived by his two sons, Gregory and Jamie; his sister Carole Silvergold; his mother; his ex-wife, Shirley; many family members and endless, ever-growing hordes of friends, acquaintances and co-conspirators. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, JOHN L.

He was Financial Vice President of Sinclair Oil Corp. and Executive Vice President and a Director of American Standard, Inc. He was also a Director of Air Products and Chemicals, Inc. In NYC, he was a member and former President of the University Club, and a member of the Links and Harvard Clubs. A WW II veteran, he was a graduate of Union College and Harvard Business School. In retirement, the Grants were residents of Tuscon, AZ, and Santa Barbara, CA. Mr. Grant is survived by his loving wife Carolyn Hubbell Grant and numerous nieces and nephews. A memorial service will take place in Santa Barbara, CA. Remembrance gifts may be directed to Union College, Schenectady, NY 12308, Class of 1945.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONS, ELEANOR
description: ARONS-Eleanor On December 27, 1998, at the age of 83 at Morningside Nursing Home, Bronx, NY. She is survived by her three children, Ludwig, Raymond and Lynne; three grandchildren, Jonathan, Nicholas and Anthony Arons. She was a gifted painter, studying with Samuel Breecher, and created master works and private collections throughout the country. She was married to Hy Arons, a popular pianist of the 1940s and 1950s who died in 1991. She will be remembered for her talent, zest for life and charismatic personality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, DR. ELIZABETH H.
description: ROBERTS-Dr. Elizabeth H. The Board of Directors, faculty, administration and the students of the New York College of Podiatric Medicine and the Foot Clinics of New York mourn the passing of their beloved and esteemed Board member, professor emeritus and alumna. A lecturer and prolific contributor of articles to professional publicatons, Dr. Roberts authored several books on podiatry. In 1989 Dr. Roberts was elected a Distinguished Practitioner by the National Academy of Practice. In 1997 she was the recipient of the Distinguished Service Award of the APMA. She was a founding member of the APMA Writers Association. Our heartfelt condolences go to her loving family. Donations can be made to the Dr. Elizabeth H. Roberts Award for Excellence and Empathy in Podopediatrics, c/o NYCPM, 1800 Park Ave, NYC 10035. Alfred G. Gerosa, Chairman Board of Trustees Louis L. Levine, President and CEO

title: Of Overstuffed Operas, and the Met as Victorian Drawing Room
description: You have to be careful about reading too much into the reactions of audiences at the Metropolitan Opera. After all, opera buffs are passionate sorts, prone to fleeting enthusiasms as well as die-hard devotions. Last season, when the avant-garde director and designer Robert Wilson took a curtain call at the premiere of his production of Wagner's ''Lohengrin,'' he was vehemently booed. Nonetheless, when the glacially paced production with its abstract light-shaft sets returned this fall, Mr. Wilson bravely took the stage again, this time to cheers and bravos.

title: Physicists Discover Another Unifying Force: Doo-Wop
description: The arcane language of physics is not exactly the stuff of song lyrics, but the Cernettes, billed as the world's first particle physics rock band, have hit the Internet. Even if nonphysicists fail to get their musical jokes, the Cernettes count on a growing audience of admiring scientists.

title: Schroder Aide Typifies New German Subtlety

But look up at the mop of hair and mischievous eyes of Mr. Schily, the German Interior Minister, and some of the contradictions of the man and his country begin to come into focus.

title: Milder Months Bring Bigger Babies
description: If every little millimeter counts in the height of your children, a spring or fall birth might give them an edge. European researchers do not know why but those babies are longer and by age 18 taller than other children.

title: The Universe as Telescope
description: Faraway in the cosmos, where everything is separated by distances measured in hundreds and billions of light-years, sometimes a galaxy or cluster of galaxies in the foreground intersects the light from an even more distant object. The conjunction plays visual tricks, creating mirages that are becoming a practical tool of astronomy, a kind of natural telescope.

title: 82 Smuggled Immigrants in a 3-Day Period, a Record, Are Seized in Florida
description: Eighty-two illegal immigrants from Cuba, Haiti and Jamaica were dropped off at eight places between Key West and West Palm Beach over the last three days in a flurry of smuggling that takes a page from the drug trafficking in the seas off South Florida, Federal officials said today.

title: AMR AGREES TO SELL AIRPORT GROUND-SERVICES UNIT
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, has agreed to sell its airport ground-services unit to an investment fund managed by Castle Harlan Inc. for an undisclosed price. AMR Services provides passenger check-in, ticketing and boarding, cargo loading, aircraft marshaling, cabin cleaning, fueling and other services at more than 60 airports. The unit, which employs nearly 8,000 people, is expected to have 1998 revenue of more than $220 million. The parent company, based in Fort Worth, is selling the unit to Castle Harlan Partners 3, a $630 million investment fund managed by Castle Harlan, a merchant bank based in New York. The sale will complete AMR's plan, announced in September, to divest itself of three subsidiaries.

Dr. Castelnuovo has been a major force in the success of the group, particularly the Flushing Center, where he had worked for the past 37 years. His energy and determination, as well as his compassionate and caring demeanor have made him one of the most valuable physicians in the group. He will be sorely missed by his colleagues, staff and patients.

title: IMC GLOBAL TO SELL ITS SODA ASH OPERATIONS TO MINCORP
description: IMC Global Inc., the world's biggest producer of phosphate and potash fertilizer, said yesterday that it would sell its soda ash and boron chemicals operations to Mincorp L.L.C., a Citigroup Inc. venture capital fund, for about $520 million. IMC Global will retain a minority stake in Mincorp. IMC acquired the boron and soda ash operations as part of its $1.4 billion acquisition of closely held Harris Chemical Group Inc. in April, which IMC bought primarily for its operations that make salt. IMC, based in Northbrook, Ill., said it would take a charge of about $30 million, or 26 cents a share, related to the sale. The shares of IMC rose $1.6875 each, to $21.3125.

title: A Resignation At True North
description: True North Communications in Chicago said yesterday that Richard S. Braddock, 56, nonexecutive chairman and member of the board, would resign at the end of January to take the position of chairman and chief executive at Priceline.com, an Internet retailer of discount airline tickets. No decision has been made regarding a successor, said Cheryl Harbour, a spokeswoman for True North.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

title: Malaysia Money Supply Grew 3.3% in November
description: Malaysia's money supply growth accelerated in November for the first time in 15 months, in what may be a sign that the country's economic slowdown is bottoming out. The central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, said the broadest measure of money supply, or M-3, expanded 3.3 percent in November from a year earlier, up from a 2.5 percent gain in October and down from September's 4 percent rise.

title: The Euro's Promise and Peril
description: The creation of the euro -- combining 11 European currencies, including the German mark, the French franc and the Italian lira -- is a historic milestone on the path toward European union. It will push European countries to adopt more similar economic policies while depriving individual nations of significant powers they now enjoy. At best, it will make Europe into an economic machine rivaling the United States. At worst, it will lead to political strife within the Continent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKAT, MARION
description: BURKAT-Marion. Died in her sleep on December 21 in Stamford. She lived in Danbury for many years where, with her husband Leonard, she founded and ran the Burkat Program Note Service. The company, now managed by Howard Burkat, was the first, full-time organization of its kind, and continues to serve hundreds of the world's best known musical organizations. Its archives contain notes on over 15,000 musical works, and is the world's most read information source for classical music. Mrs. Burkat was born in Boston in 1919 and graduated from Dorchester High School and Radcliffe College. Her parents were Rose and Alan J. Gumner, of Boston. From 1951 to 1963, she lived in Brookline where she was Executive Director of the Brookline League of Women Voters. Marion Burkat was Director of the Radcliffe Club of New York in the midsixties and lived in Manhattan. Later, living in Ridgefield, Southbury, and Danbury, CT, she was an officer and board member of the Radcliffe Club of Fairfield County. Mrs. Burkat is survived by her son Howard of Scarsdale, and her daughters, Susan Burkat Trubey of Royal Oak, Michigan, and Caroline Burkat Hall of Danbury. Also surviving are six grandchildren. Funeral arrangements are private. A memorial service will be held in the spring in Stockbridge, MA. Contributions may be made to the Copland Heritage Association, Box 2177, Cortlandt Manor, New York 10566.

title: KITTY HAWK TO EXIT AIR PASSENGER BUSINESS BY NEXT YEAR
description: Kitty Hawk Inc., the world's largest air-only freight carrier, said yesterday that it would cut the work force of its charter air service unit by 1,500, or 55 percent, to exit the passenger business. Kitty Hawk, of Dallas, said its American International Airways division would be an all-cargo contract airline by the time the job cuts are complete at the end of next year. Kitty Hawk has struggled with high maintenance costs and low profit margins since it acquired American International in November 1997. American International carries freight and operates charter flights for cruise lines and tour companies.

title: Man Who Dared To Write About A Geisha's Mind
description: To write ''Memoirs of a Geisha,'' the fictional reminiscences of a geisha in Kyoto during the 1930's and 40's, Arthur Golden, a 42-year-old father of two, and an American at that, had to cross three great boundaries, gender, nationality and history. He had to imagine what it would be like to be a 9-year-old girl sold to a geisha house. He had to understand what the same character at 15 would feel when she faced the nasty old man who had just made the highest bid in an auction of her virginity. He also had to know the smallest details of her daily life: how she would apply her makeup and create her elaborate hairstyle.

Fujita will write off 280 billion yen in bad loans and other losses in the year ending in March. Fujita is suffering from weak demand and difficulties collecting bad loans.

title: Editorial Observer; Bill Bradley: A Dollar, a Dream, a Big Bounce

It was, apparently, the weight of the books that was dragging him down. (''You always take 10 times more than you can read.'') Certainly it was not the wardrobe. ''You'd be surprised how superfluous it is to change your shirt,'' he confided.

title: KN ENERGY SAYS LAGGING DEMAND WILL LOWER EARNINGS
description: KN Energy Inc., which owns 25,000 miles of natural gas pipelines in the Western and Midwestern United States, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter and full-year earnings would plunge because warm weather had reduced demand in the Midwest. KN Energy said it expected earnings of 8 cents to 32 cents a share in the quarter. That was far less than the 92-cent average estimate of analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation. The company had earnings of 89 cents in the corresponding period last year. KN Energy, based in Lakewood, Colo., said earnings were also hurt by narrower margins on sales of fuels extracted from gas, and by costs related to high gas inventories. Shares of the company fell $1.9375, to $36.375.

David is also mourned by his loving mother Lillian Golden and his sister Carol Golden Einhorn, both of Providence, Rhode Island. David's career in magazine advertising spanned twenty years, where he served in Senior Sales and management positions at ''GQ'', ''Vanity Fair'', ''Departures'' and ''The New Yorker'' magazines. Most recently, he was the Director of American fashion and retail advertising at ''The New Yorker''. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1968 with a B.A. in English and served as an English teacher in the Peace Corps in Ethiopia. title: PREMISYS EARNINGS MAY FALL; EXECUTIVE ON SICK LEAVE
description: Shares of Premisys Communications Inc. skidded 15 percent yesterday after the company, a telecommunications equipment maker, warned of weak profits in its second quarter and said its chief executive would be off the job until June because of frostbite. The chief executive, Nicholas J. Williams, was stranded at a ski resort in California in sub-freezing weather for two days last week after getting lost while skiing. Premisys' board will decide this week whether to appoint an interim chief executive. Premisys, which makes products that handle voice and data traffic, now expects earnings of 8 cents to 10 cents a share for the quarter ended last Friday. Analysts had forecast profit of 16 cents a share. Shares of Premisys dropped $1.50, to $8.375.

title: Post-Holiday Haul
description: As the curbsides begin to disappear under bags of tinsel and leftover fruitcake, it is a good time to think not about what we bring home for the holidays but about what we throw away afterward. New York City's 7.3 million people, plus the 34 million or so tourists who will have been through town this year, produce about 26,000 tons of refuse a day. We dutifully recycle about 2,000 tons of that load -- an amount that should increase now that the city has wisely agreed to weekly recycling. That still leaves a lot of the smelly stuff, some commercial, some residential, that must be carted off and sent elsewhere.

title: On the Trail of the Monarch, With the Aid of Chemistry

description: The Fairchild Corporation, based in Dulles, Va., disclosed over the weekend that it would buy Kaynar Technologies Inc., a maker of specialty fasteners based in Orange, Calif., for $28.75 a share, or $267 million. It will also assume debt of $98 million. Fairchild, which plans to merge Kaynar with its Fairchild Fasteners unit, said the move was expected to increase the division's revenue by 72 percent, to $685 million for the year beginning on July 1. Kaynar's stock jumped $2.875 a share, to $27.50, in Nasdaq trading, while Fairchild's shares were up 68.75 cents, to $14.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: For Athletes, Better Focus With Hypnosis
description: Moments before the gun sounded to start his World Cup 400m race, Iwan Thomas gently tugged on his left ear lobe. This subtle movement helped him block out the noise of the crowd and the runners on either side of him. Like a number of other top athletes, Mr. Thomas has been using hypnosis to enhance his performance. The action of pulling his ear lobe is known as an associative post-hypnotic command, which brought him into a heightened state of concentration. He won the race that day, capping off his best season ever.

title: Choosing Right to Make Healthiest and Tastiest One and the Same
description: I was at a holiday party last week. As you might guess, there were platters of cookies, cakes and candies to tempt the weak of will. But the three dishes that disappeared the fastest were a lentil soup, a salad of lentils, rice and fresh vegetables and a hot-smoked salmon fillet. Were these downed first because the nutrition police were watching, because the partygoers were a particularly health-conscious bunch, or because these dishes were simply delicious?

title: Bottler's Debt Refinanced

The remaining $160 million was rolled over by ING Bank and Bank of America for a three-month term.

Mr. Schickele also knows enough German to pun successfully on the most revered titles in the repertory.

title: ADAC STOCK DROPS AFTER REPORT ON ACCOUNTING
description: Shares of Adac Laboratories tumbled 19 percent yesterday after the company, a supplier of medical-imaging equipment, said it would restate its financial results for the last three years because of accounting problems. The company said it might show reduced earnings for 1996 and 1997 after making the adjustments. The results for the full year of 1998 are not expected to be affected significantly, although those for individual quarters could be, the company said. The problems relate to the method used to account for expenses and revenue. Adac, based in Milpitas, Calif., supplies medical imaging equipment and data systems used in nuclear medicine, radiology, cardiology, oncology and neurology. It had revenue of $323.3 million for the fiscal year ending in September 1998. Shares of Adac fell $5.25 each, to $21.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Gloria Marie Stradtner, 72, Protector of Animals, Dies
description: If you saw her at all, you'd see her in a cemetery late at night. She was there on the hottest, stickiest summer night when New Yorkers without air-conditioners couldn't sleep, and she was there when the temperature was below zero and the snow was hip-deep and nobody was awake.

title: In a World Of Cuisine, A Longing For Food

Cooking trends have bombarded us from all directions, cookbook sections in bookstores have grown into multicolored labyrinths, restaurant dishes have become ordeals to deconstruct -- both physically and sensually. And many home cooks have followed these trends into the chaos.

title: MORGAN PRODUCTS AGREES TO ACQUIRE ADAM WHOLESALERS
description: The building-products concern Morgan Products Ltd. said it had agreed to acquire Adam Wholesalers, a closely held distributor of windows, doors and millwork, for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition will create one of the nation's largest wholesale distributors of millwork building products, with annual sales of more than $700 million and more than 2,000 employees and 26 distribution centers nationwide. Morgan, based in Williamsburg, Va., had 1997 sales of $412.2 million and 16 distribution centers. Its products include Morgan and Premdor doors and Andersen window systems. Adam, based in Sharonville, Ohio, has annual sales of $345 million.

title: Wrong Partner for Russia
description: Russia will make a grave mistake if it follows through on plans to reunite with the former Soviet republic of Belarus. The merger scheme announced last week by President Boris Yeltsin and his Belarussian counterpart, Aleksandr Lukashenko, may never come to pass. No formal agreement was signed and many of Mr. Yeltsin's declarations these days cannot be taken at face value.

title: A DiMaggio Rule on Medical Privacy
description: After emerging from a coma in a Florida hospital last month, Joe DiMaggio let the world know that he didn't care if his illness was a big story. He told his doctors that he was angry that the most intimate details of his cancer, coma and pneumonia were out there for all to read.

title: Under Prodding, 2 Apologize for Cambodian Anguish

title: China Jails 2 Dissidents, Reinforcing Tough Stance
description: Chinese officials today reinforced their recent efforts to silence political opposition, sentencing two New York-based dissidents who had recently sneaked back into China to work to promote democratic change to three years in a labor camp.

description: Stock prices rose yesterday for the eighth consecutive trading day, the longest winning streak in more than two years.

title: Purdue Pulls Off Surprise At Alamo

title: At the Funeral For McAlary, A Wide Mix
description: Mike McAlary, the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist for The Daily News, was remembered at his funeral yesterday by several of his disparate but prominent friends as a reporter of unusual fortitude who accomplished some of his best work while slowly dying of colon cancer over the last two years.

title: Diet Coke Shifts Duties To Wieden & Kennedy
description: In an advertising change involving its second-largest brand, the Coca-Cola Company in Atlanta said yesterday that it would shift the lead creative duties on Diet Coke between roster agencies, moving the assignment to Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., from Lowe & Partners/ SMS in New York. Annual worldwide spending on the brand, sold in many countries as Coca-Cola Light, was estimated at $100 million.

title: McCall Is Said to Decide Against a Senate Race in 2000 to Succeed Moynihan
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, whom Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan had pressed to run for the seat the Senator will leave when he retires in 2000, has decided not to run for the Senate and plans to serve out his term in Albany, Mr. McCall's associates said last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTELNUOVO, DR. LAMBERTO G.

He is survived by his nephew Paolo, nieces Rosella and Lori, sisterin-law Sally and great nieces and nephews Federico, Francesco, Gabrielle, Ricardo, Victoria and Olympia. Lamberto was the youngest of three brothers and he died December 23 on route to the funeral of his oldest brother Piero who died suddenly that same morning. Lamberto was raised in the Jewish community in Rome and obtained his medical degree at the University of Lausanne, Switzerland during the war. After coming to America in 1953, he stayed close to his family in Rome returning frequently.

title: Political Memo; Did Anyone Really Think This Couple Would Last?
description: Last fall, Edward I. Koch and Rudolph W. Giuliani -- partners in New York City politics until they effectively stopped talking to each other about five years ago -- taped a televised endorsement for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato that playfully evoked their rivalry. For both, it proved to be less unpleasant than they had expected, according to associates of each.

title: Just Like Home, if Home Happens to Be in France
description: LUCIEN is a new, crowded, somewhat disheveled little French place that serves old-fashioned homey meals. It is perhaps an unexpected turn for the owner, Lucien Bahaj, who has spent his career in the dining rooms of trendy fusion restaurants like Indochine, Canal Bar, Mad.61 and Elephant. But Mr. Bahaj, who recently opened Lucien, his first restaurant, with his wife, Phyllis, says that he decided to return to what he knew best.

title: Even Cowboys Get the Blues
description: It takes a lot of courage nowadays for a director to tackle anything resembling a classic western. But in adapting Max Evans's 1961 novel, ''The Hi-Lo Country,'' to the screen, that is precisely what Stephen Frears, the British director of ''My Beautiful Launderette'' and ''The Grifters,'' has attempted in his wildly ambitious new film. If the threads of the story ultimately slip from his grasp, in its best moments the movie feels like an epic hybrid of ''Red River'' and ''The Last Picture Show.''

title: Ex-Hosts to Sue QVC Network, Charging Bias

title: PRIMARK IN PACT TO ACQUIRE A-T FINANCIAL FOR $35 MILLION

Primark, based in Waltham, Mass., collects, integrates and delivers financial, economic and market-research information. A-T Financial provides market data, news and and software to money managers, traders, banks and other institutional investors through local and regional networks and the Internet.

title: Where the Metal Is Really Metal
description: Scrap metal defines Einsturzende Neubauten, the German band that finished a three-night stand at the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night. Its members pounded on a garbage-can lid and on a big blue chemical barrel; they tapped on hanging metal tubes, poured buckets of gravel down an amplified metal chute, rattled a jet-engine turbine and whacked various pipes and hunks and sheets of metal. They also had standard rock instruments -- bass, guitar, keyboard -- but their music was defined by clangor and drones.

description: When Nigem D., a college freshman, thinks about the kind of life he could be leading, he remembers his friend Burnell. The last time he heard about him, Burnell was in jail on charges of drug possession.

title: SURGE COMPONENTS AGREES TO PURCHASE ORBIT NETWORK
description: Surge Components Inc., a maker of electronic products, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Orbit Network Inc. for about $66 million as it sought to expand its business on the Internet. Surge, based in Deer Park, N.Y., said it planned to exchange 25 million shares for Orbit, based in Novato, Calif., which connects consumers with travel suppliers using the Internet and other networks. The acquisition will help Surge build its business on the Internet as a link to leisure and international travel suppliers. The company also sells electronics products on the Internet. Surge's shares soared $1.53125 each, to $2.625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: South Korean Economy Poised for a Turnaround
description: South Korea's economy is expected to shrink about 4.5 percent in the fourth quarter of this year, much less than the widely forecast contraction of 6 percent, the Ministry of Finance and Economy said yesterday. The estimated decline from a year earlier compares with contractions of 6.8 percent in the previous quarter and 5.9 percent for the first nine months of this year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLOOMFIELD, SYLVAN, M.D.
description: BLOOMFIELD - Sylvan, M.D. 1911-1993. Forever in the hearts of his wife, family, and friends.

title: Hans Oeschger, Geologist, 71, An Expert on Greenhouse Gases
description: Hans Oeschger, a Swiss geologist who sounded early warnings about the risk that emissions of industrial waste gases might bring on climate change, died on Friday, after a long illness, according to press reports from Bern. He was 71.

title: Hyundai Motor Expects A Loss for the Year
description: The Hyundai Motor Company said yesterday that its sales had fallen by more than a fifth this year, making it all but certain that the company, South Korea's largest auto maker, would lose money for the first time in almost two decades. Sales were expected to slide to less than 9 trillion won ($7.5 billion) this year from 11.7 trillion won the previous year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, SAUL
description: FINKEL-Saul. The Young Israel of West Hempstead has suffered a great loss with the passing of Saul Finkel on Tuesday, December 29th, 1998. Mr. Finkel was a beloved member and an individual devoted to his Jewish heritage. He is survived by his wife Muriel and two sons, and is mourned by the entire community. Rabbi Yehuda Kelemer Mark Nathanson, President

title: Poultry Ruling Opens Door To a Different Foie Gras
description: A NEW Government ruling on imported poultry may not send American chicken producers running for cover, but it's big news for connoisseurs of foie gras. For the first time, the uncooked livers of French geese will be sold in the United States.

title: Monterey: The Next Napa (or Is It Burgundy?)
description: BACK in the late 1970's, Dan Lee left the University of California at Davis with a shiny new winemaking diploma and headed off to his first job, in Monterey County on the Central Coast. This was not a promising start. ''People looked at me a little strangely, and a few of them sort of laughed,'' Mr. Lee said.

title: TR FINANCIAL ASKS HIGHER PRICE IN MERGER WITH ROSLYN
description: The TR Financial Corporation, the parent of Roosevelt Savings Bank, said yesterday that it would end its agreement to be bought by Roslyn Bancorp Inc. unless Roslyn agreed to pay about $25 million more than the companies had originally agreed. TR Financial said Roslyn had until this Saturday to increase its offer to 2.1137 Roslyn shares for each TR Financial share from the current offer of 2.05 shares. Roslyn said it had no plans to increase the share-exchange ratio. A merger of the two Long Island companies would create the fourth-largest savings bank in New York State. TR Financial's shares fell $2.125, to $36.50, while Roslyn's shares rose 50 cents, to $21, in Nasdaq trading. Roslyn's shares have fallen about 20 percent since the merger agreement was announced. At yesterday's price, the value of the original deal is more than $755 million.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MARRIOTT TO SELL EIGHT HOUSING UNITS TO AUREUS GROUP
description: Marriott International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell eight Brighton Gardens assisted-living communities to the privately held Aureus Group L.L.C. for $140 million. Under the deal, Marriott's Senior Living Services unit will operate the communities under long-term agreements. Marriott, based in Bethesda, Md., and best known for its Marriott and Ritz-Carlton lodging chains, operates more than 100 full-service and assisted living communities. Aureus, based in Dallas, develops and acquires senior living communities in the United States.

title: BASKETBALL: Designing Men; Cazzie Russell, Former Knick, Coaches From the Heart
description: Students at Hunter College were making posters for the game Saturday on campus. ''They'll read,'' Mike Brown, the Hunter basketball coach, was saying recently, ''come see us play Savannah College of Art and Design -- and their legendary coach, Cazzie Russell!' ''

title: Officers' Killing of Woman in Car Leads to Dispute Over Facts and Motives
description: A 19-year-old black woman was killed here in a hail of police bullets as she sat in her disabled car, a gun in her lap, early Monday, leading family members to accuse the officers of murder and local civil rights officials to ask for calm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISFELD, JACK
description: WEISFELD-Jack. Beloved husband of Anita. Loving father of Barry and Elaine. Brother of Caroline. Services were held.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. Japan's currency rose on concern that Japanese exporters, who have amassed vast amounts of dollars, are now selling them for yen to repatriate profits. The dollar cost 115.53 yen in New York, down from 115.90.

title: ARTS ABROAD: Devotion Refuses to Yield; Alzheimer's Disease Cannot Divide a Literary Couple
description: Iris Murdoch, the celebrated author of 26 rigorously intellectual novels, stood uncertainly in the doorway of her living room, her face frozen in the blank expression that is a sure badge of Alzheimer's disease. It was only when she saw her husband, the critic, professor and novelist John Bayley, that a flicker of comprehension sparked in her eyes. But it was gone, as quickly as it came.

title: Devils Display Levity, But Keep Perspective
description: The Devils were playful after practice today, laughing and joking as they finished up and boarded the team bus back to Washington to await their game with the Capitals on Wednesday night.

title: Ex-Biogen Chief Says He Quit Over Conflicts With Chairman
description: James R. Tobin said yesterday that he did not resign suddenly last week as Biogen Inc.'s president and chief executive to take another job. Rather, Mr. Tobin said, he left one of the top United States biotechnology companies over what he called conflicts with its chairman, James L. Vincent.

title: Dolphins Bulk Up at Tackle for Bills' Visit
description: The Miami Dolphins have been through an emotional wringer over the last three weeks. Down, up, down. Now, as they prepare for Saturday's wild-card playoff game against Buffalo, they are finding two huge sources of optimism.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SUNOCO INC., Philadelphia, an oil refiner and retailer, plans to buy back $150 million worth of its stock, or about 5 percent of its 90.4 million shares outstanding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERBSEN, LAURA TREVES,
description: ERBSEN-Laura Treves, 87, died peacefully in her sleep December 26. Wife of the late Henry Erbsen. Loving mother of Claude Erbsen, and loving grandmother of Diana, Allan and Michael. Interment is private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTESINOS, MEZHY
description: MONTESINOS-Mezhy. Born in Quito, Ecuador, September 2, 1939, died December 27, 1998. Beloved wife of Jaime; devoted mother of JJ, married to Wendy, and Maritcita, married to Kenneth; loving daughter of Melida Martinez; adored grandmother of Karina, Austin, and Sebastian. Mass Wednesday, 10AM, at Saint Eugene's Church, Yonkers, NY. Reposing at Romano Family Funeral Home, 24 Depot Square, Tuckahoe, NY. Interment Mount Hope Cemetery. Contributions to Albert Einstein Hospital, Bronx, New York would be appreciated.

description: He Can't Even Get A Car Stolen Here

title: G.O.P. IN CONGRESS SPLITS OVER TRIAL
description: The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, and the 13 House Republicans planning to prosecute an impeachment trial of President Clinton in the Senate clashed today over whether to call any witnesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURY, SABRINA
description: KURY-Sabrina. Age 35. On December 27, 1998. Beloved daughter of Bernard and Valerie. Sister of Susannah and Kristin. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, December 29th, 5-9PM with service Wednesday 11:30AM. Interment in Florida. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Fountain House, (NYC), National Alliance for the Mentally Ill or the American Cancer Society.

title: Liberties; Acquitting Himself Well
description: Going for impeachment in the House, Republicans behaved like giddy hedonists. They did what felt good, heedless of harm to their party or the country.

title: Talk of League to Rival the N.B.A. Is Just That . . . Talk
description: As the prospect of the National Basketball Association season being canceled increases, so has talk that a rival league will be formed.

title: Ford Introduces Sport Utility-Pickup Truck
description: The Ford Motor Company's Lincoln luxury division has introduced a combination sport utility-pickup truck, the Blackwood, as part of its effort to capture younger buyers and predict the evolution of the light-truck market.

title: CALENDAR
description: Ring In With Rossini

title: After Crashes, New Bus Rules Are Weighed
description: As investigators seek the causes of three serious bus accidents in five days, Federal regulators and lawmakers in New York and New Jersey are considering tough new rules and enforcement measures, ranging from requiring seat belts or defensive-driving instruction to restricting drivers from too much time at the wheel in the after-midnight hours.

title: A Safer New York
description: As New Yorkers look ahead to the new year, they can take satisfaction in the vibrant stock market and the tourist boom that continue to create new jobs. The Yankees won the World Series and the Jets are headed into the playoffs. The litter that once filled midtown is largely gone. But perhaps more than anything else that has lifted spirits, the city is safer. Another piece of good news came recently in the sharp decline in homicides this year. As of Monday there were 620 homicides in 1998, a pace that is below the 1964 total of 636 homicides. Turning the homicide rate back 34 years is an impressive feat, given that 2,262 people were killed in the city in 1990.

title: Of Perjury And Precedent
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday Treat for Tigers
description: Faced with the opportunity to be home for the holidays, Princeton's Nick Rankin made the most of it.

title: Romantic Intrigue and Touching Passion
description: American Ballet Theater's luscious-looking production of ''The Merry Widow'' found its perfect home at Prudential Hall at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center on Monday night. The center's two handsome theaters are well appointed yet warm and welcoming. And the Prudential stage offers both ample space and an intimate proscenium frame that are perfect for this tale of romantic intrigue in Paris early in this century.

title: THE NEW EUROPE: Money That Binds; Primer on Euro: From Birth To Growth as Unifying Force
description: This border city in Alsace-Lorraine has been French and then German and now French again, depending on who won the last war. But today it is a placid outpost in a more unified Europe: a home for the European Parliament, and a mecca for cross-border shoppers.

title: Isles Show Nothing On a Trip To Florida
description: Not so long ago, the Islanders dominated the Lightning. Really, really dominated the Lightning.

title: Journal; Nicole Kidman's Behind
description: If the theater is a temple, it's no surprise that the most popular faith on Broadway this holiday season is ''The Blue Room,'' to which pilgrims flock from miles around to worship Nicole Kidman's tush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSON, BOBBY
description: BENSON-Bobby. On Dec. 21, 1998. The dance world mourns the passing of Bobby Benson, dancer/ teacher extraodinaire! His dance expertise will always be artistically embraced by those whose lives he touched. John Lucchese and friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZLOCZOWER, WALTER AUGUST
description: ZLOCZOWER-Walter August 22, 1931 - December 27, 1998. Beloved husband of Charlotte, devoted father of Jeffrey and Anita, adored grandfather of Cherise, Daniel, and Alyse. To know him was to love him. Memorial Services, January 24, at 2:30PM, The Abode, New Lebanon, NY (snow date, Jan 31). In lieu of flowers, please send donations to American Cancer Society for Adenoid Cystic Carcenoma research.

title: Discordant Concerto, Played Upon Two Hearts
description: Anand Tucker's double biography of the renowned cellist Jacqueline du Pre (Emily Watson) and her sister, Hilary (Rachel Griffiths), is one of the most insightful and wrenching portraits of the joys and tribulations of being a classical musician ever filmed. At the same time, this study of two gifted sisters who are so close they can literally read each other's minds is an astoundingly rich and subtle exploration of sibling rivalry and the volcanic collisions of love and resentment, competitiveness and mutual dependence that determine their lives.

title: A Feast of Hong Kong Delicacies
description: EDDIE SCHOENFELD loves Chinese food. He loves it so much he has spent the better part of his life hanging around Chinese restaurants. He is a restaurateur who was taught to cook by a legendary master chef, worked at the original Shun Lee Palace and thinks nothing of flying off to Hong Kong for a few good meals.

title: A Dish Handled With Care
description: OSSO BUCO, the glorious Italian dish of fork-tender, marrow-filled veal shanks in a natural sauce, takes time but almost no attention. In the two hours or so it takes to cook, you'll need to stand over it no more than 20 minutes. Even better, the meat holds up well enough overnight for 90 percent of the cooking to be done while you're watching television the night before you serve it.

title: Returning Dissidents Sentenced by China
description: Chinese officials reinforced their recent efforts to silence political opposition, sentencing two New-York-based dissidents who had sneaked back into China recently to work for democratic change to three years in a labor camp.

title: Sports of The Times; A Sportsman Who Really Was in Need
description: FOR altogether different reasons, Mike Peplinski would agree with a weekly magazine that recently acclaimed 1998 as the greatest sports year of the century. In terms of personal achievement, he made it all the way from Eau Claire, Wis., to the Winter Olympics. And in a show of transcendent sacrifice for the sake of the team, his father-in-law furnished something worth more than any color medal, or big-money contract.

title: U.S. Is Joining 2d Suit Against Hospital Chain
description: The Justice Department announced yesterday that it had joined a lawsuit filed by a whistle-blower against the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, bringing new allegations that the company defrauded Federal health programs through a scheme involving bogus expense claims.

title: Calling a Truce on Divorce Warfare
description: ''Nobody wins in long, drawn-out divorce cases, not spouses and especially not the children who are caught in the middle,'' says New York State's Chief Judge, Judith Kaye. With that thought in mind, Judge Kaye has announced a series of practical changes intended to make the process of breaking up less adversarial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATKIN, IRVING
description: SLATKIN-Irving. On December 28. Devoted father, brother, uncle. Remembered with affection and respect by all who knew him.

title: Seton Hall Captures 7th in Row With Ease
description: When Seton Hall plays weaker teams, such as Boston College, the swingman Gary Saunders is a handy player to have. He proved that today, scoring 23 points to lead the Pirates past the Eagles, 79-63, at Continental Arena.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: A Testy Mayor Serves Success Stories to Reporters
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was feeling expansive yesterday as he ticked off a list of what he saw as his accomplishments of 1998, taking credit for drawing a record number of tourists to the city, battling crime, keeping the New York Stock Exchange from moving, cutting the welfare rolls and, closer to home, losing 38 pounds.

title: Forceful Entry by Police Shatters Peace of Mind
description: Alexandra Chernikova did not want to move her family into a housing project, fearing it would be unclean and unsafe. So after she and her husband separated in 1996, she worked two jobs, hoping to make enough money to stay in their apartment in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. But she could not afford the rent, and she and her son and daughter moved into the Marlboro Houses in Gravesend in April.
