title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWEY, ROBERT F.
description: DEWEY-Robert F. Died in North Hollywood, CA, Friday, December 25, 1998 at age 67. Born January 29, 1931 to Charles and Marjorie Evans Dewey in Pleasantville, NY where he was raised & educated. He served in the army in the Korean War. Mr. Dewey is survived by a sister, Dorothy Goodding, of Friendswood, TX and a nephew, Charles Goodding.

title: A Steady Hand, So Far
description: It is encouraging to see the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, taking an assertive yet balanced leadership role in the Presidential impeachment crisis. He seems to have drawn the right lessons from watching a temporary House leader, Robert Livingston, collapse under the task of guiding that chamber through its hearings.

title: Suit Over Tip Ends With a Settlement
description: The Tiff over the Tip is over.

title: SHELL SELLS RUBBER UNIT TO DOW CHEMICAL
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, which is selling off its chemical businesses in an effort to counteract the damage done by low oil prices, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its general-purpose rubber business to the Dow Chemical Company. Terms were not disclosed. The agreement includes manufacturing plants at Etang de Berre, France, and Pernis in the Netherlands, which the British-Dutch oil giant will continue to operate on Dow's behalf. Dow Chemical is based in Midland, Mich.

title: When Gold, Not Platinum, Was Fresh
description: All a rapper over 30 has to do these days is chant ''old school,'' and the crowd will explode. Slick Rick took that wisdom at its word in his Monday night show at Tramps: after he did that once, he barely did anything else. It was a nonshow, a quick and unconvincing affair that seemed more like a bid for the revocation of his performing license than an event that had been advertised as ''the Ruler returns.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, DR. CHARLES
description: SCHWARTZ-Dr. Charles, composer, on December 24, 1998. Founder and musical director of Composers' Showcase, he devoted a lifetime to the encouragement, support and presentation of new music through his series of Contrasts in Contemporary Music at the MOMA, the Whitney Museum and Lincoln Center. We express deepest sympathy on his passing and grieve with the family on this loss. Friends of Composers' Showcase

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MALLEY, THOMAS J., JR.
description: O'MALLEY-Thomas J., Jr. Age 62, of Pelham Manor, NY, died Tuesday Dec. 29, 1998. He was the dear brother of Mary Theresa O'Malley. Mr. O'Malley was a graduated of All Hallows High School, Holy Cross College and Fordham Law School. He was formerly an Assistant District Attorney in Bronx County. He was currently employed as Special Senior Counsel for The Department of Justice in Washington, D.C. Visiting hours on Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 79 P.M. at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, NY. Mass at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Pelham Manor, NY on Monday at 10 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

description: The stain on his record will endure, reflecting a six-month prison term for drug use that disrupted a long and colorful career of public service.

title: The Immigrant Lockup
description: Thousands of people who are not accused of any crime or who have completed prison terms for minor crimes spent this Christmas -- and may spend the next -- in jails around the nation. They are immigrants detained by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which has filled its own detention centers and has now resorted to using local and county lockups.

description: U.S. Fighters Attack Iraqi Missile Site

title: Non-Orthodox Rabbis Win A Court Skirmish in Israel
description: In a court decision that is expected to reawaken the divisive issue of who is a Jew, a district judge here today ordered the Israeli Government to recognize conversions to Judaism performed by non-Orthodox rabbis.

title: For Actors and Agents, On-Line Links to Casting Directors
description: Early this year, Bonnie Black, a Hollywood talent agent, got a call from a casting director who was working against a deadline that even the toughest cinematic hero might have had trouble beating. The casting director had less than 20 hours to find an actor to play the role of an F.B.I. agent on the television series ''Players.''

title: Better Pay That Fare; Someone's Watching
description: It will cost a subway fare to see the completed ''Oculus'' in its final resting spot, inside the turnstiles of the sprawling Park Place station of the IRT line in Manhattan, where 300 mosaic eyes, like the one below, already dot the walls.

title: Brooklyn, Month by Month, On Stages Lost and Found
description: As Thomas Wolfe might have said, only the dead know Brooklyn's lost theaters. ''Showplaces,'' a 1999 calendar from the nonprofit group Brooklyn Information and Culture, immortalizes many that are gone, like B. F. Keith's Orpheum on Fulton Street, left, home to chaste vaudeville performances, and the opulent R.K.O. Albee on Albee Square.

title: U.S. Court Approves Livent Aid Package
description: Livent Inc. said yesterday that a United States court had given final approval to $24.2 million in financing from Angelo, Gordon & Company, which is intended to tide the troubled theater company over while it completes its reorganization.

title: A Lost Canyon Beckons, And Pasadena Responds
description: THOUSANDS of visitors jet here to see the Rose Parade and the Rose Bowl, and tens of thousands ply Southern California's freeways to get to New Year's Day events. But then there are the happy few who simply step out of their Craftsman bungalows to head down the hiking trails of Arroyo Seco and walk to the game via the city's majestic river canyon. The ritual trip down boulder-lined stairways set among the oaks and sycamores and into the fabled wash is not a short cut but a pleasure, known primarily to residents of Pasadena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, SAUL
description: FINKEL-Saul. The Young Israel of West Hempstead has suffered a great loss with the passing of Saul Finkel, Monday, December 28th, 1998. Mr. Finkel was a longtime beloved member and a veteran of World War II. He is survived by his wife Muriel, two sons Mark and Herb, and sister Marilyn Lerner, and is mourned by the entire community. Rabbi Yehuda Kelemer Mark Nathanson, President

title: Tour-Bus Inquiry Appears To Focus on Driver Error
description: State police officers investigating two recent nonfatal Atlantic City tour-bus accidents appear to be focusing on driver error, but in both cases have been unable to interview the drivers about reports from passengers that the bus operators fell asleep at the wheel, a police spokesman said today.

title: Carry-On Skirmishes
description: THERE has been combat in the air during this holiday season and heightened tension at airport security check-ins. I refer not to the sorties against Iraq but to new airline carry-on baggage policies. United Airlines and Delta, especially, have been strictly limiting carry-ons to two -- and on busy flights, just one -- each item no larger than 22 by 14 by 9 inches, or ''45 linear inches'' in airline lingo.

title: In America; Justice Confounded
description: Here we go again.

title: 44 Texas Stores Are Sold
description: U.S. Restaurant Properties Inc. said today that it had bought 44 Texas convenience stores from the Fina Oil and Chemical Company, part of Petrofina of Belgium, for $20.3 million in cash. U.S. Restaurant, a Dallas-based real estate investment trust, owns and manages franchise restaurants including Arby's and Burger King. The acquistions, all in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, bring the number of properties it owns and operates to 852.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, WARREN H.
description: HELLER-Warren H. International attorney and former president of W.R. Grace International on December 29th, 1998. Husband of Jeanine Heller. Service Thursday, 11 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Essay; Office Pool, 1999
description: Avid players of last year's pool were ahead of the curve on the bull market's incredible longevity, but were ''misled'' -- in 1998's favorite euphemism -- on just about everything else. Forget all that; what is past need not be prelude:

title: Mother of the Octuplets Goes Home to Recover
description: The 27-year-old woman who gave birth to octuplets this month said today as she was about to be released from the hospital that she was not the least bit upset when doctors told her she was to have so many, many babies. Quite the contrary.

title: Conspiracy Not Found In Bombing In Oklahoma
description: A state grand jury created largely through the efforts of a grieving grandfather and a suspicious legislator ended 18 months of investigation into the Oklahoma City bombing today, saying it had found no evidence of a broader conspiracy or a Government cover-up.

title: HOUSE PANEL SAYS CHINESE OBTAINED U.S. ARMS SECRETS
description: A select House committee, in a classified report unusual for its bipartisanship, has found that over the last 20 years China obtained, sometimes through theft, some of the most sensitive of American military technology, including nuclear weapons design, Government officials and witnesses before the panel say.

title: China Reports 7.8% Growth, Close to Goal It Set for '98
description: China said today that it achieved economic growth of 7.8 percent for 1998, essentially meeting the 8 percent goal set by political leaders at the beginning of the year.

title: A Reprimand for Concert Coughers
description: The bronchial frailties of New York concert audiences in the winter are famous enough to be fodder for discussion -- or at least, passing wisecracks -- on the Internet, and musicians have for decades bewailed the seemingly unrestrained coughing that mars so many performances. Mostly, performers quietly bear the noise as part of the cost of doing business in New York, but at a New York Philharmonic concert on Tuesday evening, Kurt Masur found his patience sorely tested.

title: Chief Leaving Cancer Center After 18 Years
description: Dr. Paul A. Marks, the president and chief executive of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and one of the city's most important medical figures, said yesterday that he would retire soon after the start of the new year.

title: A Minolta Manager Is Accused in Kickbacks
description: A manager for the Minolta Corporation and five other people were charged yesterday in what prosecutors described as a kickback scheme that defrauded Minolta out of $4.5 million it paid for printing jobs that were overstated or never performed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALABER, SHAANA
description: BALABER-Shaana. Beloved wife of Dr. John Ciambotti; loving mother of Robertson Smith, and stepmother of Gia Ciambotti; adoring sister of Barbara BalaberStrauss; dear aunt of Elizabeth (David) Lewison and Nancy Staruss; cherished daughter-in-law of Paula Quinn. Services were held. Mount Sinai Memorial Park and Mortuary, Los Angeles, California.

title: At Game Site, Chat Fans Find Their Voices
description: THE Internet is an orchard of unintended consequences. The network itself, with all its content and clamor and chaos, is an unintended consequence of Pentagon research. And like some kind of magic-realist garden plot, it is a place where every seed, whether carefully planted or heedlessly strewn, sprouts into a different species, blossoms into yet another species and bears unexpected mutant fruits. People bend it into shapes you wouldn't expect.

title: Brazil to Raise $5.6 Billion In Special Steps to Cut Deficit
description: Brazil announced a series of special measures today to raise 6.7 billion reais, or $5.6 billion, to help cut a budget deficit and make up for shortages expected in tax revenue next year.

title: BORDEN CHEMICALS HIRES BANKERS TO EXPLORE OPTIONS
description: Borden Chemicals and Plastics L.P., the second-largest United States maker of methanol, said yesterday that it had hired Evercore Partners and Salomon Smith Barney to find ways to improve return to shareholders, which could include the sale of the company. The shares of the company, based in Columbus, Ohio, rose 37.5 cents, to $4.3125, giving the company a market capitalization of almost $160 million.

description: In percent

title: Lethargic Rangers Outmanned By Coyotes
description: Having spent three full days without a game in sunny Arizona, the Rangers were rested and ready for tonight's match against the Coyotes. With all three members of their first line out of the lineup, the Coyotes were weakened against the visitors from New York.

description: FERRANTI-David. On December 24, 1998. Beloved son of Carol and Eugene; loving brother of Neil and sister-in-law Jessie; dear uncle of Caitlin and Julia. Service on Thursday, 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in David's memory to Greenpeace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTIGAN, FRANCES GAYNOR
description: HARTIGAN-Frances Gaynor. 88, died peacefully Dec. 30, 1998 in Albany, NY after suffering many years of Alzheimers Disease. Born in Troy, NY, she resided there until 1980 and was the daughter of the late John Dolan and Josephine A. McGovern Gaynor. Frances graduated from Catholic Central High School, attended the College of Mount Saint Vincent and graduated from the State University of New York at Albany. She taught English for many years at Troy High School, Troy, NY. She was the former president of the Seton Guild, former president of the United Community Services of Rensselaer County and former chairman of the Rensselaer County of Mental Health. She also formerly belonged to the Country Club of Troy, NY. Her husband, Vincent A. Hartigan, predeceased Frances in 1987, whom she married in 1935. Survivors include her children, Mary Anne Shrank of Albany, NY, Maurice H. Hartigan, II and his wife Anne Magilligan of Mount Kisco, NY, Vincent A. Hartigan, Jr. and his wife Katherine McGuire of Chicago, IL, John Gaynor Hartigan of Albany, NY and Anthony Francis Hartigan and his wife Ceile Blakeslee of Concord, NH; sister of Sister Mary Carmel, RSM of Albany, NY and Mrs. Charles F. Murphy of Albany, NY; dear friend of Eva Cox, Ecolia Morman and Gussie Biskin; also survived by 18 grandchildren and several nieces and nephews. Funeral services Saturday from the McVeigh Funeral Home, 208 North Allen St., Albany, NY 518489-0188, thence to the Church of St. John's-St. Ann's, Albany, NY. Relatives and friends are invited and may call Friday, 4 to 8 PM in the funeral home. Interment will follow the mass at St. Mary's Cemetery, Troy, NY. Those wishing to remember Frances and her family in a special way may send contributions to either the Retirement Fund of the Sisters of Mercy, 634 New Scotland Ave., Albany, NY 12208 or St. John's Center, 154 Franklin St., Albany, NY 12202.

title: REPUBLIC BANCSHARES CUTS 340 JOBS
description: Republic Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had dismissed 340 employees in its mortgage banking units, or 54 percent of its loan production staff, as part of a reorganization of the money-losing units. Republic, based in St. Petersburg, Fla., one of the largest Florida-based banks, said it would probably report an operating loss of $20 million in the fourth quarter, or $1.99 a basic share, about twice the size of the loss the company warned it would have a month ago. Republic also said it would take a $7.5 million pretax charge in the fourth quarter from the layoffs and associated costs. Prices for mortgage- and other asset-backed securities have fallen in recent months, which has led to losses for some lenders.

title: Cartoonists Old and New Are Drawn to the Net
description: PETER SINCLAIR began writing and drawing his comic strip, ''Alex's Restaurant'' in 1990. The strip details the life of a restaurant run by a rat-race dropout, Alex, and peopled by a crew of holistically minded, slightly batty regulars. These include Cranbrook, a soup-dropping, wild-haired waiter who explains the more obscure items on the menu (like the three-day fast), and Dr. Andy Vial -- a thinly veiled, respectful lampoon of Dr. Andrew Weil, the nationally known dispenser of medical advice -- who stops by the restaurant to promote books like ''You Never Know, It Might Help'' and ''Hooked on Colonics.''

title: FIRST SECURITY TO ACQUIRE XEON FINANCIAL
description: First Security Bank of Nevada, a unit of the First Security Corporation, agreed yesterday to acquire the Xeon Financial Corporation, a holding company for the Nevada Banking Company, widening its customer base in the state. The shareholders of Xeon, based in Stateline, Nev., will receive $10.14 a share at the completion of the merger. The transaction apparently is worth more than $28 million, based on Xeon's 2.8 million shares outstanding as of March 3. First Security's shares rose 81.25 cents yesterday, to $22.5625. Xeon's shares rose $2 each, to $9.50.

title: Phish as Usual: A Tour In Time and Genres
description: Musicians dream of being in a band like Phish: a stable, long-running group that can fill Madison Square Garden for four nights, has fans that cheer for every instrumental crescendo and is determined to keep its music unpredictable. It's also a band that cherishes the details dear to musicians: melodic twists and tempo changes, eclectic borrowings and room to improvise. Most bands on the arena circuit repeat themselves, but Phish follows the template left by the Grateful Dead. Knowing that many fans will come back for every local show, Phish sets out to be novel every night.

title: In California, Water Rights Are as Hot as Ever
description: Two Southern California counties are locked in a classic battle over sprawl and water. Last month, the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors gave approval to Newhall Ranch, a new 21,000-home community in northeast Los Angeles County that would be the largest planned development in its history. The complex of homes, shops, schools and office parks is being marketed as an idyllic community of five villages nestled along the wild Santa Clara River. But Newhall Ranch butts against the border of Ventura County, an agricultural center, and conservationists and officials there believe the project will cause problems with flood control and water run-off, and may siphon off Ventura County's groundwater. The Los Angeles board says it will not authorize any construction unless the site has adequate water.

While LVMH, the world's largest luxury-goods company, has denied plans to sell its 11 percent stake in Diageo, it has said the stake is not strategic.

title: HOSPITALITY PROPERTY BUYS 17 MARRIOTT HOTELS
description: Hospitality Property Trust, a hotel investment trust, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 17 hotels from Marriott International, the world's second-largest lodging company, for $201.7 million. Seven of the hotels included in the transaction are in service, while the other 10 are under construction. When all 17 hotels are acquired, the minimum rent payable by Marriott to Hospitality Property Trust will be approximately $21.3 million a year. Hospitality Property Trust, based in Newton, Mass., owns approximately 150 hotels.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Hip-Hop Stretches A Common Deadline
description: Hip-hop never stands still, even in the waning weeks of the year. While most of the music business stops putting out new releases by mid-November so it can promote hits for Christmas, rappers have pushed the deadline well into December. These recent releases extend established product lines from hip-hop conglomerates like No Limit and the Wu-Tang Clan or update the careers of well-connected figures like Redman and Timbaland. Like most of 1998's hip-hop, the albums have more to do with consolidation than innovation, but there's no shortage of skills as producers and rappers work their chosen domains.

title: Corrections

Lord Soper, the Methodist minister and soapbox orator at Speakers' Corner at Hyde Park in London, referred imprecisely to his position on euthanasia. He supported voluntary euthanasia and served for many years as vice president of the Voluntary Euthanasia Society of England; he did not condemn all forms of it.

title: H. E. Davis, 93; Transit Engineer
description: Prof. Harmer E. Davis, the founding director of the California Institute of Transportation Studies at the University of California at Berkeley, died on Dec. 24 at his home in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 93.

title: Internet Providers Feel The Holiday Crush, Too
description: On-line retailers urge shoppers to buy on line to avoid big crowds, slow traffic and long lines. But during the holiday shopping season, it seems that the virtual shopping experience had some analogous drawbacks: longer waits to log on and more frequently dropped calls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, RABBI NAHUM B.
description: SHULMAN-Rabbi Nahum B. The Officers, Members of the Board and the Administration of OHEL, BAIS EZRA and The Lifetime Care Foundation for the Jewish Disabled mourn the passing of a dedicated member of our professional staff whose efforts during OHEL's early and formative years helped OHEL grow and meet the challenges of caring for those in the Jewish community at risk. May his family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Moishe Hellman OHEL President David Mandel Chief Executive Officer

title: Economic Scene; Rising health premiums don't mean medical inflation is back.
description: THE most worrisome economic tiding for the new year is that health care premiums for employer-based coverage will rise by 10 percent or more in 1999. The startling figure, based on preliminary data from private employers and the program covering Federal employees, is out of line with scant rate increases over the last four years. And it raises the question of whether managed care plans have returned to the days of double-digit rate increases, abandoning their promise to smother medical inflation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARIN, DORIS
description: MARIN-Doris. Beloved wife of the late Gabe. Devoted mother of Carol and Robert Zeles and William Marin. Dear sister of Marilyn Friedman and Donald Pollock. Cherished grandmother of Michelle and Joseph Zeles. Services at ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, Thursday at 12:30 P.M.

title: Three Players Denied Clearance to Play Overseas
description: A Federal judge today denied an attempt to force the National Basketball Association to provide clearance for three players to join teams in Europe, instead sending them to an arbitrator to negotiate the matter.

title: Anti-Drug Group Selects Ogilvy
description: The White House Office of National Drug Control Policy in Washington said yesterday that it had awarded Ogilvy & Mather New Yorkthe largest of three contracts for a big new anti-drug campaign aimed at young Americans, which is running as paid advertising rather than as public service announcements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATTEN, TONY
description: BATTEN-Tony. His many friends & admirers mourn the passing of a distinguished filmmaker during Christmas week after a long illness, and extend deepest condolences to his wife Ghislaine Hermanuz, her son Dahoud, parents Olga and John Edmonds, sister Evelyn and brother John. Services will be held Sunday, January 3 at 4 PM at Benta's Funeral Home, St. Nicholas Avenue and 141 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Malcolm X Museum Fund, Inc.

title: A Trial Without Evidence?
description: Those who would have the Senate truncate its impeachment proceedings present us with an intriguing proposition: a trial without evidence, a verdict without facts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONRAD, FRANCIS B.
description: CONRAD-Francis B. Devoted father of Peter and Margery and Alan and Susan. Grandfather of Jennifer, Samantha and Allison. Service on Monday, 11 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A MILLION GHOSTS: A special report.; Revenge or Justice? Cambodians Confront the Past
description: When the man named Sor saw that he had been recognized, he covered his face with a scarf and tried to disappear into the crowd. But Vann Nath caught him.

title: Hot Times in the Auld Country
description: CAROUSING chilled and inebriated in Times Square is a popular option for many people who usher in the New Year on this side of the Atlantic Ocean. In Scotland, an equally enthusiastic celebration called Hogmanay is observed.

title: Light Play With Rustic Woods
description: Light is splintered by strips of ebony rattan and oak rattan and softly patterned by the square natural palm shade on top. ''These are literally hand-woven in huts and imported from someone in South Africa,'' said Bebe Regnier, the owner of Lampworks. Best for task lighting, the shades range from small clip-ons ($90) to large two-toned shades ($400). To the trade only, at Lampworks, 979 Third Avenue; (212) 750-1500. LINDA LEE

title: Resolutions For Happy PC Year
description: REMEMBER the scene in ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' when the apes confront their first computer? The computer just sits there, a silent monolith, unblinking, not even deigning to offer a cryptic error message. The apes have no access to technical support and, driven mad by frustration, they grab clubs and go on a rampage, smiting any chimp who is wearing a pocket protector.

title: Watching the Ball on Line
description: New Year's revelers no longer need to tune to the television to watch the ball drop at Times Square. This year, a modem connection and a monitor will do just fine. The festivities will be carried by a host of major Web sites, including www.Broadcast.com, www.msnbc.com and www.timessquare.org.

title: New Contest Is Melding Stock Frenzy and the Web
description: On-line marketing and the frenzy of interest in the stock market combine in a new Internet-based contest that promises to pay out a very real $20 million grand prize. The catch is that to win, you must guess all six numbers in a given week's Friday close of the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the last 8 of 10 numbers in the closing volume.

title: A Year Dwindles Down and So Do Temperatures
description: Gone are the jogging shorts and lightweight jackets. New Yorkers swathed in winter gear scurried through the streets yesterday as temperatures sank into the teens by evening after a high of 39 at 4 A.M. And even those readings were deceptive, since a fierce wind made it feel well below zero, a biting contrast to the relative warmth of the beginning of the week.

title: A Foreign Flair for an American Form
description: Over the century jazz has been able to absorb all sorts of outside influences, and at the Blue Note on Monday night the bassist Avishai Cohen and his band worked to place Middle Eastern music in the formal scheme. Mr. Cohen, originally from Israel, had his friend Amos Hoffman playing Middle Eastern melodies on the oud, a stringed instrument, and for the most part the music worked.

title: Fight at Basketball Game Leads to Murder Charge
description: A teen-ager is being sought in connection with the fatal shooting of a 19-year-old man with whom he had fought earlier that night at a high-school basketball game, the Cumberland County prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAWCETT, JACKSON
description: FAWCETT-Jackson. On December 24, 1998, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Bessie, loving father of Susan Sosin and Cynthia Parham, adoring grandfather of Clifford, Tyler, and Clarissa. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday, January 4th, at 12 noon. Interment to follow at Hackensack Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Hospice Family Care, 310 South Williams Boulevard, #

title: Op-Art
A Balanced Attack Helps Huskies Soar
description: With a 10-2 record, including victories in its last four games, Villanova appeared to be a formidable opponent for No. 1 Connecticut when they squared off tonight in a Big East contest.

title: YACHT RACING; Inquiry and Condolences in Australia
description: As the Government of New South Wales ordered a coroner's inquiry into the death of the six yachtsmen competing in the Sydney-Hobart yacht race, the commodores of the hosting yacht clubs on Thursday visited the families of five sailors who died during the storm-ravaged event.

title: PACIFIC GULF SELLS 5 PROPERTIES FOR $78.5 MILLION
description: Pacific Gulf Properties Inc., a real estate investment trust, sold five multifamily apartment communities in Washington State for about $78.5 million as it exits that market to concentrate on industrial properties. Pacific Gulf, based in Newport Beach, Calif., sold the five apartment communities to a New York-based investor group. The company will use proceeds from the sale to buy seven industrial properties in California, Arizona and Oregon from the Rreef Funds, a private real estate trust, for $76 million. The company also agreed to buy an additional property in Phoenix from the Rreef Funds for $26.1 million. Pacific Gulf is looking to sell its remaining 11 multifamily properties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARDELMANN, DR. ROBERT L.
description: FARDELMANN-Dr. Robert L. of Garden City, NY died peacefully at home December 27. A memorial service will be held Saturday, Jan. 2, 10:30 AM at the Garden City Community Church, corner Stuart Avenue and Whitehall Blvd. in Garden City, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Rutgers University Crew Program, Rutgers University Foundation, 7 College Ave., New Brunswick, NJ 08901-1261.

title: Keep Your Superstores
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about a clash between American warplanes and an Iraqi missile battery misstated the type of missile that shot down the U-2 spy plane flown by Francis Gary Powers over the Soviet Union in 1960. It was an SA-2, not the SA-3 fired by Iraqi forces at the American planes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAR, JOSEPH
description: STAR-Joseph of Roslyn Heights, New York. Died on December 16, 1998. Aerospace engineer, he held patents in many fields. A member of Tau Beta Pi, listed in ''American Men and Women of Science,'' known for his writings and expertise on the Rolls Royce automobile. He leaves his wife of 52 years, Virginia, his son Jordan, two sisters, wonderful relatives and many valued friends.

title: Starcom to Open An Internet Unit
description: Starcom Media Services in Chicago, the media services agency owned by the Leo Burnett Company, said yesterday that it would open Starcom IP, a unit focusing on media planning and buying on the Internet.

title: Government in the Netherlands Thwarts Modern Pilgrim's Progress
description: Almost four centuries after the Netherlands gave the Pilgrims refuge from persecution in England, a leading American scholar on the Pilgrims seems to have been caught in the Dutch Government's crackdown on immigrants and has been ordered to leave the Netherlands by Jan. 15.

title: GENESIS TO SELL 20 BRANDS ON EXCITE AND WEBCRAWLER
description: The catalogue sales company Genesis Direct Inc. reached an electronic commerce agreement with the world's second-largest Internet search company Excite Inc. The deal brings more than 20 Genesis catalogue brands to Excite and Webcrawler Web sites. Shares of Genesis Direct, based in Secaucus, N.J., jumped 39 percent, gaining $2.8125 each, to $9.875, in Nasdaq trading. The deal brings Genesis products, including the multisports Web site proteam.com, to Excite's Internet site and to its affiliate site Webcrawler. The agreement also allows for Excite, based in Redwood City, Calif., to have promotions in Genesis Direct catalogues and merchandise shipments, as well as other sales and promotions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, ROMY
description: FREEDMAN-Romy. Age 18, succumbed to her four year battle on Dec. 29, 1998. Service today at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan, at 1:30 P.M. Romy will be remembered as a loving daughter, grand daughter, niece, cousin, and friend.

title: Is Core Curriculum Outdated?; Columbia's Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks, a Symposium and New York Tours
description: A New Year's Tradition

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Market Declines After 8 Days of Gains

title: Russian Financial Woes Take a Toll in Cigarettes
description: After committing nearly $1 billion to build new factories in Russia, most Western tobacco companies have been hit with heavy losses since financial turmoil took hold this summer, but they say they will remain in the market until the economy picks up again.

title: TV Guide's Chief Is Stepping Down
description: David H. Steward, president and chief executive at TV Guide magazine in New York, part of News America Publishing Group, said yesterday that he would resign, effective immediately. Mr. Steward, 41, joined TV Guide in those posts in November 1997 after six years at Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia in New York.

title: Machine Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: But Is It Going to Rain?
description: FEW natural events are as vexing as the unpredictability of the weather.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE MARK FALLS. The dollar rose against the German currency as the few dealers in the market tried to balance their holdings before the start of the new year. In New York, the dollar settled at 1.6783 marks, up from 1.6717.

title: East Harlem Teen-Ager Is Charged After a 3-Year-Old Dies of Internal Injuries
description: At first, the authorities said, Jose Muniz said his girlfriend's son had died after falling and hitting his head. Then, they said, Mr. Muniz claimed he had been carrying the child when he slipped and fell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROUS, EDYTHE
description: BROUS-Edythe. On December 26, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Howard. Devoted mother of Robert (Shelley) and Kenneth (Margot). Loving grandmother of Lindsey, Daniel, Michael and Jeffrey.

title: S.& P. Is Changing an Index Procedure
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it would change the time it announces changes in its stock indexes so that the announcements will not affect a stock's official closing price.

title: Kansas State Is Unable To Live Up to Promise
description: Bill Snyder and his Kansas State Wildcats broke the cardinal rule of the bowl season. They came to a game they didn't want to play in and didn't feel guilty about it until the last 12 minutes. By then it was too late to stave off an upset.

title: Where the Spirits Feel at Home
description: EVERY day except Sunday, when she goes to church, Mama Lola ambles down several flights of vinyl-covered stairs to a tiny basement altar beside the washer-dryer in her three-story home in Flatbush, Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the death of one of the octuplets born to a Houston woman misstated the date on which seven of the children were born. The first child was delivered on Dec. 8 and the rest were born on Dec. 20, not Dec. 17.

title: Critic's Notebook; Beyond the Meteors, Another, Riskier '98
description: I'll remember 1998 as the year I spied a display box with rows of what looked, from a distance, like identical videotapes with black-and-flame-colored covers. But at close range it turned out to hold two different titles packaged in suspiciously similar ways. Each featured the oversize, noble heads of its actors against a blazing backdrop. Each signaled a tale of something terribly important at stake. Each beckoned with the portentous look of an experience not to be missed, not even in four-by-seven-inch form.

title: AT&T Passes Hurdle in Plan To Buy TCI
description: The Federal Government took a big step toward redefining the Internet today when the Justice Department approved the proposed $31.8 billion acquisition of the cable giant Tele-Communications Inc. by AT&T.

title: Polyester Cherries: They're Back
description: When is the last time anyone saw red cherries on a tablecloth -- except at antiques shows, where vintage cloths sell for premium prices? Now, Sure Fit is releasing Camelot, a printed tablecloth with a botanical motif on a yellow ground that would look at home on a Formica table, circa 1956. It even feels vintage, with a blend of cotton and polyester that favors polyester. Available next month at Montgomery Ward, from $11 to $23. LINDA LEE

title: Federal Regulators Approve British Petroleum Purchase of Amoco
description: Federal regulators approved the proposed purchase of Amoco by British Petroleum P.L.C. today after extracting a handful of minor antitrust concessions from the new company, which will become the world's third-largest petroleum company.

title: In Times Sq., a Dry Run for New Year's 2000
description: The half-million revelers expected to gather in Times Square tonight may not realize it, but they will really be attending a dress rehearsal.

title: Judge Rules for a Student In a Free-Speech Case
description: In one of the first rulings of its kind, a Federal judge in the Eastern District of Missouri said on Monday that a school district had violated a high school student's free-speech rights by suspending him for remarks he made on his personal Web site.

title: Woman Fatally Stabbed In Queens Laundromat
description: A 25-year-old woman was fatally stabbed last night in the Queens laundromat where she worked, the police said.

title: The LeFrak Legacy; In New Complex, a Builder Seeks Status as a Visionary
description: Sam LeFrak was pounding his palms on a conference table so hard the telephone was bouncing. He was yelling. He was cursing. Someone tried to get a word in, but it was no use.

title: Attention, Shoppers, This Just Landed
description: Is there a Dish Doctor in the house? The molded plastic drain rack with its own detachable tray is new. But its curvy style is reminiscent of the 1950's -- or perhaps a plastic pontoon boat. Designed by Marc Newson, an Australian who lives in London, the dish rack has twin cups, or what Mr. Newson calls ''silos,'' for utensils. Blue-tipped spines hold the dishes in place. Water collects in the tray.

title: Chilean Bottler's Stake
description: Embotelladora Andina S.A., Chile's biggest Coca-Cola bottler, agreed to buy back the stake it does not already own in a Chilean bottler from the Coca-Cola Company, part of a plan to increase its sales of fruit juices and water. Andina plans to repurchase for an undisclosed amount the 49 percent stake in bottler Vital S.A., which it sold to Coca-Cola for $28 million in 1996.

title: U.S. Review of Options-Exchange Deals
description: The. Justice Department has requested information from the nation's four major options exchanges about how proposed mergers between them will affect options trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAER, MORRIS (MOE)
description: BAER-Morris (Moe). Park East Synagogue mourns the death of Morris Baer, father of our devoted members Stephen and Vivian Mook Baer, Sisterhood Honorary Co-Chair. Our deepest sympathy to them and the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Cobble Hill Denounces Plan for a Homeless Shelter
description: For the last five years, Cobble Hill has prospered with New York City, its stately brownstones drawing young couples to its quiet streets just blocks from downtown Brooklyn.
